title: Robust Multimodal Information Bottleneck for Satellite-to-Ground Task-Oriented Communication
authors: Jiayi Huang, Dingzhu Wen, Youlong Wu, Yuanming Shi, Ting Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: In this paper, we study satellite-to-ground taskoriented communication for edge inference tasks, where a satellite extracts, fuses and encodes multimodal feature vectors and then sends them to a ground server under inevitable channel noise conditions for downstream processing. However, the multispectral and multi-resolution characteristics of multimodal satellite remote sensing data render traditional multimodal methods inapplicable. To reduce the data redundancy caused by the high-dimensional and complex multimodal vectors generated onboard while retaining key information and enhancing robustness against channel noise. We propose a Robust Multimodal Information Bottleneck (RMIB) framework which considers channel noise and communication bandwidth and introduces a new information bottleneck optimization objective. By applying this objective through end-to-end training, we optimize the feature extraction, fusion and encodes multimodal data into robust and effective feature vector in noisy communication environments by reducing redundancy and enhancing feature discrimination. To tackle the RMIB objective function, we derive a tractable variational upper bound using the Variational Information Bottleneck technique to overcome the computational intractability of mutual information. Experimental results demonstrate that our method not only outperforms baseline techniques in classification accuracy on three datasets but also enhances robustness against channel noise and reduces communication overhead.

title: Adaptive Learning Models for Personalized Literary Education: A Hybrid AI Approach
authors: Shalini Infanta. L, Malavika M P, Surya S, Rudhra TS, R. Manimuthukumar, Saranya R
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In recent years, there has been a growing interest in individualized pedagogies in literary study as adaptive learning environments facilitated by artificial intelligence (AI) have gained traction. Traditional instructional pedagogies and approaches are adept to bypass noticing learners' differences in researching knowledge comprehension, pacing, and motivational engagement levels. In this project we present an integrated, AI-enabled adaptive learning framework comparing predictive analytics with established cognitive theories for learning and engagement. The framework utilizes an ongoing, multimodal assessment of comprehension proxies, interactional reading traces, and prior knowledge schemata to continuously curate literary texts, Socratic questions or prompts, and structured scaffolding for individuals based on their evolving learner profiles. Based on a systematic literature review, a number of clear gaps persist in the field - name) under-contextualized pathways, rigid feedback loops, and disconnects from cognitive instructional principles. For the prototype, a concurrent mixed-methods design triangulated the statistical distillation outcomes to qualitative interview and annotation data acquired from a sample of secondary students. Compared to the controls we observed statistically significant levels of improvement in all areas investigated including comprehension test scores, selfdirected reading behaviours, and participatory equity. In tandem, teacher respondents noted a perceived decrease in instructional burden with enhanced assessment for learning, and again in equal measure a perception of greater curriculum entitlement. The results evidenced here spotlight an emergent capability for a hybrid AI framework to develop individualized, meaningful instructional conversations in literary studies, and we advocate for their systematic engagement into future curricular planning and pedagogical regulation.

title: Comparison of Modern Deep Learning Models for Toxicity Detection
authors: Vladyslav Horodnyk, Dmytro Sabodashko, Viktor Kolchenko, Ivan Shchudlo, Volodymyr Khoma, Yurii Khoma, Marek Baranowski, Michal Podpora
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The proliferation of online platforms and the increasing reliance on digital communication have intensified the need for effective toxicity detection mechanisms. Improper online interaction, including hate speech, cyberbullying, harassment, and threats, can be harmful not only for individuals but also to society in general. This study investigates the performance of various deep learning models in identifying online toxicity. We explore the capabilities of these models to accurately classify different types of toxic language, including its subtle forms and nuanced expressions. The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) as chatbots in commercial applications, such as healthcare and customer service, introduces new challenges for toxicity detection. Despite LLMs’ potential to enhance efficiency and accessibility of chatbots, their susceptibility to generating inappropriate or harmful language can be easily exploited. This research specifically examines the dangers of toxicity resulting from trusting LLMs deployed as interactive agents in commercial settings.

title: Synthetic Data Generation for Natural Dye-Based Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells Using GAN with kNN Stabilization
authors: Azlin Natasha Binti Azman Fauzi, Haryati Binti Jaafar, Hidayani Binti Jaafar
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) offer a low-cost and environmentally friendly alternative to conventional photovoltaic devices, with natural dyes serving as key sensitizers. In this study, eight natural dye sources—pineapple, pomegranate, red onion, sweet potato, red chili, watermelon, grapes, and tamarind—were investigated for DSSC fabrication. Multiple characterization techniques were employed during data preparation, but electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was selected for further analysis due to its ability to provide detailed information on charge transfer resistance and double-layer capacitance. To identify the most representative sample for synthetic data generation, Nyquist plots and ROC-SVM analysis were applied, leading to the selection of the red onion sample. A generative adversarial network (GAN) was trained using this optimal sample to produce synthetic EIS data. To improve the stability and reliability of the generated dataset, k nearest neighbor (kNN) post-processing was applied. The resulting GAN+kNN data closely matched the real measurements, with Rct showing a mean of 38.0 Ω (real = 37.5 Ω), which improved to 37.6 Ω after k-NN adjustment, while the standard deviation decreased from 0.8 to 0.3 Ω. Similar improvements were observed for Rs and Cdl. These results demonstrate that the GAN+kNN approach can generate reliable synthetic DSSC datasets, offering a practical tool for data augmentation and potentially reducing experimental workload in natural dye-based DSSC research.

title: Wearable IoT and ML Techniques for Enhancing CVD to Identify the Risk Level for Disease Prediction and Diagnosis
authors: Nallabariki Praveen Kumar, G Sanjiv Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Recent improvements in wearable IoT devices and machine learning have developed many ways to observe and predict heart related health problems. These devices can continuously check important body signals such as heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen level and ECG readings. By identifying this information the machine learning methods like Random Forest, SVM and Neural Networks can help to identify early symptoms of heart related diseases. But many existing systems mainly use fixed or general data and do not continuously observe the personal health. The proposed system solves this problem by using wearable devices and smart learning models to provide continuous and person specific risk identification for heart diseases. With real time tracking and data analysis the system mainly provides warnings at the correct time and clear information about a person's heart condition. This helps the users to take better care of their health and supports early medical help when it is required and also reduces long term healthcare problems. It also helps doctors to have a better understanding of the patient's heart problems so that they can follow better methods to cure the disease. As we know prevention is better than cure so this system helps in preventive healthcare and allows us to take an action before the serious condition is developed.

title: Deep Learning in Multiomics Sciences: Where We are, Emerging Topics, and Future Challenges
authors: Fabrizio Celesti, Maria Fazio, Antonio Celesti
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Multiomics is an emerging biological analysis approach in which the datasets come from multiple “omics”, such as genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and microbiomics. Nowadays, the convergence of Deep Learning and multiomics sciences presents an unprecedented opportunity to dissect the intricate interplay of biological processes. Specifically, multiomics data integration, propelled by Deep Learning methodologies, has revolutionised biological research, enabling a more holistic understanding of complex biological systems and disease mechanisms. This paper explores the current landscape of Deep Learning applications in multiomics, highlighting state-of-the-art techniques, emerging research areas, and the challenges that lie ahead. In particular, we delve into the application areas and computational methods that have been considered so far, offering guidance to researchers navigating this intricate field.

title: A High-Level Data Placement Approach for Load Balancing on Parallel File Systems
authors: Eduardo C. Inacio, Mario A. R. Dantas
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: As emerging distributed data-intensive applications impose ever-increasing capacity and performance requirements on modern extreme-scale computing environments, mitigating input/output (I/O) performance bottlenecks remains of utmost importance. A source of I/O contention in such environments is related to load imbalance on data servers of the parallel file system (PFS), usually employed as the back-end storage system under these conditions. This variance in data distribution can be particularly severe in applications with synchronous parallel I/O phases, in which each processes transfers data to an individual and independent file. Focusing on addressing this issue, this research work introduces the N-N Round-Robin (N2R2) data placement approach. With minimal information about the application workload and the configuration of the PFS, this heuristic approach can effectively distribute the load across data servers. Experimental results demonstrate N2R2 reduced, in average, 97% of the variance of the load on data servers, compared to traditional data placement approaches implemented in popular PFSs, in scenarios with up to 50,000 processes and data transfer of approximately 931 GiB.

title: WIP: Robots in Synch, Engineers in Harmony: A Synchronizing Firefly Robot Kit for Enhancing Student Engagement Through Positive, Community-Centered Emotions
authors: Derrick W. Yeo, Krystelle Fernandez, Hadi H. Soweidan
abstract: This WIP Innovative Practice paper explores the integration of technical learning outcomes with emotionally resonant experiences in a first-year robotics course using a swarm of synchronizing firefly robots. These robots are individually programmed but synchronize the periodic flashing of their lights as a community. Students have described these displays of emergent behavior as ‘magical’ and as generating fostering positive emotions. We hypothesize these emotions can help students develop a sense of community while supporting their ability to acquire technical skills in the lab. The programming of each robot affects the emergent behavior of the swarm, enabling a strong coupling between computational and emotional aspects of the learning experience. This preliminary paper outlines a short sequence of weekly lab sessions in which these robots will be introduced, forming part of a first-year engineering design and robotics course at the University of Michigan. A preliminary assessment scheme that draws from engineering education literature to analyze subjective data, with a particular focus on student interviews and reflections is also described. A pilot offering is planned for September 2025 with results to be presented at FIE in November. Conference participants will also have the opportunity to interact with a small firefly swarm and discuss how emotional elements might be helpful in other educational contexts.

title: Linking Coastal Water Quality to Blue Carbon Ecosystems Health: A Case Study from Hong Kong
authors: Majid Nazeer, Chung Ching Ho, Man Sing Wong, Tahir Sattar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Mangroves, a wetland ecosystem located on the coastlines, provide a myriad of ecosystem services, one of which is the filtration of sediments and absorption of pollutants from the coastal areas. The study aimed to explore the impact of different water parameters on the growth of mangroves wetland in Hong Kong and to find the main factors encouraging and restricting the growth of wetlands by finding the correlation between the wetland and the coastal water quality parameters. The objective of this study was achieved by using the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) and modified normalized difference water index (MNDWI) to assess the health and area of the wetland, respectively, and assessing the correlation of different coastal water quality parameters provided by the Environmental Protection Department (EPD) of Hong Kong, with the growth of wetlands. The study found that temperature positively correlated with NDVI, indicating increased vegetation growth. Whereas, the salinity negatively correlated with NDVI, highlighting the benefits of low low-salinity environment for enhanced vegetation. A limited influence of suspended solids, chlorophyll-a, was found with NDVI.

title: WIP: Leveraging LLMs for Enforcing Design Principles in Student Code: Analysis of Prompting Strategies and RAG
authors: Dhruv Kolhatkar, Soubhagya Akkena, Edward F. Gehringer
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper explores the integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) into the code-review process for open-source software projects developed in computer science and software engineering courses. The focus is on developing an automated feedback tool that evaluates student code for adherence to key object-oriented design principles, addressing the need for more effective and scalable methods to teach software design best practices. The innovative practice involves leveraging LLMs and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to create an automated feedback system that assesses student code for principles like SOLID, DRY, and design patterns. It analyzes the effectiveness of various prompting strategies and the RAG integration. Preliminary findings show promising improvements in code quality. Future work will aim to improve model accuracy and expand support for additional design principles.

title: WIP: Tutoring System Using a Large Language Model
authors: Balaji R Rao, Naveen Mathews Renji, Carlo Lipizzi
abstract: This innovative practice Work-in-Progress (WIP) paper describes early design, implementation, and pilot evaluation of SSE-EduBot, a course-specific tutoring assistant that integrates semantic search with a LoRA-fine-tuned Llama-213B model. AI in education is a promising domain for the utilization of LLMs to make personalized learning materials using elements of generative AI. This can help educators “riff” on traditional teaching by leveraging Gen AI as tutoring systems. We design a system targeted for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0} \boldsymbol{+}$</tex> student graduate data science course. The three-stage pipeline (1) retrieves answers from prior instructor-student emails, (2) invokes the fine-tuned model when no archival match is found, and (3) reformats the output into conversational prose for a web interface. A curated corpus of lecture transcripts, slides, and textbook excerpts, augmented with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 4,300$</tex> automatically generated question-answer pairs, serves as the domain knowledge base. Preliminary comparisons against ChatGPT-3.5 on representative queries show that SSE-EduBot delivers more context-aligned explanations and reduced domainspecific hallucinations/verbose explanations. Deployment on the university server for the upcoming semester will help collect real-world interaction data to refine retrieval precision, response latency, and ethical guardrails. We share the reproducible workflow and outline next steps toward scaling the approach across additional courses and disciplines.

title: Multi-Objective Fault Detection and Maintenance in Industrial IoT Using the Decentralized Policy-Based RL Model
authors: Natrayan L, Sudhakar Reddy Kota, M. D. Raj Kamal, Dasari Veeraswamy, S. Kaliappan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The extension of Internet of Things applications in the Industries makes a very good impact in the various sectors for the processing of sensing, learning and decision making. Instead of centralized servers, a Federated learning system ensures the system maintains data integrity and security. Reinforcement learning enhances the reliability of the IoT system, which operates based on the reward for actions taken to accomplish a task. In IIoT systems, many machines and equipment's are involved, where multi-parameter sensing is the major task. Therefore, this paper addresses the multiple parameters transmitted by sensors over the network using a Federated learning system. In the Federated learning system, the moving average method is employed, which becomes unstable when multiple sensor data are involved during the engagement of layer wise aggregation. Policy-based Reinforcement learning helps in the aggregation process of Federated learning. In this way, the proposed work showed 99.1% accuracy with an F1 score of 98.2%. The four factors are used for multi-objective scenarios, based on which the reliability obtained is 95.5%.

title: Channel Estimation and Passive Beamforming for Pixel-based Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces with Non-Separable State Response
authors: Huayan Guo, Junhui Rao, Alex M. H. Wong, Ross Murch, Vincent K. N. Lau
abstract: Pixel-based reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) employ a novel design to achieve high reflection gain at a lower hardware cost by eliminating the phase shifters used in traditional RIS. However, this design presents challenges for channel estimation and passive beamforming due to its non-separable state response, rendering existing solutions ineffective. To address this, we first approximate the non-separable RIS response functions using a kernel-based method and a deep neural network, achieving high accuracy while reducing computational and memory complexity. Next, we propose a simplified cascaded channel model that focuses on dominated scattering paths with limited unknown parameters, along with customized algorithms to estimate short-term and long-term parameters separately. Finally, we introduce a low-complexity passive beamforming algorithm to configure the discrete RIS state vector, maximizing the achievable rate. Our simulation results demonstrate that the proposed solution significantly outperforms various baselines across a wide SNR range.

title: ESGaussianFace: Emotional and Stylized Audio-Driven Facial Animation Via 3D Gaussian Splatting_supp1-3651640.pdf
authors: ye pan
abstract: Most current audio-driven facial animation research primarily focuses on generating videos with neutral emotions. While some studies have addressed the generation of facial videos driven by emotional audio, efficiently generating high-quality talking head videos that integrate both emotional expressions and style features remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose ESGaussianFace, an innovative framework for emotional and stylized audio-driven facial animation. Our approach leverages 3D Gaussian Splatting to reconstruct 3D scenes and render videos, ensuring efficient generation of 3D consistent results. We propose an emotion-audio-guided spatial attention method that effectively integrates emotion features with audio content features. Through emotion-guided attention, the model is able to reconstruct facial details across different emotional states more accurately. To achieve emotional and stylized deformations of the 3D Gaussian points through emotion and style features, we introduce two 3D Gaussian deformation predictors. Futhermore, we propose a multi-stage training strategy, enabling the step-by-step learning of the character's lip movements, emotional variations, and style features. Our generated results exhibit high efficiency, high quality, and 3D consistency. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques in terms of lip movement accuracy, expression variation, and style feature expressiveness.

title: Nonnegative Least Squares-Based Multicontact Models for Explicit Model Predictive Control of Dexterous Manipulation_supp2-3642253.pdf
authors: Weibing Li
abstract: In dexterous manipulation, learning-based methods have achieved success while requiring extensive data and lacking interpretability, whereas model-based methods are interpretable but costly due to the nested optimization in model predictive control (MPC). Recently, based on simplified algorithms, explicit model methods have overcome some difficulties and achieved satisfactory performance. In this article, a simplified nonnegative least squares (NNLS)-based quadratic programming (QP) algorithm is utilized to obtain the approximation solution to the dual QP of the contact model, with a hyperparameterized solution to the NNLS formulation used. As a result, an explicit and interpretable ContactNNLS model is proposed, eliminating the need to solve the nested optimization. The ContactNNLS model delivers a more general form when compared with the existing explicit models. Besides, the ContactNNLS model is integrated into an MPC to approximate the time-stepping prediction, leading to a ContactNNLS-MPC algorithm for dexterous manipulation. The effectiveness of the ContactNNLS model and the ContactNNLS-MPC algorithm is verified in extensive simulated tasks. Moreover, the ContactNNLS-MPC is further applied to a real Allegro hand for on-palm reorientation tasks, demonstrating its practicality and feasibility.

title: Subjective-objective Emotion Correlated Generation Network for Subjective Video Captioning_supp1-3649363.png
authors: Zhendong Mao
abstract: The emotional video captioning (EVC) task, which aims to generate factual descriptions based on the perceived subtle visual emotion cues, has received more and more attention and research. However, EVC is essentially an objective video captioning task, and ignores the subjective emotional reactions of video viewers, which cannot reflect personalized affective understandings of different viewers on the same video. To fill the research gap, we investigate the subjective video captioning (SVC) task in this paper, which aims to generate emotional captions by incorporating viewers’ personalized emotional reactions upon the EVC task. SVC is extremely challenging, which lies in two aspects: 1) the correlative emotion perception between subjective and objective emotions; and 2) the collaborative generation between emotional and factual information. To this end, we propose the Subjective-Objective Emotion-Correlated Generation Network (SO-ECGN) in this paper. Specifically, our SO-ECGN leverages the proposed dynamic mask attention and emotion domain shifting module to achieve the objective emotion incremental learning, and then, a subjective-objective emotions correlation module is proposed to adaptively combine two perspective emotions to provide accurate emotion guidance (i.e., emotional polarity and intensity) for each generation step. Furthermore, an emotion-correlated decoder is proposed to generate subjective captions by adaptively referring to factual information and emotional information. Extensive experiments on three challenging datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach and each proposed module, i.e., reaching 79.2%, 45.1% on BLEU-1, CIDEr metrics on EmVidCap-L dataset.

title: Computational Optimization Techniques to Design RF Circuits
authors: Aijaz M. Zaidi, Ahmed A. Kishk, S.P.Shiva Prakash, Jugul Kishor, Sumer Singh Singhwal, Binod K. Kanaujia, Sembiam R. Rengarajan, Ladislau Matekovits
abstract: We present a comprehensive review of computational optimization techniques for the design of RF circuits. Important design techniques used to optimize RF circuits, such as genetic algorithms (GAs), particle swarm optimization (PSO), reinforcement learning (RL), Bayesian optimization (BO), and space mapping (SM), are discussed. The basics of the techniques, their merits, and their drawbacks are covered so that new researchers can understand the relevant theories of the techniques. A comparative analysis of design techniques is included. This article also provides insights into the present state and future directions of the optimization techniques.

title: Negative Semantic Guided Identity Boundary Construction for Open-World Person Re-Identification_supp1-3651057.pdf
authors: Wei-Shi Zheng
abstract: Person re-identification (ReID) aims to match person images of the same identity under different camera views. Conventional ReID models mainly consider a closed-world setting where person identities in query and gallery are exactly the same. However, in real-world applications, query identities and gallery identities usually do not exactly contain the same persons. Therefore, open-world ReID has been proposed to match the images of gallery identities (targets) with a large number of non-gallery identities ( non-targets). Since some non-targets are quite similar to the targets, the ReID model may make incorrect judgments when verifying these non-targets. To solve this problem, we leverage the impressive cross-modal matching capabilities of the large vision-language model (VLM) to construct Negative Semantic guided identity boundaries for each person to develop the open-world ReID model (NS-ReID). To construct the identity boundary, we propose Virtual Non-target Repulsion that utilizes negative semantics to prompt the ReID model to push virtual non-targets away from the targets. The prompts expressing negative semantics offer a different perspective to guide the training process to avoid contradictory optimization. Moreover, we propose the Dual-Boost Refinement Learning strategy to train learnable identity prompts to capture detailed identity information, which is essential for constructing the identity boundary since the variations among identities are comparatively small. These facilitate the model in constructing the wide identity boundary of each person. Extensive experiments on two benchmark ReID datasets demonstrate that our proposed NS-ReID achieves state-of-the-art performance compared with existing methods.

title: Integrating Generative AI into Cybersecurity Education: A Study of OCR and Multimodal LLM-Assisted Instruction
authors: Karan Patel, Yu-Zheng Lin, Gaurangi Raul, Bono Po-Jen Shih, Matthew W. Redondo, Banafsheh Saber Latibari, Jesus Pacheco, Soheil Salehi, Pratik Satam
abstract: This research category full paper describes an LLM assisted instruction integration with a virtual cybersecurity lab platform. The rapid digital transformation of Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR) systems is transforming today's workforce needs, increasing skill set gaps, especially for the older workforce. With an increasing emphasis on STEM skill sets like robotics, automation, artificial intelligence (AI), and security, the workforce will have to be re-skilled and up-skilled to meet future industry needs. Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI), has the potential to aid building of this workforce, by assisting trainee's by acting as instructional assistant, helping students build skill sets while performing experiential learning exercises. This paper presents a generative AI based instructional assistant integrated into a prior experiential learning platform. This instructional assistant uses a zero-shot, optical character recognition (OCR) based Large Language Model (LLM) assisted Instruction pipeline integrated into the legacy Cybersecurity Labs-as-a-Service (CLaaS) platform developed in 2015. The instructional agent assits the experiential learning by extracting the text from slide images using Tesseract OCR and to generate simplied instructions by prompting a general-purpose LLM enabling real-time instruction optimization with minimal infrastructure and integration effort. The instructional assistant was evaluated in a live university course and where in student feedback was collected using a 1-to-10 rating scale, with an average feedback score of 7.83 on 42 responses, indicating a strong perceived usefulness of the instructional assistant. In addition, we conducted a comparative study using multimodal LLMs that directly interpret slide images with the OCR pipeline, to analyze the computational overhead, and operational costs. While the multi-modal LLM pipeline performed better on slides with dense visual content, the OCR-LLM-based pipeline delivered comparable pedagogical value on text-centric slides with a significantly lower overhead, and operational costs. This work demonstrates that a lightweight and easily integrable pipeline can effectively bring modern generative AI capabilities into legacy platforms, offering a scalable enhancement for improving student comprehension in technical education settings.

title: From Current-Controlling Field-Effect Device to Intelligent Machines: How a Tiny Switch Sparked the Computing Revolution and Modern Artificial Intelligence_supp1-3651179.pdf
authors: Samar K. Saha
abstract: The computing revolution and the rise of modern artificial intelligence are rooted in the physics of semiconductor devices, where the field effect transistor (FET) emerged as the archetypal “tiny switch” enabling digital logic. This article commemorates the centennial of Lilienfeld’s pioneering conception of the field effect device, situating it as the intellectual and technological seed of the digital age. The narrative traces the continuum from Lilienfeld’s early vision and Alan Turing’s theoretical foundations of computation, through the invention of the transistor and the advent of transistorized computers. It examines the paradigm shift brought by integrated circuits (ICs), highlighting IBM’s System/360 and System/370 as milestones in architectural unification and silicon integration. The discussion then explores the realization of the metal-oxide-semiconductor (MOS) FET (MOSFET), the birth of the microprocessor, and the breakthroughs in complementary MOS (CMOS) technology that enabled high-density integration and ushered in the fourth generation of computers. Special attention is given to the challenges of MOSFET scaling, the emergence of multiple gate architectures such as FinFETs (fin FETs), and inventive extensions of planar devices including ultra-thin body FETs and buried halo MOSFETs. Finally, the article discusses how domain-specific architectures: Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), and other application-specific ICs have leveraged advanced FET technologies to drive the current era of intelligent machines. By weaving together historical milestones, device innovations, and architectural transformations, this article underscores how the physics of the transistor switch continues to shape the trajectory of computing and artificial intelligence.

title: The Global Landscape of Research on AI Literacy: A Bibliometric Analysis of Trends, Collaborations, and Emerging Themes
authors: Jeya Amantha Kumar
abstract: This full research study paper presents a bibliometric analysis of 902 peer-reviewed publications on Artificial Intelligence Literacy (AIL) indexed in Scopus from 2021 to early 2025, mapping key trends, gaps, and future directions. The findings indicate a sharp rise in publications from 2023 onward aligns with the widespread adoption of generative AI tools in education. Furthermore, the analysis revealed that social sciences, computer science, and engineering fields dominate the publication landscape, with the majority of research being published in educational technology journals. The United States, Hong Kong, and China emerged as major contributors, though global collaboration remains uneven, particularly in Europe, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Next, author keyword co-occurrence revealed eight thematic clusters linking AIL to ethics, education levels (K-12 and higher education), GenAI, digital literacies, and instructional design, while identifying underexplored areas such as early AI exposure and informal learning. Additionally, the textbased co-occurrence analysis of titles and abstracts further revealed four major themes: classroom AI integration, behavioral measurement, ethical considerations, and GenAI. However, despite rapid growth, gaps persist in methodological diversity, interdisciplinary participation (particularly in STEM and biomedical domains), and representation of marginalized communities. Hence, recommendations and implications are discussed to address these gaps and guide ongoing AIL research.

title: Quantitative Multiphoton Elastin-Collagen Imaging Differentiates Histologically Ambiguous Lung Adenocarcinoma Subtypes_supp1-3651647.docx
authors: Shu Wang
abstract: Accurate differentiation of lung adenocarcinoma subtypes is critical for personalized surgical strategies, particularly in intraoperative differentiation between adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) and invasive adenocarcinoma (IA). However, tissue distortions such as alveolar rupture or collapse induced during surgery frequently lead to subtype misclassification. Conventional histological staining limited by their inability to quantitatively characterize collagen and elastin fibers, fail to address this clinical challenge. To overcome these limitations, we developed a quantitative Multiphoton Elastin-Collagen Imaging (qMECI) method, specifically targeting diagnostic ambiguities between AIS and IA. qMECI employs label-free multiphoton microscopy to simultaneously capture microarchitectural features of collagen and elastin fibers, extracting ten quantitative metrics encompassing fiber distribution patterns, spatial arrangement, and morphological parameters. Experimental results demonstrate that qMECI identifies critical discriminative signatures of extracellular matrix remodeling, including collagen-elastin coverage, hyperplastic reorganization, and vascular-aligned growth patterns. By integrating quantitative biomarkers such as relative fiber distribution and area ratios, qMECI enables objective differentiation of two diagnostically challenging scenarios: alveolar collapse-type AIS versus acinar-pattern IA and alveolar rupture-type AIS versus papillary IA. This method holds significant potential to refine intraoperative diagnosis workflows, thereby reducing misdiagnosis risks and overtreatment.

title: The Eddy-Current Sensor-Free Control for a Bearingless Slice Motor With the PM’s Third Harmonic
authors: Yu Wang, Haohui Wang, Zhili Wang, Wenjuan Hao
abstract: Eddy-current sensor-free control based on reusing Hall sensors of a bearingless slice motor system can reduce the volume, cost, weight, and the impact of shear on transmitted liquid. However, the algorithm will fail in the presence of the PM’s third harmonic. Hence, this article presents the eddy-current sensor-free control algorithm based on the two negative sequence coordinate transformation in parallel with different frequencies (TNSPDF). The random and disordered signal in the Hall output is modulated into asymmetrical component about the displacement vector angle through negative sequence coordinate transformation at different electrical frequencies, achieving decoupling between the displacement vector angle and the motor electrical frequency. The interference signal does not lead to any pulsation in the estimated displacement; rather, it evolves into a significant coefficient for the purpose of displacement identification. The validity and effectiveness of the proposed method are verified through experiments on a bearingless permanent magnet slice motor system.

title: Multiclass Eye Disease Classification on Fundus Images Using EfficientNet-B3 and Grad-CAM
authors: Adelia Putri Ramadhani, Tri Arief Sardjono, Eko Agus Suprayitno, Nada Fitrieyatul Hikmah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Eye diseases such as Diabetic Retinopathy (DR), Glaucoma, and Cataract are among the main causes of global blindness, making early detection crucial to prevent irreversible retinal impairment. However, the manual evaluation of fundus images by ophthalmologists continues to be the primary diagnostic approach, limited by the availability of human resources, particularly in rural or disadvantaged areas. This study introduces an automated multi-class classification system for eye diseases using a deep learning model based on the EfficientNetB3 architecture, supported by Grad-CAM visualization to improve model interpretability. The system was trained using the Ocular Disease Intelligent Recognition (ODIR) dataset, which was categorized into five classes, including Normal, Diabetic Retinopathy (DR), Glaucoma, Cataract, and Other Diseases, the which has been simplified to only contain Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD). Pre-processing includes Circular Border Cropping, RGB Channel Extraction, CLAHE, Median Filtering, resizing to $300 \times 300$ pixels, and data augmentation. The model included pretrained ImageNet weights and was fine-tuned on the last $\mathbf{1 0 0}$ layers with a learning rate of $1 \mathrm{e}-6$ and a dropout rate of 0.3. The proposed model achieved a training accuracy of 97.08%, a validation accuracy of 87.20%, and a testing accuracy of 89.26%. These results indicate significant potential for medical application. The model can assist with triage or function as diagnostic tool in teleophthalmology and radiology processes. Future study may explore the application of other deep learning architectures and varied datasets to improve classification accuracy. Furthermore, combining additional imaging modalities beyond fundus images could expand the system’s application and improve diagnostic reliability.

title: Ethical AI and Data Integrity: Best Practices and Emerging Concerns
authors: Rahul Rishi Sharma, Deepankar Dixit, Vamshi krishna Ayyam, Pavan Kumar Adapala, Laxman Doddipatla, Bhaskar Babu Narasimhaiah, Rajit Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper investigates the interplay between ethical artificial intelligence (AI) and data integrity, with emphasis on fairness, transparency, accountability, and trustworthiness as the foundation of responsible AI systems. Using a mixedmethods design combining literature synthesis, comparative framework analysis, and sectoral case studies in healthcare, finance, criminal justice, and retail, the study validates an integrated lifecycle model for ethical AI. Results demonstrate that models incorporating bias mitigation, fairness-aware constraints, and explainable mechanisms trained on validated datasets significantly outperform baselines: accuracy improved by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6-10 \%$</tex> across domains, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-scores increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-12 \%$</tex>, and AUROC/AUPRC consistently exceeded 0.90. The difference between equalized odds and demographic parity has been filled in by more than half, and the calibration errors have gone down from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6-7 \%$</tex> to less than 3 %. Both fairness metrics showed a lot of improvement as well. The results indicate that the amalgamation of ethical norms with data integrity safeguards enhances both social responsibility and prediction robustness. They also provide a model for the implementation of reliable AI in various fields.

title: LoRA Enhanced Large Language Models for Fault Diagnosis in Smart Factories
authors: Natrayan L, Seeniappan Kaliappan, T. Roseline Velankanni, N. Lakshmi, Ramya M
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Advancements in smart factories require systems that are more efficient in terms of adaptability, efficiency and explainability. Fault diagnosis is a crucial aspect in the predictive maintenance of smart factory systems, where it is necessary to consider multi-parameter systems to determine the states of the machines. Therefore, the parameter efficient fine-tuning is helpful to consider the multiple parameters for real-time monitoring of the machine conditions. Hence, the paper proposes the LoRA-based Large Language Model (LLM) for the fault diagnosis and multi-class classifications of faults in the machines for the smart factory systems. It identifies fault-specific patterns in the input sensor data, and historical data are used to find anomalies in the machine's states. The proposed work simulated using three datasets of multi-parameter type from Kaggle, where it showed 91.8% accuracy with fewer inference types compared to other fine-tuning methods. The fault detection rate of the proposed work is 82.5 %.

title: Special Session: Students' Experiences and Sense of Academic and Social Belonging within the ‘Globalized’ Engineering Graduate Education: Translating Research into Practice
authors: Eunsil Lee, Susan Sajadi
abstract: This special session will guide participants - engineering educators involved in graduate education - to reflect on their current strategies and considerations in research and practice related to supporting engineering graduate students. Through reflective and interactive discussions, participants will have the opportunity to question or evaluate whether they have adequately considered the globalized characteristics of the engineering education learning environment when studying or supporting the experiences and sense of belonging of both domestic and international students. Structured small- and large-group activities are designed to help participants explore the interplay of globalized dynamics in students' experiences, navigate similarities and differences between domestic and international students, and identify potential gaps between student perceptions of supports and barriers and those held by participants; who design support strategies and structures. By the conclusion of the session, we hope participants will gain actionable insights to enhance their research and practice by collaboratively brainstorming improvements based on evidence-informed discussions and activities.

title: VishGuard: AI-Powered Real-Time Defense Against Voice Phishing
authors: Deepali Lokare, Rahul More, Suruchi Deshmukh, Pankaj Chandre, Arun Ghandat, Rohini Bhosale
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Voice phishing, or “vishing,” has emerged as one of the most deceptive and rapidly growing cyber threats in recent years. Exploiting the psychological trust associated with real-time voice communication, attackers often impersonate legitimate entities-such as banks, government agencies, or tech support-aiming to coerce individuals into revealing sensitive information including personal identification numbers, bank details, and login credentials. As vishing tactics grow more sophisticated through the use of AI-generated voices and spoofed caller IDs, traditional rule-based or static detection systems are proving inadequate. These legacy approaches typically lack real-time capabilities, suffer from high falsepositive rates, and struggle to adapt to evolving fraud patterns. This research proposes a comprehensive, AI-driven voice phishing detection system capable of analyzing calls in real time by leveraging a fusion of state-of-the-art technologies. The core architecture integrates Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) tools such as Whisper or Wav2Vec for live speech-to-text conversion, enabling immediate linguistic analysis. It employs Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques using models like BERT to detect deceptive language patterns, urgency, and manipulative cues. Simultaneously, the system extracts acoustic features such as pitch, tone, speech rate, and vocal stress, which are often indicative of deceptive intent. These multimodal features are fed into a hybrid ensemble of machine learning models, including Random Forest, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and deep learning architectures like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, to classify the call as legitimate or suspicious. A real-time web-based interface allows for live monitoring of conversations between two entities, while dynamically updating the phishing probability score based on ongoing interactions. The system further enhances user trust by offering explainable AI outputs, providing reasons behind each classification decision. Evaluation on a curated dataset demonstrates a detection accuracy exceeding 98 %, with strong performance metrics across precision, recall, and latency. The system is scalable, user-friendly, and well-suited for integration into modern communication infrastructures including VoIP services.

title: Design of 3D-Printed Ankle-Foot Orthosis and Gait Training Test
authors: Chi Hung Wang, Po Sung Chen, WeiRen Chen, Yu Jin Wang
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: Traditional AFO is cumbersome to manufacture and difficult to fully fit the patient's limb, limiting its clinical effectiveness. Although 3D printing technology has the advantages of rapid production, high customization and excellent fit, it still faces challenges such as insufficient material durability, high technical threshold for professional software processing and modeling, and clinical research is mainly limited to the ability to walk in a straight line, and lacks systematic evaluation of dynamic functions such as standing, turning and walking. In this study, TPU combined 3D scanning and desktop 3D printing technology to create a personalized AFO, and designed a nine-week, three-times-a-week rehabilitation training program for clinical validation in 20 stroke patients. The evaluation indicators included 3-metre walking speed, the BBS, and TUG. The results showed that the average walking speed of the patients increased to 0.79 m/s, the gait cycle was shortened to 9.8 seconds, the BBS score was consistent with 90.45%, and the TUG test performance was significantly improved during the withdrawal period (Z=2.64, p < 0.01). The results of this study show that 3D printed AFO has certain potential in improving the gait and balance function of stroke patients, making up for the shortcomings of AFO material strength, time-consuming modeling, and dynamic multi-stage mobility ability assessment, and providing a reference for clinical application.

title: Enhancing Visual-Language Alignment in LLaVA: DeepSpeed-Optimized Fine-Tuning for Coherent Multimodal Generation
authors: Cheng-Ho Yeh, Yu-Lun Chang, Tsung-Lu Michael Lee
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: This paper presents a DeepSpeed-optimized fine-tuning approach to enhance visual language alignment in LLaVA multimodal systems. Unlike conventional scaling methods, our targeted alignment strategy strengthens semantic coherence between visual inputs and textual outputs, specifically addressing multi-turn dialogue consistency and context-aware image interpretation. We validate this framework through medical image analysis, where our CLIP-based vision language model interprets visual features and associates them with clinical terminology. Fine-tuned on 400,000+ image-text pairs, the system demonstrates improved contextual relevance and reliability in multimodal response generation. Experimental results show substantial improvements over baseline models in semantic coherence and medical documentation tasks, with multilingual support (Mandarin, English, Japanese) enhancing clinical accessibility. This work advances both visuallanguage alignment theory and practical AI-assisted healthcare applications.

title: Using Generative Adversarial Networks to Improve the Accuracy of Person Re-identification
authors: Oleksandr Kyrylenko, Roman Kvyetnyy
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents an analytical overview of the use of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) in person re-identification (re-ID) tasks. The study highlights contemporary GAN-based methods, including style transfer across cameras and domains, synthetic data generation for augmentation, and adversarial training of invariant features. Key GAN architectures (CycleGAN, UnityGAN, StarGAN) are reviewed alongside practical implementations and compared with non-GAN approaches. The paper identifies the benefits of using GANs (enhanced model adaptability and generalization) and limitations (training instability, potential artifacts). Additionally, it proposes promising theoretical directions for improving the accuracy and efficiency of re-ID systems. A novel method is introduced that integrates the reID task directly into the GAN training process.

title: TalentScout: Multimodal AI-Driven Expert Finding in Organizations
authors: Murugan Sankaradas, Kunal Rao, Giuseppe Coviello, Srimat Chakradhar
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Identifying subject-matter experts within organizations remains a challenging task due to the scale, heterogeneity, and unstructured nature of enterprise knowledge assets. We present TalentScout, an AI-driven expert identification system that constructs a unified, skill-centric knowledge graph by ingesting and analyzing diverse media, including research papers, reports, presentations, transcripts, and supervisor recommendations. TalentScout’s modular architecture integrates document parsing, audio/video transcription, metadata extraction, large language model-based skill extraction, multi-factor author disambiguation, and evidence-weighted skill attribution. At query time, TalentScout decomposes natural language queries into canonical skill requirements, traverses the constructed knowledge graph, and ranks experts based on aggregated skill weights, document quality, and endorsement signals, providing document-level justifications for each recommendation. We evaluate TalentScout on multiple public and internal enterprise datasets, including DBLP, TREC Enterprise, Tilburg, and ManConCorpus. Using standard information retrieval metrics such as Precision@5, Recall@5, nDCG@5, and Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR), TalentScout consistently outperforms leading baselines, achieving up to 24% higher Precision@5 in early expert retrieval. The results highlight TalentScout’s scalability, transparency, and accuracy, establishing it as a practical solution for evidence-based expert discovery and organizational talent management.

title: Risk Evaluation of Fresh Agricultural Products Supply Chain Based on the AHP Method- Case Study of Wuhan Agriculture Trade Markets
authors: Yang Zhao, Zhaozhe Wu, Xuan Fang, Zijie Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In China, fresh agricultural products are in large consumption as compared with other countries, according to authorized research data, such products consumption proportion is $\mathbf{2 3} \% \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{3 0} \%$, but in USA and Japan the proportion is under 5%. And these products during supply chain processes are often in normal temperature but with characters of perishability, store difficulty and other special characters. Usually, Agriculture Trade Markets are the mid-suppliers of these products, so there are more supply chain risks for them. This study firstly investigated Wuhan Agriculture Trade Markets with questionnaire and on-site visit method, gathering true data, and found that risk factors include information, distribution, procurement, environment, and then split the four factors into ten factors and used AHP method to analyze weights of these factors. After that different risks were evaluated according to the weights, and suggestions were provided to lower the risks. Finally, a conclusion is made to summarize the article, which provides certain reference for other similar enterprises in fresh agricultural products supply chains.

title: Reduced-Order Kernel Smoothed Regression for Sensor Networks Using Aggregated Data Fusion
authors: Leonid Lyubchyk, Olha Kostiuk, Klym Yamkovyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The issue of recovering distributed regression from local noisy measurements collected through a sensor network operating in data fusion mode is analyzed. The proposed solution integrates regularized kernel machine learning on aggregated data with semi-supervised learning on the original set of sensor measurements, aiming to reduce model complexity and smooth the recovered dependencies. The data aggregation technique relies on regularized clustering of the entire set of sensors, considering the distances between them while minimizing local measurement variation within a cluster by incorporating a regularizer as an appropriate penalty function. Additional smoothing is achieved by adjusting the kernel function to reflect the geometric structure of the sensor network.

title: Big Data Analytics for Polio Surveillance in Balochistan: Insights from Apache Spark
authors: Syed Muhammad Akbar, Sibghat Ullah Bazai, Bushra Shaukat Ali, Muhammad Imran Ghafoor, Uzair Aslam Bhatti, Zawar Ullah Bazai
abstract: Polio is a significant public health issue in Balochistan, Pakistan, because the immunization rates are very low, the area is afflicted with sociopolitical unrest, and the people are misinformed. In this paper, the authors take advantage of Apache Spark, which is a scalable engine of big data analytics, to process a large amount of polio vaccination data in nine campaigns in Quetta, Killa Abdullah, and Pishin, where the risk is high. The analysis is aimed at finding the relationship between missed and rejected cases, drivers of refusals, and relating the vaccination coverage to Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) cases. The results indicate that the primary reasons for refusals are misconceptions and religious beliefs, the greatest of which were registered in Quetta. The analysis based on correlation analysis, , and K-means proves the presence of significant correlations between missed vaccinations and refusals and shows areas that are inclined to use specific interventions. This study (contrary to previous research) is based on Apache Spark as a tool of processing real-time big data as opposed to the use of static tools (WEKA or SPSS). The findings indicate that Apache Spark can be used in the real-time detection of anomalies and monitor campaigns to create insight that can be used to make informed policy decisions to enhance immunization efforts in underserved communities.

title: Optimized Hyperparameter Settings in the Classification of Rice Variety in Philippines: An Image Processing Approach
authors: Carmelo Alejo D. Bisquera, Michael John P. Robles, Fitzerald D. Lim, Isaac Angelo M. Dioses, Darios Alado, Simeon N. Domingo, Jesusimo L. Dioses
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Using morphological image data, this study proposes a machine learning-based framework for the non-destructive classification of rice grain kinds. MATLAB's Image Processing Toolbox was used to image and process 974 rice grains, including Sinandomeng and Jasmine varieties. Key features like area, major axis length, minor axis length, equivalent diameter, and perimeter were extracted using grayscale conversion, Canny edge detection, and morphological operations. Three neural architectures—Shallow DNN, Simulated TabNet, and Simulated NODE—were trained in Python using the standardized extracted data. With less training time and a smaller model size than the others, the Simulated NODE performed the best, with 92.82% accuracy, 93.53% precision, and 92.82% recall. These results show how lightweight neural networks may be used to identify rice varieties in real-time, scalable, and economically. This makes them a viable substitute for laboratory-based techniques and advances automated agricultural quality assurance systems.

title: EfficientNetV2B3 and NasNetmobile Fusion method in Classification of Citrus Diseases
authors: Rhowel Dellosa, Isaac Angelo Dioses
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This paper describes a hybrid deep learning system that combines the EfficientNetV2-B3 and NASNetMobile architectures to automatically detect and classify citrus leaf illnesses, notably blackspot and citrus-canker. The hybrid model improves multiscale feature extraction and classification performance by leveraging EfficientNetV2-B3's compound scaling and NASNetMobile's neural architecture search capability. The dataset, which consisted of tagged citrus leaf images, was divided into training and validation sets, with model performance measured across 30 epochs. According to the experimental data, the suggested model attained a 95% classification accuracy while displaying consistent convergence and little overfitting throughout the training phase. While traditional deep learning models may generate somewhat superior accuracy, the hybrid approach offers a computationally efficient and scalable alternative ideal for real-time agricultural environments with restricted processing resources. The results show that the integration of EfficientNetV2-B3 with NASNetMobile successfully balances performance, interpretability, and hardware feasibility.

title: Design of a Dual U-Slot Patch Antenna for CubeSat Platforms
authors: Najet Bougdima, Mondher Dhaouadi, Fethi Choubani
publish: 2025 IEEE Twelfth International Conference on Communications and Networking (ComNet)
abstract: In the context of the Internet of Things (IoT) and CubeSat nanosatellites, compact and high-performance printed antennas are essential to ensure reliable and efficient wireless communications. Compact, lightweight, and easy to integrate into the limited space of CubeSats, this antenna requires careful optimization to achieve high radiation efficiency, stable polarization, and sufficient bandwidth, while meeting the miniaturization and electromagnetic compatibility requirements of the space environment.As part of our research, we propose a new miniaturized patch antenna architecture, specifically designed for single-unit CubeSat platforms for IoT satellite applications. By combining innovative geometry, geometric phase shifting techniques, and a precisely centered feed, our design significantly improves polarization stability, usable bandwidth, and antenna gain. Furthermore, the use of space-grade substrates ensures better resistance to dielectric losses, improved radiation efficiency, and optimal mechanical compatibility with the structural and environmental constraints of CubeSat missions.We present the design and analysis of a double-aperture rectangular U-shaped patch antenna optimized for the 7.5 GHz X-band operating frequency. The antenna is fabricated on a 1.6 mm thick FR-4 substrate (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</inf> = 4.4) using a microstrip feed configuration. Simulation results obtained from HFSS indicate excellent impedance matching, with a reflection coefficient S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf> lower than −30 dB. The antenna achieves a gain higher than 12 dBi and exhibits a directional radiation pattern, making it well-suited for space-based or long-range wireless communication applications.These performances demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed structure for embedded systems that require compactness, high efficiency, and ease of fabrication. Furthermore, the design enhances radiation efficiency and ensures mechanical compatibility with the structural and environmental constraints typically associated with CubeSat missions.

title: User-Centric Technology in Mobile Loyalty: The Role of Gamification and TAM
authors: Muhammad Ghifari Khalif, Margareth Setiawan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of gamified loyalty program on customer loyalty intention behavior within the Food and Beverages mobile application in Indonesia, while also contributing to the ninth SDG by exhibiting how gamification mobile platform can facilitate digital innovation and sustainable growth. The study was using Technology Acceptance Model as the basis, exploring the five relations among constructs: Gamified Loyalty Program (GLP), Perceived Ease of Use (PEOU), Perceived Rewards (PR), Perceived Usefulness (PU), and Loyalty Intention (LI). Data were collected from 200 respondents through purposive sampling and analyzed using PLS-SEM. The findings indicate that GLP significantly affects both PEOU and PR, which in return influence PU. Both PEOU and PU positively contribute to LI, affirming the applicability of TAM in this context. The result suggests that intuitive gamified features and meaningful rewards enhance user perception of ease and value, ultimately fostering stronger loyalty intention. This study offers practical insight for F&B brand seeking to optimize digital engagement strategies and contribute to the theoretical advancement of gamification and technology acceptance in the emerging market.

title: Qaostream: A New Stream Cipher Based on Quantum Chaotic Map
authors: Muhammad Rafif Irfan, Nadine Claudia Silalahi, Santi Indarjani, Indah Emilia Wijayanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: This research proposes a robust stream cipher by enhancing the Quantum Chaotic Map (QCM)-based PRNG, which was found to exhibit statistical inconsistencies under certain initial conditions. The proposed design integrates the unpredictability of QCM with some nonlinear post-processing stages, such as a state initialization stage using SHA256 and the utilization of a Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) to produce a 256-bit keystream block. The initialization process is followed by a warm-up phase to reduce the correlation between the seed and the output. The entire extensive testing process showed that the generated keystream is able to pass all categories in the NIST Statistical Test Suite (NIST STS) for data as large as 1 billion bits. The keystream also passed the Dieharder Test. Additionally, this algorithm achieves near-ideal values in several key metrics, such as an avalanche effect of $49.9737 \%$, a correlation coefficient of 0.00015, a linear complexity ratio of 0.5000, and excellent throughput speed. Based on the test results that showed a good behavior of the proposed stream cipher as a random function, this algorithm has the potential to be used as a secure cryptographic symmetric system.
