title: A Deep Learning-Based Framework for Personalized Laptop Recommendation from Natural Language Input
authors: Sri Melvani Hardi, Riyanda Azis Febrian, Dewi Sartika br Ginting
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: Selecting a laptop that aligns with individual user preferences poses a significant challenge due to the wide variation in hardware specifications and pricing across available models. This research proposes a laptop recommendation system that integrates Natural Language Processing (NLP) and deep learning methodologies to address this issue. Specifically, the system employs FastText word embeddings to transform natural-language user inputs into vector representations, which are subsequently processed by a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to predict matching laptop profiles. The training dataset comprises detailed laptop specifications, along with "Suitable For" labels indicating different user categories. After preprocessing and embedding, the model is optimized using a cosine similarity-based loss function. Recommendations are generated by computing the cosine similarity between the inferred user vector and the precomputed laptop vectors. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model attains an average Mean Cosine Similarity of 0.9396, indicating high accuracy in relevance matching. Furthermore, the system exhibits strong generalization capabilities when confronted with heterogeneous input types, including code-mixed language queries and minor typographical errors, thereby enhancing its applicability in real-world scenarios.

title: WIP: Understanding and Addressing Barriers to Industry Engagement in Undergraduate Engineering Programs
authors: Brahim Medjahed, John Cristiano, Sebastian Dziallas, Jean Huang, Michelle Edith Jarvie-Eggart, Stephanos Matsumoto, Chris Sharp, Rabih Younes
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper presents an early-stage study aimed at advancing meaningful industry engagement in undergraduate engineering education. While such collaborations offer clear benefits for student motivation, skill development, and career readiness, their adoption remains limited. To explore current practices and barriers, we conducted a national workshop with over 60 faculty and staff from diverse institutions across the US at an engineering education conference. Participants identified common challenges-such as time constraints, resource limitations, and institutional misalignment-as well as strategies like pilot programs, faculty incentives, and dedicated liaisons. Findings inform ongoing efforts to implement and scale sustainable, high-impact academic-industry partnerships.

title: WIP: Teaming Performance as Measured by Peer Evaluations: A Comparison Between Hyflex Team and Face to Face Team
authors: Junqiu Wang, Fazel Ranjbar, P.K. Imbrie
abstract: This work-in-progress, research-to-practice paper investigates the impact of team interaction modality (i.e., face-to-face, hyflex, or virtual) on student peer evaluations. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, a large public university shifted its first-year engineering fundamentals course sequence, including all team-based projects, to a fully online format. Over time, the course delivery evolved into a hyflex model and has since returned to a fully face-to-face. These three distinct interaction modalities provide a unique opportunity to examine how the mode of interaction influences students' teaming experiences. Specifically, this study addresses the following research questions: Do students evaluate their peers differently depending on whether their teams collaborate in a face-to-face, virtual, or hyflex mode?

title: An Improved Finite-Time Equivalent-Input-Disturbance Approach for Control Systems with Unknown Disturbances
authors: Hantao Wang, Jinhua She, Jianqi An, Seiichi Kawata, Makoto Iwasaki
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: This paper presents an improved finite-time equivalent-input-disturbance (IFTEID) approach that estimates the EID in a finite time. A finite-time state observer and an improved finite-time EID estimator ensure the finite-time convergence of the EID estimation and make improvement for the disturbance-rejection performance of a control system. The upper bound of the disturbance and its first derivative are not required in the design of the IFTEID approach. The rigorous proof of the EID-estimation error is presented.

title: An Exploration of User Biometric Identification In XR Applications Based On User Head Movement
authors: Owen Dossett, Ke Lyu, Maohong Liao, Han Li, Xianglong Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: User identification is essential for securing electronic devices, especially in immersive environments such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR). Traditional identification methods typically rely on proactive, one-time authentication, rendering them susceptible to common security threats and inadequate for providing continuous protection after login. Furthermore, existing user identification solutions for VR/AR head-mounted displays (HMDs) often compromise user convenience or require additional hardware, increasing cost and complexity. Although significant research has explored biometric-based identification in VR/AR, many proposed methods face practical challenges: they often depend on extensive sensor data or demand intrusive user interactions, limiting their suitability for diverse real-world scenarios. In this work, we present a lightweight and practical biometric user identification algorithm that utilizes only head movement patterns—eliminating the need for auxiliary sensors such as external cameras or controller-based inputs, and imposing no extra tasks on the user. Our approach is platform-independent and can generalize to new tasks without retraining. We validate its effectiveness through comprehensive experiments on multiple public datasets. Results demonstrate that our method achieves high identification accuracy with minimal data and computational overhead, making it a scalable and viable solution for continuous user identification in next-generation AR/VR applications.

title: Leveraging Real-Time Facial Emotion Recognition with Machine and Deep Learning for Enhancing Students' Classroom Engagement
authors: Sushmitha S S, Swetha Appaji Parivara, Pooja Shukla, K.P. Harshavardhan, Ramesh Saini, Senduru Srinivasulu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Real-time facial emotion recognition based on machine and deep learning can bring revolutionary potential in improving student engagement in the learning context. The proposed study features an efficient framework which identifies, tracks and interprets the emotion aspects of facial expressions of students in classroom activities based on effective computer vision applications. The whole system is performed in three main steps: Facial detection and tracking, emotion typing and emotion data display. A Centroid Tracker is used in face tracking to detect and track individual students in real time, and a convolutional neural network (CNN) which was trained using the FER2013 dataset which has seven emotions which this system can recognize facial expressions. This affective response is then graphically represented to teachers giving them an idea of attentiveness of students and mood. Moreover, OpenCV deep learning module can also be used to integrate with variety of pre-trained models, which boosts the accuracy of recognition in the live environment. Real time feedback helps teachers to constantly adapt the method of their instruction to either sustain or upsurge the level of interest among the students. The accuracy and relevance of the classical is validated on experimental basis by use of live webcam feed, tests of the multiplicity of images. More than realizing a better understanding of classroom dynamics, this emotion-conscious strategy will establish the basis of intelligent, responsive educational environments served by the deployments of affective computing and artificial intelligence (AI). Overall accuracy of the suggested CNN-based face emotion identification system with Centroid Tracking is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 8. 6 \%}$</tex>.

title: Consumer Sentiment Analysis Using NLP: Real-Time Brand Monitoring Across Social Media
authors: Prithvi Siva Sankar Shunmuga Sundaram
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This essay discusses an advanced, all-around real-time strategy for analyzing opinions on social media. NLP, deep contextual learning, and mood prediction are used. The system embeds unstructured international text semantically. The system can detect speech, tone, and setting subtleties. Attention processes and transformer-based structures assist the model in determining which text parts affect emotion polarity, intensity, and significance. A temporal forecasting algorithm forecasts unexpected public opinion and feeling shifts. It outperforms logistic regression and BERT in accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, specificity, and sensitivity. Computer metrics like mean absolute error, root mean square error, and area under the curve indicate real-time system performance, growth, and stability. Integrating forecasting helps people make smarter, more proactive decisions by projecting brand opinion trends and potential issues. The suggested method scales, predicts, and simplifies dynamic mood analysis. This allows organizations to gauge brand sentiment, predict customer behavior, and strategize in fast-changing digital areas. With contextual natural language processing and temporal analytics, systems for analyzing mood on social media become smarter, more predictive, and more aware of individuals.

title: ViT-TSNet: A Hybrid Spatio-Temporal Transformer for Accurate Timestamped Driver Action Recognition
authors: Anargha K, Linu Shine
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Detecting driver actions with precise timestamps is critical for improving road safety by identifying distracted behaviors that may lead to accidents. We propose ViT-TSNet, a novel action recognition framework that combines the spatial encoding capabilities of Vision Transformers (ViT) with the temporal modeling of TimeSformer to accurately localize and classify driver actions in video sequences. Evaluated on the AI City Challenge 2024 Track 3 dataset—a multi-angle video dataset of diverse driver behaviors—ViT-TSNet outperforms conventional approaches by effectively capturing spatiotemporal dependencies. Its hybrid architecture enables robust tracking of sequential actions, making it ideal for real-world applications requiring granular behavioral analysis. Compared to lightweight MobileNet (limited in complex action recognition) and standalone ViT (lacking temporal awareness), ViT-TSNet achieves superior accuracy (93.75%) and precision (96.88%). The results demonstrate that explicit temporal modeling is essential for precise timestamp detection, positioning ViT-TSNet as a scalable solution for driver monitoring systems.

title: The Influence of Advertising on Consumers Purchase Decisions in Malls
authors: Rangga Pratama Wiradinata, Siska Komala Sari, Astri Novianty, Kohbalan Moorthy, Agus Pratondo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: It is essential to understand how advertisements influence consumer purchasing decisions to design effective marketing strategies in competitive mall environments. Although mall advertisements are common, the actual impact on consumer behavior remains under investigated. This study examines the influence of mall advertisements by classifying respondents into three classes: Not Influenced, Sometimes Influenced, and Influenced. Survey data were collected from 311 mall visitors, capturing behavioral responses across advertising related indicators. A Random Forest (RF) classification model was used to identify the most influential predictors, achieving an accuracy of 89.39%, and revealed that ad noticing frequency, ad exposure before purchase, and brand familiarity were the strongest predictors of consumer influence. These results align with theories such as familiarity heuristics and show how repeated ad exposure and brand recognition shape consumer responses. To contextualize model performance, a Decision Tree (DT) classifier was also evaluated as a baseline with 86.82% of accuracy. The findings confirm that mall advertisements play a meaningful role in shaping consumer behaviors and that RF models offer valuable insights for predicting advertisement effectiveness.

title: Blockchain-Enabled AI Framework for Peer-to-Peer Energy Markets: Simulation and Case Studies in KSA
authors: Mounir Bouzguenda, Adel Benhamed, Noura Karray, Mohamed Amine Ksiksi
publish: 2025 IEEE Twelfth International Conference on Communications and Networking (ComNet)
abstract: Peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading is emerging as a cornerstone of smart grids, enabling prosumers to directly exchange electricity while reducing dependence on centralized intermediaries. This paper presents an integrated framework that leverages blockchain for secure, transparent, and automated transactions, and artificial intelligence (AI) for accurate forecasting and dynamic optimization. Blockchain ensures trust through tamper-proof records and smart contracts, while AI enhances forecasting of renewable generation and load, optimizes market clearing, and enables adaptive bidding strategies. The framework is demonstrated through case studies in the UK and Saudi Arabia, highlighting its alignment with digital transformation goals and Vision 2030 initiatives. A six-house simulation validates the technical feasibility of decentralized trading, showing improved efficiency, reliability, and user empowerment through blockchain immutability and AI-driven decision-making. The results confirm that AI–blockchain synergy can enhance sustainability, scalability, and cost-effectiveness in next-generation smart energy systems.

title: Modelling Process Mining Benefits: A context of Indonesia and Australia
authors: Nungki Dian S Darmayanti, Abel Armas-Cervantes, Sherah Kurnia, Arti Dian Nastiti, Ahmad Ainun Herlambang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Process mining refers to a family of techniques used for extracting knowledge from business process data (e.g., event logs). This technology grows in popularity as Gartner project 25% of global enterprises will adopt process mining tools by 2026. Aligning to this advancement, organizations require to understand its benefits including its enablers and inhibitors to maximize the adoption. This study proposes a conceptual framework called: Process Mining Benefits Model (PMBM), constructed from an extensive literature review coupled with interviews from 9 participants from Indonesia and Australia. These countries were chosen to reflect the early adopters (Indonesia) and more mature adopters (Australia). The proposed conceptual framework can be used to pave further research in process mining benefit thus, it is anticipated organizations will make informed decisions when investing in process mining initiatives.

title: A Federated and Blockchain-Enabled Approach for Agricultural Risk Management and Yield Prediction
authors: Murugesan Mohana Keerthi, Anil Pandurang Gaikwad, Venkateswara Rao Harimasa, Mahua Majumdar Bose, Mohit Tiwari, Mrutyunjay Padhiary
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: For increasing customer satisfaction on internet sites, precise suggestions are necessary. Traditional suggestion algorithms, on the other hand, often fail to adequately adjust to the immediate behaviours of users. The purpose of this research is to demonstrate an interactive architecture that depends on deep learning and offers the ability to optimise suggestion effectiveness by collecting both immediate and future user choices. Extraction of variable behaviours from user interactions is accomplished by a structure via the use of session-based RNNs, or recurrent neural networks, that are equipped with mechanisms for focus. Furthermore, Graphical Convolutional in nature Neural (GCNs) improve the learning of the relationships among users and things. Refinement of embedded contexts is achieved by the method by the incorporation of attention to oneself converters, which guarantees extremely precise and individualised suggestions. Complete evaluations conducted on comparable datasets have shown that the suggested system surpasses both the cooperative filtering along with deep learning-based models up to 85% for suggestions that are already in use. Comparing our strategy to the benchmark approaches, we can get a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15-25 \%$</tex> gain in Mean Reciprocity Rank (MRR) and Normalised Discounts Continuous Gain (NDCG). It has been shown via the findings that the client interaction structure that has been suggested considerably improves the reliability of actual time recommendations, resulting in a perfect candidate for adaptable content distribution.

title: Optimal Provisioning of Hybrid Service Function Chains with Guaranteed Disaster Resilience
authors: Mohamed Abderrahmane Madani, Fen Zhou, Ahmed Meddahi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Network Function Virtualization (NFV) provides a flexible mechanism for deploying Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) within Service Function Chains (SFCs), thereby streamlining data transfers between end-users and edge/cloud resources. The distinct requirements for forward and backward traffic—each carrying different types of content—give rise to Hybrid SFCs (HSFCs), which must be carefully designed to address unique deployment and performance concerns. However, achieving robust disaster resilience in HSFC-based NFV environments poses significant challenges, as natural or hardware-induced disruptions within Disaster Zones (DZs) can degrade service quality or even cause outages. This paper describes the Resilient Hybrid Service Function Chain Resource Optimization (R-HSFC-RO) approach to ensure both efficient resource utilization and sustained service delivery under disaster conditions. Our model considers bandwidth consumption, computational resource allocation for VNF execution, VNF instantiation overheads, and end-to-end latency requirements. For resolution, we propose a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model and Constraint Programming (CP), thereby enabling optimal solutions. Simulation results demonstrate that R-HSFC-RO reduces total costs by up to 50%, enhances disaster resilience, and maintains high operational efficiency.

title: IoRT ROS 2 Applications: Evaluating Zenoh and VPN for Robotic Networking in the Edge-Cloud Continuum
authors: Lei Fu, Gaurav Kapoor, Leonardo Militano, Giovanni Toffetti Carughi, Thomas Michael Bohnert
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Applications in the Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT) add an additional layer of complexity over traditional robotics, namely, networking and communication with the edge and the cloud. The field of cloud robotics has already revolutionized robotic systems, among others, by offloading computationally intensive tasks to the cloud. However, existing approaches are not necessarily suitable for real-time communication and distributed computing, and are not natively supported by widespread robotic middlewares such as ROS 2. Traditional Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) have been widely adopted for secure communication, but often introduce complexity in the setup and latency that can hinder real-time performance. Zenoh, an emerging data-centric networking framework, offers an alternative with low-latency, efficient data dissemination optimized for edge-to-cloud scenarios. Zenoh also integrates seamlessly with ROS 2, enabling lower overhead communication. This paper presents a comparative study of VPN and Zenoh in edge-cloud robotics, focusing mainly on communication latency, data throughput, and fault tolerance within a real-world robotic use case. Through experimental analysis, we highlight the strengths and limitations of both approaches and provide insight into their suitability for distributed robotic applications. The findings contribute to understanding the trade-offs between security, latency, and scalability in networking solutions for the IoRT.

title: Enhancing Spatial Data Processing with Event-Driven Command Query Responsibility Segregation
authors: Harshad Deshpande
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Managing large-scale spatial data requires scalable architectures that efficiently handle frequent updates and diverse query demands. This study explores the application of the Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern to spatial databases, focusing on OpenStreetMap (OSM) data processing. A novel event-driven approach is implemented using the Change Set Watcher (CSW), which distributes real-time updates to various services while optimizing read and write operations. The system architecture enables independent scaling of rendering, routing, and search functionalities, improving query efficiency and reducing database load. Performance evaluations demonstrate the benefits of event-based filtering, highlighting CQRS as a viable strategy for large-scale geospatial applications. The study also identifies challenges related to consistency, event ordering, and fault tolerance, offering insights into future improvements for spatial database management.

title: AI in Performance Management: Automating Feedback, Goal Setting, and Appraisals for Improved Productivity
authors: I. M. Christina Febiula, S. Nagaraju, Anik Ghosh, R.R. Venugopal, C.Ruby Sharmila, K. Manimekalai
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: When AI supports performance management, it integrates a transition from episodic subjective evaluations to continuous objective, individualized processes. This paper introduces a framework of AI-based systems that automate a core set of functions - feedback, goal setting, and appraisals and improve employee engagement and productivity. AIenabled systems change performance management by utilizing machine learning, natural language processing, and predictive analytics to map individual and organizational goals in real time, provide feedback in real-time, and provide appraisal without human bias. Furthermore, the AI-enabled performance management system reduces the managerial burden of conducting performance management, increases transparency and minimizes bias in evaluations. The paper outlines potential implementation challenges such as data privacy, ethics of AI accountability, algorithmic accountability, and organizational readiness. The paper includes three case studies from industries in the technology, education, and manufacturing sectors with evidence of significant improvements in employee satisfaction, accurate performance, and operational alignment. The paper concludes by positioning AI systems in an organization as an enabler of agile and responsible human capital management and offers recommendations for policy and future research concerning ethical uses of AI.

title: Optimized Classification of Chronic Liver Disease via Combined Whale Optimization and Simulated Annealing Techniques
authors: Madhur Grover, Jaskirat Singh, B. U. Anu Barathi, Swetha Rajagopal, Shabeeh Asghar Abidi, T. Manoj Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Chronic liver disease (CLD) is a disorder that presents a great diagnostic difficulty because of its variety. The proposed research presents a new classification system in combination between WOA (Whale Optimization Algorithm) and SA (Simulated Annealing) to select features better in 3D CT liver images. To start with, 73 texture features in high dimensionality were achieved including GLCM, GLGCM, GLCCM, Tamura, and neighborhood difference matrices. The suggested WOA-SA hybrid was useful in the aspect of reducing dimensionality since it closed the redundant features to a smaller optimum of 25 features and was still diagnostic. This was followed by the classification of these features which used an ensemble design of multiclass SVM, k-NN, and Random Forests with the strength of weighted majority voting. Experimental testing on a balanced clinical data set proved to achieve high classification results of 97.8 percent accuracy and sensitivity and specificity of 95.1 and 94.4 respectively on the five liver conditions. Such findings performed far better than individual classifiers and current techniques, which proves the stability and the diagnostic possibilities of the hybrid approach to CLD classification development.

title: A Novel Blockchain Protocol Design Integrating Lightweight Cryptography for Secure, Fast, and Scalable Transaction Verification
authors: Diganta Sengupta, Amit Sahu, Sonu Sharma, Arishya Begum, Rahul Arora, Sruthi P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study offers a safe and smart blockchain solution which fits the needs of IoT devices with little power. Given how quickly IoT networks are growing, it has become necessary to guarantee that transactions can be verified securely, fast and without limits. Traditional blockchain technologies are secure but still need a lot of processing power and can deliver slow transaction validation. So, we recommend a new verification process that uses a random number generator together with the Keccak-256 cryptographic hash. This method greatly lowers the computing burden that is usual when using SHA-256 and RIPEMD-160. Transactions in the protocol are verified using a combination of hash results and random numbers, making the system safe and efficient, without help from any central entity. Evaluations of the proposed system reveal that it handles verification and execution faster than both the Bitcoin network and the EPBC network. Its ability to create strong avalanches and the lower expense of computing make the Keccak-256 algorithm perfect for lightweight, decentralized IoT solutions. This study increases the scalability and efficiency of the Internet of Things using blockchain technology.

title: Design and Develop Hybrid Multipath Routing Approach for Proficient Energy Consumption in FANET
authors: Gaurav Soni, Arun Singh Kaurav, Ravi Verma, Advin Manhar, Jitendra Pratap Singh Mathur, Amit Chandra Patak
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The UAVs are making a temporary connection to their neighbours in FANET. The UAVs can roam around freely in a certain area to sense their neighbours for sending data. Sending data through the sender required an enough energy and batteries cannot be used to get this energy back or replace it. UAVs have limited battery or energy power, so nodes and the network need to use their power efficiently to last longer. The primary problem with UAVs in Flying hoc Network (FANET) is that they don't have enough energy. Single UAV can store valuable information but successfully transfer of data to other UAVs is not easy task in FANET. In general, a UAVs in a FANET has trouble staying connected since the worth of the channels changes and the battery life is short. So, to control the communications well, we need an efficient algorithm. This novel research presents an innovative multi-path routing strategy designed to enhance energy efficiency and strong connection establishment. This approach always picks the UAVs in the cluster that have the high 100382energy among all of their neighbours, but it puts a higher focus on nodes that don't move around often. Here, the intermediary nodes are using up their energy by accepting and sending data. The proposed strategy uses the energy and movement of UAVs. The sender UAVs got a response to each request and chose the node with the most energy to deliver the data. The new energy-efficient technique makes the network work better than regular shortest-path routing. Performance measurements like routing overhead, throughput, and delay are used to measure how well the routing works.

title: Network Traffic Matrix Imputation via Large Language Models
authors: Kaiwen Jiang, Fenglin Yan, Yan Qiao, Meng Li, Yuxuan Li, Mauro Conti
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable zero-shot capabilities across various domains. This paper pioneers the application of LLMs’ outstanding knowledge and reasoning abilities to the challenging task of Traffic Matrix (TM) imputation. However, the application poses significant challenges due to the skewed TM distribution and the deficient traffic feature under low sampling rate. To address these issues, we propose TM-LLM, the first LLM-based model specifically designed for TM imputation. Our approach includes two critical designs: Firstly, we develop an adversarial training strategy to pre-impute TM data, allowing the LLM to understand the distributional features even when faced with extensive missing data. Secondly, we devise a TM-specific embedding scheme along with a crafted prompt template, which enables our approach to harness LLMs’ exceptional inferential ability. Experimental results show that TMLLM significantly outperforms state-of-the-art imputation methods, achieves a notable 16.5% -44.8 % improvement in accuracy over the current best baseline, while reduces measurement costs by 80 % - 96 %. It can accurately capture the traffic pattern even when the sampling rate is extremely low. The code for reproducing our experiments is publicly available<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>. These findings strongly indicate the breakthrough potential of LLMs in network TM analysis tasks.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>The experimental codes with our methods and the datasets are available at https://github.com/FILingK/TM-LLM

title: WIP: Protect: a Framework for Preserving Project-Based Learning Integrity in the AI Era
authors: Xiaoguang Ma, Yanwei Wu, Mehdi Roopaei, Jing Wang
abstract: This work-in-progress paper introduces the PROTECT framework, an innovative methodology designed to safeguard the integrity of PBL in engineering education facing the challenge of the escalating capabilities of artificial intelligence (AI). As AI systems increasingly demonstrate advanced chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning, code generation, and automated reporting, ensuring that student work genuinely reflects individual effort is paramount. The PROTECT framework, rooted in experiential learning and authentic assessment literature, embeds seven interconnected pillars to ensure authentic student engagement and learning. Personalization tailors project to individual student contexts; Realism incorporates real-world complexities to expose AI's limitations; Originality mandates multimodal deliverables beyond text; Taxonomy (Guided Progression) structures projects to advance through increasing cognitive complexity; Evaluation Diversity employs varied assessment modalities like oral defenses; Constraints establish clear boundaries for appropriate AI use; and Transparency requires students to document and disclose their AI tool usage. This comprehensive approach addresses AI's current limitations, such as its lack of technical depth, multimodality output, or creative problem-solving. Pilot implementations of PROTECT in engineering courses have shown promising results, including increased pass rates, improved student performance, and a significant reduction in AI misuse, with only one AI-generated submission attempt observed among approximately 230 assessments. This framework offers actionable strategies for integrating robust assessment practices into PBL, balancing AI integration with authentic, student-centered learning outcomes. Future work will extend PROTECT across diverse engineering domains, refining evaluation mechanisms and exploring scalable models to mitigate AI misuse.

title: WIP: Navigating Reintegration Challenges After a Research Abroad Experience
authors: N/A
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice study examines the reintegration challenges faced by U.S. undergraduate and graduate engineering students returning from a research abroad program. The 3-year NSF-funded International Research Expericences for Students (IRES) program, “NSF Interdisciplinary Research in Smart City (NSF IRSC),” provides an eight-week immersive research experience at Seoul National University, where students engage in interdisciplinary projects focused on sustainable and smart cities. While such international research programs are designed to broaden students' perspectives and develop global competencies, the reintegration process is often overlooked—potentially limiting students' ability to translate these experiences into long-term academic and professional growth. Grounded in theories of crosscultural adaptation and transformative learning, this study explores how students reconcile newly acquired knowledge, research methodologies, and collaborative practices with the academic expectations and institutional norms of their home universities. It focuses on how NSF IRSC participants navigate their return to domestic academic environments, particularly in adapting to differing research cultures, collaboration styles, and institutional structures. Preliminary results from studying the first two cohorts out of three are presented in this work. Findings will inform the development of targeted reentry support strategies to enhance the integration of international research experiences into students' academic trajectories.

title: Digital Twin Enabled Control of a 4-DOF Robotic Arm
authors: Maiza Matloob, Zulkifal Zulkifal, M. Aizaz Khan, Khadija Asim, Shahkar Ahmad Khan, Abid Imran
abstract: In the era of industrial automation and smart manufacturing, systems integration of physical and virtual has become essential. Digital Twin technology facilitates remote monitoring, prediction, and control of robotic systems, thereby improving efficiency, adaptability and real time decision making. This paper describes the development of a Digital Twin of the DOBOT Magician robotic arm on ROS 1 Noetic on Ubuntu 20.04 for precise synchronization and real time control. The system successfully mirrored the physical robot's movements, sensor feedback, and joint states, and so could be used to automate pick and place operations in industry. Stable and low latency data exchange was achieved through a wired communication interface.

title: Diabetic Retinopathy Classification Using EfficientNetB3 and Grad-CAM Visualization
authors: Sharfina Nabila Larasati, Mohammad Nuh, Tri Arief Sardjono, Nada Fitrieyatul Hikmah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a diabetes-related eye disease that can lead to irreversible vision loss if not detected early. It occurs due to damage to retinal microvasculature, resulting in lesions such as microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and exudates. This study proposes an automated DR classification system using the EfficientNetB3 deep learning architecture, combined with Grad-CAM visualization to enhance model interpretability. The system was trained using fundus images from the APTOS 2019 and IDRiD datasets, and further evaluated on an external test set from Undaan Eye Hospital, Indonesia. Prior to training, preprocessing steps including cropping, resizing, and color and contrast normalization were applied to standardize input images, while data augmentation was used to address class imbalance. A two-stage transfer learning strategy was implemented: an initial phase using ImageNet pre-trained weights followed by fine-tuning on DRspecific data. The final model achieved an accuracy of 88.32%, and Grad-CAM visualizations demonstrated that the model consistently focused on clinically relevant retinal regions. These results suggest that the proposed method provides reliable and interpretable DR classification, with strong potential for realworld clinical application.

title: A New Scheme of Ruling Line Removal Using RGBB Based Method for Potential Dysgraphia Handwriting Images
authors: Siti Azura Ramlan, Iza Sazanita Isa, Abdul Aziz Abdul Muttalib, Ahmad Puad Ismail, Muhammad Khusairi Osman, Zainal Hisham Che Soh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Dysgraphia handwriting images exhibit distinct processing difficulties due to multiple factors that impact the formation of handwriting, such as lines, noise, scanner settings, and various writing patterns. Although histogram projection based on pixel intensity is commonly used for line removal, it is generally limited in its applicability. It requires attention for handwriting with dysgraphia due to irregular writing patterns. Therefore, this study introduces a customized ruling line removal algorithm based on the Red-Green-Blue-Black (RGBB) method. The algorithm analyzes the black and RGB channel pixel intensities, which enhances image processing and complement operations and morphology, followed by reconstructing missing pixels where letters overlap with ruling lines. The resulting structural similarity index is high, with an average score of 0.89 on the Structural Similarity Index (SSIM). The proposed method holds technical significance as it enhances the processing and extraction of features from handwriting.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Electronic Waste Management and Classification in Smart Cities
authors: Amogh S Guthur, Pranava Swaroop N, Kausthub Rao Mohite, Aditya, Pranav Sastry, Syed Thouheed Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: India, being a rapidly advancing nation, faces significant challenges in managing its growing electronic waste (e-waste) due to increased demand and consumption ratio. This research contributes towards a comprehensive deep learning approach for automated detection and classification of electronic waste (e waste) using convolutional neural networks (CNN) and transfer learning techniques. The proposed method achieves accurate identification and categorization of e-waste. In the detection phase the model detects e-waste from the input dataset image via belting approach and then categorizes them into pre-defined classes such as smartphones, television, keyboard, motherboards, laptops etc. achieving an accuracy of 93.67%, demonstrated with labeled bounding boxes around e-waste objects. The proposed deep learning approach offers scalability and adaptability for real world e-waste management systems.

title: The Future of AI-Powered Auditing: Enhancing Accuracy and Reducing Errors
authors: Siddharth S Karale, Sudip Debkumar Chatterji, Jaya Krishna Modadugu, Avinash Hanmant Ghadage, Hasan Ali Alsailawi, Mustafa Mudhafar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies is significantly improving monitoring functions while also transforming audit functions by providing increased precision, audit scalability, and real-time monitoring capabilities. In this paper, we propose an audit methodology based on artificial intelligence (AI) that incorporates the processes of data gathering, data cleansing, machine learning application, and anomaly detection to streamline error-prone audit processes and increase audit accuracy. A multi-stage model was built and tested in five industry sectors, and the model demonstrated better performance in anomaly detection and audit efficiency in all the sectors tested. The AI technologies have proven, using a novel-designed Audit Enhancement Index (AEI), to have substantially more efficiency in comparison to the traditional methods of auditing in a data-rich industry. An additional detailed workflow diagram and summary chart have been provided to visually demonstrate the advantages of the system over the traditional methods. AI can redefine the auditing processes from a post hoc examination of information to an ongoing, intelligent reevaluation of real-time data streams. This research has the potential to significantly advance automation in auditing and change perceptions of auditors to vision strategists empowered by instantaneous AI data analysis.

title: JSBSim and FlightGear as a Reinforcement Learning-Based Aircraft Testing environment
authors: Vynokur Oleksii, Perova Iryna
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation-based framework for training and evaluating reinforcement learning (RL) [1] agents in the context of aircraft control. The environment is built on the JSBSim flight dynamics model [2] and the FlightGear visual simulator [3], offering a realistic and customizable platform for testing intelligent control systems. The study introduces a PPO-based agent [4] enhanced with LSTM [5] for capturing temporal dependencies, targeting complex aerial maneuvers and autonomous landing tasks. Integration is achieved through a custom communication bridge using FlightGear’s generic input interface in UDP mode [6], [7], ensuring real-time control transfer. The agent is implemented using the Stable-Baselines3 framework [8], and training is managed via a Gym-compatible interface [9]. We further explore data collection strategies for training predictive models and discuss future steps involving visual feedback and deep learning integration. Experimental validation confirms the feasibility of the approach for replicable and robust RL-based aircraft guidance systems.

title: Novelty Detection Based on One-Class Support Vector Machines with Recursive Feature Elimination
authors: Hayder A. Hussein, Said Amirul Anwar
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Novelty detection focuses on identifying new, unusual, or outlier observations that deviate significantly from the target class. The detection process in some cases is challenging due to the presence of unimportant features in the dataset. Hence, there is a necessity to eliminate the insignificant features in the dataset to improve the novelty data points detection. This paper proposes a novelty detection framework that combines One-Class Support Vector Machines (OCSVM) with Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), empowered by Random Forest (RF) feature importance. In this work, the RFE-RF selects the four most significant features from each training set, reducing its dimensionality prior to the novelty detection modeling using an OCSVM. Hyperparameters for the OCSVM classifier are optimized via a 5-fold cross-validation technique. Experiments on five publicly available benchmark datasets show that the proposed algorithm improves overall detection accuracy compared to transformation-based feature reduction techniques. Based on the results, the proposed algorithm outperforms other approaches in the accuracy of the classification, registering at an average of 75% while producing a more balanced trade-off between the classification of the target data points and the detection of the novelty or outlier data points.

title: Optimizing Rice Irrigation Scheduling through Rainfall Forecasting Using LSTM-Based Model
authors: Benyamin Sibarani, Teddy Mantoro, Media Anugerah Ayu, Rahmadya Trias Handayanto
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Inefficient irrigation management due to weather uncertainty is a major challenge in maintaining rice productivity in Indonesia. Conventional irrigation practices are often wasteful of water and are not adaptive to climate change. This study addresses this problem by proposing a deep learning-based rainfall prediction model for irrigation schedule optimization. The method used is the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) algorithm trained using historical climatological data (temperature, humidity, sunshine duration) from the Open-Meteo platform. The main contribution of this study is the development of an accurate prediction model and its application in an intelligent irrigation recommendation system. Evaluation results show that the LSTM model achieves excellent performance with a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) value of 4.15 mm on test data. Recommendation system simulations also show the potential for significant improvements in water use efficiency compared to fixed scheduling methods. This study proves that the application of LSTM can be an effective solution to support precision agriculture and climate risk mitigation in the Indonesian agricultural sector.

title: Edge Computing and Immersive Technologies in Retinal Healthcare: Diagnosis with VR and AR
authors: Poonam Balasaheb Dhole, Priya Raghunath Jamdade, Sachin Jagadale, LK Vishwamitra, Atul Agrawal, Satish Pokharkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Edge computing plays vital role in healthcare also enables data processing at real time, helps to reduce latency and enhances decision-making with clinical perspective. In case ophthalmology, where early detection of diseases like diabetic retinopathy, age-related macular degeneration helps to prevent vision loss. Traditional methods hold few limitations like latency, bandwidth. Edge computing resolves these challenges to overcome in disease detection. Edge devices which are AI enabled improves the outcomes by real time data analysis. The combination of Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) helps in enhancing care, also these aids are more supportive in training and patient awareness about the diseases, particularly AR is useful in the diagnosis and surgery. This blending of AR and VR creates a powerful ecosystem for managing not only the retinal diseases but also helpful while working with other issues in healthcare domain. The EdgeEnabled Retina Disease Detection Algorithm utilizes deep learning models to deliver 96% accuracy with minimum processing time of just 1 second. However, hardware limitations and cybersecurity risks challenge are to be considered and accordingly future developments has to be made to improve better connectivity and real time analysis of data can be made. To reduce the blindness and to improve ophthalmic care edge computing will definitely become a hope as an advanced technology.

title: Investigation of Sparse Antenna Arrays
authors: Vladimir Yu. Volkov, Gleb A. Babanin
publish: 2025 Antennas Design and Measurement International Conference (ADMInC)
abstract: The article analyzes the characteristics of sparse antenna arrays in comparison with homogeneous ones. The properties and limitations of nonlinear algorithms using sample estimates for the correlation matrix of input signals and the allocation of subspaces of signal and noise are investigated. To implement the co-array method, a direct extension of the sample correlation matrix is used. Practically important sparse configurations of MRA, Coprime, and MISC with a small number of antenna elements are considered.

title: Accounting for the Interaction Between a Dummy Finger and Joint Modular Soft Actuators for Multi-Joint Support Using a Novel FEM-Based Approach_supp1-3653334.mp4
authors: Jose Gomez-Tames
abstract: Soft actuators are safer than rigid robots for hand rehabilitation, yet their performance can be significantly affected by interactions that occur on multi-joint systems. Actuator–finger and actuator–actuator interactions can impact bending output and make actuator performance dependent on the actuation pattern. To address this, we developed and validated a finite element model of a three-joint modular actuator system attached to a dummy finger. The simulation revealed that the displacement between actuators, and the contact area between the fingers and the actuators are key factors influencing actuator performance. We proposed a novel attachment method to enhance contact area and reduce actuator displacement and compared it against five existing designs across two actuator types and three actuation patterns. Our results demonstrate improved bending and reduced dependence of actuator performance on actuation pattern. This study makes a dual contribution to the area of soft robotics for hand rehabilitation by proposing a novel FEM framework for modeling soft actuators attached to multi-joint systems as well as providing insights on attachment method design for soft actuators in hand rehabilitation, emphasizing the importance of actuator-actuator and actuator–finger interactions.

title: Fusing Tabular Features and Deep Learning for Fetal Heart Rate Analysis: A Clinically Interpretable Model for Fetal Compromise Detection_supp1-3652309.pdf
authors: Lochana Mendis Paskuwal Handi
abstract: Objective: Cardiotocography (CTG) is commonly used to monitor fetal heart rate (FHR) and assess fetal well-being during labor. However, its effectiveness in reducing adverse outcomes remains limited due to low sensitivity and high false-positive rates. This study aims to develop an interpretable deep learning model that fuses FHR time series with tabular clinical features to improve prediction of fetal compromise (umbilical artery pH $< $ 7.05). Methods: We introduce Fusion ResNet, a novel architecture combining residual convolutional networks for FHR signal processing with a parallel neural network for tabular features. The model was trained and internally validated on a private dataset of 9,887 FHR recordings. External validation was performed on the open-access CTU-UHB dataset comprising 552 recordings. Model interpretability was evaluated using Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) and Gradient-Weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM). Results: Fusion ResNet achieved a mean area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 0.77 during internal cross-validation and a state-of-the-art AUC of 0.84 on the CTU-UHB dataset, outperforming existing deep learning approaches. SHAP analysis identified key clinical features contributing to predictions, while Grad-CAM highlighted salient FHR patterns linked to fetal compromise. Conclusion: The proposed model enhances predictive accuracy while providing clinically meaningful explanations, enabling more transparent and reliable CTG interpretation. Significance: This work demonstrates the potential of interpretable deep learning to improve fetal monitoring by integrating multimodal data, supporting timely and informed decision-making in obstetric care.

title: Real -Time Gesture Recognition for Human-Robot Interaction Using mmWave Radar and Deep Learning
authors: M Yellamma, Wasib Bin Latif, M. Koilraj, M. Manjula, Subhashini Peneti, Mateti Vedaansh
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Gesture recognition has become an important enabler to a human-robot interaction (HRI) that is intuitive and contactless. However, the traditional vision-based methods are usually constrained by changes in lighting, occlusion, privacy considerations, and the high computational requirements. In order to overcome these difficulties, the paper suggests a real-time, privacy-aware gesture recognition system based on mmwave radar sensing and lightweight CNN + temporal attention deep learning system. The offered system includes a hierarchical pipeline that includes mmWave radar signal acquisition, signal clutter removal and range-Doppler processing, temporal-spatial features encoding, and attention-based classification based on confidence fusion. The framework attains a total accuracy of 96.5 across six classes of gestures and end-to-end latency of less than 50 ms, which means that the control of a robot can be done easily and in a responsive manner. The great robustness is proved by experimental tests on 25 subjects in different environmental conditions, where the AUC values reach over 0.95 in all classes of gestures. Through comparison analysis, the suggested model proves to be better than the baseline CNN, BiLSTM and 3D-CNN models without sacrificing the computational complexity rendering it best suited to be deployed on the edges. The findings show the promise of mmWave radar sensing as a versatile alternative to vision-based HRI in providing real-time gesture-based HRI. The future research will delve into multi-user interaction, increased rank of gestures, and adaptive learning to be implemented more widely.

title: Applying Software Engineering Principles to Interdisciplinary AI Curriculum Development
authors: George Frazier, Nan Sun, Joseph Kendall-Morwick
abstract: This innovative practice full paper describes a novel approach to developing a multi-disciplinary AI literacy curriculum using software engineering principles. The curriculum is structured to minimize prerequisites, ensure scalability, and emphasize interdisciplinary learning across diverse undergraduate programs. By integrating Lehman's Laws of Software Evolution, agile development, and lean startup principles, this model enables continuous refinement based on faculty input and institutional feedback. Validation through faculty engagement and institutional approval highlights its feasibility and interdisciplinary adoption. Beyond AI literacy, this framework offers a scalable model for designing interdisciplinary curricula in emerging technologies, ensuring accessibility and integration across disciplines.

title: Human-in-the-Loop Systems for Adaptive Learning Using Generative AI
authors: Bhavishya Tarun, Haoze Du, Dinesh Kannan, Edward F. Gehringer
abstract: A Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) approach leverages generative AI to enhance personalized learning by directly integrating student feedback into AI-generated solutions. Students critique and modify AI responses using predefined feedback tags, fostering deeper engagement and understanding. This empowers students to actively shape their learning, with AI serving as an adaptive partner. The system uses a tagging technique and prompt engineering to personalize content, informing a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system to retrieve relevant educational material and adjust explanations in real time. This builds on existing research in adaptive learning, demonstrating how student-driven feedback loops can modify AI-generated responses for improved student retention and engagement, particularly in STEM education. Preliminary findings from a study with STEM students indicate improved learning outcomes and confidence compared to traditional AI tools. This work highlights AI's potential to create dynamic, feedback-driven, and personalized learning environments through iterative refinement.

title: Reconstructing Historical Monuments and Environments: A Digital Approach to Education
authors: Mario Casillo, Liliana Cecere, Francesco Colace, Angelo Lorusso, Michele Pellegrino
abstract: The advancement of digital technologies is radically transforming the ways in which historical and architectural heritage is studied, preserved and passed on to future generations. This work proposes an integrated methodology for the digital reconstruction and management of historical monuments, based on the integrated use of Heritage Building Information Modeling (HBIM), Digital Twin (DT), IoT sensors and Machine Learning (ML) algorithms. Through the creation of high-fidelity digital models, updated in real time through environmental monitoring systems, it is possible to obtain a dynamic and predictive vision of the state of health of historical structures. The case study of the Leproso Bridge in Benevento, constitutes a concrete example of the application of this methodology: starting from surveys performed with terrestrial laser scanners and drone photogrammetry, an HBIM model was generated and subsequently integrated with data from environmental sensors, to develop a functional DT for the simulation of evolutionary scenarios, both historical and future. This digital platform makes it possible to visualise the transformations undergone by the artefact over time, monitor its current state, and predict structural degradation phenomena through automated analyses. In addition to its contribution in terms of conservation, the proposed approach represents an innovative educational resource. Students and teachers are involved in immersive, interdisciplinary learning experiences that combine art history, structural engineering, digital modelling and materials science. The interactive and data-driven environment fosters the development of transversal skills such as critical thinking, collaboration between disciplines and the conscious use of technology in heritage conservation. In conclusion, the combination of HBIM, DT, IoT and AI emerges as a powerful tool for both research and conservation design, as well as for historical memory education in a sustainable and participatory perspective

title: Orchestrating Multimedia Transcoding Functions at the Edge: a Serverless Approach
authors: Gaetano Francesco Pittaà, Yasin Saedi, Gianluca Davoli, Davide Borsatti, Carla Raffaelli, Daniele Tarchi, Walter Cerroni
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Traditional Cloud-based multimedia transcoding approaches struggle with issues like latency and bandwidth limitations. In this work, we experiment with strategies that exploit Edge computing capabilities to get around such constraints. We focus on an on-demand multimedia transcoding service for real-time video streaming on the uplink, leveraging a state-of-the-art Edge Computing service orchestrator to handle its provisioning. We regard this as a use case for the orchestration platform, with the objective of enhancing the experience of the user as well as keeping important metrics in check, including resource utilization and load distribution over the Edge compute nodes. We perform evaluations on a physical testbed to assess the performance of the Edge-based system using real-world video transcoding workloads.

title: Evolving Software Engineering Education Through Undergraduate Peer-Mentorship
authors: Azim Abdool, Daniel Joseph Ringis, Akash Pooransingh, Aniel Maharajh
abstract: This innovative practice full paper looks at teaching the software development lifecycle to undergraduate students through peer-mentorship. We deployed a cross-year mentorship project for software engineering using introductory (level 2) and advanced software engineering (level 3) courses. All students in the advanced level 3 course had previously experienced the introductory level 2 course and would have insight into the expectations for the deliverables of the introductory software development project. The introductory course group project is an authentic assessment that focuses on designing and prototyping a software solution to address societal needs. They must adhere to software development lifecycle protocols as a team and deliver a prototype product, along with complete documentation, by the end of the semester. The advanced course student groups are assigned as managers (product, project, HR, Risk etc.) to mentor the introductory course groups. The approach highlighted in this paper builds on previous work [1], which ensured the acquisition of proper software engineering skills through industry mentorship. However, there was need to change the focus to using cross-year student mentorship to improve the degree of accountability and control over the mentorship process while improving the execution of the software project within a limited timeframe. This innovative approach not only enhances student learning outcomes but also optimizes faculty resources and fosters a collaborative learning community within the software engineering program.

title: Direct Data-Driven Impulsive Control With Average Impulse Interval and Event-Triggered Mechanism
authors: Mingxia Gu, Abdujelil Abdurahman, Malika Sader, Cheng Hu, Haijun Jiang, Shiping Wen, Jinde Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Controlling discrete-time linear systems with unknown model information while reducing control costs poses considerable obstacles. To tackle this issue, this paper proposes two novel data-driven impulsive control (IMC) frameworks for discrete-time linear systems. First, unlike most existing IMC strategies that rely on accurate system models or system identification, the proposed methods can directly design controllers based on measured data. Moreover, for data-driven IMC schemes that respect the average impulsive interval, the exponential stabilization of the system is demonstrated under the strong rank condition by leveraging relevant data and invoking the concepts of Lyapunov functions and the iterative synthesis procedure. Second, to reduce unnecessary impulsive actions during information transmission and thereby enhance control performance, a data-driven event-triggered impulsive control (ETIMC) approach is examined by combining event-triggered control with IMC. To mitigate the requirement for persistent excitation of input data, the concept of data informativity is utilized for analysis, and sufficient criteria for system stabilization under the proposed data-driven ETIMC are established in conjunction with the collected data. Ultimately, the validity of the theoretical results is verified through two illustrative examples.

title: Teaching Programming in the Age of AI: Transforming Pedagogy Amidst Code-Generating Technologies
authors: Asad Azemi
abstract: This innovative to practice full-paper examines how the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) tools capable of generating code—exemplified by systems such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot—has instigated a pedagogical shift in how programming is taught and learned. As these AI tools become more deeply embedded in professional and academic practices, educators are compelled to reassess traditional pedagogical approaches and realign them with the demands of an AIaugmented future. This paper explores the profound implications of these developments for computer programming education, focusing on the challenges that instructors face and the promising opportunities for curricular innovation. While AI tools provide valuable learning assistance, they risk encouraging superficial understanding if students rely on them excessively. We begin by reviewing major challenges associated with the use of AI tools by students, such as the ease with which students can generate complete code solutions without engaging in the problem-solving process. The birth of code-generating AI also poses significant challenges in maintaining academic rigor and assessment fairness. We also cover a short review of strategies and processes that instructors are employing to combat this issue. Finally, we will present our proposed innovative approach, which includes the integration of AI into programming education by shifting the focus from merely producing code to designing and architecting software systems. This approach encourages students to use AI as a collaborative tool, fostering creativity, strategic thinking, and ethical reasoning. This approach requires greater emphasis on systems thinking and design, which can foster an entrepreneurial mindset.

title: Anonymous Two-Party Authentication and Key Establishment With Trusted Server for Future-Proofing Security of Mobile Communication System
authors: Dharminder Chaudhary, Uddeshaya Kumar, Saibal Kumar Pal, Gaurav Mittal, Narendra Khatri
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: In cellular systems, user devices (UEs) establish secure sessions with each other through a trusted server such as the Home Subscriber Server (HSS) or Authentication Center (AuC). The proposed two-party authenticated key establishment allows two users to authenticate and exchange encrypted data with minimal involvement of the server -improving efficiency and scalability in mobile communication. Moreover, this paper presents a cryptanalysis of two post-quantum authentication and key agreement protocols proposed by Dabra et al. and Kumar et al. Our analysis identifies specific weaknesses, a design flaw in the registration phase of Dabra et al.’s protocol, and vulnerabilities to identity guessing and impersonation attacks in Kumar et al.’s scheme. Motivated by these findings, we propose a new communication framework for a two-party authenticated key establishment protocol assisted by a server. In the proposed model, user UA initiates communication by sending a request to a central server and receives a corresponding response to establish an authenticated session key with user UB. Notably, user UB does not need to interact with the server during session initiation or key derivation phases, thereby significantly reducing communication overhead and enhancing efficiency. Through extensive formal analysis and simulation, our protocol achieves 21.37% and 19.99% improvement in computational efficiency and 35.13% and 21.05% reduction in communication overhead compared to the lattice-based authenticated key agreement protocols of Dabra et al. and Kumar et al., respectively. Furthermore, the proposed scheme ensures key freshness, meaning that each session key is unique and has never been used in any prior communication session. This guarantees that every session remains protected by a distinct cryptographic key, even when the same users communicate repeatedly. Additionally, user UA can establish a secure session with user UB without revealing its identity to either UB or any intermediate server, thereby preserving user anonymity. Overall, the proposed protocol offers strong privacy guarantees while enabling secure, authenticated communication with a minimal number of message exchanges.

title: Virtual Collagen Mapping for Quantitative Microarchitectural Analysis in Whole-Core Pancreatic Tissue Microarrays_supp1-3651753.pdf
authors: Rajesh Kumar
abstract: Collagen remodelling plays a critical role in the progression of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) to pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), though misdiagnosis often occurs due to the resemblance with chronic pancreatitis (CP). While second harmonic generation (SHG) microscopy is the current gold standard in research for visualizing fibrillar collagen, it is not utilized for routine histopathological use. This study highlights the need for an alternative method for quantitative collagen analysis that is compatible with standard hematoxylin and-eosin (HE) stained histopathological slides. Using the computational image-to-image translation approach, whole-core standard brightfield HE images of pancreatic tissues were translated into the new collagen images. From these computationally translated collagen images, quantitative collagen measures were extracted for PDAC, PanIN, CP, and normal pancreatic tissues, and their statistical significance was evaluated. Among the four classes, PDAC tissues exhibited the highest collagen alignment (n = 58, p < 0.01, R² = 0.2594), while normal tissues showed the lowest fiber density (n = 58, p < 0.0001, R² = 0.3569). Seven machine learning models were assessed to differentiate neoplastic from non-neoplastic tissues cores based on collagen measures extracted from the translated collagen images. Feature importance and ROC-AUC analyses both identified fiber length and collagen deposition area as the most prominent parameters, achieving AUC values of 0.83 and 0.73, respectively, for distinguishing between the tissue classes. The findings demonstrate that the collagen images derived from standard HE stained tissue microarrays (TMAs) whole-core images enable quantitative assessment of collagen remodelling across pancreatic lesions. Additionally, the study indicates that cross-modality image translation, as a cost-effective alternative, has the potential to offer deeper insights into histopathology and tissue microenvironment analysis without requiring collagen-specific imaging equipment or external labels, thereby further supporting its feasibility for integration into standard clinical workflows.

title: Multiverse: A Simulator for Evaluating Entanglement Routing in Quantum Networks_supp1-3651126.pdf
authors: Amar Abane
abstract: We present MQNS, a discrete-event simulator for rapid evaluation of entanglement routing under dynamic, heterogeneous configurations. MQNS supports runtime-configurable purification, swapping, memory management, and routing, within a unified qubit lifecycle and integrated link-architecture models. A modular, minimal design keeps MQNS architecture-agnostic, enabling fair, reproducible comparisons across paradigms and facilitating future emulation.

title: Direct Thruster Force Optimization via Sparse Linearized Gaussian Process Model Predictive Control for ROV Trajectory Tracking_supp3-3647874.mp4
authors: Zhenzhong Chu
abstract: Traditional hierarchical remotely operated vehicle (ROV) control suffers from feasibility gaps between motion control and thrust allocation (TA). Modeling uncertainties further complicate the control problem. While GP-MPC can handle these uncertainties, it introduces nonconvex optimization problems with prohibitive computational costs. This article proposes a sparse linearized gaussian process-based direct thruster optimization MPC strategy (SL-GP-MPC) that addresses both control architecture and modeling problems. The proposed approach eliminates the TA layer by formulating thruster forces as direct optimization variables, thereby removing the feasibility gap inherent in hierarchical control structures. Furthermore, sparse linearized Gaussian processes enable convex approximation of the nonconvex GP-MPC, significantly improving computational efficiency while preserving complete probabilistic modeling capabilities. Theoretical analysis demonstrates the algorithm’s recursive feasibility and asymptotic stability. Pool experiments validate the superior performance of the proposed method in complex hydrodynamic environments.

title: Dual-Polarized Phased-Array Antenna With Asymmetric Coupled-Line Network and a Matched Observation Combiner for Self-Calibration
authors: Seong-Ju Lim, Chanhee Lee, Chihyun Cheong, Sol Kim, Jong-Won Yu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, we propose a dual-polarized multibeam array with asymmetric coupled lines for antenna-connected self-calibration. The coupled lines are integrated along the edges of aperture-coupled slot-fed microstrip patch antennas with a matching network to equalize the coupling responses of asymmetrically fed V- and H-polarization paths. A matched <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4{:}1$</tex-math></inline-formula> radial resistive combiner further stabilizes the coupled-signal collection by mitigating combiner-induced amplitude/phase distortion and enhancing inter-port isolation. The proposed network achieves tightly matched coupling characteristics across both polarizations over the operating band. To validate the design, a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times 2$</tex-math></inline-formula> dual-polarized module and a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times 8$</tex-math></inline-formula> array with a stacked four-beam transmit front end were implemented at 3.4 – 3.8 GHz. Multibeam measurements confirm that the self-calibrated beams closely agree with simulations without noticeable degradation of radiation characteristics, demonstrating reliable dual-polarized self-calibration under antenna-connected operation.

title: Endfire Full-Space-Scanning Dual-Mode Antenna Based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons
authors: Xiang-Hao Meng, Zhi-Jie Wei, Zhang-Qi Liao, Ya-Wen Liu, Wen-Zhong Lu, Xiao-Chuan Wang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this study, an endfire full-space-scanning dual-mode antenna based on spoof surface plasmon polaritons (SSPPs) is proposed. First, a composite U-shaped SSPP cell is utilized, and outer strips are periodically loaded on both sides to form a periodic radiation structure. The propagation constant and dispersion characteristics of SSPPs can be flexibly adjusted. Second, odd-mode SSPPs are excited for endfire radiation, and two SSPP segments with different parameters are combined to lower the sidelobe level. Third, through appropriate modulation and effective suppression of the open stop band effect, full-space scanning and high scanning rate are achieved. Finally, prototypes are fabricated and measured to verify this design. For the endfire mode from 7.0 GHz to 7.8 GHz, a high gain ranging from 12.02 dBi to 14.69 dBi is realized, and the sidelobe level is lower than −10 dB. For the beam scanning mode from 9.8 GHz to 12.5 GHz, full-space scanning is achieved, with a stable gain varying from 9.41 dBi to 11.31 dBi and a high scanning rate of 7.43°/%.

title: Dike: Deep Reinforcement Learning For Function Scheduling in SLO-targeted Serverless Edge Computing
authors: Chen Chen, Emanuele Carlini, Richard Mortier
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Serverless computing is regarded as a good match for distributed edge infrastructures. However, bringing the function-as-a-service model to a highly dynamic, distributed, and heterogeneous pool of resources has its fair amount of challenges. Allocation of functions to the proper resource is an essential operation that avoids over-provisioning and the relative waste of computational resources. In this work, we propose Dike, a bi-level function scheduling and resource allocation framework designed to meet end-to-end latency SLOs (service-level objectives). Dike leverages deep reinforcement learning to balance resource provisioning and monetary cost by incorporating both composite cost and SLO violations into the reward. Extensive simulations with real-world production workloads demonstrate the superiority of Dike. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithms approximate the results of state-of-the-art ILP solver within a factor of 1.08 while dramatically reducing the scheduling time.

title: Water Safety Under the Lens: A Field Survey and Rapid AI-Powered Escherichia coli Detection in Peshawar and Swat Regions
authors: Jehad Ur Rahman, Mohsin Ali Shah, Sabir Aziz, Samad Riaz, Gul Muhammmad Khan
abstract: Drinking water is crucial for the subsistence of human. Without food for a few days, humans can survive, but without water, it is hard to survive even for 3 to 6 days. Many people residing in the different regions of the world are facing the fecal contamination issues and have no availability of clean drinking water. Two of the big reasons for fecal contamination in drinking water occur if the region is affected by flood and if the sewage has entered the sanitary pipelines due to leaks. Peshawar is one of the oldest cities, having the old sanitary pipelines, as well as Swat, which is one of the flood-affected cities of Pakistan, and our proposed work detects the Escherichia coli (E. coli) contamination in the drinking water of the different areas of Peshawar and severely affected areas of Swat after 6 hours of incubation using a custom-made image device that is deployed by our trained YOLOv8 model mAP@50 of 97%. The experiments performed on the water samples of 18 different areas of Peshawar and 10 areas of Swat. The results show the contamination by E. coli bacteria in the Fizagat area is high compared to 9 other areas in Swat, and water samples of Inner City Peshawar were highly contaminated compared to 17 other areas of Peshawar. In future work, the other old residential and flood-affected regions of Pakistan will be covered, i.e., Dir, Nowshera, Mardan, Dera Ismail Khan, etc.

title: MAIA:AI System for Repetitive Demand Resolution in Brazil
authors: Eduardo Caruso Barbosa Pacheco, Glauber Machado Pinto
