title: Explainable Human Activity Recognition Using IMU Data: A Shapley-Value-Based Method
authors: Xinyu Yuan, Seiichi Kawata, Juan Zhao, Jinhua She
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Deep learning models have greatly improved human activity recognition (HAR) using inertial measurement unit (IMU) data. Compared to previous machine learning methods, deep learning models automatically learn features from raw IMU data, leading to more accurate activity recognition. However, the black-box nature of deep learning models limit their application in high-risk areas that require transparency and interpretability. To improve the interpretability of the model, we designed an interpretable human activity recognition method that integrates convolutional neural networks, gated recurrent units, and interpretable analysis based on Shapley value, which is named XRGHAR. Our work not only quantifies the contribution of IMU channels to activity recognition via a global explanation method but also employs interpretable results as feedbacks to enhance model performance. We conducted comprehensive experiments on the HuGaDB dataset and achieved the accuracy of 92.5 %. XRG-HAR significantly improves the model’s interpretability while also leverages interpretable results to improve the performance of recognizing human activities.

title: Designing the Key Components of the Antenna-Feeder System for Road Radars
authors: T. E. Sayfullin, E. P. Grakhova, A. A. Ishmiyarov, G. S. Voronkov
publish: 2025 Antennas Design and Measurement International Conference (ADMInC)
abstract: This article focuses on the development of essential elements for road radars that are installed in the same direction as vehicle movement within the Russian Federation. It outlines an approach for implementing and designing a scanning phased antenna array that operates in the K-range frequency of 24.05–24.25 GHz. A simulation model of the emitter and antenna array has been created, and a method for implementing a beam-forming scheme has been established, particularly through the use of the developed simulation model of the Wilkinson bridge.

title: Detecting and Protecting from Hostile Behavior in Flying Ad hoc Networks for Data and Route Security
authors: Avinash Singh, Ankur Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In a flying ad hoc network, each UAV moves freely within the environment, gathers data from various situations (such as disasters, remote sensing in forest regions, border surveillance, traffic monitoring, and wildlife monitoring), and sends all this information to the base station or other UAVs. Malicious UAVs are affecting the network performance. FANET security is a major concern today. Flying devices, also known as drones, have capabilities such as capturing images and are equipped with special sensors that gather specific types of data. However, they have limited processing and memory capacity, which prevents them from performing large-scale data processing or decision-making. Sybil attacker is one of the most harmful attackers since they have stolen the identities of other UAVs and used them to for data dropping. In this paper, proposes a Route and Data Security for hostile Behaviour Prevention (RDSBP) approach for sybil attacker in FANET. Implement a route security system using behaviour analysis on the base station device to detect this type of malicious activity. The attacker node modifies the routing table to make a false route decision, while it diverts the route by updating the next hop address field in the routing packet. The basic function of RDSPB is to identify the actual attacker identity. The base station is responsible for monitoring, controlling, alert message generation, and packet-level filtering for the entire network. While the flying device wants to send data to the intended receiver or base station, it calls the AODV routing procedure and broadcasts the generated route packet into the network. The performance of RDSBP is compared with LOAD and LPAR and the security performance of novel security scheme is better.

title: An Extension of Pixel-Shift Pairing Strategies for Self-Supervised Ultrasound Denoising
authors: Kuntoro Adi Nugroho, Yudi Eko Windarto, Arseto Satriyo Nugroho
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Ultrasound imaging is widely used in clinical practice but suffers from speckle noise that obscures fine details and complicates downstream analysis. Supervised denoising requires clean–noisy pairs that are rarely available, highlighting the need for self-supervised approaches. We extend the fast blind denoiser Noise2Fast by introducing simple yet effective one-pixel horizontal and vertical shifts before subsampling, generating additional pseudo input–target pairs. This augmentation in-creases training diversity while keeping inference computation-ally efficient. Experiments on three datasets (BUSI, Fetus, Tel-U) under controlled noise conditions show consistent improvements over existing self-supervised baselines. For example, at $\sigma _s^2 = 0.5$ our method achieves PSNR values of 25.72 dB, 29.09 dB, and 25.71 dB, outperforming Noise2Fast and Neighbor2Neighbor in most cases. Ablation studies confirm that both shift directions provide complementary gains, though effectiveness varies with dataset and noise severity. While improvements are modest and evaluations rely on synthetic noise, the results demonstrate a practical strategy for ultrasound denoising and motivate future work on adaptive extensions and larger architectures.

title: User Experience–Driven Design and Evaluation Framework for Electronic Shelf Label Systems in Smart Retail Environments
authors: Siti Norbaya Daud, Nurul Azlia Mat Saat, Norriza Hussin, Siti Nazirah Muhamad Zainuldin, Lim Wen-I, Siti Azirah Binti Azhari
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: The integration of Electronic Shelf Label (ESL) systems into smart retail environments has revolutionized in-store operations and customer engagement by enabling real-time price updates, dynamic promotions, and automated inventory management. However, existing ESL research predominantly focuses on technical efficiency, with limited attention to the user experience (UX) perspective, which is critical for optimizing both customer satisfaction and staff performance. This study proposes a User Experience–Driven Design and Evaluation Framework for ESL systems that embeds human-centered design principles and usability evaluation metrics throughout the system development lifecycle. The framework comprises four iterative phases—user research, task analysis, UX-centered interface design, and evaluation—providing structured guidance for developers and retailers in designing intuitive and efficient ESL interactions. A conceptual case study based on a simulated medium-sized retail environment is presented to illustrate the framework’s application and expected outcomes. The conceptual findings indicate potential improvements in task efficiency, error reduction, and perceived usability among both store staff and customers. This work establishes a conceptual foundation for integrating UX principles into ESL system development and highlights the need for future empirical validation and cross-context evaluation within IoT-enabled smart retail ecosystems.

title: Hadamard Transform on a Modified Unit Circle Qubit Model
authors: Tetiana Onyshkevych, Valerii Hlukhov
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In this paper, methods for performing the Hadamard transform are analyzed to organize quantuminspired computations. The Hadamard transform is illustrated on the Bloch sphere and on the unit circle, both as a direct transformation and as a result of successive rotations of a vector. In addition, the effect of the Hadamard gate on the smoothly changing state of the qubit was investigated and the corresponding graph is presented. The paper proposes a qubit model in the form of a modified unit circle, which combines operations only with real numbers in the standard unit circle and symmetry of the Bloch sphere. This makes it possible to abandon the analysis of the vector phase when analyzing the behavior of the qubit model, that is, to abandon the use of complex numbers (amplitudes) when simulating. The model is oriented towards implementation in FPGA.

title: Topological Data Analysis (TDA) as a Framework for Understanding Deep Learning Behavior
authors: K. Karuppiah, Selvavinayagam Velusamy, M. Nazreen Banu, D. Sunantha, G. Jenitha, R. Brindha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The rising complexity and opacity of deep learning models over the years has made interpretability, transparency, and trust-worthiness for these models increasingly important. Many common explainability techniques are based off gradient-based, or perturbation based approach that could fail to understand global aspects of neural network behavior. In this paper, we introduce Topological Data Analysis (TDA) with special emphasis on persistent homology, as one of the most useful and powerful frameworks for understanding, and visualizing deep learning model dynamics, through regards to the structured, or topological features in high-dimensional activation spaces in which TDA can expose important patterns (clusters, loops, voids, etc.) as the behavioral traits that neural networks exhibit. We examine the evolution of topological signatures during training in order to understand characteristics such as feature learning, overfitting and generalization. We present experiments using standard architectures (such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs)) across datasets such as MNIST and CIFAR-10 which show that persistent diagrams and barcodes are useful for distinguishing structural changes in learned representations. Additionally, TDA-based summaries also offered model agnostic analysis which allowed us to compare representations across different architectures and optimization strategies. By bringing together topological perspective with traditional performance metrics, this study expands our understanding of model behavior, and sets the stage for topology aware model design and evaluation, ultimately establishing TDA as an important approach in the pursuit of explainable and interpretable deep learning.

title: A Deep Learning-Based Model for Forest Canopy Height Mapping Using Multi-Source Remote Sensing Data
authors: Jiapeng Huang, Yue Zhang, Xiaozhu Yang, Fan Mo
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Forest canopy height is a critical structural parameter for accurately assessing forest carbon storage. This study integrates Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation(GEDI) LiDAR data with multi-source remote sensing features to construct a multi-dimensional feature space comprising 13 parameters. By employing high-dimensional feature vectors of “spatial coordinates + environmental features,” the proposed deep learning-based Neural Network-Guided Interpolation (NNGI) model effectively harnesses the capacity of deep learning to model complex nonlinear relationships and adaptively extract local features.This method adopts a dual-network collaborative architecture to dynamically learn interpolation weights based on environmental similarity in the feature space, rather than relying on fixed parameters or merely considering spatial distance, thereby effectively fusing the complex nonlinear relationship modeling capability of deep learning with the concept of spatial interpolation.Experiments conducted across five representative regions in the United States demonstrate that the overall accuracy of the NNGI model significantly outperforms traditional machine learning methods,Pearson correlation coefffcient (r)=0.79, Root Mean Square Error (RMSE)=5.38 m, Mean Absolute Error(MAE)=4.04 m, Bias=-0.15 m. In areas with low (0-20%) and high (61-80%) vegetation cover fractions, the RMSE decreased by 37.52% and 5.37%, respectively, while the r-value increased by 15.87% and 35.90%, respectively. Regarding different slope aspects, the RMSE for southeastern and western slopes decreased by 30.38% and 18.70%, respectively. This study provides a more reliable solution for the accurate estimation of forest structural parameters in complex environments.

title: CAUSALNAV: A Long-term Embodied Navigation System for Autonomous Mobile Robots in Dynamic Outdoor Scenarios_supp1-3653283.mp4
authors: xueqian WANG
abstract: Autonomous language-guided navigation in large-scale outdoor environments remains a key challenge in mobile robotics, due to difficulties in semantic reasoning, dynamic conditions, and long-term stability. We propose CausalNav, the first scene graph-based semantic navigation framework tailored for dynamic outdoor environments. We construct a multi-level semantic scene graph using LLMs, referred to as the Embodied Graph, that hierarchically integrates coarse-grained map data with fine-grained object entities. The constructed graph serves as a retrievable knowledge base for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), enabling semantic navigation and long-range planning under open-vocabulary queries. By fusing real-time perception with offline map data, the Embodied Graph supports robust navigation across varying spatial granularities in dynamic outdoor environments. Dynamic objects are explicitly handled in both the scene graph construction and hierarchical planning modules. The Embodied Graph is continuously updated within a temporal window to reflect environmental changes and support real-time semantic navigation. Extensive experiments in both simulation and real-world settings demonstrate superior robustness and efficiency.

title: Modular Model Adaptation for Online Learning in Streaming Text Classification_supp1-3651427.pdf
authors: Hyuk-Yoon Kwon
abstract: The dynamic nature of streaming data often introduces distribution shifts that challenge typical text classification models. This paper proposes an online learning framework tailored for streaming text classification under distribution shifts. First, we decompose a neural network-based text classification model into distinct modules and analyze the varying impact of updating these modules under different types of shifts. Based on this insight, we define three novel indicators to efficiently measure the extent of distribution shifts without evaluating the entire model. These indicators enable the development of predictive models that dynamically optimize module update strategies, balancing learning efficiency and accuracy in real-time. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first approach to systematically adapt model updates according to a trade-off between efficiency and accuracy in online text classification. Extensive experiments on real-world streaming datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our method, which consistently outperforms both static update strategies and state-of-the-art online text classification models. Our code and data are publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/bigbases/modular-online-adaptation</uri>.

title: Information-Maximized Soft Variable Discretization for Self-Supervised Image Representation Learning_supp1-3648138.pdf
authors: Chuang Niu
abstract: Self-supervised learning (SSL) has emerged as a crucial technique in image processing, encoding, and understanding, especially for developing today’s vision foundation models that utilize large-scale datasets without annotations to enhance various downstream tasks. This study introduces a novel SSL approach, Information-Maximized Soft Variable Discretization (IMSVD), for image representation learning. Specifically, IMSVD softly discretizes each variable in the latent space, enabling the estimation of their probability distributions over training batches and allowing the learning process to be directly guided by information measures. Motivated by the MultiView assumption, we propose an information-theoretic objective function to learn transform-invariant, non-trivial, and redundancy-minimized representation features. We then derive a joint-cross entropy loss function for self-supervised image representation learning, which theoretically enjoys superiority over the existing methods in reducing feature redundancy. Notably, our non-contrastive IMSVD method statistically performs contrastive learning. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of IMSVD on various downstream tasks in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. Thanks to our variable discretization, the embedding features optimized by IMSVD offer unique explainability at the variable level. IMSVD has the potential to be adapted to other learning paradigms. Our code is publicly available at https://github.com/niuchuangnn/IMSVD.

title: Design and Simulation of a Hybrid-Controlled Bidirectional Buck-Boost Converter for Dual Power Flow Applications
authors: Philip Nathanael Erlangga Sitorus, Tri Desmana Rachmildha
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: The increasing demand for bidirectional power conversion systems has accompanied the rapid growth of energy storage technologies, electric vehicles, and DC microgrids that require flexible and efficient bidirectional power management. One of the key challenges in such systems is maintaining voltage stability under dynamic variations in input voltage and load conditions. A bidirectional buck-boost converter offers an effective solution for regulating bidirectional power flow, yet its overall performance strongly depends on the control strategy used. This study proposes the design and simulation of a hybrid control system for a bidirectional buck-boost converter to achieve robust voltage regulation under varying operating conditions. The proposed hybrid control dynamically determines the switching modes buck, boost, or freewheeling based on the instantaneous values of inductor current and capacitor voltages, based on a decision rule derived from the converter's state-space model. The mathematical model of the converter is formulated for four switching configurations and implemented in the MATLAB Simulink environment using MATLAB Function blocks. Simulation results demonstrate that the hybrid control successfully maintains the output voltage close to the reference value, with a rapid transient response and minimal steady-state oscillation, even under fluctuations in the source and load. The proposed method demonstrates high robustness and flexibility, with the presence of parasitic components such as resistances not significantly affecting system performance, thereby simplifying state-space analysis compared to conventional PI control. Moreover, the hybrid control does not require high-accuracy sensor measurements, allowing the converter to operate reliably even when implemented with low-resolution ADC hardware. The findings confirm that the proposed hybrid control method enhances the dynamic performance and voltage regulation capability of bidirectional buck-boost converters, making it a promising solution for renewable energy storage systems, electric vehicle power interfaces, and DC microgrid applications that require efficient, reliable, and adaptive power control.

title: Expert-Integrated Stacking Model for Estimating Software Development Effort
authors: Mohammad Haris, Fang-Fang Chua, Amy Hui-Lan Lim
abstract: Software providers are expected to deliver products on time, within budget, and in line with client expectations. Achieving this requires accurate effort estimation, which helps determine the necessary manpower, resources, timeline, and costs involved in software development. However, widely employed traditional "Software Development Effort Estimation (SDEE)" techniques are considered outdated, inflexible, and inaccurate due to the growing complexities of modern software. Expert estimation remains a pivotal traditional technique for exploiting human expertise, although relying entirely on this technique results in human bias and subjectivity. Machine Learning (ML) has recently acquired prominence to improve SDEE. Nonetheless, ML models based on a single algorithm may lead to suboptimal accuracy and be ineffective in handling a wide range of SDEE challenges. Besides, existing studies neglect human involvement and rely entirely on ML, which may overlook contextual factors and nuances that experts could provide based on their expertise and domain knowledge. This research proposes a novel stacking model, designated as EXpert-Integrated DiverSe-Bagging EnSembles Stacking for SoftwarE DEvelopment Effort Estimation (Xpert-S3E4). To develop, six diverse bagging ensembles are initially employed as base learners and integrate expert estimations to complement their estimations. Subsequently, "Feed-Forward Deep Neural Network (FFDNN)" is employed as a meta-model for the final SDEE. The Xpert-S3E4 model outperformed five existing SDEE models, achieving lower MSE, MAE, and RMSE and higher R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> across two diverse datasets, SEERA and USP05-FT.

title: WIP: Piloting Three New Sociotechnical Modules for an “Introduction to Circuits” Course
authors: Karen E. Nortz, Cynthia J. Finelli, Susan M. Lord
abstract: This work-in-progress, research-to-practice paper focuses on piloting three sociotechnical modules developed for a circuits course. Engineering instruction often isolates technical skills from real-world challenges, although integrating sociotechnical concepts has been shown to enhance student learning and engagement. Despite its importance, many instructors face challenges in incorporating sociotechnical topics. To address these challenges, we recruited a cohort of graduate students to create sociotechnical modules for an “Introduction to Circuits” course. We piloted three modules to groups of former circuits students to assess the efficacy of the modules before implementing them broadly. After participating in the module facilitated by its creator, undergraduate students in the pilot completed an evaluation survey. Overall, they reported the modules to be interesting and engaging, believed that the social topics were well integrated with the technical ones, and appreciated the real-world examples. The modules were refined based on the student feedback and will be facilitated in both small and large “Introduction to Circuits” classrooms.

title: POSLOG: Creating a Part of Speech Tagger for Log Messages
authors: Kilian Dangendorf, Sven-Ove Hänsel, Jannik Rosendahl, Felix Heine, Carsten Kleiner, Christian Wartena
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: IT-systems generate log messages containing important information about the system’s health. Automatically analyzing and understanding these messages improves system resilience and security. Since log messages contain many fragments in natural language, using typical methods for natural language analysis, like part of speech (PoS) tagging and parsing have been applied to log analysis. However, as log messages differ significantly from normal written English, existing PoS taggers achieve limited accuracy on them (only $\mathbf{7 8}-\mathbf{8 8} \boldsymbol{\%} \boldsymbol{)}$. We present PosLog, a PoS tagger specifically designed for log messages. The core of our work is the construction of a training corpus, specialized in technical language of logs, tagged with the UpOS tagset. On a wide range of log messages from 16 different real systems, we apply five state-of-the-art PoS taggers and use majority voting strategy to determine PoS tags. Subsequently we apply automated corrections based on word-level patterns and tagset consistency. Tokens that still lack consensus are then manually annotated. Based on this corpus, we train PosLog, a CRF-based PoS tagger, which achieves 96 % accuracy.

title: The 42% Accuracy Drop: When Vision Transformers Fail Across Medical Imaging Datasets
authors: Jaffer Shah Jahangeer, P Shanmugavadivu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper reports a crucial failure mode for Vision Transformers in medical imaging through zero-shot evaluation of DINOv2 on diabetic retinopathy (DR) detection. Through zero-shot evaluation, and using an identical experimental protocol through a unified processing pipeline, we observe a catastrophic drop of 42.33 % accuracy between two standard diabetic retinopathy datasets: we see DINOv2 achieves 96.18 % binary classification accuracy on APTOS (3,662 images) but only 53.85 % on IDRiD (597 images). This striking drop in performance occurs despite both datasets representing the same clinical task of 5-grade diabetic retinopathy severity classification from fundus photographs. A unified analysis shows that this apparent “success” on APTOS is attributable to the model's ability to classify Grade 0 (no DR) with an F 1 -score of 95.71 %. In contrast, the model only achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-scores of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$43-52 \%$</tex> for minority disease grades, illustrating that DINOv2 does not adequately detect minority disease grades on either dataset. On IDRiD, the model totally fails to detect Grade 1 diabetic retinopathy (0 % precision and recall) and we find that attention mechanisms exhibit less than 1.2 % intersection over union overlap with clinical annotation of lesions. Analysis of the feature space revealed that separability is extremely poor, showing an Adjusted Rand Index of 0.092 on IDRiD, compared to 0.231 on APTOS. This data highlights that high accuracy on a single dataset for medical imaging cannot be generalized to another dataset, even for the same disease and imaging modality, which has serious implications for the reliability of zero-shot foundation model performance in direct clinical applications.

title: Research on new energy load forecasting strategy with machine learning
authors: Jiangtao Guo, Rui Yin, Longjun Zhang, Yuan Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: To address challenges in renewable energy integration and low load forecasting accuracy, this study proposes a machine learning-integrated strategy for renewable energy prediction. The proposed approach first designs a load forecasting model based on TCN-BiGRU-Attention that accurately captures load time-series characteristics and process coupling relationships, thereby improving short-term prediction accuracy. Subsequently, the model's hyperparameters are optimized using an enhanced Hippopotamus Optimization (HO) algorithm to enhance diagnostic performance and generalization capabilities. Experimental results show that the proposed HO-TCN-BiGRU-Attention model outperforms other models in both error control and fitting capability. By automating hyperparameter optimization through an improved Hippo algorithm (HO), the model effectively captures key features in aluminum electrolysis load sequences and models both short- and long-term dependencies. This multi-model fusion approach reduces prediction error by 43.1%, providing high-precision decision support for renewable energy scheduling and enhancing practical applicability.

title: Context-Aware Sarcasm Detection Using User Behavior and Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Yuvraj G Nikam, Love Kumar, Dhanshri Amol Shinde
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Sarcasm detection is a fine-grained problem in natural language processing since it depends on implicit meaning, context features, and user behavior. This paper is a comparative analysis of several learning approaches to predicting sarcastic content by fusing textual features, contextual features, and user behavioral features. The experiments are performed on standard test sets, i.e., Twitter, Reddit, and MUStARD, by using classical machine learning approaches, deep neural network architectures, and transformer-based systems. The outcome suggests that transformer-based systems, namely BERT and RoBERTa, significantly outperform traditional systems. Moreover, employing context features and user behavior features improve classification performance with significant improvement in F1-scores. These findings establish the need for multi-dimensional modeling to determine sarcastic content and provide a baseline system to be extended towards multimodal, cross-lingual, and explainable systems to predict sarcastic content.

title: Federated Transformer Graphs for Secure Multisite Predictive Maintenance Across Industrial Sensor Networks
authors: Omar Isam Al Mrayat, Jatinder Kaur, Rajib Guha Thakurta, Mukesh Soni, Javlonbek Kurbonov, Mansi Ankur Trivedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study introduces Federated Transformer Graphs (FTG), a framework for multisite predictive maintenance that protects user privacy and combines graph relational learning with temporal attention, enabled by industrial sensor networks. In addition, each node must know how to use transformer attention to duplicate long-range deterioration, how to document interactions between sensors using graph convolutions, and how to integrate multi-modal sensors in the local area. Even if there isn't a central place to store raw data, a fusion block can nevertheless make predictive representations. A secure federated layer might use homomorphic encryption and differential privacy to aggregate changes made to many sites. This lets people work together while keeping their information secret. FTG can find faults and estimate RUL at once with multi-location benchmarks. With good time-series, graph, and table baselines, such an outcome is possible. FTG decreases the Miss@1% FA to 20.3% at the operational low-false-alarm threshold, which is a 9.6 percentage point improvement over the next best. It also has an AUPRC value of 0.873 and a classification AUROC rating of 0.962. The MAE and RMSE drop to 5.3 and 8.3, respectively, because of FTG. It makes the probability more accurate (Pinball <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tau=0.9= 4.2$</tex>) and makes sure that uncertainty is distributed out evenly (Coverage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.93$</tex> with small gaps). This results in an approach that is both effective and secure for Industry 4.0. Inference operates on a millisecond scale; therefore, the procedure is still accurate even if the distribution changes.

title: Comparison of Performance of Virtual and Non-virtual Machine Using Geekbench 6
authors: Marek Durana, Miroslav Kvassay
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Virtualization is a foundational technology in modern IT infrastructure, enabling efficient resource utilization and flexible system management. This paper compares the performance of virtual machines (VMs) and bare-metal (non-virtualized) systems using Geekbench 6 on a Linux platform with KVM and Proxmox. We systematically benchmarked single-core and multi-core performance across various VM configurations and resource allocations. Our results indicate that single-core performance in VMs is consistently lower than on bare metal, with multi-core workloads experiencing further degradation as VM count increases. These findings highlight the importance of careful resource allocation and monitoring in virtualized environments and provide a baseline for developing more efficient dynamic scaling algorithms for Linux-based virtualization. In our tests, running a virtual machine (VM) with all 12 CPU cores and 24 GB RAM achieved a multi-core Geekbench 6 score of 4757, while the bare-metal (host) system scored 8057. This means the VM was about $41 \%$ slower (or, had a $41 \%$ performance overhead) compared to the host. When running 8 VMs in parallel (each with 2 CPU cores and 4 GB RAM), the total combined score was 7149, which is about 89% of the bare-metal score.

title: Segmentation of Student Stress Levels Using Gaussian Mixture Models
authors: Yudha Islami Sulistya, Maie Istighosah, Nisrina Hanifa Setiono, Laila Ramadhani Putri, Ahmad Uffi Lestari Ma’ruf
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: Student stress is a multidimensional phenomenon that influences academic performance, psychological well-being, and social functioning. This study segments stress levels among students using a probabilistic clustering approach based on Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM). A dataset of 1,100 student records with 20 features across psychological, physiological, environmental, academic, and social domains was preprocessed, standardized, and reduced via Principal Component Analysis (PCA), retaining 16 components that explained 95.6% of the total variance. GMM clustering was tested across configurations, with model selection guided by Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) and Akaike Information Criterion (AIC). The optimal solution was achieved with four clusters and a full covariance type (BIC = 20,001.18; AIC = 17,904.89). The resulting clusters were interpreted as Social Stress (Mixed) (Cluster 0), Psychological Distress (Cluster 1), Resilient / Low Stress (Cluster 2), and Physiological Stress (Mixed) (Cluster 3). Distribution across clusters was balanced, with three groups of about 300 students and one group of approximately 200. Validation results confirmed strong performance, with an Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) of 0.7102, Normalized Mutual Information (NMI) of 0.7280, and a Silhouette Score of 0.4867, reflecting good alignment with labels and clear inter-cluster separation. Visualization of clusters in reduced PCA space further demonstrated that GMM successfully identified distinct subgroup structures. These findings highlight the potential of combining PCA with GMM to uncover nuanced stress patterns, providing valuable insights for targeted academic and mental health interventions.

title: Bird Sound Classification Using Two-Channel Markov Transition Field Transformation Images and Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Tricia Jonina B. Alcisto, William Caleb Arcena Perez, Angie M. Ceniza-Canillo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: Bird sounds are a rich source of information that can significantly enhance our understanding of avian biodiversity, behavior, and their ecological roles. Ornithological research is driven by the need to understand avian biodiversity and their ecological dynamics. It relies heavily on accurate identifications and analysis of bird sounds. The manual analysis of bird songs is time-consuming and is prone to human errors, limiting the scope and efficiency of research efforts. Despite these problems, research efforts and technological advancement has made it possible to automate the process of species classification based on their sound. This study presents a novel approach for automated bird sound classification using Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients combined with Spectral Contrast, creating a two-channel MTF image representation processed through a CNN model. This approach captures both timbral and harmonic characteristics in a unified image representation. Ten bird species were studied and will be classified: (1) barn swallow, (2) Eurasian coot, (3) Gray Heron, (4) Gray-Headed Canary Flycatcher, (5) Kentish Plover, (6) Large-Billed Crow, (7) Purple Heron, (8) Rock Pigeon, (9) Whiskered Tern, and (10) Wood Sandpiper. Each species represents a mix of habitats. Each gathered from BirdCLEF 2024 data set, a large-scale benchmark for bird sound classification. The model's performance resulted in an 89.9% score in the accuracy metric, 89.5% in precision, 88.9% in recall, and lastly 89.2% for the F1-score. The approach outperformed its ablation study with a performance gain of approximately 4%, and 3.6% over the baseline approach.

title: Optimizing Cloud Migration: A Case Study Approach to Application Modernization
authors: Tapsi Nagpal, Shiv Kumar, Vijay Mohan Shrimal, Girish Paliwal, Kanta Prasad Sharma, Raghav Mehra
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: One of the most basic but important problems faced by websites or applications is sudden increases in user traffic. The main ideology of this project is to reduce the traffic issues over these websites or applications. To reduce the workload over a particular server, we have created multiple servers and divided microservices over them so that, whenever the load increases over the main server, the extra load can be transferred to other servers. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a Secure Cloud Migration Strategy (SCMS) that combines step-by-step migration planning, microservice-based restructuring, and built-in security practices. The framework distributes applications across multiple servers, applies load balancing, and continuously monitors performance. This design reduces latency, prevents traffic slowdowns, and improves overall system scalability.

title: Face Recognition Attendance System for Examination Settings in University
authors: Hazlina Haron, Ruffinus Rusell Anak Magar, Chang Ke Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: The exponential growth of digital technologies has redefined how higher education institutions manage administrative processes, including student attendance. Traditional attendance-taking during examinations is a time-consuming task, vulnerable to impersonation, human error, and inefficiency. This study presents the design, development, and evaluation of a Face Recognition Attendance System (FRAS) that leverages mobile computing and artificial intelligence to automate attendance tracking in examination environments. The system combines a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) deployed through TensorFlow Lite and Firebase for secure cloud synchronization. Using the Agile development framework, the project was iteratively tested across multiple university examination sessions. Experimental results demonstrate an average recognition accuracy of 95.4% under normal lighting conditions, along with a $70 \%$ reduction in total attendance processing time compared to manual procedures. The proposed FRAS model demonstrates practicality, reliability, and scalability, making it suitable for future integration with institutional digital ecosystems. This paper contributes a validated model for biometric attendance in academic settings. Specifically, the system offers a solution that achieves near-perfect identity verification ($\gt98 \%$) in realtime, a framework that is scalable across diverse examination venues and integrates seamlessly with existing university databases. A comprehensive discussion on the ethical and data security implications is also provided, offering a blueprint for compliant deployment.

title: Color Space Effects on Visual Feature Learning in Breast Cancer Detection
authors: Mohammed Abdulla Salim Al Husaini, Mohamed Hadi Habaebi, Yousuf Nasser Al Husaini, Rawad Abdulghafor, Mohammad Abrar
abstract: Breast cancer remains a critical health concern globally, and early detection is vital for improving patient outcomes. This study explores the effectiveness of deep learning for breast cancer detection using thermal images processed through various color spaces. A modified Inception MV4 architecture was employed for classification, leveraging reduced network complexity to enhance speed and efficiency. The methodology involved training on the DMR dataset, comprising 1,800 thermal images, and evaluating performance across ten color schemes, including RGB, LAB, YCbCr, and CYMK. Results showed that the CYMK color scheme achieved the highest validation accuracy (98.18%) and the lowest validation loss (0.0598), with the shortest training time (3.01s per epoch). LAB and YCbCr also demonstrated strong performance, while grayscale and XYZ schemes lagged. This work confirms that color space optimization can significantly impact deep learning performance. Future work will investigate multi-color space fusion strategies and real-time deployment for clinical decision support systems.

title: GoodBot: The Engineering and Computer Science Student's Best Friend
authors: Otávio Lube dos Santos, Davidson Cury, Pedro David Netto Silveira, Wagner De Andrade Perim, Jadson Do Prado Rafalski
abstract: This research-to-practice paper investigates how the mental health of undergraduate engineering and computer science students affects academic performance, highlighting the development of a chatbot named GoodBot as a comprehensive solution for mental health assessment, psychological support, and crisis alerts. The study emphasizes the crucial role mental well-being plays in academic success, examining how stress, anxiety, depression, and self-esteem influence learning and performance. A key contribution is the detailed presentation of GoodBot's development stages. Designed not only to assess students' mental states, GoodBot provides supervised psychological guidance, offering resources and personalized strategies to manage stress and emotional difficulties. Additionally, the chatbot alerts faculty and institutions to critical situations, such as students experiencing mental health crises, facilitating prompt intervention and support. The paper reviews studies advocating proactive mental health strategies for university students, positioning GoodBot as a versatile complement to traditional counseling services. Preliminary results, including usage statistics from engineering and computer science students, demonstrate GoodBot's effectiveness as an emotional support tool. Finally, the paper stresses the importance of integrated, preventive measures for student mental health, proposing solutions like GoodBot in combination with clear institutional policies to foster healthier, inclusive learning environments. Ethical considerations regarding GoodBot's implementation, particularly concerning sensitive data security and privacy, are also addressed.

title: A Choose-Your-Own-Adventure Game Using Branching Path Implemented By Fuzzy Logic
authors: Muhammad Ariff Armani Ruslan, Nur Azima Alya Binti Narawi, Norizan Mat Diah, Norsafinar Rahim, Nor Ashikin Mohamad Kamal
abstract: This research looks at the design and development of a narrative driven Choose-Your-Own-Adventure game using networked branching path implemented by fuzzy logic. Since linear storytelling fails to keep players engaged, this research fills the gap by implementing dynamic and interactive storytelling approaches that encourage higher user interaction. Previous research has confirmed that Choose-Your-Own-Adventure games help user engagement, critical thinking, and cognitive advancement. This research aims to develop on these findings by looking into how fuzzy logic provide dynamic outcomes that helps increase player immersion through providing different consequences for player choices rather than relying on predetermined consequences. This research advances the understanding of how networked branching along with fuzzy logic can be used to create games that improve decision-making skills while improving player engagement.

title: How Mentors Benefit from a STEM-Based eMentoring Program
authors: Cameron D. Denson, Niloufar Bayati, Jameelah Hayes
abstract: The following full research paper provides the results of a mixed-method study that examined the benefits of a STEM-based eMentoring experience for underrepresented student mentors. The eSTEM program engages underrepresented students in engineering-related experiences supported by near-peer relationships with college mentors of similar backgrounds, experiences, and interests to bolster students' STEM identity. eSTEM relies on an innovative research-based four-pronged mentoring protocol [1]. Using a mixed-method research methodology this paper reports on the benefits of the eSTEM program for mentors guided by the following research questions; (a) Does participation in the mentoring program result in improved outcomes for mentors?, and (b) What factors did mentors report as influential to the mentoring experience? Results from the study provided evidence that eMentoring can have positive personal, professional and educational impacts on the mentors. Our findings also provided insight into program elements that facilitate successful implementation of an eMentoring program from the mentors' perspective.

title: Epistemic Learning Through Work Placements: Boundary Crossing, and Tools as Boundary Objects
authors: Maartje Van den Bogaard, Johannes Strobel, Yezenia Marquez, America Rodriguez
abstract: This paper explores the role of tools as boundary objects in engineering co-op experiences, examining how students navigate between academic and workplace environments. Drawing on qualitative interviews with 23 engineering students who completed workplace placements, the study investigates students' development of epistemic beliefs about professional practices and tools. The research identifies software packages like Excel, MATLAB, and CAD programs as significant boundary objects that both connect and highlight differences between educational and professional settings. While these tools provide continuity between environments, students encounter significant discontinuities in their application, required proficiency levels, and integration into workflows. The study applies Akkerman and Bakker's four boundary-crossing mechanisms—identification, coordination, reflection, and transformation—to analyze how students leverage these tools to develop professional identities and adapt to workplace cultures. Findings reveal that students experience a substantial gap between academic preparation and industry expectations, particularly regarding software proficiency. In academic settings, students typically learn basic functionality, while industry demands advanced usage and integration with other systems to solve complex, real-world problems under financial, safety, and time constraints. The research suggests engineering education could better prepare students for workplace transitions by emphasizing adaptability across software platforms, advanced applications, and authentic problem-solving that more closely mirrors professional practice. This study contributes to understanding how boundary objects facilitate epistemic learning in engineering education and professional development.

title: Affordance RAG: Hierarchical Multimodal Retrieval with Affordance-Aware Embodied Memory for Mobile Manipulation_supp1-3653281.mp4
authors: Ryosuke Korekata
abstract: In this study, we address the problem of openvocabulary mobile manipulation, where a robot is required to carry a wide range of objects to receptacles based on freeform natural language instructions. This task is challenging, as it involves understanding visual semantics and the affordance of manipulation actions. To tackle these challenges, we propose Affordance RAG, a zero-shot hierarchical multimodal retrieval framework that constructs Affordance-Aware Embodied Memory from pre-explored images. The model retrieves candidate targets based on regional and visual semantics and reranks them with affordance scores, allowing the robot to identify manipulation options that are likely to be executable in real-world environments. Our method outperformed existing approaches in retrieval performance for mobile manipulation instruction in large-scale indoor environments. Furthermore, in real-world experiments where the robot performed mobile manipulation in indoor environments based on free-form instructions, the proposed method achieved a task success rate of 85%, outperforming existing methods in both retrieval performance and overall task success.

title: Meta-FL EHR- Intelligent and Federated System for Transmission of Electronic Health Records
authors: Lakshmaiya N, Sudhakar Reddy Kota, Premkumar Dhanasekar, S. Kaliappan, Anand Rajendran
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: A Patient's health record helps track the patient's health condition from historical conditions to the present. This requires storing the patient's health data, which involves collecting and processing various types of data. The data obtained from the patient needs to be stored and analysed for future purposes. In the process of sharing the patient data, the centralised system suffers from data integrity and security issues. Federated approaches are widely adopted for sharing patient information without the need for actual patient data to be transferred. In Federated learning, conventional approaches follow normal mathematical operations during the aggregation process, where fairness in adaptation is often compromised in these systems. The Meta Learning FL model effectively aggregates patient data by allocating weights to local updates based on pre-trained models. This improves the fairness and generalisation among the patient data, where the accuracy of the proposed work attained 85 % which shows an improvement of 10 % compared to the conventional FedAVG model using the MIMIC III dataset from Kaggle.
