title: Advanced Deep Learning Architectures for Enhanced Predictive Accuracy in Decentralized Blockchain-Based Risk Mitigation
authors: Shikhar Verma, K.P. Harshavardhan, Sukhman Ghumman, P. Kavipriya, Shankargouda Lakkangoudr, Swetha Appaji Parivara
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In an age characterized by intelligent distributed systems, achieving proactive risk reduction by precise predictive modeling is a significant problem. This study introduces a unique methodology—Blockchain-Integrated Transformer Ensemble Framework (BiTE-F)—that combines sophisticated deep learning algorithms with decentralised blockchain systems to improve forecast accuracy and reliability in dynamic contexts. The proposed architecture utilizes an ensemble of Transformer-based models, trained local on node-specific data using federated learning methodologies, permit situational and domain-aware prediction avoiding the need for central data aggregating. To ensure data integrity, facilitate model transparency and provide tampering obstruction, BiTE-F incorporates an encrypted blockchain layer that documents hashing snapshot of training datasets, model revisions, and predictions records. A decentralized agreement technique, Proof-of-Model-Integrity (PoMI), guarantees the acceptance of only correct and reliable modeling their contributions into the global ensembles. Moreover, smart contracts are used for automating the creation of risk alerts and the corresponding mitigation solutions in real time. This collaborative integration enhances distributed systems with safe, transparent, and precise risk modeling capacities. The suggested approach is especially appropriate for sectors such as healthcare, financial services, industrial IoT, and cyber-physical systems, where trust, precision, and real-time insights are critical. The suggested BiTE-F framework had an overall accuracy of 98.6% in predicting performance.

title: Design Considerations of Microstrip-Based Ku-Band Satellite Communication Phased Arrays: Causes and Mitigation of Gain Degradation in Wide-Angle Beam Steering
authors: Maria Muraveva, Ivan A. Illarionov, Andrey V. Mozharovskiy, Mikhail Dudkin
publish: 2025 Antennas Design and Measurement International Conference (ADMInC)
abstract: This paper presents a study of the excitation and propagation mechanisms of surface waves in the structure of a wideband microstrip phased array antenna (PAA) designed for circular polarization in Ku-band satellite communication systems (SatCom). Surface waves lead to the emergence of blind angles during wide-angle beam steering (exceeding 120°). The study briefly outlines the architecture of a printed-circuit antenna element, highlights key topological challenges in implementing cavity structure, and provides experimental results of the PAA’s scanning performance. The primary causes of gain degradation in such arrays during wideband frequency operation and wide-angle scanning are identified, including reduced radiation efficiency and the appearance of blindness dip in scan element pattern. Special emphasis is placed on engineering design methodologies to mitigate these effects in centimeter-wavelength microstrip PAAs, including arrays employing sequential rotation technique (SRT) for element excitation.

title: Multimodal Situation-aware Data Generation for Activity Recognition in Intelligent Wearable Systems
authors: Giuseppe D’Aniello, Lidia Fotia, Matteo Gaeta, Zia Ur Rehman
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Traditional Human activity recognition approaches mainly focus on activity recognition from sensor signals, overlooking the situational and contextual understanding crucial for human-like reasoning. To address this gap, we propose a situation-aware synthetic data generation architecture for wearable computing systems, extending our previous SA-WCS architecture. Our architecture introduces a generative module capable of synthesizing realistic multimodal data, combining sensor signals and contextual information, conditioned on highlevel situations. By leveraging conditional generative models such as CVAE, CGAN, Diffusion Models, we generate situationrich synthetic data that improve model generalization, addresses data scarcity, and improves robustness for situation recognition tasks. Experiments on the Extrasensory dataset demonstrate that models trained with our synthetic data achieve a $4.34 \%$ improvement in accuracy and $11 \%$ gain in balanced accuracy over baselines. Unlike previous HAR data augmentation methods that generate only sensor signals, the proposed approach explicitly integrates situation awareness during generation, supporting more intelligent, context-aware wearable systems.

title: Wideband Dual-polarization 1×3 Subarray for Active Antenna Systems MIMO of Base Stations 5G
authors: M. R. Kirillova, S. S. Churkin, Ivan A. Illarionov, Evgeniy L. Varentsov, Alexandra A. Dudnikova, Andrey V. Mozharovskiy
publish: 2025 Antennas Design and Measurement International Conference (ADMInC)
abstract: This paper presents a 1×3 wideband antenna subarray dedicated for in a transceiver radio unit with an integrated antenna (Active Antenna System, AAS) of modern mobile communication systems M-MIMO 5G NR (New Radio). The antenna element of the subarray is a dual-polarization (±45o slant linear polarization) dipole radiator based on a vertically oriented crossed printed circuit boards (PCBs). A specific 1:3 feeding system has been developed that combines the power from the antenna elements. The dimensions of the antenna subarray are 0.5λ×2.1λ×0.4λ. The antenna subarray return loss level is 20 dB. The antenna gain is about 11 dBi, and the crosstalk discrimination of the far-field radiation is less than −25 dB in the operating frequency range of 3.3–3.8 GHz (n78 band). The relative bandwidth of operating frequencies is 50% at a level of 10 dB return loss (RL). The main lobe radiation pattern half-power beamwidth is 32.5° in the vertical plane and 98° in the horizontal plane. The side lobe level is not exceeding 13 dB. To reduce the mutual coupling between the antenna elements within the subarray, additional metal walls were used. They are realized on printed circuit boards (PCBs). These walls allow obtaining a port-to-port isolation level of 25 dB and cross coupling levels between adjacent subarrays of at least 20 dB when combining several subarrays into an antenna array. In addition, the antenna subarray prototypes were manufactured and tested. The measurement results of the produced prototypes confirmed the simulation results.

title: Toward Resilient IoT-Based Communication Architectures for Disaster Response
authors: Luciano Miuccio, Daniela Panno, Salvatore Riolo, Corrado Santoro, Federico Fausto Santoro
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: The increasing frequency and intensity of natural disasters, driven by climate change, underscore the crucial role of communication systems in modern emergency management. Unlike energy infrastructures, which have advanced toward greater autonomy and resilience, traditional communication networks remain highly centralized, rigid, and dependent on fixed power sources, making them particularly vulnerable during crises. These limitations hinder their adaptability and reliability in disaster scenarios. To address these challenges, recent efforts have focused on rethinking emergency communication architectures by leveraging heterogeneous technologies such as Mobile Base Stations (BSs), Low-Power Wide-Area Networks (LPWANs) for Internet of Things (IoT) connectivity, and satellite communications. These innovations enable the creation of dynamic, reconfigurable architectures capable of adapting to rapidly changing conditions in real time. However, enabling such flexibility requires more than new architectures. Indeed, it demands intelligent, secure, scalable, and real-time operational strategies. To this end, in this paper, we propose a forward-looking vision for emergency communication infrastructures that integrates both existing and emerging network entities. We examine the specific communication-related challenges posed by disaster scenarios and advocate for the adoption of innovative architectures to support timely, informed responses. Finally, we outline future research directions aimed at embedding emerging technologies into these architectures to enhance the capabilities of nextgeneration emergency communication systems.

title: Application of Quantum Computers to Study the Dative Bond Between Pyridine Molecule and Lithium Ion
authors: Fatemeh Ghasemi, Yukio Kawashima, Kyungsun Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Hybrid quantum-classical algorithms offer a promising pathway to address computational challenges in domains such as chemistry, physics, and materials science. In this work, we present a hybrid embedding framework to simulate the dative interaction between a lithium ion and a pyridine molecule. This represents the first implementation of quantum hardware for evaluating the binding energy of a non-covalent dative-bonded complex. Due to the current limitations of classical simulators and noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices—typically restricted to circuits with a few dozen qubits—we employ an embedding strategy where a chemically active region is treated on a quantum processor, and the remainder is modeled classically. Without error mitigation, results from quantum hardware show notable deviations from exact energies. To address this, we implement two combined error mitigation strategies, CEM1 and CEM2, both of which significantly improve total energy estimates. This work highlights the practical potential of variational quantum algorithms for studying complex molecular systems relevant to catalysis, hydrogen storage, and battery technologies.

title: Prediction of Vector Borne Diseases Using Machine Learning Models Based on Environmental and Clinical Data
authors: Santhiya S, Senthil Kumar S, Praveen Kumar R, Rohith V, Vinothini K, Sathishkumar V E
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Delayed detection and ineffective treatment are the main reasons why mosquito-borne illnesses like dengue fever and malaria have become a major obstacle to health advancement in tropical areas. In order to predict vector-borne diseases by examining environmental and clinical characteristics, the proposed work assesses five machine learning models: Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Means clustering, Random Forest, Naive Bayes, and K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN). These models are trained and tested in the study using a labelled dataset from certain geographic locations. Oversampling techniques are used to guarantee a balanced class distribution in order to address the problem of imbalanced datasets. With an 89% prediction accuracy, the SVM model outperforms K-Means clustering (86%), Random Forest (67%), Naive Bayes (64%), and KNN (30%). Early vector-borne infection prediction is made easier by the SVM-based model's incorporation of clinical and environmental variables. The results of the trial demonstrate the strategy can save time and money by allowing medical professionals to take preventative action before crises occur. A thorough assessment of the models' performance is provided by a detailed examination of recall, precision, and F1-score.

title: Targeted Augmentation for Imbalanced Dashcam-Based Road Crack Detection Using RT-DETR
authors: Abdul Moiz Qarni, Gul Muhammad Khan, Abdul Rafay Qarni
abstract: Road crack detection using dashcam footage poses significant challenges, primarily due to the strong class imbalance between crack and non-crack images. Standard augmentation techniques typically apply transformations uniformly across all images, which does not effectively address this imbalance. In this paper, we propose a targeted augmentation strategy that applies transformations only to crack-positive images, while leaving background images unchanged. When combined with RT-DETR (Real-Time Detection Transformer) for instance segmentation, our approach improves the class balance by a factor of five (from 17.1:1 to 3.4:1) and achieves higher detection accuracy compared to conventional augmentation methods. We evaluate the proposed method on a custom dashcam dataset of 5,678 images and present a detailed analysis of the augmentation process, training procedure, and performance results. This work demonstrates the potential of targeted augmentation for real-time crack detection, geospatial road mapping, and driver assistance applications.

title: Secure protection of 3D content through reversible geometric deformation
authors: Khélian Larvet, Jean-Pierre Pedeboy, William Puech
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: The widespread use of 3D objects in many fields poses new challenges for their secure transmission, storage and visualization. While selective encryption methods allow format compliance and enable adjustable security by selectively encrypting 3D geometry, they produce visible noise and disrupt geometric coherence which reduces compression efficiency. In this paper, we propose a reversible deformation method for 3D object protection that breaks with state-of-the-art 3D security approaches by offering more natural and visually coherent protection. The deformation is applied directly to the geometry, controlled by a secret key, and can be adjusted to achieve the desired level of visual security. Experimental results presented on a large database demonstrate that our method offers protection comparable to selective encryption, while providing significantly greater resilience to reconstruction attacks such as Laplacian smoothing, particularly at low security levels where selective encryption is more vulnerable. This work introduces a new direction for format-compliant 3D object protection, designed for secure visualization in untrusted environments.

title: Data-independent Beamforming for End-to-end Multichannel Multi-speaker ASR
authors: Can Cui, Paul Magron, Mostafa Sadeghi, Emmanuel Vincent
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) in multichannel, multi-speaker scenarios remains challenging due to ambient noise, reverberation and overlapping speakers. In this paper, we propose a beamforming approach that processes specific angular sectors based on their spherical polar coordinates before applying an end-to-end multichannel, multi-speaker ASR system. This method is data-independent and training-free. We demonstrate that using a group of beamformed signals improves ASR performance compared to using the same number of raw microphone signals. Moreover, increasing the number of signals used for beamforming further enhances recognition accuracy, leading to a more efficient use of multichannel signals while reducing the overall input load for the ASR system. We conduct experiments on the AMI meeting corpus, where the proposed method reduces word error rate by up to 11% and improves speaker counting accuracy by up to 27% relative compared to a multichannel ASR baseline system that does not exploit beamforming.

title: Development of an Intelligent and Visualized Substation Operation and Maintenance System Based on a 3D Digital Platform
authors: Cheng Chen, Hua Tan, Hong Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: The application of a 3D digital platform in the construction of intelligent visualization operation and maintenance (O&M) systems for substations enables the use of modern technological tools to digitally manage substation equipment and infrastructure. Information and data generated throughout various stages can be acquired in real time and analyzed to provide a reliable basis for system development, thereby enhancing the reliability and safety of system operation and maintenance. Furthermore, with the active involvement of specialized O&M personnel, and the integration of big data analytic and intelligent algorithms, the efficiency of operations and the accuracy of decision-making are significantly improved.

title: A Systematic Literature Review of Sentiment Analysis: Growth, Modalities and Techniques
authors: Nisha, Sumit Mittal
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Sentiment analysis has gained interest amongst researchers in the past few years. It is a crucial area that can be applied in the fields of natural language processing (NLP), Affective computing, and the detection of emotions and opinions from humangenerated data. Starting from text-based sentiment analysis, recent advancements have emerged into the multi-modal domains, including speech, videos, facial expressions, and physiological signals like Electroencephalography (EEG), Electrocardiogram (ECG) for sentiment analysis. The systematic review provides the number of publications in the field of sentiment analysis, as well as a literature survey from 2015 to 2025. This article presented the various datasets available, methodologies used, and their performance in terms of accuracy to find the sentiments. We also mentioned the various approaches used for sentiment analysis using different modalities. Finally, the review identifies research gaps, the need for multidomain sentiment models, and the future directions for working in robust and more efficient sentiment analysis.

title: A Teleoperation System of Shallot Watering Robot for Precision Farming
authors: Nurul Zainal Fanani, Yeni Cahyani, Yoga Pradana Putra, Lukman Hakim, Adri Gabriel Sooai, Ika Widiastuti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Teleoperation technology in agriculture offers a practical solution to reduce physical labor and improve efficiency. This study presents the design and implementation of a teleoperated shallot-watering robot using a radio frequency (RF)-based remote system. Compared to Bluetooth or IoTbased methods, RF provides longer range and greater stability in low-signal rural environments, making it more suitable for open-field farming. The robot employs servo motors for throttle and steering control, enabling responsive irrigation operation. Experiments evaluated control range and mobility under different throttle and pusher pipe settings. Results show the robot reached a maximum speed of $0.1814 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and maintained stable control beyond 140 meters, proving its robustness for medium-scale farmland. This work supports precision farming by lowering manpower needs, enabling flexible irrigation scheduling, and offering a cost-effective platform with potential for future IoT integration in smart farming systems.

title: AI Based Pattern Detection for Fighter's Aircraft
authors: P. Jayadharshini, C. Vasuki, S. Santhiya, S. Fowjiya, A. Nithyasri, K. B. Sri Sathya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Aircraft identification is a critical function in aviation safety; however, identification errors or delayed detection of aircraft patterns run a high level of risk. Traditional surveillance platforms cannot identify civil or military airplanes frequently due to camouflage patterns during complicated situations. Hence, this paper is advancing a cutting-edge solution based on real-time reliable detection of aircraft patterns through the YOLOv8 neural network architecture. A rich dataset is constructed to train the model, and an easy-to-use web application is created to support real-time analysis. The users can upload images and enter relevant information, and the system can return quick identification results. This proposed method follows an accurate and efficient approach for gathering datasets, training, validating, and deploying the model. Test results indicate that the use of YOLOv8-based models increases detection accuracy and reduces cases of misidentification which augments countermeasures of aviation security. The approach provides a dependable and efficient solution for real-time identification of airplanes which has tangible applications in airspace surveillance and security management.

title: LipTalk: Deployable Context-Aware LipTalk for Clinical Communication
authors: Nirase Fathima Abubacker, Cindy Koh Xin Yi, Md Baharul Islam
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Patients who cannot vocalize often struggle to convey symptoms during clinical encounters, increasing the risk of misunderstanding and delayed care. We present LipTalk, a mobile system that combines LipTalk (visual speech recognition) with facial-expression analysis to support patient/clinician communication. The pipeline couples a 3DCNN/BiLSTM lipreader with CTC decoding and a lightweight 2DCNN affect classifier, deployed via an Android client with server-side inference. On the publicly available datasets, our LipTalk achieves 54.8% character accuracy (CAR), 22.9% character error rate (CER), 55.6% word accuracy (WAR), and 46.2% word error rate (WER); the affect module reaches 64.1% test accuracy. A simple context-aware re-ranking yields a +2.3pp gain in WAR over lip-only decoding. Prototype tests indicate sub-second end-to-end latency for short utterances, suggesting feasibility for bedside use while motivating clinical data collection and broader evaluation.

title: Application of DLNM Framework to Analyze PM2.5 Impact on Respiratory Mortality with COVID-19 Effect Modification
authors: Mengtong Xia, Md Maruf Hasan, Ning Xin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Fine particulate matter (PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf>) poses significant health risks and environmental quality risks. Despite advances in research, the temporal patterns and nonlinear characteristics of its health effects are still not fully understood. Traditional analytical methods often fail to capture the complex and dynamic nature of changing environmental conditions. This study applies distributed lag nonlinear models (DLNMs) to examine the relationship between PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> exposure and respiratory mortality in California from 2014 to 2023, focusing on changes during the COVID-19 pandemic. DLNMs use flexible statistical techniques, including Bsplines for the exposure dimension and natural splines for the lag dimension, allowing the model to capture both nonlinear exposureresponse relationships and temporal dependencies. The results reveal a nonlinear, U-shaped exposure-response curve, with the lowest relative risk observed at PM 2.5 concentrations of $20-22 \mu \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$, and a sharp increase in risk at higher concentrations. Notably, the correlation between PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> and health outcomes differed before and during the pandemic. Before the pandemic, there was a significant positive association (relative risk $\mathbf{R R} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1 . 1 8 9}$; $\mathbf{9 5 \%}$ confidence interval [CI]: $\mathbf{1 . 1 7 8}-\mathbf{1 . 1 9 9}$ per $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{g} / \mathbf{m}^{\mathbf{3}}$ increase). However, during the pandemic, the association was much weaker $(R R=1.006; 95 \% \mathrm{CI}: 0.991-1.021)$, representing a $15.4 \%$ reduction. These findings provide crucial evidence for developing adaptive air quality management strategies and emphasize the need to conduct environmental health risk assessments tailored to local conditions.

title: TGRU-Net: Transformer Ghost Residual U-Net for Automatic Building Detection from High-Resolution Satellite Images
authors: Heri Prasetyo, Abrar Dwi Fairuz Nadhif, Muhammad Anang Fathur Rohman, Abid Ammar Mahdy, Hafidh Muhammad Akbar, Chih-Hsien Hsia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: Building detection is still an important issue in various urban applications such as urban planning, infrastructure development, and so on. In building detection there will be difficulties if it is done using traditional methods because many buildings are made of similar raw materials, so a more sophisticated method is needed to detect buildings automatically. Advances in technology have led to more sophisticated methods that can be implemented, one of which is a neural network that can be used for automatic building detection. However, neural networks require a large enough memory because the number of parameters is quite large. Based on these problems, the Transformer Ghost Residual U-Net (TGRU-Net) architecture is proposed for automatic building detection from high-resolution satellite imagery from the Massachusetts Building Dataset. The proposed method is based on U-Net using Residual Network, Vision Transformer, and Ghost Bottleneck. The proposed method will be trained using a training set and after training it will be tested using a test set. The test produces an F1-Score and IoU which will be compared with several previous methods. The proposed method produces better performance than the previous methods with an F1-Score of 85.26%, an IoU of 74.37%, and a parameter of 11.66 million.

title: Improving the Performance of Wavelet Transform Optimization using Inequality Constraints
authors: Daria Koshutina, Galina Shcherbakova, Svitlana Antoshchuk, Maria Glava
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Optimization methods based on gradient estimation are widely used in automated control and diagnostic systems. However, due to the unsmooth surface and multimodality of the target functions, they have low noise immunity. Optimization methods with wavelet transform can increase noise immunity. However, previously developed methods of this type are characterized by low performance. Therefore, in this paper, we investigate an optimization method with a wavelet transform, which, by introducing second-order constraints and reducing the number of calls to the oracle for the values of the objective function, can improve the speed of searching for the optimum in important problems of the specified systems. An improvement of the optimization method using the wavelet transform with second-order constraints (in the form of inequalities) is presented. A justified reduction in the number of processing stages with a hyperbolic wavelet function can improve the efficiency of searching for the extremum of the objective function when solving classification problems.

title: The Effect of Social Media Influencers on Customer Repurchase Intention
authors: Howell Bernardi Salim, Putu Erick Ananda, Veronica Veronica, Erwin Halim
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This study examines the impact of influencers on consumer behavior, focusing on their role in driving repurchase intentions. While influencer marketing is widely used to promote businesses, its long-term effect on customer loyalty remains uncertain. The research aims to address this gap by analyzing the mechanisms linking influencer-driven promotions to repeat purchasing behavior. Data were collected from 440 Indonesian respondents between April and May 2025 using Google Forms and non-probability sampling, targeting individuals who had previously purchased products due to influencer promotions. Although participants were from various regions, the study emphasizes Indonesia’s growing reliance on social media in shaping consumer culture. Eleven hypotheses were tested, with ten showing statistical significance. Findings highlight the significant influence of emotional engagement and satisfaction in sustaining customer loyalty, suggesting that businesses leveraging influencer marketing should prioritize these factors to ensure lasting repurchase intentions and strengthen the effectiveness of influencer-driven strategies.

title: Neuro-insertion Concept of the Nuclear Reactor Digital Twin
authors: Yuliia Tarasich, Oleksandr Letychevskyi, Vladyslav Volkov
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Digital twins of nuclear reactors are critical for predicting and mitigating catastrophic events, yet existing solutions struggle with incomplete datasets and inaccurate predictions of critical states. This paper reviews the state-of-the-art in nuclear reactor digital twins, identifies key limitations, and proposes a novel neuro-insertion approach. By integrating neural networks with multi-level, multi-agent insertion modelling, this methodology enhances prediction accuracy and enables robust scenario analysis, even with limited data. The approach leverages algebraic behaviour modelling to simulate complex reactor interactions and neural networks to provide real-time event detection, addressing challenges such as false positives and critical event forecasting. We discuss its implementation potential and outline future research directions to advance nuclear safety and operational efficiency.

title: Explaining Mental Disorder Classification in Dialogues: Turn-Level Analysis and Label Dynamics
authors: Rini Wijayanti, Iftitahu Ni’Mah, Ekasari Nugraheni, Ana Heryana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: This study proposes a multi-turn dialogue-based approach to classify mental disorders in Indonesian, utilizing a pretrained BERT model and multi-CLS dialogue representations. Each [CLS] per turn is processed using an attentive pooling mechanism to generate a final prediction. As part of the explainability protocol, we analyze attention distributions, perform perturbation-based faithfulness tests (role-level ablation, turn-level leave-one-out, progressive context insertion), and evaluate label dynamics to trace label transitions between turns. The results show that explainability analysis provides critical insights into how models depend on various parts of conversations, with user utterances and the middle segments of conversations emerging as the most influential factors in determining classification decisions. This demonstrates that the proposed method supports both accurate and transparent decision-making in multi-turn dialogue models.

title: Efficient Optimization of User Costs in Microservice Deployment Through Distributed Column Generation
authors: Yuxiang Liu, Bo Yang, Kaili Huang, Sicheng Liu, Qi Liu, Xinping Guan
abstract: In microservice architecture, each industrial application is decomposed into multiple microservices and deployed on cloud servers to provide timely services to users. However, existing methods rarely optimize service deployment strategies from the user's perspective to reduce the leasing costs of cloud servers. Furthermore, accurately estimating the required number of instances and resource utilization for microservices remains challenging, and decision-making in large-scale scenarios also faces significant timeliness constraints. To solve this problem, this article proposes a Column Generation deployment strategy, which decomposes the microservice deployment problem into a master problem for scheme selection and subproblems for scheme generation and proves the gap between its convergent solution and the optimal solution. A Distributed Column Generation strategy is further introduced to enable efficient problem-solving. Experimental results based on real-world server pricing demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits a high degree of consistency with the theoretically optimal solution. Compared to the baseline methods, it reduces the average total cost of ownership (TCO) for users by 11.3%, while the decision-making time is only 21.5% of that of the comparative methods. At the same time we used our approach to make deployment decisions for real industrial microservices and deployed them on real cloud servers. Compared to the baseline approach, it reduces TCO by 4%, but decision-making is 97% faster.

title: Improving Zero-Shot Entity Linking with Chinese Feature Convolution Embeddings
authors: Jian Pan, Zhiwei Wu, Yanjun Li
abstract: Zero-shot entity linking (ZEL), a fundamental technique for many downstream natural language processing tasks, aims to accurately associate textual mentions with specific entities in a knowledge base. However, Chinese ZEL remains challenging due to the limited research on Chinese entity linking and emerging entities. The predominant two-stage model often overlooks the unique characteristics of Chinese, which limits its ability to capture a wider range of semantic information. To address this, we propose CFCE-ZEL, a ZEL model based on Chinese Feature Convolutional Embeddings (CFCE), which is built upon the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) architecture for contextualized representations and integrates a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for Chinese feature extraction. The model adopts a two-step framework that generates and ranks candidate entities to produce the final entity linking results. It further employs a convolutional neural network and integrates Chinese-specific feature embeddings at both image and character levels, namely glyph and radical embeddings, to enhance word representations and mitigate the impact of out-of-vocabulary words. Moreover, we employ FAISS and knowledge distillation to improve the efficiency of the two-stage model while maintaining a balance between speed and performance. Extensive experiments on the Hansel dataset show that CFCE-ZEL outperforms multiple baselines in both candidate entity generation and ranking, while maintaining high efficiency with FAISS and knowledge distillation.

title: A Novel Simpler GMRES Algorithm With Nonorthogonal Krylov Bases for Solving Electromagnetic Field Problems by MoM
authors: Xinyuan Cao, Xiangxiang Liu, Qi Qi, Chenghua Fan, Jian Liu, Xiaojing Kuang, Meng Kong, Zhongxiang Zhang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: Simpler generalized minimal residual (SGMRES) is a classic variant of the regular generalized minimal residual (GMRES) method that does not require upper Hessenberg factorization, which is applicable to solving matrix equations generated by the method of moments (MoMs). In this article, an accelerated technique by implementing the Gram–Schmidt process in a low-dimensional space is applied to improve the SGMRES algorithm, which can significantly reduce the elapsed CPU time. The analysis of the principle of the new algorithm is discussed in detail. Numerical experiments are reported to illustrate the performance and effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

authors: N/A

title: FractalSort: High Precision Compressed Radix Sort on FPGA
authors: Michael Dang’ana, Hans-Arno Jacobsen
abstract:
State-of-the-art large data set high-precision sorting algorithms typically use hardware-accelerated radix sort. Advances in Dynamic Random Access Memory, Flash and High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) have enabled faster bandwidth intensive merge operations, where distribution-dependent data pre-processing techniques such as stochastic sampling bucketing offer alternatives impacted by increased data passes and vulnerability to data skew.

This work addresses these limitations by introducing a compressed radix-sorting scheme for high-precision keys. Whereas radix sort histograms grow exponentially with precision, FractalSort guarantees bounded histogram size through the novel compression scheme which translates into smaller sorting circuits and reduced memory usage. Another key contribution is the novel optimized merge algorithm, which eliminates the need for data pre-processing and bucketing leading to higher bandwidth efficiency and reduced algorithm complexity. Using a tree-based recursive sorting architecture for space efficiency and low latency, the algorithm achieves fast sorting that exceeds the state-of-the-art on the CPU, FPGA, and GPU by 6x, 2.5x, and 3x bandwidth-adjusted throughput on 4GB to 2TB data sets. FractalSort is implemented on Xilinx Virtex UltraScale+ FPGA empirically demonstrating on-chip sorting at 20 Tb/s capable of memory-to-memory sorting of 32-bit keys at 3.2Tb/s using HBM.

title: WIP: Experiment Exploration in Computer Organization - Design a Computer for Running Software
authors: Shanshan Li, Ninghan Zheng, Yuchao Gao, Xiaojun Wu, Weidong Liu
abstract: This Research-to-Practice Work in Progress paper introduces the exploration on the experimental teaching of course Computer Organization. The course of Computer Organization mainly introduces the composition of the computer and how the computer works, that is to say, this course not only introduces the composition of the hardware, but also teaches how the software runs on the hardware. In the course teaching, especially in the experimental teaching, the design of a simple prototype computer system is the key point. We establish a series of experiments to form a computer system experiment, aiming at teaching students with a practice on basics of computer hardware and some of the related basic software. This paper focuses on the experimental teaching, from the course contents setting to experiments arrangement, to achieve an experimental teaching system. And this paper presents some key points for the experiments, and gives the experiment arrangement. In about ten years' trial, this experiment has gotten some positive result in teaching.

title: Repeated Measures Investigation of Self-Efficacy in Jonassen-Inspired Problem-Based Learning for Aerospace Engineering Students
authors: Sama Ghoreyshi, Andrew Olewnik, Scott Ferguson
abstract: This study examines how exposure to a problembased learning (PBL) environment influences undergraduate engineering students' self-efficacy in problem-solving. Conducted in an introductory aerospace engineering course redesigned according to Jonassen's design theory of problemsolving, the study followed students as they engaged with four ill-structured, complex problems, two single-week and two multi-week case analysis and selection problems. Using a quantitative design, we collected pre- and post-reflection survey data, including a Likert-scale item on self-efficacy, at multiple points throughout the course, resulting in ten self-reports per student. While overall analyses showed an increase in students' self-efficacy beliefs from pre-to-post course measurements, repeated measures revealed notable fluctuations across episodes, influenced by the specific context, expectations, difficulty, and level of support associated with each problem. These patterns suggest that although individual problems contributed to increased confidence, such gains were not fully stabilized or transferable to new contexts. The findings underscore the dynamic and context-sensitive nature of selfefficacy development in PBL settings and suggest that singular pre/post measures may overlook key moments of change. Sustained, transferable gains in self-efficacy may require repeated, long-term engagement with open-ended problems that vary in type, expectation, and support.

title: A Data Mining-Based Prototype for Predictive Mental Health Analytics in Schools
authors: Muhammad Habli Nasution, Sfenrianto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Globally, mental health disorders impact one in seven adolescents, with the Indonesia–National Adolescent Mental Health Survey (I-NAMHS) reporting Indonesia as 34.9% having at least one mental health issue. Concerns such as anxiety, depression, and stress affect academic performance among students. Although data mining has been utilized in mental health research, focused studies on younger school-aged populations are limited. This study addresses the gap by focusing on school-aged populations and developing a predictive model using the Cross-Industry Standard Process for Data Mining (CRISP-DM) framework. Unlike most existing work focused on university students, this model is tailored to early adolescents and demonstrates the potential for integration into school information systems. A dataset of 426 junior and senior high school students from a single institution with 16 attributes was used and evaluated across three scenarios: junior high, senior high, and combined datasets. The decision tree achieved the highest accuracy (91.59%) on junior high school dataset, while the random forest outperformed others on senior high school (95.07%) and combined datasets (95.28%). To demonstrate practical application, a prototype system was developed to integrate predictive analytics into school support structures. This prototype highlights the feasibility of deploying data mining for early detection of mental health risks in educational settings. The findings underscore the potential of predictive mental health analytics to support early detection efforts among school-aged students, thereby enhancing educational outcomes through targeted, data-driven interventions.

title: A Retrospective Study to Understand Student Coding Style Quality via Static Analysis
authors: Francisco T. S. S. Pereira, Roberto A. Bittencourt, Elaine H. T. Oliveira, David B. F. De Oliveira
abstract: This research full paper carries out an investigation of student code quality regarding coding style conventions with the support of static analyzers (SA). In programming courses, students need to learn both about code correctness and quality. Autograders have been used to support checking correctness of student code, but quality has mostly been ignored. SAs may be used to provide reports on code quality, such as checking whether students abide by coding standards and adequate coding style. Related work on student code quality in programming courses is scarce, especially in CS2 courses. The study analyzes a code dataset from 496 students from 10 different CS2 classes, and describes coding style issues both qualitatively and quantitatively. From prevalent style issues, we derived four metrics to summarize coding style problems related to formatting and naming identifiers. Then, we characterized student coding style to understand its relation with autograder student performance. Results provide more thorough understanding of student code quality regarding style, which may be useful to both researchers and instructors.

title: DVD-MapAL: Deep Visual Feature-Driven Map-Assisted Localization for Planetary Spacecraft Exploration.
authors: Xubo Luo, Zeyuan Zhao, Shengyang Zhang, Xue Wan, Wei Zhang, Leizheng Shu
abstract: Spacecraft autonomous localization is a fundamental capability for space missions, including rover planetary surface exploration, satellite on-orbit servicing and lander precision landing tasks. While conventional approaches predominantly depend on ground-based observatories, their lack of autonomy and scalability limits their applications in deep-space exploration tasks. This paper presents Deep Visual Feature-Driven Map-Assisted Localization (DVD-MapAL), a novel method that combines visual odometry with prior map constraints to establish a self-contained localization system. The proposed architecture introduces two key innovations: (1) a coordinate-constrained pose optimization module that dynamically corrects cumulative errors in visual odometry through geometric consistency verification, and (2) a lightweight deep feature descriptor with a spatial inhibition mechanism enabling robust projection estimation between orbital imagery and pre-existing maps. We release a comprehensive simulation dataset containing 11,721 photorealistic images with six-degree-of-freedom annotations, generated through Unreal Engine and AirSim platforms. Experimental evaluations demonstrate DVD-MapAL’s superior performance, achieving 23.64% lower mean positional error than ORB-SLAM3 in spacecraft scenarios. Further validation on real-world datasets reveals 17.89% improvement over conventional visual localization methods, particularly in feature-deprived extraterrestrial environments. The open-source implementation and benchmark dataset will be made publicly available.

title: MSHANet: A Multiscale Hybrid Attention Network for Motor Imagery EEG Decoding
authors: Yanlong Zhao, Dianguo Cao, Haoyang Yu, Guangjin Liang, Zhicheng Chen
abstract: Brain-computer interface (BCI) technology has significant applications in neuro rehabilitation and motor function restoration, especially for patients with stroke or spinal cord injury. Motor imagery electroencephalog-raphy (MI-EEG) is widely used in BCIs, but its nonlinear dynamics and inter-subject variability limit decoding accuracy. In this paper, a multiscale hybrid attention network (MSHANet) for MI-EEG decoding, which consists of spatiotemporal feature extraction (STFE), talking head self-attention (THSA), dynamic squeeze-and-excitation attention (DSEA), and a temporal convolutional network (TCN), is proposed. MSHANet was evaluated via within-subject experiments using BCI Competition IV Datasets 2a and 2b, as well as EEGMMID, achieving decoding accuracies of 83.56%, 89.75%, and 75.66%, respectively. In cross-subject experiments on the three datasets, the mode lattained accuracies of 69.93% on BCI-2a, 81.85% on BCI-2b, and 79.67% on EEGMMID. In addition, we propose an electrode spatial structure-aware encoder. This technique encodes the spatial positions of electrodes in the original data, enabling the model to obtain richer spatial electrode information at the input stage. In within-subject and cross-subject tasks on BCI-2a, this encoding improved the decoding performance by 2.83% and 2.91%, respectively. Visualization was also employed to elucidate feature distributions and the effec tiveness of its attention mechanisms. Experimental results demonstrate that MSHANet performs exceptionally well in MI-EEG decoding tasks and has high potential for clinical applications, particularly in neurorehabilitation and motor function reconstruction.

title: Disentangling the Effects of Different Big Data Analytics Skills on Firm Innovation
authors: Chuhan Cao, Wenjing Cai, Xiaowu Zhu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Big data analytics (BDA) has emerged as a transformative enabler of firm innovation, enabling organizations to extract insights from data and identify new business opportunities. While prior research has largely focused on the overall impact of BDA on innovation, limited attention has been given to how distinct BDA skill sets (i.e., technical and managerial) influence different types of innovation. Using survey data from 443 Chinese firms, our findings indicate that BDA technical skills primarily enhance exploitative innovation, while BDA managerial skills contribute to both exploratory and exploitative innovation. Additionally, the interaction between technical and managerial BDA skills fosters a synergistic effect, further strengthening a firm’s ability to facilitate ambidextrous innovation. This study contributes to the understanding of how BDA skill sets can be leveraged to drive firm innovation and ultimately enhance firm performance.

title: SmartHealth Grid: A GIS-Based System for Mapping and Allocating Medical Resources During Emergencies
authors: Rama Bansidhar Dan, Aishwarya Dubey, Challa Geya Akshatha, Kiran Bankapur, Sujal Malviya, Shubhi Srivastava
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: SmartHealth Grid aims to address the critical issue of time-taking processes delaying proper care during a medical emergency by integrating an online platform. In a time crucial emergency, patients can save time by not tediously contacting each hospital facility to ask for the availability of a certain equipment/doctor, instead they can directly access all the nearby hospitals along with relevant information like their distance, equipment etc. In case of an emergency where no time can be spared for searching, an SOS alert feature automatically calculates and calls the ambulance which will reach the fastest. While waiting for the ambulance, the patient can receive guided first- aid recommendations through a chatbot. Additionally, a blood donation portal is also provided where users can volunteer to donate or request a donation. This multifunctional system provides timely, informed and accessible information and ensures that it's never too late for proper care.

title: Beaver: Estimating Future Risks at Scale in Real-World Deployments
authors: Marco Balduzzi, Roel Reyes, Jessica Balaquit, Ryan Flores
publish: 2025 APWG Symposium on Electronic Crime Research (eCrime)
abstract: Malware continues to pose a significant threat to organizations worldwide, with various forms of malicious software enabling criminal activities. To protect against these threats, security solutions such as anti-malware and intrusion-detection-systems have been introduced over the years. However, while these solutions work well, especially when combined, they tend to detect attacks only when they are already happening. In this paper, we adopt a proactive strategy aimed at anticipating threats before they occur. We introduce a system that leverages the activities of users on their machines and over the Internet to predict future malware outbreaks. Our solution estimates the risk for different classes of malware, enabling organizations to proactively implement mitigation strategies tailored to their risk profiles. We deploy our implementation in a real-world setting and conduct a large-scale risk study across 10.7 million endpoints collected over a period of one month. Our empirical study provides insights on the behaviors that most significantly put users at risk, the categories of endpoints that are most vulnerable to specific malware, the distribution mechanisms used to operate malware campaigns, among other findings we share with the community.

title: WIP: Evaluating the Effects of Active-Learning Implementation in a Foundational Engineering Course
authors: Cathy Ishikawa, Praveen Meduri, Sergio Aguilar-Rudemetkin, Mohammed E. Eltayeb, Milica Markovic
abstract: With the aim of improving rates of degree completion and entry into the workforce, this work in progress research investigates whether integrating Project-Based Learning (PBL) into a first-year electrical and computer engineering course affects students' self-efficacy and intentions to persist in the field. Using a pre-post survey design comparing four baseline lecture-based sections (Fall 2023) with six PBL-enhanced sections (offered Spring 2024 and Fall 2024), we measured self-efficacy with validated Likert-scale items and future goals using a 0–10 agreement scale. While PBL self-efficacy scores were slightly higher (at both times of semester), the effect was not significant. However, students in PBL sections demonstrated significantly higher intent to continue in engineering compared to baseline students. Furthermore, a significant interaction effect indicated that while intent to continue scores decreased over the semester in baseline courses, they remained stable in PBL sections. Our results add to evidence for positive outcomes with PBL and may encourage others to implement similar changes.

title: pH-responsive PANI Thin-film Sensor Based on Etched Fiber Gratings_supp1-3650076.docx
authors: Qi Wang
abstract: This work establishes a new paradigm for robust, real-time pH sensing by integrating a silane-coupled polyaniline coating with an etched fiber Bragg grating. Unlike diffusion-reliant optical sensors, our design transduces pH via rapid polymer strain, achieving a sub-15-second response— four times faster than typical hydrogel-based sensors. The key innovation lies in a dual-optimization of etching and coating processes, secured by a silane coupling agent that eliminates PANI adhesion issues. This results in great stability: a minimal signal drift (RSD <5.5%) over 10 days, extending the sensor’s lifespan by orders of magnitude compared to its non-silane counterparts. Such a design introduces an innovative technological framework for the creation of dependable real-time pH monitoring systems, holding significant potential for applications in environmental surveillance and the biomedical sector.

title: Bridging Educator Gaps in Computer Science: A Collaborative Professional Development Model
authors: Aetesam Ali Khan Ashar, Sharmin Akhter, Jiangjiang Liu
abstract: This full research paper explores programs for supporting middle and high school teachers in delivering highquality computer science (CS) education. The main focus is to conduct comprehensive studies on effective professional development programs to bridge the gaps in computer science education. Recognizing the lack of rigorous CS courses at the middle and high school levels, particularly due to the lack of qualified teachers, we examine professional development (PD) programs considering university partnerships, mentoring, sustained expertise, curriculum development, and nurturing local professional communities among educators. The study demonstrates that embedded professional development, delivered within the school environment, offers sustained mentorship, hands-on engagement with CS teaching practices, and consistent support that strengthens teacher confidence and instructional skills. Embedded PD programs improved teacher content knowledge and instructional skills, while also promoting higher levels of student participation and achievement in computer science. This work shows the importance of integrating embedded PD programs in pre-college CS education and proposes a collaborative professional development model with recommendations for structuring effective and scalable programs that promote CS for all.

title: Sensor Placement in a Passive Sensor Network for Scan-Based Ship Localization
authors: Taruna Tiwari, Christopher Funk, Shuo Li, Benjamin Noack
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Maritime safety remains vulnerable to GNSS spoofing, limited detection ranges, and environmental uncertainties, even with the use of positioning systems such as AIS and shore-based radar. To address these challenges, previous work introduced SeaSentry, a passive shore-based sensor network designed to detect and monitor vessels. The placement of sensors within the network significantly impacts the accuracy of vessel localization and tracking, as both the number and spatial configuration of sensors determine positioning performance. This study proposes a grid-based search for optimizing sensor placement in scan-based vessel localization. A network of fixed sensors is analyzed to identify the optimal positions for additional sensors, using the Cramér-Rao Lower Bound (CRLB) to quantify the minimum achievable localization error. Experiments conducted in the Neuburgweier region of Germany demonstrate the potential of the proposed grid-based search approach to establish a robust optimization technique for practical deployment. The findings also underscore the importance of strategic sensor placement and validate the approach through empirical results.

title: AnomalyTrack: Scalable and Self-Adaptive Anomaly Detection in Large-Scale 5G Networks
authors: Michel Santos Da Silva, Adriano Guilherme Silva Rocha, Lourenco Alves Pereira
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Next-generation mobile networks, evolving from 5 G Stand-alone (5 G SA) toward 6 G, require real-time adaptability to monitor large-scale, dynamic deployments. However, traditional monitoring methods struggle with the growing volume and interdependence of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), limiting the effectiveness of threshold-based detection. This paper introduces AnomalyTrack, a scalable, self-adaptive anomaly-detection framework that (i) details the exact implementation parameters of LOF, COF, IF-LOF, ARIMA, and SARIMA for full reproducibility; (ii) specifies its physical placement and resource footprint inside the 5 G core; and (iii) quantifies which KPIs contribute most to detection accuracy. Tested on one year of real-world data from a commercial Mobile Network Operator, AnomalyTrack processes 524019 KPI time series every 30 min, achieving 97% detection accuracy with inference latencies below $\mathbf{5 s}-\mathbf{9 6. 5 \%}$ faster than conventional monitoring. These results demonstrate a practical path toward zero-touch automation in large-scale $\mathbf{5 G}$ and forthcoming 6 G networks.

title: Impact of Active Cooling Systems on Solar Panel Efficiency and Net Energy Production
authors: Ferry R A Bukit, Yanuar Z. Arief, Arman Sani, Riswan Dinzi, Pribadi Prima Sitompul
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: The operation of solar panels is highly dependent on environmental conditions to provide a reliable power source. Temperature is one of the important ecological factors that directly affect the performance of solar panels, as higher operating temperatures reduce efficiency. In this study, two active cooling systems were applied to solar panels: water and air cooling using a heatsink and fan. The aim was to analyze the efficiency by comparing the energy produced by the panels with the energy consumed by the cooling systems. The results showed that solar panels equipped with a cooling system improved the operating efficiency compared to those without cooling. Among the tested methods, solar panels equipped with a heatsink and fan demonstrated the highest average operational efficiency, reaching 17.912%, followed by the water-cooling system, which achieved 17.832%. In contrast, solar panels without a cooling system showed the lowest average efficiency of 17.161%, highlighting the important role of thermal management in panel performance. However, when considering net energy output, the water-cooling system produced the highest net energy production, which was approximately 518.501 Wh, representing a 2.887% increase compared to the uncooled panel (503.951 Wh). In contrast, although the heatsink system improved instantaneous efficiency, its higher energy consumption resulted in a net energy output of only 455.900 Wh, which is 9.535% lower than that of the uncooled panel. These findings suggest that while active cooling improves solar panel performance, the choice of cooling method must consider both efficiency and energy consumption improvements to maximize net energy production.

title: Large Models Empowered End-to-End AI for Split Learning in Native AI Future Networks
authors: Liming Huang, Yulei Wu, Dimitra Simeonidou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: The emergence of sixth-generation mobile communication networks (6G) marks a paradigm shift toward native artificial intelligence (AI) architectures, where AI is deeply embedded in the network infrastructure. At the core of this transformation is End-to-End (E2E) AI, which enables autonomous monitoring, orchestration, and reasoning across distributed AI workloads. A key enabler of scalable E2E AI is split learning, where deep neural networks are partitioned across edge and cloud nodes to meet the performance and efficiency demands of 6G applications. However, the reliability of split learning is particularly vulnerable to performance degradation arising from communication delays, resource dynamics, and model drift. These issues pose significant challenges that traditional monitoring and maintenance techniques fail to address effectively. To tackle these challenges, this paper proposes a Large Models Empowered Proactive Maintenance Framework tailored for split learning in native AI future networks. The framework integrates Large Forecasting Models (LFMs) for continuous segment-level performance monitoring and Large Language Models (LLMs) for root cause reasoning and adaptive recovery planning. By aligning with the principles of E2E AI, the proposed system enables anticipatory anomaly detection, interpretable diagnosis, and automated corrective actions, thus enhancing the resilience, scalability, and autonomy of AI-native 6G networks. Experimental results demonstrate the framework's ability to maintain stable split model performance under dynamic system conditions, offering a practical path toward intelligent and self-sustaining AI service delivery in next-generation networks.

title: Incremental Online Learning of Randomized Neural Network with Forward Regularization_supp1-3652081.pdf
authors: Ponnuthurai Nagaratnam Suganthan
abstract: Online learning of deep neural networks faces challenges such as delayed non-incremental updating, increasing consumption, retrospective retraining, and catastrophic forgetting. To alleviate these drawbacks and achieve progressive immediate decision-making, we propose a novel Incremental Online Learning (IOL) framework of Randomized Neural Networks (Randomized NN), facilitating continuous improvements and analytics to Randomized NN performance in online scenarios. Within the framework, we further formulate IOL with ridge regularization (-R) and IOL with forward regularization (-F), both avoiding retrospective retraining and catastrophic forgetting. Moreover, the incremental algorithms for -R/-F on non-stationary batch stream are derived, featuring recursive weight updates and variable learning rates. Compared to -R, we recommend -F which improves learning performance using future unlabeled observations while further reducing online regrets to offline global experts. Additionally, we conduct a detailed analysis and theoretically derive relative cumulative regret bounds of the Randomized NN learners for -R/-F under adversarial assumptions via a novel methodology and present several corollaries, from which we observed the superiority in online learning acceleration and declined regret bounds of employing -F in IOL. Finally, our proposed methods were rigorously examined across diverse tasks, from simulation, regression, and classification tasks, to long-term time-series forecasting (LTSF) and continual learning (CL) fields, which distinctly validated the efficacy of the IOL frameworks and the advantages of forward regularization.
