title: Electrochemical Sensor for Detecting Heavy Metals in Irrigation System in the Philippines
authors: Engr. Marianne M. Sejera, Lucky Roveel D. Arco, Vin Diesel B. Alduheza
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: This study presents a low-cost electrochemical sensor for real-time monitoring of heavy metal peak potential (Pb, Hg, Cd) in agricultural irrigation systems. The system applies Anodic Stripping Voltammetry (ASV), utilizes a potentiostat interface circuit for the analog reading of the Arduino microcontroller, and uses wireless data transmission to enable on-site detection and analysis. A graphical user interface (GUI) visualizes data trends and provides actionable insights for farmers. Data validation demonstrated around 85.63% overall accuracy in heavy metal detection, with an expected reduced system cost compared to existing solutions. The prototype was tested in Lucban, Quezon Province, Philippines, confirming its feasibility for small-scale agricultural applications.

title: A DAO-based Blockchain Donation System with Smart Contract-Driven Project Prioritization
authors: Lau Wen Xuan, Shamsul Kamal Ahmad Khalid, Lokman Mohd Fadzil
abstract: Existing donation platforms suffer from limited transparency, centralized governance, and minimal donor participation in fund allocation decisions. Donors often lack visibility into how their contributions are used and have no role in prioritizing charitable projects. These shortcomings undermine trust and reduce engagement. In this paper, a DAObased blockchain donation system is proposed to address these challenges by enabling decentralized, transparent, and automated governance. Built on the Ethereum blockchain using Ganache, MetaMask, and Solidity smart contracts, the system allows verified donors to vote on project prioritization. Smart contracts autonomously execute fund distribution based on vote proportions, removing administrative discretion. The platform consists of eight functional modules, developed using Agile methodology, and implements key DAO features such as token-based eligibility, one-person-one-vote enforcement, and trustless execution. Functional testing validated 24 key system features, while security tests confirmed strong password policies, MetaMask-based identity, and reCAPTCHA protection. User acceptance testing with total 20 donors and 15 administrators resulted in satisfaction scores of 4–5 on a 5-point Likert scale. This research demonstrates how DAO principles can be applied to real-world philanthropic ecosystems, transforming donation systems from passive funding channels into participatory, community-governed platforms.

title: Design and Application of Edge Computing Architecture for Real-Time Control in Smart Microgrids
authors: Ivan Pashchuk, Mykhailo Dombrovsky
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources into electrical grids results in a significant increase in realtime data flows, thereby posing the challenge of their timely processing to ensure the stability, efficiency, and reliability of grid operation. This study proposes using Edge Computing for real-time control in smart Microgrids (MGs) to enhance efficiency. By processing data closer to the source, Edge Computing reduces latency, enabling faster decision-making for power balancing and load management. The system integrates peripheral devices, edge servers, and cloud infrastructure, with Fog Computing enhancing resilience. Real-time data on weather and economic factors optimizes renewable energy use, reduces CO2 emissions, and helps manage peak loads. Historical data predicts load behaviors and electricity demand, while intelligent algorithms ensure efficient energy management. Specialized hardware enables microsecond-level performance and dynamic workload distribution. This architecture offers a scalable solution for decentralized management and control in Smart Grids (SGs) and Microgrids (MGs), improving system stability and supporting renewable energy integration.

title: Nonlinear Integral Models of Eye Movement System in the Classification System of Human Psychophysiological States
authors: Vitaliy Pavlenko, Denys Lukashuk
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The technology for modeling the human eye movement system (EMS) based on nonlinear integral models in the form of second-order Volterra polynomials has been further developed. The identification of the EMS in the form of multidimensional transient characteristics is performed using data from identification “input-output” experiments, which involve test visual stimuli and innovative eye-tracking technology. Experimental studies of the respondent’s EMS were conducted for the psychophysiological states “Normal” and “Fatigue”. To determine the first- and second-order transient characteristics, the least squares method was applied to the responses of the EMS to step test signals of different amplitudes. The variability of the EMS transient characteristics for different psychophysiological states was assessed. For the classification of psychophysiological states, diagnostic feature spaces were constructed: a heuristic feature space and a feature space based on the sampling of transient characteristics. Machine learning datasets were generated. The most informative robust feature pairs were identified based on the probability of correct recognition (PCR) criterion for state classification using the Bayesian method, achieving PCR values of up to 93.75% for Respondent 1 and up to 95.24% for Respondent 2. For the first time, an adequate quadratic EMS model was constructed using three test signals of different amplitudes, which provides a simplified model structure, reduced identification error, and enables the formation of informative features for the classification of psychophysiological states.

title: Research on the Effectiveness of Court Decision Classification Based on Text Mining
authors: Tetiana Drakokhrust, Khrystyna Lipianina-Honcharenko, Nataliia Martsenko, Tetiana Nadvynychna, Mykola Telka, Andrii Semeshkin
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This study analyzes the effectiveness of court decision classification using text mining methods. It explores automated approaches for categorizing court decisions (civil, criminal, and administrative cases) through machine learning algorithms. The classification was conducted using TF-IDF vectorization combined with logistic regression, achieving an accuracy of $96 \%$. A comparative analysis of keyword-based and algorithmic text analysis methods was conducted, highlighting their strengths and weaknesses. The findings indicate that administrative law cases have a higher risk of misclassification due to terminological similarities with civil law cases.

title: Chilli Variety Classification and Providing Disease, Pesticide and Health Insights Using ML
authors: S. Nagini, N. Lakshmi Kalyani, Uduthala Medha, Jongoni Vishwajitha, Jella Sumitha, Bhavya Harshita Annavarapu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Chilli is a crop that is grown in many parts of the world, has considerable economic importance and occupies the rank of the fourth most cultivated crop in the world. This paper aims to develop a machine learning based model to classify different types of chillis found in a particular region. In this study, a collection of 50 image data sets for five chili types-Bhut jolokia, Kashmiri red chili, Guntur Sannam chili, Jalapeno, and cayenne have been grouped by a supervised learning task. Specifically, the Random Forest algorithm is used, where the model is trained to differentiate between types of chilis based on their visual characteristics, for example, shape, color and texture thus achieving an accuracy of 93.12 %. The high consumption of chilies is likely to contribute to the usage of herbicides, pesticides and other chemicals in the farms rain causing the contamination of crops and endangering the health of consumers. As a result, this model integrates both aspects, that is, it not only does chili variety classification but also examines the normal conditions under which chili crop production is done and the diseases that affect chilies during production, the pesticides used and the effects after the consumption of the products. For example the Kashmiri Chili variety suffers from damping off disease which is generally treated with the use of copper oxychloride 50 % W and Mancozeb, the side effects include the risk of thyroid dysfunction, skin and eyes irritations, and nervous system disorders as a result of exposure to Mancozeb. By complementing classification with essential information on agriculture, it is hoped that this system will act against consumer health threats.

title: Comparative Analysis of Closed-form and Metaheuristic-based Power Allocation in SISO VLC-NOMA Systems
authors: Samman Ashraf, Aamina Akbar, Abdul Waheed, Amena Ejaz Aziz
abstract: Visible Light Communication (VLC) systems can benefit from Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) to enhance spectral efficiency. This work investigates a Single-Input Single-Output (SISO) VLC scenario where power allocation coefficients are computed using both closed-form expressions and metaheuristic optimization algorithms. Under decoding-order and fairness constraints, the goal is to maximize the sum of users’ data rates. Simulation results for data rates and bit error rates demonstrate that while GA/PSO consistently achieve higher data rates, closed-form schemes can deliver superior BER when users are widely separated, highlighting the trade-offs between data rate and reliability. This dual-metric perspective provides a balanced and realistic understanding of power allocation strategies in VLC-NOMA networks.

title: WIP: Elementary Pre-Service Teachers' Perceptions of Engineering Within Integrated STEM
authors: Ursula Nguyen, Deepika Menon, Guy Trainin, Azadeh Hassani, Fatemeh Ashrafabadi
abstract: This innovative practice work in progress (WIP) paper describes a STEM methods semester for elementary preservice teachers (PSTs). Research indicates that STEM methods courses are often taught in isolation, providing future elementary teachers with limited opportunities to experience integrated STEM (iSTEM) teaching and learning. Moreover, studies suggest that future elementary teachers have limited knowledge about engineering design and its possible connection to science, mathematics, and/or technology. In this WIP paper, we address these limitations through our STEM methods semester. Our innovative practice lies in the design of this STEM methods semester, in which about 80 elementary PSTs are enrolled in science, innovative learning technologies, and mathematics methods courses. For the preliminary evaluation of this innovative practice, we utilize content analysis to examine elementary PSTs' reflections about their experiences with iSTEM teaching and learning. Results from this WIP will inform the revision of course assignments as well as future course activities and topics to better support future elementary teachers in implementing iSTEM.

title: Machine Learning–Driven Functional Chain Scheduling for Medical Emergency Assistance in Smart Healthcare
authors: Haewon Byeon, Vedamurthy Gejjegondanahalli Yogeshappa, Aadam Quraishi, Mukesh Soni, Mansi Ankur Trivedi, Mandeep Narang
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: To effectively manage classification and prioritization in medical emergency assistance, this study proposes a machine learning (ML)–driven functional chain scheduling framework for health medical information networks. Medical emergency services are classified into four categories based on urgency level and service area, with corresponding priority weights assigned. A system architecture integrating Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Function Virtualization (NFV) is designed to support dynamic and scalable service deployment. To minimize the total weighted completion time, a scheduling optimization model is formulated. For different problem scales, two complementary ML-based algorithms are employed: a Matching Game algorithm for small-scale instances and a Q-learning reinforcement learning algorithm for large-scale, dynamic scenarios. The Q-learning model adaptively optimizes scheduling policies through continuous interaction with network states and service demands, enhancing real-time decision-making efficiency. Simulation results show a reduction of up to 26.6% in total weighted completion time for small-scale problems using the Matching Game approach and up to 40 % improvement for large-scale problems with Q-learning compared to traditional heuristic algorithms. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed ML-driven framework in achieving accurate service prioritization, optimal resource utilization, and rapid emergency response, providing a foundation for intelligent and adaptive smart healthcare infrastructures.

title: Can LLMs Classify CVEs? Investigating LLMs Capabilities in Computing CVSS Vectors
authors: Francesco Marchiori, Denis Donadel, Mauro Conti
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Common Vulnerability and Exposure (CVE) records are fundamental to cybersecurity, offering unique identifiers for publicly known software and system vulnerabilities. Each CVE is typically assigned a Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) score to support risk prioritization and remediation. However, score inconsistencies often arise due to subjective interpretations of certain metrics. As the number of new CVEs continues to grow rapidly, automation is increasingly necessary to ensure timely and consistent scoring. While prior studies have explored automated methods, the application of Large Language Models (LLMs), despite their recent popularity, remains relatively underexplored.In this work, we evaluate the effectiveness of LLMs in generating CVSS scores for newly reported vulnerabilities. We investigate various prompt engineering strategies to enhance their accuracy and compare LLM-generated scores against those from embedding-based models, which use vector representations classified via supervised learning. Our results show that while LLMs demonstrate potential in automating CVSS evaluation, embedding-based methods outperform them in scoring more subjective components, particularly confidentiality, integrity, and availability impacts. These findings underscore the complexity of CVSS scoring and suggest that combining LLMs with embedding-based methods could yield more reliable results across all scoring components.

title: Symbolic Bootstrapping in Deep Networks Using Differentiable Logic Graphs and Conceptual Alignment Layers
authors: Venkateshwaran Shanmugham
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study concentrates on the amalgamation of deep neural networks with a verifiable architecture that preserves gradient-based learning. We will also employ Conceptual Alignment Layers (CAL) and Differentiable Logic Graphs (DLG) for this. The goal of these research pathways is to create a neural-symbolic system. You may use CAL to turn symbolic operators like AND, OR, and NOT into their continuous versions when you train a relational network. These operators will always be able to talk to each other as long as this goes on. Another beneficial feature about CAL is that it makes representations of ideas more stable, which makes it less likely that semantic drift will develop. The technique outperforms the best methods on twelve distinct assessment criteria, demonstrating a high degree of conceptual quality and logical coherence. Some of the things being looked at include how accurate, consistent, resilient, scalable, and easy to understand they are. In many circumstances, our method works well. For example, when used jointly, it is 99.3% accurate, and when used independently, it is 99.0% accurate. At the end of the operation, we got the following concept metrics: F1 = <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92.8 \%, C K A=0.87, T C A V$</tex> directionality <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.79$</tex>, prototype purity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.92$</tex>, and inter-concept <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$M I=0.11$</tex>. It not only keeps the F1 value high, but it also keeps the calibration error lower than the present baselines. This is done to make sure that CAL is still dependable when it comes to new concepts. You can still acquire the performance you need by employing trimming and modularization, even when symbolic restrictions make calculations much more expensive. The results show that there is always a trade-off between keeping prediction accuracy high and coping with scenarios that need a lot of data and change fast, even if the rules are straightforward to follow.

title: WIP: A Computational Approach to Streamlining Information Management for Farmers Developed through a Community-Engaged Learning Experience
authors: Eddy Pan, Arianne Fong, Alessandra Ferzoco
abstract: In this innovative practice work-in-progress paper, we present the preliminary idea of a community-engaged learning (CEL) experience where two undergraduate engineering students interleaved time spent working on a farm with community partners, and time spent in the lab researching and developing a software tool to support farm operations. The quality of the student experience, the relationships with community partners, and the technical work seemed to be mutually reinforcing. We are not intending to make recommendations or generalizations from our practice but rather are seeking language and frameworks to connect separate facets of the experience to the literature on motivation, community-engaged learning, and educational experiences that take place in natural settings. In addition, we are seeking ways to think about the combination of elements, how they support each other, and where we might explore those combinations in other educational scenarios.

title: WIP: High School Student Experiences in Engineering: Perspectives and Insights
authors: Sanjeev M. Kavale, Medha Dalal
abstract: This work-in-progress paper explores high school students' experiences in an introductory engineering course, as part of a broader longitudinal study. The last decade has shown significant growth in K-12 engineering education. Similarly, a pre-college initiative was launched in 2018 aiming to make engineering education accessible to high school students. This study explores their experiences in engineering design projects. Specifically, we explore the similarities and differences in these experiences based on gender. The research question addressed in this study is: “How do high school students experience engineering projects, and in what ways are these experiences similar or different across genders?“ Student surveys were conducted from 2019 to 2023 annually to evaluate the curriculum and understand students' experiences in early engineering classes. This study focuses on analyzing the open-ended responses of 296 high school students from 33 schools across 20 states in the academic year 2022 -23, using thematic analysis. The analysis revealed a set of themes that have gender-based trends in engagement with engineering projects. Both male and female students emphasized the value of hands-on learning, collaboration, and creativity. Notably, female students more frequently explained the real-world applications, while male students showed a stronger focus on technical tools and autonomous problem-solving. Also, female students valued practical, socially relevant projects and the creative process of design; whereas male students expressed greater interest in utilizing technologies and seemed to value outcomes of creativity. These results have implications for the broader engineering community to create more meaningful and inclusive pre-college engineering experiences.

title: CMOS Compatible Low-loss Optical Tunnel Vias for 3D Photonic Integration
authors: Sarad Subhra Bhakat, Kumar Piyush, Chintapalli Sam, Riddhi Goswami, Arnab Goswami, Eloi Marigo Ferrer, Hor Chee Hoong, Ng Chew Yan, Bijoy Krishna Das
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: The dimensional limit of a single-mode waveguide cross-section is the fundamental roadblock of designing compact and large-scale planar photonic integrated circuits (PICs). The other limitation is the choice of waveguide core materials for designing various passive and active components for the application specific PICs. Fortunately, besides crystalline Si, plenty of other options of waveguide core materials such as epitaxially grown Ge, PECVD/LPCVD grown SiN, AlN, etc., are available for the utilization of advanced CMOS fabrication process compatible silicon photonics technology in silicon-on-insulator (SOI) platform. However, because of the absence of a suitably designed optical via, hybrid structure waveguide components and multi-layered three-dimensional PIC designs couldn't be effectively implemented till date. Here, we have proposed a low-loss compact optical tunnel via (OTV) design as a solution for 3D photonic integration. Using a standard Maxwell's equation solver, we have shown that the insertion loss of such a OTV design can be <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.1dB for a broad wavelength range of operations around 1550nm. We have also shown low-loss performance of such OTVs can be arrayed in designing complex PICs with hybrid waveguide components. The materials and design dimensions have been chosen carefully such that the proposed 3D-PICs can be easily manufactured in conventional CMOS foundries. We have also presented wavelength dependent loss (WDL) and polarization dependent loss (PDL) of various OTV designs for hybrid photonic interconnects using 3D-FDTD simulations.

title: The Collaborative Disposition: What Students Say
authors: Renée McCauley, Mihaela Sabin, Bonnie K. MacKellar, Tammy VanDeGrift, Stephanos Matsumoto, Amruth N. Kumar
abstract: This full research paper contributes to current work on fostering the collaborative disposition among computing and engineering students. Collaborative work is essential in computing and engineering, given the scope and complexity of the projects within these fields. However, little is known about how to cultivate this disposition in the undergraduate classroom. The motivation of this research is to identify the categories of behaviors that students associate with being collaborative. The research questions for this study are: 1) What do students describe as collaborative practices applied to their coursework? and 2) What do students report as factors that prevent them from being collaborative? In computing courses at three institutions, students were asked to complete programming assignments and complete a reflection prompt after each assignment that asked “Describe an example of you being collaborative when completing this assignment. Otherwise, describe the circumstances that prevented you from being collaborative”. Responses were qualitatively/thematically analyzed resulting in the identification of ten categories of collaborative behaviors and nine categories of factors that impeded collaborative behavior. The significance of the study is that it deepens understanding of the collaborative disposition and identifies conditions that promote or discourage it. The results of this work will help educators design classroom interventions that will facilitate the development of the collaborative disposition among computing and engineering students.

title: Classification of Stunting in Children in Pemalang Regency Using Random Forest and K-Nearest Neighbors
authors: Rangga Aditya Nugraha, Putu Harry Gunawan, Eko Darwiyanto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Chronic malnutrition during early childhood often leads to stunting, a critical public health issue across Indonesia. Specifically in Pemalang Regency, 2023 data indicate a prevalence rate of 15.3%. To address this, the present research constructs a Machine Learning (ML) framework designed to accurately classify stunting cases within this specific demographic. The primary contribution of this work is the implementation of a robust pipeline that combines Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) with systematic hyperparameter tuning. This approach specifically addresses the challenge of extreme class imbalance to improve sensitivity to minority stunting cases. Performance evaluation was conducted using the Random Forest and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithms, with StandardScaler for normalization. The dataset exhibited a severe 9:1 imbalance, with 9,915 normal samples and only 1,045 stunting cases. Initial experiments on the imbalanced data yielded high accuracy (up to 97.99%) but failed to capture the minority class effectively, resulting in poor F1-scores (approximately 41-44% for KNN). However, integrating SMOTE significantly improved metric performance across all models. The optimized Random Forest model achieved superior results on the balanced dataset, attaining 96.94% accuracy, 88.00% precision, 78.00% recall, and an F1-score of 83.00%. These findings confirm that pairing data balancing techniques with model optimization is the most effective strategy for reliable stunting detection in the region.

title: Enhancing Text Based Email Spam Detection Using Attention Based Long Short-Term Memory
authors: Mona Aziz, Syifa Nurgaida Yutia, Desi Nurnaningsih
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: The rise of electronic communication has led to an increased amount of junk emails, thereby making spam a serious cyber security threat. Specifically, in the Indonesian scenario, it is difficult to identify spams due to its nature of containing Indonesian language in an English format, making it easier to evade filters. Conventional Machine Learning Models may find it difficult to identify such trends and may not be flexible enough to adapt to new trends of spams. To overcome this problem, this research proposes the application of text-based spam classifiers designed by applying Long Short-Term Memory with Attention Mechanism. The proposed model was then tested with an Indonesian dataset of 2,617 clean emails, split with an 80-20 ratio of train and testing set. From the experimental findings, it has been seen that by implementing Attention Mechanism in LSTM, one can achieve better accuracy with improved sensitivity and stronger context, with an accuracy of 97.75% and above 97% Precision, Recall, and F1 score respectively, thereby making it more viable and effective with new advances in advanced email security systems.

title: Study of Optical Wireless–Wired GPON Using FSO for Inter-Building Communication
authors: Aisyah Nabilah Hanaseptyani, Yus Natali, Mohammad Roihan, Aisyah Novfitri, Catur Apriono
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: An optical wireless-wired network is a necessity to provide broadband communication. The optical wireless, a free space optic (FSO) system, is connected to an optical wired network, a gigabit passive optical network for connecting two buildings. FSO underlays the GPON network, with the FSO output signal becoming the input signal for the GPON network can be a solution for interbuilding communication. This study discusses FSO feeders for GPON networks in a different building for communication within an institution. FSO transmission simulation within these buildings is carried out in a simulation. The FSO scheme is proposed in three free space propagations: clear sky, rain, and fog. The worst condition of fog-free space propagation is chosen for moderate attenuation to determine the maximum distance between two buildings. The visibility is also included for fog attenuation. The simulation results show FSO works reliably up to 600 m in clear-sky, 600 m for rain, and 540 m for fog weather. On the access side, the GPON network still provides BER standards. The simulation standard references are ITU-T G.984.2 for GPON, and ITU-R P.1817, F.2106-1 for FSO. The performance of both networks conforms to the ITU standards.

title: Data Analytics Framework for Personalized Persuasive Technologies: A Theoretical Approach
authors: Muhammad Aiman Md Zuki, Nazlena Mohamad Ali, Chaw Jun Kit, Muhammad Yudhi Rezaldi, Shuhadah Othman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: The effectiveness of persuasive technology systems is fundamentally constrained by their inability to adapt to individual user differences and dynamic behavioural contexts. This paper presents a comprehensive theoretical framework for integrating advanced data analytics approaches with personalised persuasive technology interventions. Drawing from behaviour change theories, computational persuasion models, and machine learning paradigms, we propose a multidimensional analytical framework that addresses the personalisation challenge through dynamic user modelling, contextual adaptation, and temporal optimisation. Our theoretical contribution synthesises insights from the COM-B behavioural model, reinforcement learning theory, and predictive analytics to establish a foundation for developing adaptive persuasive systems. The framework provides significant theoretical gaps to understand how data-driven methods could improve the effectiveness of personalised persuasive systems. In the meantime, while keeping scalability and dealing with ethical challenges. This paper gives a systematic theoretical framework for making personalised persuasive systems that can adapt to complex patterns of human behaviour.

title: BDI-Driven Indoor Positioning and Assistance via Hermes Mesh Networks and LLM Interfaces
authors: Mario Bonanno, Miriana Russo, Corrado Santoro, Federico Fausto Santoro, Alessio Tudisco
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Recent years have seen an overwhelming diffusion of digital assistants thanks to an endless amount of resources being employed in the research and production of sharper, faster and more powerful neural networks. These advancements have enabled users from diverse backgrounds to access complex datasets through simple natural language inquiries. Using only natural language, users can interact with data fetching services without needing to understand their underlying technical implementation. Our project takes root in such an ever-changing environment and addresses the long-standing necessity of an indoor localisation system in medium-to-large buildings, such as offices or schools. We will present the potential of our architecture, achieved via a state-of-the-art implementation of a mesh communication network between ESP32 microcontrollers based on advanced technologies such as LoRa, Bluetooth Low Energy and the framework Hermes. Pursuing maximum adaptability, the whole application has also been modelled over the BDI paradigm, given its superb information hiding capabilities and ease of understanding. To facilitate the process, a specialised custom library called DEMOCLE was fine-tuned and employed, which enables distributed knowledge programming on embedded devices. Finally, user interaction is managed by a Large Language Model-based artificial intelligence, capable of translating human requests into SQL queries that precisely access the collected data to meet the inquirer’s needs.

title: Development of a Prediction Model for Academic Performance Decline Using Two-Layer Ensemble Progressive Learning
authors: Sondius Matogu Budiman Silalahi, Richardus Indrajit, Teddy Mantoro
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Educational data mining (EDM) has emerged as a critical field for leveraging academic data to improve decisionmaking in schools and support early interventions for at-risk students. Despite the availability of rich academic data, school counseling services often remain reactive, with interventions occurring only after performance declines, creating a gap for proactive early-warning systems. To address this, a Two-Layer Ensemble Progressive Learning model is proposed: the first layer integrates Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Random Forest (RF) through weighted voting, while the second layer fuses inter-semester predictions to capture progression dynamics. Adaptive curriculum features covering curriculum-alignment behavior and knowledgedomain grouping are engineered to be readily replicable across schools, relying only on routinely collected curriculum and assessment records. On the aggregated evaluation set ($\mathbf{N}=\mathbf{2 4 0}$), we obtain micro-averaged Accuracy $=0.929$, Precision $=0.723$, Recall $=0.895, \mathrm{~F} 1=0.800$, and $\mathrm{ROC} \mathrm{AUC}=0.902$. Under 10fold grouped, time-aware cross-validation, the ensemble achieves macro-averaged Recall $=0.912$ and $\mathbf{F 1}=0.866$. The confusion matrix ($T P=34, F N=4, F P=13, T N=189$) highlights strong recall and low false negatives, which are critical for early interventions. This study makes three key contributions: a progressive ensemble that leverages inter-semester dynamics; adaptive curriculum features that are readily replicable across schools; and a practical implementation flow that enables school counselors to move from reactive to proactive intervention.

title: Determination of Liquid Relative Permittivity Using a Parallel Wire Capacitive Sensing Technique
authors: Aung Mon Chan, Thet Pai Oo, Akkarat Boonpoonga, Suramate Chalermwisutkul
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: This paper presents a parallel-wire capacitive sensing system designed for partial immersion in liquids to characterize their dielectric properties. The sensor models the total capacitance as a parallel combination of contributions from air and the material under test (MUT). Capacitance values were obtained through analytical calculation, Ansys Q3D simulation, and experimental measurement using air, ethanol, and distilled water (DI). Results from all methods showed close agreement across these test samples. The proposed sensor exhibits high sensitivity to variations in permittivity, offering a low-cost and effective solution for real-time liquid characterization in industrial and biomedical applications.

title: QoS Prediction for Satellite-Based Avionic Communication Using Transformers
authors: Hind Mukhtar, Raymond Schaub, Melike Erol-Kantarci
publish: IEEE Transactions on Machine Learning in Communications and Networking
abstract: Satellite-based communication systems are crucial for providing high-speed data services in aviation, particularly for business aviation operations that demand global connectivity. These systems face challenges from numerous interdependent factors, such as satellite handovers, congestion, flight maneuvers, and seasonal variations, making accurate Quality of Service (QoS) prediction complex. Currently, there is no established methodology for predicting QoS in avionic communication systems. This paper addresses this gap by proposing machine learning-based approaches for pre-flight QoS prediction. Specifically, we leverage transformer models to predict QoS along a given flight path using real-world data. The model takes as input a variety of positional and network-related features, such as aircraft location, satellite information, historical QoS, and handover probabilities, and outputs a predicted performance score for each position along the flight. This approach allows for proactive decision-making, enabling flight crews to select the most optimal flight paths before departure, improving overall operational efficiency in business aviation. Our proposed encoder-decoder transformer model achieved an overall prediction accuracy of 65% and an RMSE of 1.91, representing a significant improvement over traditional baseline methods. While these metrics are notable, our model’s key contribution is a substantial improvement in prediction accuracy for underrepresented classes, which were a major limitation of prior approaches. Additionally, the model significantly reduces inference time, achieving predictions in 40 seconds compared to 6,353 seconds for a traditional KNN model. This approach allows for proactive decision-making, enabling flight crews to select optimal flight paths before departure, improving overall operational efficiency in business aviation.

title: FedMon: Federated eBPF Monitoring for Distributed Anomaly Detection in Multi-Cluster Cloud Environments
authors: Sehar Zehra, Hassan Jamil Syed, Ummay Faseeha
abstract: Kubernetes multi-cluster deployments demand scalable and privacy-preserving anomaly detection. Existing eBPF-based monitors provide low-overhead system and network visibility but are limited to single clusters, while centralized approaches incur bandwidth, privacy, and heterogeneity challenges. We propose FedMon, a federated eBPF framework that unifies kernel-level telemetry with federated learning (FL) for cross-cluster anomaly detection. Lightweight eBPF agents capture syscalls and network events, extract local statistical and sequence features, and share only model updates with a global server. A hybrid detection engine combining Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) with Isolation Forests enables both temporal pattern modeling and outlier detection. Deployed across three Kubernetes clusters, FedMon achieves 94% precision, 91% recall, and an F1-score of 0.92, while cutting bandwidth usage by 60% relative to centralized baselines. Results demonstrate that FedMon enhances accuracy, scalability, and privacy, providing an effective defense for large-scale, multi-tenant cloud-native environments.

title: Climate Refugees in Literature and Real Life: Blockchain and AI for Ethical Storytelling and Data Protection
authors: Rati Sood, Sushma Jaiswal
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The growing number of people displaced by climate change also raises questions about capturing people's stories as well as distributing as well as archiving such knowledge. The paper compares as well as contrasts climate refugee stories under two converging prisms of works of literature as well as digital media. While literature as a practice makes it possible to analyze the affective as well as social dynamics of involuntarily displacements, the process of collecting as well as distributing stories via digital media also makes a series of technical as well as moral concerns. The AI as well as Blockchain hybrid model of ethical data protection as well as storytelling. AI is scrutinized in terms of content curation as well as linguistic analysis, while blockchain is considered in terms of data protection as well as tracking of consent of privacy in interconnect devices. The paper argues that while AI as well as blockchain could support scale and protection of narrative processes, both should be enacted in such a way that insures protection of participation, transparency, as well as accountability. Otherwise, scale mechanisms will more fortify inequalities as well as erase displaced people's dignity.

title: Cloud-Integrated Multi-Agent Middleware for Dynamic Adaptive 3D Map Generation in Disaster-Response Robotic Systems
authors: Izuru Akahori, Mingkang Chen, Jingtao Sun, Jun Yamaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Disasters such as earthquakes and tsunamis occur frequently all over the world. Relief activities using swarm intelligent robots have become essential and indispensable. This paper proposes a distributed middleware that can automatically adapt to environmental changes, such as secondary or N-th disasters, sudden obstacles, and network instability, for robots distributed to indoor rescue activities after a disaster. Multiple agents can interact with each other and their environments, and the system is built on a general cloud. The agent controls data messaging, task migration, and duplication to manage key adaptation processes across robots and the cloud, and our adaptation manager controls the agent’s lifecycle, which includes creation, relocation, execution, and termination. It enables dynamic reconfiguration of robot behavior in response to changing environmental conditions. In addition, this paper also effectively verifies our examples by implementing three pre-defined policies. Through experimental results, we preliminarily verify the effectiveness of our proposed approach.

title: InterARM: Interpretable Affective Reasoning Model for Multimodal Sarcasm Detection
authors: Tan Yue, Rui Mao, Xuzhao Shi, Erik Cambria
abstract: Multimodal sarcasm detection (MSD) aims to identify sarcastic expressions by integrating multimodal and contextual cues to capture cross-modal semantic inconsistencies. However, existing studies face challenges: fine-grained sarcastic cues are implicit and dispersed, large generative models suffer from gradient vanishing in classification tasks, and cross-domain generalization remains limited. To address these limitations, we propose InterARM, an interpretable affective reasoning model that introduces a structured sarcasm reasoning paradigm. Specifically, we introduce a three-stage training strategy based on curriculum learning, consisting of 1) sarcasm classification learning, 2) structured sarcasm reasoning learning, and 3) step-selective hierarchical reward reinforcement learning. The model generates reasoning chains across modalities to analyze sentiment polarity and semantic conflicts. We also construct the MSD-CoT dataset with 3,200 image-text pairs with 19,200 human-annotated reasoning steps. Experiments show that InterARM achieves superior performance on the in-domain and out-of-domain datasets, outperforming larger MLLMs such as Qwen2.5-VL-7B and GPT-5-mini while maintaining high interpretability and strong cross-domain generalization.

title: A Low-Carbon Autonomous Operation Method for Energy-Intensive Industrial Parks Based on Dynamic Games Among Multiple Subjects
authors: Qingzhi Zhang, Jianghui Tang, Ge Liu, Yaqi Ding, Yifeng Gao, Xiaolei Bai, Liming Yin, Wei Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: To tackle environmental issues in Regional Integrated Energy Systems (RIES) and resolve conflicts among multi-market stakeholders, this study introduces a collaborative optimization method using multi-game theory for the carbon trading mechanism and a tiered IDR strategy. The dual-incentive IDR strategy is implemented in four steps. First, a tiered reward-penalty carbon trading mechanism controls carbon emissions from market stakeholders. Second, an IDR strategy balancing price incentives and carbon compensation is designed for end-users. Third, a multi-agent low-carbon operation mechanism based on carbon trading and game-theoretic cooperation is built, considering the decision-making abilities of entities like power generation, load, and energy storage, with decision-making models developed for all stakeholders. Finally, the proposed model is solved using the Adaptive Differential Evolution (ADE) algorithm and the Gurobi solver. Simulation results verify the model's effectiveness in the low-carbon operation framework, enabling each stakeholder to adjust their strategy to balance the system's economic and environmental benefits.

title: Research on Fault Diagnosis of Photovoltaic Power Plants Based on Image Recognition Technology
authors: Feng Xu, Weikang Wang, Xiaowei Yang, Yingying Kong, Yichen Fang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Addressing the low efficiency and poor accuracy of traditional methods in photovoltaic (PV) power plant fault detection, this paper proposes a multi-morphology fault diagnosis model based on image recognition technology. The model integrates the Segformer image segmentation method with an improved TOOD detection framework, incorporating deformable convolution and a DiffusionDet decoder to enhance feature extraction and localization capabilities for multiple fault types, including hot spots, soiling, glare, and diode short circuits. Experimental validation was conducted using a constructed dual-spectrum image dataset containing 13,728 images. Results show that the proposed MD-TOOD model outperforms mainstream detection models in terms of mAP, particularly excelling in distinguishing morphologically similar faults (e.g., hot spots vs. soiling) and accurately localizing glare regions, thereby significantly improving the accuracy and robustness of PV power plant fault diagnosis.

title: Employ Blockchain to Boost Cloud Computing Cybersecurity: Product Data Integrity and Appropriate Access with Smart Contract Regulations
authors: A. Jaya Mabel Rani, Vijayanarayanan. A, Karthiga. R, Nisha M, Amandeep Nagpal, Hemalatha R
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The prevalence of cloud computing has changed how enterprises store, process and manage data. But the migration now also widens the attack vectors for cybersecurity threats leading to issues with data integrity, privacy and access in unauthorized manners. This work puts forward a blockchain based security framework to strengthen the security of cloud computing by protecting the integrity of product data and controlling access using smart contract rules. With blockchain-based decentralized, append-only, immutable ledger and smart contract programmability, the architecture supports secure data sharing, auditable trails, enforceable access rule automation that is not dependent on central parties. The blockchain works in the proposed system as trusted data infrastructure on which all transactions of crucial product data creation, request or update, are registered in an unchangeable way. The access to, as well as the modification of particular dataset is governed by smart contract living on blockchain, that enforce pre-defined access policies. This mitigates single-point of failures and insider attacks experienced by centralized cloud deployments. The framework is cloud-ready and is being gradually integrated with a penetration testing framework for cloud, as an overlay security layer. An anomaly detection with AI could be added to check access patterns and activate appropriate security procedures in case of suspicion. The blockchain-oriented architecture also enables distributed identity management, making it possible for enterprises to securely manage access control for identity across multi-cloud environments. Performance evaluation shows that our solution mitigates unauthorized accesses by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40+\%$</tex> while also making the auditing of the logs so much easier (because of the immutability) and compliance cost minimal (as smart contracts do the job of security checks). In addition, it supports cross-organization computing in cloud ecology while keeping the data privacy. This work tackles the challenge of keeping cloud computing scalable and flexible while providing strong cybersecurity. Leveraging blockchain's trust model with a programmable access control and data integrity verification, the platform provides a secure, transparent, and a self-regulating cybersecurity infrastructure for cloud infrastructure. The proposed framework can be directly extended to any domain including manufacturing, healthcare and supply chain management where secure product data handling is a necessity.

title: Adaptive Prompt Intelligence: Towards Self-Evolving Conversational Agents
authors: Shilpi Yadav, Lipika Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Human-machine communication is becoming more and more complicated, which requires conversational agents that will be able to constantly improve themselves and be aware of the situation. The conventional models of dialogue are based on fine-tuning that is not dynamic and they do not have any means of long-term adaptation in the process of real-life communication. This paper attempts to overcome this drawback by presenting a novel dynamic meta learning network named Cognitive Gradient Modulation Network (CGMN) - which enables the autonomous learning of conversational behavior. CGMN encompasses a Meta-Cognition Engine to trace linguistic consistency, a Gradient Modulation Layer to do localized parameter change-offs and an Evolutionary Memory Bank that maintains the history of context adaptation. The model uses user sentiment, coherence pattern, and task performance metrics through a Cognitive Feedback Reinforcement loop to improve the model dialogue strategies as a running record. CGMN uses lightweight gradient gating, opposed to the use of traditional retraining-based techniques, to allow efficient real-time fine tuning. The proposed model is tested experimentally to illustrate that the model has a high adaptability, long-term consistency, and the entropy of responses is less than in baseline transformer-based agents. All in all, CGMN provides a platform to build some self-regulating conversational systems that develop with the interaction of the user, forming the transition between a fixed large language model and a fully autonomous cognitive dialogue system. The suggested CGMN attained an overall accuracy of 95.6 percent, exhibiting enhanced flexibility and precision relative to current conversations models.

title: HI-MobileNet: A Lightweight Deep Learning Framework for Automated Diagnosis of Harlequin Ichthyosis
authors: Athul Joe Joseph Palliparambil, Anandhu P Shaji, Rajeev Rajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Harlequin Ichthyosis (HI) is a hereditary condition characterized by severe skin defects. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial for improving neonatal outcomes. Still, automated categorization is difficult because of small datasets and minute morphological differences. Using dermatological images, this work assesses two lightweight deep learning models: MobileNetV2 and a custom CNN for HI subtype recognition. By effectively utilizing transfer learning and synthetic data augmentation to solve data shortage, MobileNetV2 attained the greatest accuracy than CNN, surpassing previous architectures. The computational efficiency and validation by doctors of the model highlight its fit for use in diagnosis environments with limited resources. This work provides a scalable framework to bridge gaps in understudied medical domains by advancing AI-driven tools for rare diseases.

title: The Impact of Late-Night Phone Use on Sleep and Mental Health: The Role of Behavioral Adaptation Strategies
authors: Abdullah Musharaf, Nafil Yasir, Faisal Bukhari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: The increasing number of people using their phones right before going to bed has raised concerns about how it might affect their sleep and mental health. This study examines the relationship between nighttime phone use and important sleep parameters, including mood disorders, onset latency, sleep duration, and daytime sleepiness. The data was collected through a survey of 139 participants that analyzed phone usage patterns, sleep quality, and mental health.Excessive phone use at night is associated with a 65% decline in sleep quality and a 70% increase in daytime fatigue. Regression analysis also showed that for every additional hour of nighttime phone use, there was a 0.37-point reduction in sleep quality. However, participants who reported behavioral interventions, such as scheduled breaks and mindfulness exercises, experienced a 30% decrease in fatigue.These findings emphasize the importance of structured interventions over simple screen-time restrictions, offering a data-driven approach to improving digital wellness and sleep quality.

title: WIP: Comparing the Impact of Learning Strategy Interventions in Varied Teaching Contexts
authors: Alex Phan, Huihui Qi, Minju Kim, Marko V. Lubarda, Curt Schurgers
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice study examines how different instructional contexts influence the effectiveness of teaching engineering students learning strategies. Self-regulated learning is a vital skill for lifelong learning, particularly in the engineering profession, where rapid technological advancements require continuous adaptation. Although self-regulated learning is essential, explicit teaching of learning strategies for self-regulation is not standard in traditional engineering classrooms. Lack of targeted metacognitive training can impact students' ability to study effectively and master complex concepts. Factors such as limited instructional time and resources often hinder the integration of valuable learning interventions in practice. In this study, we examine how instructional contexts influence the transferability of knowledge gained from learning interventions. Using evidence-based learning strategies such as active recall, spaced learning, and knowledge organization, we implemented an intervention across three distinct instructional settings: a self-enrolled workshop, a guest lecture in a student success course, and a series of integrated lessons and assignments in a junior-level engineering classroom. Transferability was assessed using a pre-intervention survey and a follow-up survey administered 3 to 12 months later, measuring whether students integrated the strategies into their study routines and identifying which strategies were most effectively adopted across instructional contexts. Preliminary data suggests that teaching learning strategies within the context of an engineering classroom can provide the highest transferability. However, delivering it in a workshop specifically targeting engineering students can also be a viable pathway for learning strategies such as active recall. This work provides insight into alternative pathways for effectively integrating learning skills into engineering students' education. While preliminary results show varying transferability, it can help administrators and faculty better understand trade-offs when introducing learning interventions.

title: A Deep Experimental Study of Ensemble-Based Phishing Detection in Centralised and Federated Settings
authors: Esraa Jamil, Javier Garcia-Blas, Sadi Alawadi, Jesus Carretero
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Phishing attacks remain a major cybersecurity threat in today’s increasingly interconnected world, exploiting human vulnerabilities to bypass traditional defenses. This study evaluates a range of Machine Learning and Deep Learning models for phishing detection using three datasets: phishing-only, legitimate-only, and a balanced merged dataset. The experiments were carried out using centralized and FL approaches, with further robustness evaluation under adversarial scenarios such as phishing injection and label-flipping attacks. The results demonstrate that DL models, particularly LSTM and MLP, delivered strong performance in both stand-alone and ensemble setups. Notably, FL models preserved comparable performance and even slightly better accuracy than centralized models, while enhancing privacy, scalability, and robustness. Under adversarial scenarios, FL models maintained high robustness, validating the practical effectiveness of privacy-preserving phishing detection in real-world environments. In centralized settings, LSTM achieved up to 96.00% accuracy on phishing data, while heterogeneous DL ensembles (LSTM, MLP, CNN) further enhanced performance to 97.13%. This advantage was especially evident during crossdistribution evaluations, where LSTM bagging showed strong generalization, achieving up to 85.73% accuracy. In federated settings, LSTM models reached up to 86.75% accuracy and an F1-score around 86%. Even under phishing injection and data poisoning attacks, the 10-client LSTM model showed the best balance with 83.33% accuracy, 85.67% F1-score, and the highest AUC of 91.40%. The 10-client CNN and 15-client MLP models also performed well, with accuracies around 83.7% and F1-scores above 85.5%, with MLP reaching an AUC of 91.13%.

title: Improving Retention in a Fast-Paced Software Engineering Master's Degree for Career Changers Using a Skills Profiler
authors: Paulo Fernandes, Christopher Stuetzle, Maria-Isabel Carnasciali, Torrey DiPalma
abstract: This innovative practice paper falls under the Innovative Teaching and Learning track and focuses on improving graduate student retention in an online software engineering master's program (MSCS-SE) designed for career changers through the use of a novel onboarding process. The MSCS-SE, launched in 2021, targets students without a computer science or mathematics undergraduate degree Traditionally, many such students have struggled with the program's fast-paced introductory programming course. We developed an onboarding scheme to support student success featuring a Master Skills Profiler (MSP) placement exam and a foundational programming course. The MSP helps students assess their overall initial skill levels in programming and mathematical foundations. Based on the results, students receive tailored course recommendations. Those identified as needing additional preparation are encouraged to take a Basic Programming and Discrete Mathematics course, which fills knowledge gaps but does not count toward degree credits. To further support students, a tuition waiver was introduced for those placed into this preparatory course. This approach encourages students to make an informed decision rather than self-assessing into an overly challenging course, ultimately improving retention and program success. Retention data from multiple cohorts indicate that the onboarding scheme improved student persistence. Initial findings show that students who followed the placement recommendations were more likely to successfully complete the first programming course and, ultimately, the program. The tuition waiver further increased enrollment in the preparatory course, ensuring students had the necessary foundation. Future work includes a deeper longitudinal analysis of student outcomes and expanding the approach to other graduate programs.

title: Impact of Blinkit: Spatio-Temporal GNN Framework for Sustainable Demand Forecasting in Q-Commerce
authors: N. Udaya Prakash, Ramar Veluchamy, M. Ganesan Alias Kanagaraj, K. Sathiyamurthi, K.K. Karthick, V. Vimalnath
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The rapid commerce platforms have transformed city retailing through the delivery of groceries and other necessities within a few minutes, which requires highly accurate demand forecasting and last-mile logistics. To overcome the drawbacks of the previous models, which could not describe the complicated spatial and time interactions, a graph-based predictive model of Blinkit, which is one of the leading Q-commerce providers, was developed. Spatio-temporal graphs of large-scale transactional records and real-time rider mobility data were modelled as a multi-layer and analyzed as a Graph Neural Network with predictive analytics. The efficiency of transportation was determined by using SUMO-based urban network simulation. The proposed system attained an absolute error in the demand forecasting mean of 2.7 %, an F1-score of 0.93 on surge detection, and an average error on delivery time of 3.5 minutes. The simulation outcomes also showed that it will utilize 86 % of its fleet, a maximum congestion index of 0.48, and the emission of carbon per delivery is 24 % less. These results prove the capability of the framework to contribute to the efficiency of quick-commerce and enable sustainable consumer-oriented operations.

title: Prediction to Explanation: A Review of Machine Learning and XAI in Telecom Customer Churn Analysis
authors: Kaustubh Sutar, Sneha Soni, Snehlata Barde
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The telecommunications sector is challenged by an economic issue of customer retention and this systematic literature review indicates a gap in research for churn prediction where tree-based ensembles are the most implemented solution method and hybrid systems and SVMs are feasible alternatives with the greatest prediction accuracy, however, due to the “black box” nature of these findings, they are not applicable. Explainable artificial intelligence frameworks such as SHAP and LIME try to create interpretation and transparency for predictive modeling; however, our research reveals that an overwhelming majority of attempts at XAI come from one untested framework. We fill the gap with a dual-framework validated approach with global and local explanations to sustain a reasonable understanding of churn predictors. This research creates the state-of-the-art ML-XAI field with a path toward enhanced predictability and transparency for actionable results in prediction for churn.
