title: Optimal Tracking Control of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems Using Simplified Reinforcement Learning
authors: Pengju Ning, Lingjie Duan, Changchun Hua
abstract: This article investigates the optimal tracking control problem for high-order uncertain nonlinear systems by developing a simplified reinforcement learning (RL) framework with minimal neural networks (NNs). In contrast to conventional RL-based schemes that rely on recursive backstepping and require <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3n$</tex-math> </inline-formula> NNs (where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n$</tex-math> </inline-formula> is the system order), the proposed method leverages high-order fully actuated (HOFA) system theory to reformulate the dynamics into a compact normal form. This enables a unified, nonrecursive controller design that requires only three NNs regardless of the system order, thereby significantly reducing computational complexity and facilitating practical implementation. Furthermore, this work overcomes a critical theoretical deficiency in existing simplified RL strategies, where the vanishing minimum eigenvalue of the NN basis function correlation matrix often leads to invalid Lyapunov stability analysis. A novel critic–actor weight update law is designed to bypass this problematic matrix, rigorously guaranteeing the semiglobal uniform ultimate boundedness of the closed-loop system without requiring persistent excitation (PE) conditions. Simulation results on a representative example demonstrate the effectiveness and computational efficiency of the proposed approach compared with existing methods.

title: A Biologically-Inspired Flapping-Wing Air Vehicle with Active Folding-Wings_supp1-3653275.mp4
authors: Jae-Hung Han
abstract: Flapping-Wing Aerial Vehicles (FWAVs) offer unique advantages over traditional fixed-wing and rotary-wing aircraft, including superior maneuverability, energy efficiency, and the capability to navigate through cluttered environments. These features make them highly promising for applications in reconnaissance, search, rescue, and exploration of confined spaces. However, many designs cannot morph or fold their wings, significantly restricting their adaptability during flight. Without active morphing, these vehicles struggle to optimize their wing configurations for different flight modes, reducing overall efficiency and agility. Additionally, many of them are designed with synchronized wing motions, preventing independent control of the left and right wings or variations in flapping amplitudes, which further limits their dynamic performance and maneuverability. To overcome these challenges, a biologically inspired FWAV, KRoSwan, featuring an active folding-wing mechanism, is developed. This system employs servo motors as direct-drive actuators, enabling simultaneous control of both flapping and folding motions. This novel approach significantly enhances the degrees of freedom in wing movement, granting improved agility and adaptability. The methodology involves designing the robotic platform, formulating its dynamic and aerodynamic models, and conducting extensive flight tests to validate its performance. This research advances the development of FWAVs by integrating active wing morphing and independent wing control, paving the way for more agile, adaptable, and efficient bio-inspired aerial robots.

title: A Hydro-Intelligence Body: Cognitive Architecture for Project-Oriented Autonomous Water Systems Driven by Multi-Modal Sensing and Water Utility Panel
authors: Min Chen, Yue Wang, Lejun Ai, Xiangju Cheng, Jixuan Xie, Haodong Yi, Enpeng Lan, Jia Liu, Jiaxin Luo, Yu Qiu, Rui Wang, Xiao-Kun Wu, Wenjing Xiao, Yixue Hao, Long Hu, Delu Zeng, Zhicai He, Gang Wei, Siyuan Liu, Fuxin Zhang, Hongwu Tang
abstract: The advancement of emerging technologies such as unmanned aerial vehicles and distributed sensing devices has accelerated the development of Autonomous Intelligent Systems (AIS) with integrated perception, communication, and computation capabilities. However, in mission-critical consumer applications such as smart cities, a major challenge lies in designing a computational architecture that combines deployment flexibility with domain-specific expertise, enabling continuous self-evolution and collaborative decision-making based on dynamic sensing data. To address this challenge, we propose a novel hierarchical cognitive architecture. The framework adopts a project-based methodology, where project engineers can autonomously construct systems by selecting utilities from a utility panel that integrates physical models, data-driven models, and AI models. The system’s intelligence is powered by federated knowledge engine, which coordinates a set of domain-specific fine-tuned large language models (LLMs), and orchestrates their collaboration through a multi-agent workflow to execute complex tasks. We conduct extensive experiments demonstrating that, compared with several general-purpose LLMs, our fine-tuned model under our approach exhibits a significantly lower frequency of moderate-to-severe hallucinations in the water resources engineering domain. These findings validate the feasibility of constructing a federated knowledge engine. Furthermore, this work provides a robust and scalable platform for developing next-generation consumer-grade AIS that require high reliability and physical interpretability.

title: Communicating the Value and Contributions of Engineering Education Research to Multiple Stakeholders
authors: Cynthia J. Finelli, Katreena Thomas, Lisa Benson
abstract: This workshop provides an opportunity for participants to take action on developing a structured advocacy campaign to address critical challenges facing the field of engineering education research (EER). Workshop materials and activities are based on input from EER scholars and stakeholders. They collaboratively worked to identify and articulate the value of EER, develop a strategic communication plan, and lay out actionable objectives for promoting EER within multiple stakeholder groups. The first workshop goal is to synthesize and communicate the value and contributions of EER to multiple stakeholder groups. The second goal is to gather feedback on advancing the strategic campaign by developing clear, consistent messaging about the value of EER in accessible language and formats for three main stakeholder groups: industry, academia (particularly those in decision-making roles), and the general public (including policymakers and legislators).

title: Gate-Induced Drain Leakage Effect-Driven 1T FeFET TCAM for Large-Scale Integration
authors: Xinghui Wang, Jiuren Zhou, Siying Zheng, Haiwen Xu, Wenxin Sun, Zhou Wang, Jie Liang, Bing Chen, Yan Liu, Yue Hao, Genquan Han
abstract: We propose a novel ferroelectric field-effect transistor (FeFET)-based ternary content addressable memory (TCAM) that exploits the gate-induced drain leakage (GIDL) effect to achieve ambipolar functionality. This design introduces the first FeFET TCAM with symmetric source/drain ohmic contacts, delivering significant advantages in cell scalability and fabrication simplicity, thereby establishing a foundation for large-scale TCAM array integration. The device’s matching functionality was validated under both static and transient conditions, exhibiting a reliable noise margin and a current ratio of approximately 10, maintained after over <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times 10^{{3}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> query cycles or <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10^{{4}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> s of query delay. This strategy paves the way for the next generation of high-throughput, large-scale TCAM arrays.

title: Near limit boundary selection of power system operation mode based on GMM
authors: Hao Wang, Dabo Zhang, Weichao Xu, Pengjie Yu, Mengbo Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: The traditional safety and stability assessment of power systems mainly relies on deterministic typical scenarios and historical operating data. However, under the influence of a high proportion of renewable energy, fundamental flaws are gradually exposed. Existing scenario selection methods are easily dominated by conventional operating scenarios and difficult to capture low probability near limit conditions caused by sudden changes in new energy output and extreme weather. In order to overcome the shortcomings of existing technical fields, this paper proposes a near limit boundary power system scenario selection method based on Gaussian mixture probability model. The Gaussian mixture model is used to perform probability clustering on high-dimensional data, and the posterior probability screening model is combined with the overlapping transition regions and Mahalanobis distance quantification of statistical risks near the limit. The two work together to achieve bidirectional coupling between the probability model and optimization control, accurately characterizing the near limit boundaries of the new power system and effectively generating high-dimensional feature scenarios.

title: Inclusive Cybersecurity and Safety Risk Assessment Model for Cyber-Physical Systems Using Mamdani Fuzzy Inference System
authors: Mardiana Mohamad Noor, Ali Selamat, Nurulakmar Abu Hussain
abstract: Cyber Physical Systems (CPS) comprise heterogeneous components that engage with both the physical environment and human activities. These components function synergistically to deliver diverse capabilities that enhance human life, the operation of physical systems, and ecosystems. CPSs, particularly Industrial Control Systems (ICS), have frequently been targeted by cyberattacks due to their substantial reliance on technological interconnectivity and the adoption of emerging technologies such as the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT), along with vulnerabilities arising from security misconfigurations and human factors. Comprehensive CPS risk management should encompass assessments of both physical and functional safety and cybersecurity. Thus, this document introduces a quantifiable and inclusive cybersecurity and safety risk assessment (ICSRA) model employing the Mamdani Fuzzy Inference System. The assessed risk using the proposed model indicates that insiders, among other risk factors, present the most significant cybersecurity and safety threat in CPS due to their potential to manipulate operational usability and their physical presence within the OT segment. The proposed ICSRA has also demonstrated superior accuracy, achieving 90% in listing the most analogous threats in ICS as reported by a trusted solution provider, when compared to existing quantitative risk models.

title: Exploring Communication Efficient Methods for Homomorphic Encryption Federated Learning
authors: Yuri Dimitre de Faria, Leandro A. Villas, Allan M. de Souza
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Cross-silo Federated Learning (FL) enables multiple institutions to collaboratively train machine learning models without directly sharing sensitive data. However, despite the absence of explicit data sharing, significant security risks remain, such as gradient inversion attacks that reconstruct private data from local client updates. To mitigate these risks, Homomorphic Encryption (HE) has been widely explored, allowing computations on encrypted data without decryption. However, HE introduces substantial computational and communication overhead, limiting its practical feasibility. To address this challenge, this work presents SlidHE, an efficient technique that integrates packing and packet sparsification methods with various selection strategies to significantly reduce overhead while preserving privacy and maintaining model accuracy, even in heterogeneous (non-IID) data settings. Experimental results demonstrate that SlidHE outperforms existing methods by effectively balancing efficiency, security, and performance. The full implementation of SlidHE is available on GitHub<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>https://github.com/AllanMSouza/SlidHE

title: From Play to Proficiency: A Systematic Literature Review on Learning Modalities and Transition Strategies in CS and AI Education
authors: Yousuf Amanuel, Johannes Krugel
abstract: This full research paper provides an overview of the learning modalities: unplugged learning (UL), visual/blockbased programming (VBP/BBP), and text-based programming (TBP) for teaching computer science with focus on machine learning and artificial intelligence. We emphasize these learning modalities due to their clear distinctions in terms of technicality and language specificity, ranging from the non-technical and device-independent nature of UL to the more technical and language-specific characteristics of TBP. We performed a systematic literature review, which identified 90 studies that aligned with our eligibility criteria. The analysis systematically compared the learning modalities by deriving qualitative insights into their characteristics, effectiveness, and applicability; it also explored their suitability for different learning stages and strategies to facilitate transitions, ultimately uncovering best practices and identifying areas for improvement. UL can improve the understanding of computational concepts and basic algorithms. VBP improves conceptual understanding in more complex and challenging topics. Secondary school is the most common stage for initiating the VBP-to-TBP transition, with dual presentation being the most used modality. While VBP helps reduce programming misconceptions during this phase. Challenges remain regarding teachers' limited programming knowledge and tools' accessibility.

title: Student Interest and Choice of STEM Majors: A Systematic Review of Contributing Factors
authors: Syeda Fizza Ali, Saira Anwar
abstract: This full research paper presents a systematic review of the factors that influence students' interest in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. In recent years, extensive research has focused on identifying the factors that influence students' early interest in STEM fields, ultimately guiding their college major choices related to these fields. Given the extensive literature on the topic, a synthesis of the findings is warranted. This paper reviews and synthesizes these findings using the lens of Social Cognitive Career Theory, and addresses the following research questions: 1) What factors influence interest in STEM fields in K-12 students? and 2) What factors influence the choice of STEM fields in undergraduate students? We searched for articles that investigated factors influencing STEM interest and choice across four databases: Education Source, ERIC, IEEE Xplore, and ASEE Peer. Based on predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria, we shortlisted 27 articles. A thematic analysis of the articles revealed that for K12 students, social influences, learning and motivational factors, such as performance and self-efficacy beliefs, as well as identitybased factors like gender and first-generation status, were influential in developing STEM interests. For undergraduate students, influential factors in the choice of STEM majors included prior exposure, social influences, outcome expectations, and personal interest. These findings can inform educators and researchers working to enhance retention and recruitment in STEM fields. This review highlights the factors that are instrumental in designing effective interventions to increase students' interest in STEM, emphasizing the role of community and positive learning experiences.

title: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Models for Estimating Li-ion Batteries State of Health
authors: Fernando Gunawan, Lityo Putra Sudarso, Pieter Allen, Diana, Shania Priccilia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Accurate prediction of lithium-ion battery State of Health (SoH) is crucial for safe and efficient energy management, particularly with the increasing prevalence of electric vehicles. This paper compares several machine learning (ML) models, such as Random Forest, Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Support Vector Machine (SVM), for estimating SoH using the NASA Battery Dataset. Where only discharge cycles from the dataset were used. The dataset was further preprocessed to extract relevant features such as voltage, current, temperature, and State of Charge (SoC). Models were trained using Python with scikit-learn for Random Forest, SVM, and XGBoost for the XGBoost model. Model performance was evaluated using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and the coefficient of determination (${R}^{{2}}$). Results show that Random Forest achieved the best score with the lowest MAE (0.32) and a high ${R}^{{2}}$ (0.92), demonstrating its effectiveness in SoH prediction. While XGBoost also showed strong performance (MAE of 0.56 and ${R}^{{2}}$ of 0.92). Lastly, the standard SVM model had the weakest performance and the performance was improved with hyperparameter tuning.

title: Integrative AI Practices Across Disciplines: Innovations in Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, and Economics Education
authors: Xiaoguang Ma, Yanwei Wu, Xiaotong Liu, Jing Wang
abstract: This full innovative practice paper describes an interdisciplinary approach leveraging generative AI tools to enhance teaching and learning across computer science, electrical engineering, and economics education. Driven by rapid AI technology development and recognizing that traditional lectures often fail to address individualized learning gaps, educators from these disciplines implemented innovative AI practices, utilizing key tools like ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Google NotebookLM. These approaches support technical, operational, and strategic learning objectives by tailoring experiences, designing dynamic in-class activities, preparing comprehensive quiz reviews, and generating realistic scenarios that bridge theories with practical applications. In Computer Architecture, for instance, instructors utilized the POSED framework (Plan, Outline, Sources, Evaluation, Draft) to efficiently create and refine teaching materials while rapidly incorporating student feedback. At the same time, Google NotebookLM offered personalized support through lecture summarization and quiz generation. Built on prior research in AI-based tutoring and constructivist pedagogies, this framework extends traditional applications by incorporating agentic AI and personalized learning pathways. To evaluate the effectiveness of the integrated AI technology, a survey-based study revealed those integrations increased student engagement and enhanced comprehension of complex topics. However, the evaluation also indicates varied acceptance levels, with concerns regarding the optimal pacing of AI integration, the necessity for robust ethical oversight, and the ongoing challenge of maintaining a balance between AI support and instructor-led guidance. The findings offer actionable strategies for educators to align AI functionalities with pedagogical goals, providing insights into scalable, interdisciplinary AI-enhanced teaching practices. Future work will examine long-term retention and refined assessment frameworks.

title: WIP: Fostering Meaningful Reflective Practice Through Concept Mapping in Graduate Engineering Education
authors: Shih Hui Lee, Khairiyah Mohd-Yusof
abstract: This work in progress innovative practice category paper examines how integrating concept mapping as regular practice supports the development of reflexive engineering educators. Reflection is a crucial tool for developing students' professional growth and effectiveness as engineering educators. Nevertheless, graduate engineering students frequently struggle to reflect meaningfully by connecting educational theories with teaching experiences. In this study, concept mapping is employed to scaffold students in reflecting their experiences. Data were obtained through concept maps and weekly written reflections. Content analysis is used to show how concept mapping shapes students' reflective progression. A coding scheme based on Kember's reflection framework was developed to identify reflective elements in student work. Preliminary analysis showed that students who constructed more complex concept maps—incorporating more key concepts and linking words—typically engaged in deeper levels of reflection. As time progressed, some students' concept maps grew more sophisticated, with a corresponding advancement in reflection depth from habitual action to understanding and reflection levels. The study contributes to both theoretical understanding of reflective practice development and practical approaches for preparing future engineering educators. Additionally, the findings could inform strategies to scaffold understanding of concepts and reflective practice in engineering education, with potential applications across STEM disciplines.

title: Identification of Digital Competencies to Strengthen the Graduation Profile of Students Close to Graduation From a Polytechnic University in Central Mexico
authors: Martha P. Robles Gutiérrez, Noemi V. Mendoza Diaz, Lourdes E. Del Razo Robles, Omar A. Dominguez-Ramirez, Luis Arturo Guerrero Azpeitia
abstract: This research full paper describes a mixed-method study; it focused on identifying the components that make up the digital competencies of higher education students close to graduating from the industrial field. A four-phase methodology was developed: 1) Surveys and interviews; 2) Data analysis; 3) Definition and development of digital competencies; and 4) Reporting and dissemination of results. To gather the necessary data, two steps were undertaken: 1) Administration of questionnaires to 132 students, and 2) Conducting interviews with 10 faculty members and 5 employers from small and mediumsized enterprises in the region. The information collected was analyzed both separately and comparatively. The questionnaire design was based on international Digital competence frameworks proposed by leading scholars in the field. Interviews with faculty and employers were conducted at their workplaces to better understand their environments and enrich the responses with contextual insights. The interview design was supported by an analytical matrix that related digital usage to both substantive and operational functions of the graduate profile. Interview validation was carried out with two types of faculty members: part-time lecturers who teach specialized courses within the educational program, and full-time faculty (researchers) who are involved in research and development projects within productive sectors, besides their teaching responsibilities. The results of the study identified the digital competencies required to strengthen the student's graduate profile, comprising six key dimensions. The proposed digital competencies integrate students' digital skills, the criteria considered essential by faculty for effective learning, and the labor market demands identified by employers.

title: Clicker-Free Motion-Controlled Mouse Using Arduino
authors: Dheer Parikh, Michelle Tang, Jude Cheng, Puyuan Liu, Gyuseok L. Kim
abstract: This innovative practice full paper presents a project-based learning (PBL) experience in which high school students developed a clicker-free, motion-controlled mouse. Millions of individuals suffer from upper limb mobility impairments. At the same time, hand-held electronic devices have become increasingly integral to daily life, spanning both professional and recreational activities. Typical computer mice require clickerbased input, which can lead to significant accessibility challenges for individuals with limited hand mobility. This paper demonstrates an assistive device for individuals with fine motor skill impairments. This lightweight <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(40 ~\mathrm{g})$</tex>, body- wearable mouse alternative using Arduino and an MPU 9250 accelerometer and gyroscope enables cursor control and clicking via acceleration and tilt, allowing use with various body placements, such as the head, arm, or leg. Physical gestures are translated into computer inputs to eliminate physical buttons. These inputs are further analyzed and processed to reflect the functions of the mouse by coding. Students' reflections highlight that this PBL engages them in a real-world challenge. This hands-on project fosters interdisciplinary learning, problem-solving, and teamwork, allowing students to bridge theoretical concepts and real-world applications within microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) and computer engineering. Furthermore, a mastery experience with a high level of autonomy enables students to gain strong self-efficacy.

title: Learn to Enhance Sparse Spike Streams
authors: Liwen Hu, Yijia Guo, Mianzhi Liu, Yiming Fan, Rui Ma, Shengbo Chen, Lei Ma, Tiejun Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: High-speed vision tasks have long been a challenge in computer vision. Recently, the spike camera has shown great potential in these tasks due to its high temporal resolution. Unlike traditional cameras, it emits asynchronous spike signals to capture visual information. However, under low-light conditions, spike signals becomehighly sparse, and the sparse spike streamseverely hinders theeffectiveness of existing spike-based methods in high-speed scenarios. To address this challenge,we introduce SS2DS, the first deep learning framework that enhances sparse spike streams into dense spike streams. SS2DS first estimates the spike firing frequency within sparse streams. Subsequently, the spike firing frequency is enhanced by a neural network. Finally, SS2DS decodes the enhanced spike stream from the enhanced spike firing frequency sequence. SS2DS can adjust the temporal distribution of sparse spike streams and improve the performance degradation of existing methods in low-light and high-speed scenarios. In order to evaluate sparse spikestream enhancement,we construct both synthetic and real sparse spike stream datasets. The real dataset iscollected in dynamic scenarios using the third-generation spike camera.By comparing the reconstruction results, enhanced spike streams achieve an average improvement of +0.78 MA, -18.42 BRISQUE, and -1.42 NIQE over sparse spike streams. Moreover, the enhanced spike streams also benefit other spike-based vision tasks, such as 3D reconstruction (+1.325 dB PSNR, +0.005 SSIM, and -0.01 LPIPS) and super-resolution (+0.63 MA, -13.67 BRISQUE, and -1.28 NIQE). Code and datasets will be released after publication.

title: Integrating a Customized AI Chatbot in Database Design and Programming Course
authors: Shamima Mithun, Rajagopal Sankaranarayanan
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper describes our initiative to integrate a customized AI conversational agent in our Intro to Data Management course in Fall 2024 at Purdue University in the United States to support students with concept comprehension and in-class activities. This work uses a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) based customized chatbot using the Mindjoy application to provide students with precise and relevant responses. We customized the chatbot's capabilities by incorporating domain-specific knowledge and adding conversational constraints. This tailored chatbot was implemented in the CIT 21400 (Intro to Data Management) course to function as a tutor, enabling students to ask questions and receive customized answers within the context of their introductory database management curriculum. To evaluate its effectiveness, we conducted anonymous surveys based on the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and Self-Determination Theory (SDT). TAM was used to assess the perceived usefulness and ease of use with respect to the adoption of this new technology by students, while SDT offered insights into how the chatbot supported students' choices in learning (autonomy), their confidence in understanding the concepts of the database (competence) and their participation in the course material (relatedness). The surveys aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the AI tutor in the undergraduate course and the overall value of the comprehensive AI experience for students. Results indicated positive outcomes across all evaluation criteria, reinforcing TAM's hypothesis that perceived usefulness enhances the adoption of this technology. Students also provided constructive feedback for further improving the chatbot, highlighting key areas such as enhanced contextual awareness and greater adaptability to complex queries, though findings are exploratory given the limited sample.

title: A Literature Review on Engineering and Social Entrepreneurship Competencies for Developing Responsible and Entrepreneurial Engineering Workforce
authors: Arsalan Ashraf, Aileen Huang-Saad, Dayoung Kim
abstract: This research paper explores the competencies necessary for a responsible and entrepreneurial engineering workforce. Although there have been various efforts to identify and measure engineering entrepreneurship competencies, limited research has focused on expanding the scope to encompass social entrepreneurship competencies. Therefore, in this paper, we address the following research question: What social entrepreneurship competencies complement traditional engineering entrepreneurship knowledge, skills, and attitudes? To answer this research question, we conducted a literature review on engineering entrepreneurship competency and social entrepreneurship competency. By synthesizing the literature on those two topics, we identified competencies that can complement traditional engineering entrepreneurship knowledge, skills, and attitudes. Through the integration of these competencies in engineering education, engineers can develop abilities to develop innovative and responsible solutions to various societal challenges, fostering a new generation of technically skilled and socially conscious professionals. Ultimately, the results of this study will guide educational initiatives aimed at nurturing socially responsible and entrepreneurial leaders within the engineering workforce.

title: Large Language Model-based defect detection in context of industry 5.0
authors: Kai Quan Foong, Saaveethya Sivakumar, King Hann Lim, Chye Ing Lim, Ing Ming Chew, Siew Eng Fui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: The transition from manual labor to automation, driven by Industry 4.0 and the emerging Industry 5.0, has significantly transformed manufacturing. However, defects are still unavoidable in manufacturing, especially in the metal domain. To avoid substantial economic and reputational losses, defect detection is a must to guarantee long-term quality and durability of metal products. Despite high accuracy in defect detection, advanced Artificial Intelligence (AI) models like Large Language Models (LLMs) and Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) can optimize production processes, improve efficiency, and lower operational costs. This drives the emergence of AI agents, which are autonomous systems powered by advanced AI models to efficiently perform complex tasks. Thus, this paper is aimed to address the question of how LLMs and MLLMs can enhance defect detection efficiency and interpretability in Industry 5.0 manufacturing systems. To achieve this, a comparative and conceptual analysis is conducted among the studies applying LLMs and MLLMs in a workflow, in terms of data collection, models, and evaluation metrics. In addition, this paper also further studies the practical applications and limitations encountered among the studies.

title: Incremental 3D Panoptic Segmentation Using Texture and Depth Information
authors: Chun Wan Sia, King Hann Lim, Jonathan Then Sien Phang, Choo W. R. Chiong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Online 3D panoptic segmentation has encountered difficulty in processing input point cloud in large scene scenarios due to the unordered nature of point cloud. It requires several stages of point clustering and grouping in order to extract meaningful object instances. In this paper, an incremental segmentation pipeline is proposed to achieve real time panoptic segmentation. The proposed pipeline consists of a SLAMbased reconstruction system and a point-based segmentation model. The reconstruction pipeline employs a SLAM pipeline combined with a pinhole camera model for RGB-D to point cloud reconstruction. The use of the pinhole model removes the need for per-scene training and fully leverages the depth maps to generate point cloud with rich geometric detail. The reconstructed partial point cloud is then fed into a transformerbased model for incremental panoptic segmentation. A pointfiltering process is introduced to remove high-confidence points by comparing the new input with the previous frame. The filtering process eliminates redundant data, resulting in a more effective segmentation process and faster inference speed.

title: Meta Learning-based Multimodal Recommendation with Adaptive User Modality-Aware Preference Integration
authors: Zhenchao Wu, Hongteng Xu, Xu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Owing to the incorporation of multimodal content, multimodal recommender systems contribute to powerful representation learning and promote personalized recommendations. However, most existing methods directly mix various modality embeddings and ID embeddings by element-wise sum as final representations. This strategy hardly distinguishes the importance of different representations and entangles the ID and modality effects, and thus is unable to fully leverage multimodal features to facilitate personalized recommendations. To address this problem, we design a meta-weight net to learn the relevance between pairwise embeddings (including modality embeddings and ID embeddings) from users and items, respectively. Specifically, the proposed model first performs graph convolutional networks to generate the modality and ID representations for users and items. For each type of user representation, we calculate its relevance weights with all types of item representations with the designed meta-weight net. Afterward, we utilize these relevance weights to adaptively integrate the corresponding probability scores to calculate the final recommendation result. Moreover, we adopt contrastive learning to alleviate the data sparsity issue and introduce the KL divergence constraint to better align user preferences and multimodal content. Experiments on three public datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach performs better than the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Towards Personalized Programming Instruction Using Generative Language Models
authors: Julieto E. Perez, Jennifer Joyce M. Montemayor
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: As demand grows for flexible and personalized learning tools, especially for novice programmers, this work-in-progress investigates the use of generative language models to produce tailored explanations of programming concepts. In this study, GPT-3 was prompted to generate various explanation styles—direct, example-based, comparative, and analogical—to better align with diverse learner preferences. Human annotators evaluated and ranked the generated explanations, and their feedback was used to create a refined dataset. The generated dataset was then used to fine-tune a GPT-2 model, enabling it to produce context-aware and pedagogically relevant explanations. Preliminary results suggest that generative models can support the development of adaptive tutoring systems by generating educational content that responds to individual learning needs. Future work will focus on deeper evaluation, integration into interactive platforms, and assessing learner outcomes.

title: Study on the Competitiveness of High-Quality Development of Manufacturing Supply Chain in Jiangmen City
authors: Xiaoshi Chen, Muhamad Zulkiflee Osman, Wei Wei, Jixu Zhu, Lei Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Based on the analytic hierarchy process (AHP), this study constructs a competitiveness evaluation system for the high-quality development of manufacturing industry in Jiangmen City from the perspective of supply chain, which contains five first-level indicators and 22 third-level indicators, including industrial scale, industrial efficiency, innovation ability, green environmental protection and opening up. Through the AHP method to calculate the weight of each indicator and arrive at the comprehensive evaluation results, shows that the manufacturing industry of Jiangmen City has demonstrated a high level of competitiveness in a number of dimensions. Among them, “industrial scale” and “industrial efficiency” are particularly outstanding, becoming the core competitiveness; “opening up” and “green environmental protection” have also achieved remarkable results. The “opening-up” and “green environmental protection” aspects have also achieved remarkable results and enhanced the comprehensive competitiveness. However, the score of the “innovation ability” dimension is relatively low, which has become a key bottleneck restricting its high-quality development. The findings of the study can provide theoretical support and policy suggestions for the Jiangmen manufacturing industry to optimize supply chain management, enhance competitiveness and achieve high-quality development.

title: Adaptive Shaping and Characterization of Electrostatically Actuated Mesh Reflectors_supp1-3650229.pdf
authors: Zachary C. Cordero
abstract: Electrostatically actuated mesh reflectors are a promising technology for space-based sensing and communication antennas. Key advantages over current passive mesh reflectors include the ability to correct surface distortions (e.g., from manufacturing defects and environmental disturbances) and to achieve beam steering and beam shaping via dynamic adjustment of the reflector surface. Implementation of an electrostatically actuated mesh requires a method for determining optimal control voltages that achieve a desired reflector shape. This work demonstrates such an inverse method using a simplified numerical model of a linear isotropic elastic membrane subject to nonlinear electrostatic pressure. The model is used to determine the number of electrodes required to achieve a desired surface error. A prototype reflector, consisting of a 0.5-m diameter gold mesh and 9 electrodes, is constructed and various reflector shapes, including non-axisymmetric ones, are produced and refined using an open-loop controller based on the method. Before refinement, the experimentally measured RMS surface error is within 840μm of the target shape. The method is also shown to be useful for fine-tuning the shape; with only 3 iterations of surface refinement, the RMS error is reduced to within 231 μm. The experimentally characterized surface error proves that the method can adapt to unmodeled mechanics, achieving the desired shape precision for operation at 35 GHz Ka-band. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations of the target and experimental reflector surfaces were performed, and it was found that the fine-tuned surfaces had sufficient surface precision for convergence of the main lobe of the antenna pattern. This work demonstrates both the viability of, and method for achieving, shape control of an electrostatically actuated reflector.

title: Creating Smart Learning Objectives Relationship Between Application Engagement and Performance
authors: Chris M. Bahng, Anurag Srivastava, Daniel S. Bahng, Ahmed Ashraf Butt, Asefeh Kardgar, Swetha Nittala, Saira Anwar
abstract: This full research paper examines the impact of Educators Guidebook for Understanding Instruction by Design and Experience (EdGUIDE), a web-based software tool designed to guide instructors in creating aligned curricula. One of the features of the EdGUIDE tool aims to introduce the formulation of SMART learning objectives through a structured, three-step process based on Bloom's Taxonomy. We hypothesize that participants' application engagement (the amount of time spent with EdGUIDE) may impact their conceptual performance in creating SMART learning objectives. The primary research question guiding this investigation is: How does the participants' application engagement relate to the change in conceptual performance from pre-use to post-use of EdGUIDE? We employed a quantitative, correlational research design. We conducted Spearman's rank correlation and simple linear regression analyses to explore the relationship between application engagement and participants' conceptual performance with EdGUIDE. This paper examines the relationship between the learning objective creation process and the change in participants' conceptual performance from pre- to post-test. Our results found no statistically significant relationship between time spent and the change in test scores. The correlation values, however, suggest that participants become less engaged with each step of the learning objective creation process. The study suggests that improvements are needed to EdGUIDE's design, particularly in the process of creating learning objectives. Such changes may help to improve participants' application engagement and resulting performance. Future research should investigate the impact of such tools on instructors' stress and fatigue, and explore potential mechanisms to optimize EdGUIDE as an effective instructional design tool.

title: A Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Approach for Enhanced Spectrum Resource Allocation in NR-V2X Mode 2
authors: Xinyu Chen, Kexun He, Jing Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3 GPP) has introduced New Radio Vehicle-to-Everything (NR-V2X) as an evolution of Cellular V2X (C-V2X) to satisfy the increasingly stringent communication requirements of emerging V2X applications. In NR-V2X Mode 2, vehicles autonomously perform decentralized spectrum resource allocation via the Sensing-Based Semi-Persistent Scheduling (SPS) algorithm. Nevertheless, the performance of SPS significantly degrades under scenarios with high vehicle density and aperiodic traffic patterns, which hinders the system’s ability to meet Quality of Service (QoS) demands. To address these challenges, this study proposes MMATD3-SPS, an enhanced resource allocation algorithm that integrates a Multi-Agent Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MMATD3) framework into the conventional SPS scheme. By leveraging channel state information and application-layer metrics, and applying a reward decomposition strategy, the algorithm optimizes the resource selection process. Experimental results demonstrate that MMATD3-SPS improves the packet reception rate by approximately 10% in high-density traffic environments. Moreover, it ensures that 80% of data packets are updated within 100 milliseconds under aperiodic traffic conditions. These results highlight the proposed algorithm’s robustness and scalability, underscoring its potential for deployment in dynamic and complex vehicular communication scenarios.

title: PsyBART: A Large-Model-Based Dialogue System for Depression Therapy
authors: Wenlong Wu, Qian Yang, Yuezhi Yang, Yuchun Huang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Depression among university students is a significant concern, yet existing conversational AI systems in psychological counseling often struggle with generating contextually relevant and therapeutically effective responses. To address these challenges, we introduce PsyBART, a dialogue system based on the BART architecture, enhanced with preencoded expert knowledge from extensive counseling data. Our method allows for the generation of specialized and contextually appropriate responses tailored to mental health therapy. Experimental results show that PsyBART outperforms existing models across multiple metrics, including Readability, Informativeness, Personality, Specialization, Effectiveness, and Accuracy, demonstrating its potential as an effective tool for AIdriven psychological counseling.

title: Feature Mapping: an Approach to Improve Cross-Silo Federated Learning on Tabular Data
authors: Tomsy Paul, Muhammed Ashiq Ameer, Santhosh Kumar G
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL), since its introduction, has been primarily focusing on the cross-device realm. Many algorithms, assumptions, and issues found here are unsuitable for the Cross-silo realm. The FL algorithms on tabular data blindly assume that the features are exactly the same across all silos. Although feature naming standards exist, a vast amount of data generated even before the machine learning era still play a vital role in the learning process. We propose a simple technique called Feature Mapping, where the features of the global model are manually mapped to the features of local data before the commencement of FL. This one-time process ensures data minimization and also the presence of mandatory features in participating silos. The motivation behind the work is the analysis of actual data from the Electronic Health Records of Neuroblastoma patients from many hospitals worldwide. The proposed method has been tested on similar data from the TARGET Database of the National Cancer Institute of the United States on the Intel Open FL framework.

title: XAI-Enabled Deep Convolutional Model for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome Detection from Ultrasound Imaging
authors: Konduri Sai Meghana, Thasni T, Gadeela Shravinya, Sakhamuri Sri Sai Siri
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age, often diagnosed through ultrasound imaging. Manual interpretation is subjective and dependent on expert evaluation, leading to variability in clinical outcomes. This study develops an end-to-end deep learning framework for automated and explainable PCOS detection. The framework integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with transfer learning using pre-trained models such as VGG-16 and NASNet-Mobile, and employs Gradient-weighted Class Activation Map-ping (Grad-CAM) to provide visual explanations of classification decisions. Data augmentation was applied to address dataset limitations and improve generalization.A dataset of 150 annotated ultrasound images (100 training, 50 testing) was used. Models were trained to identify key features such as color intensity, texture patterns, contours, and cystic structures. Comparative evaluation showed that NASNet-Mobile achieved the highest accuracy (93.8%), outperforming VGG-16 (92.3%) and a baseline CNN (85.4%). Grad-CAM heatmaps confirmed the models focused on clinically significant regions, reinforcing diagnostic reliability.The results demonstrate that the proposed deep learning framework, enhanced with transfer learning and explainable AI, provides accurate and interpretable PCOS detection, supporting clinical decision-making and scalable integration into diagnostic workflows.

title: Quadrupped-Legged Robot Movement Plan Generation using Large Language Model
authors: Muhtadin, A. B. M. Vincentius Gusti Putu, Ahmad Zaini, Mauridhi Hery Purnomo, I Ketut Eddy Purnama, Chastine Fatichah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Traditional control interfaces for quadruped robots often impose a high barrier to entry, requiring specialized technical knowledge for effective operation. To address this, this paper presents a novel control framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) to enable intuitive, natural language-based navigation. We propose a distributed architecture where high-level instruction processing is offloaded to an external server to overcome the onboard computational constraints of the DeepRobotics Jueying Lite 3 platform. The system grounds LLM-generated plans into executable ROS navigation commands using real-time sensor fusion (LiDAR, IMU, and Odometry). Experimental validation was conducted in a structured indoor environment across four distinct scenarios, ranging from singleroom tasks to complex cross-zone navigation. The results demonstrate the system’s robustness, achieving an aggregate success rate of over 90% across all scenarios, validating the feasibility of offloaded LLM-based planning for autonomous quadruped deployment in real-world settings.

title: Towards Robust Gait Identification: A Frequency Domain Approach in Varied Surveillance Environments
authors: Yeojin Song, Luca Quagliato, Sewon Jang, Egene Chung, Seoyeon Ko, Seoyeong Hwang, Junhyug Noh, Taeyong Lee
abstract: This study introduces a frequency domain-based gait recognition framework designed to improve the accuracy of identifying and tracking individuals in diverse surveillance environments. Our approach transforms 2D gait variables, extracted from 25 key points, into frequency domain representations using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), effectively integrating video and sensor data. We developed the E-GAITS (Ewha GAit Identification Towards Surveillance system) dataset, which includes a wide range of environmental variables, to support this framework. The proposed methods, sensor value imitation and feature encoding, were extensively tested under various conditions, including different lighting scenarios and indoor/outdoor settings. The results demonstrate high recognition accuracy, with the integration of Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) sensor data significantly enhancing performance, especially in low-light conditions. Despite the reliance on the off-the-shelf pose estimation algorithm, which has limitations in poor lighting, the framework sets a new benchmark for gait-based identification systems and shows significant potential for applications in security and forensic analysis. Future work will focus on improving robustness and exploring additional biometric modalities to further enhance accuracy.

title: Comparative Analysis of Anatomic Plane MRI and Classifier Performance for Autism Spectrum Disorder Classification Using LBP-FOS Features
authors: Ari Kusumaningsih, I Ketut Eddy Purnama, Mauridhi Hery Purnomo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This comparative analysis presents a novel approach for Autism Spectrum Disorde (ASD) classification using Local Binary Pattern (LBP) features and First Order Statistics (FOS) features from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data. Our study, utilizing the Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange I (ABIDE I) dataset, implements a comprehensive framework that evaluates multi-plane versus single-plane approaches. Our study implements a comprehensive analysis framework incorporating multiplane (axial, coronal, and sagittal) and single-plane approaches, evaluating four distinct automatic slice selection methods. We utilized distinct machine learning classifiers to determine optimal classification performance across different anatomic planes. Results demonstrate that area-based slice selection with LBP features significantly enhances classification performance, with the multiplane approach consistently outperforming singleplane configurations. Notably, the axial plane yields superior discriminative features compared to other planes. When augmented by a voting mechanism across multiple planes, the Random Forest classifier achieved an accuracy of $\mathbf{9 2. 4 4 \%}$, establishing itself as the most reliable algorithm for ASD classification among the investigated classifiers.

title: Con-GBERT: Convolutional Attention-Based GBERT for Grapheme-to-Phoneme Conversion in Low-Resource Zhuang Language
authors: Qin Donghong, Wang Chunxi, Zhao Di, Wu Zhongyang, Zhao Zhuoyang, Bi Min, Bai Fengbo, Bao Dongxue
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: This study introduces Grapheme BERT (GBERT) to the grapheme-to-phoneme (G2P) task for the first time, specifically for the Zhuang language, a low-resource language with a complex tonal system. We developed a convolutional attention-based GBERT (Con-GBERT) pre-trained grapheme model, enhancing the traditional GBERT by introducing lightweight convolution modules to better model local grapheme features. Furthermore, a tone-aware weighted learning mechanism and a convolution-based attention improvement scheme were designed. Experiments on a proprietary Zhuang corpus demonstrated that the Con-GBERT-based G2P model performed exceptionally in both medium and low-resource G2P tasks. It achieved an error rate close to 1% under mediumresource conditions (8,000 training samples) and reduced the phoneme error rate (PER) and word error rate (WER) to 7.45% and $\mathbf{1 5. 4 0 \%}$, respectively, under low-resource conditions (1,000 training samples). These results significantly outperformed the traditional Transformer baseline model’s 16.38% PER and 32.40% WER. The findings indicate that the convolutional attention-based pre-trained grapheme model Con-GBERT offers a clear advantage in improving Zhuang G2P task accuracy and provides a new solution for speech technology research in low-resource tonal languages.

title: Deep Learning and Physical Unclonable Functions for Secure Authentication in Smart Environments
authors: Fulvio Bergantin, Alberto Falcone, Agostino Forestiero, Davide Macrì, Marzia Settino, Vincenzo Caligiuri, Antonio De Luca, Giorgia Mammoliti
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: User and device authentication is essential in smart environments to guarantee secure access to delicate information and systems. Traditional authentication methods, such as passwords and biometrics, often have significant vulnerabilities, including susceptibility to brute-force attacks and replication. This paper proposes an innovative authentication mechanism that leverages the strengths of Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) for generating unique device/user signatures and Siamese Neural Networks (SNNs) to accurately compare these signatures with certified ones. PUFs exploit the intrinsic manufacturing variations of hardware components to provide a unique, unclonable identifier for each user or device. In particular, optical PUFs use the inherent randomness and microscopic imperfections generated during the fabrication process in optical materials or structures. SNNs, designed to compare the similarity between two inputs by learning a shared embedding space, offer robust capabilities in identifying related entities based on limited or noisy data. Our approach enhances security by combining the unique properties of PUFs with the comparison abilities of SNNs, reducing computational overhead and storage requirements. The results show that the proposed method outperforms traditional authentication techniques in accuracy and resilience, offering a scalable solution for secure user and device authentication.

title: End-to-End Deep Learning and Machine Learning Framework for Chronic Heart Failure Detection from Phonocardiogram Signals
authors: G. Kalyani, Subashree R, Puli Ramya, Kodimela Sruthi, P. Deepika, Chinthareddy Ramya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Chronic heart failure (CHF) is a progressive and potentially life-threatening condition characterized by the heart's inability to pump blood efficiently. Early and accurate diagnosis is critical for effective disease management and improved patient outcomes. Traditional diagnostic methods such as echocardiography, although reliable, are costly, require specialized equipment, and are not always accessible in lowresource settings. Phonocardiogram (PCG) signals, which capture heart sounds using non-invasive and cost-effective digital stethoscopes, offer a promising alternative for automated screening. This study presents a hybrid framework combining traditional machine learning and end-to-end deep learning approaches for the detection of CHF from PCG recordings. The methodology involves comprehensive pre-processing for noise reduction, segmentation of cardiac cycles, and extraction of discriminative time-frequency features such as Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and spectrograms. Machine learning classifiers, including Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Random Forests, are compared with end-to-end convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures that learn directly from spectrogram representations. Experimental evaluation on publicly available and curated CHF-PCG datasets demonstrates that the proposed CNN-based approach achieves superior performance, with an accuracy exceeding 96%, sensitivity of 95.4 %, and specificity of 96.7 %, outperforming traditional ML models. The results highlight the potential of combining heart sound analysis with deep learning for reliable, low-cost, and accessible CHF screening in both clinical and remote healthcare settings.

title: Xiaohang: Research on the Construction and Application of Educational Intelligent Agents Based on Large Language Models
authors: Ying Li, Xiaozhou Zhang, Tongyu Zhu, Haifeng Gao, Guoliang Zhang, Guopeng Wang
abstract: This study focuses on developing educational agents capable of understanding and adapting to learners' complex cognitive behaviors. We propose a “Reverse Turing Test” (RTT) framework to evaluate AI's ability to perceive human cognition and construct an adaptive teaching agent, “Xiaohang,” based on Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs). The research employs four key methods: RTT, multimodal data perception, adaptive teaching strategies, and memory-reflection mechanisms. RTT captures learners' cognitive states through interactive dialogues, multimodal perception collects multidimensional data (text, speech, images), adaptive strategies adjust teaching plans based on real-time feedback, and memory-reflection mechanisms optimize subsequent teaching outcomes. Experiments conducted in project-based learning (PBL) scenarios demonstrate that Xiaohang significantly enhances the quality of problem formulation, creativity in solution design, and task completion efficiency, validating its effectiveness in improving educational outcomes.

title: Beyond the Naked Eye: Automated Delivery Analysis in Cricket with Computer Vision
authors: Muhammad Shoaib Ahmad, Rana Umer Riaz, Naeem Ullah, Faisal Bukhari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Computer vision has really changed how we track and analyze performance in sports. By using automated imaging feedback, coaches can assess players, spot key events, and rethink strategies far faster than by watching tape alone. Cricket provides a vivid case study: researchers now employ neural networks for ball tracking, pose estimation, and play identification. Yet most commercial setups cost a small fortune, because they bundle multiple synchronized cameras with specialist hardware that grassroots clubs cannot afford. To bridge that gap, the present work describes a single-camera, budget-minded system that still delivers detailed ball-tracking data. A bespoke computer-vision pipeline stitches together off-the-shelf components and open-source code. Core routines include a tuned YOLOv5 detector, a linear Kalman filter, and a custom homography stage that maps field coordinates from standard video. Rigorous backyard trials confirm the pipeline dishes out useful objective metrics, but uneven homography calibration remains the fly in the ointment as it drags accuracy down when the camera angle shifts quickly. The system proves itself as a lightweight coaching aide, not as a rival to the super-slo-mo rigs seen on television. Moving forward, we’ll need to tackle these issues like bouncing camera mounts, glare, and shifting light conditions while also expanding the analysis tools so community clubs can gain deeper insights without stretching their budgets.

title: A Comparative Analysis of HPS and MMoE Models for Multi-Task Learning: Empirical Evaluation on Office-31 and NYUv2 Datasets.
authors: Chung-Yi Tu, Amina Enkhbayar, Ariel Pratama Menlolo
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: Balancing shared representations and task-specific demands is a key challenge in multi-task learning (MTL). This study compares Hard Parameter Sharing (HPS) and Multi-Gate Mixture-of-Experts (MMoE) against Single-Task Learning (STL) on two datasets: Office-31 for domain-specific classification and NYUv2 for complex semantic and geometric tasks. Results show that STL outperforms MTL methods on tightly coupled, small-scale tasks (Office-31). Conversely, MMoE excels on NYUv2 tasks like depth estimation and surface normal prediction, highlighting its strength in dynamically managing task conflicts and enhancing specialization.
