title: Multi-Objective Optimization for Charging Paths Planning and Energy Efficiency in UAV-Assisted Wireless Rechargeable Sensor Networks
authors: Shuaiwei Wang, Sujin Hou, Dandan Ou, Chen Zhang, Fang Mei, Lu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for long-range energy replenishment and data collection in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) across various scenarios seeks to minimize energy consumption by optimizing the scheduling and visiting sequence of the UAV’s hovering points. The problem can be modeled as a joint scheduling and trajectory optimization problem (JSTOP). To address the challenges posed by the limitations of the traditional JSTOP algorithm, we propose a multi-objective optimization algorithm-based joint scheduling and trajectory optimization scheme (MOJSTOP), which consists of two sub-algorithms, the improved multi-objective simulated annealing algorithm (Improved MSA) and the improved non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (Improved NSGA-II). The Improved MSA algorithm is well-suited for small-scale scenarios. In contrast, the Improved NSGA-II algorithm is designed for large-scale scenarios where the UAV has limited energy capacity. In addition, it introduces a new optimization objective that focuses on the energy utilization efficiency of the UAV. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed MOJSTOP scheme exhibits superior computational efficiency, convergence, and stability in solving the JSTOP problem compared to other algorithms and is applicable to various terrains.

title: FFE-DETR: Frequency-Aware Feature Enhancement for Object Detection in Low-Light Scenarios
authors: Yufeng Li, Chao Song, Chuanlong Xie
abstract: Object detection is a core task in computer vision, yet its performance is severely degraded in low-light environments, where foreground objects blend into the background, feature contrast is reduced, and object boundaries become blurred, ultimately impairing detection accuracy. To address this problem, we propose FFE-DETR, an end-to-end detection framework specifically designed for low-light scenes. The model incorporates a Frequency-Aware Feature Enhancer that applies Laplacian pyramid decomposition to separate low-frequency and high-frequency components. The low-frequency features are globally modeled to enhance foreground saliency and emphasize object boundaries, and the enhanced representation subsequently guides high-frequency detail restoration and noise suppression, yielding clearer and more discriminative features. In addition, a Multi-Scale Adaptive Feature Fusion module is introduced to efficiently integrate shallow texture information with deep semantic cues, enhancing the feature representation capability across different scales. Experimental results on widely used low-light benchmarks demonstrate that FFE-DETR consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods and achieves significantly superior detection accuracy, highlighting its effectiveness and robustness.

title: A Multiphysics Domain Decomposition Method for Transient Electro-Thermo-Mechanical Analysis
authors: Qi Qiang Liu, Hongyang Li, Shuai Zhang, Absalom E. Ezugwu, Wen-Sheng Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: This paper presents a novel multiphysics domain decomposition method (DDM) for fully transient electro-thermo-mechanical analysis of complex electronic devices, based on the dual-primal finite element tearing and interconnecting (FETI-DP) framework. The global problem is reduced to a system involving interface and corner degrees of freedom, together with independent subdomain problems, thereby significantly lowering computational complexity. A nodal integration scheme constructs system matrices directly using Vandermonde and differentiation matrices, supporting non-uniform high-order interpolation without Gaussian quadrature. Physics-dependent subdomain partitioning enables tailored discretization for each physical field, enhancing modeling flexibility and algorithmic generality. The method maintains high accuracy in large-scale simulations, supports automatic corner-node selection, and is inherently parallelizable. Several benchmarks validate its accuracy, efficiency, and scalability in simulating challenging transient electro-thermo-mechanical problems.

title: Question Understanding and Temporality Guiding for Video Question Answering
authors: Jiahao Lu, Sisi You, Bing-Kun Bao
abstract: Video Question Answering (VideoQA) aims to answer a question based on the content of a given video. Recent methods adapt image-text pre-trained models to the VideoQA task by designing learnable temporal modules within the image encoder. However, these methods struggle to fully comprehend the questions and effectively extract temporal information due to 1) over-reliance on candidate answers and 2) lack of explicit temporal modeling. Specifically, since the question is fixed in different question-answer pairs, existing models tend to focus on the varying candidate answers. Moreover, existing methods merely utilize the classification loss to constrain the confidence of candidate answers, failing to differentiate the effectiveness of temporal information and to explicitly guide temporal modeling. In this paper, we introduce the Question Understanding and Temporality Guiding (QU-TG) method to address the aforementioned limitations. To reduce over-reliance on candidate answers, we propose providing diverse questions through question selection and enhancing the model's comprehensive understanding of questions through question-video matching. To conduct explicit temporal modeling guiding, we propose negative video prevention and positive video guidance to conduct explicit temporal modeling guiding. Negative video prevention incorporates a prevention loss to discourage the model from making predictions based on erroneous temporal cues, whereas positive video guidance utilizes classification loss to encourage the model to derive correct answers from positive videos. Extensive experiments on the NExT-QA, IntentQA, STAR-QA, and Causal-VidQA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and generalization of our method.

title: Early Stage Fault Detection of Rolling Bearing Using a VMD-TEO-RF Framework
authors: Muhammad Jamshaid Khan, Sun Beibei, Xiao Songhua, Hou Junqi
abstract: Rolling bearings play a vital role in mechanical systems by supporting rotational motion, minimizing friction, and sustaining heavy loads. However, reliable fault detection remains challenging due to the nonlinear and non-stationary characteristics of vibration signals. This study proposes a hybrid fault diagnosis method that integrates Variational Mode Decomposition (VMD) with the Teager Energy Operator (TEO) to enhance the fault-related features in vibration signals. The extracted features are classified using machine learning algorithms, with a primary focus on Random Forest (RF). The performance of the proposed VMD-TEO-RF approach is benchmarked against other classifiers including K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) and Support Vector Machine (SVM). The VMD-TEO-RF model achieved a classification accuracy of 99.9%, outperforming KNN (85%), and SVM (90%). Additionally, a comparative analysis with the conventional Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) method highlights the superior sensitivity and accuracy of the proposed technique. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in detecting incipient faults in rolling bearings, offering a reliable and scalable solution for predictive maintenance in industrial applications.

title: Carbon-Efficient Internet Video Streaming
authors: Zichen Zhu, Tian Guo, Sheng Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Carbon-efficient computing has drawn significant attention recently aiming to achieve environmental sustainability. Several computation intensive applications, such as deep learning, have been studied in the community for carbon optimizations. However, video streaming, one of the most popular and resource-consuming Internet applications, is under-explored for carbon efficiency. In this paper, we for the first time investigate the carbon efficiency of video streaming systems with the goal of reducing carbon emissions caused by hosting the video streaming service. We develop a dynamic workload migration mechanism utilizing real-time carbon intensity data to select the hosting data center. Furthermore, to minimize the impact on the end-user experience, we consider the migration frequency to maintain service stability when making the migration decisions. The evaluation results indicate significant carbon reductions and acceptable stream switching overhead.

title: RRC Signaling Storm Detection in O-RAN
authors: Dang Kien Nguyen, Rim El Malki, Filippo Rebecchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) marks a significant shift in the mobile network industry. By transforming a traditionally vertically integrated architecture into an open, data-driven one, O-RAN promises to enhance operational flexibility and drive innovation. In this paper, we harness O-RAN’s openness to address one critical threat to 5G availability: signaling storms caused by abuse of the Radio Resource Control (RRC) protocol. Such attacks occur when a flood of RRC messages from one or multiple User Equipments (UEs) deplete resources at a 5 G base station (gNB), leading to service degradation. We provide a reference implementation of an RRC signaling storm attack, using the OpenAirInterface (OAI) platform to evaluate its impact on a gNB. We supplement the experimental results with a theoretical model to extend the findings for different load conditions. To mitigate RRC signaling storms, we develop a threshold-based detection technique that relies on RRC layer features to distinguish between malicious activity and legitimate high network load conditions. Leveraging O-RAN capabilities, our detection method is deployed as an external Application (xApp). Performance evaluation shows attacks can be detected within 90 ms, providing a mitigation window of 60 ms before gNB unavailability, with an overhead of $1.2 \%$ and $0 \%$ CPU and memory consumption, respectively.

title: Enhancing 2-Wheeler Safety Through Adaptive Data Management with Fuzzy Logic
authors: Cláudio Asensio, Marcos Mendes, Pedro Rito, Duarte Raposo, Susana Sargento
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The growing need for healthier and more ecofriendly city transport has empowered the enforcement of electric and smart bikes, which integrate sensors and communication technologies to improve monitoring and safety. This paper presents a data management architecture designed to enhance the efficiency and adaptability of 2-wheeler monitoring and safety systems. The architecture integrates a data stream service and a persistence system, using fuzzy logic to dynamically prioritize and manage data transmission. The data stream service ensures the delivery of critical messages, such as diagnostics, malfunction and safety alerts, while the persistence system stores data batches and schedules their transmission based on factors such as priority, deadlines, and expiration status. Experimental evaluations show that fuzzy logic-based prioritization significantly reduces message waiting times, outperforming traditional approaches. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed solution in ensuring reliable and timely data management under varying conditions.

title: Visualizing Quadratic Attributes Using Projectile Simulator and Real Life Examples
authors: Divya Kaushal, Sheng-Jen Hsieh
abstract: This innovative practice full paper presents an interdisciplinary instructional module for teaching quadratic functions to high school sophomores and juniors, addressing the challenge students face in differentiating between quadratic and linear functions, particularly their graphical representations. Students use PhET interactive simulators to explore the characteristics of quadratic functions, including concavity, increasing interval, decreasing interval and rate of change. The practical applications of quadratic functions, particularly in sports and science (e.g., projectile motion), are emphasized to connect the abstract concepts to real-world scenarios. The effectiveness of the module was assessed through pre- and post-tests. T-tests and F-tests were conducted to analyze the data. The t-test revealed a statistically significant learning gain of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 \%}(\mathbf{p}<0.001)$</tex> after implementing the module. The rejection of the F-test suggests that individual learning gains varied among students.

title: Analyzing Lifestyle and Predicting Longevity Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Ignatius Kevin Wijaya, Akmal Hendrian Malik, Diana, Shania Priccilia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Life expectancy is a key indicator of population health, influenced by a complex combination of socioeconomic, health, and demographic factors. The purpose of this study is to evaluate three machine learning models-Random Forest (RF), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN)-using the WHO life expectancy dataset. The methodology involves data preprocessing, feature optimization through Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), and model evaluation using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and R-squared ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$). The results show that $\mathbf{R F}$ achieved the highest predictive accuracy ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=$ 0.9701, MAE $=1.0092$), followed by XGBoost ($R^{2}=0.9663$, MAE $=1.1672$), and ANN ($\mathbf{R}^{2}=0.9399$, MAE $=1.6155$). Notably, XGBoost was the most computationally efficient model. Across all models, HIV/AIDS prevalence, income composition, and adult mortality were identified as the most influential features.

title: The Overlooked Role of 'Academic' Sense of Belonging: A Multi-Methods Study of Academic and Social Sense of Belonging Among Students in Globalized Engineering Graduate Education
authors: Monica Perez Olmedo, Alex Struck Jannini, Wilson Marcias, Eunsil Lee
abstract: Students' sense of belonging is a critical factor influencing their academic and psychological outcomes. Despite the theoretical distinction between social and academic sense of belonging in higher education, prior literature in engineering and computing education has predominantly emphasized the social dimension of sense of belonging. To address this gap, this multi-methods research explores the multidimensional nature of sense of belonging - academic and social sense of belonging - in the context of globalized engineering graduate education, while navigating students' perceptions of uniquely globalized educational setting. The quantitative survey study aims to investigate how academic and social sense of belonging within different two types of engineering graduate student communities - a research lab and an academic unit - interact in influencing students' satisfaction and intention to stay. The study considers the potential interplay of students' citizenship status (e.g., domestic vs. international) in shaping their academic and social sense of belonging. The qualitative open-ended survey study aims to explore how students perceive the advantages of and challenges in the globalized educational environment, understanding how the context-specific characteristics interact with students' sense of belonging and broader educational experiences. The findings suggest that academic and social sense of belonging play distinct roles in shaping different types for engineering graduate students, while also highlighting the significance of academic sense of belonging - an often-overlooked aspect of sense of belonging in literature - in influencing students' intention to stay. This research contributes to advancing the sense of belonging literature by expanding the conceptual understanding of sense of belonging.

title: Sea Animal-Inspired Metaheuristics for No-Wait Flexible Flow Shop Scheduling in Small-Scale Bakery Enterprises
authors: Cecilia E. Nugraheni, L. Abednego, G. Eugene
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: This study investigates the performance of three sea animal-inspired metaheuristic algorithms—Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA), Jellyfish Search Optimizer (JSO), and Walrus Optimization Algorithm (WaOA)—in addressing the No-Wait Flexible Flow Shop Scheduling Problem (NWFFSP) in the context of small-scale bakery production. The scheduling problem is modeled as a two-stage process with heterogeneous machines and strict no-wait constraints, and evaluated under both single-objective and multi-objective scenarios. Three experiments are conducted to assess algorithm performance based on makespan and total oven idle time (ToIT), using a factorial parameter design across sixteen configurations. Results indicate that JSO consistently outperforms the other two algorithms in both solution quality and robustness, while WaOA provides stable alternatives with moderate competitiveness. WOA performs weaker and is more sensitive to parameter tuning. These findings offer practical insights into the suitability and behavior of sea-inspired metaheuristics in real-world scheduling applications. This work contributes a reproducible benchmark and comparative insights for future research on bio-inspired scheduling techniques.

title: Development of A Data-Driven Adaptive Setpoint Recommendation for Energy and Emission Optimization in Air Conditioning Systems
authors: Irdina Rusyda Kamila Arsil, Muhammad Suryanegara, Listyo Edi Prabowo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: In most cases, air conditioning units are commonly operated at static temperature settings, often without adjustment to changing environmental or occupancy conditions. This results in excessive energy consumption and has the potential to compromise occupant thermal comfort. This research presents the development of an IoT-based system designed to optimize energy consumption of AC usage through automated recommendations based on real-time data collection. The system integrates environmental and occupancy sensors with an artificial neural network-based nonlinear regression model that is trained to predict AC power consumption based on features such as room humidity, climate conditions, and room occupancy levels. The optimal AC temperature setting is determined through an optimization algorithm to achieve the minimal power consumption target. A responsive web dashboard is developed as a user interface that provides real-time monitoring of data related to AC energy usage, environmental conditions, room comfort level, and released carbon emission. This dashboard also displays the generated recommendations based on current condition. A test conducted in a classroom in Faculty of Engineering Universitas Indonesia resulted in an achieved energy savings and emission reduction up to 42,36% under controlled conditions. This is also while maintaining thermal comfort measured using the PMV index. The result of this study shows that a data-driven recommendation approach supported by user awareness can significantly improve the energy efficiency of AC usage.

title: Implementation of Business Intelligence in Analyzing Merchant Sales E-Stall Crunchy
authors: Santoso Sant, Rama Rosadi, Nizirwan Anwar, Tugiman Tugiman, Rico Septia Bimawan
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Utilizing data for strategic decision-making is the key to business success. Merchant E-Stall Crunchy faces challenges in analyzing large and complex sales data to enhance its performance and competitiveness. Therefore, the implementation of Business Intelligence (BI) is essential to enable effective and efficient sales data analysis. This study aims to implement a BI system capable of providing strategic insights for the merchant through interactive data visualization, sales trend analysis, and the identification of best-selling products and peak sales periods. The study employs the Design Science Research (DSR) method, which includes the stages of problem identification, implementation, and evaluation. The data used in this research are derived from the Merchant E-Stall Crunchy sales database, which includes daily transactions, product categories, and customer information. The tools utilized include Claude 3.7 Sonnet for comprehensive data visualization. System evaluation is conducted using the User Acceptance Testing (UAT) approach to measure effectiveness and user satisfaction. The expected outcomes of this study are analytical reports on sales trends and recommendations for data-driven marketing strategies.

title: Artificial Neural Network MPPT and Intelligent Energy Management for Grid-Integrated Hybrid PV-Wind-Battery Systems
authors: Ahnaf Rashid, Ahmed Zubair
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: This paper presents the design and simulation of a grid-connected hybrid renewable energy system that integrates solar photovoltaic (PV) systems and Wind Energy Conversion Systems (WECS) with a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) via a centralized DC bus architecture. The system incorporates boost converters for renewable sources, a bidirectional DC-DC converter for efficient BESS control, and a full-bridge inverter equipped with an LCL filter to facilitate reliable interaction with the grid. The Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm is employed to maximize renewable energy extraction, offering faster response and enhanced efficiency in comparison with traditional methods. Additionally, a comprehensive energy management strategy, guided by realtime renewable energy generation and the state of charge (SOC) of the BESS, governs the coordinated operation of battery charging and discharging, as well as power exchange with the grid, thereby enabling seamless bidirectional power flow and optimal system performance. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed system in enabling real-time control, efficient energy management, and robust grid interaction under dynamic operating conditions. Keywords-artificial neural network (ANN), maximum power point tracking (MPPT), photovoltaic (PV) system, wind energy conversion system (WECS), battery energy storage system (BESS).

title: Security of the Three-Pass Protocol on Permutations
authors: Artem Lavdanskyi, Emil Faure, Vitalii Bondar, Oleksandr Kharin, Alimzhan Baikenov, Sakhybay Tynymbayev
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In the context of modern digital communication, securing information exchange is increasingly critical, particularly against evolving threats in cryptanalysis. This research investigates the security aspects of the three-pass protocol based on permutations, focusing on identifying and mitigating potential vulnerabilities. The study proposes a set of guidelines for ensuring secure communication through this protocol. The protocol’s robustness against brute-force attacks is analyzed and compared with other well-known cryptographic protocols, such as the Shamir three-pass protocol and the MasseyOmura cryptosystem. The results highlight the importance of key length and permutation structure in maintaining security, particularly when dealing with large key spaces. Additionally, the practical implications of implementing this protocol in real-time communication systems, considering the computational demands and potential optimizations are explored.

title: Designing Meta-Intelligent Adaptive Cybersecurity Architectures to Enable Real-Time Threat Mitigation in Immersive, Multi-Layered Internet Infrastructure Ecosystems
authors: Sharon M, Shaik Valli Haseena, Trapty Agarwal, S. Pragadeswaran, Tarun Kapoor, T Ravi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The growing complexity of the multi-layered Internet infrastructure eco-systems e.g. smart cities, industrial IoT networks, and extended reality ecosystems requires evolutionary intelligent and adaptive cybersecurity frameworks with the real-time threat mitigation capabilities. This paper is going to present a new Meta-Cognitive Swarm Intelligencedriven Cyber Defense Architecture (MCSI-CDA) that brings well-coordinated meta-cognitive learning, swarm intelligence, and zero-trust enforcement to autonomously and proactively provide planless and continuous cyber defense. Its architecture features Meta-Cognitive Learning Engine (MCLE) which can self-regulate the detection strategies on the basis of uncertainty in the environmental situation and past performance. Considering the idea of how resilience and fault tolerance can be achieved, a Swarm Intelligence Coordination Layer (SICL) can offer decentralized anomaly consensus based on bioinspired optimization algorithms. The Zero-Trust Policy Enforcer (ZTPE) provides stringent access control and blockchain-based auditability with the Multi-Layered Threat Perception Module (MTPM) tracing contextual anomalies through graph neural networks across the physical, cyber and application layers. Moreover, a Quantum-Resilient Cryptographic Unit (QRCU), protecting communication channels against quantum-powered adversaries in the future, is also in use. Collectively these will constitute a single, selfadaptive security infrastructure with the ability to learn, grow and react in milliseconds. The suggested MCSI-CDA framework is an important advance on the way to the development of intelligent, real-time, and scalable cybersecurity solutions applied to the next generations of hyper-connected digital frameworks. The suggested MCSI-CDA approach has an overall accuracy of 97.8%.

title: Thermally Robust AlScN Memristors With Thickness-Optimized Resistive Switching for Harsh Environment_supp1-3650484.docx
authors: Jingjing Chang
abstract: AlScN-based memristors exhibit significant potential for nonvolatile memory storage and neuromorphic computing applications. However, the mechanisms underlying resistive switching in AlScN-based devices at subcoercive fields remain an open question. Here, we present a single-layer AlScN-based memristor and investigate the impact of AlScN film thicknesses on storage performance. Remarkably, the storage window of the memristor increases progressively with increasing AlScN film thickness. The switching ratio reaches approximately 300 for the AlScN-based device. Moreover, the effects of high-temperature annealing on memristor performance demonstrate that the devices maintain excellent uniformity and reproducibility and preserve a well-defined memory window (~9) even after 10 min of thermal treatment at 1073 K.

title: Robust Phantom-Assisted Framework for Multi-Person Localization and Vital Signs Monitoring Using MIMO FMCW Radar_supp1-3651442.pdf
authors: Yonathan Eder
abstract: With rising cardiovascular and respiratory disorders and an aging population, healthcare systems require efficient non-contact vital sign monitoring (NCVSM) solutions. This study introduces a robust framework for multi-person localization and vital signs monitoring using multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar in cluttered environments. First, we developed a hardware phantom that simulates multi-person NCVSM scenarios using recorded thoracic impedance signals to replicate cardiopulmonary dynamics, enabling repeatable validation under diverse conditions. Second, we designed a robust algorithm for multi-person localization leveraging sparse signal processing with physiological characteristics, alongside dictionary-based vital signs estimation that handles interfering respiration harmonics. An adaptive signal refinement procedure enhances continuous NCVSM accuracy by leveraging estimate continuity. Performance was validated through 12 phantom trials and 12 human trials in single- and multi-person scenarios, demonstrating superior performance. In multi-person human trials, our method achieved respiration rate accuracies of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$94.14\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$98.12\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$98.69\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> within error thresholds of 2, 3, and 4 breaths per minute, respectively, and heart rate accuracies of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$87.10\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$94.12\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$95.54\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> within the same thresholds, highlighting the framework's potential for reliable healthcare and IoT applications.

title: Model Quantization for Resource-Efficient DNN Implementation of MAC Protocols in Industrial IoT
authors: Luciano Miuccio, Daniela Panno, Salvatore Riolo, Antonino Salemi, Anita Schilirò
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming a key enabler in Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) applications, supporting intelligent functionalities such as predictive maintenance, energy optimization, and adaptive communication. However, deploying Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) on resource-constrained IoT devices (IoTDs) remains a significant challenge due to limited computational resources, memory, and energy availability. In this paper, we investigate the effectiveness of model quantization techniques in reducing the computational and memory demands of DNNs, with a focus on the implementation of MAC protocols learned via Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL). Specifically, we evaluate Post-Training Quantization (PTQ), static and dynamic, targeting inference on general-purpose CPUs embedded in Microcontroller Units (MCUs). We assess the performance of these techniques based on deployment metrics (disk usage, runtime memory, and inference time) and communication metrics (e.g., throughput). Experimental results demonstrate that quantization significantly improves deployability on constrained hardware while maintaining good levels of communication performance, enabling efficient integration of AI-based MAC protocols in HoT networks.

title: Integrating Behavioural Science using the Psycho-Intelligence Framework in Connected Systems
authors: Celestine Iwendi, Ezekiel Gabriel Nwibo, Vandana Sharma, Collins Lemeke, Salome Enoshi Uwah, Kumasuun Kimberly Ukura
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The fast-growing convergence of neuroscience, behaviour computing, and adaptive artificial intelligence (AI) offers the possibility to transform human, machine interaction. This work presents Psycho-Intelligence, a new, closed-loop system that merges electroencephalography (EEG) and inertial motion unit (IMU) signals to adaptively recognise and react to users' cognitive and affective states. Levying low-cost wearable sensors (Muse EEG and MPU-6050), the system has real-time signal acquisition, sophisticated preprocessing, spectral and statistical feature extraction, as well as multimodal fusion features. Dimensionality reduction and feature selection techniques, including Principal Component Analysis and XGBoost gain metrics, enhance learning optimally. Multiple machine learning algorithms like Random Forest, SVM and XGBoost are trained to identify engagement states with high accuracy, warranted by extensive testing through cross-validation, ROC AUC, and F1-scores. The pipeline is incorporated into an adaptive feedback system that can regulate chatbot tone, learning material, or interactive graphics based on detected user states. Statistical validation with linear mixed models confirms the robustness of EEG-derived measurements in engagement prediction. The research establishes a new paradigm for emotionally intelligent AI systems and provides a technical foundation for ethical, real-time psycho-behavioural intelligence for communication networks, education systems, and cognitive health monitoring.

title: Enhancing 6LoWPA Performance in Lossy Networks Using Complex and Combined Header Compression
authors: Nin Hayati Mohd Yusoff, Kamil Abdullah, Julkifli Ag. Besar, Norazlina Ahmad, Anu Sathyajith Mathew, Axel Sikora
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Header compression is vital for efficient IPv6 communication in constrained IoT networks like 6LoWPAN. However, traditional IP Header Compression (IPHC) lacks selective retransmission and optimized fragmentation, reducing its effectiveness in lossy environments. This study evaluates three strategies-IPHC-only, Static Context Header Compression (SCHC)-only, and a combination IPHC + SCHC-using Contiki-NG and the Cooja simulator on a multi-hop Sky mote mesh network under varying success rates ($40 \%-100 \%$), focusing on energy consumption, latency, and retransmission overhead. Results show the IPHC + SCHC combination outperforms both standalone methods across all metrics. At $40 \%$ success, it lowers energy use by $28 \%$ over IPHC-only and $16 \%$ over SCHC-only. Latency drops by $27 \%$ and $13 \%$, respectively, while retransmissions are cut by $35 \%$ and $15 \%$. These gains stem from combining IPHC’s lightweight compression with SCHC’s selective ACK-on-Error retransmission. This combination offers a scalable, energy-efficient solution for real-time, lowpower IoT networks in smart cities, CPS, and industry. Future work will examine secure compression using DTLS and OSCORE, real deployments, and machine learning-based context adaptation.

title: Innovations to SAP ERP Platform Cybersecurity: Hybrid Cryptographic Techniques for Integrity, Authentication, and Confidentiality in International Business Operations
authors: Chandra Doddapalli Ramachandra Reddy, Sumanth Aswath Narayana, Sathiyandrakumar Srinivasan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system is what keeps businesses running all around the world. It assists with shipping, finance, the supply chain, and managing people in international trade. As businesses travel to foreign nations, it gets difficult to protect ERP systems because of different rules, IT platforms, and more advanced cyber threats. Some of the time, standard cybersecurity measures work, but they don't usually defend the areas of integrity, authentication, and secrecy as well as big corporations need them to. This article talks about innovative ways to make SAP ERP systems safer, like using hybrid cryptography. These measures make sure that vital firm information stays safe, is only available to people who need to see it, and is kept safe from others who shouldn't be able to read it. The system that is being presented uses both symmetric and asymmetric cryptography, as well as more advanced methods like elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) and homomorphic encryption. Because symmetric encryption works well, it can be used to send a lot of data. On the other hand, asymmetric approaches are good for making sure that people are who they say they are and keeping keys safe. We can do secure math on encrypted data with homomorphic encryption without giving up any of the original data. They follow international rules including HIPAA, GDPR, and ISO 27001, which makes businesses feel safe from legal and operational problems. Case-based simulations show that data privacy has improved, authentication times have gone down, and the system is more resistant to common attack types like man-in-the-middle, brute force, and insider threats. This study improves the cybersecurity of businesses by showing how well hybrid cryptography can solve the unique problems of keeping SAP ERP systems safe in worldwide settings. Adding these new ways not only makes the system stronger, but it also makes sure that business around the world works smoothly, lawfully, and with resilience. As cyber risks grow, our research shows that new ideas in cryptography are needed to maintain multinational businesses safe, dependable, and working smoothly.

title: MIPS: Scalable Multi-Level Architecture for Real-Time MQTT Protocol Security in IoT
authors: Agostino Forestiero, Antonio F. Gentile, Emilio Greco, Davide Macrì
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has established the MQTT protocol as a de facto standard for lightweight, machine-to-machine communication. Existing intrusion-detection solutions often incur prohibitive latency for edge devices or fail to detect subtle, protocol-level attacks. We introduce MIPS (MQTT Intrusion Prevention System), based on a three-stage architecture that combines (ⅰ) ultrafast volume screening, (ⅱ) MQTT-semantic classification, and (ⅲ) adaptive behavioural analytics. Level 1 uses a five-feature Random Forest model to classify 72.1% of all traffic with an average latency of just 0.0156 ms per flow. Samples with low confidence are escalated to Level 2, a 30-feature Gradient Boosting classifier, while the most ambiguous 2.8% are passed to a Level 3 neural network for advanced pattern analysis. We evaluated MIPS on a proprietary corpus of 15 000 MQTT flows (3.07:1 attack-to-normal ratio). On a split of 10 000 training and 5000 test flows, MIPS achieves a final F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>-score of 0.893 and an accuracy of 90.2%. In the comparative benchmark conducted for this study, MIPS obtained a higher F1-score than all tested single-stage baselines, including Random Forest and XGBoost. This detection performance is achieved while sustaining a throughput of 82 776 flows/s, validating the architecture’s suitability for real-time edge environments.

title: Multidimensional Assessment of Sustainable Development Projects
authors: Kateryna Kolesnikova, Tetiana Olekh, Ardak Mukhamediyeva, Bohdan Haidabrus, Zhanibek Kairatuly
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In this paper, a new multi-aspect evaluation model for sustainable development projects is developed with the aid of the Markov chain. In contrast to traditional methods, which commonly fail to account for the dynamic stochastic character of the implementation process, the proposed model takes the complexity of project behaviors into account by decomposing it into a set of well-defined states, along with their transition probabilities. The structure provides better visibility into project outcomes so you can make proactive, data-driven decisions. A directed graph and a state transition matrix are employed to represent the process, providing six different levels at which success is evaluated. Using probabilistic evaluation, the model facilitates the early recognition of risks and increases the certainty of project planning and performance. With this method, you can monitor and adjust to the evolving real work in progress and increase the likelihood of success for complex development efforts. The model offers a rational and quantitative approach for enhancing management efficiency and the resilience and sustainability of overall project outcomes.

title: Learning in the Digital Era: How AI-Based Chatbot Satisfaction Shapes Academic Performance among Indonesian Students
authors: Joni Suhartono, I Gusti Made Karmawan, Drajad Wiryawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: This study examines the impact of student satisfaction with using AI-based chatbots on their academic performance at a private university in Indonesia. A survey using the Roscoe Research Formula with 361 respondents, analyses using SmartPLS software, found that ease of cognitive interaction, quality of results, and emotional support significantly increased user satisfaction, thereby encouraging continued use, positively impacting the students' academic performance in this study. Conversely, perceived usefulness and trust did not significantly influence student performance and academic achievement. In addition, this study emphasises the importance of designing adaptive and intuitive chatbots to support the emotional aspects of students as respondents

title: Optimization of 5G Base Station Placement in Urban Environments Using a Genetic Algorithm
authors: Saad Malik Talha, Serhii Siden, Roman Tsarov, Svitlana Kiiko, Liudmyla Bubentsova, Kseniia Tryfonova
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive mathematical model and simulation-based framework for structural optimization of 5 G mobile networks in dense urban environments. The proposed model jointly considers spatial base station (BS) placement, intersystem interference, received signal power, SINR, and individual user data rates. A genetic algorithm with adaptive selection, crossover, and mutation operators, enhanced with a local search mechanism, is applied to determine the optimal number and locations of BSs. The fitness function aims to maximize the average data rate while introducing penalties for overloaded BSs, excessive deployment density, and violations of Quality of Service (QoS) constraints. The results demonstrate that the average user data rate improves with increased BS density only up to a critical point, beyond which interference begins to dominate, leading to performance degradation. These findings highlight the importance of intelligent optimization methods in 5G network planning and suggest directions for future research involving parameter tuning and adaptive radio resource management.

title: Machine Learning Approach to Explore the Relationship of Innovation and Financial Factors in Renewable Energy Companies
authors: Hui Shan Lee, Kee Seng Kuang, Bik Kai Sia, Shyue Chuan Chong
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: In the era of rapid energy transition, renewable energy firms are now increasingly pressured to stay afloat in profitability and increase innovation levels. Despite extensive research linking innovation and financial performance, empirical evidence in the renewable energy sector remains fragmented, especially in the manner in which innovation and financial structure to determine the profitability in firms. The non-linear nature of these relationships can be difficult to explain using the traditional econometric models. This study aims to examine the impact of innovation and key financial determinants such as innovation, sales, total debt to equity, total debt to capital invested, total assets, total intangible assets, and current ratio on return on assets (ROA) among the top 50 renewable energy firms worldwide from 2020 to 2024. Using a machine learning framework, seven algorithms were employed: Naïve Bayes, Logistic Regression, Multilayer Perceptron, Sequential Minimal Optimization (SMO), J48 Decision Tree, Random Tree, and Random Forest. Model performance was evaluated. The results reveal that tree-based models, particularly Random Tree and Random Forest, being more effective than linear and probabilistic models in predicting the profitability of a firm. Random Tree was the most accurate, whereas Rand Forest was more generalized, which proves its efficiency in real-world prediction. These results indicate that the relationships between innovation and profitability in renewable energy companies are non-linear and multi-dimensional, which are conditioned by the interaction of the intensity of innovation, leverage, and asset efficiency. The novelty of this research is that it combines financial and innovation data in the context of a machine learning algorithm to evaluate sustainable industries financially.

title: Detection of AI-Generated Art Model: A CNN Densenet Framework Transfer Learning Approach
authors: Patrick Neil M. Santiago
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This study presents the development of an AI-driven classification framework using a DenseNet convolutional neural network (CNN) to differentiate between real and AI-generated (fake) images. With the increasing sophistication of generative models, distinguishing authentic visual content from synthetic ones has become a critical challenge in digital media authentication and artificial intelligence ethics. The proposed DenseNet architecture leverages dense connectivity and feature reuse mechanisms to efficiently extract both low-level texture features and high-level semantic representations, ensuring optimal feature propagation and gradient flow. The model was trained and validated on a balanced dataset of real and AI-generated images. Results demonstrated outstanding performance, achieving an overall accuracy of 99.61%, with precision, recall, and F1-scores all exceeding 99% for both classes. The training and validation loss curves showed rapid convergence, indicating strong generalization and stable learning behavior. Furthermore, the confusion matrix revealed only two minor misclassifications out of 512 validation samples, emphasizing the model’s robustness and reliability. These findings affirm the potential of DenseNet as an effective and accurate tool for AI-generated content detection. The study concludes that DenseNet’s architecture provides a viable framework for digital content authenticity verification and recommends extending the dataset to include generative outputs from newer AI models to enhance resilience against evolving synthesis techniques.

title: IoT and Machine Learning for Smart Warehouse Management in Logistics
authors: V. Vimalnath, K.K. Karthick, Ramar Veluchamy, N. Udaya Prakash, K. Sathiyamurthi, M. Ganesan Alias Kanagaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The intensive development of supply chain activities and logistics has brought a need to have smart and responsive warehouse management systems. The work is a hybrid strategy of implementing Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, coupled with the use of Machine Learning (ML) tools, to create a smart warehouse management system that will lead to the increased efficiency of operations, minimization of delays, and optimization of the use of resources. The suggested approach relies on the use of real-time IoT sensor data to monitor inventory and track goods and identify anomalies and uses ML models to forecast demand, optimize storage placement, and simplify order-picking operations. In contrast to how traditional warehouse systems are based on rule-based automation, autonomy of decision-making with the integration of IoT and ML through continuous learning of dynamic environments in warehouses. The framework also assists in predicting maintenance of the handling equipment and minimizes the use of energy as well as being accurate when it comes to inventory management. The proposed solution is very relevant to the contemporary and data-driven supply chain ecosystem because experimental assessment shows that the productivity, accuracy and general logistics performance have been greatly enhanced.

title: Optimizing Custom Convolutional Blocks for Pre-trained CNNs in Tuberculosis X-ray Analysis via Bayesian Optimization
authors: Nicholas Nevan Kurniawan, Reynard Amadeus Joshua, Ivan Sebastian Edbert, Alvina Aulia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This study optimizes Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures for tuberculosis (TB) X-ray detection. Leveraging transfer learning, ResNet50, Inception V3, and DenseNet121 models, which were pre-trained on RadImageNet, were fine-tuned with appended custom convolutional blocks. Their hyperparameters (filter count, kernel size, pooling type) were meticulously tuned using Bayesian Optimization, targeting F1score. Evaluated on a public Kaggle TB dataset, optimized models achieved high metrics, including F1-scores of 0.9469 (ResNet50), 0.9662 (Inception V3), and 0.9573 (DenseNet121), with others consistently above 0.90. These results validate Bayesian Optimization for tailoring custom layers, producing robust, highperforming TB detection models and highlighting the need for architecture-specific tuning.

title: Outfit Recommendations with Deep Learning-Based User Body Type Classification for Virtual Try-On
authors: Ahmed Beryl Bayanaka, Susi Juniastuti, Surya Sumpeno, Eko Mulyanto Yuniarno, Arta Kusuma Hernanda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This research proposes an outfit recommendation system integrating deep learning-based body type classification with virtual try-on technology. The system captures realtime images via camera, processes them using computer vision techniques, and extracts key body measurements including height, shoulder circumference, and waist circumference. These measurements are used to calculate Waist-to-Shoulder Ratio (WSR) and Waist-to-Height Ratio (WHtR), which serve as the foundation for classifying users’ body types into three categories: underweight, ideal, and overweight. The system employs MediaPipe Pose to detect 33 body landmarks for accurate measurement, with calibration processes ensuring precise conversion from pixels to centimeters. The virtual try-on component uses perspective transformation to overlay clothing images onto the user’s body, dynamically adjusting to follow movements. Based on classification results, the system provides personalized outfit recommendations tailored to the user’s body type and gender, displayed as visual icons with descriptive captions. Testing with 15 subjects demonstrated measurement accuracy with Mean Absolute Error under 5% and effective clothing visualization that adapts to different body types. This integration of body classification with virtual try-on technology creates a personalized shopping experience that can potentially reduce return rates in fashion e-commerce while enhancing customer satisfaction. The system demonstrates how technological innovation can address contemporary challenges in the fashion industry through personalized digital experiences that accommodate individual body characteristics

title: Analyzing the Importance of Spatio-Temporal Patterns in Eye-Tracking Sensor Data for Predicting Perceived Usability and User Experience
authors: Fabian Engl, Juergen Mottok, Michael Burmester
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: This study examines eye-tracking sensor data from 121 participants interacting with six websites to evaluate the predictive value of different eye movement features for perceived usability and user experience (UX). In total, over 36 hours of eye-tracking data, recorded at 250 Hz and totaling 32 million gaze points, were transformed into second-order eye movements events and then into third- and fourth-order machine learning features. Usability and UX ratings, collected through short versions of the User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ) and AttrakDiff questionnaires, served as labels for training six machine learning models. Results show that spatio-temporal metrics, particularly saccade sequences and Area of Interest (AOI) transitions, are the most predictive. Models trained on fourth-order features consistently outperform those based only on aggregated third-order metrics, highlighting the importance of preserving scanpath structure and sequential gaze behavior for predictive performance in eye-tracking-based Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) research.

title: WIP: Enhancing Game-Based Learning with AI-Driven Peer Agents
authors: Chengzhang Zhu, Cecile H. Sam, Yanlai Wu, Ying Tang
abstract: This work-in-progress paper presents SPARC (Systematic Problem Solving and Algorithmic Reasoning for Children), a gamified learning platform designed to enhance engagement and knowledge retention in K-12 STEM education. Traditional approaches often struggle to motivate students or facilitate deep understanding, especially for complex scientific concepts. SPARC addresses these challenges by integrating interactive, narrative-driven gameplay with an artificial intelligence peer agent built on large language models. Rather than simply providing answers, the agent engages students in dialogue and inquiry, prompting them to explain concepts and solve problems collaboratively. The platform's design is grounded in educational theory and closely aligned with state learning standards. Initial classroom pilots utilized a multi-method assessment framework combining pre- and post-tests, in-game analytics, and qualitative feedback from students and teachers. Preliminary findings indicate that SPARC significantly increases student engagement, with most participants reporting greater interest in STEM subjects and moderate gains in conceptual understanding observed in post-test results. Ongoing development focuses on refining the AI agent, expanding curriculum integration, and improving accessibility. These early results demonstrate the potential of combining AI-driven peer support with game-based learning to create inclusive, effective, and engaging educational experiences for K-12 learners.

title: RL-LSTM Enhanced Hybrid Navigation: An Intelligent APF Approach for Differential Wheel Drive
authors: Shrestha Ghosh, Hrity Sinha, Nabanita Adhikary
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This study introduces a hybrid path-planning method for a two-wheel mobile robot by integrating artificial potential field guidance, memory-based directional smoothing, and reinforcement learning with an interactive graphical interface. Users can define initial and target positions and obstacles in a two-dimensional space. The robot navigates safely toward the target by combining force-based attraction and repulsion, past motion data, and adaptive decision-making through learning. The system enables real-time training, path visualization, and curve smoothing. This approach improves movement through complex environments by combining classical navigation techniques, memory-driven behavior, and intelligent learning for better flexibility and obstacle avoidance.

title: Modern Day Perspective on History and Education Through the Lens of Artificial Intelligence
authors: Swakshyar Saurav Talukdar, Ankita Borgohain, Kaushik Kalita, Meghali Nath, Syamanta Hazarika, Dipti Saikia
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This article discusses how artificial intelligence can recreate data, adjust to individual needs, and understand to improve history lectures. We recreate historical data using contextual embeddings, temporal modeling, and attention approaches to preserve event order and significance. Education uses reconstructed stories to tailor learning to students' needs. Reinforcement learning increases personalization by changing ideas based on student engagement and performance, but fairness constraints apply to all student groups. Definition tools like attribution scores, saliency maps, and Shapley value projections enhance trust and openness. These strategies assist specialists in interpreting model results. The new framework is more accurate, meaningful, easy to read, fair, and long-lasting and helps individuals remember what they've learned. Scores above 90 indicate technical skill and teaching effectiveness improvements. The recommended framework improves learning and practice by merging cultural heritage, flexible education, and dependable AI. The procedure is technologically advanced and socially acceptable. It promotes accurate storytelling, fair education, and long-term knowledge. This study suggests that AI-powered technology could revolutionize how history is taught, stored, and understood today.

title: Intelligent System for Adaptive Resource Management in a Hybrid Educational Laboratory
authors: Mykhailo Karpa, Oleksandr Osolinskyi, Ihor Maikiv, Ivan Tsiupa
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents the system architecture for adaptive resource management within a hybrid educational laboratory. The system supports real-time experiment scheduling, dynamic user authorization, and resource optimization. A mathematical model is introduced to minimize user waiting time and maximize equipment utilization. The implementation includes a prototype on ESP32 microcontrollers with web-based interfaces for access control and session management. Simulation results demonstrate the system’s feasibility in real-world educational settings.

title: Determinants of AI-Driven Accelerated Learning for Junior Auditors
authors: Aulia Balqis Koming, Cut Dara Julianti Vaizira, Bambang Leo Handoko
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: This study investigates how Artificial Intelligence (AI) utilization supports accelerated learning among junior auditors in Indonesia. Drawing upon the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), this research examines the influence of perceived usefulness and perceived ease of use on AI utilization and its subsequent impact on learning acceleration. Using a quantitative approach with data from 104 junior auditors analyzed through Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM), the findings reveal that both perceived usefulness and perceived ease of use significantly affect AI utilization, which in turn enhances accelerated learning. Beyond confirming TAM in the auditing context, this study extends the model by positioning AI not merely as a technological tool but as a catalyst for cognitive development and experiential learning within professional settings. Theoretical implications emphasize the integration of human–AI collaboration in accounting education and training.

title: Cross-Layer Optimization of LEO Routing via DoA Statistics and SDN Domain Assignment
authors: Ioannis Nakas, Theodoros N.F. Kaifas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Low Earth orbit mega-constellations promise global connectivity but strain classical routing, which either relies on static "snapshot" topologies or greedy signal-to-noise metrics. Both approaches suffer from instability under fast geometry and frequency dynamics. We present a cross-layer routing framework under software defined networking (SDN) control that couples physical-layer direction-of-arrival (DoA) statistics with network-layer objectives. Our design models residual DoA errors as autoregressive processes, incorporates antenna pattern loss and array gain into link viability, and defines per-edge costs as a blend of expected transmission time (ETT), normalized SNR, delay, boresight error and array gain. Stability is reinforced by TTL-like survival terms, mild inter-plane penalties, and reliability floors on edge and path success. Domain assignment is solved as a capacity-constrained LEO–MEO matching with hysteresis and dwell timers, reducing controller thrash. A detailed control-plane overhead model accounts for adaptive telemetry, piggybacking, pushes and installs. Using a Walker constellation with GEO controllers and MEO forwarders, we show that the proposed approach achieves lower delay, higher delivery and longer path survival than both snapshot shortest-path (SSP) and SNR-only baselines, while keeping control airtime below capacity. Results hold across seeds, weight sweeps and ablations, demonstrating that DoA-aware, cross-layer metrics substantially improve stability and efficiency in large-scale LEO networks.

title: ToP-CK: Technological Pedagogical Content Knowledge and Adaptive Feedback Integrated Robot Path Planning
authors: Tingjun Lei, Timothy Sellers, Chaomin Luo, Lin Gong, Zhuming Bi, Jiawen Wang
abstract: This innovative practice full paper describes a hybrid pedagogical framework for teaching sampling-based path planning, addressing the challenges posed by its algorithmic complexity. Traditional methods like project-based and active learning often struggle to convey these concepts effectively. To address this, we propose a hybrid pedagogical framework that integrates Technological Pedagogical Content Knowledge (ToPCK) with Adaptive Feedback-Driven Ongoing Projects (AFOP). Implemented in an Advanced Robotics course, this method combines structured content delivery with adaptive, hands-on learning experiences. It features a Multi-Practice Exercise-Enabled Method (MPEM), enabling students to explore sampling-based algorithms through code modification and iterative experimentation. AFOP personalizes learning by adjusting project complexity based on individual progress and feedback, promoting selfpaced, outcome-focused learning. To evaluate effectiveness, we use milestone projects, exams, Q&A sessions, and student interviews. Pre- and post-semester self-assessments aligned with ABET standards guide continuous instructional improvement. Results indicate significant gains in engagement and comprehension, with students demonstrating both conceptual understanding and practical problem-solving skills in robotics sampling-based path planning.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Cloud Logs with Sparse Transformer
authors: Anu V.R.
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Log anomaly detection plays a crucial role in the analysis of cloud log files by identifying irregular log entries that may signify system faults or security breaches. With the growing complexity of modern computing systems, traditional manual analysis methods have become increasingly impractical and time-intensive. Consequently, recent advancements have focused on leveraging machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques for automated log anomaly detection. Among these, transformer-based models grounded in natural language processing have demonstrated promising results. However, their effectiveness can be limited when dealing with highly unstructured log data or when anomalous events are distantly located within the logs. This limitation is primarily due to the quadratic computational complexity of standard transformers with respect to input sequence length. To overcome this challenge, sparse transformer architectures have emerged, offering sub-quadratic complexity and improved scalability. In this study, we propose a sparse transformer-based approach for analyzing cloud log data, aimed at enhancing anomaly detection and supporting evidence acquisition in cloud forensic investigations. The proposed sparse transformer-based model is evaluated using annotated benchmark datasets, with performance assessed primarily through F1-scores and the estimated probability density functions of anomaly scores. The experimental results demonstrate that the sparse transformer model consistently outperforms two other baseline models in terms of F1-score across multiple datasets, indicating that the ability to process larger input sequences contributes positively to anomaly detection performance.

title: Tracking Shifts in Major and Concentration Combinations: Trends and Implications in a School of Electrical and Computer Engineering
authors: Jacqueline Rohde, Lakshmi Raju, Elliot Moore
abstract: This full research paper examines trends in major and concentration enrollment in a School of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) in the United States following the implementation of a curricular model that requires students to select two concentrations (called “Threads”) consisting of upperlevel technical courses as part of their degree. We explore the effects of this implementation on student enrollment data (i.e., Thread selections and changes of major). We found moderate differences in the popularity of different Threads, and that popularity levels have changed over time for certain Threads (while others have been remarkably consistent). Even though students do not take Thread courses until relatively later in the curricula, students are declaring Threads in their first and second years. Although these specific concentrations are unique to the institution, this paper contributes to broader efforts in ECE and beyond to help students develop specialization within an expansive engineering discipline.

title: Integrating E-Commerce and Games for Mental Wellbeing
authors: Andrea Tze-Ern Chai, Chien-Sing Lee
abstract: Mental health is declining in many academic levels, from primary to tertiary institutions. This study extends and transfers ideas from successful Southeast Asian e-commerce websites to design and develop an integrated well-being-e-commerce-gamification system. Borrowing from related work, Beary Happy dedicates space for students, with interactive elements designed to promote relaxation and alleviate stress; community-building to encourage likeminded individuals to connect, share experiences, and provide mutual support; a reward system to encourage engagement. Findings confirm the importance of meaningful achievements, meaningful chat functions (community building) and meaningful incentives in alleviating stress/anxiety. Personalized recommendations of real-world objects/environments may increase use of Beary Happy and improve mental health. Repurposing for younger children, to teach e-commerce, e-health, e-learning, community building, and customization, may increase avenues for use.

title: Real-Time Task Allocation for UAV Swarms in Complex Environments via Dynamic Hierarchical Attention GNN (DHA-GNN)
authors: Xinhua Wang, Ziyuan Ma, Shuang Shi, Huajun Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents the dynamic hierarchical attention graph neural network (DHA-GNN), an innovative framework designed for real-time task allocation in UAV swarms navigating complex, dynamic environments, such as urban cityscapes and rugged mountainous terrains. DHA-GNN integrates hierarchical feature aggregation with adaptive multi-level attention mechanisms to model evolving graph structures, capturing real-time interactions among heterogeneous UAVs, tasks, and environmental dynamics. The methodology employs self-learning graph representations to optimize task prioritization and resource allocation under constraints like dynamic obstacles, communication disruptions, and shifting mission priorities. Extensive simulations across diverse scenarios, including industrial facilities, forested regions, and counter-UAV operations, demonstrate that DHA-GNN achieves a task allocation accuracy of 98.7%, outperforming traditional methods by 15% in efficiency and reducing decision latency to 0.0023 milliseconds. It excels in urban (98.2% accuracy) and rugged terrains (97.6% accuracy), ensuring robust adaptability. These results establish DHA-GNN as a leading solution for UAV swarm intelligence, significantly enhancing operational efficiency in disaster response, surveillance, and military applications.

title: Automated Medical System for Rural Communities to Provide Medication without Human Interruption Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Sreedhar Kumar S, Nishaat Fatima, Ayesha Noorain, Syed Thouheed Ahmed, Syeda Ayesha Siddiqha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: For rural people all throughout the world, access to medicine is a major problem. People in rural areas frequently have poor access to medical services and must travel great distances to get medication, which can be costly and time-consuming. To address this problem, an automated medicated system namely Real Time Health Monitor System (RTHMS) has been developed and it uses to provide medication to rural people without human intervention using machine learning techniques. The RTHM system consists of a machine learning algorithm that is trained to generate medication based on a patient's live pulse rate, and temperature readings. The proposed RTHM system is designed, which is user-friendly and accessible to people with limited technical skills. It is also highly secure and meets all requirements for the generating the medication. Overall, this automated medicated system represents an important innovation in generating medicine prescription if abnormal for rural communities. Patients in remote places may experience better health outcomes and pay less by having access to drugs without human interaction.

title: Non-invasive Blood Pressure Measurement with Piezoelectric Sensors
authors: Sami Trimech, Carsten Wolff, Christof Röhrig
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The monitoring of the blood pressure of patients is a very important tool for medical treatments. Especially, the continuous non-invasive monitoring provides useful information for time series analysis and long-term signal processing. Simple wearable sensors support this type of blood pressure measurement and provide high comfort for patients. Such sensors can be combined with smart devices and support various use cases in individualized health management. This paper presents and discusses the concept of a non-invasive blood pressure measurement based on piezoelectric sensors. This type of sensors promises to required features for medical wearables. The paper presents the state-of-the-art in non-invasive blood pressure measurement based on wearable sensors and the prior research on piezoelectric sensors, especially for pressure measurement. A concept for a blood pressure measurement system with all relevant components is presented and the design decisions are justified by comparison with the state-of-the-art. The presented concept is currently researched and the paper presents first findings of this work-inprogress. An important part of the paper is the presentation of the research design for the development and validation of the blood pressure measurement system.

title: SmartFoodGuard: AI-Powered Quality Monitoring and Safety System for Sustainable Food Consumption
authors: Vasavi Ravuri, K Sai Anuradha, M Pavani Tejasri, Navya Taduri, Vempati Indupriya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: While the food supply chain across the globe has developed in the past few decades, it is still under mounting pressure from fast population growth and escalating environmental issues. Inefficiencies persist, dispersed data systems exist, and no effective tools for food quality tracking across stages are still prevalent among farmers, retailers, and consumers. So far, such issues have frequently led to food waste, financial loss, and heightened concerns about safety and transparency. Accordingly, the present work presents SmartFoodGuard, a system based on artificial intelligence that applies in both machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) methodologies. The system constantly monitors food freshness, anticipates spoilage, and assesses nutritional value in real time. Accordingly, by facilitating data-driven decision-making and enhancing supply chain transparency, SmartFoodGuard seeks to reduce food waste, promote food safety, and foster sustainable practices. In total, these initiatives support worldwide efforts in ensuring the responsible management of resources and assist in securing public confidence in food safety and quality regulation.

title: DBAB: A Dual-Branch Adaptive Balance Framework with Optimized Plasticity Branch for Class-Incremental Learning
authors: Xinyu Chen, Heqian Qiu, Chenghao Qi, Ruisong Dai, Hongliang Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: In the context of class-incremental learning, the primary challenge for models is to overcome catastrophic forgetting. Leveraging the strong generalization ability of frozen pre-trained models can significantly enhance model performance and alleviate catastrophic forgetting during training. To enable models to better adapt to downstream tasks, fine-tuning pre-trained models for new tasks is a common approach. However, current works struggle to balance plasticity and generalization performance after fine-tuning, as fine-tuning causes model parameters to overwrite knowledge of old tasks. This paper proposes a Dual-Branch Adaptive Balance (DBAB) framework, which consists of a plasticity branch fine-tuned from a pre-trained model and optimized for downstream tasks, and a generalization branch with frozen pre-trained parameters. The framework designs an adaptive balance mechanism for the dual branches, introduces learnable balance coefficients to dynamically fuse class prototype distances from both branches, and devises a loss function for training and regularizing the balance coefficients. This ensures a better balance between plasticity and generalization during the incremental learning process. To optimize the plasticity branch in the DBAB framework, an Adaptive Plasticity Module (APM) is proposed. Considering the heterogeneity of embedding distributions in continuous learning of downstream tasks, APM employs Mahalanobis distance for anisotropic feature alignment, uses a covariance matrix to dynamically adapt to the heterogeneous distributions of new tasks, and improves and stabilizes the Mahalanobis distance-based classification method.Experimental results show that DBAB outperforms multiple state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods on benchmark datasets such as CIFAR100 and CUB200, demonstrating significant performance improvements.

title: Electrolyte-Gated Graphene FETs for Acetylcholine Detection via Functional Layer-assisted Transfer Approach
authors: Ksenija Arslanova, Bajramshahe Shkodra, Sebastian Klenk, Kathrin C. Knirsch, Andreas Hirsch, Anja Köhler-Karaaslan, Niko Amend, Dirk Steinritz, Tanja Stimpel-Lindner, Georg S. Duesberg
abstract: Acetylcholine (ACh) detection is essential for studying the cholinergic system and diagnosing neurodegen erative disorders. Here, we present a graphene field-effect transistor (GFET) biosensor functionalized with acetyl cholinesterase (AChE) enzyme for label-free ACh sensing. To preserve the intrinsic properties of graphene and enhance biosensor performance, we employ a Functional Layer-assisted Transfer (FLaT) strategy. This approach enables direct post-growth functionalization of graphene with a perylene bisimide (PBI) linker, preventing contamination during transfer and serving as a stable, non-covalent anchoring layer for biofunctionalization. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analyses confirm a cleaner and more uniform surface for FLaT-treated graphene compared to non-functionalized graphene, while Raman spectroscopy verifies the high quality of the CVD-grown material. AChE enzymes are covalently attached to the PBI layer using carbodiimide cross-linker chemistry. The successful surface chemistry was confirmed by AFM and X-ray electron spectroscopy (XPS). The resulting enzyme-functionalized, electrolyte-gated GFETs operate at low gate voltages (∼1V), making them well-suited for biosensing in aqueous environments. They exhibit calibrated responses to ACh concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 1000 μM, effectively covering the physiologically relevant range found in the central nervous system. This work demonstrates the potential of the FLaT based GFET platform for sensitive, stable, and scalable neurotransmitter detection.

title: Astraeus: Rapid Container Deployment with Lazy Pulling in Satellite Edge Cloud
authors: Yuqi Yang, Peng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Satellite edge cloud technology combines edge computing and satellite communications to improve data processing and reduce latency. However, traditional satellite systems have fixed hardware configurations and functions after launch, lacking the ability for dynamic adjustment. Due to the high-speed motion of low earth orbit (LEO) satellites and limited communication windows, the software update processes can take tens of thousands of seconds, posing significant challenges to meeting real-time requirements. To address these challenges, this paper proposes Astraeus, an efficient containerized deployment strategy designed to tackle the difficulties of heterogeneous software deployment and high startup latency. We propose a cluster partitioning strategy tailored for large-scale satellite nodes and design a cluster collaboration mechanism based on data partitioning and bandwidth resource optimization, which enables fast distribution of large image files. Furthermore, we innovatively integrate lazy pulling technology into the satellite edge cloud. This approach significantly reduces the dependency on downloading complete images for container startup by fetching only the image index files and dynamically loading the required content during runtime. Experimental results show that our proposed approach reduces container deployment time by $99 \%$ and accelerates file distribution speed by $98 \%$.

title: From Pixels to Policy: Data Driven Spatiotemporal and Statistical Framework for Quantifying Environmental Risk in Gujranwala, Pakistan
