abstract: The rapid urbanization witnessed in mid-sized cities in Pakistan has intensified environmental degradation, resulting in rising land surface temperature (LST) and air pollution. As per WHO, the annual average concentration of PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf> in large Pakistani cities is more than 15 times the safe limit of 5 μg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> [3], [5]. In Punjab province districts are highly susceptible to environmental pressure [7]. In these, Pakistan's fifth-largest city and third-largest industrial hub, Gujranwala district, exhibits the alarming trend of urban sprawl, Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for Multi-Criteria Decision-Making (MCDM) to identify spatial environmental vulnerability. Seven prominent indicators LST, Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), Normalized Difference Built-up Index (NDBI), Particulate Matter (PM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</inf>), Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD), Carbon Monoxide (CO), and Nitrogen Dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), were derived from Landsat, Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS), and Sentinel-5Precurser datasets respectively. The AHP results validated spatially by calculating UHI and UTFVI trends in the area whereas, Statistical verification using one-way ANOVA and Post-Hoc Tukey's Honestly Significant Difference (HSD) tests confirmed the presence of significant differences in LST in the different zones (p < 0.05), supporting the robustness of the proposed model. The findings show extreme environmental pressure with high density found in industrial and central urban zones.

title: Comparative Analysis of Classical Machine Learning Models and Deep Learning in Rose Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Kent Amadeo Timotheus, Theodore Zachary, Jason Ho, Shania Priccilia, Diana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of classical machine learning (ML) models and deep learning (DL) models for the classification of rose leaf diseases. The study evaluated three ML models (k-Nearest Neighbors, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine) and three DL models (Convolutional Neural Network, ResNet-50, and VGG16Net) to classify four categories of rose leaf diseases: healthy leaves, black spot, leaf holes, and dry leaves. An initial dataset of 3,113 images was augmented to 12,000 images to ensure class balance. Image preprocessing involved region segmentation, cropping, and resizing to $224 \times 224$ pixels. For the ML models, features were extracted using Grey-Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM), specifically Contrast, Dissimilarity, Homogeneity, Energy, and Correlation. The dataset was divided into a 70:30 train-validation ratio. The results indicate that two of the deep learning models, CNN and VGG16Net, significantly surpassed the ML models in accuracy, with CNN achieving the highest accuracy at $98.87 \%$ and VGG16Net at $97.58 \%$. While the ML models performed consistently, Random Forest achieved a competitive accuracy of $80.88 \%$. Notably, ResNet-50 underperformed all other models.

title: Analysis of the Third Factor in Lightning-Induced Tripping: The Mechanism of Insulator Micro-Current Flashover Triggered by High-frequency Induced Voltage during Lightning Strikes on Overhead Ground Wires
authors: Ke Li, Bo Lu, Jian Zhang, Wenguang Ma, Jianggao Hong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Lightning currents manifest as an electromagnetic pulse wave characterized by multi-frequency bands and high energy. Existing theories categorize lightning-induced faults into two types: (1) back-flashover caused by overvoltage when lightning strikes a tower, and (2) shielding-failure when lightning bypasses the overhead ground wire (OGW) and directly strikes a phase conductor. By referencing the calculation method for induced voltage (current) in parallel power-frequency lines, this study derives the mutual inductance coefficient M between the OGW and adjacent energized conductors. Subsequently, applying electromagnetic induction formulas to the lightning electromagnetic pulse frequency f and surge current IL, it is found that the induced voltage coupled to parallel phase conductors within half a span can reach 50–100 kV. Under high-frequency electric fields during thunderstorms, the capacitive impedance of moistened insulators is only 30–50 kΩ. At this induced voltage level, the high-frequency current traversing the insulator attains 1.2 A, surpassing the hazardous threshold of insulator leakage current and thus provoking flashover-induced tripping. ATP-EMTP simulations of a 220 kV transmission line confirm that lightning strikes on OGWs can generate induced voltages, leading to insulator-ground micro high-frequency currents. This process subsequently initiates power-frequency current flashover, resulting in insulation breakdown failure.

title: Optimizing Emotion Detection with Attention-Enhanced Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Israr Ur Rehman, Zulfiqar Ali, Zahoor Jan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Emotions are essential to human comprehension and communication. In fields including psychology, affective computing, and human-computer interaction, the ability to predict emotions from visual data, especially facial expressions has grown in popularity. Conventional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are good at identifying important aspects of pictures, but they frequently can’t focus on the most important areas for detecting emotions. In this study, a novel architecture is proposed that integrates a multi-head attention mechanism with CNNs to address this limitation, enabling the model to concentrate on crucial facial regions associated with emotional expressions. Our approach leverages the hierarchical feature extraction strengths of CNNs to capture detailed patterns in facial expressions. The model’s capacity to identify tiny emotional cues is improved simultaneously through the attention mechanism, which dynamically highlights the most discriminative regions. Extensive experiments on benchmark emotion recognition datasets validate our model’s superiority, demonstrating significant accuracy improvements over conventional CNN-based models. These results highlight how our attention-enhanced CNN architecture can propel advancements in virtual reality, human-computer interaction, and affective computing, which analyzes and reacts to human emotions.

title: Guidelines for Designing Engineering Problems to Bootstrap Students' Deep Learning Based on Productive Failure Reflecting Brain Activity
authors: Tathyana Moratti, Runu Proma Das, Yeongji Lee, Aarti Sign, David Kraemer, Beshoy Morkos
abstract: This analytical review identifies guidelines for designing engineering problems to bootstrap engineering students' deep learning. Literature shows that one way to bootstrap deep learning is through failure. A well-established framework for this pedagogical strategy is Productive Failure by Manu Kapur [1]. The failure approach is further supported by studies of brain activity, measured by electroencephalogram (EEG) during student problem-solving. This review focuses on establishing guidelines to operationalize the Productive Failure framework and EEG measurements for designing engineering problems. Through an exploration of prior literature regarding Productive Failure, engineering problem practices, and brain activity, the authors conducted a theory synthesis to identify these guidelines. The findings of each identified theme were clustered by similarity. Each cluster was named and considered as a guideline. The nine guidelines were organized into two main settings: individual and group, and just group. Eight guidelines were identified for individual and group settings: Challenging, Contextualized, Contrast and variety of cases, Low computation load, Scaffolding abstract items, Explain and communicate, Planned and analyzed investigations (lab), and Safe mindset (classroom environment). The only guideline for the group setting is Planned to collaborate. Future research on Meaningful Failure, a framework specifically designed to facilitate learning through failure in engineering education, will be conducted.

title: The Design of Complete Coverage Path Planning for a Service Robot
authors: Ching-Lung Chang, Yu-Ting Chien
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: This paper presents two effective path planning strategies—region-priority traversal and fixed-path priority—to enhance navigation efficiency for service robots operating in complex indoor environments. The proposed approach utilizes occupancy grid-based segmentation combined with a genetic algorithm (GA) to optimize the visiting sequence of subregions, thereby minimizing redundant traversal. By integrating a heuristic local path planner, the method ensures complete coverage with fewer directional changes and smoother robot motion, making it adaptable to diverse spatial configurations. A rectangular decom-position-based partitioning establishes a structured foundation for segmentation, and inter-region navigation is modeled as a Traveling Salesman Path Problem (TSPP), solved using GA to handle irregular obstacle distributions. The study further incorporates subregion path information into inter-region cost evaluation, constructing a comprehensive cost model. Simulation results show that while the fixed-path priority strategy yields slightly longer paths, it significantly reduces turning frequency and overall cost, offering smoother navigation and improved maneuverability at the expense of computation time and overlap rate.

title: Heart Disease Prediction Using TabNet-A Deep Learning Model
authors: Nyemeesha V, C Laxmi Pranitha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Since many decades, heart diseases have been increasing and became serious one among other diseases because of its strong impact on human life. It is a major cause for mortality and morbidity across the globe, it needs early and accurate prediction and diagnosis. Present prediction systems use deep learning, ML and AI to generate models, which are used in predicting heart disease due to their interpretability and greater efficiency on datasets. This paper aims to improve heart disease prediction by considering features like gender, family history, resting heart rate, hemoglobin A1C, stress level and physical activity level in addition to present factors used in prediction, so as to know is gender playing a role in heart diseases occurrence or they are passing down genetically or does stress can effect our heart health or does hemoglobin level in blood matter in heart failure. We have used Tabular Network also known as TabNet, a deep learning approach which is used specifically in structural tabular data and selecting relevant features for prediction, to predict heart diseases Framingham heart disease dataset is used which consists of gender, family history and other features. It uses dynamic feature selection for predicting the heart diseases efficiently and achieving an accuracy of approximately 90 % while evaluating the model. Our results indicate that including the features gender and family history has produced more accurate information about the heart disease occurrence, is helpful to build models which can predict the heart disease more precisely and accurately.

title: Memecoins Through the Lens of Reddit
authors: Andrea Michienzi, Barbara Guidi, Andrea Belliani
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: With the advent of Web3, many online services have been revolutionised through decentralisation. With blockchain as the main decentralisation engine, online social media platforms have witnessed a new life. Recently, memes have come into play, providing new opportunities for community aggregation, giving birth to the so-called memecoin phenomenon. Memecoins are blockchain-backed cryptocurrencies that can be freely traded, and people can discuss them online. They represent a new scenario in which social and economic aspects are tightly intertwined, but external figures or events can also influence the activity of each token. In this paper, we provide an analysis of the relationship between the social and economic spheres of memecoins and how external factors influence their activity. We conducted our analyses on six case studies taken from different contexts and with unique histories, downloading data from various subreddits and blockchains. The findings show that each memecoin has unique distinctive features and that the activity around them is influenced by crypto-influencers, scams, or even external events.

title: Multimodal Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Classification Using Vision and Acoustic Inputs
authors: Santhiya S, Jeevithaa R V, Jayadharshini P, Vaanmugilan T, Shyam S, Ragul G
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are started to use in military zones during wars, which creates fears regarding safety, privacy, and national security. In order to track their utilization effectively, we require effective mechanisms to identify and classify UAVs. Classical camera-based vision detection is poor in low light, fog, as well as under vision obstacles. It also subsists with vision since the UAVs emanate distinguishable sound patterns used for identification. A framework is proposed for the classification of UAVs that incorporates both vision as well as audio data. We worked on the dataset Roboflow, comprised of five classes: drone, helicopter, aircraft jet, bird, and plane. We worked on the YOLOv8 [1], ResNet18 CNN, as well as the Vision Transformer. ResNet18 CNN obtained the best visual accuracy, reaching 98.44%, followed by satisfactory results from YOLOv8 and ViT. We utilised the Drone AudioDataset for audio analysis. It comprised the CNN, the LSTM, as well as the Vision Transformer, where the ViT achieved the best precision, 95.81%. The results show that combining optical and acoustic techniques improves detection reliability, especially in challenging real-time conditions. Ongoing research will be directed towards building derivative fusion techniques to construct variable, accurate, and secure UAV surveillance platforms.

title: Towards Improving Arbitrary-Shaped Text Detection with Boundary Adaptation in Noisy Scene Images_supp1-3652839.pdf
authors: Aishwarya Soni
abstract: Accurate detection of arbitrary-shaped text in natural scenes remains a challenging problem, particularly under real-world noise conditions such as blur, occlusion, uneven lighting, and cluttered backgrounds. These factors degrade local features and boundary precision, hindering the performance of existing contour-based methods. To address this, we propose Ray Contour Net (RC-Net), a robust framework for boundary adaptation in noisy environments. RC-Net incorporates a Noise- Aware Attention Module to obtain noise-robust features and an Active Contour Point Initialization Module that emits contour points in a polar coordinate system anchored at local text centers. These are refined by a Deformation Module using lightweight transformers to ensure shape-aware, noise-tolerant adaptation. Additionally, we introduce a Tightness Evaluation Loss (TEL) to enforce precise boundary predictions. Extensive experiments on six benchmark datasets including Total-Text, CTW-1500, MSRATD500, ICDAR 2015, ICDAR2019 ArT, and ICDAR2019 MLT demonstrate consistent F-measure improvements of 2% to 3% over strong baselines, validating the effectiveness and robustness of our method.

title: Enabling Coexistence: Dynamic Channel Allocation for Scalable LEO-GEO Networks
authors: Nermine Hendy, Akram Al-Hourani, Shiva Raj Pokhrel, Deol Satish, Kandeepan Sithamparanathan, Jonathan Kua
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: The growing coexistence of LEO and GEO satellite systems within shared frequency bands introduces critical co-channel interference challenges. This paper presents a robust and dynamic framework for evaluating spectrum allocation strategies to mitigate such interference in GEO–LEO satellite networks. We investigate and compare three allocation schemes: random, optimization-based, and Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-driven strategies. A simulation environment modeled on real-world geometries over Australian ground stations is developed, incorporating a OneWeb-style LEO constellation alongside configurable GEO satellites. Performance is assessed using metrics such as Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR), interference power, signal throughput, and spectral efficiency. Results demonstrate that the learning-based allocation reduces interference and enhances system throughput, offering a scalable solution for future multi-orbit satellite networks coexistence.

title: Deep Learning Based Classification of 45 Days Chicken Freshness Using Convolutional Neural Networks and Adam Optimizers
authors: Vladi Dejan D. Magdirila, Vince Gabriel L. Obien, Flordeliza L. Valiente
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: The freshness of chicken is a critical factor for food safety, quality control, and consumer satisfaction. This study presents a system that classifies the freshness of whole 45-day-old chickens with skin intact using the VGG19 Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture and the Adam optimizer. The main hardware components include the Raspberry Pi 4 Model B and the Raspberry Pi Camera Module v3. A black-background capture box with controlled LED lighting and a rotating table was designed to ensure consistent image quality from multiple angles. The dataset consisted of 599 images, with 599 used for training, and 45 images each for validation and testing. To ensure specificity, 200 images of pork and beef were included so that the system only detects chicken. Freshness was categorized into three classes: fresh (0–4 hours post-slaughter), slightly fresh (4–6 hours), and old (6–8 hours). The system achieved classification accuracy of 88.24% for fresh, 78.57% for slightly fresh, and 85.71% for old, resulting in an overall accuracy of 84.44%. Precision, recall, and F1-score were 0.8455, 0.8417, and 0.8430 respectively, demonstrating the system’s capability to reliably classify chicken freshness.

title: The Topological Connectivity and Assortativity of Social Networks
authors: Dong Yan, Yan Ni Huang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Social networks have become an indispensable part of individual life. This paper takes two different types of social networks, Epinions and Twitter, as empirical objects to analyze the topological connectivity and assortativity of actual social networks. The interactive behaviors in social networks usually follow a decaying power law distribution. The empirical analysis shows that they both have approximate scale-free characteristics, but exhibit different degree assortativity. The individual connectivity tendency of the social network Twitter(X) is characterized by assortativity (positive correlations), while the network Epinions has moderate and weak degree disassortativity (negative ones).

title: WIP: Lifelong Learning in Electrical Engineering Education Using a Stakeholder Approach for Electrified Aviation
authors: Olof Lindahl, Jennifer Leijon
abstract: This work in progress innovative practice category paper introduces teaching using a stakeholder approach. It illustrates how this approach may be used in an electrical engineering lifelong learning course to support student learning about technology implementation involving far-reaching industry change. The stakeholder approach involves group work where students get to discuss who the important organizations, or stakeholders, are in relation to a complex electrical engineering challenge. This is a suitable approach in a lifelong learning course where students have professional experience to draw on. The uniqueness of this innovative practice is in using a stakeholder approach to teach electrical engineering in a field that is undergoing particularly rapid change involving many interconnected organizations. The paper presents the stakeholder approach, and teaching using this approach is exemplified by a lifelong learning course on the electrification of aviation. The approach is evaluated by drawing on interviews with both the teacher using this approach, and with students learning with it, in both cases for the first time. Teacher and student feedback suggests that the stakeholder approach is engaging and encourages class discussion, yet that it can also be challenging to teach with the first time around. The main take-aways from this paper are to show the usefulness of the stakeholder approach and encourage fellow teachers to give the approach a try when teaching about challenges in electrical engineering whose solutions require understanding the importance, roles, and motivations of several stakeholders.

title: Developing Effective Attitudinal Character Indicators to Support Character Development
authors: Stephen Frezza, Iryna Ashby, Marisa Exter
abstract: This Work-in-Progress paper presents an approach for developing and validating attitudinal indicators for dispositional aspects of learning. As technical education increasingly emphasizes ethical and professional competencies alongside technical skills, the need to understand not only what students do but why they do it has grown urgent. This WIP study explores the development of attitudinal indicators as a tool to support character development in engineering and computing education. While traditional behavioral indicators focus on observable actions, attitudinal character indicators (ACI) will help surface underlying motivations, providing a richer, more nuanced understanding of professional behavior. Using a two-phase mixed-methods design, this study first employs a qualitative Delphi method to generate a consensus-based set of ACIs, followed by Q methodology to reveal shared patterns of belief and value orientations among diverse stakeholders. The findings are expected to offer actionable tools for educators aiming to cultivate well-rounded, virtuous graduates in technical fields.

title: Optimized Data Preprocessing and Dimensionality Reduction Framework for FPGA-Based Embedded Systems Using Hybrid Sparse-Probabilistic PCA
authors: Sowmya Dondeti, Sayanti Chatterjee, N Sandeep Chaitanya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The main aim of traditional data preprocessing in embedded systems often prioritizes accuracy at the cost of latency and energy efficiency. This paper proposes a novel FPGA-based data preprocessing framework that unifies adaptive dimensionality reduction, sparse transformation, and hardware-aware computation within a single design. Unlike conventional PCA implementations, the proposed architecture introduces a Hybrid Sparse-Probabilistic PCA (HSP-PCA) approach that dynamically balances sparsity and probabilistic variance retention, tailored for FPGA-based computation pipelines. By optimizing covariance computation and eigen decomposition using pipelined matrix multipliers and quantized feature representations, the framework significantly reduces on-chip resource utilization. Experimental results demonstrate a 43% latency reduction, 38% memory efficiency gain, and 52% higher energy efficiency compared to baseline preprocessing. The results validate that adaptive hybrid PCA integrated with reconfigurable hardware provides a scalable, low-power, and high-throughput solution for embedded intelligence.

title: AMFC-DEIM: Improved DEIM With Adaptive Matching and Focal Convolution for Remote Sensing Small Object Detection
authors: Xiaole Lin, Guangping Li, Jiahua Xie, Zhuokun Zhi
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: While Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based methods for small object detection in remote sensing imagery have advanced considerably, substantial challenges remain unresolved, primarily stemming from complex backgrounds and insufficient feature representation. To address these issues, we propose a novel architecture specifically designed to accommodate the unique demands of small objects, termed AMFC-DEIM. This framework introduces three key innovations: (1) the Adaptive One-to-One (O2O) matching mechanism, which enhances Dense O2O matching by adaptively adjusting the matching grid configuration to the object distribution, thereby preserving the resolution of small objects throughout training; (2) the Focal Convolution Module, engineered to explicitly align with the spatial characteristics of small objects for extracting fine-grained features; and (3) the Enhanced Normalized Wasserstein Distance, which stabilizes the training process and bolsters performance on small targets. Comprehensive experiments conducted on three benchmark remote sensing small object detection datasets: RSOD, LEVIR-SHIP and NWPU VHR-10, demonstrate that AMFC-DEIM achieves remarkable performance, attaining AP<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_{50}$</tex-math></inline-formula> scores of 96.2%, 86.2%, and 95.1%, respectively, while maintaining only 5.27M parameters. These results substantially outperform several established benchmark models and state-of-the-art methods.

title: AI-Based Low-Cost Approach for Cardiac Anomaly Detection
authors: Leonardo Augusto de Aquino Marques, Paulo Eugênio Da Costa Filho, Israel Da S. Felix de Lima, Wilson Douglas Jales Simonal, José Igo Soares Camilo, Ewerton Leandro de Sousa, Wesley Costa Da Silva, Antonio Wallace Antunes Soares, Augusto Venâncio Neto, Eduardo Nogueira Cunha, Dario Vieira Conceiçäo
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Continuous cardiac monitoring is essential for high-risk patients, enabling early anomaly detection and timely medical interventions. However, traditional ECG systems are often cost-prohibitive and lack widespread accessibility. This study explores the feasibility of a low-cost cardiac anomaly detection device using AD8232 sensors, ESP32 microcontrollers, and embedded AI for real-time signal analysis. Drawing on the authors’ previous research in electrical signal characterization for device identification and AI applications in embedded systems, as well as current literature on ECG-based monitoring, the present study discusses key technical challenges and possible approaches for system implementation, including signal acquisition, processing, hardware selection, and computational performance. A DIY approach is adopted to foster community-driven innovation and facilitate the system’s replication and further enhancement. The results indicate that the proposed device is not only technically viable but also has the potential to democratize access to continuous cardiac monitoring, thereby making a significant contribution to the healthcare field.

title: Exploring Generative AI Models for Creating Culturally Rich and Immersive Worlds in Chinese Animated Content
authors: Shijun Cui, Julina Binti Ismail Kamal, Dehua Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The use of generative AI models has transformative potential to generate culturally immersive animated worlds in the Chinese animation industry. These models primarily reflect rich cultural heredity in a reflection of the global demands for unique content. This work employs systematic literature reviews to study state of the art generative AI models and how they enable and pose challenges for cultural integration and implications. However, the findings examine that AI recreates old traditional Chinese art forms and can benefit storytelling, but it is limited by cultural sensitivity, ethical concerns, as well as technical difficulties. Leveraging generative AI for culturally rich, globally appealing animations while addressing challenges in the field is the focus of this research.

title: Mitigating Exam Barriers for Neurodivergent Students: A Study on Sensory Adaptations in Computing Assessments
authors: Aidan McGowan, Neil Anderson, Christopher Smith
abstract: This Work-in-Progress (WIP) study explores the impact of sensory-adapted examination environments on neurodivergent students in a postgraduate computing module within an MSc Software Development program. As concerns about generative AI increase pressure to reintroduce invigilated exams in higher education, there is a renewed urgency to ensure such environments are accessible for all learners. Neurodivergent students—including those with autism, ADHD, dyslexia, and dyspraxia—often face unique sensory and cognitive challenges that are not fully addressed by standard accommodations such as extra time or separate rooms. The module included three examinations throughout the course. While the first two were completed under typical conditions for students in the specialised quiet room, the final exam—weighted at 50%—introduced a set of tailored, sensory-friendly adjustments. These included: (1) noise-cancelling headphones with the option of white noise, music, or silence; (2) a fixed overall exam duration, incorporating extra time and rest breaks to reduce time-related anxiety; and (3) an editable digital exam format to support accessibility and executive functioning. Eleven neurodivergent students opted into the specialised quiet room setting. Post-exam surveys and interviews revealed that all students rated their experience of the adjustments at the highest level (5/5), reporting improvements in focus, reduced anxiety, and greater comfort during the exam. Performance data indicated a 2.0% increase in average scores following the adjustments, compared to a 0.9% increase across the overall cohort. While the small sample size limits statistical generalisation, these results suggest that sensory-adapted environments may offer meaningful benefits for neurodivergent learners. This study underscores the value of moving beyond conventional accommodations toward more holistic and personalised approaches to exam accessibility. Further research is needed to assess the scalability of such interventions across larger and more diverse student populations.

title: Assessing Student Attention Levels in the Classrooms Using Large Language Models
authors: Medha Mohan Ambali Parambil, Kole Suzuki, Kazuyuki Murase, Salah Bouktif, Luqman Ali, Hamad AlJassmi, Fady Alnajjar
abstract: This research category full paper describes how traditional methods for assessing student attention in classrooms are subjective, time-consuming, and challenging to scale. This study investigates how the Gemini 1.5 pro Large Language Model (LLM) combined with You Only Look Once (YOLO)-v11 object detection can automate student attention assessments in online and offline learning environments. Classroom videos were analyzed using three prompt variations, with and without YOLO assisted tracking, and performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were evaluated. The ground truth was established through manual evaluation by three expert instructor volunteers using standardized rubrics, resulting in strong inter-annotator agreement as measured by Fleiss's Kappa. Results indicate that integrating YOLO object detection models with LLMs significantly improves classification accuracy by reducing false positives and enhancing student tracking, while prompt specificity influences attention state recognition. The highest accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(93.55 \%)$</tex> was achieved when combining YOLO with a structured prompt detailing observable behaviours. These findings highlight the potential of combining vision-based AI with language models for real-time classroom monitoring to assess student attention levels with applications in improving engagement and educational analytics.

title: Efficient nebulization of argon plasma-jet-activated water via surface acoustic waves for surface bacterial inactivation_supp1-3651243.pdf
authors: Ming Tan
abstract: Plasma-activated aerosols produced via surface acoustic wave (SAW) nebulization has the potential for improving surface disinfection processes by providing wider distribution coverage due to the dispersibility of the aerosols. Motivated by previous studies showing that increasing the electrical conductivity of air plasma-activated water led to a significant reduction in the SAW nebulization rate, which poses a severe limitation to the efficiency of the technology, we evaluate here the use of argon plasma-jet-activated water as an alternative to air plasma-jets. Compared to the higher electrical conductivity of air plasma-jet-activated water (0.3 mS/cm ≤ σe ≤ 4 mS/cm), argon plasma-jet-activated water has substantially lower conductivity (4 μS/cm ≤ σe ≤ 40 μS/cm) and hence more efficient nebulization (103% higher nebulization rate compared to that for deionized water, in contrast to 65% lower nebulization rate with air plasma-jets). Nevertheless, despite its lower electrical conductivity, the argon plasma-jet-activated water was observed to maintain Escherichia coli (E. coli) inactivation efficacy even after 4 days of storage due to the high hydrogen peroxide concentrations that were produced. This is in sharp contrast to air plasma-jet-activated water, which yielded only limited bacterial inactivation efficiency (approximately 10.5% reduction) even when fresh and surprisingly promoted E. coli growth after one day of storage. In particular, we found that 2.4 g of the argon plasma-jet aerosols, equivalent to just 10 mins of nebulization, was capable of achieving 100% bacterial inactivation, thus alluding to the platform’s potential for efficient and effective spray-based surface disinfection.

title: WIP: Examining a Different Approach to Create Successful Opportunities for Collaboration between University and Community Partners in International Service Learning
authors: Kadri Parris
abstract: This innovative practice WIP paper describes a relatively new course that was created at The Ohio State University and first offered in 2019, centered on international community-based service learning in the South American nation of Guyana. The course was created based on the principles of IDEO's human centered design which focuses on three different phases of the design process, namely, Inspiration, Ideation and Implementation. These three phases were applied in a three-year cycle, where each year focused on one design phase. The first full cycle was successfully completed in December 2023 with the installation of solar powered generator systems in two communities in Guyana. A unique feature of this collaboration was the direct interaction between university faculty and communities without the presence of third-party facilitators. This approach was successful because strategies employed included faculty working with local government in Guyana, understanding the local culture, consistent and effective communication and prioritization of reciprocity. The first cycle essentially took five (5) years to complete due to disruptions that were a direct result of the COVID-19 global pandemic in 2020. The intentional design was chronicled carefully in every completed year of the cycle to ensure that each subsequent batch of students could build on the work of the previous groups. The potential significance of this contribution is that it can offer valuable insights for universities wishing to facilitate these faculty-led international partnerships. Future research will include conducting a narrative study to better understand the perspectives of faculty, students and community partners.

title: Federated Learning Approaches for Secure and Privacy-Preserving Brain Image Processing
authors: Suneet Gupta, Swaroop Reddy Gayam, VinayKumar Dunka, Sudharshan Putha, KDV Prasad, Buvsara Tashmuradova
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study introduces federated learning (FL) designs that combine homomorphic encryption, differential privacy, and gradient clipping to secure and speed up brain image processing. Federated learning has revolutionized medical machine learning while respecting privacy. The proposed method lets several medical facilities train deep learning models simultaneously while ensuring data privacy and fulfilling all standards. Federated Averaging (FedAvg) and differential privacy protect data, reduce leaks, and accelerate model convergence. A privacy budget tracker monitors privacy loss and ensures long-term privacy protection. The suggested method outperforms FL techniques in accuracy, communication overhead, computing efficiency, privacy, security, scalability, and energy efficiency. The technology increases accuracy to 94.8%, reduces transmission costs to 150 MB, and increases computing performance to 1.8 million FLOPs per second. The privacy score is 9.5/10, and the security score is 9.0/10, protecting you from dangers. It can scale to 500 clients, making it more scalable than other methods. Health care compliance has increased to 9.8/10, with more people following HIPAA and GDPR. With these advancements, the FL framework is one of the best methods for analyzing brain images with privacy protection. It allows safe, effective, and scalable medical AI app use.

title: AI-Powered Detection of Body Fluid Markers for Early Warning of Lifestyle Diseases
authors: Rama Bansidhar Dan, Darshan D G, Lohith gowda C P, Mithun Raj Urs T V, Ranganatha N
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This project introduces an AI-based web application for the prediction of disease risks through body fluid biomarkers. Key blood test values (e.g., BMI, Cholesterol, Triglycerides, HDL, LDL, Creatinine, BUN) are input by the user to receive a general risk assessment for their health condition. The backend is an application of machine learning algorithms trained on an actual clinical dataset to determine the input's predictive power for diseases like diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, kidney function impairment, and metabolic syndrome-from else. The system returns a risk score, along with biomarkers that contributed most to that risk, together with relevant health advice. As an educational and informational tool, this solution aims to allow users to better appreciate their health condition and prompt them to pursue further investigation through health professionals.

title: LMAgent: A Large-scale Multimodal Agents Society for Multi-user Simulation_supp1-3651078.pdf
authors: Wu Liu
abstract: The believable simulation of multi-user behavior is crucial for understanding complex social systems. Recently, large language models (LLMs)-based AI agents have made signifi cant progress, enabling them to achieve human-like intelligence across various tasks. However, real human societies are often dynamic and complex, involving numerous individuals engaging in multimodal interactions. In this paper, taking e-commerce scenarios as an example, we present LMAgent, a very large scale and multimodal agents society based on multimodal LLMs. In LMAgent, besides freely chatting with friends, the agents can autonomously browse, purchase, and review products, even perform live streaming e-commerce. To simulate this complex system, we introduce a self-consistency prompting mechanism to augment agents' multimodal capabilities, resulting in significantly improved decision-making performance over the existing multi agent system. Moreover, we propose a fast memory mechanism combined with the small-world model to enhance system ef f iciency, which supports more than 10,000 agent simulations in a society. Experiments on agents' behavior show that these agents achieve comparable performance to humans in behavioral indicators. Furthermore, compared with the existing LLMs-based multi-agent system, more different and valuable phenomena are exhibited, such as herd behavior, which demonstrates the potential of LMAgent in credible large-scale social behavior simulations.

title: Emoticore: An Optimized 4-Channel EEG-Based Emotion Detection System
authors: Zeba Mehaboob A, Airin Basal, Sreeram Manghat, Aswanth M P, Fathima Safa V P
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: In affective computing, healthcare, and human-computer interaction, the use of EEG signals for emotion detection is becoming more and more significant. In order to objectively categorize emotional states, these systems examine brainwave activity. Nevertheless, the majority of current models depend on high-density electrode arrays, like those with 14 or 32 channels, which guarantee high accuracy but have drawbacks in terms of affordability, portability, and computational effectiveness. It is essential for real-world applications to reduce the number of channels without appreciably compromising accuracy. In order to reduce hardware complexity and maintain accuracy that is comparable to traditional 14- channel models, we propose a novel optimized 4-channel EEG-based emotion detection system. Using the four- quadrant emotion model (valence vs. arousal), it carefully chooses electrode locations that are best suited for emotion classification. A Random Forest Regression model is trained using the DEAP dataset, which is a popular emotion recognition benchmark. By fine-tuning the model, it becomes more effective at mapping EEG features to emotional states, and our system achieves an accuracy of 83.3%, proving its viability for low-cost, portable emotion detection. Our system improves EEG-based emotion recognition by addressing issues of cost and portability, improving accessibility, and detecting stress, anxiety, and depression in mental health monitoring, as well as adaptive human-computer interfaces that react dynamically to user emotions.

title: Comparative Analysis of GNSS and INS Loose and Tight Integration Navigation Accuracy in Complex Urban Environments
authors: Xiaoqing Wang, Junli Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: In complex urban environments, GNSS signals are vulnerable to interference, which significantly affects the performance of integrated navigation systems. This paper presents a systematic evaluation of the navigation accuracy of GNSS and INS integration using both loose and tight coupling strategies under such conditions. First, mathematical models for both integration approaches are derived. Then, field experiments are conducted using real-world data collected in both coupling modes. Experimental results show that under normal GNSS signal conditions, the tightly coupled method improves positioning accuracy by 9.09% in the North direction and 18.18% in the Up direction compared to the loosely coupled method, while the positioning error in the East direction remains essentially the same for both. In terms of velocity accuracy, the tightly coupled system demonstrates improvements of 9.09%, 20.00%, and 20.00% in the North, East, and Up directions, respectively, with particularly notable enhancements in the East and Up components. For attitude estimation, the tightly coupled system improves heading, roll, and pitch accuracy by 0.60%, 2.61%, and 22.39%, respectively. When GNSS signal outage occurs, the loosely coupled system is unable to provide navigation or positioning outputs, whereas the tightly coupled system can still output navigation data, albeit with reduced accuracy. Therefore, in complex urban environments, tight GNSS and INS integration is recommended as the preferred strategy to ensure better accuracy and availability in integrated navigation.

title: Fine-Tuning of a BERT Model for Oncology EHR Analysis in Brazilian Portuguese
authors: Bruna A. O. De Brito, Itamir de M. Barroca Filho, André M. Gurgel, Jean M. M. De Lima, Ramon Malaquias
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: This study presents a fine-tuning of the BERTimbau model for Named Entity Recognition (NER) in Electronic Health Records (EHR), focusing on oncology data in Brazilian Portuguese. The proposed approach employs an annotated dataset formatted in the Inside-Outside-Beginning (IOB) scheme, enabling precise extraction of clinical entities. The model was trained using the BERTimbau Base Tokenizer, with hyperparameters optimized through the Hugging Face library. Experimental results demonstrate robust performance, achieving F1scores between 0.83 and 0.85 across disease, procedure, and medication categories. When applied to a dataset of 125,825 new clinical records, the model achieved a correct identification rate exceeding 92%, underscoring its potential for medical decision support. Key challenges include enhancing classification accuracy for less frequent entities and adapting the model to diverse clinical contexts. Future directions involve dataset expansion, data augmentation techniques, exploration of more advanced transformer-based models, and integration into hospital decision support systems to further improve healthcare analytics.

title: THERAPICK: An Integrated Approach for ARTI Antibiotic Recommendations Using Rule-Based Logic, Tanimoto Similarity, and Multidimensional Data
authors: Meidina Tantri, Norma Hermawan, Achmad Arifin, Mohammad Nuh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Antibiotic resistance poses a critical global health crisis, exacerbated by inappropriate prescribing for Acute Respiratory Tract Infections (ARTI). This study presents THERAPICK, a system integrating clinical data (WHO Guidelines, CARD, ATC, KEGG, SMILES) to recommend antibiotics. A rule-based approach assesses antibiotic need from patient history and weighted symptoms, while filtering with ATC codes (J01) generates clinically relevant alternatives. Molecular similarity, calculated via the Tanimoto coefficient and validated with KEGG classification, identifies different pharmacological classes to mitigate cross-resistance risk. Unlike prior systems relying on culture-based testing, THERAPICK leverages molecular and pharmacological profiling for safer recommendations. The system successfully filtered 57.21% of irrelevant antibiotics from CARD, with structural analysis showing $\mathbf{8 5. 6 \%}$ of low-similarity alternatives ($\mathbf{0. 1 - 0. 4}$ Tanimoto coefficient) belong to different pharmacological classes. Securely implemented with a FastAPI backend and web frontend, THERAPICK provides rational, data-driven recommendations, supporting safer and more efficient clinical decision-making for ARTI treatment.

title: Multi-label Emoji Prediction on an Urdu Twitter Dataset using Deep Learning
authors: Touqeer Abbas, Muhammad Ahsan Aziz, Dr. Khalid Saleem, Fatima Tuz Zuhra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Urdu has a complex linguistic structure. It has notable challenges for Natural Language Processing (NLP), especially in emoji prediction on platforms like Twitter. Despite emojis enhancing emotional expression globally, Urdu remains underexplored due to limited resources. This study addresses multi-label, multi-class emoji prediction using a large-scale dataset of 1 million Urdu tweets. This dataset labeled with both single and multiple emojis, covering 2,114 unique emojis. Sequential models like LSTM showed limitations in capturing long-range dependencies, while transformer-based models, particularly fine-tuned RoBERTa, offered better contextual understanding. We further introduce a novel Semantic Similarity-Based Emoji Prediction (SSEP) approach, combining word and emoji embeddings with Facebook AI Similarity Search (FAISS) to enhance semantic matching and retrieval. Comparative evaluation with English, Chinese, Hindi, and Arabic methods highlights the unique low-resource constraints of Urdu. Results demonstrate that transformer-based and semantic similarity methods outperform traditional models, with SSEP achieving the highest performance, establishing its effectiveness for emoji prediction in low-resource languages.

title: YOLO V8-Based Illegal Fishing Detection Using Underwater ROV and ASV Robot Through UDP Communication
authors: Revansyah Armadito, Soraya Norma Mustika, Arya Kusumawardana, Achmad Hamdan, Viola Malta Ramadhani, Safaa N Saud Al-Humairi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated (IUU) fishing is a multidimensional challenge that threatens the sustainability of global marine resources, particularly for Indonesia as the world’s largest archipelagic state. One of the most destructive forms of IUU fishing is the use of bottom trawl nets, which can severely damage seabed ecosystems and endanger both fish populations and the livelihoods of small-scale fishers. Although regulations such as Ministerial Regulation No.2/2015 of the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries explicitly ban the use of trawls, violations remain prevalent, especially in remote coastal areas due to limited monitoring and surveillance technologies. This study proposes the development of an underwater monitoring system based on autonomous technology and artificial intelligence by integrating a Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) and an Autonomous Surface Vessel (ASV). The ROV is equipped with a Raspberry Pi controller and an underwater camera for capturing live video footage, which is transmitted to the ASV via User Datagram Protocol (UDP) communication over Cat5 LAN cable. The ASV, powered by Jetson Orin Nano, serves as the data processing and communication hub, enabling real-time object detection using the You Only Look Once version 8 (YOLOv8) algorithm—a deep learning method renowned for its speed and accuracy in object classification. The models were trained using Roboflow and showed excellent performance, with an accuracy rate of 95%. On testing, the system successfully detected 241 non-trawl objects and 115 trawl objects, which shows the effectiveness of the model in classifying fishing gear in real-time.

title: Investigating the Role of the Instructional Team in Enhancing Student Teamwork Experiences in an Introductory Cybersecurity Course
authors: Aparajita Jaiswal, Paul Thomas, Sudip Vhaduri, Prateek Jaiswal, Sarah Rodenbeck
abstract: This innovative practice full research paper explores the role of the instructional team in supporting teamwork within a large, project-based course for first-year cybersecurity students. The study investigates how instructional teams can enhance collaboration and problem-solving skills critical for student success. Guided by two research questions, the study examines: (1) How do students perceive the effectiveness of instructional team support in facilitating teamwork? and (2) What aspects of instructional support shape students' collaboration experiences? At semester's end, 141 students completed a survey reflecting on their teamwork experiences and the instructional team's role. Thematic analysis of the qualitative responses revealed that students highly valued clear guidelines and expectations provided by the instructional team, which improved assignment understanding and coordination. Constructive feedback helped students refine their work, particularly on team milestones. Responsiveness and timely communication were frequently praised, with students noting the importance of quick, helpful replies. The instructional team also assisted with conflict resolution and interpersonal challenges, ensuring a productive team environment. Office hours were especially important for interpreting feedback and improving outcomes. Additional support included teaching teamwork strategies and offering emotional encouragement, which students found motivating. However, students suggested improvements such as clearer, more actionable feedback, refined rubrics, additional templates or examples, and more proactive outreach. These findings underscore the critical influence of a responsive instructional team in fostering collaboration in projectbased learning. By addressing students' feedback, instructional teams can more effectively support the development of essential teamwork and professional skills in STEM education.

title: Control-Communication Co-Design for Cloud–Fog Automation over 5G-TSN: A Coupling Loop Method under Network Uncertainty
authors: Xuanzhao Lu, Qimin Xu, Meihan Lin, Xin Li, Jinglong Zhang, Cailian Chen, Xinping Guan
abstract: The cloud–fog automation (CFA) paradigm accelerates Industry 4.0 by enabling fully automated industrial systems through interconnected wired and wireless devices. However, dynamic uncertainties such as environment-induced network delays and disturbances challenge the stability and efficiency of these systems. To address these issues, this paper proposes a control–communication co-design framework named C<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>L (Control– Communication Coupling Loop), which integrates 5G and Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) to coordinate transmission and control across cloud and fog layers. A hierarchical control strategy is introduced based on a delay threshold derived from Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) analysis, enabling dynamic selection between cloud and fog control units for both stability and responsiveness. To ensure timely and reliable control input delivery under uncertain networks, we develop a deterministic transmission mechanism centered on a novel metric, Packet Loss Tolerance (PLT), which quantifies how many consecutive losses the system can endure while maintaining stability. Additionally, a new optimization criterion, Pareto Deviation Value (PDV), is proposed to avoid combining control and communication costs with incompatible physical units. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method enhances control robustness and communication efficiency in complex industrial networks.

title: TransMap: Transformer-Enhanced Divide-and-Conquer Reinforcement Learning Framework for Efficient CGRA Compilation
authors: Jingyuan Li, Wenbo Yin, Lingli Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Coarse-grained reconfigurable architectures (CGRAs) combine flexibility with high performance, making them a promising solution for data-intensive computing. CGRA compilers are essential for determining how data flow graphs (DFGs) are executed on hardware. Recently, machine learning-based compilers have garnered significant attention for CGRA compilation. However, few deep learning compilers leverage the rich attentional information between DFGs and the CGRA abstractions effectively. Meanwhile, traditional compilers continue to struggle with inadequate compilation quality and long compilation time. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning-based compiler that integrates transformer encoders with reinforcement learning (RL) to address these issues. The transformer encoder captures task dependencies by embedding feature maps from both the DFG and CGRA abstraction. Additionally, we design a tree-structured RL agent that employs spectral clustering to explore the extensive mapping solution space, optimizing task-to-resource allocation. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) compilers, achieving an average 1.22× improvement in compilation quality, a 33.39% increase in throughput, and a 12.83× speedup in compilation time, underscoring its potential to enhance CGRA performance.

title: Optimal Computation Load Balancing for Integrated Service Caching and Offloading Systems in Hierarchical Cloud Architecture
authors: Dongho Ham, Yeongjin Kim, Jeongho Kwak
abstract: Mobile services such as Augmented Reality (AR) and online gaming require high computing and storage resources with real-time data exchange with servers. However, mobile devices are resource-constrained and cloud computing incurs additional network latency which makes them dissatisfactory to use such mobile services. To tackle this challenge, service caching has been emerging as a critical technology that provides services by leasing resources from mobile edge computing (MEC) servers located close to the users. Unlike content caching, which stores data only for delivery, service caching utilizes both computing and storage resources, and thereby should be jointly considered with code offloading which offloads the processing workloads of mobile devices to servers. Therefore, the conventional caching strategy that caches the most popular services may not be the best choice, and the intertwined nature of service caching and code offloading policies makes the system operation complex. In this paper, we formulate an average cost (energy consumption, offloading payment) minimization problem of mobile devices constrained by service queue stability in a three-layer (mobile/MEC/cloud) network architecture. We apply a statistic-based dynamic optimization framework to derive an online-fashioned interTWined Interplay between Storage and Transmission, namely TWIST algorithm that jointly makes decisions of service caching, CPU clock frequency of mobile devices, and code offloading. Next, via theoretical analysis, we show the trade-off relationships between the average cost of mobile devices and service delay. Finally, extensive simulations demonstrate that TWIST can save up to 51% of cost for the same delay of 2.41sec. compared to the existing algorithms.

title: Implementing a Praxis of Change: A Comparative Case Study on Interactive Methodologies and the Instruction of Engineering Ethics
authors: Hortense Gerardo, Alessandro Marinoni, Raymond De Callafon
abstract: This Work-in-Progress paper introduces an experiential, game-based intervention for teaching engineering ethics to upper-level undergraduates in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (MAE). Traditional ethics instruction often emphasizes compliance and regulatory frameworks, which may inadequately prepare students for real-world dilemmas characterized by incomplete information, ambiguous trade-offs, and the need for trust among interdisciplinary teams. To address this gap, we developed a role-playing card game grounded in experiential learning theory, socio-technical systems thinking, and moral development frameworks. Students assume roles as Managers or Engineers within fictional companies competing for a client's sponsorship. Managers are briefed on project priorities (e.g., cost, sustainability), while Engineers possess information about available resources. This asymmetrical distribution of knowledge simulates real-world engineering environments and requires students to iteratively negotiate and revise design proposals under ethical and practical constraints. An “Ethics Points” system incentivizes decisions that prioritize stakeholder accountability, and final scoring rewards trustworthiness over profitmaximization. The educational setting includes mixed-methods assessment: post-game surveys to evaluate changes in ethical sensitivity and moral reasoning; qualitative reflection essays; and observational analysis of team dynamics during gameplay. Preliminary results indicate heightened engagement, improved ethical awareness, and stronger collaboration-findings that align with existing literature on the benefits of simulation- and game-based learning in engineering ethics. This intervention aims to humanize STEM instruction by embedding ethical reasoning into collaborative, interactive activities. The findings offer implications for broader integration of trust-centered pedagogies in interdisciplinary engineering courses and professional training contexts.

title: Developing Leadership Skills in Software Engineering Students - a Case Study of a Leadership Development Framework
authors: Nicolas Nascimento, Afonso Sales, Rafael Chanin
abstract: This Research-to-Practice full paper evaluates the impact of a leadership development framework within a Mobile Application Development (MAD) course, focusing on the integration of Scrum, Challenge-Based Learning (CBL), and shared leadership. The study addresses the growing importance of soft skills in software engineering education and aims to provide insights into the influence of this framework on the leadership skills of software engineering students. The framework combined agile practices, specifically Scrum, with CBL and shared leadership, incorporating “role rotation” in which student teams rotated Scrum roles (Scrum Master and Product Owner) at the end of each sprint. An 8-week case study was conducted with nine teams, four of which applied the framework. After each sprint, all team members completed a questionnaire to assess their teamwork, with a final Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) questionnaire administered at the end of the development cycle. The results showed that the framework was easy to adopt, improved team collaboration, and empowered students to take proactive leadership roles. Although the generation of CBL guiding questions had less impact than anticipated, the overall structure supported collaborative learning. Some students suggested that the role rotation ceremony could be shortened to better align with Scrum Sprint Retrospective outcomes. These findings provide valuable insights for academia and industry. In academia, the framework offers a way to enhance software engineering education by integrating leadership skills development into Scrum-based group projects. For industry, the framework can foster improved team cohesion by reframing leadership as a collaborative process.

title: DC Off-board Vehicle to Grid/Building/Home: A Survey and Gap Analysis_supp1-3652429.pdf
authors: CARINA ENGSTROM
abstract: In recent years, the research interest in bidirectional charging of electric vehicles has increased significantly, driven by improved accessibility to charging and payment information as well as the increasing emphasis on integrating variable renewable energy sources more effectively into the grid. Integrating bidirectional charging with the grid/building/home can also reduce grid congestion. Despite this, broader implementation of this technology has not yet been achieved. In this context, this paper comprehensively surveys direct current (DC) off-board vehicle to grid/building/home chargers and analyses the gaps which prevent the technologies' wide implementation. These gaps are analysed by considering areas such as the development direction of bidirectional charging technology, battery cost and its degradation, V2G applicable standards, grid codes and charging protocols, deployment of V2G chargers (off-board versus on-board/wireless), market feasibility of V2G services, and the cost of bidirectional off-board chargers. The first survey of twenty-five commercial bidirectional chargers is presented and investigated in relation to the above-mentioned areas. Four key (technical, regulatory, financial, and behavioural) barriers are identified and discussed for the wide implementation of vehicle to grid/building/home charging.

title: Fault-Tolerant Multiport Single Diode Bridge for Distributed PV Power Collection and Voltage Step-up
authors: Taize Sang, Jianjun Ma, Shuli Wen, Miao Zhu, Zhang Dezhen, Shuo Guan, Xianger Shen
abstract: In this paper, a fault-tolerant Multiport Single Diode Bridge (MSDB) converter is proposed for distributed photovoltaic collection and DC voltage step-up. During normal operation, with consideration of the varying PV output power, the converter achieves regulation under different input powers with inner bridge phase-shift modulation. The power transfer capacity and soft-switching operation region under the normal operation mode are analyzed. When a short-circuit fault occurs at certain DC PV port, the fault port isolation and non-fault port reconfiguration are realized through the modulation strategy. The proposed topology is compared with the traditional parallel and series topology in terms of cost, volume, and power loss. Both normal operation and fault reconfiguration are tested through simulation and experimental results, in verification of the proposed topology and modulation methods.

title: FedAuth: A Lightweight and Privacy-Enhanced Authentication Scheme for Federated Learning in IoVs
authors: Kaiping Cui, Xia Feng, Chun Wang, Yuanbo Guo
abstract: In the Internet of Vehicles (IoVs), certificateless-based authentication has emerged as a promising approach to secure federated learning (FL) participation. However, existing certificateless-based authentication schemes still exhibit three notable limitations: (i) some schemes cannot provide security against public-key replacement (PKR) attacks and key-leakage threats; (ii) most existing schemes do not take realistic coalition attacks into account; (iii) while some schemes applicable to FL settings can offer relatively comprehensive security guarantees, they often rely on costly cryptographic operations. These limitations make it challenging for certificateless authentication frameworks to simultaneously ensure high security and low latency, particularly in resource-constrained FL deployments within IoV environments. To address these challenges, we propose FedAuth, a certificateless, lightweight, and privacy-enhanced authentication scheme tailored for FL in IoVs. First, FedAuth establishes a structured pseudonymization mechanism that enables vehicles to anonymously participate in the FL process while maintaining accountability. Afterwards, FedAuth ensures robust authentication security by cryptographically anchoring key generation to each vehicle’s pseudonym, enforcing strict key validation, and introducing hash-bound multi-layered signature verification that prevents signature recombination, thereby resisting PKR attacks, coalition attacks, and key-leakage threats. Second, FedAuth guarantees the authenticity and integrity of gradients through lightweight signature construction, which supports batch authentication while avoiding expensive operations such as bilinear pairings, thereby reducing latency. Security analysis shows that FedAuth preserves identity privacy and ensures model integrity in the face of adversarial conditions. Experimental results confirm that FedAuth significantly reduces computational overhead by at least 43.42% and saves not less than 19.8 KB of communication cost per 100 vehicles, outperforming state-of-the-art schemes in both efficiency and robustness.

title: The Impact of Big Data Analytics in Evaluating Green Bond Performance and Assessing Environmental Impact
authors: Yanan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This work aims to explore the application of big data in evaluating and quantifying the performance of green bonds through Big Data Analytics (BDA) with a particular focus on predictive analytics and sentiment analysis. Financial instruments for sustainable development, like green bonds, remain complicated in addressing the measurement difficulties economically and ecologically, primarily because of market uncertainty and the dynamic environment. Forecasting is used to determine financial profitability and measures of economic sustainability. In contrast, sentiment analysis is applied to evaluate the opinion of the public and other stakeholders about environmental activities. Notably, in the context of the current research, the quantitative research paradigm was chosen for this position, and it was applied when distributing a questionnaire to 250 working professionals within the fields of green finance and environmental impact assessment. Lastly, the paper demonstrates that the developed predictive model explains 72.9% of the Green Bond's performance, and the sentiment model explains 69.4 % of the environmental effect. Thus, these studies support the notion that adopting big data and analytics in conjunction with green finance and increasing transparency and corporate responsibility can tackle some of these problems and align with sustainable goals.

title: Broadening Participation in CS Research with Scalable Undergraduate Research Mini-Projects
authors: Bridget Agyare, Manooshree Patel, Alicia Matsumoto, Gireeja Ranade
abstract: This innovative practice full paper presents an approach to broadening undergraduate participation in computer science (CS) by integrating research mini-projects into a large CS course. Undergraduate research experiences can increase student retention rates in STEM pathways, with a notable impact on students from historically underrepresented groups (HUGs). However, these research experiences are often inaccessible to students, particularly in high-demand research areas and at large institutions. Inspired by Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs), we develop a scalable approach where research mini-projects are introduced into a standard, upper-division optimization for machine learning (ML) course. Through careful structuring of the project we are able to offer this to classes of hundreds of students, with limited teaching assistant support and relatively low instructor burden relative to traditional CUREs. In the post-project survey, most participants, including students from HUGs or with no prior research experience, reported moderate to large gains in readiness for further research, understanding of the engineering-mathematics research process, the ability to read and comprehend scientific literature, and self-confidence. Our specific offerings have been released publicly for easy replication.

title: Identifying Key Psychological, Biological, Lifestyle, and Social Risk Factors for Mental Health using Random Forest and Gradient Boosting Models
authors: Qurratu Aina Syafiah Abu Hassan, Mahayaudin M. Mansor, Nurain Ibrahim, Siti Shaliza Mohd Khairi, Norsyela Muhammad Noor Mathivanan, Gunardi
abstract: Mental health disorders affect over 970 million people worldwide, approximately one in eight, with prevalence increasing since 1990. This study applied Random Forest (RF) and Gradient Boosting (GB) algorithms to identify key psychological, biological, lifestyle, and social risk factors in a cohort of 1,000 individuals, with a nearly balanced target variable of 51.5% with and 48.5% without mental health diagnoses. The performance of the GB model exceeded RF in accuracy and sensitivity, though both models exhibited low specificity (<80%), indicating caution for clinical use. Feature importance metrics, including Gini impurity for RF and Gain, Cover, and Frequency for GB, assessed each factor’s contribution and consistency across multiple data splits of 70:30, 80:20, and 90:10. Stress level consistently emerged as the strongest key risk factor, with consultation history and severity of mental illness showing moderate influence; stress is modifiable through interventions such as stress-reduction programs, mindfulness training, and cognitive-behavioural therapy. Biological factors (age, gender) had minimal influence and are non-modifiable, though awareness can support personalised strategies. Social factors (work hours, occupation) and lifestyle factors (sleep, physical activity) were moderate-to-weak but modifiable. The country as a social factor influenced model training but had limited impact on predictions for new data related to mental health. Overall, the findings offer practical guidance for interventions targeting modifiable factors, while non-modifiable factors inform personalised approaches.
