title: WIP: A Canvas Public Course for Electrical Engineering
authors: Theresa M. Swift, Steve E. Watkins, Amardeep Kaur
abstract: This work-in-progress, research-to-practice paper describes a Canvas public course for multiple electrical engineering classes and analyzes usage patterns by students. With the public course visibility setting in Canvas, Missouri University of Science and Technology created a comprehensive public course to support six required classes dealing with circuit analysis and electronics for majors and circuit/electronics for non-majors. This interrelated content is available in a single online location, has a consistent format, and has a variety of resource types. This study seeks to understand patterns in student usage of the repository so that the resources and their implementation can be tailored for learning effectiveness. The intent is to guide the next iteration of development.

title: Reinforcement Learning Meets the Cloud: A Q Learning Framework for Efficient Task Scheduling
authors: Kıvılcım Naz Böke, Syed Shah Sultan Mohiuddin Qadri, Ahmet Kabarcık
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: Information technology is essential in our daily lives, with cloud computing (CC) being a key advancement. Its popularity is growing, but as more users join, the system can become complex. Although various traditional solutions tackle this problem in CC, thanks to developments and innovations in machine learning (ML), more effective and diverse ways are being developed. These developments enable users to access CC systems at a lower cost. Moreover, they help cloud providers deliver their services to customers more efficiently, with lower costs and reduced energy consumption, contributing to the creation of a more sustainable CC environment. Therefore, this study focuses on the Q-learning algorithm, a type of ML that can be helpful in scheduling tasks in CC, and presents a detailed analysis with a comparative performance evaluation against traditional methods like Round Robin (RR). Our experimental results demonstrate that the Q-learning algorithm not only provides stable outcomes but also significantly outperforms Round Robin (RR) in minimizing task scheduling costs, offering a more efficient and adaptive approach for managing cloud resources.

title: An Intelligent Search Engine Integrating Neural Networks and ElasticSearch for Semantic and Personalized Retrieval
authors: Vitaliy Bozhovskiy, Halyna Klym
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The intelligent search system based on neural networks and ElasticSearch is designed to deliver fast, accurate, and context-aware information retrieval. The project explores the integration of neural models for semantic understanding, image recognition, and personalized ranking to overcome the limitations of traditional keyword-based search. By combining full-text indexing with convolutional and graph-based AI modules, the system achieves improved relevance, flexibility, and scalability across diverse data types. Special attention is given to optimizing performance and maintaining low latency even under high loads and with all AI components enabled. The experimental evaluation focuses on search speed, semantic model quality, and user-specific ranking effectiveness, demonstrating the system’s ability to adapt to noisy data and vague queries while preserving high precision and diversity of results.

title: An Improved Robustness of Microphone Array Speech Enhancement in Complex Environment
authors: Quan Trong The, Nguyen Thi Huyen Chau
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Robust speech enhancement in adverse and complex environment is an essential problem of almost digital signal processing system, such as surveillance device, smart-home, mobile device, teleconferencing system, voicecontrolled equipment, robotics, cochlear implant. Microphone array (MA) is an efficient technique for extracting the original clean speech data while eliminating the surrounding noise, interference or other noise from different directions. Superdirective beamformer (SDB) is widely installed in numerous speech applications due to its high directivity factor towards the sound source, and the ability of concerning the steered beampattern at certain direction. However, in an annoying recording scenario, the imprecise configuration of MA geometry, the inaccurate estimation of preferred steering vector, the different microphone sensitivities, the moving head of speaker, the error of defined sampling frequency, the imprecise representation of recording situation, the SDB beamformer’s performance often degraded. Therefore, speech distortion and the existence of remaining noise at SDB beamformer’s output signal still a challenge task. In this contribution, the author proposed a modified SDB beamformer to enhance the evaluation in reducing the speech distortion, musical noise and increasing the speech quality in realistic real-life recording environment. The promising results has confirmed the capability of the author’s suggested technique in decreasing the speech distortion to $13.3 \mathbf{d B}$, suppressing the noise level to 9.1 dB and improving the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) to 9.8 dB. The obtained promising result shown that the proposed method can be integrated into multiple microphones system to resolve complicated problem, such as automatic speech recognition, reverberation.

title: Chameleon Swarm Algorithm Optimized Deep Learning Framework for Robust Android Malware Detection
authors: Insha Ali, Piyush Kumar Shukla, Raju Baraskar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The proliferation of Android-based applications as primary access points to e-governance platforms has intensified concerns regarding malware that threatens citizen privacy, service integrity, and national digital infrastructure. While deep learning (DL) techniques have demonstrated significant promise in Android malware detection, their performance is limited by sensitivity to hyperparameter tuning, redundant features, and imbalanced datasets. This paper proposes a novel Chameleon Swarm Algorithm (CSA)optimized deep learning framework for robust Android malware detection in e-governance environments. Inspired by the adaptive hunting strategies of chameleons, CSA balances exploration and exploitation to optimize feature subset selection, hyperparameter tuning, and class-weight calibration in deep neural architectures. The framework integrates static (permissions, API calls, opcodes) and dynamic (network traffic, system calls) features into a hybrid CNN-BiLSTM model, with CSA performing meta-heuristic optimization. Experiments conducted on benchmark datasets (Drebin, CICMalDroid 2020, AndroZoo) demonstrate that the CSA-optimized model outperforms state-of-the-art approaches-including PSO, GA, Grey Wolf Optimizer, and Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm-across metrics such as F1-score, AUC, and MCC. The framework achieves 97.8 % accuracy with a 2.4 % reduction in false positives, highlighting its effectiveness in protecting citizen data and ensuring the trustworthiness of Android-based e-governance services. Beyond improved detection, the system offers feature interpretability, energy efficiency, and adaptability for real-world deployment, contributing toward the vision of a resilient Cyber Surakshit Bharat.

title: Satellite-Based Analysis of Forest Damage in Ukraine’s Protected Areas
authors: Sofiia Drozd, Nataliia Kussul, Andrii Shelestov
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Ukraine’s protected forests face growing threats from military actions, illegal logging, and economic activities, requiring continuous monitoring. Current methods are often complex and resource-intensive, limiting scalability and frequent use. This study introduces an innovative satellite-based approach for rapid forest damage detection, providing a scalable, resource-efficient solution with minimal data and computational needs. We propose an anomaly detection method using the B4 spectral band in Sentinel-2 imagery, which has been experimentally identified as the most effective for detecting forest damage in Ukraine. Our findings show that the proposed method effectively distinguishes between undamaged and damaged forest areas. We identified significant forest destruction in protected areas of eastern, northern, and southern Ukraine, particularly in regions affected by active hostilities. However, the analysis also uncovered damaged forest areas in the Carpathian region and western Ukraine, suggesting that other factors such as economic activities and illegal logging may also contribute to forest degradation. Among the most affected protected areas are Siverskyi Donets River Valley (forest damage as of 2024 - 55.59 th. ha), Chornobyl Radiation and Ecological Biosphere Reserve (13.14 th. ha), Sviati Hory National Park (13.12 th. ha), Kreminski Lisy National Park (8.62 th. ha), and Oleshky Sands National Park (8.27 th. ha). Overall, by 2024, 249.71 th. ha of forest in protected areas had been damaged, accounting for approximately 5.17% of the total protected forest area in Ukraine.

title: Digital Monitoring of Microalgae Cultivation and Harvesting
authors: James Chun Ket Tai, King Hann Lim, Emmanuel Yahaya, Leonard Umban Anak Pengarah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Microalgae cultivation and harvesting require a real-time monitoring system to perform an optimization in the automated control. To perform a close-up monitoring, a digital monitoring system is proposed to observe the growth of microalgae with six parameters, i.e. temperature, $\mathbf{p H}$, dissolved oxygen, electrical conductivity, ammonia-nitrogen, and nitrate. These sensors are integrated with a programmable logic controller and Raspberry Pi for real-time data logging in a $\mathbf{4 0 ~ L}$ cultivation tank. The installation of two RGB cameras are used to observe the green index of the microalgae. It is compared with the standard biomass measurements using optical density absorbance at 680 nm. As an observation, there is a sinusoidal cycle happening in the dissolved oxygen and $\mathbf{p H}$ graph when microalgae carry out its photosynthesis. At the early stage of cultivation, several fluctuation occurs in the electrical conductivity and nitrate due to the microalgae activities. The change of image gradient indicates that the growth of microalgae can be linearly associated with the change of concentration. It can be an indicator for the harvesting process to be taken. The integration of color intensity with the sensory can provide a real-time monitoring for better understanding of microalgae cultivation and harvesting.

title: Analysis of Tourist Perceptions of Islamic Religious Tourism in Java Island Based on TOURQUAL Dimensions Using IndoBERT and ABSA Model
authors: Bayu Nalury, Herry Irawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Islamic religious tourism holds significant potential as a driver of national economic growth, particularly on Java Island. However, the evaluation of religious tourism quality based on online reviews is still rarely conducted using a structured analytical approach. Although sentiment analysis has been widely applied in various sectors, the integration of Indonesian language models with the Tourism Quality (TOURQUAL) framework remains underexplored in this context. This study proposes a hybrid analytical model integrating Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis (ABSA) with IndoBERT and classifying results using the six Tourism Quality (TOURQUAL) dimensions: Accessibility, Environment, Technical Quality, Human Element, Experience, and Safety. The approach is applied to online reviews of five major mosques on Java Island: Istiqlal Mosque, Al-Jabbar Mosque, At-Ta’awun Mosque, Namira Lamongan Mosque, and Surakarta Palace Grand Mosque. The findings reveal several negative evaluations that significantly influence tourist perceptions across multiple service dimensions, providing a structured basis for improving religious tourism service quality and supporting Indonesia’s efforts to achieve SDG 12.

title: Surrogate-Assisted Multi-Objective Optimization of Axial Flux Permanent Magnet Machines Using Machine Learning and Genetic Algorithm
authors: Mudassar Sajid, Faisal Khan, Shoaib Azmat, Khizer Rafique, Wasiullah Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: This paper presents a computationally efficient multi-objective optimization framework to enhance average torque and reduce torque ripple in single-sided axial flux permanent magnet machines. A Genetic Algorithm (GA) first explores the design space, defined by key geometrical parameters, using finite element analysis (FEA). Although the GA effectively identifies high-performance solutions, it is inherently constrained by substantial computational demands. To address this limitation, a surrogate machine learning model called Support Vector Regression is developed and trained on finite element analysis data generated during GA evolution. The developed model predicts machine performance with exceptional accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> 0.99, Mean Absolute Error 1.18), achieving a reduction in optimization time of over 99.99% without compromising fidelity. This hybrid approach (GA + surrogate model) combines precise optimization with fast predictions for efficient machine design. The proposed hybrid framework represents the computationally efficient optimization approach for 3D machines that integrates genetic algorithms with machine learning.

title: Advancing Cyclist Safety: A Robust Collision Avoidance System with DBSCAN-Enhanced Clustering and Bayesian-Optimized Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Lee Hong Thean, Wai Tong Chor
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: The safety of cyclists remains a critical concern due to the increasing risk of collisions with rear-approaching vehicles, often made worse by poor visibility and blind spots. This paper presents a novel system to enhance cyclist safety via a collision prevention system for a bicycle by detecting and tracking rear-approaching vehicles. The system utilizes Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) to cluster LiDAR data points for identifying vehicles, achieving a mean absolute percentage error of 0.56 % and employs an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) to estimate their positions and velocities. The EKF is enhanced with a distinctive feature of adaptive parameterization with Bayesian Optimization that balances sensor trust and model fidelity, yielding a 34.38 % improvement over the standard EKF in estimation accuracy under varying cycling scenarios. Extensive simulations demonstrate the ability of the proposed method to detect and track multiple rear vehicles at high estimation accuracies and thus, enable timely cyclist alerts. By leveraging advanced clustering and adaptive filtering techniques, the proposed estimation framework offers a robust solution in reducing bicycle-related accidents.

title: Multiobjective Optimization With Minimum Output Error and Maximum Efficiency for WPT Systems Based on Discrete Neighborhood Search–Model Predictive Control Scheme
authors: Fei Xu, Hualei Zheng, Xian Zhang, Zhixin Chen
abstract: Traditional control schemes for wireless power transfer (WPT) systems struggle to achieve zero voltage switching (ZVS), output stability, and efficiency optimization simultaneously. To address this limitation, this article proposes a discrete neighborhood search–model predictive control (DNS-MPC) strategy for multiobjective optimization in inductor-capacitor-capacitor-series (LCC-S) compensated WPT systems, addressing three critical requirements: output regulations, transmission efficiency maximization, and ZVS realization. First, a mathematical model of the WPT system is developed based on circuit analysis. The derived expressions are then used to identify the operating regions that ensure ZVS across all power switches. Second, a composite cost function is formulated to systematically coordinate voltage tracking precision and power loss minimization. Third, the DNS-MPC strategy is developed to simultaneously achieve precise output voltage regulation, high efficiency, and ZVS operation over a wide load range without auxiliary circuits. Experimental validation under multiple operating points (80/100/120 V references) demonstrates consistent performance: the maximum voltage fluctuation is limited to 0.26 V, peak efficiency reaches 93.92%, and efficiency variation remains within 4.22% and ensures ZVS operation. Additional tests under coil misalignment confirm robust operation with efficiency above 89%, and detailed loss analysis shows that system losses were reduced by 29.1%, 25.22%, and 38.99% at load resistances of 20, 50, and 100 Ω, respectively.

title: FRDP: A Micro Free-Flying Robot With Dual-Vector Propulsion in Space Station
authors: Yimin Zhu, Xiaoyu Ji, Lixian Zhang, Yifei Dong, Yihang Ding
abstract: This article details the design, modeling, and control of the FRDP, a novel free-flying robot with an innovative dual-vector propulsion structure for space station. Compared with the existing free-flying robots, FRDP achieves a significant reduction in weight and size by decreasing the redundancy of the propulsion module, while maintaining stronger mobility when carrying more sensing and computing modules. A new control allocation method for this dual-vectored propulsion structure is presented, enabling the generation of thrusts and torques in six degrees of freedom (DOFs) using four actuators. To adapt to various mission requirements, FRDP features both energy-saving mode and performance mode. The dynamic modeling and controller design for both modes are described, and the maneuvering performance and energy efficiency of the two modes are analyzed and compared. Simulation and real-world experimental results fully validate the effectiveness of the designed dual-vector propulsion structure and dual-modal controller, demonstrating FRDP’s potential for task execution in space station environments.

title: Relationship Between Wave-Related Reynolds Number and Doppler Velocity at Grazing Incidence_supp1-3653263.pdf
authors: Michael Stresser
abstract: We show empirical evidence that the mean spatial gradient of the Doppler velocity, measured by a coherent X-band marine radar at grazing incidence, serves as a reliable proxy for measuring the so-called wave-related Reynolds number - defined as the product of air-side friction velocity and significant wave height divided by the kinematic viscosity of the surface water. Comparisons to approximately 180 hours of in situ observations spanning various environmental conditions in the Southern North Sea yield an overall squared correlation coefficient of 0.93, and a normalized root-mean-square error of 16%. These results suggest that coherent marine radar offers a practical and relatively cost-efficient tool for observing key parameters related to ocean surface dynamics and air-sea interactions, such as whitecap coverage.

title: Designing Laboratory Courses for Undergraduate Students in Materials Science and Engineering - a Systematic Review
authors: Anurag Srivastava, Bilal Mansoor, Saira Anwar
abstract: This full research paper aims to identify how lab courses have been designed for materials science courses and best practices for course development. As of 2024, only 48 universities in the United States have ABET-accredited Materials Science and Engineering (MSE) undergraduate degrees. One of the accreditation criteria is for students to be able to conduct experiments, analyze data, and draw conclusions from the experiment, typically met through laboratory coursework. Understanding effective approaches to lab design is critical for developing new or revised MSEN curricula. To address this need, a systematic literature review was conducted to answer the following research question: What are the different types of laboratories used to teach materials science concepts? The review was guided by the principles of the Processing, Structure, Properties, and Performance (PSPP) framework and the Experiential Learning Theory (ELT). Articles reviewed for the study were searched using the Compendex and ERIC databases, resulting in search string that yielded 293 articles. Following the principles of inclusion and exclusion criteria, 20 articles were reviewed for the final synthesis. Open coding and thematic analysis were used for article synthesis. The three themes identified were in-person laboratories for students, computational laboratories for students, and project-based laboratories. All articles illustrated the integration of the four cycles of ELT with the PSPP framework, highlighting their benefit in designing lab courses. The paper serves as a resource for educators who are exploring possible ways to develop laboratory courses for MSEN undergraduate programs.

title: WIP: Skill Extraction and Matching in Workforce Development: A Comparative Analyses of BERT and Generative Language Models to Inform the Design of an Interactive Digital Skills Platform
authors: Samson Kwaku Nkrumah, Sara Morrissey Tucker, Fiona Boyle, Joseph Walsh
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice category paper describes a comparative analysis of Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Transformers (BERT) and Generative language models (Gemini and Llama-3.2) for skill extraction and matching to inform the design of an Interactive Digital Skills Platform (IDSP). The research addresses the challenge of aligning workforce skills with regional economic transitions, particularly in areas shifting from resource-dependent industries to renewable energy for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs). The study employs Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to extract both explicit and implicit skills from unstructured text (CVs, job descriptions, course information) and map them to standardised ontologies. The methodology includes synthetic data generation, model fine-tuning, and performance evaluation using precision, recall, F1-score, and Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR). Preliminary findings indicate that BERT-based models demonstrate superior performance in semantic understanding and comprehensive coverage (0.78 recall), while Generative models show strengths in precision (0.64) and ontology alignment when combined with contextual embeddings. The research contributes to workforce development by enabling personalised career guidance and reskilling recommendations that align with regional economic needs and sustainability goals.

title: EDEN: Efficient Dual-Layer Exploration Planning for Fast UAV Autonomous Exploration in Large 3-D Environments_supp1-3639779.mp4
authors: Xuebo Zhang
abstract: Efficient autonomous exploration in large-scale environments remains challenging due to high planning computational cost and low-speed maneuvers. In this article, we propose an efficient dual-layer exploration planning method. The insight of our dual-layer planning method is efficiently finding an acceptable long-term region routing and greedily exploring the target in the first region of routing at high speed. Specifically, we propose a long-term region routing approximate algorithm, called “exploration-oriented heuristic double-tree algorithm”, to ensure real-time planning in large-scale environments. Then, the viewpoint in the first routing region with the highest curvature-penalized score, which can effectively reduce decelerations caused by sharp turn motions, will be chosen as the next exploration target. To further speed up the exploration, we propose an aggressive and safe exploration-oriented trajectory planning approach to enhance exploration continuity and speed. The proposed method is compared with state-of-the-art methods in challenging simulation environments. The results show that the proposed method outperforms other methods in terms of exploration efficiency, computational cost, and trajectory speed. We also conduct real-world experiments to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The code will be open-sourced.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: Topology-Aware Transformer-Based Federated Learning for Spatially Decentralized IIoT Infrastructure
authors: Venkateshwaran Shanmugham
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper introduces a transformer-based architecture for topology-aware federated learning, accompanied by a detailed elucidation of the framework. One of the anticipated uses for it is in large Internet of Things (IoT) networks. This strategy helps individuals learn by using graph-theoretic properties like degree, betweenness, and closeness centrality. Older systems used raw sensor data, but this approach is different. When every node in the network knew exactly what they were supposed to do and how they fit into the communication system, we knew we had attained our aim. Transformational topologies may illustrate both geographical and temporal connections while still keeping data safe. Training on the device itself makes this procedure feasible. You may use topology-weighted aggregation to incorporate local changes to a global model. You can modify the weights depending on how important the data is to the structure. This is one technique to make sure that the model is both robust and fair. The findings of this technique are better than those of the federated learning, graph-based, and transformer-based baselines when it comes to accuracy, progress, and growth. The findings were better in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and area under the curve (AUC) when training was cut back and transparency was increased. This design is great for Internet of Things devices that don't need a lot of processing power because it requires very little power and has very minimal reasoning latency. It can easily manage enormous networks and is robust even when it needs to deal with data that isn't IID, which is a serious concern for the economy. This is the best part. There are a number of potential strategies to improve the IIoT's federated learning. These include learning more about the structure, gaining more accurate representations, and following the advised steps. When all of these elements operate together, they produce a private system that can change and grow better at both operations and making predictions. Future intelligent IIoT systems could utilize this design to make informed decisions about dispersed industrial platforms.

title: An Intelligent System for Detecting Malicious Messages in IP Telephony within a Corporate Network
authors: Andriy Melnyk, Ihor Romanets, Ruslan Shevchuk, Oleh Kvasnytsia, Yurii Popyk, Vladyslav Ivanyna
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents an intelligent system for detecting malicious messages in IP telephony within a corporate network. This system employs innovative traffic analysis methods, enabling the timely detection of harmful or anomalous messages that could pose a threat to corporate communication security. The paper outlines the basic principles of its operation, including the use of machine learning techniques, big data processing, and integration with existing network monitoring systems. Special attention is given to the algorithms used for detecting and classifying threats, as well as the technology that ensures real-time traffic analysis and filtering. The scientific novelty of this work lies in the design and implementation of a system for detecting malicious IP telephony messages within a corporate network, which differs from known solutions by incorporating modules and procedures for detecting anomalous messages in IP telephony traffic based on an ontological approach, as well as real-time access distribution.

title: Casper: A Causality-inspired Defense with Confounder against Label Inference Attacks in Vertical Split Federated Learning_supp1-3652013.pdf
authors: Meng SHEN
abstract: Vertical Split Federated Learning (VSFL) allows participants to collaboratively train a better model with different features vertically partitioned in the same sample space, where the model is divided into bottom model and top model by the cut layer, trained by passive and active participants respectively. However, in the process, the labels owned by the active participant will still be inferred or stolen by curious or malicious passive participants. In this paper, we propose Casper, a causality-inspired defense mechanism with a confounder against label inference attacks in VSFL. Casper first analyzes the feasibility of optimizing the training process in VSFL at the intervention level from a causal perspective. It then introduces a confounder consisting of cut layer output reconstruction and label obfuscation to disrupt the direct causality between cut layer outputs and labels. Additionally, we integrate selective discrepancy training to further ensure model utility by strategically balancing training between active and passive participants. Extensive experiments conducted on four datasets across different tasks demonstrate that Casper effectively preserves label privacy while maintaining model performance, significantly outperforming current advanced defending methods in VSFL.

title: Deep Learning for Smart Surveillance: Multi-Class Detection of People, Weapons, and Masks using YOLOv11
authors: Ludovica Beritelli, Roberta Avanzato, Luca Guarnera, Francesco Beritelli, Sebastiano Battiato
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Computer vision technologies are revolutionizing the field of security, providing intelligent and automated tools for crime prevention. In this study, we propose an advanced approach for the simultaneous detection of people, weapons, and facial masks in images extracted from surveillance camera video streams. Unlike most works in the literature, which focus on static and less contextualized scenarios, our method operates on real-world, dynamic scenes using the YOLOv11 architecture. Experimental results show an accuracy of 65.35% on the test set, with a weighted precision of 71.94%, demonstrating the model’s ability to reduce false positives. This work represents a concrete step towards intelligent monitoring systems, with promising improvements achievable through dataset optimization and the integration of advanced deep learning techniques, aiming to enhance public security effectiveness.

title: Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Crime Prediction in Montgomery County
authors: Aishwarya Reehl, Bo Yang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Crime Prediction is an integral part of keeping the community safe and harmonious. To provide the ability to predict crime even in the smallest form to the respective authorities to anticipate concerns, prevent victims from being targeted, and allocate their resources in the best possible way. This paper determines the use of a Machine learning algorithm to predict Crime in Montgomery County. The newly proposed pruned CatBoost algorithm with decision trees helps increase the precision for the crime prediction to 86.66%. This research also shows how we can pre-process information as needed for prediction algorithms.

title: The AI Policy Module: Developing Computer Science Student Competency in AI Ethics and Policy
authors: James Weichert, Daniel Dunlap, Mohammed Farghally, Hoda Eldardiry
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) further embeds itself into many settings across personal and professional contexts, increasing attention must be paid not only to AI ethics, but also to the governance and regulation of AI technologies through AI policy. However, the prevailing post-secondary computing curriculum is currently ill-equipped to prepare future AI practitioners to confront increasing demands to implement abstract ethical principles and normative policy preferences into the design and development of AI systems. We believe that familiarity with the ‘AI policy landscape’ and the ability to translate ethical principles to practices will in the future constitute an important responsibility for even the most technically-focused AI engineers. Toward preparing current computer science (CS) students for these new expectations, we developed an AI Policy Module to introduce discussions of AI policy into the CS curriculum. Building on a successful pilot in fall 2024, in this innovative practice full paper we present an updated and expanded version of the module, including a technical assignment on “AI regulation”. We present the findings from our pilot of the AI Policy Module 2.0, evaluating student attitudes towards AI ethics and policy through pre- and post-module surveys. Following the module, students reported increased concern about the ethical impacts of AI technologies while also expressing greater confidence in their abilities to engage in discussions about AI regulation. Finally, we highlight the AI Regulation Assignment as an effective and engaging tool for exploring the limits of AI alignment and emphasizing the role of ‘policy’ in addressing ethical challenges.

title: Decoding AI Impact: Longitudinal Analysis of Code Submissions in Programming MOOCs
authors: Leo Leppänen, Juho Leinonen, Arto Hellas, Erkki Kaila, Linda Mannila
abstract: This full research paper investigates how the emergence of large language model (LLM)-based tools has influenced student code submissions in Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) on programming. The rise of LLMs has introduced new opportunities and challenges in programming education, particularly regarding how students approach programming tasks. As code submissions can be used as artifacts representing the learning process, analyzing submissions before and after the wide-spread adoption of LLMs can provide insight into changes in how and whether students' approaches to solving programming tasks have changed and more broadly whether the way how programming is practiced has evolved. Using programming assignment submission data from two University-level programming MOOCs, we explore whether and to what extent code submissions have changed after the emergence of LLMs. Our analyses focus on quantitative metrics from the MOOCs, including number of submissions, code lengths, stylistic aspects, and code complexity and originality. Our results highlight that there are some differences in the high-level metrics extracted from submissions between the pre- and post-LLM era, although the differences are largely subtle. We discuss possible reasons for the subtle differences.

title: Blockchain and NLP Integration for Transparent AI-Enabled e-Governance
authors: Nandini Shirish Boob, Myasar Mundher Adnan, Amit Dutt, Aasheesh Shukla, Shashi Prakash Dwivedi, V. Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The convergence of artificial intelligence (AI) and e-Governance promises unprecedented efficiency and personalization in public service delivery. However, the proliferation of AI, particularly models reliant on Natural Language Processing (NLP) for automating administrative tasks, citizen interaction, and policy analysis, introduces significant challenges pertaining to transparency, accountability, and data integrity. The “black-box” nature of complex NLP models and the potential for algorithmic bias can erode public trust in automated government systems. This paper proposes a novel integrative framework that leverages blockchain technology to introduce a layer of immutable transparency and verifiable auditability to AI-enabled eGovernance. We elucidate how blockchain's distributed ledger can be utilized to create tamper-proof records of NLP model training data, model versions, decision-making processes, and citizen-government interactions. The integration ensures that every AI-driven outcome, from a automated service request classification to a sentiment analysis of public feedback, is traceable and auditable against an immutable chain of evidence. This research delineates the architectural principles for such a synthesis, discusses key implementation challenges, including scalability and privacy, and posits that the blockchain-NLP synergy is not merely supplementary but foundational for building next-generation, transparent, and trustworthy AIdriven public sector institutions.

title: WIP: Supporting Engaging K12 Outreach Through Engineer-Educator Collaborations
authors: Joni M. Lakin, Hope Whiteside, Virginia A. Davis, Kay Love, Cheryl Seals, Edward W. Davis
abstract: This innovative practice WIP paper focuses engineer-educator collaborations that promote K-12 teacher career knowledge. Many K-12 teachers in the STEM disciplines are eager to keep their course content aligned with cutting-edge disciplinary research and with future career paths for their students. However, the demands of the classroom prevent teachers from staying up-todate with the latest trends. One solution to this issue is to create collaboration opportunities with STEM researchers where teachers can learn about the researchers' work and help the researchers translate their research to the K-12 classroom, such as part of an educational outreach project. These collaborations can improve the engagement of the STEM classroom and potentially encourage more students to pursue STEM careers.

title: Full-Arm Wearable Haptic Interface Incorporating Force Feedback and Joint Constraint Mechanisms
authors: Ralph Christian Llasus, Clyde Daniell Padernal, Glenn Magwili
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: This paper tackles the design of a user control device for a telemanipulation system in the form of a wearable full-arm exoskeleton in the user’s right arm with an implementation of a force feedback and joint restriction mechanism. The problem with the current telemanipulation controllers is that they lack the degrees of freedom (DoF) to encompass the entire arm for control, and at the same time provide insufficient or no feedback mechanism to simulate the feeling of grasping and touching objects from a robot arm to the hand. The prototype is a 3D printed wearable device embedded on a combined glove and arm sleeve made of cloth, spanning from the fingertips to the shoulder. It uses retractable strings to measure flexing of the joints, a wrench mechanism for the shoulder, and a combination of the MPU6050 and HMC5883L for wrist roll motion. To restrict the joints, MG996R motors are used to counter the rotation of their connected strings by rotating in the opposite direction to their motion. In addition, vibration motors are at the fingertips. Tests had shown that the error between the actual and measured flexing angles is within 5% acceptance, along with a delay of less than 100ms for transmission distances within 10m.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Predicting Employee Attrition in the Healthcare Sector
authors: K.K. Karthick, V. Vimalnath, N. Udaya Prakash, Ramar Veluchamy, M. Ganesan Alias Kanagaraj, K. Sathiyamurthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Organizational stability, staff performance, and quality of patient treatment can all be negatively impacted by staff turnover in healthcare. In the health sector, forecasting staff turnover requires models that are accurate and interpretable. This research utilizes a Hybrid Attention-based Deep Neural Network (HADNN) that combines TabNet feature encoding with an Attention Residual Fully Connected Network (AR-FCN). Whereas TabNet is beneficial when it comes to sparse hierarchical feature selection, AR-FCN uses residual attention for improved gradient stability and representation learning. The model was trained and validated on a healthcare staff dataset containing 15,238 records and 42 features. Cross-validation and SMOTE balancing is utilized during the validation. With an F 1 -score of 0.96, an AUC value of 0.98, and an accuracy rate of 96.8%, the developed HADNN performed better than Random Forest, XGBoost, MLP, and TabNet alone in predicting results. The workload index, tenure length, and stress index are the highest three parameters in the feature importance ranking. The findings show that HADNN makes forecasts that are interpretable, accurate, and stable, which are beneficial for healthcare workforce management decisions.

title: Improved Acceleration-Level Motion Planning Method for Robot Manipulators Corrupted by Noise
authors: Xiyuan Zhang, Zuoli Ye, Yaran Liu, Dongsheng Guo, Weidong Zhang, Shuai Li
abstract: Motion planning (MP) is one of fundamental issues in robot manipulators. Various MP schemes at joint velocity and acceleration levels are reported, but the noise impact is usually neglected. This paper presents an enhanced version of the acceleration-level MP (ALMP) method, incorporating additive noise considerations, specifically designed for robotic manipulators. Then, such an improved method, which is based on the pseudoinverse of robots’ Jacobian matrix, is theoretically proven to be robust against different types of noise. As case studies of the improved method, the noise-tolerance repetitive motion planning (NT-RMP) and the noise-tolerance minimum acceleration norm (NT-MAN) scheme are established for robot manipulators. Simulation and experiment results under the UR5 and Panda robot manipulators corrupted by different noises further validate the effectiveness and practicality of such two schemes and the improved ALMP method.

title: Research on the Applicability of the Objective Function for Parameter Identification of Load Model Based on Sensitivity Analysis
authors: Hanzhe Li, Xing Qu, Jintao Zhou, Juan Wen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the selection of objective functions in the parameter identification of load models lacks theoretical basis, the adaptability of three commonly used objective functions, namely mean square error, mean absolute error and root mean square error, is evaluated. By means of the first-order sensitivity theory, the influence of three commonly used objective functions on the parameter identification performance of the load model is evaluated from three dimensions: the convergence speed of parameter identification, the stability of the output curve, and the noise adaptability. The evaluation results show that the mean square error and root mean square error perform better in terms of the convergence speed of parameter identification and the stability of the output curve, while the mean absolute error has stronger robustness and adaptability in a noisy environment. Through simulation analysis, conclusions consistent with the theoretical evaluation results are obtained.

title: Energy Demand Assessment to Initiate CO₂ Emissions Reduction in Niger Transport Sector by 2050
authors: Aboubakar Amadou Y Mohamed, Arouna Saley Hamidou, Hamidine Mahamadou, Makinta Boukar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: In Niger, the transport sector is the main consumer of petroleum products, with a consumption of 355 kilotonnes of oil equivalent (ktoe) in 2021 far ahead of the industrial and domestic sectors. This study assesses the future energy demand in the transport sector with a view to initiating a reduction of direct CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by 2050. Using the Model for Analysis of Energy Demand (MAED), simulations were carried out based on an analysis of past trends in energy consumption and associated emissions. Three scenarios have been developed: the Reference Scenario, the Ambitious Scenario, and the Energy Transition Scenario. By 2050, the projected energy demand reaches 6.93 Giga Watt-year (GWyr), 13.06 GWyr, and 10.77 GWyr respectively for these scenarios. The results suggest that the Energy Transition Scenario is the most viable way to reduce direct CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions, provided that significant investments are made in low-carbone energy infrastructure and transport systems.

title: Gamification in Photovoltaic Panel Learning: Boosting Engagement and Knowledge Retention
authors: Sara Akbarnejad, Roghayeh Gavagsaz-Ghoachani, Amirhosein Mansouri, Matheepot Phattanasak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Incorporating game-based learning can significantly boost student motivation, engagement, and understanding in complex technical subjects. In this study, a game-based educational method is proposed to improve learning of photovoltaic panel concepts. In the first step, an educational video covering the main content was provided to students. Next, a set of questions was created in different categories, each with varying point values. After watching the video, students were grouped and took turns selecting and answering questions. If a complete response was given, the group received full points for that question, while partial answers earned fewer points. At the end, the group with the highest score was declared the winner and awarded a prize. Evaluation of this method showed that it not only increased student focus, motivation and interaction but also supported review and reinforcement of educational content. Additionally, designing this game in PowerPoint made the creation process quick and straightforward.

title:
Towards an Early-Warning System for Respiratory Health: Predicting NO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Exposure with LSTM–GRU–CNN–Hybrid Model
authors: Tanzil Aziim, M. Yoka Fathoni, Maghda Luqyana, Rindi Indah Lestari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Increased concentrations of nitrogen dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) in urban air have become a serious issue due to their impact on respiratory health, especially for vulnerable groups. To support mitigation efforts, an accurate NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration prediction system is needed as a basis for developing an early warning system. This study compares the performance of four deep learning-based approaches, namely LSTM, GRU, CNN, and the hybrid models CNN-LSTM and CNN-GRU. The evaluation was conducted using the Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) metrics. The results show that the pure CNN model produced the highest performance with an MAE of 0.896, an RMSE of 1.076, and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.996. Meanwhile, CNN-GRU also showed competitive results with an MAE of 1.718, an RMSE of 1.929, and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.989. In contrast, the CNN-LSTM combination produced the lowest performance. These findings confirm that the CNN architecture is capable of capturing spatial-temporal patterns in air pollution data very well and has the potential to be applied as the basis for an early warning system for NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> exposure. Thus, this study contributes to the development of artificial intelligence-based predictive solutions for environmental and public health.

title: Towards a Safe and Trustworthy LLM-RAG Chatbot for Hemodialysis Patient Education: Design, Implementation, and Preliminary Evaluation
authors: Prabu Kresna Putra, Elvira Nurfadhilah, Siska Pebiana, Esa Prakasa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: The increasing demand for accurate, timely, and personalized medical information in healthcare, especially for chronic disease management such as hemodialysis, has prompted the development of advanced technological solutions. This paper presents Chatbot Lisa, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (LLM-RAG) system designed to assist hemodialysis patients by providing relevant and accurate medical information. The focus of this paper is on the system architecture, highlighting the use of the Django framework for the frontend, Sanic for asynchronous request handling, and ChromaDB for semantic retrieval. The chatbot engine leverages the best model, Sahabat AI LLM Model with BGE-M3 embedding model. Additional features, such as user authentication and continuous feedback mechanisms, are included to improve the user experience and support iterative system refinement.

title: Advanced Security Framework for Threat Mitigation in Cloud Computing Environments
authors: Naga Sai Mrunal Vuppala, Kishore Subramanya Hebbar, Devdas Gupta, Vishal Sharma, Vandana Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The complexity of distributed infrastructures, multi-tenancy and common advancement of sophisticated cyber-attacks all contribute to growing threats to cloud computing environments. Conventional security solutions are frequently ineffective in handling mezzo-day attacks, insiders and vulnerabilities of quantum kind. In an attempt to counter these shortcomings, this paper introduces new mitigation method in Intelligent Quantum-Resilient Adaptive Defense Mechanism (IQ-ADM). Proposed reinforcement tool integrates the deep reinforcement learning into the tool to permit adaptive and independent threat detection with the emergence and homomorphic encryption may secure privacy with analytics across many nodes. In addition, quantum-safe cryptography primitives are added in such a way that, to provide resilience to attacks by future quantum computing. The system relies on the concept of federated learning to analyze user behavior, traffic patterns, and infrastructure utilization without sharing valuable raw information and therefore offer an ideal balance of safety and consistency. It employs a trust management layer, used as a blockchain boosts data integrity and responsibility in the communications between the nodes and a dynamic policy engine, powered by game-theoretic optimal assignment of defensive resources. IQ-ADM provides an upgradable cryptography defense system that can sustain the key workloads of the existing cloud eco-sphere with the advantages of state-current adaptive intelligence. The outcomes indicate that this solution is a solution to the major security issues, as the protection is solid and will withstand under the fluctuating and risky conditions in cloud computing environments. The suggested framework attains an overall accuracy of 96.2% proving its efficacy in secure cloud computing settings.

title: Pattern-Based Runtime Protocol Verification for Industrial Automation
authors: Oguike Ahaneku, Philipp Melzer, Radu Vidrascu, Eduard Zechner
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In industrial automation, validating processes against required protocols is crucial for ensuring correct operations. This paper presents a novel, formally grounded, pattern-based approach to protocol checking that models manufacturing process steps as composable patterns built from domain-specific primitives representing workcenters and carriers. The approach supports both positive (desired) and negative (forbidden) patterns, enabling dual-mode validation of process sequences. This structured approach enhances modularity, scalability, and adaptability across diverse manufacturing environments. The pattern-matching mechanism is formalized as a lightweight, domain-aligned runtime-verification model and deployed across multiple European manufacturing plants. Empirical analysis shows a statistically significant reduction in fault rates ($\mathbf{p}=0.0383$), with average fault rates dropping from 8.81% to 0.27% following deployment. These results demonstrate the protocol checker’s effectiveness in detecting violations, identifying root causes, and improving process reliability. This work provides a practical and flexible alternative to traditional formal verification.

title: Bayesian Joint Spatio-Temporal Analysis of HIV/AIDS, Hepatitis B & C, and Tuberculosis in Central Java
authors: Elza Ully Tiara Tampubolon, Ro’fah Nur Rachmawati, Dianadewi Riswantini, Rifani Bhakti Natari, Bagus Kusuma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: As one of the most populous provinces in Indonesia, Central Java reports consistently high burdens of HIV/AIDS, Hepatitis B & C, and Tuberculosis, as reflected in administrative health service data from the Indonesian Health Insurance Agency (BPJS Kesehatan). This study aims to simultaneously analyze the spatio-temporal patterns of these three diseases and estimate their relative risks using a Bayesian Joint Spatio-Temporal Model. The model incorporates shared and disease-specific spatial and temporal effects, with parameter estimation performed through the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA). Secondary data from BPJS Kesehatan covering 35 districts and cities in Central Java for the period 2019–2023 were analyzed. Results showed that Hepatitis B & C had the highest shared spatial effect $\left( {\delta _2^S = 0.434} \right)$, indicating strong geographic risk factors, while Tuberculosis exhibited the highest shared temporal effect $\left( {\delta _3^T = 0.614} \right)$, reflecting substantial dependence on temporal dynamics. Relative risks (RR) for HIV/AIDS were elevated in Surakarta City, Salatiga City, and Sukoharjo, whereas Hepatitis B & C consistently showed high risks in Surakarta City, Semarang City, and Salatiga City. Tuberculosis displayed high risks across most regions, with extreme values in Magelang City, Tegal City, and Kudus. Posterior probabilities that RR > 1 supported these findings, particularly for Tuberculosis (p > 0.9). These results underscore the concentrated disease burden in urban areas and highlight the need for spatio-temporal based interventions, including active screening, integrated services, and more effective control strategies in priority regions.

title: Mobile-Friendly Dog Breed Recognition Using ResNet-18 with Structured Pruning
authors: Jonathan David Concha Matas, Muhammad Zaid Mohsin, Baraa Alkilany, Haider Ali Khan, Raja Hashim Ali, Adnan Shah
abstract: Fine-grained image classification, like differentiating between various dog breeds, is difficult because many breeds look very similar and there often isn’t enough labeled training data. In this study, we compared a custom CNN built just for this task with a well-known model called ResNet-18, using the Stanford Dogs dataset. We trained both models in exactly the same way so the comparison would be fair. Our custom CNN reached 66.46% accuracy, while ResNet-18 reached 80.82%, showing that large pre-trained models are much better at noticing tiny differences between similar breeds. When we looked at the mistakes, we saw that the models often mixed up breeds that look alike, such as Siberian Huskies and Eskimo Dogs. We also tested how stable the models were in different conditions and found almost no accuracy change (only 0.40%) between indoor and outdoor photos. To make the models more efficient, we removed 30% of the channels in ResNet-18, which caused only a small 1.49% accuracy drop but still allowed it to run quickly on a mobile CPU at about 64.31 milliseconds per image. These results show the balance between accuracy, speed, and readiness for real-world use in fine-grained image tasks. Our evaluation setup gives helpful guidance for designing strong and efficient dog-breed classifiers, and future improvements could involve mixing custom and pre-trained layers, using smarter hardware-friendly pruning, and adding explanation tools to make the predictions easier to understand.

title: From Benchmarking to Prediction: Energy Profiling of Industrial Systems Using Machine Learning
authors: Dimitris Kallis, Moysis Symeonides, Marios D. Dikaiakos
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The widespread adoption of IoT has driven the development of cyber-physical systems (CPS) in industrial environments, leveraging Industrial IoTs (IIoTs) to automate manufacturing processes and enhance productivity. The transition to autonomous systems introduces significant operational costs, particularly in terms of energy consumption. Accurate modeling and prediction of IIoT energy requirements are critical, but traditional physics- and engineering-based approaches often fall short in addressing these challenges comprehensively. In this paper, we propose a novel methodology for benchmarking and analyzing IIoT devices and applications to uncover insights into their power demands, energy consumption, and performance. To demonstrate this methodology, we develop a comprehensive framework and apply it to study an industrial CPS comprising an educational robotic arm, a conveyor belt, a smart camera, and a compute node. By creating micro-benchmarks and an end-to-end application within this framework, we create an extensive performance and power consumption dataset, which we use to train and analyze ML models for predicting energy usage from features of the application and the CPS system. The proposed methodology and framework provide valuable insights into the energy dynamics of industrial CPS, offering practical implications for researchers and practitioners aiming to enhance the efficiency and sustainability of IIoT-driven automation.

title: Measuring Physiological Response and Mental Workload of AR Users in Assembly Learning: Implications for Educational Multimedia Applications
authors: Nadia Daliana, Dino Caesaron, Muhammad Iqbal
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: This study investigated the impact of Augmented Reality (AR) media as a learning tool for assembly, functioning as a transformative interactive multimedia service in the field of education. Addressing the limitations inherent in conventional assembly teaching methods, this study aims to analyze their impact on users physiological responses (heart rate) and mental workload (NASA-TLX). A comparative experimental design was employed by dividing the participants into AR and non AR groups. Heart rate measurements were obtained during the preexperiment, experimental, and post-experiment phases, whereas mental workload assessments were conducted post-experiment using the NASA-TLX instrument. Although the heart rate analysis did not show statistically significant differences between the two groups, the consistent heart rate patterns observed across all phases indicated physiological responses related to task demands when using multimedia services. Conversely, mental workload results showed that AR users reported significantly lower NASA-TLX scores (M = 15.8660) than the non AR group (M = 38.9340), (t(df) = -3.273(4.191), p = 0.029). These findings highlight the effectiveness of AR as a multimedia service capable of optimizing cognitive load during the learning process. As an initial study, this research provides valuable insights into the physiological effects and mental workload of AR, thereby contributing to the development of the literature on multimedia services and applications in education. In addition, these results can serve as a reference for the development of more effective AR-based learning services in the future.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for Threat Detection in Cloud Computing
authors: Sai Vamsi Chennupati, Somnath Banerjee
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper provides an in-depth discussion of ML (machine learning) algorithms to identify threats in cloud computing infrastructure, with a specific focus on intelligent detection of anomalies, intrusions, and malicious behaviors in dynamic cloud networking conditions. The suggested architecture applies a hybrid architecture with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to extract features and LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks to evaluate beginning and ending temporal behavior. A database containing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> samples of network traffic (normal operation and threatinduced operation) was referenced in the form of a cloud database. Preprocessing methods such as normalization and feature selection through Recursive FIre Elimination (RFE) method served data preprocessing. Experimental analysis revealed that the hybrid CNN-LSTM model had an Accuracy of 98.3 % and a Precision of 97.6%, a Recall of 98.1, and a False Alarm rate (FAR) of 1.2, although compared with the traditional algorithms like SVM and random forest, the hybrid model highly surpassed them in accuracy, precision, recall, and FAR. The proposed plan is quite adaptable to evolving threat profiles and inter-cross-live relations between virtual machine generations. Overall, the results prove the model is effective in deploying cloud services that are resilient to and secure against advanced attack-based bases.

title: Routing in Memoryless Quantum Networks: A Lexicographic Approach with Fidelity Guarantee
authors: Hilal Sultan Duranoglu Tunc, Milad Ghadimi, Riccardo Bassoli, H. P. Frank Fitzek
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: While routing methods in the literature often assume the use of quantum memory, this study proposes a routing algorithm designed for memoryless quantum networks. The algorithm leverages lexicographic optimization principles to hierarchically prioritize and optimize multiple objectives such as distance and capacity. This approach identifies the shortest paths between source-destination pairs within the decoherence time and selects a path that satisfies the minimum capacity require ments. To prevent entanglement fidelity from dropping below the desired threshold, purification is applied. Simulation results demonstrate the algorithm’s ability to manage latency while enhancing throughput effectively. The study comprehensively analyzes performance metrics under varying capacity values, request numbers, and threshold fidelity levels. Additionally, to the best of our knowledge, it is the first study to calculate latency, including queuing delay, in the context of quantum networks. Future research aims to explore optimal threshold fidelity values that balance throughput and latency performance.

title: Is Ransomware an Economically Distinct Attack Type? An Event Study of Market Reactions
authors: Ambarish Gurjar, Dalyapraz Manatova, Benjamin Staples, Spencer Chambers, L. Jean Camp
publish: 2025 APWG Symposium on Electronic Crime Research (eCrime)
abstract: Ransomware attacks have emerged as a significant threat, but has this new mode of attack transformed the economic calculus of cybersecurity? Before the emergence of ransomware, vulnerabilities could be characterized largely as having high negative network externalities while also creating risks for vulnerable parties. However, with ransomware’s rise, attackers can more directly extract payments from victims. Such a shift may change negative externalities into directly tangible and quantifiable costs for affected firms.To investigate whether ransomware victims internalize these costs, we compute Cumulative Abnormal Returns (CARs) around ransomware disclosure dates. Specifically, we leverage an event-study methodology to estimate CARs across multiple event windows for publicly traded firms affected by ransomware and compare these effects against prior findings in the cybersecurity finance literature. Our results show that firms in the critical manufacturing sector experience negative returns, whereas firms in the information technology and communications sector exhibit comparatively mild effects and a faster recovery trajectory, often showing positive cumulative abnormal returns in longer windows.Our findings illuminate an important difference in how the market reacts to ransomware incidents in different sectors. However, our findings could also imply that standard market valuations may understate the full economic impact of such incidents, failing to incentivize adequate investment in risk remediation.

title: Energy-Efficient and Balanced Cloud Task Scheduling Using Lion Optimization Algorithm with Elite Opposition-Based Learning
authors: Henning Titi Ciptaningtyas, Fuad Dary Rosyadi, Nadine Haninta, Hafara Firdausi, Khakim Ghozali, Annisaa Sri Indrawanti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Cloud computing has emerged as a vital technology for providing scalable and flexible access to computing resources. With the increasing demand for cloud services, efficient task scheduling has become critical to ensure optimal performance, balanced resource utilization, and reduced energy consumption. This study proposes the integration of the Lion Optimization Algorithm (LOA) with Elite Opposition-Based Learning (EOBL) to improve task scheduling in cloud computing environments. The simulation was conducted using CloudSim, configured with $\mathbf{5 4}$ virtual machines, 18 hosts, and 6 datacenters. Three datasets were employed: the San Diego Supercomputer Center (SDSC) Blue Horizon logs, a simple random dataset, and a stratified random dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that LOA outperforms the Genetic Algorithm (GA) in several parameters, including average execution time and imbalance degree. Furthermore, the hybrid LOA-EOBL significantly enhances scheduling performance across multiple criteria, such as makespan, total wait time, average start and finish times, scheduling length, throughput, resource utilization, and energy consumption. The improvements are consistent across all datasets, with notable advantages observed in complex workloads represented by the SDSC dataset. These findings highlight the potential of LOA-EOBL as an effective hybrid optimization method for cloud task scheduling, offering improvements in efficiency, fairness, and sustainability compared to traditional approaches.
