title: Recognizing Emotion on Faceless Images Using Deep Learning Approach
authors: Media Anugerah Ayu, Teddy Mantoro, Ammar Ramadhan
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Human emotions are intensively shown through facial expressions. However, in the real world, many images are only with partial or occluded faces, or even with unavailable faces; whereas these images contain/express emotions in them. This paper explores the feasibility of recognizing emotions on faceless images using deep learning techniques. This research aims to compare the performance of Inception and Baseline Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models in recognizing emotions from images, specifically focusing on photos and paintings. Inception models, known for their superior performance in image classification tasks, have shown promise in emotion recognition. However, the effectiveness of these models compared to baseline CNNs in the context of emotion detection remains to be explored. By conducting a quantitative analysis of both models, this research seeks to determine which architecture is more suitable for accurately recognizing emotions in images. The findings of this study may contribute to the development of more efficient and accurate emotion recognition systems, particularly in applications such as social media platforms, where automatic tagging of images can enhance user experience and content discovery.

title: Automated Mitosis Detection in Breast Cancer Histopathology Images Using Deep Learning
authors: Umair Makhdoom, Usman Ali Shams, Sadia Noureen, Jichuan Xiong, Muhammad Qasim Mehmood
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Breast cancer remains the most commonly diagnosed cancer in women, with over 2.3 million new cases and 670,000 deaths in 2022 alone, according to the WHO. Accurate grading is crucial and relies heavily on identifying mitotic figures in histopathology slides, a task that’s both tedious and prone to human error. In this work, we propose a fully automated pipeline using YOLOv8 for mitosis detection in whole-slide images. We divide high-resolution slides into 512×512 patches, remove background-heavy ones, and apply stain normalization for consistency. These patches are then processed using YOLOv8, enhanced with mosaic augmentation and an anchor-free head for fast and precise detection. Trained on the MITOS-ATYPIA-14 dataset, our model achieved 95.2% mAP@0.5, 90.3% precision, and 92.8% recall overall. For non-mitotic nuclei, precision reached 96.4%, while true mitotic figures showed 84.2% precision and 92.4% recall competitive with or better than existing methods. We also introduce a lightweight interface for expert review and feedback, making this solution both accurate and practical for real-world breast cancer diagnosis.

title: Wind speed missing value imputation model for high-altitude regions based on wind vertical distribution characteristics
authors: Lin Li, Yuhan Wang, Jin Wang, Xiaobei Li, Yuzhe Yang, Yongqian Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Wind power technology continues to advance, while viable development areas are becoming increasingly scarce. Consequently, the exploitation of wind resources in high-altitude regions is gaining significant attention. However, the complex topography and highly variable meteorological conditions in these areas result in wind characteristics that differ markedly from those at lower altitudes. Applying conventional missing data imputation methods from wind resource assessment can lead to substantial errors. To this end, this paper proposes a hierarchical imputation model called WSTC-HI, based on the spatiotemporal characteristics of high-altitude wind resources, addressing the collaborative filling of missing values in multi-height-layer wind resource data at high altitudes. By effectively reconstructing missing values using existing wind measurement data, this model resolves the difficulty of filling multi-height wind speed data gaps in high-altitude regions, which arises from the complex vertical structure and strong temporal dependency of wind resources. Given the pronounced vertical structure and strong temporal dependence of wind resources in high-altitude regions, raw wind speed data is clustered into multiple wind conditions using clustering algorithms. A reference height is selected within each cluster, and the Reformer model is employed for long-sequence modeling. Its locally sensitive hash attention mechanism and enhanced reversible residual network robustly handle complex missing patterns. Concurrently, wind shear index is utilized to achieve collaborative imputation of wind speeds across multiple height layers. Compared to Reformer imputation model, this model achieves a 11.6% reduction in root mean square error (RMSE) for imputation results and demonstrates significantly improved accuracy.

title: Short term Forecast of transformer error based on variational modal decomposition and gated cyclic element encoder decoder model
authors: Chen Hu, Liang Zhu, Aichao Yang, Haohan Zhen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: With the wide application of electronic transformer, the prevention of the error state of transformer becomes more and more serious. In order to further improve the prediction ability of transformer faults, this paper proposes a combined prediction model based on variational modal decomposition and cnn-gru-ed to predict transformer errors in the ultra short term. First of all, in view of the problem that the error related feature set of transformer is too complex, this paper selects the high correlation features through correlation analysis; Secondly, this paper introduces particle swarm optimization algorithm to optimize the parameters of VMD, and then decomposes and reconstructs the historical error and relevant feature sequences; Then, CNN-GRU-ED prediction models are established for each reconstructed signal to predict. Finally, the prediction results are superimposed to obtain the final prediction results. This paper takes the test data of a substation as an example, and compares it with direct prediction, recursive prediction and multi input and multi output models in single-step and multi-step prediction respectively. The results show that the model proposed in this paper is better than other models in prediction effect.

title: Biophysically Informed Diffusion Transformers for Predicting Personalized Drug Efficacy in Heterogeneous Tumor Environments
authors: Ramgopal Kashyap, Meenu Sahu, Madhu Malini John, Rachana Rastogi, Advin Manhar, Shanti Rathore
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This research proposes a biophysically informed diffusion transformer paradigm to assess tailored therapy efficacy in diverse tumor settings. Combining genetic, geographical, and therapeutic data is tricky, but this research successfully accomplishes it. Divide the tumor into cells or areas to start the multi-stage computer pipeline. It then records geographic and molecular heterogeneity using multi-omics, imaging, and phenotypic data. Graph-based models track whether molecules are comparable between nodes and spatially close. Node embeddings and edge properties are processed using diffusion-weighted aggregation and multi-head attention. Biophysical constraints enable realistic molecular propagation, and drug-target interactions generate a drug-aware graph. Patient-specific data helps the algorithm learn from clinical and experimental results, improving predictions. The model was compared to graph-based approaches and attention-enhanced transformers using many criteria. Prediction accuracy, MSE, AUCC, F1-score, calibration error, convergence time, and computing efficiency were considered. Regular graph models performed poorly, with prediction accuracy between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$82\%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$84\%$</tex>. But attention-based transformers boosted performance by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$86\%$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$87\%$</tex>. The biophysically informed diffusion transformer proposed had the strongest prediction performance, scoring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92.1\%$</tex> with low error rates, adequate computing efficiency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(88\%)$</tex>, and great discrimination (AUC 0.95). These results demonstrate that the framework can correctly reproduce tumor settings and include patient-specific drug-target interactions and feedback. This strategy produces a simple, scalable, and therapeutically relevant precision oncology tool. It advances predictive computer medicine by helping clinicians choose the best treatment for each patient.

title: Design and Develop MITRE ATT&CK Based Cybersecurity Threat Detection Model
authors: Gurinder Pal Singh, Rohit Bajaj, Manish Kumar Hooda
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study introduces an advanced cybersecurity threat detection framework built upon the MITRE ATT&CK knowledge base to address persistent threats in Internet of Things (IoT) environments. The proposed system integrates feature extraction, temporal modeling, anomaly scoring, attention mechanisms, and graph-based correlations to capture both short-term and long-term dependencies in telemetry data from RAM, CPU, registry, file systems, and network events. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the model surpasses traditional and modern intrusion detection systems in multiple dimensions of performance, achieving 97% precision, 96% recall, 97% F1 score, 96% accuracy, and 95% balanced accuracy while maintaining a detection delay as low as 3 seconds and minimizing the false negative rate to 4%. Furthermore, the model achieves superior ranking accuracy (96%) and alert efficiency (95%), ensuring effective prioritization of critical threats in real-time. These findings validate the model as a robust, adaptive, and context-aware solution for strengthening IoT cybersecurity against evolving advanced persistent threats.

title: CFSM: A Novel Causal Feature Selection Module for Two-Dimensional Out-of-Distribution Generalization_supp1-3616163.pdf
authors: Nanyang Ye
abstract: In real-world scenarios, training and test data are often collected in diverse settings, leading to domain shifts arising from evolving environments and selection bias. While causality-inspired methods have shown promising results in tackling the out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization issue, prior methods treat the discovered differences across domains as confounding variables. While effective in handling domain differences (i.e., unseen environmental features in test data), they may fail when confronted with intricate spurious correlations in real-world datasets. In this study, we first analyze this limitation to inadequate modeling of causal intervention and derive the OOD generalization bound to explain the challenges it introduces. To address this problem, we propose a modified causal intervention approach to mitigate various types of confounders. Motivated by the mathematical formulation of our modified causal intervention, we introduce the Causal Feature Selection Module (CFSM) to suppress model weights on both domain-differences features and spurious correlation features. Integrated within the Base Feature Extraction Module, In-Sample Module, and Cross-Sample Module (B-I-C architecture), CFSM collectively neutralizes the confounding effects arising from both domain discrepancies and correlation distinctions, thereby achieving causal feature selection. Under mild assumptions, we prove that the proposed CFSM method can achieve strictly lower OOD errors. Further experiments conducted on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Compared to previous deconfounding methods, our method not only mitigates the effect of domain-differences features but also the hard-to-identify spurious correlation features, achieving significant improvements in two-dimensional OOD generalization.

title: Exploring Educational Video Games for Learning Scrum: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Javier Alegre Landáburu, Daniel López-Fernández, Jesus Mayor, Edmundo Tovar Caro
abstract: This research paper explores educational video games for learning Scrum. Scrum, one of the most widely adopted agile frameworks in the software industry, remains challenging to teach due to its practical and team-based nature. Educational digital games have emerged as promising tools to bridge this gap by offering experiential and engaging learning environments. This systematic literature review examines 22 peer-reviewed studies that explore the use of digital games to teach Scrum concepts, roles, and practices in higher education and professional contexts. The analysis reveals a growing diversity of technological platforms, including web-based simulations, and immersive virtual reality. Most games focus on simulating core Scrum events such as Sprint Planning, Review, and Retrospective, often through active learning and gamification mechanics. However, gaps remain in the simulation of the whole Scrum framework and advanced practices (e.g., Planning Poker, role-specific tasks), in multiplayer experiences, and especially in conducting rigorous empirical validations. Findings highlight the motivational benefits of using serious games for Scrum education, while also underscoring the need for more rigorous research designs and broader implementation. Future work should focus on comprehensive, pedagogically grounded games that are empirically validated and leverage emerging technologies for scalable, collaborative, and realistic Scrum training.

title: Pathway to Computing: An Innovative Approach to Inviting Non-Computing Students into Graduate Computer Science Programs
authors: James Anderson, Jing Wang, Xinming Ou, Sudeep Sarkar
abstract: This innovative practice full paper describes a unique Pathway to Computing graduate certificate program at our university, designed to equip college graduates with non-computing degrees with the technical proficiencies necessary for entering graduate computer science programs or the technical job market. Based on previous work <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$[1,2,4]$</tex>, we developed a stand-alone program that provides a breadth of computing through eight fully online courses in carefully chosen topics. Each spans eight weeks and is tailored for students with diverse scheduling constraints. These courses are designed to cover essential topics, leading to a comprehensive understanding and core computer science skill sets. The program has attracted diverse cohorts of students from various fields such as Liberal Arts, Business, Health, and Science. The gender distribution among enrolled students is 70 % male and 30 % female. Initial results have shown that 83 % of program graduates have entered into master's degrees in computing. Some students may have aspirations extending to PhD programs. The Pathway to Computing program provides students with a stand-alone certificate that fills in an educational gap without requiring a complete degree with its associated costs. Initial experience shows that the program is equipping students with skills that they can readily apply in their job to help them advance in their career. The program's flexible design allows students to choose between full-time and part-time attendance, accommodating their busy schedules. This flexibility ensures that students can balance their educational pursuits with other life commitments.

title: WIP: Assessing 21st Century Skills of High School Students in a Machine Learning Workshop with TinyML
authors: Algeir P. Sampaio, Paulo C. M. A. Farias, Roberto A. Bittencourt
abstract: This research WIP paper describes a case study on the introduction of machine learning concepts in K-12 Education, providing students with more direct contact with new artificial intelligence technologies and potentially promoting an approach to foster the so-called 21st century skills, which enable students to deal with the technological world available in today's society. Working on skills such as Learning and Teamwork (LTE), Communication (COM), Citizenship and Social Responsibility (CSR), and proficiency in Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) may enable K-12 students to deal with work requirements that will be increasingly needed within the marketplace. In this study, we evaluated the perception of first-year high school students, between 15 and 17 years old, from a Brazilian public school regarding their own mastering of 21st century skills. The results show us how much such perceptions can be influenced by contact with knowledge of new technologies, even at an introductory level. In our case study, we used the TinyML framework, promoting an initiation to machine learning with the use of small hardware devices and minimizing the use of programming to simplify understanding and increase student motivation.

title: EchoVision: Intelligent Ultrasonic Glasses for Enhanced Blind Navigation
authors: Amruta Amune, Savit Pandita, Shardul Walunj, Rajshekhar Shinde, Shrikar Bende, Harsh Sathe
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper details the whole design, implementation, and assessment of a low-cost ultrasonic glasses system designed specifically to assist visually impaired individuals in real-time obstacle detection and navigation. The proposed EchoVision system measures the distance of objects in the user's path precisely by using an ESP32 microprocessor and an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor. When it detects an obstruction within a preset range, it immediately sounds a buzzer to alert the user. The device's design places a high premium on user comfort, portability, and energy efficiency. It is a small wearable device that runs on a 9V battery and has an integrated buck converter to maintain a constant voltage. The system is capable of more than just detecting obstacles. It also has a web-based interface that uses Firebase integration to provide cloud-based navigation support and turn-by-turn voice directions using GPS tracking and speech synthesis. The system can detect obstacles with a mean absolute percentage error of 2.25% over distances of 10 to 200 cm, respond in real time with a system latency of less than 150 milliseconds, and be accepted by users in controlled trials with visually impaired participants, according to experimental validation. The prototype overcomes major problems with traditional mobility aids like white canes and guide dogs by making it easier to see obstacles at head and chest level while keeping the cost low and making it easy to get for a lot of people, especially in developing countries. User feedback shows that 80% of people find the system easy to use, which shows that it could be a useful assistive technology for helping blind people move around on their own and live better lives.

title: AI-Powered Customer Segmentation: Enhancing Targeted Marketing Strategies Through Machine Learning
authors: S. Vijay Mallikraj, Sudarshan A. Pawar, Snehal Hole, Rajeev Gupta, Hasan Ali Alsailawi, Mustafa Mudhafar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In the emerging age of marketing fueled by data, precise customer classification is pivotal for boosting business operations. The study outlines a novel hybrid methodology for customer segmentation that integrates Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM), utilizing age, spending score, session time, and purchase frequency as parameters. While GMM adapts for flexible and probabilistic customer classification, DBSCAN serves to eliminate noise and discover core centre groupings. The clusters showed significant differences from one another. One cluster, for example, demonstrated high spending, long session time, and a high frequency of purchases, which showed engagement and value. The method improves the precision of the segmentation and gives clear and practical recommendations for marketing campaigns, customer retention strategies, and efficient budgeting. The study proved that a combination of density and probabilistic approaches is effective for analyzing customer diversity and behavioral patterns.

title: Enhancing Student Success in CS1: A Self-Selected Experience-Based Grouping Approach
authors: April R. Crockett, Gerald C. Gannod, Neena Thota
abstract: This full innovative practice paper explores how a self-selected, experience-based grouping model in CS1, grounded in Self-Determination Theory (SDT), supports student autonomy, competence, and relatedness. Over three semesters, we evaluated its impact on motivation, performance, and retention using surveys, instructional diagnostics, and grade analysis. Results suggest that offering students choice in their learning environment enhances belonging and academic success in CS1.

title: Bias-Mitigation and Multi-Task Deep Learning for Facial Attribute Prediction Across Demographics
authors: Boxuan Chen, Aiman Darakhshan, Raja Hashim Ali, Umme Rabab Syed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Facial attribute prediction is central to advancing human–computer interaction, affective computing, and socially responsible AI. Conventional single-task models, which separately predict age, gender, or emotion, often suffer from limited generalization, inefficiency, and demographic bias. This work proposes a lightweight multi-task convolutional neural network (CNN) that jointly predicts age, gender, and emotion using shared feature representations. The framework integrates strong data augmentation, adversarial training, and fairness-aware strategies to enhance robustness under variations in pose, illumination, and occlusion while reducing demographic disparities. To enable real-world usability, pruning and quantization are applied to design compact models suitable for deployment on mobile and IoT devices. The proposed method is validated on two benchmark datasets: UTKFace for age and gender, and CK+ for emotion recognition. Experimental results demonstrate that the multitask approach consistently outperforms single-task baselines, achieving improved accuracy across all three attributes while reducing fairness gaps between demographic groups. The model also maintains high accuracy with significantly reduced computational cost, which enables a real-time inference on platofrms that have some resource constraints. These findings highlight the potential of multi-task CNNs as a practical and equitable solution for various applications.

title: Ransomware Detection using Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Ayesha Bashir, Nargis Bibi, Nazeer Muhammad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: This research focuses on significant weaknesses that have been established due to the extensive usage of IoT devices that make them easy targets for ransomware attacks. This research uses machine learning approaches LightGBM, Random Forest and ensemble method (LightGBM and RF). Random Forest and LightGBM, both are tree based algorithms. Dataset UGRansome is used. According to experimental findings, LightGBM, Random Forest and the ensemble method show very good results. This research proves a flexible and computationally efficient approach to improve detecting ransomware in IoT networks with limited resources. This study uses lightweight tree-based models enhanced by Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) and ensemble learning to demonstrate the effectiveness of models and interpretability in IoT environments.

title: Exploring Graduate Student Views on Robotics Policy Relevant Information
authors: Sogol Balali, Jennifer Parham-Mocello, Brent Steel, Michael D. Jones, Waseq Billah
abstract: This full research paper explores the perspectives of Computer Science (CS) and Public Policy (PPOL) graduate students on the presence of embodied AI systems (i.e., AI-powered robots) in public spaces. Robots in public spaces pose unique challenges due to their embodiment, emergence, and social valence, raising societal, ethical, and regulatory concerns. These challenges disrupt established legal norms, requiring nuanced policies. As AI becomes more integrated into daily life, public concern about its societal impact grows, emphasizing the need for robust technology policies and ethical education. Research shows that public perceptions of AI are often more negative than views on algorithms, associating AI with fear and uncertainty. While studies address public perceptions of AI, little research focuses on how future technologists and policymakers perceive embodied AI and its challenges. To address this, we used the Narrative Policy Framework (NPF) to investigate CS and PPOL students' views on concerning robots and related policy issues. Through semi-structured interviews with three CS and four PPOL graduate students, we identified five categories of concerning robots, with self-driving cars and humanoid robots being the most prominent. We examined 10 policy challenges, 16 policy solutions, and the roles of key stakeholders. These findings offer insights into interdisciplinary education, AI policy development, and robotics literacy, fostering collaboration between technical and societal fields and preparing students to develop ethical AI technologies and informed public policies.

title: Cross-View and Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning for Radar Object Detection
authors: Qiaolong Qian, Yi Shi, Ruichao Hou, Haoyu Qin, Gangshan Wu
abstract: Frequency-modulated continuous-wave radar is a cornerstone of advanced driver assistance systems thanks to its low cost and resilience to adverse weather. Yet the absence of explicit semantics makes radar annotation difficult, and the scarcity of large-scale labeled data limits the performance of radar perception models. To address this issue, we propose a self-supervised framework for object detection directly from Range–Azimuth– Doppler (RAD) cubes that learns transferable representations from unlabeled radar data. Specifically, we introduce cross-view contrastive learning to model correspondences among complementary views of the RAD cube, encouraging the network to capture spatial structure from multiple perspectives. In addition, an auxiliary cross-modal contrastive objective distills semantic knowledge from vision into radar. The joint objective integrates cross-view and cross-modal signals to strengthen radar feature representations. We further extend the framework to cross-domain pretraining using datasets from different sources. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves radar object detection performance, especially with limited labeled data.

title: Integrating Random Forest, CNN, and ANN for EMG-Based Upper Limb Movement Recognition
authors: Muhammad Muzhafar Mohammad Zawawi, Wan Mohd Bukhari Wan Daud, Norafizah Abas, Rubita Sudirman, Mohamad Osman Tokhi, Mohd Juzaila Abd Latif
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This research introduces a hybrid machine learning model for upper-limb action identification utilizing surface electromyography (EMG) signals extracted from several muscle areas— forearm, biceps, and triceps. To increase discriminability across motor tasks, EMG features were extracted and fused at the feature-level in time and frequency domains. The proposed hybrid architecture contains Random Forest (RF), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and Artificial Neural Network (ANN) classifiers. Twelve healthy subjects executed six action trials all including grip (low, medium, strong), wrist flexion/extension, and elbow flexion/extension. The hybrid RF-CNN-ANN had an overall accuracy of 53.4% compared to 15% for a single ANN, and 48% for a single RF framework. Results indicated fuming EMG features across regions improved recognition performance and robustness compared to one region, demonstrating a desirable first step toward considering intelligent rehabilitation and prosthetic -control.

title: EPINET-Lite: Rethinking Mixed Convolutions for Efficient Light Field Disparity Estimation Network
authors: Ali Hassan, Tingting Zhang, Karen Egiazarian, Mårten Sjöström
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Convolutional neural networks are widely used for light field disparity estimation. However, many state-of-the-art deep learning models are computationally expensive due to their reliance on standard convolutions with varying kernel sizes. In this paper, we analyze the effect of various advanced convolution operations with different kernel sizes for feature extraction in a state-of-the-art light field disparity estimation network. Based on this investigation, we propose an optimized mixed convolution layer to extract relevant features using multiple kernel sizes in parallel, while maintaining significantly lower computational cost. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach reduces model complexity by up to 4.2× while also improving disparity estimation accuracy. These findings make the proposed convolutional operation more practical for light field applications, where efficient spatial and angular feature extraction is essential for improved model performance.

title: Hybrid Framework for Liver Image Enhancement and Detection Using Double-Stage Gaussian Filter and CNN
authors: Jagmeet Sohal, Prabhjot Kaur, E. Murali, Ramabai V, Neha Jaswani, S. Gopinath
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The study presents a Modified Double-Stage Gaussian Filter (MDSGF) together with submerged Marker Controlled Watershed Transform (MCWT) on abdominal CT images-this filter is to achieve Automated Liver Segmentation (ALS). Proposed MDSGF really improves quality of liver CT images (LCTIs) as it still maintains the anatomic details and shows better texture, contrast, and edge accentuation. Dual Gaussian processing, CLAHE, and the wavelet based fusion process the image generating superior outputs that can be used in specific segmentation. MCWT subsequently divides the region of interest into liver and other foreground elements with the help of the watershed and foreground estimation principles. Using the LiTS comparison of the system has revealed an enormous progress in terms of accuracy and computational complexity in the element of segmentation. In comparison to conventional and deep learning-based approaches, the method resulted in a DICE of 0.948, Jaccard Index of 0.901, VOE of 0.080 and RVD of 0.093 with less segmentation time of 2.3 seconds. The result indeed shows that MDSGF-MCWT method has been efficient and capable of a sound solution to liver segmentation, even in errored/noisy or weak contrasted images.

title: Impact of Traditional, Blended, and Online Learning on Students Performance in Higher Education Using Data Mining Approach
authors: Shruti Sharma, Sharda Haryani
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study investigates how traditional, blended, and online pedagogical approaches influence academic outcomes in higher education. Applying data mining methodologies, the research extracts and analyses patterns from a multi-institutional educational dataset. Key variables including final grades, student engagement metrics, and attendance records are examined to assess the efficacy of each learning mode. The results yield actionable insights for refining instructional design and formulating data-informed educational policies.

title: Stakeholder Hierarchy and Conway's Law: Impact on Backlog Management Strategies in Agile Teams Post-COVID
authors: Samir Ohri, Ijya Bhatnagar Ohri
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The study investigates how the organization communication structure, the hierarchy of stakeholders and fast communication platforms can influence the product backlog management in the distributed agile teams. The research relies on the Convey Law and explores how communication patterns are developed that impact on the clarity of backlog and prioritization. A survey of 467 agile practitioners was carried out quantitatively in various industries and the data obtained were analyzed with the help of MANOVA, chi-square and Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) in order to establish the factors that influence backlog efficiency. Findings have shown that the hierarchical nature of an organization has a strong influence on decision-making processes, whereas the active involvement of stakeholders and the wider application of communication instruments can contribute to a better understanding of a backlog and the stability of its priorities. These relationships are strong in the post-COVID remote and hybrid environments, which proves the Law of Conway to be still relevant in modern agile environments. The paper provides reallife advice on how to improve alignment, minimize the number of communication bottlenecks, and reinforce the distributed backlog practices. The next generation needs to consider AI-based prioritization systems, cross-cultural virtual teams, and how to create adaptive structures of globally distributed agile teams.

title: How Experiential Learning (Internships, Live Projects) Enhances Sustainability Competencies in Management Education
authors: Priya Rathore, Sushil Dadhich, Saurabh Chandra, Swati Jain, Calwin Rose
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The demand for managers capable of engaging with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) responsibilities has intensified, bringing sustainability-oriented management education to the forefront. Experiential learning-particularly internships and real-world project engagements-has emerged as one of the most promising pedagogical methods for building sustainability-related competencies. This paper synthesizes insights from leading Scopus-, Web of Science-, and ABDCindexed research to examine how experiential learning nurtures skills such as systems thinking, strategic sustainability judgement, ethical reasoning, collaboration, and integrated problem-solving. Previous research [5], [6], [12]; consistently demonstrates that students who actively confront authentic sustainability challenges exhibit enhanced learning, more professional maturity, and a stronger dedication to sustainable practices. Recent developments in responsible management education and circular operations further substantiate these patterns. The research strongly shows that well-structured experiential pedagogies should be regarded as fundamental elements of management curriculum rather than mere supplemental learning opportunities

title: SlideCraft: Context-aware Slides Generation Agent
authors: Kunal Rao, Giuseppe Coviello, Murugan Sankaradas, Ciro Giuseppe De Vita, Gennaro Mellone, Srimat Chakradhar
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Creating effective slide presentations requires adapting both content and structure to match the communication context e.g. whether the presentation is for summarizing to executives, or reporting progress to research supervisors. In research and enterprise environments, this need for context-sensitive presentations often leads to repeated, manual reformatting of the same material to suit different audiences. Existing generative systems support slide creation but typically rely on structured inputs, assume a fixed format, and offer limited ability to iteratively refine outputs through natural language feedback. Moreover, they rarely accommodate organizational constraints such as formatting guidelines, domain-specific terminology, or branding requirements. We present SlideCraft, a context-aware generative agent that autonomously creates and edits slide presentations based on natural language instructions. SlideCraft infers the intended presentation context, such as an “executive-facing” or a “project review” summary for technical oversight, and selects the appropriate slide template. It then synthesizes content from input documents, enriches it with external knowledge and internal assets, assembles it into a structured intermediate representation, and generates a validated slide deck. SlideCraft supports both, first-time slide creation and iterative updates, operating through familiar natural language interfaces like email or messaging tools. Our experiments demonstrate that SlideCraft consistently produces high-quality, context-aware presentations tailored to diverse communication settings, with minimal human input and reliable adherence to enterprise constraints.

title: Cumulative Correlation Violation (CCV): A Quantitative Metric for Residual Randomness in System Identification
authors: Maizura Mohd Sani, Aznilinda Zainuddin, Mohammad Farid Saaid, Mohd Khairi Nordin, Ihsan Mohd Yassin, Mohd Nasir Taib
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Traditional metrics in system identification— such as Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Akaike Information Criterion (AIC)—quantify prediction accuracy and parsimony but do not assess the temporal structure left in residuals, a core indicator of whether a model has extracted all systematic dynamics. We introduce the Cumulative Correlation Violation (CCV), a lightweight residual diagnostic that sums the absolute autocorrelation coefficients exceeding the 95% white-noise bounds (±1.96/√N) across L lags, with O(N•L) complexity. CCV was evaluated with MLP–NARX models on two chaotic benchmarks: the Mackey–Glass (MG) delay system and the Rössler attractor (RA). Under a small hyperparameter search, the MG model (p*=8, 32 hidden; 353 params) attains low errors (MSE: 1.294×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> training and validation, 1.439×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> test) and strongly negative AIC (−1.41×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> training and validation; −2.96×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> test); yet CCV remains moderate (6.99 training and validation; 6.59 test), revealing subtle but statistically significant low-lag dependencies that error magnitude alone would miss. For RA (p*=10, 20 hidden; 241 parameters), performance degrades from training and validation to test (MSE: 1.16×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> → 1.67×10⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>; AIC: −1.90×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> → −1.84×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>) and CCV stays elevated (4.00 training and validation; 4.24 test), aligning with visible residual structure in ACF/CCF plots and indicating under-specification for the 3-state dynamics. Across both systems, CCV complements MSE/AIC by directly quantifying residual "whiteness," enabling practitioners to diagnose subtle misspecification in otherwise accurate models and to confirm fundamental failures when generalization deteriorates— providing a practical objective for balancing accuracy, complexity, and residual quality in nonlinear system identification.

title: Blending Technology and Tradition: Perception on AI, Local and Native Teachers in English Learning
authors: Idrus Jamalulel, Anfitri Sihombing, Daniel Hutapea
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Integrating with AI in the education sector is becoming crucial and impactful for students’ English performance and analyzing junior high school students’ perceptions of teaching effectiveness across AI, local, and native English teachers in Taiwan, there is still limited empirical evidence on how students perceive on this, without such understanding the attempt of Bilingual 2030 policy which might limited alignment with students need. This study employs a qualitative approach, conducting interviews with a total of 357 junior high school students in Taiwan. Moreover, this study developed a structured questionnaire assessing students’ experiences regarding learning outcomes. Data were collected through in-depth interviews guided by instruments which has been designed from the literature and pilot testing, with participants who have engaged with AI-enhanced, local, and native teachers in Taiwan. The study also examines the perceived strengths and limitations of AI, local, and native teachers in fostering language acquisition, students’ motivation, and personalized learning. The findings suggest that a blended instructional teaching model, which integrates AI tools, local, and native teachers in learning English, can enhance students’ language acquisition and cultural relevance in Taiwan’s English Education System. Furthermore, this study provides new insights into students' preferences for AI, local teachers, and native teachers.

title: Artificial Intelligence Enabled Decision Support System for Hospitality Operations
authors: Pankaj Kumar Tyagi, Gagandeep Passi, Dev Raj, Sumit Kumar, Priyanka Tyagi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The dynamic service industry is increasingly in need of flexible computational capabilities to be able to sense, reason, and behave in the rich experience space. This article presents a model, the Neuro-Semantic Synergic Orchestrator (NSSO), a high-level cognitive model, which means the reasoner combines both neuro-symbolic reasoning and context-sensitive orchestration. The NSSO uses an integrative perception layer, which combines heterogeneous data, including sensory, behavioral cues and environmental, into single with regard to situational embeddings. These embeddings are fed into a Hybrid Site-Muscular Encoder which consists of extracting latent intent, relational bonds, and operational synergies using transformer-generated attention and graph reasoning. The Dynamic Synergy Engine is an engine that continuously re-configures resource flows, service pattern, and experiential parameter based on a process of optimization by reinforcement. The NSSO is unique in the sense that, unlike the traditional predictive systems, it develops and adapts to new semantic calibration, and it therefore has the ability of learning new implicit human and environmental correlation as time progresses. Experimental simulations show that the framework improves the situational awareness, lessens cognitive latency in adapting processes, and improves using experience to make personalization. The given architecture offers the basis of autonomous cognitive ecosystems that can transform various domains of service with sustainable transformation and data-driven data transformation. The suggested NSSO system attained an overall operational accuracy of 93.8 percent, demonstrating its exceptional dependability and precision in adaptable decision orchestrating.

title: A Review of Research Progress on ResNet and Its Fusion Applications
authors: Nanju Wu, Dechao Sun
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: As a representative architecture in deep neural networks, Residual Networks (ResNet) have played a pivotal role in computer vision and natural language processing, particularly in training ultra-deep models. However, emerging applications such as edge computing and cross-modal reasoning expose ResNet to challenges including dynamic task generalization, feature alignment across modalities, and lightweight deployment. This paper presents a comprehensive review of recent advancements in ResNet and its fusion applications. It first analyzes the architectural evolution of ResNet from the perspectives of gradient optimization and degradation mitigation. In the domain of medical imaging, it evaluates the effectiveness of transfer learning and meta-learning frameworks-such as MetaLR-in small-sample scenarios. For cross-modal fusion, it investigates the integration of ResNet with Transformers and graph neural networks, highlighting both collaborative mechanisms and computational bottlenecks. Although strategies such as multi-scale modeling and attention mechanisms have improved performance, ResNet still faces limitations in longrange dependency modeling, adaptive training, and efficient reasoning under resource constraints. Future research should emphasize lightweight architecture design, modality-aware alignment, and incremental learning strategies to enhance its adaptability to multi-modal and edge-oriented tasks.

title: Unsupervised Recognition of Prehabilitation Movements: The Role of Personalised Data and Remote Monitoring
authors: Khalid Al-Naime, Adnan Al-Anbuky
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: Accurate recognition of human physical activities is essential for continuous fitness monitoring, particularly in prehabilitation and post-operative rehabilitation programs for surgical patients. As the demand for surgical interventions increases and healthcare resources remain limited, remote monitoring has emerged as a scalable and effective solution. However, unsupervised activity recognition methods in this context are still underdeveloped, hindered by challenges such as inconsistent connectivity, privacy concerns, and the absence of standardised monitoring frameworks. This study investigates the influence of three data types—personalised, non-personalised, and categorised—on the accuracy of physical activity recognition within the Any-Time Any-Where Prehabilitation and Rehabilitation (ATAW-RHB) framework. By analysing patient-specific movement data, the study evaluates recognition rates for three common activities: cycling, rowing, and walking, across various intensity levels. Findings demonstrate that personalised data significantly improves recognition accuracy, achieving up to 96.8% for cycling, while lower accuracy was observed for walking (approximately 70%). These results highlight the critical role of personalisation in enhancing recognition performance, improving monitoring transparency, and enabling more tailored and effective remote care. The proposed approach contributes to the advancement of remote patient monitoring systems by establishing a data-driven foundation for personalised healthcare delivery. It supports healthcare providers in optimising care strategies while reducing patient burden and minimising the need for frequent hospital visits.

title: Threat Model for the Modern LMS Platforms Based on 5G/6G Technologies
authors: Bakhytzhan Akhmetov, Sergiy Gnatyuk, Dinara Basshykyzy, Bauyrzhan Tynymbayev
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: LMS platforms are attractive targets for cybercriminals because of the large amount of sensitive data (particularly personal data of students, faculty, test scores, and financial information). The threat model consists of the main current cyber threats to LMS platforms, in particular: phishing attacks, credential stuffing, data privacy attacks, SQL injection and other web-based attacks, DDoS attacks, exploitation of vulnerabilities in third-party plugins and extensions, ransomware, unauthorized access and API attacks, exploitation of vulnerabilities in non-updated software, and insider threats. Creating a model is an important part of security system development, which will allow more accurate selection of defence mechanisms and procedures. In addition, the paper presents recommendations for ensuring LMS cybersecurity in the context of the realization of different types of threats.

title: Optimization of Error Control Coding in High-Speed Optical Broadband Networks Using Machine Learning
authors: Edo Lutfi Mahanani, M. Rendra Perdana Kusuma D, M. Imansyah Basudewa, El Nissi Hamasiah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: The exponential growth of data-driven services such as cloud computing, IoT, and video streaming demands highly reliable and high-speed optical broadband networks. However, system performance is limited by impairments such as noise, dispersion, and nonlinearities, which lead to higher bit error rates (BER). Error control coding (ECC) offers an effective solution, though trade-offs exist between complexity, latency, and coding gain. This study presents an optimization framework that integrates ECC with machine learning (ML), specifically a Random Forest (RF) classifier, to enhance physical-layer reliability and adaptive decision-making. Using simulations of 16-QAM over an AWGN channel, three schemes were evaluated: uncoded, Hamming (7,4), and convolutional coding. Results show that convolutional coding achieved the most significant improvement, providing the lowest BER, highest coding gain, and superior Q-factor across the 0–12 dB SNR range, while Hamming coding offered moderate performance enhancement. The RF classifier effectively categorized link quality (Good, Marginal, Poor) with 95% accuracy, achieving macro-averaged precision of 0.926, recall of 0.956, and F1-score of 0.935. These findings demonstrate that the synergy between ECC and ML not only reduces errors and improves signal quality but also enables intelligent, adaptive network operation, making the approach promising for next-generation high-speed optical broadband systems.

title: Performance and Efficiency of EfficientNet Models in MRI-Based Brain Tumor Detection
authors: Louis Oktovianus, Robert Tanriwan, Ivan Sebastian Edbert, Diana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Brain tumor detection, especially from MRI images, is an important task in the healthcare industry due to the high fatality rates of certain types of brain tumors such as gliomas, meningiomas, and pituitary tumors. This study compares the accuracy and performance of the EfficientNet family models (B0 to B7) in brain tumor classification from MRI images. The research evaluates both the classification accuracy and computational efficiency of these models. The dataset used is Kaggle’s Brain Tumor MRI dataset, containing approximately 2,500 images divided into four classes: glioma, meningioma, pituitary, and no tumor. All EfficientNet models are compared using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics to determine the most accurate and efficient architecture. The results show that EfficientNet B7 achieves the highest performance with an accuracy of 0.93598 $(93.598 \%)$, precision of $0.93572(93.572 \%)$, and recall of $0.93398(93.398 \%)$, followed closely by EfficientNet B2 with an accuracy of $0.93445(93.445 \%)$. These findings highlight the potential of implementing deep learning models such as EfficientNet in real-world medical applications, as they offer an optimal balance between accuracy and computational cost. Furthermore, the study suggests that early diagnosis-and potentially future integration into treatment planning-of brain tumor patients can be enhanced through AI-based medical imaging systems.

title: Long-Term Feature Point Tracking for Camera Pose Estimation in Forest Fire Scenes
authors: Hao Zhang, Xiaobo Lu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Recently, the continuous expansion of forest areas has imposed new demands on forest fire prevention systems. However, the characteristics of weak textures and high dynamics associated with smoke and fire have rendered many traditional pose recovery methods ineffective. Building upon conventional learning-based Visual Odometry (VO) approaches, we focus on feature point tracking as our primary strategy. By incorporating temporal information from sequential images into the trajectory prediction pipeline, we achieve more accurate pose estimations through temporal modeling of feature points and trajectory filtering. We conducted experiments on a challenging virtual forest dataset, demonstrating that our method outperforms several established benchmark approaches. Additionally, we tested our model on a collected forest fire dataset, yielding promising results. Our research holds significant implications for forest protection and the mitigation of forest fire disasters.

title: Predicting Civil Case Processing Times Using Machine Learning: A Case Study from the Italian Judicial System
authors: Chiara Maragò, Rosita Guido, Francesca Guerriero
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The efficiency of courts and prosecutors offices is crucial to ensure the protection of citizens’ rights and freedoms and to fulfil their social responsibilities. Increasing workloads within judicial systems, combined with excessive times to process cases and limited human resources, pose significant challenges in dealing with delays and backlogs. Quantitative data, such as case backlogs, the duration of proceedings, and the number of incoming and pending cases, could be exploited for Artificial Intelligence tools to forecast workloads and improve the performance of judicial systems, although their adoption still remains limited. This paper explores the application of five popular Machine Learning regression models-linear regression, decision tree, random forest, extreme gradient enhancement, and categorical enhancement-to predict the time (measured in days) required to process a number of civil cases. The performance of these models is evaluated using standard metrics. The main goal is to assess the potential of Artificial Intelligence tools in the judicial domain, contributing to the development of more efficient management strategies for the future. The Italian case study is particularly challenging because the performance of its judicial system is below the European average. For this reason, a case study from the Italian civil judicial sector is presented.

title: An Innovative Secure Multimodal Biometric Verification and Encryption Scheme Using Integrity Key Cryptography and Feature Level Fusion in Cloud Computing
authors: B. Madhavi, Narender Singh Kharola, Rashi Saxena, Rajanikanth Sanku, Ratnesh Jain, Rohit Shrivastava
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This work introduces a Secure Multimodal Biometric Authentication and Encryption System using Integrity Key Cryptography and Feature-Level Fusion for cloud computing (MBIC-FF). The system brings together data from fingerprint, iris and finger vein biometrics using Fisher Vector and weighted Gaussian Mixture Model, making the data available at the feature level for integration. The FMMF approach produces a bio-integrity key used in a revised AES-GCM-IV scheme that greatly increases protection of data on the cloud. The performance is tested using False Acceptance Rate (FAR), False Rejection Rate (FRR), encryption time and decryption time. FMMF-based authentication achieved a much better average FAR of 0.15 and a much lower FRR of 2.1, surpassing all the single modalities. FMMF files performed encryption and decryption in 28 ms and 31 respectively. Impersonation, spoofing and inside as well as DoS attacks are successfully stopped by the system which keeps cloud-based biometric authentication safe, efficient, and private.

title: WIP: Mapping Misconceptions Across Key Electric Circuit Concepts
authors: Vincent Fakiyesi, Olanrewaju Paul Olaogun, Isaac Dunmoye, Nathaniel Hunsu
abstract: This work-in-progress paper presents the development of the Electric Circuits Concept Diagnostic (ECCD), a tool aimed at identifying and measuring engineering students' misconceptions in electric circuit concepts. Electric circuits are fundamental to electrical engineering, yet many students hold misconceptions that impede learning. Existing concept inventories often fail to distinguish between students with no prior knowledge and those who possess incorrect but confident beliefs. This study introduces the ECCD, which includes 30 items assessing key electric circuit concepts such as Voltage/Potential Difference, Current/Charge, Complete Circuit, and RLC components. The test comprises three tiers: a multiple-choice content knowledge tier (Tier 1), an open-ended reasoning tier (Tier 2), and a multiplechoice confidence level tier (Tier 3). Data from 254 undergraduate engineering students who participated in the pilot test were analyzed. This paper reports preliminary findings from Tier 1 (content knowledge) and Tier 2 (confidence levels), revealing prevalent misconceptions, particularly in Voltage/Potential Difference and Current/Charge, with a notable proportion of students demonstrating high confidence in incorrect responses. The next phase of this research will include analysis of Tier 3 (reasoning) responses and more comprehensive statistical analyses to refine the diagnostic tool and further explore misconceptions in electric circuit concepts.

title:

                    -CNT Resistive Sensor for Low-Temperature Detection of Electrolyte Solvent used in Lithium-Ion Batteries
authors: Chinwe Nyenke Tait, Colin Mazzola, Phoebe Ho, Ajay Kola
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: As with technical innovations, public skepticism often follows, especially when the innovation directly impacts their everyday lives. For instance, Electric Vehicles (EVs) face criticism due to the perceived risks from the addition of LithiumIon Batteries (LIBs), which can partake in Thermal Runaway Propagation (TRP) and fires. During thermal runaway events, extreme heating and the release of toxic gases such as hydrogen $\left(\mathrm{H}_{2}\right)$, carbon dioxide $\left(\mathrm{CO}_{2}\right)$, carbon monoxide (CO), methane $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{4}\right)$, volatile organic compounds (VOC), and others occurs. Among these, Dimethyl Carbonate (DMC) - a component of LIB electrolyte having a significant mole fraction percentage relative to other gases expelled during TR - was chosen as the target substance for the sensor to detect. In the process of determining the ideal sensor for testing, it is important to consider both the evaporating temperatures of DMC and the sensor’s ability to perform in a realistic environment. We introduce a resistive gas sensor for low-temperature, early detection of electrolyte leakage of Lithium-Ion Batteries (LIBs). The sensor is synthesized from tin oxide (SnO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) and carbon nanotubes (CNT) deposited onto interdigitated gold (Au) electrodes. SnO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> offers a strong sensitivity towards target gases and CNT possesses the quality of reducing operating temperatures of metal-oxide-semiconductor sensors. With these approaches, the application of such sensors could play a crucial role in improving the safety of passengers in EVs, the longevity of these vehicles, and public faith in Electric Vehicles.

title: Coconut Milk Freshness Classification using Mamdani-Type Fuzzy Logic and VOC Sensor Data
authors: Rajina R Mohamed, Razali Yaakob, Tuan Dir Tengku Mohd Azahar, Nor Azura Husin, Nurul Azwaani Salehuddin Haqe
abstract: The freshness of coconut milk is of critical domination on consumer security, product quality, and shelf-life management. Invasive sensory and microbiological assessments are subjective and are time-intensive. The current study proposes a fuzzy logic technique utilizing the data derived using an electronic nose (e-nose) that has volatile organic compound (VOC) sensors in order to predict the freshness of coconut milk. Four gas sensors (MQ2, MQ5, MQ6, and MG135) were used to develop a Mamdani-type Fuzzy Inference System (FIS) in MATLAB that represent complex and non-linear nature of the relationship between concentrations of gases and level of spoilage. This system uses expert-based rules and customized membership functions to determine the freshness into three groups (Fresh, Medium, and Poor). In comparison to expert sensory results, the fuzzy logic model provided an 88% overall classification accuracy showing results capable of dealing with uncertainty in actual food data. Compared to others machine learning model, the proposed system is fully transparent, allowing it to be interpreted and deployed in food monitoring systems. This paper demonstrates the feasibility of using fuzzy logic, based in simple computation, as an independent mechanism of intelligent food quality evaluation, which may be the solid basis of real-time, portable food freshness measurement devices in the food sector.

title: ATSG: Adaptive Token Linking With Segment Anything Model Guidance For Weakly Supervised Remote Sensing Image Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yifan Zhang, Zhiguo Jiang, Haopeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Semantic segmentation of remote sensing images is vital for applications such as urban planning and disaster monitoring. However, the high cost of pixel-level annotations often results in limited labeled data, necessitating weakly supervised learning approaches. Unlike natural images, remote sensing images typically contain numerous small objects with substantial intra-class variations and high inter-class similarities, which poses challenges for generating high-quality pseudo label. Additionally, while Vision Transformer (ViT) have been integrated into Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation (WSSS) for their global modeling capabilities, they are prone to over-smoothing in dense scenes, which impedes model learning. To address these challenges, we propose two novel modules: the Adaptive Token Linking Module (Adalink) and the Segment Anything Model (SAM)-Guided Boundary Refiner module(SGBR). First, Adalink employs a dynamic aggregation mechanism to analyze semantic diversity across the middle layer of ViT, adaptively selecting feature layer and constructing token correlation graphs. It leverages a self-supervised encoder to extract hierarchical token relationships, which to supervise pseudo label generation, thereby reducing erroneous activations in cluttered scenes and improving pseudo label quality. Second, SGBR utilizes the zero-shot segmentation capability of the SAM to refine segmentation results by incorporating object and boundary priors from the output images, significantly enhancing the completeness of small object segmentation and overall accuracy. Extensive experiments on the ISPRS Potsdam, ISPRS Vaihingen, and iSAID datasets demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance and exhibits strong practical value in processing complex remote sensing scenes. Code will be available at: https://github.com/zhangyifan25/ATSG.

title: Exploring the Impact of Classroom Composition on Women's Experiential Identity, Interest, and Self-Efficacy in Microelectronics
authors: Laura M Cruz Castro, Maryam K Multani, Andrea Ramirez-Salgado, Andrea Goncher, Isabella Victoria, Gabriella Taboada
abstract: This full research paper examines how a short 1.5-hour microelectronics workshop can influence students' experiential identity, interest, and self-efficacy in microelectronics, with a focus on gender composition in classroom settings. The microelectronics industry is critical to modern technologies, and the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022 underscores the need for a diverse domestic workforce. However, women remain underrepresented in STEM fields, which may affect their educational experiences and long-term career persistence. Using a quasiexperimental design, this study explored two research questions: [RQ1] Can a short 1.5-hour microelectronics workshop influence participants' Experiential Identity, Interest, and Self-Efficacy in microelectronics? [RQ1.1] Is this influence differential for women and men? [RQ2] Does classroom composition affect the influence of the workshop on women's Experiential Identity, Interest, and Self-Efficacy in microelectronics? Thirty-three undergraduate students were randomly assigned to classrooms with varying gender composition. Results indicated overall improvements in experiential identity, interest, and self-efficacy, with the most significant gains among participants in classrooms with adequate female representation. In the Women-Represented (WR) classroom, women showed the largest increases in experiential identity (82.35%) and self-efficacy (50%), with a smaller positive change in interest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.0089 \%)$</tex>. In the Mixed-Male-Represented (MMR) classroom, gains were more modest and there was no change in interest, suggesting peer composition matters. These findings align with Social Cognitive Career Theory, highlighting the importance of successful learning experiences in fostering self-efficacy and interest. The study demonstrates the value of short-term interventions and the role of gender composition in shaping equitable outcomes in microelectronics education.
