title: WIP: Structured AI Tutoring in Engineering Education
authors: Alberto C. Cruz, Anjana Yatawara, Maruti Misha, Jianjun Wang
abstract: This innovative practice Work-in-Progress paper presents a structured approach to integrating AI tutors into undergraduate engineering education at a Hispanic-Serving Institution. The study focuses on two upper-division computer architecture courses and explores how large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT-4o, can be scaffolded to support student learning. Our approach emphasizes guided AI interaction rather than direct answer generation. It is grounded in Vygotsky's Zone of Proximal Development and implemented through the ADDIE instructional design model. Two scaffolding protocols—AI Think-Aloud and AI-Driven Pair Programming—are proposed, that foster metacognitive engagement and collaborative problem-solving. The paper highlights the need for differentiated instruction aligned with Universal Design for Learning (UDL) to assist individuals who lack skills necessary to take advantage of LLMs. Preliminary findings suggest that structured AI integration can enhance learning outcomes and engagement, while minimizing risks associated with unregulated AI use. Evaluation methods include SOLO taxonomy analysis of student-AI interactions and short-term longitudinal survey data on student attitudes. The work contributes to emerging frameworks for ethical, inclusive, and pedagogically grounded AI adoption in engineering classrooms.

title: A Novel Hybrid Wireless Power Transfer Coupler for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Application
authors: Pan Sun, Yaodong Xiang, Guoli Feng, Enguo Rong, Yilin Liu, Xiaochen Zhang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: The special structure of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) poses challenges to the integrated design method and power transmission capability of the couplers used for their wireless charging. This paper proposes a new inductive and capacitive combined hybrid wireless power transfer coupler for UAV. Among them, the capacitive coupler is designed as a six-plate structure. A receiving plate and a shielding plate are installed on each of the two landing gears of the UAV, and the transmitting plates are installed on the ground. The FR4 epoxy insulating material is filled between the plates to increase the coupling capacitance. The inductive coupler adopts a square coil form, which is installed on the belly of the UAV. Inductive coupler and capacitive coupler compensate each other for reactive power while transmitting power, which eliminates the need for additional compensation network components on the receiving side. Secondly, based on the single-sided LCLC compensation network, this paper presents a parameter design method that can adjust the power transmission ratio of inductive and capacitive couplers. Then, the component stress analysis was conducted. Compared with the inductive power transfer (IPT) and capacitive power transfer (CPT) systems that have the same coupler and similar compensation network, the proposed system significantly reduced the stress on the coupler. Finally, an experimental prototype is established to verify the scheme. The experimental results show that the system can transmit 500W at an efficiency of 80.7%, which means it can be used for wireless charging of UAV.

title: Subjective-objective Emotion Correlated Generation Network for Subjective Video Captioning_supp2-3649363.png
authors: Zhendong Mao
abstract: The emotional video captioning (EVC) task, which aims to generate factual descriptions based on the perceived subtle visual emotion cues, has received more and more attention and research. However, EVC is essentially an objective video captioning task, and ignores the subjective emotional reactions of video viewers, which cannot reflect personalized affective understandings of different viewers on the same video. To fill the research gap, we investigate the subjective video captioning (SVC) task in this paper, which aims to generate emotional captions by incorporating viewers’ personalized emotional reactions upon the EVC task. SVC is extremely challenging, which lies in two aspects: 1) the correlative emotion perception between subjective and objective emotions; and 2) the collaborative generation between emotional and factual information. To this end, we propose the Subjective-Objective Emotion-Correlated Generation Network (SO-ECGN) in this paper. Specifically, our SO-ECGN leverages the proposed dynamic mask attention and emotion domain shifting module to achieve the objective emotion incremental learning, and then, a subjective-objective emotions correlation module is proposed to adaptively combine two perspective emotions to provide accurate emotion guidance (i.e., emotional polarity and intensity) for each generation step. Furthermore, an emotion-correlated decoder is proposed to generate subjective captions by adaptively referring to factual information and emotional information. Extensive experiments on three challenging datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach and each proposed module, i.e., reaching 79.2%, 45.1% on BLEU-1, CIDEr metrics on EmVidCap-L dataset.

title: Accessibility and Accommodations for Students with Disabilities in STEM Higher Education: Synthesis of Research on Computing, Physics, and Engineering
authors: Morgan H. McKie, Stephanie J. Lunn
abstract: This research full-paper examines how accessibility and accommodations are defined and implemented across Computing, Engineering, and Physics in higher education. Students with disabilities face unique challenges related to course content, lab access, instructional methods, and assistive technology, which can hinder their success in STEM fields. To explore how disciplines support these students, we conducted a scoping literature review of 386 papers, narrowing to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=29$</tex> based on inclusion criteria. Our analysis identified three dominant framings of accessibility: (1) Technical Accessibility, emphasizing learning technologies and assistive tools; (2) Physical and Sensory Accessibility, focusing on inclusive design in spaces and labs; and (3) Pedagogical Accessibility, highlighting inclusive instructional strategies. While all three fields recognize the importance of accessibility, computing and Engineering tend to prioritize technical solutions, whereas Physics often emphasizes physical access and curricular changes. These disciplinary differences suggest that accessibility efforts are shaped more by fieldspecific demands than by a unified framework. By understanding how accessibility and accommodations are conceptualized across disciplines, educator and institution can adopt targeted strategies to support students with disabilities and create a more inclusive learning environment in STEM.

title: Antecedents and Outcomes of Learning Management System Usage: Evidence from Developing Country Educational Institutions
authors: Hanan Kuzat, Ibrahim Magboul, Fadi Herzallah
abstract: Background: This research-to-practice paper explores the growing use of Learning Management Systems (LMS) in education, particularly focusing on higher education institutions in Qatar. While LMS adoption is widespread in developed countries, developing nations like Qatar face challenges in usage. Method: The study addresses a gap in prior research by identifying and empirically testing both the antecedents and outcomes of LMS usage, using survey data from 433 students and Structural Equation Modelling (SEM). Findings: Key findings show that 9 out of 12 antecedents significantly influence LMS usage, which in turn positively affects all three perceived outcomes. The study contributes to the understanding of LMS adoption in developing countries and offers practical insights for educators and policymakers. Implications: This study contributes to the adoption of technology and instructional technology literature by offering valuable insights for researchers and practitioners in educational institutions. Moreover, this study is among the few to integrate selected antecedents and outcomes of LMS usage in one model.

title: Efficient Continuous Object Tracking with Fog-Assisted Boundary Detection in IoT-Enabled WSN
authors: Nagina Ishaq, Ata Ullah, Mehreen Mushtaq, Osama A. Khashan, Matloub Hussain, Anwar Ghani
abstract: Continuous object tracking in IoT-enabled Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) requires fast, energy-efficient boundary detection, especially for dynamic phenomena such as toxic gas leakage or wildfire spread. However, existing approaches often rely on cloud-centric processing, resulting in high transmission delays and excessive energy consumption due to large-scale node activation. This paper proposes Boundary Detection of Continuous Objects (BDCO), a fog-assisted scheme that reduces communication overhead and improves boundary accuracy. BDCO organizes the network into grid-based clusters where the Cluster Head (CH) filters anomalous data using a selective aggregation mechanism and forwards only relevant boundary-related information to the fog node (FN). The FN then applies a convex-hull-based boundary estimation model, enabling precise boundary formulation while minimizing node activation. The proposed scheme is implemented in NS-2.35 and demonstrates substantial improvements in energy consumption (3.00E+06), service delay (22 ms), end-to-end delay (33 ms), packet loss ratio (3.0), and boundary accuracy (0.85) compared to existing approaches. Overall, the BDCO scheme provides a more energy-efficient and delay-aware solution for real-time boundary detection of continuous objects in an IoT-enabled WSN environment.

title: Transferring Policy of Offline Reinforcement Learning from Hybrid Dataset to Real World via Progressive Neural Network_supp1-3653285.mp4
authors: Guangliang Li
abstract: Offline reinforcement learning (Offline RL) provides a compelling solution for applying RL in high-risk or resourceconstrained real-world domains such as healthcare, autonomous driving, and robotic manipulation, where online exploration can be unsafe or impractical. However, Offline RL faces critical challenges arising from limited data coverage and potential distributional mismatch between the pre-training dataset and real-world environment. In this paper, we propose to allow an agent to learn from a hybrid dataset: high-quality real-world data and high-diversity simulation data, and assume that the dynamics of the simulation and the real world do not match, but the state space is the same. To address the policy extrapolation error and potentially catastrophic failures because of out-of-distribution actions and sim-to-real gap, we use progressive neural networks (PNNs) to transfer the offline policy to the real world. Results in two robotic manipulation tasks with a six-degree-of-freedom Ned robotic arm show that, the hybrid dataset facilitates faster offline learning and better adaptation to real-world tasks during online learning. In addition, further analysis shows that transferring the offline policy via PNN can not only effectively retain the policy learned from the hybrid dataset and bridge the gap between simulation and reality data, but also allow the agent to explore in a more diverse distribution of samples during online learning.

title: Low-Light Welding Defect Detection Using Retinex-Enhanced YOLOv11 for Steel Welding Inspection
authors: Yonky Pernando, Nur Afny Catur Andryani, Andry Chowanda, Widodo Budiharto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Welding defect detection in low-light industrial environments remains a challenging task due to poor brightness, low contrast, and high noise levels that degrade image quality and hinder reliable feature extraction. To address this limitation, this study integrates a Retinex-based adaptive illumination enhancement module into the preprocessing stage of the YOLOv11 detection framework. The proposed method improves the visibility of weld seams and defect textures by restoring illumination balance and preserving structural details. Experimental results demonstrate significant gains in detection performance, with increased precision, recall, and mAP metrics compared to the baseline model. Quantitative evaluations using PSNR and SSIM further confirm the superiority of the proposed enhancement technique over classical methods such as Gamma, LIME, and Retinex SSR. Although the approach effectively enhances performance under challenging lighting conditions, real-time efficiency and robustness in uncontrolled industrial environments remain open issues. Future work will focus on optimizing high-capacity YOLO architectures through Knowledge Distillation (KD) to develop lightweight student models capable of achieving high accuracy with reduced computational cost, enabling practical deployment in real-world welding inspection systems

title: Integration of Big Data, Dynamic Systems, and Artificial Intelligence in Local Government Decision Making: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Sumirah, Budi Nugroho, Adi Wibowo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Digital transformation in local governments requires a data-driven, adaptive, and precise decision-making approach. This study identifies the challenges, trends, and opportunities in the application of Big Data, Dynamic Systems, and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to support local government decision-making. Using a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) approach, 45 scientific publications were systematically analyzed to uncover the contribution of these technologies to the efficiency, accuracy, and responsiveness of public policy. The study results indicate that the integration of these three technologies has the potential to form a predictive and prescriptive decision support system, enabling local governments to formulate evidence-based policies, conduct policy simulations, and predict the long-term impacts of policies. However, the implementation of these technologies still faces significant challenges, particularly in terms of data interoperability, infrastructure readiness, and limited human resource capacity for advanced analysis. Therefore, improving cross-sector data integration, developing human resource capacity, and strengthening technological infrastructure are key to optimizing the benefits of these technologies for local governance.

title: BERT-Based Multi-Task Classification Model for Free Health Check-Up Program Analysis
authors: Oja Widiyatama, Fatur Rozak, Andri Fachrur Rozie, Andria Arisal, Dian Kurniasari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Assesing public perception is vital for ensuring the effectiveness government program. This study analyzes public responses to the government’s Free Health Check-Up Program using data extracted from tweets on Platform X posted between October 20, 2024 and March 31, 2025. The study employs a multi-task classification approach in which the first task classifies tweets as either news or public service announcements, while the second task performs sentiment analysis. For comparison, single-task and multi-class classification model were also developed as baselines, allowing a comprehensive evaluation across different strategies. The dataset was preprocessed using a combination of the NLTK method, custom-built dictionary, and the InSet Lexicon-Based method for automatic sentiment labeling. The classification model used was IndoBERT, which is a BERT-based model and was optimized using the Design of Experiment technique. The multi-task classification approach demonstrated optimal performance. Achieving Content type classification reached an accuracy of 87.05% and F1-score of 84.04%, while sentiment classification achieved an even higher accuracy of 89.76% and F1-score of 87.07%. The model was trained with dropout rate of 0.2, learning rate of 5e-5, batch size of 32, weight decay of 0.1, and 5 training epochs. These result demonstrate the potential of multi-task classification and the IndoBERT model for analyzing public sentiment on social media platforms.

title: Expanding Life Expectancy Prediction With Digital Health and Personal Data Integration
authors: Vladyslav Malanin, Illya Chaikovsky, Olexander Palagin
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper introduces an innovative multiplatform autofill framework designed for the Ukrainian population’s personalized life expectancy tool, called the Life Calculator. By integrating digital health data from Apple Health, Google Fit, clinical records through Helsi, and government documents using Diia’s multisharing API, we automate questionnaire completion, removing the need for extensive manual data entry. We clarify the system architecture, which includes native application embeddedbrowser techniques, robust data mappings, and secure client-side workflows. Moreover, we present emulated results that indicate a 60% reduction in completion time and a 40% decrease in input errors. We also discuss the implementation of privacy-preserving mechanisms to ensure compliance with GDPR and Ukrainian data protection laws, and we outline future directions for expanding data sources and leveraging advanced analytics.

title: Design of an AI-Assisted Support System for Manual Procedure Education Using LLMs and RAG
authors: Hsin-Ying Wu, Chi-Ching Lee
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: In many manual-operation-based courses, such as those involving microscope use, students' ability to review after class is limited by the high cost of equipment and the inability to carry specimen slides. As a result, they cannot easily revisit specimens or reproduce classroom observations. Moreover, key teacher instructions are often delivered verbally and not fully recorded in teaching materials, forcing students to rely on time-consuming video reviews. Existing teaching systems typically rely on static images, lacking interactivity and platform integration, and are insufficient to meet learning needs. To solve the above problems, this study designs an AI-assisted teaching system that combines large language model and retrieval-augmented generation technology. The system consists of modules such as textbook uploading, segmentation indexing, search generation and interactive interface. It supports users to upload classroom text books and quickly obtain review texts and reference materials through prompts, thereby improving data availability and learning efficiency. In addition, the system is also planned to support images and multimodal data in the future, and will introduce learning effectiveness assessment and multi-platform authentication mechanisms. The initial construction has been completed, and it is planned to conduct small-scale closed testing in actual courses to collect feedback to optimize system functions and verify application potential.

title: Using NLP Tools for Processing Unstructured Information for Financial Reports
authors: Oleksii Ivanov, Vlad Iatsiuta, Vitaliy Kobets
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper investigates the application of Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools for processing unstructured business data and automating the analysis of financial video content. We propose a unified system architecture that converts diverse data types into text format for streamlined processing by large language models. An experimental study using ChatGPT-4o demonstrates the system's effectiveness in analyzing financial YouTube videos, achieving 100% accuracy in company AMZN and stock ticker recognition, and successfully extracting structured investment insights, including risk assessments and price forecasts. Validation against actual stock market performance over one year showed 90% prediction accuracy, with 100% precision and an F 1 -score of 94.7%. These results confirm that NLP technologies can reliably transform unstructured financial media into structured investment intelligence, significantly improving decision-making speed and quality for investors, analysts, and business professionals.

title: Real-Time Defect Detection and Intervention System for FDM Printers Using Accelerometer Data
authors: Kemel Shomenov, Md. Hazrat Ali, Essam Shehab
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printers are widely used for prototyping and small-scale production; however, they require continuous supervision to prevent defects, which can lead to materials and time wastage. Excessive vibrations during the printing process often cause such defects. Therefore, it is essential to develop a vibration monitoring mechanism. Although prior research studies have focused on employing vibration data and machine learning to detect problems such as nozzle clogging and filament jams, little research attention has been given to real-time, automatic corrective measures. This study focuses on developing an economical, autonomous defect detection system based on accelerometer data. The system monitors vibration patterns in real-time and applies the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to analyze frequency domain data. Upon detection of defects, the system, which, implemented using Python, automatically pauses or stops the printer. The defect identification accuracy is enhanced using Cosine Similarity, which compares real-time data with the normal state of the printer. Experimental results indicate that the system can effectively detect changes in vibration patterns, such as those caused by loose belts, and implement immediate corrective actions. This autonomous approach significantly reduces material waste and improves the overall reliability of the 3D printing process. This research study contributes to the field by integrating defect detection with real-time interventions, providing a practical solution for improving the efficiency of FDM printing.

title: Evaluating Scalability and Success Rates of Exact and Approximate N-Queens Solvers
authors: Sinjini Banerjee, Ali Faisal, Hemant Kumar, Yasir Jamal, Raja Hashim Ali, Adnan Shah
abstract: The N-Queens problem is a canonical benchmark in combinatorial optimization, used to evaluate exact, heuristic, and metaheuristic approaches. Despite extensive research, unified comparisons of runtime, memory consumption, and solution reliability across paradigms remain limited. This paper presents a systematic evaluation of four algorithms—Depth-First Search (DFS), Hill-Climbing (HC), Simulated Annealing (SA), and Genetic Algorithms (GA)—implemented within a common Python framework. Each solver was tested on board sizes N ∈ {10,30,50,100,200} over 100 independent trials under standardized conditions, measuring runtime, peak memory, and success probability. Results show that DFS achieved 100% success for N =10 but failed beyond N =30 due to exponential scaling. HC delivered 100% success up to N =50 but degraded to 50% success at N =200. SA maintained 88–100% success across all scales with moderate runtime (0.05–3.5 s) and memory usage (6–11 MB). GA achieved universal 100% success but required higher computational resources (0.1–10 s, 12–40 MB). These findings reveal practical trade-offs: exact methods for small instances, HC for rapid mid-scale solutions, SA for balanced performance, and GA for maximum reliability. The results provide actionable guidelines for selecting algorithms in resource-constrained optimization contexts.

title: Designing a Theoretical AI-Based Fault Detection System for Rocket Engines
authors: Aarav Sojatia, Manan Sojatia, Kamal Kumar Sethi, Prajal Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Fault detection in rocket engines is of prime importance for mission reliability, crew safety, and maintaining the structural longevity of propulsion systems. Traditional methods of engine diagnosis often involve threshold-based monitoring, hardware redundancy, and human visual inspection, which may only be able to catch faults well after they have grown severe, leaving little time for effective intervention. Modern rocket engines incorporate increasingly sophisticated component assemblies and sensing arrays, which are generating large volumes of dynamic telemetry that traditional systems cannot parse effectively. With advances in AI, ML, and DL, today's aerospace engineers have access to powerful analytics that can much more precisely detect subtle deviations from nominal operation. The paper proposes a theoretical design for an AI-based rocket engine fault detection architecture based on recent literature related to anomaly detection, temporal neural networks, autoencoders, and physics-informed learning. It integrates multi-sensor telemetry, signal preprocessing, LSTM-based temporal modelling, autoencoder-based unsupervised anomaly detection, and physics-informed neural network checks within an ensemble decision framework with human-in-the-loop verification. Sources for verified figures are listed next to each placeholder. The design illustrates how hybrid physics-AI systems can detect combustion instability, turbopump degradation, and injector anomalies with better early warning and reliability compared to traditional threshold-based approaches.

title: Periodic Event-Triggered Quantized Control for Nonlinear Systems With Packet Losses and Large Transmission Delays
authors: Xun-Lin Zhu, Xiuxiu Zhang, Jumei Wei, Changyun Wen, Hai Lin
abstract: This paper investigates the design problem of periodic event-triggered quantized control (PETQC) for general nonlinear networked control systems (NCSs) with multiple communication channels between the plant and the controller. The transmission of information over these channels is asynchronous, and the transmission instants are determined by a local dynamic event-triggering mechanism (ETM). In each channel, continuous signals are sampled and quantized with a dynamic quantizer (DQ) before being transmitted due to limited bandwidth. In addition, large transmission delays may occur, packets may be lost and even without acknowledgements. To tackle these challenges, we introduce auxiliary variables and design appropriate jump rules to monitor the changing process of the total network-induced errors. Meanwhile, we propose new design conditions for ETM and DQs, and develop an encoding rule and a decoding algorithm. Then, we construct a new Lyapunov function and design a PETQC strategy to ensure the input-to-state stability of the nonlinear NCSs. Next, we construct triggering functions and dynamic variables for the event trigger in each channel. Compared with the existing literature, the proposed design conditions for periodic ETM involve fewer constraints and are less conservative. Finally, the efficiency and less conservatism of the theoretical results are illustrated by simulation studies.

title: Exploration-Enhanced Proximal Policy Optimization
authors: Yinglong Dai, Zhi Yi, Qiangfu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: While the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm has gained widespread adoption for its ability to ensure monotonic policy improvement through constrained updates, its exploratory capabilities remain a critical limitation, often trapping policies in suboptimal regions. To address this challenge, this paper introduces a novel hybrid framework that synergizes PPO with gradient-free evolutionary algorithms, unlocking unprecedented exploration potential in high-dimensional policy spaces. By integrating the global search ability of evolutionary algorithms, our approach not only preserves PPO’s stability and monotonic improvement guarantees but also empowers it to escape local optima and discover significantly superior policies. Extensive experiments across diverse and complex environments demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed method, showcasing performance improvements over standard PPO. This work bridges the gap between gradient-based and gradient-free optimization paradigms, offering a robust solution to the exploration-exploitation dilemma in reinforcement learning.

title: Demonstration of a Subwavelength Radiofrequency Resonator for Infant Brain Imaging at 1.5 T
authors: Viktor M. Puchnin, Leila V. Sharipova, Debabrata Sikdar, Irina V. Melchakova, Alena V. Shchelokova
publish: 2025 Antennas Design and Measurement International Conference (ADMInC)
abstract: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) plays a crucial role in the early diagnosis and monitoring of neurological conditions in infants. However, conventional radiofrequency (RF) hardware is often ill-suited for pediatric applications due to its size, rigidity, and potential safety concerns. In this study, we present the design and numerical evaluation of a subwavelength RF resonator tailored specifically for infant brain imaging at 1.5 T. The proposed resonator comprises four radially oriented split-loop resonators (SLRs) that locally enhance the RF magnetic field of the birdcage body coil without requiring direct connections to the MRI scanner or active electronics. Electromagnetic simulations were conducted using both homogeneous and voxel-based models of infants. The resonator demonstrated a 5.5-fold increase in transmit efficiency of the body coil in the phantom model and a 5.8-fold increase in the voxelized model. A gain in signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 2.98 was observed compared to the body coil alone, along with a 1.46-fold improvement over a conventional local receive-only head coil. Furthermore, the application of the proposed resonator reduced the required input power and local maximum specific absorption rate (SAR), improving the SAR efficiency (or RF safety) metric from 2.75 to 4.35 μT√kg/W. These findings highlight the potential of wireless resonant devices to enhance both performance and safety in neonatal MRI without requiring modifications to scanner hardware or software.

title: A Fog-based approach to Forest Fire detection
authors: Gabriel Madruga, Claudio M. de Farias
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of wildfires, which affect vast regions of the planet every year, resulting in serious environmental and social consequences. This study proposes a solution based on communication between electronic devices that collect data in real time and send it to a regional device where anomalies in the values are detected without relying on cloud processing, guaranteeing agile and accurate analysis. The project uses a three-layer architecture, with the first layer responsible for collecting and sending information, the second for analyzing and detecting anomalies, and the third for storing data remotely for further analysis. This approach aims to balance coverage of large areas with low device costs, avoid processing delays and reduce data storage costs, resulting in an efficient and cost- effective system for monitoring and detecting forest fires.

title: Ransome Watch: A Web-Based Malware Detection and Analysis System
authors: Snehlata Barde, Hari Shankar Bakkamanthula, Omchi Reddy Papadisu, Bhargav Anangi, Satish Gonti
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This article describes RansomeWatch, a novel webbased malware detection and analysis framework, specifically focused on the identification of ransomware. This lightweight, privacy-sustaining application was created to meet the serious limitations of traditional signature-based security measures that usually require considerable software deployments and compute resources, as well as significant privacy issues. RansomeWatch follows a zero-storage paradigm, performing full file processing within the RAM, as well as ensuring secure deletion after executing a fast cryptographic hash calculation followed by a comparison to a specialized threat intelligence collection, MalwareBazaar. Our thorough evaluation shows that the system effectively detects established threats, as well as processes multiple files simultaneously, with significant speed. The RansomeWatch framework demonstrates the viability of a web-based, privacyfocused approach that remains both very accessible, as well as very compute-efficient, to the ultimate users.

title: Secure and Trustworthy Multisource Data Sharing Using Blockchain for Agricultural Risk Mitigation
authors: Murugesan Mohana Keerthi, Ch. Srinivasa Reddy, Y. Sridevi, Anil Pandurang Gaikwad, Joshuva Arockia Dhanraj, Mohit Tiwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Through the process of analysing user behaviour and making predictions about tastes recommended devices play an essential part in the delivery of personalised user encounters. It is difficult for standard prescription approaches, such as collective filtering and filtering by content, to properly record intricate connections between multiple preferences within a single proposal. For this reason, we present an artificial intelligence-enhanced recommended systems that incorporates multi-preference deep teaching techniques to increase the quality of recommendations and the level of pleasure experienced by users. Adaptive modelling of user-item exchanges is accomplished via the use of Graphical Neural Network (GNNs) and Transformer-based structures in the method that has been developed. A system for optimisation that is founded on reinforced training constantly improves suggestions by analysing input from users. Furthermore, the combination of several preferences enables the program to take into effect environmental variables, such as the record of perusing, the habits of purchases, and the aspects that are related to time. The presented model surpasses current prescription algorithms in regards of accuracy, recall, and F1-scoring as shown by numerous trials conducted on datasets taken from the actual universe. By more effectively adjusting to users' ever-changing tastes, the software can accomplish a 20% increase in the precision of its recommendations and to increase user involvement. When contrasted to traditional approaches, our methodology provides suggestions that are 90% more personalised, flexible, and adaptable. As a result, it is an excellent option for recommended engines of the future generations.

title: AI-Driven Natural Language Processing to SQL Query Generation for Enhanced Human-Machine Interaction in the Digital Era
authors: Ivan Pashchuk, Iryna Turchenko, Mykhailo Dombrovskyi, Maksym Hrushytskyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is key to enabling intuitive interaction with structured data, especially via natural language interfaces for SQL query generation. However, accurately translating complex user input into executable SQL remains challenging due to ambiguity, schema diversity, and DBMS variability. While prior work has applied transformer-based large language models (LLMs) and Text-toSQL datasets, gaps remain in voice input, multilingual support, and local data privacy. This paper introduces a desktop AI solution that combines transformer architectures, voice recognition, and Ukrainian language support to convert natural language into SQL queries. Built with GPT-4o and PyQt6, the modular system integrates intent classification, named entity recognition, and export features. Testing on 550 queries demonstrated 94% accuracy for text and 91% for voice input, outperforming comparable tools in speed and reliability. Future work will address DBMS integration, system scalability, and context-aware, conversational query refinement for improved Human-AI interaction.

title: When Project-Based Learning Meets Edge Computing: An Experience Report
authors: Zheng Song, Summit Shrestha, Zhengquan Li, Khairul Mottakin, Qiang Zhu
abstract: This innovative practice full paper describes the author's journey in creating and refining a project-based edge computing course, alongside insights gained from its execution across three iterations from 2022 to 2024. Edge computing, a paradigm shift introduced in 2016, extends cloud computing by processing data closer to the end-users at the network's edge. Despite its recognition as a burgeoning industry trend and its widespread application, a structured educational pathway to impart the requisite knowledge and skills in edge computing to students remains elusive. This paper outlines the development of a curriculum tailored for an entry-level edge computing course, emphasizing project-based learning (PBL) as its core pedagogical strategy. It delves into the formulation of learning objectives, selection of pertinent topics, identification of unique instructional challenges, and the integration of PBL to fulfill the educational aims effectively. The narrative progresses to reflect on the teaching experiences and modifications made across three consecutive offerings of the course in 2022, 2023, and 2024, respectively. Despite maintaining a consistent topic coverage and PBL methodology, each iteration introduced novel elements to the PBL design: the first focused on a student design competition, the second incorporated a survey option for online participants, and the third expanded to include an application track to accommodate a larger class size. By analyzing the students' evaluation and comments, we evaluate the course's impact on student engagement and learning. Furthermore, the paper makes a significant contribution to the academic community by offering all course materials, including the syllabus, lecture notes, programming assignments, and the PBL framework, for public access and reuse.

title: The Energy Literacy Spectrum: Understanding Students' Thoughts, Feelings, and Behaviors
authors: Sakshi Solanki, Achal Duhoon, Desen Sevi Ozkan
abstract: In this full research paper, we explore how students' enrolled in a co-taught, interdisciplinary course shapes their initial knowledge on complex topics that involve engineering, social sciences, and sustainability. We leveraged qualitative analysis on 35 interdisciplinary students' (engineering and social science majors) responses to open-ended surveys to understand how students describe energy, their emotional connection with energy-related issues, and their indicated behaviors. For this study, DeWaters and Powers's framework was utilized that consists of cognitive, affective, and behavioral dimensions. Our results will focus on how these interdisciplinary students show differences in understanding of energy concepts, their behavior and actions towards energy related issues. By using qualitative and thematic coding, the analysis helps in providing broad-level insights into how interdisciplinary students understand energy concepts and this highlights the importance of developing more effective and inclusive energy education methods. These results of different understandings of energy concepts provide insights that can help teachers in developing curriculum which integrates basic knowledge with student engagement emotionally and behavior.

title: Legal-Ethical Learning for Sustainable Transformation of 6G Software Technology
authors: Muhammad Azeem Akbar, Saima Rafi, Sarmad Saleem, Arif Ali Khan, Abdullah Ghaffar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: The evolution towards 6G technology software brings unique ethical and legal challenges in data sharing. Despite the critical importance of legal frameworks and ethical considerations, there is limited research on these aspects in the context of 6G software. This study addresses this gap through a semi-structured interview study with 38 experts from 9 countries, and identified 12 process areas, 21 challenges and their associated best practices. We propose a framework for sustainable 6G transformation, highlighting regulatory compliance, data transparency, environmental stewardship, and social responsibility as crucial factors for a legally and ethically sound transition. Our research findings provide a foundation for further contextualization and seamless consideration of ethical and legal aspects while transitioning to 6G software technology.
