title: Parameter estimation of a linear ARX model with skewed heavy-tailed noise
authors: Xin Chen, Jialong Zhang
abstract: An online variational Bayesian algorithm based on a skewed Student's t-distribution, referred to as OVB-skewt, is proposed for robust parameter estimation in linear AutoRegressive with eXogenous inputs (ARX) models. In practical applications, measurement data are often contaminated by non-Gaussian, heavy-tailed, and asymmetric noise, which poses significant challenges to conventional identification methods that typically assume Gaussian noise. To address this issue, the proposed method incorporates the generalized hyperbolic skewed Student's t-distribution into a variational Bayesian inference framework, allowing the noise characteristics to be adaptively learned during online estimation. By explicitly modeling both heavy-tailed behavior and skewness, the proposed algorithm improves robustness against outliers and asymmetric disturbances. The online formulation enables efficient processing of streaming data, making the method suitable for time-varying industrial environments. Numerical simulations and a continuous fermentation reactor (CFR) benchmark demonstrate that the proposed OVB-skewt approach achieves improved estimation accuracy compared with symmetric noise-based methods under skewed and contaminated noise conditions, while maintaining stable performance in online settings.

title: Improved Dynamic Window Approach Using Sugeno Fuzzy Logic for Mobile Robot Collision Avoidance
authors: Falah Ibnu Rachman, Trihastuti Agustinah, Yurid E. Nugraha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This research presents an improved Dynamic Window Approach (DWA) using Sugeno Fuzzy Logic for enhanced mobile robot collision avoidance in dynamic environments. Standard DWA algorithms utilize fixed weight parameters that limit their adaptability to changing environmental conditions, particularly in scenarios with moving obstacles. To address these limitations, this study develops a Fuzzy Dynamic Window Approach (FDWA) that integrates Sugeno fuzzy logic with DWA to enable adaptive weight adjustment based on real-time environmental feedback. The research methodology involves implementing and comparing three navigation algorithms: standard DWA, improved DWA, and FDWA with fuzzy weight adjustment. All algorithms were tested in simulated environments featuring both static and dynamic obstacle scenarios. Simulation results demonstrate that FDWA significantly outperforms both standard DWA and improved DWA in dynamic and complex environments with respect to navigation efficiency, speed, and collision rate.

title: ConvSE for Multiple Sclerosis Lesion Segmentation
authors: Abdul Wahab, Hafiz Muhammad Talha Ijaz, Basma Nasir, Zawar Hussain, Muhammad Nawaz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Accurate delineation of multiple sclerosis lesions in brain MRI remains difficult due to small and diffuse pathology and inter rater variability. Spatial attention models often pool over space which erodes voxel level detail and increases complexity. We introduce ConvSE module which integrates a convolution based squeeze and excitation module within a fully convolutional DenseNet for lesion segmentation. The module forms a channel descriptor by global average pooling. A two layer bottleneck with a reduction ratio predicts channel gates. The gates rescale feature responses at full resolution and the network is trained with a Dice loss and a cross entropy loss. We evaluate on the ISBI 2015 longitudinal resource using patient wise five fold cross validation on FLAIR MRI with identical preprocessing and splits to a strong attention baseline. ConvSE improves cross fold mean Dice from 0.781 to 0.811. It reaches a best fold Dice of 0.875 and a fold mean of 0.847. It reduces parameters from 13501982 to 5148386 and shortens training time while maintaining specificity near 0.999. The results show sharper boundaries and fewer false positives than the existing attention models.

title: Handover Optimization in LTE Networks Using Contextual Bandit Reinforcement Learning and Real-World Data
authors: M M Sadman Shafi, K M Istiaque, Shafayet Sadik Sowad, Mohammad Tawhid Kawser
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Handover (HO) optimization is crucial in Long Term Evolution (LTE) networks to ensure seamless connectivity and minimize unnecessary signaling. Conventional threshold-based HO mechanisms lack adaptability to dynamic radio conditions, leading to suboptimal decisions and ping-pong effects. This paper presents a reinforcement learning (RL)-based HO decision framework trained and evaluated on real-world LTE drive-test datasets from a dense urban environment in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The HO problem is modeled as a contextual bandit and solved using tabular Q-learning with a binary action space. The reward function integrates handover margin (HOM) and time-to-trigger (TTT) constraints to promote link stability and penalize unstable HOs. Evaluation on unseen traces uses nearest-neighbour state matching, while an external TTT filter further improves temporal stability. Results show consistent suppression of unnecessary HOs and alignment with reward objectives, confirming the framework’s robustness and adaptability for practical LTE deployments.

title: A Comparative Analysis on Discernment of Human Versus AI-Generated Art
authors: Hortense Gerardo, Marie Clemenceau, Kevin Tellier
abstract: This Work-in-Progress paper, submitted under the Engineering Ethics and Innovative Practice track, explores an experiential approach to ethics education for upper-level undergraduates in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (MAE) and Art History. As generative artificial intelligence (AI)-including large language models and image-generation tools-becomes more accessible, the ability to create compelling but synthetic visual media has increased dramatically. This raises urgent ethical questions regarding authenticity, authorship, and the risk of deception, particularly in the context of so-called “deepfakes.” The 2023 ENISA Threat Landscape Report identified deepfakes as a critical threat to digital trust and public security. In response, this study examines how students from divergent academic disciplines evaluate the authenticity of visual artworks. Participants engage in Real or Fake, an interactive multimedia game in which they assess 28 images to determine whether each was created by a human artist or by AI. A point-based scoring system records performance, and comparative analysis is conducted to examine differences in decision-making strategies. The game integrates concepts of Visual Commonsense Reasoning (VCR) and Visual Quotient Reasoning (VQR) to evaluate participants' ability to detect stylistic, contextual, and semantic anomalies. Preliminary results show that art history students outperform engineering students on average, suggesting that disciplinary training in visual analysis influences discernment ability. These findings highlight the value of integrating ethical reflection, AI literacy, and interpretive skills across technical and humanities curricula. The study contributes to the growing need for interdisciplinary pedagogy that equips students to critically engage with the implications of AI-generated media.

title: Explainable AI For Phishing Detection: Techniques, Challenges, and Experimental Validation
authors: Varsha V G, Dr. Princy Ann Thomas
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Phishing attacks remain a critical cybersecurity challenge, causing severe financial, operational, and reputational damage. While machine learning (ML) models have demonstrated high accuracy in phishing detection, their real-world adoption is hindered by limited interpretability, reduced user trust, and vulnerability to adversarial manipulation. This work presents a modular, applied framework that combines a Decision Tree-based detection engine with Explainable AI (XAI) techniques—SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations (LIME)—and an adversarial robustness module inspired by the Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) attack methodology. Unlike the original PGD, which is designed for continuous feature spaces, our adaptation applies controlled, bounded perturbations to phishing URL features, simulating realistic evasion tactics while preserving URL validity. This ensures the framework can assess and improve model resilience in practical threat scenarios. We evaluate the system using the Kaggle Phishing URLs dataset, achieving a baseline accuracy of 96% and 90% accuracy under PGD-inspired adversarial perturbations. Qualitative SHAP and LIME visualizations illustrate the model’s decision logic, enhancing transparency and user trust. The proposed architecture offers a scalable, transparent, and resilient phishing detection solution suitable for enterprise-grade deployment.

title: Identifying Key Molecular Features for Cancer-Related hCA Inhibitor Compounds Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Gede Prasidha Bhawarnawa, Ayu Purwarianti, Rukman Hertadi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: This study explores interpretable machine learning (ML) approach to predict inhibitors for human Carbonic Anhydrase (hCA) isoforms IX and XII, which are overexpressed in cancer, and a homeostasis isoform II. Traditional approaches to perform this, including in vitro experiments, face challenges such as costly resources and limited dataset. Hence, ML solutions are developed to mitigate these challenges with each research having their own distinct methodologies and results. This study replicates a past research's ([5]) methodology and dataset to see if additional data preprocessing steps (e.g., data cleaning) and non-linear classification models improve previous results and output feature importance information. This study's methodology involved training and validating three models: Extra Trees, XGBoost, and a novel hybrid model called NCART. The training data consists of 1 350 compounds for isoform II, IX, and XII, curated from ChEMBL database and described with RDKit feature set library. The experiments show that Extra Trees have the best performance measured with Matthew's correlation coefficient (MCC) and accuracy, but both NCART and XGBoost show competitive performance in comparison with the added benefit of interpretability. Both of these models identified van der Waals surface area (VSA), the number of rings, molecular weight, topological polar surface area (TPSA), and negative charges as the most influential features for determining a compound's activity. These findings are consistent with established drug design principles and existing patterns of clinically approved hCA inhibitor drugs, which provide insights for the rational design of new hCA inhibitors.

title: WIP: Designing Faculty Mentorship at Scale: Lessons from the Mentorship 360 Faculty Mentoring Program at Arizona State University
authors: Jennifer M. Bekki, Samantha R. Brunhaver, Ann F. McKenna
abstract: This innovative practice WIP paper describes the Mentorship 360 (M360) Faculty Mentoring Program, a multi-level initiative implemented within the Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering at Arizona State University. Faculty mentorship is a critical yet often under-resourced element of academic success and retention, especially within large, interdisciplinary engineering colleges. Designed to address the diverse needs of faculty across career stages and appointment types, M360 integrates localized school-based mentorship, individualized coaching, cross-unit collaboration through a community of practice, and values-driven professional development workshops. The program aligns with best practices in formal mentoring, emphasizing intentional mentor-mentee matching, institutional support, and inclusive design. We describe the program's structure, implementation across multiple academic units, key lessons learned, and strategies for sustaining engagement and impact. Findings highlight both the promise and challenges of embedding mentorship into faculty culture at scale, offering insights for institutions seeking to foster faculty development, wellbeing, and belonging through systemic mentorship.

title: WIP: Motivating Calculus for Computer Science Majors
authors: Rajendra K. Raj, Aaron Deever, Shari Plantz-Masters, Douglas Hart, Rahul Simha
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative practice paper describes a Continuous Structures course, with accompanying pedagogy, to make calculus more appealing and accessible to undergraduate computer science (CS) majors. The theses underlying this work are two-fold: (1) examples taken from compelling current CS areas, such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and robotics, can motivate CS students into investing in learning calculus, and (2) programming-centered pedagogy helps to complement this learning by building on skills that most CS students would already have when they take the course. This approach can address the decades-old challenge of convincing CS majors to take continuous mathematics seriously while also exposing CS majors early to new topics in machine learning and data science. This paper discusses a proof-of-concept course implementation whose preliminary evaluation led to the refining of assessment instruments and fine-tuning of research questions. It also outlines plans for expanding this approach to topics in probability and linear algebra.

title: WIP: Students in Dysfunctional Team: First Year Engineering Design Course Perspective
authors: Junqiu Wang, Fazel Ranjbar, P.K. Imbrie
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper examines the alignment between peer and self-evaluations among first-year engineering students working in teams of four at a large public university. As part of a required design course, students collaborate on both short- and long-term projects throughout the semester. Teams meet twice weekly during class and are expected to coordinate outside of class to complete assignments. To assess team functioning, a peer evaluation instrument is administered midway through the semester. The instrument includes both quantitative and qualitative components. The quantitative section is based on a validated four-factor team effectiveness model—interdependency, goal setting, potency, and trust—each measured using three Likert-scale items. Students evaluate both teammates and themselves on all items. Additionally, students allocate a total of 100 points across team members to represent their perception of each member's contribution. The standard deviation of these peer-assigned grades is used to categorize teams by potential dysfunction. Following the quantitative section, students provide open-ended comments describing observed positive and negative teamwork behaviors. This study explores the degree of discrepancy between self- and peer evaluations, particularly in teams with high grade variance. We also investigate whether teams with higher standard deviations in peer grades exhibit distinct patterns of negative behavior in their qualitative feedback. These findings aim to improve early identification of dysfunctional team dynamics and inform targeted instructional interventions in engineering education.

title: Effective SegFormer Ensemble for Diabetic Foot Ulcer Segmentation
authors: Arturas Kairys, Vidas Raudonis
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Peripheral neuropathy and arterial decease are among the most troubling diabetes complications, often leading to the development of foot ulcers. Timely diagnosis and regular monitoring significantly influence ulcer healing outcomes and semantic segmentation offers a means to support objective assessment and clinical decision-making. However, challenges such as limited training data, inconsistent annotation or visually ambiguous scenery hinder the fine-tuning of robust semantic segmentation models. The Diabetic Foot Ulcer Challenge 2022 (DFUC2022) was organized to encourage interest and development of dedicated segmentation models for this task. In this paper, we present a workflow that yielded a strong performance on the DFUC leaderboard. We analyze the impact of various model ensembling strategies for improving their performance. Efficient training routine was used to train off-the-shelf SegFormer transformers. Scaling of SegFormer models led to an F1 score of 0.733 and $6^{\text {th }}$ rank on the leaderboard using the MiT-B5 backbone. The ensemble developed during this analysis resulted in a model that achieved 0.7363 F1 score and a $3^{\text {rd }}$ rank on the leaderboard using three MiT-B5 networks.

title: WIP Bridging the Gap: Faculty Perspectives on Microlearning Implementation in Engineering and Computing Education
authors: Farhan Sadique, Suman Saha, Mahfuza Farooque, Susan Yelich Biniecki
abstract: This work-in-progress study investigates the perspectives of engineering and computing education faculty on implementing microlearning strategies such as short three to five-minute videos, simulations, and gamification. The research employs the Enhanced Critical Incident Technique (ECIT) to identify helping factors, barriers, and wish-list items for faculties related to integrating microlearning elements for student engagement. The research targets twelve participants, with preliminary findings based on the first set of interviews presented in this running paper. Data collection methods include semi-structured individual interviews. The research is guided by the ECIT framework using NVivo to uncover key factors shaping faculty experiences and aspirations regarding microlearning adoption. Preliminary findings reveal three major enablers: flexible content delivery, immediate feedback, and positive student reception. The most frequently cited barriers include difficulty simplifying complex technical content, limitations of institutional tools, and a lack of professional development focused on microlearning. Wishlist items include access to gamified and interactive tools, AI-driven personalization features, and greater institutional training and support. This study helps to bridge a critical gap by capturing the lived experiences of faculty members using ECIT. By surfacing helping factors, barriers, and aspirational needs surrounding microlearning, it offers early insights into the practical realities of microlearning adoption. These findings lay the groundwork for future faculty development initiatives and institutional strategies to foster more intentional and sustainable integration of microlearning in engineering and computing education.

title: WIP: Leveraging Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) Projects for Industry-Driven Software Development in Undergraduate Education
authors: Ross McLean, Jamie Sundance McDonald, John N.A. Brown
abstract: This Work in Progress paper presents an innovative, cross-university software development initiative using the Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) framework. Driven by local businesses seeking new revenue streams, the project engages undergraduate students in international, industry-oriented collaboration to enhance both learning outcomes and business innovation. Student teams developed interactive software prototypes in collaboration with business partners. Each project included a student Product Owner to ensure alignment with business needs. Completed prototypes were then transferred to a partner institution for full-stack implementation. This two-phase model blended distributed teamwork, cultural exchange, and authentic industry input. Data collection includes student reflections, lecturer insights, and industry feedback. Early results highlight growth in agile practices, cross-cultural communication, and stakeholder collaboration. Conference participants will gain insight into designing international, industry-led collaborations that build technical and cross-border skills. Future work will focus on improving engagement and expanding partnerships with more industry stakeholders.

title: A Secure and Privacy-Preserving Blockchain-Based Framework for Fraud-Resilient E-Health Systems
authors: Hiba Akli, Igor Stephan, Karim Zkik, Sofiane Hamrioui
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: E-health systems have revolutionized healthcare by enabling efficient data sharing and management. However, they face significant security and privacy challenges, including unauthorized access, data breaches, identity fraud, and insurance fraud. Existing solutions attempt to address these issues but suffer from single points of failure, lack of patient-defined access control, and inadequate privacy-preserving mechanisms. This paper proposes a dual-blockchain architecture integrated with Self-Sovereign Identity and Zero-Knowledge Proofs to enhance security, privacy, and fraud resilience. The framework employs Decentralized Identifiers and Verifiable Credentials for secure authentication while leveraging the InterPlanetary File System for decentralized Electronic Health Records storage. By addressing the limitations of current systems, the proposed solution ensures a more secure, scalable, and privacy-preserving e-health environment.

title: A Study and Implementation of Customizable Optical Mark Recognition Sheets for Assessments
authors: Chengcheng Han, Arun Krishna K, Pranav V, Manuel Castro, Sathiamoorthy Manoharan, Babulakshmanan Ramachandran, Elio Sancristobal, Ulrich Speidel, M G Thushara, Xinfeng Ye
abstract: In personalized paper-based assessments, where each student's correct answers and options are unique, manual grading becomes impractical and inefficient. Fatigue and human error can compromise grading accuracy and consistency, particularly in large-scale evaluations. This innovative practice full paper addresses the research question: How can an online Optical Mark Recognition (OMR) system be designed to allow instructors to create customized OMR sheets and accurately read and verify student responses in the context of personalized paper-based assessments? By leveraging classic image processing techniques, our system enhances both the efficiency and accuracy of the grading process. The automated identification and evaluation of answer sheets significantly reduce the time and effort required for scoring while ensuring uniform and error-free results. This approach not only improves the scalability of personalized assessments but also provides a fair and reliable evaluation process without the need for installed software.

title: Robust Parkinson’s Disease Screening from Speech via Self-Supervised Learning Models and Task-Wise Analysis
authors: Maria Ahmad, Naima Iltaf
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Changes in speech often precede motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease, offering a scalable and non-invasive biomarker for early diagnosis. In this study, frozen self-supervised speech encoders, namely Wav2Vec2.0, HuBERT, and WavLM, are leveraged to extract acoustic and phonetic features. These features are fed to a lightweight Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit, with attention pooling that focuses on clinically salient segments. Using speaker-independent 10-fold cross-validation on each dataset and a speaker-held-out test set for final evaluation, this study explores both overall and task-wise performance on two languages, Italian and Spanish. On Italian speech, HuBERT attains 97.9% accuracy with AUC = 99.0, approaching screening quality, while on PC-GITA, WavLM generalizes best with 88.4% accuracy and AUC = 95.8, underscoring the role of language/domain in backbone choice. Task-wise analysis shows Reading/Sentences are the most reliable, high-yield probes, with DDK also robust; Vowels/Monologue are more variable and serve as complementary evidence. The proposed pipeline is compute-efficient, and well-suited for scalable clinical pre-screening of Parkinson’s disease.

title: WIP: Multi-Agent Artificial Intelligence Model to Enhance Self-Regulated Learning and Conceptual Understanding in Computer Science Education
authors: Jeeho Ryoo, Michael Pin-Chuan Lin, Sahil Rai, Wenhao He, Seong Min Park, Marco Ho
abstract: This innovative practice WIP paper explores the integration of a multi-agent AI system to enhance self-regulated learning in computer science education. The system includes a Teaching Assistant Artificial Intelligence, which provides hints during multiple-choice quizzes, an Analytics-AI that identifies patterns of conceptual confusion, and an AI-Improver that refines the system based on student feedback. Grounded in self-determination theory, self-regulated learning principles, and cognitive apprenticeship, this approach fosters autonomy, motivation, and conceptual understanding while providing instructors with actionable insights. Evaluation will focus on student performance, AI usage patterns, and satisfaction, assessing the AI's role in supporting learning. This study demonstrates how AI-driven assessment tools can create personalized learning environments, with future work extending the system to broader disciplines.

title: A Comprehensive Fraud Detection System Based on Client Transaction History and Behavioral Data Analysis
authors: Krupali Dave, Mukesh Patidar, Manish Adawadkar, Dupagutla Sanjay Kumar, Kotte Likith, Boyina Suresh Babu, Vadisala Chaitanya
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Online transaction fraud has become a growing menace, resulting in financial losses, stealing of identities, and a diminished level of trust in online platforms. This paper's focus is on fraud detection through backlogging, wherein transaction records are continuously recorded and stored, analyzed, and used whenever suspicious activity is identified. The system analyses unusual characteristics and abnormal transaction frequency, purchase pattern, geolocation anomaly, device fingerprinting, and payment methods. On the fraud detection front, non-machine learning methods such as rules-based filtering present the front lines of defense (for example, flagging transactions of unusually high values or repeated failed attempt). At the same time, machine learning models, such as Random Forest, Logistic Regression, Neural Network are all trained on the backlog data to label transactions as genuine or fraudulent. By combining real-time monitoring with historical checking, this framework can detect fraudulent activities early while keeping false positives at a minimum. Experimental results show that this hybrid approach leads to improved detection accuracy, enhanced consumer trust, and scalable.

title: Integrating Post Quantum Cryptography (PQC) for End-to-End Security in Edge and IoT Environments
authors: Asma Abbas Hassan Elnour
abstract: Advances in the field of interconnected consumer and IoT devices have highlighted the vulnerabilities of conventional cryptography to quantum computing. This paper presents a new hybrid model of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) that provides a high level of assurance in the edge-IoT ecosystems. The model being proposed combines lattice-based methods, i.e., Kyber-786 and Dilithium-III, and an AES-GCM layer model. Moreover, a trust and key negotiation mathematical analysis brings to fore the resistance of classical and quantum attackers with module-LWE and ring-LWE assumptions. The Python-based simulation proves that the suggested method increases the throughput by 18.6% and reduces the latency by 22.4% in comparison to the conventional methods. Also, there is a reduction of energy consumption by 41.7% with the use of a hybrid design caused by the hardware-accelerated two-polynomial operations and an optimized offloading. The analysis has shown that the proposed solution satisfies the confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity with less than 7.3 ms overhead per transaction, and PQC can be used in IoT and consumer settings without compromising responsiveness and energy consumption.

title: A Survey of AI in System of Systems With a Focus on Power Electronic Systems—Part I: Design and Control
authors: Kambiz Tehrani, Noman Khan, Chouaib Djaghloul, Tanveer Abbas, Pierre Bonnet, Françoise Paladian, Christophe Pasquier, Khalil El Khamlichi Drissi, François Vurpillot, Mo Jamshidi
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has become essential in dealing with the growing complexities of modern power electronic systems (PESs). In the context of Industries 4.0, 5.0, and especially 6.0, which are considered as ultra-large-scale systems, AI is becoming essential in addressing the multidimensional challenges of PES design, energy management, and control in complex interconnected systems. This part I of our two-part survey provides a comprehensive overview of AI techniques applied to the design and control stages across the lifecycle of PES. In this survey, we consider an energy conversion chain incorporating energy sources, converters, controllers, sensors, and loads as a complex or a large system with several subsystems by integrating the AI part for several objectives among others: design, control, optimization, maintenance, fault detection, etc. Our unique contributions include: first, a complete lifecycle-oriented perspective for power electronics systems, second, structured tabular summaries emphasizing experimental validation versus simulation-only studies, third, focus on design automation and AI-integrated converter control, and fourth, identification of research gaps in hardware implementation and model interpretability. This survey also identifies open challenges and offers forward-looking insights into design automation, and AI-integrated converter control for smart grids, electric vehicles, and power systems. This article aims to serve as a roadmap for both researchers and engineers seeking to adopt AI in next-generation power electronics. Part II of this survey will focus on the maintenance and forecasting phases of the lifecycle of PES.

title: Neuroplasticity-Inspired Adaptive Intrusion Detection System for Real-Time Threat Recognition and Self-Correction
authors: Suruchi Deshmukh, Tangeda S Sandilyaditya, Ravi Yadav, Malvika Unnikrishnan, Dishant Sevak, Pankaj Chandre
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) struggle to detect evolving cyber threats—specially form zeroday attacks, Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) etc. Which are vulnerable to disruptions from manual or automated interventions that compromise their operational integrity. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel self-evolving framework integrating Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) with bio-inspired algorithms—including synaptic plasticity, homeostatic regulation, and adaptive learning mechanisms—to enable autonomous self-detection, validation, and correction of IDS/IPS functionality. The system's architecture features a multi-layered neural processing core combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for pattern recognition with neuroplasticity-inspired mechanisms that enable continuous learning from network traffic patterns. This design allows real-time detection of both known and unknown attacks, delivering improved accuracy and reduced false positive rates versus conventional approaches. Bio-inspired adaptation mechanisms further enhance resilience against dynamic threats, empowering the system to evolve alongside emerging cyber risks. Critically, the framework includes granular observation and response capabilities to manage deliberate human interventions or automatic interruptions. In such scenarios, it deploys partial or permanent corrective measures that prioritize maintaining uninterrupted IDS/IPS functionality, minimizing disruption to security operations. By merging deep learning with biological-inspired adaptability, our approach provides a robust, selfsustaining solution for modern cybersecurity challenges.

title: Ageism in the Computer Science University Classroom: A Service Learning Case Study
authors: Natalie Andrus, Alexa Smith, Hamid Tarashiyoun, Wei Lu Wang, Ihudiya Williams, Scott McCrickard
abstract: Computer science students will play a crucial role in developing technology for a growing older adult population that will reach 2 billion by 2050. The Human Computer Interaction (HCI) community must prepare these students by addressing their perceptions of older adults aged <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$65+$</tex>. We explored these perceptions by conducting a case study at a large public university. The HCI course focused on the introductory principles of HCI and empowered students to lead lectures, participate in class activities, and complete introspective homework assignments. We performed a thematic analysis on data collected from classroom observations and homework assignments to uncover themes related to age perceptions. Our study offers two major contributions: 1) Themes representing the major perceptions of older adults in HCI classrooms, and 2) Recommendations on addressing biases identified in HCI students.

title: Vision-Based Granular Detection of Aquaculture Feed Pellets: A Systematic Review
authors: John Frederick Majan, Eduardo Piedad, Karel Pabeliña, Jacqueline De Vera, Kezia Celayne Bayona, Vei Siang Chan, Farhan Mohamed, Gerwin Guba, Franz de Leon
abstract: This systematic review synthesizes computer-vision methods for detecting aquaculture feed pellets to enable precision feeding. Following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) guidelines and the Population, Intervention, Comparison, Outcome, and Context (PICOC) framework, we searched Scopus, IEEE Xplore, and ScienceDirect for English, peer-reviewed studies (2020–2025). 256 records were collected, 74 duplicates were removed and 182 titles/abstracts were screened; 17 met preliminary criteria, and 11 were included after full-text assessment using a critical appraisal rubric. Most studies used YOLO-family, one-stage detectors; alternatives (e.g., MCNN, Mask R-CNN, VGG-based pipelines) were less common. Reported accuracies are promising, but heterogeneous datasets and metrics—varying IoU thresholds and mixed use of mAP, F1, precision–recall—limit cross-study comparability and external validity. Recurrent deployment barriers include underwater variability (turbidity, lighting, occlusion), scarce public datasets for benchmarking, and limited evidence of generalization across species and farm conditions. Priorities include standardized datasets and reporting, head-to-head benchmarks of YOLO and non-YOLO models, evaluation under edgecompute constraints, and multi-site validations. Overall, vision-based pellet detection shows clear potential to reduce waste and enable feedback-controlled feeding, but broader adoption requires stronger evidence and standardization.

title: The Personality Legal Protection Methodology in the Digital Environment
authors: Anna Dzhus, Oleksandr Bandurka, Valerii Sokurenko, Oleksandr Muzychuk, Viktor Vasylenko, Serhii Vladov, Serhii Ablamskyi, Sergii Grodskyi, Volodymyr Dmytriv, Ruslan Savchyshyn
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The article proposes an integrated methodology for legal protection of individuals in the digital environment, combining an asset register, DPIA, technical countermeasures (IAM, encryption, SIEM, or DLP), logging, and response procedures. The test experiment design, evaluation metrics (incidents, recovery time, log suitability), synthetic simulation, and risk matrix are provided. A step-by-step implementation with external audit and subsequent validation on real data is recommended.

title: EEG-Based Classification of MDD Using Different Feature Sets
authors: Oleksandr Sukholeister, Adrian Nakonecnyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) remains a leading cause of disability worldwide. Electroencephalography (EEG) coupled with machine-learning provides a rapid, non-invasive decision-support tool for clinicians. Seven families of EEG features—relative power, wavelet energy, frontal-alpha asymmetry (FAA), theta-beta ratio (TBR), P300 amplitude, and their combinations were benchmarked on 90 eyes-closed resting recordings from the open TDBRAIN repository. After artefact removal, each 5 -min record was split into 10 s epochs and class counts were balanced. A grid-searched Support Vector Machine with five-fold cross-validation achieved a peak accuracy of 90.9% ($\mathrm{F} 1=90.9 \%$) using channel-wise wavelet features (198 variables); region-level averaging compressed dimensionality by $3.6 x$ while retaining 82.9% accuracy. The findings highlight the diagnostic value of spatially resolved wavelet dynamics and caution that earlier studies may be biased by gender/age imbalance and multimodal acquisitions that are not properly synchronized in time.

title: Forecasting Meningococcal Infection Dynamics in Ukraine Using Exponential Smoothing During Wartime Disruptions
authors: Volodymyr Tsukanov, Dmytro Chumachenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Forecasting infectious disease dynamics during humanitarian crises is a critical public health task. This study evaluates the use of the Exponential Smoothing method to predict the short-term dynamics of meningococcal infection in Ukraine under the conditions of the Russian full-scale invasion. Based on monthly incidence data from 2017 to 2023, the model generated January to August 2024 forecasts. The forecasting accuracy, measured by a Mean Absolute Error of 5.62 cases and a Root Mean Square Error of 6.07 cases, demonstrated the method’s robustness under incomplete surveillance and healthcare system disruption conditions. The study highlights the practical novelty of adapting simple time series methods for epidemic forecasting in emergency contexts. It shows their value for timely public health planning when mechanistic models are infeasible. The results support the integration of lightweight forecasting tools into epidemiological monitoring systems during societal instability.

title: Facial Micro-Expression-Based Deepfake Detection Using Temporal Convolutional Networks
authors: Rabia Kanwal, Noureen Hameed, Shakeel Saeed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Public trust, digital forensics, and media integrity are all facing increasing difficulties as deepfake technologies proliferate. High-fidelity manipulations are often missed by conventional deepfake detection methods, particularly as generative models advance. In order to identify deepfakes, this paper suggests a novel framework based on Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCNs) that analyzes facial micro-expressions, which are fleeting, involuntary facial muscle movements that are challenging to replicate accurately. Our method captures subtle emotional cues and temporal inconsistencies that are frequently missing or distorted in manipulated videos by modeling long-range dependencies in facial sequences. The proposed TCN-based model performs significantly better than the traditional CNN, LSTM, and Transformer-based baselines, particularly in cross-dataset and adversarial scenarios, according to evaluations conducted on a curated dataset that combines real and synthetic content annotated with micro-expressions.

title: Deep learning-based Classification for Circulating Tumor Cells
authors: Martina Russo, Giulia Bertolini, Vera Cappelletti, Cinzia De Marco, Serena Di Cosimo, Petra Paiè, Nadia Brancati
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Circulating tumor cells are a key biomarker in liquid biopsy, offering a noninvasive approach to monitor and guide therapeutic decision in cancer patients. The extreme rarity and the heterogeneity of CTCs make their identification extremely challenging. To overcome these limitations, CTC can be isolated exploiting an unbiased workflow based on Parsortix® strategy, which enriches for CTC according to their size and deformability, in combination with DEPArray ${ }^{\text {TM }}$ technology that allows visualization and selection of single CTC. Then, expert physicians manually analyze the digital images of cells acquired with DEPArray technology. The introduction of an automatic system for CTC identification into clinical workflows could facilitate the early detection of metastases, optimize treatment decision-making, and improve patient outcomes. In this paper, we present a Deep Learning-based classification pipeline to distinguish CTCs from leukocytes in a liquid biopsy, focusing on improving diagnostic procedure and accuracy. The proposed method automatically classifies images acquired with DEParray technology, obtained at “Fondazione IRCCS-Istituto Nazionale dei Tumori” of Milan. It is based on ResNet architecture, a Convolutional Neural Network for image analysis and very popular in the medical field. The introduction of a carefully designed augmentation process allows incrementing data variability, obtaining improving in the model performance. The proposed method achieves an F1 score of $0,777 \pm 0,012$. The obtained promising results encourage us to do future research in this field.

title: TC-NetTrack: An Approach for Creating Digital Evidences for Flows in IP Networks
authors: Diana Gratiela Berbecaru
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Effective network forensics analysis necessitates the capability to reproduce any network event, irrespective of the user’s motivation, the characteristics of earlier events, and whether the origin of the events was an unauthorized intruder or a legitimate user. Numerous packet analyzers, network monitoring systems, and intrusion detection tools today enable network measurement and analysis through packet capturing, which facilitates the examination and reconstruction of network events and user activities. However, they lack the ability to offer cryptographic proof for the packet flows that have been captured. Building on this motivation, we provide the initial steps toward the development of TC-NetTrack: a device that utilizes trusted computing to generate digital proof for specific packet flows captured either on a node’s network interface or across a network link. Since TC-NetTrack needs to produce evidence that holds probative value, the most suitable method to achieve this is through digital signatures. However, signing each packet individually is not practical or efficient; therefore, we adopted a method known as tree chaining. We implemented this using Merkle trees alongside an optimized algorithm for traversing the tree, which conserves both space and time when the signer generates packet flow evidence. We assessed the tree chaining technique on three different platforms, each featuring varying processors and memory capacities. TC-NetTrack could be beneficial in application scenarios or use cases that demand verification of the recorded packet flows, including stock trading, financial applications, attack analysis, or military operations.

title: Immersive Education with Mixed Reality: A Case Study at a Zoological Museum
authors: Daryn Calangi, Maria Teresa Reggio, Armando Ruggeri, Massimo Villari
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Technological advancements in Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), and Mixed Reality (MR) have enabled innovative applications in education and cultural heritage. This study presents the development and implementation of a MR experience at the Zoological Museum “Francesco Cambria” of the University of Messina, aimed at enhancing visitor engagement and learning. The MR system integrates 3D models, interactive assets, and gesture-based controls through Microsoft HoloLens 2, providing users with an immersive, multisensory experience. The system offers two visit modes: an Autonomous Mode, where visitors interact with 3D reconstructions and contextual information, and a Guided Mode, which delivers audio-narrated content based on spatial triggers. Usability and user experience were evaluated based on the System Usability Scale (SUS) and the Simulator Sickness Questionnaire (SSQ).

title: MTGRec: A Novel Sequential Recommendation based on Multi-modal Temporal Graph
authors: Gengsheng Lin, Feng Zhou, Hongbin Ye, Xiaoyuan Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Sequential recommendation has gained increasing attention due to its capability to model users’ dynamic behaviors through historical interactions and accurately predict their next preferences. However, most existing approaches heavily rely on basic item attributes while overlooking the rich semantic information embedded in multi-modal content. Moreover, they often fall short in effectively capturing the temporal evolution of user interests. To address these limitations, we are motivated to develop a novel sequential recommendation framework called Multimodal Temporal Graph Recommendation (MTGRec), which integrates multi-modal content fusion with temporal graph modeling. Specifically, the model leverages graph convolutional networks to capture local interaction patterns and employs Transformer-based architectures to learn the global evolution of user preferences over time. Experimental results on three realworld datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing model performance.

title: Preliminary Development of a Closed-Loop FES System Application with a Co-activation Map for Restoring Knee Joint Movements
authors: Adelia Safira, Achmad Arifin, Fauzan Arrofiqi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide, with around 1.7 million new cases reported in Indonesia in 2020. Hemiplegia often leads to gait impairment due to limited knee movement. Previous Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) systems for rehabilitation could not respond to real-time changes in subject conditions, and stimulation adjustment between antagonistic muscles was slow, causing unstable motion. This study proposes a closed-loop FES system integrating dual IMU sensors and a Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) with a Fuzzy Coactivation Map to coordinate quadriceps and hamstring activity based on real-time knee trajectory feedback. The coactivation mapping functioned effectively in synchronizing muscle activation. However, the knee movement produced by the system was not yet smooth and accurate, indicating that the closedloop control still requires further improvement. Future work will focus on enhancing controller responsiveness and stability to achieve better motion performance in hemiplegic patients.

title: Objective Evaluation of Upper Limb Function after Stroke using Artificial Intelligence in Post-Acute Care
authors: Yu-Chun Chen, Chia-Ying Yu, Ya-Zhu Yang, Bo-Ting Wu, Chia-Yu Hsu, Jing-Ya Peng, Chiung-Cheng Chuang
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: Objective assessment of upper limb spasticity in post-stroke patients undergoing post-acute care (PAC) programs remains a critical challenge in clinical rehabilitation due to the limitations of traditional, subjective evaluation scales. This study proposes an artificial intelligence (AI)-based quantitative approach integrating surface electromyography (sEMG) and kinematic parameters for the classification of Brunnstrom recovery stages (BRS) II to V in PAC patients. Twenty post-stroke PAC patients and six healthy controls participated in the study. sEMG signals from the brachioradialis, biceps brachii, triceps brachii, and deltoid muscles, alongside kinematic data (angle), were recorded during guide-assisted elbow extension. Feature extraction included the co-contraction index (CCI) and five time-domain parameters. After normalization, XGBoost classifiers were trained and optimized via Bayesian optimization. The model achieved high classification accuracy across all stages, with an average accuracy of 96.91% and an F1 score of 0.97. Feature importance analysis identified CCI as the most influential parameter. Furthermore, the CCI trend analysis revealed distinct fluctuation patterns corresponding to stroke severity and recovery phase in PAC patients. These findings demonstrate the potential of AI-integrated multimodal analysis for objective, quantitative assessment of upper limb function in post-stroke PAC rehabilitation, providing valuable insights for clinical decision-making and personalized intervention strategies.

title: Exploring the Role of Graduate Student Mentors in Apprenticeship-Style Undergraduate Student Research Experiences in Engineering
authors: Nosakhare Idiaghe, Jessica Deters
abstract: This full research paper examines undergraduate student researchers' perceptions of the mentoring dynamics between them and their graduate student mentors in lab settings. Undergraduate research experiences are widely recognized in literature as critical for fostering interest and preparedness for advanced studies and professional careers in STEM. Graduate student mentorship is a vital component of these experiences, often described in the literature as part of a triadic relationship. However, most studies on undergraduate research experiences focus primarily on undergraduate outcomes, offering limited attention to the graduate student's role as a bridge between faculty PIs and undergraduate researchers. The purpose of this study is to explore the perception of undergraduate researchers on their engagement with graduate student mentors during a year-long research experience. Data analyzed for this study were collected through interviews conducted at the end of the program. Thematic analysis was employed to identify key themes and draw insights from participants' experiences. The findings reveal that graduate student mentors provided critical intellectual and practical guidance, fostered observational learning, and created collaborative environments that enhanced teamwork and belonging. Participants highlighted areas for improvement, including aligning expectations, roles, and availability. The study underscores the need for structured mentorship in undergraduate research to enhance engagement, skill development, and retention in STEM. Training graduate mentors, improving project alignment of projects and interests between graduate mentors and undergraduate researchers, and fostering clear mentor-mentee roles can strengthen research experiences. Future research should focus on developing adaptable mentorship framework with transferability to variety of institutional and disciplinary contexts.

title: WIP: QUINTET: A Platform for Quantum Internet Education and Training
authors: Sahil Mangotra, Abhishek Parakh, Mahadevan Subramaniam
abstract: This research WIP paper addresses the challenges emerging from teaching of transdisciplinary fields such as secure quantum communications and quantum network. QUINTET (Quantum Internet Education and Training Synthesizer) is an innovative experiential learning platform designed to revolutionize quantum education. QUINTET's architecture comprises four key components: eight interactive course modules covering both classical and quantum aspects of networking, cryptography, and security; a Learning Objects Repository (LOR) built on object-oriented principles; curricular materials based on Kolb's experiential learning model; and a comprehensive assessment methodology incorporating both quantitative and qualitative measures. The QUINTET platform delivers hands-on experience through virtual quantum network experimentation, utilizing quantum programming libraries from major providers like IBM, Microsoft, and Amazon, simulations, programming exercises, traditional pedagogical tools, as well as interactive mini-games called gamelets. QUINTET's flexible architecture allows instructors to synthesize customized lesson plans ranging from hour-long tutorials to full semester courses. The platform features virtual labs emphasizing concrete experience and active experimentation. QUINTET includes a comprehensive, customizable learning repository complete with information retrieval capabilities and usability analysis infrastructure. This platform represents a significant step forward in preparing the next generation workforce for the quantum computing era through structured, hands-on educational experiences.

title: Bayesian Optimisation for Sensor Scheduling and Tracking with Different Acquisition Functions
authors: Alicja Szwalek, Xingchi Liu, Chenyi Lyu, Alasdair Hunter, Lyudmila Mihaylova
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Joint target tracking and sensor scheduling includes resource optimisation and gathering the most informative data for purposes such as search and rescue, fire detection and surveillance tasks. For such real-time tasks, the limited access to initial tracking data can challenge the effectiveness of traditional machine learning methods, thereby motivating the development of active sensing strategies. This paper addresses such problems and formulates the joint target tracking and sensor scheduling problems within a Bayesian optimisation framework. The key question that this framework answers is: where to position the sensors in order to accurately track an object. In the considered case study, the sensors are mobile and represented by uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs). The active sensing of the environment is based on uncertainty-guided sampling thanks to a Gaussian process representation. The main novelty lies in the formulation of the sensor scheduling and tracking within a Bayesian optimisation setting. Under this framework, a detailed comparison of different acquisition functions is carried out, to identify the most suitable solutions for an active sensing problem. Results with respect to accuracy and computational time are reported.
