title: Smart Risk Prediction for Medical IoT A Dynamic and Privacy-Preserving Cybersecurity Model
authors: Mahamood Hussain Mirza, Sai Santhosh Polagani, Chandra Sekhar Kubam, Ronish B Patel, Amita Gandhi, Lavanaya Goyal
abstract: With the rapid adoption of Medical Internet of Things (MIoT) in healthcare environments, interconnected hospital systems have significantly improved patient monitoring, diagnostics, and treatment delivery. However, this integration also expands the attack surface, making MIoT systems increasingly vulnerable to evolving cyber threats that jeopardize data privacy, system reliability, and patient safety. Addressing the limitations of static and reactive cybersecurity models, this study introduces a smart risk prediction model that ensures dynamic and privacy-preserving protection of MIoT networks. The proposed model uses a Deep Ridgelet Neural Network (DRNN) to monitor complex data flows across hospital systems and predict cyber events with high accuracy. The synthetic threat datasets and realistic attacks are integrated into discrete-event simulations to emulate diverse security incidents and stress-test system behavior under adversarial conditions. The findings reveal that the DRNN model demonstrates superior performance in detecting anomalies and forecasting risk levels, while maintaining patient data confidentiality. The dynamic nature of the model allows continuous learning from new threats, making adaptable across various MIoT environments. The proposed model enhances the resilience of healthcare systems by lightweight and privacy-aware cybersecurity solution.

title: Interactive Visual Programming on CaSMM: The Benefits and Challenges of Children's Computational Thinking Development in STEM Learning
authors: Charles Cagle, Ting Liu, Carter Mayeux, Rebecca Schlegel
abstract: This full research-to-practice paper describes the computational learning progression of 5th and 6th grade students participating in sustained problem-based programming activities. It seeks to identify predominant challenges in students' development of computational thinking and summarize the replicable solution frameworks students developed to solve problems in different contexts. Our program leverages a horizontal learning approach integrating different learning fields including engineering, computational thinking, physical modeling, and science. This study involved 5th and 6th grade authentic science classrooms at two local intermediate schools over an entire school year. Five individual lesson plans on core curriculum science topics were designed for each grade where students assembled electronics including Arduino microcontrollers, motors, and sensors, and programmed the Arduinos with a visual-programming web application. By analyzing students' codes, common programming errors were noted and categorized according to computational thinking concepts in the lesson. Over the 33 computational thinking concepts embedded in all ten lesson plans, we identified three primary programming errors that the students struggled with the most, which included the implementation of delays, digital inputs and outputs, variables, and functions. Most students successfully completed the programming tasks, indicating that our sustained learning approach was effective in helping them grasp computational thinking concepts and apply these skills to solve practical problems. We also found a slight decrease in the programming errors students made between certain lessons, though this improvement was not consistent across all lessons. We examined the reasons behind these inconsistencies to provide insights guiding the refinement of future research design.

title: Forecasting Stock Market Fluctuations in Pakistan Using PyTorch TabNet
authors: Muhammad Irfan Khan, Noshaba Zulfiqar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Forecasting stock market behavior remains a challenging task due to the inherent volatility and non-linear dynamics of financial time series. This study proposes a robust prediction framework for modeling fluctuations in Pakistan’s equity market, specifically the KSE-100 Index, using PyTorch TabNet—a deep learning architecture optimized for tabular data. The analysis utilizes daily market returns from 2019 to 2023, incorporating key variables such as closing price, opening price, daily high, and daily low to estimate percentage changes in returns. Data preprocessing involves normalization, isolation-forest-based outlier detection, and systematic handling of missing values to ensure dataset integrity. Model performance is evaluated using Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), achieving values of 0.0347 and 0.0618, respectively. These results demonstrate that TabNet provides competitive predictive accuracy compared with traditional and contemporary deep learning methods. Overall, the findings indicate that PyTorch TabNet offers a reliable and efficient solution for forecasting short-term movements in the KSE-100 Index, delivering valuable insights for investors, analysts, and financial decision-makers.

title: Predictive Analysis of Student Dropout in the Computer Science Program at the University of Brasilia
authors: Giovana Pinho Garcia, Maristela Holanda, Marcelo Mandelli, Jonathan Rosa Moreira, Dilma Da Silva
abstract: Student dropout is a major challenge in Brazilian public higher education, particularly in computer science programs, where rates can exceed 40%. As most of Brazil's top universities are public and tuition-free, high dropout rates not only affect individual academic paths but also strain the broader educational system. This study investigates dropout factors beyond academic performance, incorporating socioeconomic variables, university admission methods, and the effects of the 2012 Quota Law, which reserves 25% of university admission slots for low-income students. This research explores how educational data mining, enhanced by socio-economic data, could identify key predictors of dropout in computer science programs. Using student data collected from a top federal university over the period 2013-2020, the study applies three machine learning algorithms - Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Random Forest (RF) - to build predictive models. The results show that the models achieved over 90% accuracy in predicting dropout. The most significant predictors include Grade Point Average (GPA), performance in introductory programming courses, and the mode of admission. These findings offer valuable insights for university administrators seeking to reduce dropout rates. While the study focuses on one institution, its implications extend across Brazil's federal university system, where similar admission and evaluation policies are employed. The findings suggest that combining academic and socio-economic data can inform more effective retention strategies in computer science programs.

title: Multi-Scale Robustness Evaluation of Deepfake Detectors
authors: Muhammad Nurkhoiri Hindratno, Gembong Satrio Wibowanto, Nova Hadi Lestriandoko, Pesigrihastamadya Normakristagaluh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Deepfake generation has advanced rapidly, raising serious challenges for information integrity. Existing work has examined many detection scenarios, but resolution variation remains a relevant factor to investigate. This study presents a systematic evaluation of deepfake detectors under multi-scale inputs using the standardized DeepfakeBench framework. Four benchmark datasets (UADFV, Celeb-DF-v1, Celeb-DF-v2, and DFDCP) were downsampled to lower scales. Six detectors were assessed, representing naive (XceptionNet, EfficientNet-B4), frequency-based (SPSL, SRM), and spatial-based (UCF, RECCE) methods. Frame-level Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC) was used for evaluation. The results show that detectors maintain stable performance at intermediate scales but all degrade substantially under extreme downsampling, reflecting their reliance on fine-grained spatial cues. Dataset complexity further shapes robustness, with simpler datasets yielding higher baselines but more realistic ones remaining challenging across all scales. Among the detectors, SRM (frequency-based) demonstrates the highest resilience to resolution loss, while UCF (spatial-based) achieves the strongest performance at moderate resolutions. These complementary strengths highlight the need for hybrid, resolution-invariant architectures that combine spatial and frequency cues to ensure consistent detection across diverse visual conditions.

title: Building Interaction Virtual Reality From the 3D Orthomosaic Model
authors: Perwira Ali Dzulfikar, Mochamad Azriel Saliqin, Ayung Candra Padmasari, Muhammad Yudhi Rezaldi, Abdurrakhman Prasetyadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: City modelling from 3D orthomosaic techniques has been developed previously, but it is still passive because it is one-way, so it cannot enable users to interact. This research aims to build city modelling from 3D orthomosaic techniques to be interactive, to make users interact, and to be used as virtual reality content. The method used is design and development research (DDR), which focuses on product design and development to provide a product solution. This research is a virtual reality content for tsunami simulation education. The research stages carried out from this DDR method are need analysis, design, development, testing, revision, implementation, and evaluation. The results of this study indicate that city modelling from 3D orthomosaic techniques, which are further processed using Blender and Unity software, can produce interactive 3D orthomosaic models to be used as virtual reality content. Thus, 3D orthomosaic models are concluded to be an alternative tool for creating virtual reality content.

title: Improving User Privacy Through Deep Learning: JavaScript Tracking Detection
authors: Aminah Alqahtani, Mounir Frikha, Ahmad Aljughaiman
publish: 2025 IEEE Twelfth International Conference on Communications and Networking (ComNet)
abstract: The web environment has evolved from being dominated by individual or organizational content creation to a complex web of interrelated webpages featuring content from various third-party websites involved in activities like advertising and analytics. This shift, while contributing to free content and innovation, has raised significant privacy concerns. Many researchers have increasingly focused on the privacy implications of third-party tracking of users’ browsing activities. This paper provides an overview of existing tools designed to defend against various tracking methods. It proposes a framework that utilizes deep learning to counteract tracking practices by classifying JavaScript asking or functional snippet and compares it with existing privacy tools. The aim is to empower users to gain control over their online privacy. This innovative solution leverages deep learning techniques to identify JavaScript programs and enhance privacy defenses, ultimately striving to strengthen privacy in the web tracking domain by preventing detection evasion through code.

title: Research on the Legal Effect and Judicial Challenges of Smart Contracts in Logistics Electronic Bills of Lading
authors: Xi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In the trend of the integration of global trade and digital technology, the problems of traditional paper bills of lading have become prominent. Smart contracts provide technical support for the innovation of electronic bills of lading. Based on the practices of enterprises such as COSCO Shipping, this paper explores the legal effect, judicial challenges, and related practical dilemmas of smart contracts in logistics electronic bills of lading. Smart contracts, relying on blockchain technology, possess characteristics such as immutability, serving as property rights vouchers, and automatic execution. They meet the provisions of the Civil Code of the People’s Republic of China on contracts and have legal effect. Enterprises like COSCO Shipping actively promote the application of electronic bills of lading, and international enterprises also have corresponding practices. However, smart contracts face challenges in judicial determination, including difficulties in the application of procedural laws and disputes over the property rights voucher attribute in substance. Additionally, there are major difficulties in technical implementation, such as industry collaboration barriers and technology adoption obstacles, as exemplified by the suspension of projects by leading enterprises. In the future, development should be promoted from aspects such as technical optimization, improvement of the legal framework, and construction of an industry - collaborative ecosystem to drive the digital transformation of the shipping industry.

title: Design and Analysis of a Miniaturized Nested Multi-Ring CSRR for Aircraft Navigation and Radar Systems
authors: M Pallavi, B R Shivakumar, Aldo W. Morales
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: The present research outlines a miniaturized, dual resonance, negative refractive index, nested multi-ring complementary split-ring resonator (CSRR) metamaterial (MTM) structure constructed exclusively for augmenting the performance of antennas deployed in airplane navigation systems. The proposed CSRR design is a single-layer structure, comprising asymmetrically inclined L-shaped slits etched on the top conductor of 1.6mm thick FR-4 substrate, while the ground copper is fully removed to optimize its electromagnetic (EM) properties. The overall size of the structure is $22 \times 22 \times 1.6 \mathrm{~mm}^{3}$, and it exhibits resonant frequencies at $\mathbf{1 . 0 9 G H z}$ (encompassing $0.95 \mathrm{GHz}-1.12 \mathrm{GHz}$) and 1.2GHz (encompassing 1.14GHz 1.27GHz), with a comprehensive negative index response stretching from 0.5GHz to 1.27GHz. The resultant effective medium ratio of 12.86 validates the design efficiency and compactness of the structure. The unit-cell is placed strategically on the ground plane of an end-fire antenna intended for use in aviation navigation, arranged as an $3 \times 3$ array. This coupling has led to significant improvement in impedance bandwidth from 7 MHz to 93 MHz, raising the fractional bandwidth from $0.71 \%$ to $8.89 \%$. The radiator performance is enhanced without compromising the antenna gain. The proposed MTM is simulated, and optimized using HFSS software, guaranteeing precise EM response and confirming its appropriateness for high-performance aerospace systems.

title: A Framework for Autonomous and Sustainable Crop Protection: An Intelligent Multi-Objective Pesticide Application System
authors: Tanya Sinha, Aparna Keshari, Sahil Chauhan, Himank Jadhav, Leeladhar Chourasiya, Sushma Khatri, Kamal K Sethi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: It truly is an intelligent solution that minimizes the pesticide uses on the crop while maximizing the crop yield that is how the world is moving towards developments in sustainable agriculture. Traditional spraying methods generate two major problems concerning overuse of chemicals, environmental pollution, and labor efficiency. Recent investigations have delved into IoT-enable pesticide spraying robots which automate field operations [1] [4] and are capable of real time monitoring and increased spraying accuracy. It appears feasible with all these systems involved; scalability, connectivity, and adaptability become limiting factors in the wide array of agricultural environments. Also included are artificial intelligence systems able to do disease detection early enough combined with targeted pesticide application [5] [8]. This provides more accurate and autonomy-based operations. However, studies still remain specific on crops, consume not energy-efficient long-duration operate, and are still yet to achieve wide deployment. This research proposes the development of framework for autonomous and sustainable crop protection with IoT sensors, UAVs, and AI-driven multi-objective decision-making in a spraying system. The proposed framework depends on multi-sensor fusion, convolution neural networks for diseases identification, and reinforcement learning for adaptive spraying strategies. The system is designed to analyzes data in real-time and navigate an autonomous UAVs for precision pesticide applications while diminishing chemical wastes, costs, and environmental impacts. Saliently, these propositions is different from existing models in that it showcases scalability, cross-crop applications, and sustainability, thus being a strong solution for the next generation of precision agriculture.

title: Machine Learning Driven Predictive Model for Smart Tourism Development
authors: Pankaj Kumar Tyagi, Parikshit Sharma, Priya Sharma, Deepal Mehrotra, Priyanka Tyagi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The intelligent technologies have blistering developed, and the sphere of tourism has turned into a data ecosystem where the predictive analytics plays a central role in enhancing the experiences of a tourist and maintaining the destination. The paper presents an Adaptive Geo-Contextual Experience Optimization Network (AGCEON) is a sophisticated hybrid learning architecture that can be used in predicting tourism tendencies, optimization visitor flow, as well as customizing the travel experience by combining real-time data. The model combines both geospatial and behavioral and environmental data streams obtained through IoT sensors, social media, and historical data to illustrate the interaction changes between travelers and destinations. AGCEON uses a Dual-Stream Attention Fusion system, where a Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (T-GCN) is used to analyze temporal mobility on the spatial level, and Transformer-based Context Encoder is used to forecast temporal context intent. Reinforcement layer is an additional layer that ensures the optimization of suggestions and policy decisions provided by the constant feedback, which is provided in user satisfaction and sustainability indicators. The experimental verification process on the basis of various tourism data shows that the system offered is much more predictive, flexible and environmentalconscious than the traditional models. The framework is also providing valuable guidance to smart city planners and tourism business operators and regulators so that they can effectively utilize resources and enhance the participation of the traveler. Overall, AGCEON offers a long-term and intelligent move towards the creation of the data-driven smart tourism ecosystem. The overall accuracy of the proposed AGCEON model was at 96.1 percent to predict performance.

title: On the Digital Law Development Issue in the Strengthening Ukrainian Civil Society Context: Moral and Ethical Aspects
authors: Serhii Danylo, Vitalii Naida, Valerii Sokurenko, Oleksandr Muzychuk, Andrii Iashchenko, Serhii Vladov, Oksana Vakun, Mykola Stetsko, Vasyl Sprinsyan
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The article substantiates the importance of taking into account the digital law development’s moral and ethical aspects in the strengthening of civil society and formulates promising directions for improving the Ukrainian civil society institutions activities, which are based on the digital culture formation, the family institution development, and paying more attention to moral, ethical, and worldview issues in the organizing process of the civil society institutions activities.

title: Zero Trust Meets AI: A Survey Across Multi-Cloud and Hybrid Environments
authors: Abdullah Abdulrahman Albuali
publish: 2025 IEEE Twelfth International Conference on Communications and Networking (ComNet)
abstract: The rapid shift toward multi-cloud and hybrid infrastructures has fundamentally reshaped enterprise architectures, rendering perimeter-based security models insufficient against today’s dynamic and distributed threat landscape. In response, Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) has emerged as a strategic security framework, grounded in the principle of “never trust, always verify.” This paper presents a systematic analysis of ZTA frameworks tailored for cloud-native environments, with a focus on the transformative role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in enhancing policy enforcement, anomaly detection, and trust evaluation. By mapping key developments in federated identity, workload-centric access control, and adaptive policy orchestration, we identify critical challenges such as cross-cloud policy synchronization, explainability gaps, and runtime enforcement blind spots. We make a clear claim: AI is the practical way to run Zero Trust in real multi-cloud systems. This paper moves from foundations, to a simple taxonomy, to a layered AI based design, so that engineers leave with a plan and researchers leave with a focused agenda.

title: A Trust-Enabled Edge-Assisted Depth-Based Protocol for Reliable and Secure Data Transmission in Underwater IoT
authors: S Sivsakthiselvan, S Pavithra, Karthic Sundaram, Han Yi Chiew, K Rama Abirami
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: The Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT) enables critical applications such as ocean monitoring, seismic prediction, and defense operations. However, underwater acoustic communication faces unique challenges, including limited bandwidth, high latency, energy constraints, and frequent link disruptions. These factors, coupled with the absence of robust trust mechanisms, make IoUT networks highly vulnerable to malicious attacks such as packet dropping, false data injection, and energy depletion, which degrade reliability and network lifetime. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a Trust-Enabled Edge-Assisted Depth-Based Protocol (TE-EA-DBP) for secure and reliable data transmission in IoUT. The protocol incorporates a trust evaluation model to detect and isolate untrustworthy nodes based on forwarding behavior, reliability, and residual energy. To reduce the computational load on constrained nodes, edge-assisted processing is employed for trust assessment and Cluster Head (CH) election. Furthermore, a depth-based CH selection strategy balances energy consumption and ensures stable routing paths. Simulation results show that TE-EA-DBP achieves higher packet delivery ratio, energy efficiency, and resilience to adversarial behavior compared with existing protocols, offering a scalable and dependable solution for underwater communication.

title: A Unified View of Multimodal Emotion Recognition Systems
authors: Nallanagula Subhashini, Baby Vadlana, Karnam Akhil
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In recent times, there has been a rapid growth of mental health issues among individuals worldwide. A growing proportion of the population is facing difficulties with emotional instability, depression, psychological strain and many more. These can be solved only by providing a supportive response to the user. In the early days, there was only processing of text-based requests, but as time changed, multiple modalities, such as audio and video, were also being accepted as user requests. The responses are also generated according to the input taken from the user. This paper surveys the advancements in text, audio and video emotions recognition which focusing on deep learning models, attention mechanisms and multimodal fusion techniques. Pre-trained models are used to demonstrate superior performance across multiple benchmark datasets. Despite the advancements, challenges remain in real-time deployment, like data imbalance, cross-model alignment and scenarios. Research Challenges, Future enhancements are illustrated to enhance and propose optimal model in the area of multimodal Natural Language Processing(NLP).

title: Automated Quantification of Hydrocephalus-Related Imaging Indices Using a Segmentation Model
authors: Yu Hsuan Lin, Fu Ren Xiao
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: This study presents a novel approach to quantify various imaging biomarkers related to hydrocephalus using advanced algorithms, which aim to automatically measure radiological indicators of hydrocephalus. We implemented calculations of key metrics, including the Evans ratio, Third ventricle width, Cella media index, Huckman’s index and Bicaudate index, utilizing IXI open datasets of MRI scans, and brain CT images from Neurosurgery Intensive Care Unit(NICU) patients at National Taiwan University Hospital. Our approach addresses the the inaccuracies of visual inspection and reduces the time required for measurement. To ensure the reliability and accuracy of our methods, We randomly selected 24 cases from all the images and gave them to five professionals for manual measurement as the gold standard for subsequent comparison. Our findings indicate a strong correlation between automated and manual methods, highlighting the potential of our algorithm in clinical settings for the assessment of hydrocephalus. This work not only contributes to the understanding of hydrocephalus imaging biomarkers but also demonstrates the efficacy of AI in enhancing diagnostic accuracy in medical imaging.

title: Apply Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in Virtual Reality (VR) Systems: Integrating Multisensory Feedback Technologies with Real-Time Facial Recognition of Emotions
authors: K. Banupriya, S. Varalakshmi, Maram Y. Al-Safarini, D. Kirubakaran, K. Srinija, R. Ruth Shobitha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The intersection between AI and Immersive is redefining how people are interacting with digital systems. The use of Virtual Reality (VR) environments is becoming more common in applications such as healthcare, education, entertainment and training that aim to simulate the reality. However, the degree of personalization and interactivity of VR systems is a bottleneck. In this paper, we investigate the incorporation of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for real-time facial emotion recognition in VR context and incorporate multisensory feedback to enhance the user immersion and emotional understanding as well as overall experience realism. CNNs achieved relatively high performance in extracting and classifying facial features, in particular in emotion recognition from large scaled databases. In this paper, we propose a real-time user emotion (joy, anger, surprise, sadness, and neutrality) sensing CNN model for facial recognition. The model is designed for computational efficiency facilitating easy integration into Head-Mounted-Displays (HMD) based VR systems comprising of motion tracking systems. The simulation results show that the developed CNNbased emotion recognition model can achieve>90% accuracy in real-time inference, with latency under the critical thresholds for VR's native application. User studies also prove that emotion- based feedback increases immersion, empathy and task performance, with special attention to therapeutic and training simulations. This work is part of a novel paradigm in VR development: emotional adaptivity, by combining cutting edge computer vision and ASR with sensory feedback dep'09. The presented architecture forms the base of user-/emotionaware VR experiences. It creates new opportunities in affective computing, neurorehabilitation, virtual social interaction, and adaptive learning systems. In the end, the fusion of CNN-based emotion recognition into multisensory VR environments makes the digital interaction becomes richer and humanized, and the new era of intelligent and flexible immersive systems has also been being opened.

title: LC-BERT: Dimensionality Reduction on BERT’s Vector Embeddings
authors: Andri Darnius, Taufik Fuadi Abidin, Hammam Riza
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: This work aims to raise the performance of sophisticated artificial intelligence models such as BERT by means of dimension reduction approaches. The BERT model calls for a lot of memory and processing capability to train given its millions of parameters. Based on BERT as a foundation, the approach uses whitening or sphering techniques as a dimension reduction method at the feature extraction stage. Along with a standard benchmark using the original BERT, a modified scenario is introduced that includes BERT feature extraction and whitening methods such as PCA-Whitening, ZCA-Whitening, and Bert whitening is clasified using Bi-LSTM and MLP. With four topic classes, the AG News dataset—which consists of news headlines and descriptions—forms the main center of attention for the research. Based on the results, modified scenario—which combines BERT features, BERT whitening, and a Bi-LSTM classifier performs best in terms of accuracy, F1 score, training time, and GPU memory usage. These results indicate that by means of whitening dimension reduction, text classification efficiency can be raised without sacrificing accuracy. By means of dimension reduction and parameter optimization, this work aims to improve the performance of complex models such as BERT, thereby enhancing artificial intelligence applications in resource-constrained environments.

title: Joint Punctuation Restoration and Text Capitalisation with a Hybrid XLM-RoBERTa—LSTM Model
authors: Volodymyr Shymkovych, Grzegorz Nowakowski, Sergii Telenyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Punctuation restoration is a common postprocessing task in text generation and automatic speech recognition systems. It is crucial for enhancing the readability and interpretability of transcribed text for human users. Recent state-of-the-art approaches tackle this problem using various deep learning architectures, with transformer-based models demonstrating particularly strong performance. In this work, we propose a hybrid model that combines transformer architectures with long short-term memory (LSTM) layers, leveraging both global attention mechanisms and sequential dependencies. The model is trained on the IWSLT 2012 dataset and achieves results comparable to current state-of-the-art systems. Its performance is summarised by the following metrics: accuracy -0.96, precision -0.93, recall -0.92, and F1-score 0.92. Our findings suggest that punctuation restoration serves as a valuable auxiliary task, enhancing structural understanding of text and contributing to more robust natural language representations.

title: Edge-Enhanced Encoder-Decoder Framework for ALS Detection in Abdominal LCTIs with Deep Liver Localization
authors: S. Gopinath, B Reddy, Jaspreet Sidhu, S. Raja Shree, Syed Ahmed Wajih, Preeti Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The proposed Edge-Strengthening Parallel UNet (ESP-UNet) is a high-end encoder-decoder deep learning model capable of Automatically Segmenting the Liver (ALS) in LCTIs (Abdominal Liver CT Images) and is offered in this paper. The method suggested acts as a combination of a dual-path UNet model with the use of a Kirsch edge detection filter as means of improving the silhouette of the liver boundary. The ESP-UNet takes full advantage of the two parallel UNet networks, which, respectively, accomplish liver and edge-oriented boundary segmentation, and significantly reduces the issue of under segmentation and over-segmentation that nexuses the conventional ALS designs. On the LiTS data set, the model has been tested and has shown to have superior segmentation scores compared to those provided in the means. In particular, the proposed ESP-Unet achieved a DSC (Dice Similarity Coefficient) of 0.959, JI (Jaccard Index) of 0.921, a VOE (Volume Overlap Error) of 0.039 and RVD (Relative Volume Difference) of 0.09. The above results show that the model can effectively deal with complex LCTIs with higher boundary accuracy and is a dependable form of clinical liver image analysis and diagnosis.

title: Particle Swarm-Optimized ANFIS for Medical Decision Support: A Case Study in Type 2 Diabetes
authors: Peleh Oleg, Joanna Chwał, Arkadiusz Banasik, Radosław Dzik, Ewaryst Tkacz
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This study presents an intelligent classification system for the diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) based on an Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) optimized with Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The method addresses common limitations of ANFIS related to parameter initialization by automatically tuning the number of clusters, membership function type, and training epochs. The system is evaluated on the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset using the full clinical features and a reduced set based on correlation analysis. Experimental results show that the PSO-optimized ANFIS achieves an accuracy of 81.0% and an AUC of 0.87 using only four features, outperforming the full model in terms of generalization, interpretability, and computational efficiency.

title: Privacy-Preserving Student Success Prediction Using a Federated Weighted Ensemble Under Non-IID Data
authors: Anjani Kumar, Raj Sinha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In the educational sector, data-based analytics has enabled appropriate forecasting and predicting of student success, creating deep concerns about data privacy and security. Traditional machine learning practices involve centralizing data collection, which is often infeasible because of privacy laws and limitations imposed by institutions. The authors propose a privacy-preserving federated weighted ensemble (FWE) strategy to predict student performance using distributed and heterogeneous datasets. In this approach, raw student data lives on the local machines, without sharing or disclosing, ensuring privacy, with model updates enhancing global training. Each local client (an institution) trains a local ensemble of a Logistic Regression and Random Forest machine learning model to account for linear and non-linear relationships in the data. Unlike traditional Federated Averaging (FedAvg) methods, their method adopts a data-aware weighting strategy for aggregation based on client dataset size and class balance, increasing robustness to the performance impacts of non-iid distributions on client data. The proposed framework is evaluated on a real-world student data set comprised of demographic, academic, and skills-based features across countries. The results suggest that the aggregate or global accuracy for the FWE is 98%, with a reasonable balance between low- and high-CGPA predictions. The ROC-AUC score is significantly above the threshold of 0.97, highlighting strong discrimination ability and resilience to heterogeneity. It demonstrates that the proposed framework not only maintains student data privacy, but also significantly improves predictive performance compared to FL baseline methods. Thus, the proposed framework is a scalable and privacy-preserving solution to educational analytics, allowing data collaborators to work together without compromise. In future work, we will further extend the ensemble with deep learning components, adaptive trust-based weighting, and to implement in a real-world federated infrastructure for large and scalable educational decision making.

title: TRUST-X: Real-Time Explainable Decision-Making Framework for Reinforcement Learning-Based UAV Control
authors: Hanzala Akbar, Inayat Arshad, Satwat Rahman, Fatima Aamir, Marrium Fatima, Haroon Ur Rashid Khan
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) UAVs track progress in advanced environments above ≥90% during the most challenging stages of their assignments related to search and rescue and monitoring. Still, operational trust toward autonomous systems remains low, resulting in unnecessary commands which lowers the success of the mission. To solve this problem, we present the framework TRUST-X which combines real-time explainable surrogate decision trees, SHAP-lite, contrastive explanations, and dynamic trust modeling within a looping feedback system. In simulations, TRUST-X provided interpretable insights that increased operator trust by ≥28% and decreased number of interventions by ≥37% at the same time maintaining ≥94% success rate of the mission. This surpasses the traditional DRL baselines by ≥15%. Results prove that TRUST-X increases visibility and improves the safety of human-drone operations. These are highly relevant for TRUST-X and its purpose to better support explainable human autonomous system collaborations.

title: Digital Twin-Based Smart Metering Framework with Real-Time Monitoring via Microsoft Azure IoT
authors: Muhammad Tuaha Bin Zaheen, Raja Shahmir Arshad, Asma Noor Ul Ain, Abdullah Naeem Sarwar, Muhammad Hasan Danish Khan
abstract: This paper presents a Digital Twin (DT)-based framework for smart metering systems using Microsoft Azure Digital Twins, Azure Functions, and IoT Hub to enable real-time monitoring and analysis. Through digital twin technology, physical smart meters are virtually represented to facilitate continuous data collection, modeling, and analysis. The system allows real-time energy tracking, proactive fault detection, and performance analysis through IoT and cloud computing. Azure Functions automate data processing, while Azure IoT Hub ensures secure device connectivity and bidirectional communication with TLS encryption. Local preprocessing on Raspberry Pi reduces latency and cloud dependency, improving reliability. Azure Stream Analytics and Azure Blob Storage are used for detecting data trends, fault analysis, and long-term storage. Finally, a 3D Digital Twin of the smart meter is developed in Azure Digital Twins, continuously updated via IoT Hub to produce real-time visualizations and telemetry charts. The cloud dashboard enables users to remotely track energy consumption, detect faults, and analyze patterns for effective decision-making and energy optimization.

title: Enhancing LoRaWAN Simulator for Real-World Integration and Research Experimentation
authors: Miriana Russo, Corrado Santoro, Federico Fausto Santoro, Alessio Tudisco
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: The original LWN Simulator provided a user-friendly, web-based environment for designing and evaluating LoRaWAN networks, supporting real-time interaction with virtual and real gateways, comprehensive device class simulation, and integration with production network servers. Building on this foundation, the new version introduces a transformative headless mode, enabling the simulator to operate without a graphical user interface and making it ideal for automated laboratory experiments and large-scale, reproducible research workflows. This release features a powerful API for dynamic control of node attributes, such as movement, position, and radio parameters, during simulation runtime. The simulator now supports both LoRaWAN and raw LoRa communication, with multi-frequency capabilities contributed by the open-source community, allowing experiments across diverse ISM bands. A key advancement is the digital twin framework, which enables seamless interaction between simulated nodes and real gateways, bridging virtual and physical networks for hybrid experimentation and deployment validation. These enhancements position the new LWN Simulator as a versatile and scalable tool for both academic research and industrial development, fostering innovation in LPWAN network design and testing.
