title: Optimized Blockchain Protocols for Double-Spending Mitigation Using Lightweight Cryptography
authors: Prashant Chourasiya, Gayathri, Anup Singh Negi, A. Samatha, Ritu Ahluwalia, Yasha Dubey
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study introduces a light time blockchain framework to address double-spend and 51% attacks in Proof-of-Work (PoW)-based IoT systems. The solution uses two algorithms in its design, DETCA and RNSA. The protocol uses two criteria-the least time taken by miners and the lowest number of operations-to select nodes, thereby reducing all the extra work. RNSA randomly picks <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\frac{\mathbf{3}}{\mathbf{4}}$</tex> of the nodes needed to verify blocks which greatly decreases the chances of attacks. Each simulation was done using node numbers between 10 and 175. The results demonstrate that mining time is 5.9 sec and verification time is 3.3 sec which is better when compared to previous PoW methods. Moreover, since no bad behavior was identified, double-spending and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1 \%}$</tex> attacks were prevented. Resulting from the framework is greater scalability and less energy spent, along with high security, showing that it is suited for independent, IoT technology systems.

title: WIP: Faculty Mentoring Experiences in an Evolving NSF S-Stem Project
authors: Debarati Basu, Sydney A. Cash, Omar Ochoa
abstract: In this research-to-practice WIP paper, we present experiences of the faculty mentors involved in our NSF-funded SSTEM project. This project aims to provide financial scholarship support to 25 domestic, low-income, high-achieving students who demonstrate financial need at our private university. This scholarship will enable students to pursue four-year bachelor's degrees in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or Computer Engineering, followed by a one-year accelerated master's degree in one of the following areas: Software Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, or Computer Science. We leverage evidence-based practices to foster student success and increase retention and degree attainment. Throughout the project, scholars receive continuous advising, mentoring, and academic monitoring to support their progress and success. This support comes in various forms, with faculty mentoring playing a central role. In this project, scholars are organized into cohorts based on their degree programs, with each cohort assigned a dedicated faculty mentor for the entirety of their college years. Our project currently includes five mentors, each of whom regularly meets with their cohort. Upon completing the first year of the project, we conducted IRB-approved semistructured interviews with faculty mentors. We then conducted a descriptive content analysis of the interview transcripts to identify key themes in their mentoring experiences. This paper presents the initial findings, highlighting both the challenges mentors encountered and the benefits they observed. These early insights offer a foundational understanding of how mentoring contributes to the project's success and may inform similar programs. Future work includes continued evaluation and refinement of the mentoring component.

title: An Efficient FPGA System for Hypersparse Feed Forward Networks for Chip Memory Mapping
authors: S. Kumaran, Indumathi. G. S, Padma Rapur, R.C. Thivyarathi, Bharathi Dhasan. D, Kaviyarasan P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: For highly broad and deep models, dense floating-point computing and off-chip DRAM consumption on existing GPU and CPU-GPU platforms result in substantial index overheads (sometimes exceeding 99%) and latency bottlenecks, making it difficult to deploy hypersparse feed-forward networks (FFNs) economically. Existing techniques highlighted sparse attention aimed at combined FFN-attention optimizations; these keep index structures bloated and memory-intensive. The above shortcomings are solved by the proposed FPGA-centric system that compresses indices using hybrid CSR encodings, quantizes with 4-8 bits, and maps all data to on-chip BRAM/URAM. The proposed system prevents repeated DRAM access, diminishes index dominance, and maintains performance across multiple concurrent sparse computation engines. The proposed technique for deploying hypersparse FFNs improves CPU performance by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \times$</tex>, GPU performance by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times$</tex>, and energy efficiency by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \times$</tex> while decreasing LUT/FF/DSP usage. However, it comes at the cost of greater BRAM consumption.

title: Cost Prediction Model of Power Transmission and Transformation Project Based on Improved PSO and LSSVM
authors: Hailing Jia, Song Guo, Xiaobo Huo, Xiuying Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of insufficient accuracy of the cost prediction of power transmission and transformation projects (PTTP) in the current power grid construction, this paper proposes a model based on improved particle swarm optimization and least squares support vector machine (IPSO-LSSVM). Firstly, the key factors affecting the cost of PTTP are systematically sorted out from the three dimensions of project scale, technical parameters and external environment, and the corresponding eigenvectors are constructed as model inputs. In the model construction, the nonlinear inertia weight adjustment mechanism is introduced, which effectively improves the global exploration ability of PSO, and then optimizes the parameters in LSSVM to enhance the prediction accuracy. The actual data of 40 110kV PTTP in a region from 2015 to 2024 show that the proposed IPSO-LSSVM model performs well in both the training and the test sets. The root mean square error of the test set is 333500 yuan, the average absolute percentage error is only 4.17%, and the determination coefficient reaches 0.9029. All performance indicators are significantly better than the comparison model, showing the effectiveness of the model in capturing the complex nonlinear characteristics of the cost, and providing a scientific and reliable prediction tool for the cost management of PTTP.

title: Ethical Considerations in Artificial Intelligence: A Curricular Approach for STEM Disciplines
authors: Qiping Zhang, Elizabeth Milonas, Duo Li
abstract: This research full paper explores the critical role of AI ethics in STEM education, emphasizing the need to equip students with both technical expertise and ethical responsibility. As AI rapidly advances, it brings transformative opportunities and ethical challenges across STEM fields. Using a content analysis of AI ethics-related courses offered on platforms like Coursera and EdX, the study examines course descriptions, topics, and evaluation methods to identify best practices in AI ethics education. Findings highlight a framework that incorporates case studies, active learning techniques, flipped classrooms, peer instruction, and project-based learning to foster critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and interdisciplinary engagement. The framework emphasizes core AI ethics principles such as fairness, transparency, accountability, and responsibility, advocating their integration into STEM curricula. Embedding these ethical discussions helps students develop a holistic understanding of AI's societal impacts and prepares them to address complex ethical challenges in real-world contexts. By providing practical recommendations for educators, this study supports the enhancement of STEM education through the integration of ethical considerations into technical training. Preparing students with AI ethics knowledge ensures that future technological advancements align with societal values and promote human wellbeing.

title: UAV-Assisted Real-Time Disaster Detection Using Optimized Transformer Model
authors: Branislava Jankovic, Sabina Jangirova, Waseem Ullah, Latif U. Khan, Mohsen Guizani
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Dangerous surroundings and difficult-to-reach landscapes introduce significant complications for adequate disaster management and recuperation. These problems can be solved by engaging unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) provided with embedded platforms and optical sensors. In this work, we focus on enabling onboard aerial image processing to ensure proper and real-time disaster detection. Such a setting usually causes challenges due to the limited hardware resources of UAVs. However, privacy, connectivity, and latency issues can be avoided. We suggest a UAV-assisted edge framework for disaster detection, leveraging our proposed model optimized for onboard real-time aerial image classification. The optimization of the model is achieved using post-training quantization techniques. To address the limited number of disaster cases in existing benchmark datasets and therefore ensure real-world adoption of our model, we construct a novel dataset, DisasterEye, featuring disaster scenes captured by UAVs and individuals on-site. Experimental results reveal the efficacy of our model, reaching high accuracy with lowered inference latency and memory use on both traditional machines and resource-limited devices. This shows that the scalability and adaptability of our method make it a powerful solution for real-time disaster management on resource-constrained UAV platforms.The code and DisasterEye dataset are available at: https://github.com/Branislava98/TensorRT.

title: Handwriting Biometrics for Parkinson’s Disease Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Kaab Mohammed Arzoo, Aiman Darakhshan, Fahrettin Ugur Altun, Ali Gohar, Raja Hashim Ali, Umme Rabab Syed
abstract: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a progressive neurological illness that could severely compromise an individual’s physical motor skills. Early diagnosis is a key opportunity for onset management and planning for quality of life management. Our original research questions envisioned both handwriting and speech features as a signal for early detection of PD. However, this portion of the study was focused on PD detection based on spiral images of handwriting, which were classified using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The model was trained on grayscale images of spiral drawings, provided to the model after preprocessing and resizing to a standard dimension. Grad-CAM was implemented to develop interpretable heatmaps, showing relevant areas of the spiral images that were considered when concluding. The final CNN model was able to reliably classify PD from control subjects based on handwriting characteristics. Speech signal features were investigated but did not feature as part of this implementation. This research demonstrates that handwriting analysis with deep learning computes a non-invasive, interpretable approach for screening for Parkinson’s Disease at low cost, with multimodal extensions envisaged in future work.

title: AI-assisted Intent-Mapping and translation for Digital Twins Network applications
authors: Pasquale Pace, Gianluca Aloi, Antonio Iera, Angelo Mendicelli, Paola Guarasci, Domenico Laurito
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: The aim of this work is to delve into an issue that is becoming strategic in the perspective of an effective management of future networks, namely the automatic mapping of user and network “intents” into a set of Key Value Indicators (KVI) and Key Performance Indicators (KPI) that measure the achievement of a specific goal. In particular, an effective method is proposed for an automatic translation of intents supported by artificial intelligence techniques based on large language models (LLM). Through a specific software platform, users are enabled to specify their intents in a natural or formal language, resulting in set of best-fit KVI, KPI and functional attributes to be satisfied by the QoS manager of a Digital Twin Networks (DTN). The followed approach ensures that intent-based network management can rapidly scale from simple and standardized deployments to highly customized expert-level configurations, while maintaining consistency and reliability.

title: Challenges and Opportunities in Quantum-Enhanced XAI for Medical and Healthcare Systems
authors: Raffaele Cecere, Alessandro Santopaolo, Giuseppe Felice Russo, Francesco Iodice, Vincenzo Schiano Di Cola
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Quantum technologies and explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) present an exciting avenue for improving operating workflows, customizing therapies, and improving diagnostics. Quantumenhanced XAI has the potential to revolutionize healthcare systems and medicine, making it an important field for research. These developments allow doctors to make data-driven choices, eventually improving patient outcomes and raising the standard of care. The authors have focused their essays on these topics to spark insightful conversations and promote more research into the possible uses, difficulties, and future directions of hybrid quantum systems and XAI. The authors’ focus on Quantum-Enhanced XAI is to stimulate a discussion that offers fresh viewpoints and ideas, especially concerning developing methodologies, improving current approaches, and investigating creative applications in cutting-edge fields. Lastly, the authors provide suggestions for further study and useful advice for scholars and practitioners working in the medical and healthcare fields.

title: Lightweight Monocular Depth Estimation and D3QN-based Obstacle Avoidance for UAV
authors: Shao-Hung Cheng, Kai-Hung Lin, Jhen-Deng Syu
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: With the increasing demand for autonomous unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), enhancing their perception and navigation is a key research priority. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines optical flow with the Pix2Pix generative model to improve monocular depth estimation accuracy. Incorporating the lightweight MobileNetV3 architecture further enhances performance by reducing processing latency, enabling real-time depth perception. For obstacle avoidance, a dueling double deep Q-Network (D3QN) is implemented in the AirSim environment, allowing efficient trajectory planning. By integrating these two key strategies, this work aims to provide a robust and comprehensive autonomous flight solution, equipping UAVs with enhanced adaptability and decision-making capabilities in complex environments.

title: An Agentic Reasoning-Based Feedback System for Programming Assignments
authors: Nor Anis Asma Sulaiman, Hazlina Haron, Nurshazwani Muhamad Mahfuz, Nurul Azlia Mat Saat, Siti Norbaya Daud, Syazwina Alias
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: This study introduces Explain-then-Grade, an automated feedback framework designed for programming lab assignments using agent reasoning and large language models (LLMs). Unlike conventional auto-graders, which provide marks directly and general feedback, the proposed framework requires the agent to explain detected errors prior to assigning marks, thereby enhancing pedagogical value and transparency. The framework integrates sandboxed execution, on-the-fly test generation, and structured, stepwise explanatory reasoning, ensuring that students receive constructive, rubric-aligned feedback. To evaluate its effectiveness, the system was applied to anonymized submissions from a Data Mining module and complemented with open-source student code repositories. Performance was benchmarked against classic unit test-based auto-graders and LLM-only grading models, using five dimensions: grading accuracy, explanation quality, error coverage, and efficiency. Results demonstrate that Explain-then-Grade achieved higher grading reliability ($93 \%$ accuracy, $\kappa=0.85$), superior explanation quality (4.4/5), broader error coverage ($83.7 \%$), and substantial time savings ($67 \%$). These outcomes highlight its potential to support both traditional and open and distance learning (ODL) contexts by shifting automated assessment from mere evaluation toward formative, feedback-driven learning. The study establishes a structured agentic reasoning pipeline for reproducible and pedagogically aligned automated grading.

title: A Complex-Valued Rotational Chaotic Map with Zynq-Based Hardware Implementation
authors: Xintong Li, Fenhua Bai, Ruibo Li, Xiaosong Li, Yinxing Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: Due to the existence of complex variables and parameters, complex-valued chaotic maps can exhibit much richer dynamical behaviors than real-valued counterparts. However, most existing chaotic maps focus on the real domain, while studies on complex-valued chaotic maps remain relatively underexplored. In light of this, this brief proposes a two-dimensional complex-valued rotational chaotic (2D-CRC) map. Theoretical analysis reveals that the 2D-CRC map exhibits chaotic behavior in terms of Lyapunov exponents. Property analysis shows that the 2D-CRC map exhibits rich dynamical behaviors, notably an inherent rotational property. Furthermore, a Zynq-based hardware implementation is employed to demonstrate the practical realizability of the generated strange attractors.

title: MTxLSTM: Multi-Task Learning for Gesture Recognition and Person Identification using a Miniature Radar Sensor
authors: Fei Luo, Anna Li, Zhao Huang, Kaishun Wu, Bin Jiang, Ziqing Sun, Lu Wang
abstract: Radar-based gesture recognition and person identification offer a natural, convenient, and privacy-preserving approach to human-computer interaction. However, most existing research focuses predominantly on learning for a single task, which requires separate models for each task. This separation increases the complexity of the deployment and the computational overhead. To address these challenges, this study introduces a multi-task learning framework that simultaneously performs gesture recognition and person identification using a miniature radar sensor. By leveraging radar's capacity to capture finegrained spectral and spatial motion patterns, the framework incorporates micro-Doppler and range-Doppler processing, alongside a multi-branch architecture to enhance modality-specific feature representation. It enables unified learning of shared and task-specific features within a single network architecture. The proposed model, MTxLSTM, integrates CNN and the recent xLSTM to mitigate task interference, improve generalization, and improve gesture recognition through person-specific nuances while enhancing person identification by leveraging contextual gesture information. Experimental results reveal that MTxLSTM outperforms existing multi-task learning frameworks and stateof- the-art models, achieving 99.21% in gesture recognition and 98.59% in person identification with moderate model complexity and inference speed. This study concurrently executes gesture recognition and person identification using a miniature radar sensor, and marking the first application of xLSTM in radar sensing technology.

title: Fostering Practical Skills in Computer Networks with IoT-Centric Project-Based Learning
authors: Khairul Mottakin, Zheng Song, Khalid Kattan
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper presents an innovative project-based learning (PBL) module designed to teach computer networks through the lens of Internet of Things (IoT) applications. As IoT continues to reshape technology and society, computer networks education must evolve to provide students with both practical skills and real-world insights. Traditional teaching methods often struggle to offer the hands-on experience and contextual understanding necessary to meet these demands. To address this gap, we developed a PBL module centered around IoT projects to enhance student learning outcomes in a computer networks course. The module aims to teach students: 1) modern applicationlayer protocols commonly used in IoT environments; 2) foundational IoT concepts, including IoT devices and the performance requirements of IoT applications; 3) practical skills in building and debugging network applications on IoT devices, covering topics such as IP addressing, private and public networks, network debugging tools, Raspberry Pi operations, and sensors with GPIO ports; and 4) problem-solving and collaboration skills through the design and implementation of IoT projects. Spanning four weeks, the module combines lectures, guided tutorials, and team-based projects culminating in a hands-on IoT application. The module was implemented in a senior-level Computer Networks course with 47 students in Fall 2024. A mixedmethods evaluation, including student reflections and instructor observations, revealed significant improvements in students' understanding of networking concepts and their ability to apply them in IoT contexts. Furthermore, student feedback highlighted the importance of real-world relevance and teamwork in enhancing their learning experience. These findings provide valuable insights for designing PBL modules that effectively bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application in computer science education.

title: Robust Adaptive PID Control Based on a Modified Nussbaum Function for Robots Exposed to Significant Changes in Dynamics
authors: Jeongwoo Son, Hyunah Kang, Murim Kim, Junyoung Lee, Sang Hoon Kang
abstract: Proportional-integral-derivative (PID) equipp-ed controllers are widely used in industrial robots potentially facing substantial payload and environmental variations. Their widespread use may impede the implementation of advanced robust control methods. This study presents a robust adaptive PID control algorithm that is model-independent, simple, and suitable for deployment on commercial PID-equipped devices. The proposed adaptive PID control is based on a modified version of adaptive time-delay control employing modified Nussbaum functions to ensure stability under substantial variations of robot and environment dynamics, and includes straightforward gain drift prevention schemes. The performance of the proposed adaptive PID control was experimentally evaluated with other PID controls and advanced model-independent control, showing enhanced robustness and no gain drift. These results demonstrate the potential of the proposed PID control for immediate deployment in industrial robots with a PID-equipped controller.

title: YOLOv11 based algorithm for abandoned luggage detection with dynamic radius estimation
authors: Ivan Vrsalovic, Marina Ivasic-Kos, Miran Pobar, Jonatan Lerga
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: We address the challenge of abandoned luggage detection by adapting a YOLOv11 model and validating it on the IITP20 dataset. Our methodology involves optimizing our pre-trained YOLOv11 model for the domain adaptation to specific characteristics of the IITP20 dataset. Our initial analysis revealed significant semantic inconsistencies within the dataset’s annotations; a large portion of “abandoned” luggage instances were simply items in lockers or storage areas, which do not constitute security threats. To create a more realistic benchmark, we systematically corrected these inaccuracies. A comparative analysis reveals that our person and baggage detection model, along with the proposed algorithm, achieves state-of-the-art results, demonstrating exceptional performance in scenarios relevant to security surveillance. These findings underscore the robustness of our detection approach and emphasize the importance of high-quality, semantically accurate annotations for developing reliable abandoned object detection systems in real-world applications.

title: Mobile UI/UX Energy Efficiency Profiling: A Comparative Analysis of Dark and Light Modes
authors: Muhammad Faheem Mohd Ezani, Muhammad Huzaifah Ismail, Nor Hafeizah Hassan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of mobile UI/UX design patterns on energy and performance efficiency by systematically analyzing layout rendering times and CPU utilization under different visual configurations. An automated profiling framework was developed using bash shell scripting integrated within the Android Studio IDE, leveraging ADB utilities such as top, logcat, and dumpsys for data collection. Controlled user scenarios, executed via Espresso automation, simulated browsing and selection activities in a custom Android e-Commerce simulation application under Dark Mode and Light Mode settings. Frame rendering durations and CPU usage were captured across multiple iterations to evaluate processing demands. Results indicate minimal differences, with CPU utilization averaging 31.0% in Dark Mode vs. 31.4% in Light Mode, and rendering times differing by less than 10 ms between configurations., suggesting that UI theme selection alone does not significantly influence runtime efficiency. These findings highlight the need for deeper optimization strategies beyond visual configurations in the pursuit of sustainable mobile application development.

title: Analysis of Students' Patterns and Prediction Using edX Data and Learning Analytics
authors: Pedro Manuel Moreno-Marcos, María Sanz-Gómez, Pedro J. Muñoz-Merino, Carlos Alario-Hoyos, Iria Estévez-Ayres, Carlos Delgado Kloos
abstract: This research category full paper provides new insights into the impact of specific transitions (i.e. patterns) between the different activities (session start, video, forum, problems, and pass/fail) when learners engage with Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs). Many previous contributions have computed variables related to learners' engagement with the materials, but transitions between activities might also provide meaningful information. In this line, this work aims to analyze learners' patterns in an edX MOOC about Java Programming to discover which patterns are more frequent, their variations over time and depending on the learner's performance and their relationships with the final grade. Results show that sessions often start with videos and learners who pass are more likely to show patterns including use of the forums, and their last interaction is often with a problem. Conversely, learners who fail mostly drop out after interacting with videos. Moreover, patterns show that many learners who fail do not interact with the course in the first week. Furthermore, the most correlated patterns with grades are the transitions video-problem, problem-problem, and problemvideo, and these patterns by themselves can achieve a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 0.131 when predicting grades, which shows the potential of considering these patterns when analyzing student models.

title: Development of a LiDAR-based 3D Scanner Using a Plane Mirror Base for Improved Scanning Coverage and ICP-based Pose graph SLAM Optimization
authors: Adrian Neville T. Soquita, Patricia C. Babayo, Engr. Flordeliza L. Valiente
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a LiDAR-based 3D scanning system designed to improve scanning coverage for small objects through the integration of a plane mirror base. Traditional LiDAR scanners often face limitations in capturing complete surface geometry due to restricted fields of view and blind spots. The proposed system utilizes a reflective mirror base to reflect laser beams toward otherwise unobservable areas, thereby enhancing data acquisition without additional mechanical complexity. The captured point clouds are further refined using an Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm combined with pose graph optimization to ensure accurate alignment and reconstruction. Experimental results demonstrate up to 143% improvement compared to conventional fixed-position LiDAR setups. These results validate the effectiveness of a mirror-based scanner along with the incorporation of SLAM. This offers an adaptable solution for high-accuracy 3D scanning of small objects in controlled environments.

title: Unsupervised Sensitivity Prior Generation With Diffusion Model for EIT Image Reconstruction_supp1-3642293.pdf
authors: Qi Wang
abstract: The supervised deep learning methods for electrical impedance tomography (EIT) remains limited by hand-crafted and domain-specific instructions during training. The existing unsupervised solvers for EIT trade attention to the image domain with ignorance to physical natures in the electrical field. In this article, we propose an unsupervised conditional diffusion model, referred to as SPfusion, for inhomogeneous sensitivity prior generation, which is utilized as the system matrix to solve EIT inverse problem. The conditional diffusion model first undergoes coarse training to ensure stable generation, followed by a dedicated fine training to sharpen detailed fidelity. In SPfusion, we propose a novel dual-domain denoising network, named dual-domain sensitivity prior network, that introduces the dual-domain Cartesian-based and polar-based coordinates dual-domain Transformer to efficiently capture multiscale latent representations. In addition, the decoder with U-conditional cross-attention is proposed to fully preserve dual-domain long-range dependencies. SPfusion achieves accurate noise estimation, high-fidelity detail generation of the inhomogeneous sensitivity prior, as well as high-quality image reconstructions based on model-driven methods. Experiments conducted on simulation data, real-world measurements, and publicly available benchmark demonstrate that SPfusion outperforms supervised/unsupervised and previous diffusion-based methods in terms of reconstruction accuracy and stability. The project and further information are available online.

title: Applying Improved Symbiotic Organisms Search Algorithm to solve Non-Convex Economic Environment Dispatch Problems
authors: Thang Phan Van Hong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Environmental protection has become a critical issue in modern times. As fossil energy resources dwindle, it is more important than ever to ensure environmental sustainability alongside economic efficiency. Managing fuel costs and emissions is vital for enhancing and maintaining the profitability of power plants. This paper introduces the Improved Symbiotic Organisms Search Algorithm (ISOSA) as a solution to economic environment dispatch (EED) challenges, which involve optimizing load distribution, power generation limits, and fuel constraints. ISOSA has been tested on two systems (10 and 40 generators). The analysis covers both single and multi-objective functions for each test system. Results from these tests have been compared to other methods in the literature, indicating that ISOSA is a promising new method for addressing economic environment dispatch issues.

title: Décor-AR: AR Shopping Application for Interior Design Using Immersive Intelligence
authors: M Jahnavi, Impana P, Mangalraj. P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Augmented Reality is reshaping the way people pursue interior design and shopping by allowing them to visualize their furniture, home appliances, and décor items directly in their actual spaces. Utilizing the capabilities of AR and mobile technology, we present DecorAR - an immersive and intuitive AR application that is designed to help users become better and more confident choices while shopping. Using Unity and ARCore, our system enables users to place, move, rotate, and scale multiple 3D models in their real environments using horizontal plane detection. DecorAR deals with a standard user concerns such as inaccurate spatial estimation, choosing the right size, and ensuring the design suits their space. The app was tested with different types of objects in the real-world indoor spaces. Results showed significant improvements in space organization, increased accuracy in product placement, and higher satisfaction levels. By blending AR visualization with user-friendly controls and multiobject interaction capabilities, our system provides a convenient, flexible and immersive solution to improve the home shopping experience.

title: Fuzzing OPC UA with AFLNet, ChatAFL and LibAFLstar: A Research Experience Paper
authors: Marcello Maugeri, Cristian Daniele, Federico Fausto Santoro
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: OPC UA (IEC 62541) is a protocol used in industrial control systems and building automations. The protocol is intrinsically stateful. In fact, it involves session handshakes, secure channels, and subscriptions. Its statefulness makes standard (stateless) fuzzers inefficient in finding bugs that rely deeply on the state model. In this paper, we present our practical experience in fuzzing the OPC UA protocol using three stateful fuzzers, namely AFLNet, ChatAFL, and LibAFLstar. For each fuzzer, we explain how to prepare the harness, collect the inputs, and run them. We compare the fuzzers on four different metrics: setup complexity, edge coverage, execution throughput, and time to find the first bug. Moreover, we present the steps to add a new case study (FreeOpcUA) to ProFuzzBench, a benchmarking framework widely used to compare the effectiveness of stateful fuzzers. Our experiments show that AFLNet is the easiest to configure, achieving solid coverage and fastest bug discovery. ChatAFL slightly improves coverage using LLM-expanded seeds with similar integration effort. LibAFLstar, while requiring the most setup effort, achieves the highest throughput across three tested configurations, but paradoxically the worst performance. In fact, we found that higher throughput does not translate into better bug finding and coverage without properly handling protocol complexities like sequence numbers. This experience paper presents the challenges, limitations, and performance trade-offs of each fuzzer, providing actionable guidance for researchers and practitioners seeking to apply stateful fuzzing to complex industrial protocols.

title: A Semi-Supervised Meta-Negative-Learning Approach to Few-Shot Network Intrusion Detection in Internet of Things
authors: Minyue Wu, Ying Zheng, Yin Yang, Jiachao Luo, David Shan-Hill Wong
abstract: The dynamic evolution of Internet of Things (IoT) threats necessitates reliable network intrusion detection (NID) systems. Such systems should not only respond to known security risks but also adapt effectively to emerging threats. However, practical deployments in novel IoT environments often suffer from significant data scarcity. In these cases, only a few labeled samples are available for training, which typically leads to poor performance. To address this challenge, we introduce a Semi-supervised Meta-negatIve-LEarning approach, termed SMILE, for few-shot network intrusion detection using network traffic data. Our approach begins by pretraining a baseline NID model with historical attack data, followed by an improved negative learning strategy with uncertainty-aware pseudo-negative labels. Bagging sampling is further incorporated to dynamically balance pseudo-labeled data distributions and enhance tolerance to labeling errors. SMILE enables effective knowledge transfer from historical attacks to few-shot traffic streams. Experimental results on the CICIDS-2017 dataset demonstrate that SMILE significantly improves detection accuracy by 7.30%–16.65% across diverse classifier architectures in both 5-shot and 10-shot scenarios, achieving a peak accuracy of 81.91%. Additional validation on the Edge-IIoT and IoT-23 datasets shows consistent improvements of 9.38% and 4.78%, reaching respective accuracies of 96.25% and 84.08% under 10-shot detection.

title: Centrality-Guided GCNs for Detecting Communities in Time-Varying Heterogeneous Graphs
authors: Shyam R, Sanjeev Kumar, S. Ramya, Frederick Sidney Correa, P. Sardar Maran, Vijayalakshmi P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: To better find community in heterogeneous and dynamic networks, a new model, namely RW-HeCo, is presented, which uses network centrality measures together with random walks and graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Conventional methods tend to use meta-path-based neighbour aggregate, where all the paths are considered. Not every metapath connection is importantly related to community structure, though. To overcome this inefficiency, RW-HeCo incorporates centrality-based filtering in the process and thus promotes structural importance of nodes and edges. On top of the random walks which already give stochastic traversal-based information, co-contrastive learning is used to further distinguish signal (meaningful node interactions) and noise. Such a combination enables the model to oftently represent the semantic, temporal, and structural properties of heterogeneous graphs. Its effectiveness is thoroughly evaluated on four benchmark datasets, namely ACM, AMiner, DBLP and Freebase, and the method shows its superiority in both tie strength prediction and community detection in assessment with the SOTA methods. Thanks to the priority given to node significance and the centrality-based improvements, the RWHeCo can advance the precision of community identification aside from leading to a better understanding of network evolution. It is thus very useful in dynamic large-scale network systems, e.g., social media, citation graph and knowledge graphs, where structural insight and community borders are critical. The offered system outperformed various approaches with the maximum NMI of 70.6% and Micro-F1 score of 72.1% on the BlogCatalog dataset. It clearly outdid GCN, GAT and Label Propagation.

title: Thermal Management of Lithium-ion Battery Module with Forced Air and Conditioned Air Convection and its Impact on Cell Aging
authors: Nagaraju Napa, Manish Kumar Agrawal, Bhaskar Tamma
abstract: Lithium-ion cells are extensively used in Electric Vehicles (EVs) and renewable energy storage systems due to their high energy density and specific power. However, their thermal sensitivity necessitates effective thermal management to ensure safety, performance, and extended cycle life. This study presents a 2D thermal model developed using MATLAB, which employs the transient heat diffusion equation with internal heat generation to simulate thermal behavior of Lithium-ion cells. The model is validated against experimental data at 0.5C and 1C discharge rates and incorporates forced convection using air to regulate temperatures across discharge rates from 0.5C to 2C and coolant velocities from 1 to 5 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$m/s$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Coolant with 1 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$m/s$</tex-math></inline-formula> and 25 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>C kept <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T_{max}$</tex-math></inline-formula> <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula> 40 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>C and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta T$</tex-math></inline-formula> <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula> 3 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>C for 1C. The study is extended to a 10-cell battery module subjected to dynamic drive cycles and monthly ambient temperature variations. Further, analysis is performed to estimate capacity loss of battery module and impact of different cooling methods on aging. Capacity fade analysis reveals that under natural convection, the module achieves a cycle life of approximately 1000 cycles. In contrast, with conditioned air cooling, the cycle life exceeds 2200 cycles due to significantly lower average cell temperatures and reduced thermal stress. These insights support the development of efficient thermal management systems to enhance battery durability in real-world conditions.

title: Special Session: Space Teams Academy Transforming STEM Education Through Virtual Space Exploration
authors: Jasleen Kaur, Fernando Arias, Elise Koock, Gregory E Chamitoff
abstract: Space Teams Academy (STA) aims to provide an immer-sive, hands-on STEM education experience that fosters cre-ativity, teamwork, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills, while also expanding access to higher education materials. Aligned with its mission to inspire and activate the next generation of leaders in space and STEM, STA creates a dynamic platform and ecosystem that empowers students to engage with real-world engineering challenges. Space Teams Academy is an ESSA Level 4 certified program, that's used like flight simulation software made for students to learn various space science topics and the importance of engineering and iterative design. By designing spacecraft, planning interplanetary trajectories, and solving real-world challenges like planetary exploration, remote sensing, and resource uti-lization, students learn to iterate on designs and think like engineers. This directly supports FIE's mission to showcase and promote innovative ideas and emerging trends in engineering and computing education, with STA exemplifying such innovation. Additionally, the program aligns with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) by integrating core sci-entific concepts with engineering practices, promoting inquiry-based learning, and reinforcing the iterative design process. By inspiring young minds through engaging, space-related STEM activities, STA helps cultivate a skilled workforce prepared for future careers in science, technology, and engineering. It also supports FIE's commitment to advancing best practices and pedagogical approaches that make STEM education more accessible, effective, and impactful. This special session will showcase how the STA program works and how it can be implemented in classrooms, camps, and informal learning settings to promote STEM engagement and learning outcomes. Attendees will gain firsthand experience with the STA software and learn how to adapt the platform for a variety of educational environments and learning goals.

title: WIP: Do Metadiscursive Riffs Harmonize Lecture Delivery?
authors: Chang Kyoung Choi, Aneet D Narendranath, Radheshyam Tewari
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative practice category paper presents a proof-of-concept of an evaluation and feedback method focused on instructors' classroom discourse by analyzing both metadiscourse markers (MDMs) and verb-noun (VN) combinations. MDMs, categorized as organizational, interpretive, and epistemic functions, provide insights into how instructors organize discourse, facilitate knowledge-building, and manage uncertainty within classroom discussions, as well as its impact on student cognitive processing, meaning negotiation, and engagement. VN structures, such as ‘analyze data’ or ‘construct explanations,’ indicate the cognitive demands expected from students, helping instructors assess alignment with intended learning objectives. Using a custom Python function leveraging natural language processing, VN pairs are extracted to reveal patterns aligned with frameworks such as Bloom's Taxonomy and to support integration with classroom observation protocols like Classroom Observation Protocol for Undergraduate STEM (COPUS) and the Classroom Discourse Observation Protocol (CDOP). In addition to VN analysis, by tracking the frequency and function of MDMs, we examine how instructional language fosters coherence, engagement, and epistemic positioning in STEM education. This complementary analysis enables a holistic view of teaching effectiveness by integrating both action-based linguistic structures and discourse organization strategies. Tracking both the frequency and nature of these action phrases and discourse markers enables instructors to reflect on the alignment between their teaching practices and intended learning objectives. Preliminary analysis suggests variation across instructors in their discursive stance and cognitive expectations, offering potential for enhanced instructional self-reflection.

title: WIP: Feeling Behind in an Introductory Programming Course
authors: Katherine A. Panciera, Ronald J. Nowling
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper describes analysis of a midterm survey for a first-year university Introduction to Programming class at a small, primarily undergraduate engineering university in the midwestern United States. Over 40% of students reported feeling behind at some point during the first eight weeks of the course, but they utilized resources and continued to engage in the classroom. Our recommendations include follow-up surveying to better understand causes of stress for students, collecting assignment submission data to validate behindness, and exploring curricular changes to reduce the number of students who fall behind.

title: “ChatGPT Should be Used as a Tool, But Not Mistaken for a Crutch”: Engineering Students' Ethical Perspectives After Using GenAI in an Introductory Course
authors: Campbell R. Bego, Deborah A. Trytten, Joshua C. Nwokeji
abstract: Engineering students can use generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) in ways that support their learning, but they can also use GenAI to complete entire assignments, thereby circumventing their learning. While local and global standards evolve, it is important for instructors to specify when and how to use GenAI tools appropriately, and to support and measure students' acquisitions of knowledge, competence, and ethical dispositions towards GenAI tools. This study investigated student perspectives on ethical uses of GenAI for schoolwork, following the discussion and integration of GenAI into an introduction to engineering course. The integration included a student-led discussion around GenAI following an engineering ethics lecture, and guided GenAI use in a final course programming assignment. The research question was as follows: What are first-year engineering students' opinions on the ethics of GenAI after instruction on GenAI and instruction on engineering ethics? At the end of the semester, students responded to essay-style questions about appropriate and inappropriate uses of GenAI tools within engineering school. Responses were coded inductively with three researchers using qualitative thematic analysis. Results revealed that students knew that completing entire assignments with GenAI was academically dishonest and presents a threat to both their learning and professional competence. Students also acknowledged that, when used as a tool, GenAI could improve their work product. Beyond these consistencies, there were also many different opinions about ethics, demonstrating a need for instructors to set clear expectations. Course integrations of GenAI appear to be powerful teaching opportunities to help students learn about GenAI and engage in meaningful ethical reflections around using GenAI tools for coursework and their future careers.

title: Real-Time Generation of Near Minimum-Energy Trajectories via Constraint-Informed Residual Learning: A Paradigm for Learning From Optimal Solutions_supp1-3642672.mp4
authors: Domenico Dona'
abstract: Industrial robotics demands significant energy to operate, making energy-reduction methodologies increasingly important. Strategies for planning minimum-energy trajectories typically involve solving nonlinear optimal control problems (OCPs), which rarely cope with real-time (RT) requirements. In this article, we propose a paradigm for generating near minimum-energy trajectories for manipulators by learning from optimal solutions. Our paradigm leverages a residual learning approach, which embeds boundary conditions (BCs) while focusing on learning only the adjustments needed to steer a standard solution to an optimal one. Compared to a computationally expensive OCP-based planner, our paradigm achieves 87.3% of the performance near the training dataset and 50.8% far from the dataset, while being two to three orders-of-magnitude faster.

title: osmAG-LLM: Zero-Shot Open-Vocabulary Object Navigation via Semantic Maps and Large Language Models Reasoning_supp1-3653280.mp4
authors: Fujing Xie
abstract: Recent open-vocabulary robot mapping methods enrich dense geometric maps with pre-trained visual-language features, achieving a high level of detail and guiding robots to find objects specified by open-vocabulary language queries. While the issue of scalability for such approaches has received some attention, another fundamental problem is that high-detail object mapping quickly becomes outdated, as objects get moved around a lot. In this work, we develop a mapping and navigation system for object-goal navigation that, from the ground up, considers the possibilities that a queried object can have moved, or may not be mapped at all. Instead of striving for high-fidelity mapping detail, we consider that the main purpose of a map is to provide environment grounding and context, which we combine with the semantic priors of LLMs to reason about object locations and deploy an active, online approach to navigate to the objects. Through simulated and real-world experiments we find that our approach tends to have higher retrieval success at shorter path lengths for static objects and by far outperforms prior approaches in cases of dynamic or unmapped object queries.

title: Self-Supervised Unfolding Network with Shared Reflectance Learning for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Jia Liu, Yu Luo, Guanghui Yue, Jie Ling, Liang Liao, Chia-Wen Lin, Guangtao Zhai, Wei Zhou
abstract: Recently, incorporating Retinex theory with unfolding networks has attracted increasing attention in the low-light image enhancement field. However, existing methods have two limitations, i.e., ignoring the modeling of the physical prior of Retinex theory and relying on a large amount of paired data. To advance this field, we propose a novel self-supervised unfolding network, named S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>UNet, for the LIE task. Specifically, we formulate a novel optimization model based on the principle that content-consistent images under different illumination should share the same reflectance. The model simultaneously decomposes two illumination-different images into a shared reflectance component and two independent illumination components. Due to the absence of the normal-light image, we process the low-light image with gamma correction to create the illumination-different image pair. Then, we translate this model into a multi-stage unfolding network, in which each stage alternately optimizes the shared reflectance component and the respective illumination components of the two images. During progressive multi-stage optimization, the network inherently encodes the reflectance consistency prior by jointly estimating an optimal reflectance across varying illumination conditions. Finally, considering the presence of noise in low-light images and to suppress noise amplification, we propose a self-supervised denoising mechanism. Extensive experiments on nine benchmark datasets demonstrate that our proposed S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>UNet outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised methods in terms of both quantitative metrics and visual quality, while achieving competitive performance compared to supervised methods. The source code will be available at https: //github.com/J-Liu-DL/S2UNet.

title: A Composite Remote Sensing based Agricultural Drought Monitoring Index Using Stacked Machine Learning
authors: Sana Arshad, Safwan Mohammed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: This research aimed to develop and validate a new Remote Sensing based Composite Drought Index (CDI) from meteorological and agricultural drought indices in a cloud computing platform of Google Earth Engine. The Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI) was calculated over a 23-year (2001 – 2023) in a semiarid region of Pakistan. Subsequently, the Composite Drought Index (CDI) was computed and compared with the SPEI to validate its performance. Advanced stacked machine learning methodology was adopted training and optimizing six base models (Random Forest, Extra Trees Regression, Multilayer Perceptron, Nu Support Vector Regression, Extreme Gradient Boosting, and Light GBM). In the second layer, a meta model, Stochastic Gradient Boosting, was trained from the input predictions of the base layer, achieving the highest training accuracy of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.907 and RMSE = 0.298. The SHAP kernel explainer proved the highest contribution of CDI in predicting SPEI. The newly developed CDI can be recommended for spatiotemporal droughts assessment at a regional scale in Pakistan.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Conventional and Temperature-Corrected Performance Ratios for a 100 MW Utility-Scale PV System – A Case Study of Pakistan
authors: Mohsin Atta, Sardar Taimoor Ali Khan, Akhlaq Ahmad, Samaira Zahoor, Aman Ullah, Shehzad Ahmad
abstract: The Quaid-e-Azam Solar Power Plant (QASPP), located in Bahawalpur, is the first large-scale, grid-connected, ground-mounted, fixed-tilt photovoltaic (PV) system with a solar capacity of 100 MW. The Performance Ratio (PR) is one of the key measures of a PV system’s efficiency in converting solar irradiance into usable AC electricity. To measure the impact of atmospheric temperature on the performance of the system, this paper assesses the conventional and temperature-adjusted PR of the plant using PVsyst software. Real operational data are obtained from the SCADA system and weather stations of the power plant for the year 2023, while the corresponding simulated data are generated using SolarGIS inputs in PVsyst software. To ascertain deviations in PR based on temperature, a monthly comparison of actual and simulated results is performed. The results indicate that ambient temperature greatly affects the effectiveness of the plants, which increases PR in winter and reduces PR in summer. Temperature correction gives a better realistic simulation of how PV plants can operate in local climatic conditions. The findings will help in designing, operating, and maintaining strategies of the large-scale solar plants in hot areas, i.e., Southern Punjab, Pakistan.

title: A LightGBM-Transformer Hybrid Model for Traffic Flow Prediction Using Temporal Features
authors: Fawad Ahmad, Khurram S. Khattak, Sheheryar Ahmad, Zawar Hussain Khan
abstract: Accurate traffic flow prediction is critical for intelligent transportation systems. This paper proposes hybrid models that integrate lightGBM with transformer-based architectures to improve forecasting using temporal features. The PeMS-08 dataset (approximately 100,000 records,5-minute intervals, July– August 2016) is employed for evaluation. Standalone lightGBM, transformer, and triformer models are first benchmarked. In the hybrid design, lightGBM captures feature-level temporal patterns, while transformer architectures refine sequential dependencies. Experimental results show that both hybrid models significantly outperform transformer and triformer baselines. The lightGBM+triformer hybrid achieves performance comparable to standalone lightGBM, with lower Weighted Absolute Percentage Error (WAPE), indicating improved robustness and reduced forecast bias. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining gradient boosting and transformer-based architectures for traffic flow prediction. The proposed framework contributes to more accurate and reliable traffic forecasting, supporting real-time management and sustainable urban mobility planning.

title: Comparative Lexicon-Based Sentiment Analysis Towards Indonesian ’Cek Kesehatan Gratis’ Program in X
authors: Fatur Rozak, Oja Widiyatama, Andri Fachrur Rozie, Ekasari Nugraheni, Dian Kurniasari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Sentiment analysis aims to understand a person's perspective or attitude toward a particular topic. One of its main challenges is the labeling approach, especially in the context of the Indonesian language. This study evaluates six labeling approaches: manual labeling, InSet Lexicon, modified InSet Lexicon, VADER, VADER-Translate, and SentIL. Each approach classifies data into three categories: positive, neutral, and negative. The dataset consists of 8,393 posts from the X application related to the Free Health Check Program. Three models were used for the evaluation process: Support Vector Machine (SVM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and IndoBERT. The results show that the combination of the modified InSet Lexicon and IndoBERT produced the best performance, achieving an accuracy of 94.04%, precision of 93.29%, recall of 93.47%, and an F1-score of 93.31%. These findings highlight the importance of selecting lexicon-based methods that align with the study domain and the linguistic characteristics of the data to improve the accuracy and reliability of sentiment analysis in public policy.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Predicting Solutions to Nonlinear Differential Equations
authors: Vinayak kishan Nirmale, Kalpana Devarajan, C. Ruby Sharmila, A.K. Bhuvaneswari, S. Meher Taj, G. Nandini
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Efficiently and reliably solving nonlinear differential equations continues to be a core barrier in science and engineering, since conventional analytical and numerical techniques can often be costly in computation time, become nonconvergent under severe conditions, or are difficult to adapt to a novel problem. This work proposes a machine learning framework that proposes approximate solutions by learning the underlying functional relationships directly from observational data. First, the work frames nonlinear dynamics in a larger mathematical framework and systematically considers the implicit limitations of classical methods, such as direct and iterative finite difference schemes, finite element methods, and transcendent Runge-Kutta methods. Second, it considers recent advancements in data-driven modeling approaches with a focus on fully-connected neural networks (FNN), support vector regression (SVR), and physics-informed (PINN) methods, all which are promising approaches to recovering the behavior of nonlinear systems. The last section integrates a deep multi-layer neural network with case-specific loss functions that capture the structure of the underlying differential equations and ensures that the learned representation is consistent with conservation and balance concepts. Finally, benchmark evaluations with synthetic and traditional datasets show that the new architecture outperforms the predictive accuracy and computation times of existing classical solvers and machine learning models. Ultimately, the framework offers robust performance across a broader range of nonlinear scenarios-including chaotic trajectories and cases with discontinuous coefficients. These findings demonstrate the power of hybrid approaches with AI and mathematical methods to tackle difficult scientific challenges. They represent a strong and early start to exploring deeper thoughts in scientific machine learning and symbolic regression, specific to systems characterized by nonlinear differential equations. The combination of classical numerical approaches and modern AI techniques will foster the progress of more powerful, larger scale, and also more interpretable algorithms for nonlinear differential systems.

title: A Serverless Quantization-as-a-Service Model to Run Compression Jobs for Edge Intelligence
authors: Danny De Novi, Pierluigi Dell’Acqua, Lorenzo Carnevale, Maria Fazio, Massimo Villari
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Edge computing’s rise demands efficient compression strategies for deploying Machine Learning (ML) models on resource-constrained devices. As Artificial Intelligence (AI) shifts from cloud to edge, optimizing models across heterogeneous layers is crucial. Quantization reduces numerical precision, improving model size, inference speed and energy efficiency, key for edge deployments. However, its complexity limits accessibility. To address this, we propose Quantization-as-a-Service (QaaS), a serverless framework that automates model quantization for both cloud and edge environments. Built on OpenFaaS and Kubernetes, QaaS enables on-demand execution with dynamic resource orchestration, implementing Layer 5 of Edge Intelligence (EI). Our evaluation compares quantization performance on edge devices in terms of CPU usage and execution time when performed as a service versus locally. Results demonstrate that deploying quantization workflows using Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) not only maintains computational efficiency but also reduces CPU consumption compared to standalone execution, showcasing the potential of serverless solutions in EI.

title: AI-Powered Fraud Detection in UPI and Digital Wallet Transactions Using Deep Learning Models
authors: Ebnezer, S. Mohan, S. Subalya, T. Jansi Rani
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The use of Unified Payments Interface (UPI) and electronic wallets has rapidly increased the number of transactions, raising the question of fraud. The proposed paper represents a deep learning framework based on Bi-LSTMs to detect fraud in financial transactions in real time. A very skewed dataset that consisted of 92.5 percent legitimate and 7.5 percent fraudulent transactions was used to test the system. The model recorded high performance with an accuracy of 91.8, F1-score 90.5 and PR-AUC of 0.94 compared to the traditional machine learning algorithms like the Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost. The confusion matrix analysis proved the ability of the framework to identify many fraudulent transactions and reduce the possibility of false positives, which is appropriate to use in operations. In addition, the latency of the inferences of 95 ms per transaction proved that the model can be used to detect fraud in high-volume digital payment systems in real-time. These results support the opportunity of deep learning-based solutions to increase the security of UPI transactions and improve the financial ecosystems.

title:
Bridging Theory and Practice: Insights from the Live-in-Labs
                    <sup>®</sup>
                    on Participatory Rural Appraisal and Human Centered Design
authors: Ambarish Narendran, Keerthi Prabu P, Anoop S., Adwaitha V, Yuvan Sundar S, Arya R Nair, Siva Surya S, Tonderai Manezhu, Souresh Cornet
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: A key issue in sustainable development in social communities is the absence of a structured pathway that links research and its industrial needs. As part of the Live-in-Labs® project, a workshop, field visit, and a case study have been conducted to learn, familiarize, and apply with human-centered design (HCD) and participatory rural appraisal (PRA)-based analysis. The test case considered in this is the university campus premises with a minimal area that can be covered in a short period. The field visit was conducted in Mohlai, Durg district, Chhattisgarh, and the insights gathered from the visit are presented in this paper. This paper aims to bridge the gap between the theoretical and practical implementation of the HCD and PRA tools by examining, briefing, and proposing a structural combination of tools. The paper contributes to a growing body of work that supports bridging the theory-practice divide. Ultimately, it reinforces the relevance of context-sensitive methodologies in creating inclusive and sustainable development outcomes. This study focuses on key thematic areas and aims to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through participatory development.

title: Resilience Measurement of Green Agricultural Supply Chain under the Background of Rural Revitalization
authors: Yang Hu, Yongjun Shen, Aiman Magde Abdallah Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Developing green agriculture is an important way to revitalize rural areas. To comprehensively promote rural revitalization, it is necessary to first optimize and upgrade the agricultural supply chain, and enhance the resilience of the green agricultural supply chain, which has profound significance for the high-quality development of the agriculture. The measurement of supply chain resilience is a practical tool for identifying the risk. Based on the analysis of the practical needs of supply chain resilience measurement, this paper constructs a resilience measurement index system for green agricultural supply chains in Hubei province, focusing on the four capabilities of risk resistance, emergency response, adaptation and recovery, and sustainable development. The entropy method is used to measure the resilience of green agricultural supply chains in Hubei province in the past five years, and combined with the analysis results of the model and the actual situation of green agriculture development in Hubei province, a path to improve the resilience of agricultural supply chains in Hubei province is proposed.

title: Construction of a Customer - Oriented Evaluation System Index Library for Logistics Service Quality Based on AHP
authors: Wei Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: With the rapid development of the logistics industry, consumers’ expectations for logistics service quality have continuously increased. Currently, enterprises face challenges in logistics service quality management, such as over-reliance on transportation quality and cost as primary indicators while neglecting customer needs. This paper aims to construct a customer-oriented evaluation index system for logistics enterprise service quality. Through literature research, six first-level indicators including Economy and Responsiveness and 34 second-level indicators are identified. The Analytic Hierarchy Process is applied to quantify indicator weights, and a judgment matrix with consistency testing is used to scientifically determine the weight allocation of core indicators, including Goods Intact Rate and Responsiveness Efficiency. The study concludes with applications and recommendations for selecting logistics service quality evaluation indicators from the consumer perspective, providing a data-driven framework for improving service quality and addressing customer-centric challenges in the logistics industry.
