title: AI-Based Book Classification Using Book Titles: Investigating Two-Stage NLP Approach
authors: Faisal Fahmi, Zulfatun Sofiyani, Hendro Margono, Endang Gunarti
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Assigning library classification codes improves shelving and browse-ability but remains time-consuming and inconsistent across institutions. This paper presents an AI-based method to predict Library of Congress Classification (LCC) classes and Subclasses from book titles only by using Project Gutenberg records. The study compares single- and two-stage prediction, where Stage-1 predicts the first letter of the LCC (A$\mathbf{Z})$ (e.g., $\mathbf{P}$ for Language and Literature) and Stage-2 ranks twoletter LCC classes (e.g., PR and PS) within that first-letter group. We benchmark a short-text baseline (TF-IDF with a logistic regression) against a fine-tuned transformer (DistilBERT) under author-grouped train/validation/test split sets. Experiments report Top-1/Top-3 accuracy and Macro-F1, analyze class imbalance under Full and Merge-Rare label schemes, and include a focused case study on adjacent two-letter LCC classes to characterize short-title confusions. Results show that title-only classification is feasible, where the single-stage DistilBERT model achieves the strongest Macro-F1 and the twostage variant improves the baseline (especially under the Full scheme) by reducing off-class errors, but decreases the effectiveness of DistilBERT. Besides, Top-3 suggestions support human cataloging when only titles are available.

title: Motion Magnification Analysis for rPPG
authors: Linas Saikevičius, Vidas Raudonis
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Recent advancements in camera technology have significantly improved the feasibility of image-based monitoring within healthcare contexts. Imaging photoplethysmography (iPPG) and remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) are non-invasive techniques for assessing vital physiological parameters, such as heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and blood pressure, without requiring direct physical contact. While iPPG employs conventional cameras to capture physiological variations, rPPG facilitates remote observation by detecting subtle skin colour changes associated with blood flow. Combining various rPPG methodologies, including colourbased, motion-based, multispectral, and depth-based approaches, can further enhance measurement accuracy and system robustness. In this report we used micro motion magnification analysis method.

title: Sky Classification Using CNNs for Meteorological Condition Detection
authors: Ludovica Beritelli, Roberta Avanzato, Omar Abdelaziz, Kevin Munda, Francesco Beritelli, Sebastiano Battiato
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Sky image classification under different meteorological conditions is crucial for numerous applications, including environmental monitoring and weather forecasting. In this work, we propose a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-based approach to classify sky images into four categories: “Day-clear”, “Day-cloudy”, “Nigh-clear”, and “Night-cloudy”. Several deep learning architectures were explored, and experimental results show that YOLOv11 achieved the best performance, with an accuracy exceeding 99%. Furthermore, potential future developments are discussed, such as the inclusion of rain as an additional meteorological condition to be classified. This study provides a solid foundation for improving image recognition technologies in meteorological contexts, with potential applications across various technological and scientific fields.

title: BASMEDSecure: A Logistic Regression-Based Data Hiding Framework for Securing Patient Records
authors: Basten Andika Salim, Dea Kristin Ginting, Ntivuguruzwa Jean De La Croix, Tohari Ahmad, Ayalew Belay Habtie, Md Sagar Hossen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Ensuring the confidentiality and integrity of sensitive patient records is a critical challenge in modern healthcare. Among various data security techniques, steganography, which conceals data within digital media, has emerged as a prominent solution. However, conventional methods often fail to achieve a sufficient balance between high data embedding capacity and the preservation of diagnostic image quality, limiting their practical use in clinical settings. To address this, this paper introduces BASMEDSecure, a novel data hiding framework that utilizes a logistic regression model to classify pixels based on their intensity levels. An adaptive embedding algorithm then utilizes this classification to dynamically adjust the number of secret data bits hidden within each pixel’s least significant bit. Experimental results demonstrate promising performance for the proposed BASMEDSecure, with a PSNR (expressing the quality of the stego image) ranging from 52.103 to 75.521 decibels (dB). The obtained SSIM value of 0.9999 highlights a close similarity between the cover and stego medical images, emphasizing the efficiency of BASMEDSecure in maintaining image integrity, which is crucial for accurate medical interpretations.

title: Enhancing Engagement and Learning in IT Courses: A Pedagogical Approach to Gamification
authors: Anum Masood
abstract: This paper provides a research-to-practice overview of how computer-based instruction (gamification tools, specifically Kahoot and Mentimeter) enhances student engagement, motivation, and learning outcomes in IT education. It explores theoretical foundations, implementation strategies, assessment methodologies, and key findings, offering practical insights for educators seeking to integrate gamification into their teaching practices. In recent years, the use of gamification in education has garnered significant attention for its potential to boost student engagement and improve learning outcomes. This study investigates the pedagogical impact of integrating gamification tools, specifically Mentimeter and other interactive platforms, to enhance student interaction in Information Technology (IT) courses. By adopting a pedagogically grounded approach, we explore how gamified activities can effectively promote active participation, encourage collaboration, and improve knowledge retention within computing education. Using a comprehensive literature review and practical insights, this research offers educators strategies for implementing gamification in alignment with instructional design principles and learning objectives. Furthermore, we examined the influence of gamification on student interest, motivation, and overall learning experience. Our findings highlight the importance of tailoring gamified activities to align with both student interests and core course topics. This study contributes to IT education by focusing on improving engagement and learning outcomes through interactive and gamified pedagogical methods.

title: Next-Generation Healthcare: a Secure and Voice-Driven App for Seamless Patient Engagement
authors: M. Gharbaoui, M. Moradi, A. Pacini, A. Giannoni, C. Passino, M. Emdin, S. Dalmiani, P. Marcheschi, L. Valcarenghi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The demand for continuous patients monitoring in healthcare has increased significantly, originated mainly from the need for proactive and personalized treatments. In fact, traditional periodical monitoring often fails to detect rapid physiological changes, resulting in a risk especially for patients with chronic conditions or post-surgical needs. This paper presents a voice-driven mobile health monitoring application that enables daily tracking of six health parameters, addressing the limitations of traditional periodic monitoring. Designed to cater to diverse environments, including rural and urban areas, the app ensures reliable functionality storing data locally and synchronizing with a centralized database once connectivity is available. The app integrates seamlessly with Bluetooth devices and $4 \mathrm{G} / 5 \mathrm{G}$ networks, offering scalability. It also relies on the QUIC protocol for a more secure data transmission and provides a voice recognition feature for an easy collection of health parameters thus further enhancing user experience and contributing to the growing field of mHealth.

title: Structure Design and Development of an Active Upper Limb Exoskeleton Robot for Homecare Rehabilitation
authors: Laily Asna Safira, Sumardi, Senopati Pamungkas Nagari, Farhan Bagus Rahmadika
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: This paper presents the design of an upper limb exoskeleton robot platform intended for hemiparesis rehabilitation purposes. Rehabilitation for patients with hemiparesis due to stroke is aimed at enhancing the efficiency of the recovery process through the assistance of active external power in repetitive movements that follow safe trajectories and Range of Motion (RoM) parameters. The exoskeleton is designed to perform movements with seven Degrees of Freedom (DoF), adjustable to the patient’s body dimensions. This study evaluates the performance of repetitive flexion-extension movements at the elbow joint, demonstrating that the exoskeleton can accurately follow the predefined trajectory. A motor current sensor is integrated into the electrical design to detect the presence of spasticity during rehabilitation sessions. With a feedback-based control system, the proposed exoskeleton platform shows potential for use as a homecare rehabilitation medium for patients with upper limb hemiparesis.

title: Enhancing Maritime Situational Awareness through Multimodal Fusion: Insights from a Real-World Experiment
authors: Kilian Wohlleben, Michael Hubner, Thanet Markchom, Jonathan Boyle, James Ferryman, Stephan Veigl, Andreas Opitz, Anastasios Gkamaris, Romeo Bratskas
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Effective maritime border surveillance is crucial. Challenges we face include irregular migration, smuggling, oil spills and the need for rapid search and rescue. Various sensing technologies, including AIS, SAR, optical and infrared sensors, as well as UAV-mounted sensors, clearly enhance maritime awareness. However, integrating their diverse outputs remains complex. Feature-level multi-modal sensor fusion is a well-known methodology for robust detection and behavior analysis. However, most research relies on simulations or isolated sensors, which limits practical insights. This study presents a controlled real-world experiment combining synchronized data from coastal ground sensors and UAVmounted visual and infrared sensors. The recorded dataset enables the evaluation of feature-level fusion in authentic conditions. We enhance existing fusion frameworks with additional modules and assess them using operational metrics. This study contributes to our understanding of the efficacy of multi-modal fusion in complex maritime environments, while also highlighting the significant challenges involved in transitioning from simulations to controlled real-world sensor data.

title: Artificial Intelligence Personalization: Opportunities, Risks, and the Need for Ethical Data Practices
authors: Aditi Rajendra Katare, Kenin Isaac, Jayapandian N, Geo T Jacob
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The benefits of AI personalization are numerous; however, the question still remains, what are the side effects of this feature? Will it help make shopping and enjoying content more enjoyable and efficient or will it destroy the trust of the users by creating privacy concerns. These are the issues this article has attempted to discuss and investigate. Artificial Intelligence (AI) personalization is a very helpful and useful feature, but there must remain a proper balance between personalization and data collection in order to ensure client comfort. A transparent and honest collection of data is to be expected for almost all the companies and this data is to be used responsibly. Activities like profiling must be regulated and controlled and should not be left unregulated. Despite laws being updated to be more considerate towards the privacy of users, the development of better enforcement is imperative. Regardless of the presence of appropriate laws, it is important that each individual practice the respective ethics while present in the digital universe. This article is discussed about AI personalization issues and its research challenges.

title: Sybil Attack Detection and Prevention Using Dynamic Trust Mechanism in VANETs
authors: Ashish Kumar Khare, Aradhana Saxena, Saurabh Suman, Ankita Shrivastava, Kamlesh Chandravanshi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: A Vehicular Ad Hoc Network is a set of mobile nodes forming a temporary multi-hop connection with the help of other vehicles and connected to roadside units (RSU) also. The absence of any authority from vehicle to vehicle invites many attackers that modify data, lose data, and degrade the utilization of resources. The vehicles are moving on roads with different velocities and may be possible to follow same direction or choose any other direction. Links between the vehicles are created and break in unpredictable way, which makes pretty challenging. The role of intermediate vehicles on route to forwards the traffic information to receiver. The sybil attack behaviour is a type of active attack that generates multiple identities (IDs) to gain the data from the network and drop it. The attacker node utilizes the network by spoofing the IP or MAC address, which is able to damage the complete network for personal gain. In this article the proposed sybil attack detection and protection using dynamic trust detection and prevention (SyDTDP) in VANET. The SyDTDP is focused on determining the packet loss caused by malicious activity. The article places more emphasis on malicious attacker node detection that is part of the route exploit and drops data in the communication, which decreases the overall performance of the network. The attacker's loss is more than the loss of a channel. The proposed SyDTDP detects attacker nodes and calculates the trust factor for each node, whether that node is an attacker or not. The result section compares the performance of Sybil attack detection using extreme machine learning (SyDVELM) with dynamic trust-based Sybil attack detection and prevention (SyDTDP) and gets the outcome in terms of packet receiving, number of packets captured during Sybil attacker and proposed methods, routing load, and average delay (ms). The results conclude that the proposed dynamic trust performs well in all network parameters as compared to existing security systems. The simulation of the network is done by Network Simulator 2 and deploys the VANET scenario of the attacker, SyDVELM, and the proposed SyDTDP.

title: WIP: Bias Beneath the Surface: AI-Driven Gender Representation Analysis in Academic Communications
authors: Kumara Srivatsa Kondapalli, Benny Nottonson, Devery Rodgers, Hossein Sayadi
abstract: In the digital era, the language used by educational institutions plays a critical role in shaping perceptions of equity and inclusion. Despite growing awareness, subtle gender biases remain embedded in academic communications, influencing representation and undermining equitable education, an issue that demands urgent attention. This research WIP paper presents a novel AI -driven framework to detect and analyze hidden gender bias in institutional communications, with a focus on textual content from academic websites. The framework integrates automated web scraping, sentiment analysis via a fine-tuned deep learning model, and targeted linguistic evaluations using predefined gender-associated term sets. Key metrics, including bias scores, gendered language prevalence, and representation ratios, are employed to assess disparities across institutional units. The analysis reveals measurable patterns of gender bias, offering a scalable and data-informed approach to support institutions in fostering more inclusive and balanced communications.

title: Exploring Need for Acheivement: A Machine Learning Approach for Enhancing Entrepreneurial Persistence
authors: Roohi Naaz, Bharti Ramtiyal Soni, Riya Sharma, Aditya Pai H, Tanya Rawal
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Machine learning algorithms facilitates in overcoming the traditional methods in terms of restricting modifications and manipulations, and maintain accuracy in data. The present study uses these algorithms to understand the relationship between need for achievement and entrepreneurial persistence of women entrepreneurs in Uttarakhand state. It aims to find out the positive and negative relation between motivation and persistence of females so as to frame the policies and schemes accordingly. Entrepreneurial persistence helps in maintaining long term sustainability of business ventures and as a result contributes to economic growth. In the present research, different machine learning tools have been employed for identification and analysis of predictive patterns formed between the observed variables. The results shows that need for achievement strongly predicts entrepreneurial persistence among women entrepreneurs in the state of Uttarakhand. This will enhance the procedure of policy formulation and implementation for growth of women accordingly. At large, by understanding such relationship and taking actions by way of policies and program modifications, the social and economic prosperity of the state and nation as a whole can be promised.

title: A Technological Leap in Malay Language Acquisition: Evaluating EasyMalay Application For Chinese Learners
authors: Nor Zakiah Gorment, Law Yi Feng, Mohamad NorTaufiq Norhashim, Faridah Hani Mohamed Salleh, Masyura Ahmad Faudzi, Low Loi Ming, Nazrita Ibrahim
abstract: Recently, the growing demand for Malay language proficiency among Chinese learners from mainland of China is significantly increased. However, the Chinese students are frequently struggled to learn Malay language. They have limited exposure to conventional learning experience, limited access to digital resources, and traditional teaching methods. Thus, the EasyMalay app, a mobile-assisted language learning (MALL) tool that uses gamified exercises, AI-driven feedback mechanisms, and interactive modules to help non-native learners. This study explores how technology such EasyMalay able to improvise the Malay language education in China. EasyMalay considerably enhances learners' vocabulary acquisition, according to phase 1 evaluation results. More learner autonomy and motivation are fostered by the app's adaptive learning features and real-time evaluation tools, which enhance academic performance and language proficiency. Additionally, combining speech recognition technology with culturally appropriate content improves communication and contextual awareness. The results in this study provide insights into future developments in Malay language pedagogy and support the wider adoption of EasyMalay in Chinese institutions and communities.

title: Locally Adapted Reference Frame Fields using Moving Least Squares_supp2-3634845.mp4
authors: Julio Rey Ramirez
abstract: The detection and analysis of features in fluid flow are important tasks in fluid mechanics and flow visualization. One recent class of methods to approach this problem is to first compute objective optimal reference frames, relative to which the input vector field becomes as steady as possible. However, existing methods either optimize locally over a fixed neighborhood, which might not match the extent of interesting features well, or perform global optimization, which is costly. We propose a novel objective method for the computation of optimal reference frames that automatically adapts to the flow field locally, without having to choose neighborhoods a priori. We enable adaptivity by formulating this problem as a moving least squares approximation, through which we determine a continuous field of reference frames. To incorporate fluid features into the computation of the reference frame field, we introduce the use of a scalar guidance field into the moving least squares approximation. The guidance field determines a curved manifold on which a regularly sampled input vector field becomes a set of irregularly spaced samples, which then forms the input to the moving least squares approximation. Although the guidance field can be any scalar field, by using a field that corresponds to flow features the resulting reference frame field will adapt accordingly. We show that using an FTLE field as the guidance field results in a reference frame field that adapts better to local features in the flow than prior work. However, our moving least squares framework is formulated in a very general way, and therefore other types of guidance fields could be used in the future to adapt to local fluid features.

title: Optimizing Marketing Strategies Through Cloud Computing and Intelligent Analytics
authors: Pankaj Kumar Tyagi, Priyanka Tyagi, S. Jegadeesan, Balakrishnan Ravishankar, Praveen Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The fast growth of digital ecosystems has created huge and complicated datasets that endanger the conventional marketing optimization approaches. As a solution to these issues in this paper, the author proposes the Adaptive Cloud-Driven Cognitive Insight Framework (ACCIF) - a sophisticated and smart system that is created to support better strategic marketing decisions based on real-time cloud integration and cognition analytics. The suggested framework integrates the multi-source marketing data such as consumer behavior, sentiment patterns, and market dynamics into a cognition architecture based on the cloud technology. Through neurosymbolic logic and the adaptive learning strategies, ACCIF actively optimizes the marketing knowledge according to the changing consumer scenarios and this is forecasted by predictive factors. The model is based on elastic cloud computing to support scalable computing to achieve continuous learning and quick deployment of models in distributed setting. Furthermore, there is a contextual inference module that the user preferences and cross-channel engagement intentions are latent and interpreted, which supports hyper-personalized hyper-targeted marketing therapies. Experimental approval through massive datasets shows a higher level of accuracy of response, adaptability, and ability to be cost effective in comparison to traditional analytics systems. The suggested framework offers a solid road to intelligent, data-driven marketing evolution, which guarantees higher agility, accuracy, and competitiveness of organizations that can be found in the swiftly developing digital markets. Finally, ACCIF converts raw marketing data to actionable, cognitive intelligence, which will be the merger between the computational efficiency and strategic cognition. The suggested ACCIF model attained an overall accuracy of 94.6%, exhibiting enhanced performance relative to current methodologies.

title: A Comparative Performance Analysis of Fuzzy Logic and Artificial Neural Network-Based MPPT Algorithms for Solar Photovoltaic Systems Under Rapidly Varying Weather Conditions
authors: Ahnaf Rashid
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: This study provides a comprehensive performance analysis and comparison of two prominent AI-based Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithms: Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN), under rapidly changing solar irradiance. The system, modeled in Simulink, consists of a solar photovoltaic (PV) array connected to a boost converter, which is controlled by the respective MPPT algorithms. The FLC employs a two-input, single-output rule-based system, while the ANN is a feedforward network trained on a large dataset of PV voltage and current measurements under varying conditions. Simulation results under dynamic irradiance profiles demonstrate that both controllers effectively track the maximum power point (MPP). However, the ANN-based MPPT consistently outperforms the FLC, exhibiting a faster transient response, reduced steady-state oscillations, and higher overall tracking efficiency. Specifically, the FLC shows pronounced undershoots and overshoots during abrupt irradiance changes, which lead to a notable decrease in efficiency and slower settling times. In contrast, the ANN recovers almost instantaneously with minimal fluctuations. The findings establish that the ANN-based approach offers superior dynamic performance and robustness, making it a more suitable intelligent control strategy for PV systems operating in environments with frequent and rapid weather fluctuations.

title: Optimizing Machine Learning Algorithms for Intrusion Detection: Towards Next-Generation Cyber-Security Solutions
authors: P. Rahul Das, T. Sampath Kumar, G. Kalyani
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The growing complexity of cyberattacks calls for advanced intrusion detection systems to spot and fight threats as they happen. Machine learning has become a key tool for enhancing IDS capabilities by identifying complex and novel attack patterns. This review looks at the significant advancements in machine learning for intrusion detection in the last five years. It focuses on supervised unsupervised and mixed learning models. The study looks at how deep learning setups and flexible systems can tackle changing cyber threats. Tests on standard datasets showed big gains in how fast threats are found and how well the system grows. It takes a hard look at ongoing issues like uneven data staying strong against attacks, and being clear about how it works. new ideas like team learning and AI that explains itself could lead to stronger and more open cybersecurity fixes.

title: Semantics-Preserving Dynamic Pruning for Split Inference in Log Anomaly Detection
authors: Hsin-Yun Hsu, Wanjiun Liao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Deep learning models are widely used to analyze large-scale data and detect abnormal behavior in practical systems. However, current token pruning approaches for inference acceleration face notable limitations: attention-based or threshold-based strategies risk discarding semantically important tokens, while methods that introduce additional training objectives increase optimization complexity. To address this problem, we propose SemPrune, a semantics-preserving token pruning method designed to reduce communication overhead in split inference architectures. SemPrune does not require labeled data for training. Instead, it learns a predictor to determine the optimal pruning ratio. SemPrune combines L2-norm-based importance scoring with a learned pruning ratio predictor trained by a semantics-preserving loss, enabling adaptive token retention while minimizing activation size. Experimental results across multiple log datasets show that SemPrune substantially reduces activation transmission to only 0.59%–1.75% of the original, while maintaining comparable accuracy with minimal F1 score degradation for anomaly detection.

title: Internal Audit of the Sales System: A Fuzzy-Multiple Approach
authors: Oksana Desyatnyuk, Oksana Chereshnyuk, Svitlana Sachenko, Halyna Liakhovych, Ruslan Brukhanskyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The article proposes a fuzzy-set approach to conducting an internal audit of an enterprise’s sales activities. In modern conditions of economic instability caused by military actions and global risks, traditional methods for assessing the vulnerability of sales processes are becoming less effective. An audit model based on fuzzy sets is proposed, which allows taking into account the subjective assessments of experts and incomplete information by using membership functions to assess the main risks: loss of sales markets, decline in demand, disruption of logistics, dependence on large customers, and instability of pricing policy. The paper uses a fuzzy Mamdani-type system with a rule base of 1023 rules and implementation in MATLAB using Gaussian membership functions. The constructed system allows auditors to increase the accuracy of researching the vulnerability of sales activities, optimize management decisions, and reduce risks under conditions of uncertainty.

title: FPG-NAS: FLOPs-Aware Gated Differentiable Neural Architecture Search for Efficient 6DoF Pose Estimation
authors: Nassim Ali Ousalah, Peyman Rostami, Anis Kacem, Enjie Ghorbel, Emmanuel Koumandakis, Djamila Aouada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: We introduce FPG-NAS, a FLOPs-aware Gated Differentiable Neural Architecture Search framework for efficient 6DoF object pose estimation. Estimating 3D rotation and translation from a single image has been widely investigated yet remains computationally demanding, limiting applicability in resource-constrained scenarios. FPG-NAS addresses this by proposing a specialized differentiable NAS approach for 6DoF pose estimation, featuring a task-specific search space and a differentiable gating mechanism that enables discrete multi-candidate operator selection, thus improving architectural diversity. Additionally, a FLOPs regularization term ensures a balanced trade-off between accuracy and efficiency. The framework explores a vast search space of approximately 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">92</sup> possible architectures. Experiments on the LINEMOD and SPEED+ datasets demonstrate that FPG-NAS-derived models outperform previous methods under strict FLOPs constraints. To the best of our knowledge, FPG-NAS is the first differentiable NAS framework specifically designed for 6DoF object pose estimation.

title: CompBench: Benchmarking and Comparing Image Generation with Large Multimodal Models
authors: Jiarui Wang, Huiyu Duan, Yuke Xing, Yiling Xu, Guangtao Zhai, Xiongkuo Min
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Recent advancements in large multimodal models (LMMs) have significantly enhanced both text-to-image (T2I) generation and image-to-text (I2T) interpretation. However, critical challenges in perceptual quality and text-image correspondence remain hindering the practicality of AI-generated images (AIGIs). Therefore, a reliable benchmark and automatic model for AIGI evaluation is desirable, which heavily relies on the scale and quality of human annotations. To this end, we present CompBench, the largest dataset for benchmarking and comparing image generation, which features: (i) the largest AIGI pair comparison dataset, comprising 616,346 carefully curated image pairs generated by 24 state-of-the-art AIGI models annotated with 1.6M+ human annotations, enabling robust relative quality assessment through pairwise comparison, (ii) multi-dimensional pairwise comparison from perceptual and text-image correspondence perspectives across three difficulty levels, and (iii) bidirectional benchmarking and evaluating for both T2I generation models and AIGI comparison models. Based on CompBench, we propose LMM4Comp, a LMM-based evaluation metric that learns nuanced quality distinctions from multiple dimensions for pairwise comparison at both instance level and model level. Experiments demonstrate that LMM4Comp achieves state-of-the-art performance, highly aligning to human preference. Both of the CompBench dataset and LMM4Comp metric will be released at https://github.com/IntMeGroup/CompBench.

title: Meet Your Mock Interviewer - MYMI: An AI Powered Mock Interview Simulation App
authors: Fasia Shahzad, Mariam Irfan Durrani, Muhammad Abdullah, Muhammad Ali
abstract: In the current job market, young graduates face challenges in technical interviews, despite having an extensive technical background, due to their limited communication ability and unfamiliarity with the standard interview methodology. The inability to communicate their technical expertise in an interview becomes a key factor of their failure. In order to bridge this gap, we propose Meet Your Mock Interviewer (MYMI), a web-based platform that aids aspiring software engineers prepare for technical interviews through AI-driven, voice-based simulations. The platform features an AI Interviewer that asks interview questions, listens to responses, and generates follow-up questions during the session. At the end of each interview session, a large language model evaluates the interviewee’s performance both in terms of coding performance and the ability to "think out loud", followed by a detailed feedback that can be tracked through a personalized dashboard with clear visual metrics. MYMI integrates LLM, and speech-to-text (STT) and text-tospeech (TTS) which powers the AI interviewer. MYMI features a code editor with a support for multiple languages, including Python, JavaScript, Java, and C++, allowing interviewees to practice in the coding language they are the most comfortable with. Combining AI evaluation and voice interactions with coding practice, MYMI bridges the gap between traditional interview preparation and real-world readiness, preparing young minds for the real-world technical interview.

title: Improving Intrusion Detection by using Multiclass Cyberattack Classification LightGBM, XGBoost, and Random Forest
authors: Harsh Gupta, Komal Singh, Ajay Kumar Phulre
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The tremendous growth in volume and complexity of cyberattacks poses significant challenges to the conventional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) which cannot keep pace with emergent threats and usually produce large volumes of false-positives. The present paper overcomes these shortcomings through the creation of a machine learning-based IDS on the UNSW-NB15 benchmark dataset, an actual network traffic model, and nine modern types of attacks, such as Fuzzers, Analysis, Backdoors, DoS, Exploits, Generic, Reconnaissance, Shellcode, and Worms. The proposed framework is associated with the high rate of detection and effective generalization due to thorough data preprocessing, sophisticated feature engineering, and a comparative analysis of the best models on the market, including Random Forest, XGBoost, and LightGBM. The ensemble approaches provide accuracy and more than 95% recall in multiclass attack recognition. The feature importance analysis identifies the most important network behaviors that can indicate attacks. Generally, the results indicate that the current data-driven IDS systems, when based on comprehensive datasets, can go a long way in detecting, preparing, and securing against cyber threats to the modern digital systems.

title: Spatio-Temporal Analysis of Environmental Influence Toward ARI Cases Spread in West Java Using INLA
authors: Melati Janet Livia Simanjuntak, Muhamad Syazali, Irfan Asfy Fakhry Anto, Rifani Bhakti Natari, Noersomadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI) are a major health problem in Indonesia, with West Java Province recording the highest number of cases in 2023. The surge cases in this region are allegedly caused by exposure to air pollution and changing climate conditions. This study aims to analyze the spatio-temporal relationship between eight environmental variables (temperature, humidity, rainfall, solar radiation, concentrations of PM10, SO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, CO) and the monthly distribution of ARI cases throughout 2023. The method used was a Bayesian approach with Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) as a prominent method in spatio-temporal analysis. Four model configurations of BYM1-RW1, BYM1-RW2, BYM2-RW1, and BYM2-RW2 were compared. The evaluation results indicated that the best model was BYM2–RW2, with DIC and RMSE values of 2,824.58 and 265.3, respectively. Relative Risk (RR) mapping showed the three highest values in July in Sumedang (5.29), August in Bandung Regency (4.52), and June in Ciamis (3.08). Meanwhile, the highest Standardized Incidence Ratio (SIR) was found in Subang in September (18.2), and the lowest SIR values were recorded in Sumedang in September (0.089). These results reinforce the finding that air quality and climate conditions play a significant role in the spatial and temporal patterns of ARI spread. The results of this study highlight the significant role of air pollution and climate conditions in the spatiotemporal spread of ARI and can be used as a scientific foundation for developing health interventions and policies that are more responsive to environmental risk factors.

title: Semantic guided DSM super-resolution with single-view high resolution image
authors: Maloba Abraham, Zhihua Hu, Kao Zhang, Ming Li
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Digital Surface Models (DSMs) are fundamental to urban planning, environmental monitoring, and disaster management applications. However, the inherent low spatial resolution of DSMs derived from satellite and aerial imagery significantly constrains their utility for detailed spatial analysis. This paper presents a novel deep learning framework that addresses this limitation through semantic-guided super-resolution using a singleview high-resolution image. Our approach integrates semantic features extracted from the Segment Anything Model (SAM) with traditional low-resolution DSMs and RGB imagery to enhance reconstruction quality. The framework employs a specially designed Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture that incorporates semantic-aware feature extraction and multi-modal data fusion modules. By leveraging semantic understanding from highresolution single-view images, our method provides enhanced contextual guidance for DSM reconstruction, particularly in complex urban environments where precise object delineation is crucial. Through comprehensive evaluation on the ISPRS Potsdam Dataset, our semantic-guided DSM super-resolution (SG-DMSR) model demonstrates substantial improvements over conventional approaches, achieving a PSNR increase of 2.3% and SSIM improvement of 3.5% while maintaining computational efficiency. The results highlight the significant potential of semantic context integration from single-view imagery for enhancing geospatial data reconstruction quality without requiring multiple viewpoints or additional sensors.

title: AI-Driven Tutoring in English Literature: Fostering Deeper Interpretation and Student Engagement
authors: D. Ronald Hadrian, Deepa Caroline, Niveditha R, V. Yazhini, L. Mahalakshmi, J. Gracy Nirmala
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study shows a novel technique to teach English writing with AI. People are the focus of the multi-level structure. It improves pupils' literary reading, comprehension, and analysis. Language, cognitive, and emotional development are included. Great teachers employ constructive criticism and interpretive reasoning. Most AI-based education systems focus on text analytics, but our paradigm emphasizes context and emotional connections. Learning is more fun and engaging. Vector-based modeling, semantic clustering, and reward-driven feedback improve reading. Affective computing helps the system adjust voice, style, and speed based on how the learner feels, such as joyful, curious, or concentrated. This model outperforms others in twelve key categories, including cognitive depth, emotional intelligence, contextual awareness, and input correctness, according to studies. The method produces more uniform interpretations, speedier analysis, and happier pupils. This study examines how combining AI with humanistic education alters AI-assisted learning. Along with training technical skills, it examines how AI might increase critical thinking, empathy, and long-term motivation. The framework is flexible, recognizes human feelings, and encourages intellectual growth. This advances English literature instruction greatly.

title: Advancing Education, Research, and Innovation: Empowering Women in Computing for a Sustainable Digital Future
authors: Vandana Aggarwal, Guneet Kaur Cheema, Kamal Batta, Harinder Kaur
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper explores the myriad ways in which education, research, and innovation can be used to empower women in computing to help them deliver a sustainable digital future. Through a mixed-methods research design, which combines qualitative interviews, scientometric and bibliometric analyses, and comparative quantitative research, the research question explores the lived experiences, barriers, and opportunities of women in the fields of STEM, entrepreneurship, and technology. The methodology will be based on literature reviews and decision-making analyses to determine major drivers of digital empowerment especially in developing settings. Early indicators are that artificial intelligence and digital technologies offer significant positives in helping women to access education, health, and entrepreneurial opportunities particularly in underserved communities. Nevertheless, there still remain some challenges, including the gender digital divide, institutionalised biases, and deeply held gender roles, that limit the overall involvement of women in the world of technology. The paper highlights the effectiveness of interventions, such as gender-sensitive education, inclusive leadership and focused policy actions, to strengthen the independence of women, their competence, and leadership in ICT. In addition, the incorporation of sustainability and digitalisation into highereducation courses also empowers women in the digital economy. As a result, the empowerment of women in computing is seen as an innovation driver, economic, and the achievement of sustainable development objectives which leads to the need to implement comprehensive measures to address the current obstacles and make the digital world gender-neutral.

title: Gone But Not Forgotten: Forensic Recovery of Disconnected USB-Sourced Images from Volatile Memory
authors: Syed Shayan Hussain, Shazain, Syed Rafay Ahmed, Faisal Iradat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Recovering image artifacts from volatile memory presents distinct challenges, particularly when images originate from removable media and are accessed through native image viewing applications on Windows systems. This study, to the best of our knowledge, lays the groundwork and systematically examines the feasibility of extracting image data from RAM dumps captured while the image viewing application remained active, despite the source USB storage device being disconnected. Memory dumps are investigated to identify how inmemory structures contribute to image retention. The results show that conventional file recovery approaches are ineffective due to application-specific image rendering mechanisms. Direct examination of a process’ memory regions allows recovery of the original compressed files. The findings propose a framework, using existing tools, for recovering images from memory in disconnected storage scenarios, advancing the field of memory forensics through a framework that adapts to Windows memory management behaviors.

title: Common Nail Disease Detection using Machine Learning Model
authors: Nurul Athirah Rosli, Shamimi A Halim, Azliza Mohd Ali, Ee Siew Li
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of nail diseases such as onychomycosis and nail psoriasis remains a clinical challenge due to overlapping visual symptoms and limited diagnostic resources. This study investigates the potential of deep learning models, MobileNetV2 and CNN-LSTM, for image-based classification of these conditions. Publicly available datasets were collected, preprocessed, and expanded through augmentation to enhance robustness. Both models were trained and evaluated under multiple hyperparameter configurations. MobileNetV2 consistently achieved higher performance, with a reported peak test accuracy of 99.90%, compared to CNN-LSTM’s maximum of 92.08%. To assess clinical applicability, a prototype system was developed using Streamlit, enabling users to upload nail images for automated classification. Validation against a set of dermatologist-labeled clinical images yielded a real-world accuracy of 70%. This outcome highlights both the feasibility of AI-driven nail disease detection and the limitations of dataset size, diversity, and preparation protocols. Importantly, the analysis of misclassified images revealed challenges such as lighting variability, multiple nails in a single frame, and symptom overlap, underscoring the need for more representative datasets. The contribution of this work is twofold: first, it demonstrates the promise of lightweight architectures like MobileNetV2 for nail disease detection; second, it presents a deployable prototype that bridges machine learning research with accessible healthcare applications. While the current accuracy is constrained by dataset limitations, this research provides a proof-of-concept foundation. Future work will adopt best-practice augmentation protocols, expand dataset diversity, and incorporate additional nail conditions to strengthen clinical robustness.

title: Integrating 3D-to-2D fMRI Mapping with CNN Architectures for Childhood Dyslexia Identification
authors: Santhiya S, Satheesh Kumar A, Jayadharshini P, Sree Varshine B, Rathika C, Sarankumar T
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Developmental dyslexia is a neurocognitive childhood disorder that impacts reading and school performance. Early and objective detection is therefore critical for successful intervention. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) provides high-level information regarding brain activity and connectivity, allowing machine learning methods to draw out patterns associated with dyslexia. It evaluates deep learning approaches to dyslexia diagnosis from fMRI. In particular, it is processed with slice-wise 2D convolutional neural networks (CNNs) using majority voting, projection- and montage-based 2D features, knowledge-distilled 2D CNNs supervised by 3D teacher models, direct 3D CNN baselines, and graph convolutional networks (GCNs) acting upon functional connectivity matrices. Experimental comparison highlights accuracy versus computational cost trade-offs. Results indicate that GCN models give the highest accuracy of 97.6% using connectivity-based features, whereas 2D CNN projection methods yield 93.2% accuracy with lower computational complexity. In comparison, straightforward 3D CNNs perform poorly at 89.3% accuracy. The results indicate the promise of 2D and graph-based models for practical and efficient fMRI-based dyslexia diagnosis.

title: Intelligent Voice Control in Industrial Automation: Python-Mediated PLC-HMI Integration for Conveyor Systems and Operational Resilience
authors: Lukasz Scislo, Jakub Szlaga, Mateusz Raźny
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This study presents a voice-controlled industrial automation system integrating Python-based speech recognition with PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) and HMI (Human-Machine Interface) for conveyor line control. The primary objective is to minimise production downtime by enabling hands-free operation in noisy industrial environments for people regardless of the clarity of their speech. The system architecture combines real-time speech processing with industrial control protocols, addressing key challenges such as acoustic interference from machinery vibrations and ambient noise. Experimental validation was conducted on a functional conveyor line, comparing the proposed solution against traditional control methods. Results demonstrate a significant reduction in downtime, with high speech recognition accuracy under typical factory noise conditions. The system’s robustness was tested across varying noise levels, dialects, and operator speech patterns, showing consistent performance in highvibration environments. Key innovations include adaptive noise filtering algorithms and vibration-resistant microphone placement strategies, which improved command detection reliability. Ergonomics assessments revealed a significant reduction in operator fatigue compared to manual controls. The study provides practical insights for implementing voice-driven automation in Industry $\mathbf{4. 0}$ environments while also highlighting limitations in extreme noise scenarios.

title: WIP: Explainable AI is not Self-Explainable: Findings from Design-Based K-12 AI Education
authors: Nicolas Pope, Maria Kuismin, Eetu Arkko, Henriikka Vartiainen, Juho Kahila, Matti Tedre
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper reports findings from introducing an eXplainable AI (XAI) component into AI education within two Finnish middle school classrooms. The educational intervention focused on image classification, a popular technique for introducing learners to supervised machine learning and data-driven thinking. A key moment during these interventions arises when the model does not work as expected: Learners must engage deeply in data-driven analysis to identify what in their data set might explain the unexpected behavior, collect additional data, or curate their dataset, re-train and test their model, and iterate accordingly. To support learners during the “evaluate your model behavior” phase of the ML workflow, we designed and integrated a class activation map (CAM)-based XAI component into our learning tool. This component provides learners with a heatmap-type visualization that highlights which areas of an image contribute the most to the classification result. We conducted classroom interventions with children aged 11 - 16 years, gathered written design diaries and video data, and analyzed them using qualitative content analysis. Our findings indicate that without explicit instruction on how the XAI component works and how to interpret the visualization, the learners found the component more confusing than explanatory. The study suggests future research directions for facilitating XAI-enhanced educational technology in classroom settings.

title: Exploring Undergraduate Students' Utilization and Perceptions of Generative AI in Engineering: Insights from an Introductory Statics and Mechanics of Materials Course
authors: David A. DeFrancisis, David M. Pabst, Lee A. Dosse, Jacklyn F. Wyszynski, Matthew M. Barry
abstract: This research paper examines how students utilize generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) both in and outside an introductory Statics and Mechanics of Materials course, utilizing an interactive online textbook hosted through Top Hat. The textbook features its own GenAI, called ACE, which is trained exclusively on course materials from the textbook. Researchers conducted, recorded, and transcribed six focus group interviews. Responses were analyzed into a report on each student's experience. Several key themes emerged from the focus groups, including both positive aspects, such as using ACE as a virtual tutor, and negative aspects, such as having ACE attempt to answer questions on their behalf. While this raised concerns regarding academic integrity, the responses showed that those who misused GenAI became aware of their wrongdoing and adjusted their usage to aid in learning. Students cited various reasons for changing negative habits, including developing an awareness of the potential harm of building a dependency, recognizing that GenAI was inferior to human interaction when seeking help, and being aware of AI's limitations in providing reliable knowledge. As a result, students recognized the need for in-person instruction to master a subject. The self-reported data suggests that when used appropriately, GenAI can enhance student comprehension of course material; however, when misused, it may hinder students' study habits and learning. Findings suggest that educators should consider implementing instruction on the ethical, practical, and effective use of GenAI as opposed to banning it. This multifaceted approach would minimize potential academic integrity violations while maximizing academic benefits.

title: Image-based Non-invasive Bridge Crack Detection Model for Edge Devices
authors: Athul Joe Palliparambil, Kevin Benty, Alan Cherian, Rajeev Rajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: Crack detection is a critical task for ensuring the structural integrity and safety of various infrastructures. Cracks affect the light-sensitive surfaces of materials and can cause significant damage if not detected early. The accurate classification of cracks is essential for timely intervention and effective maintenance. However, challenges such as unbalanced datasets and subtle differences between crack types can affect the model’s performance. This study evaluates the efficacy of a CNN architecture, MobileNetV2, and ViT for automated multi-class crack detection for edge devices. The 3-layer CNN network, MobileNetV2, and ViT model capture complex patterns and important features, improving performance in distinguishing crack severity. Detailed analysis using confusion matrices provides further insight into the model’s performance in three classes. This study demonstrates the potential of deep learning for structural monitoring and proposes actionable strategies for future directions.

title: Designing a Solar Energy Solution for MajherChar, Mathbaria: An Off-Grid Fishing Community Using HOMER Pro
authors: Md. Mehedi Hasan, Sharmin Siddika
abstract: This article describes a solar power system for a remote off-grid fishing community that is not electrified and is located in an isolated area, isolated by a river, for which the government cannot provide power access. The community cannot sustain a power supply using a generator simply because of the noise and environmental pollution that accompany it. An optimised PV system, together with battery storage and converter sizing, was designed using HOMER Pro software, taking into account the average energy demand of the community. Four alternatives—PV, diesel generator, PV+diesel, and PV+wind—were compared. Both solar and diesel options were cost-effective; however, we chose solar because it is significantly more environmentally friendly and does not produce operational pollution. The solar system is a reasonable, feasible, and environmentally friendly power supply for the community.

title: AI-Powered Applications in Precision Healthcare and Security Surveillance Systems
authors: Kapil Shrivastava, Mandeep Narang, Vedamurthy Gejjegondanahalli Yogeshappa, Aadam Quraishi, Vaibhav Sharma, Javlonbek Kurbonov
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study presents an integrated framework for applying advanced reinforcement learning strategies to optimize decision-making in high-stakes domains such as precision healthcare and security surveillance. By leveraging adaptive deep reinforcement learning, the proposed model dynamically refines policy behavior in environments characterized by large, complex, and evolving state-action spaces. The approach utilizes deep neural approximators, temporal difference updates, and exploration-exploitation balancing to achieve rapid convergence and resilient policy learning. Experimental evaluations demonstrate significant improvements over traditional Q-learning and deep Q-learning methods, particularly in sensitivity, specificity, robustness to noise, and data adaptability. The model further adheres to stringent data security and privacy requirements, making it ideal for applications involving medical diagnostics, real-time threat detection, and surveillance analytics. This research establishes a novel and scalable benchmark for deploying intelligent AI agents capable of delivering high-performance policy optimization under uncertain and dynamic conditions.

title: Signal Detection for Drug Safety Fusing Spontaneous Reporting System and Social Media
authors: Yifan Zhou, Matthew Bright, John Heap, Andrew R Jones, Munir Pirmohamed, Simon Maskell
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Statistical methods to detect signals of after-market adverse drug reactions from Spontaneous Reporting System (SRS) are a subject of active research in pharmacovigilance. SRS data are considered as the cornerstone in signal detection, but complementary sources of data, including social media, have also been considered. This paper proposes a Beta-Binomial distribution-based Bayesian signal detection method for fusing SRS data with social media data, and applies it to combining records from the FDA Adverse Event (AE) Reporting System and Twitter. We show that, with careful processing, particularly with respect to bias potentially introduced by the presence of high counts of drug-AEs ('masking'), fusing the multi-source data can improve performance relative to using either source alone.
