title: Automatic Detection of Corneal Ulcers Using Convolution Neural Network
authors: Rajasekaran Thangaraj, D Preethishri, B Deepa, S Geetha, V Mythily, Sivaraman Eswaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Corneal ulcers are a grave ophthalmologic problem; early detection can prevent permanent vision loss and significantly reduce the risk of blindness. Conventional diagnostic techniques are based on slit-lamp examinations that require dedicated equipment and expert interpretation, involving manual image analysis by time-consuming ophthalmologists. The CNN architectures such as Deep Keratitis, MobileNetV2, and ResNet-18 were evaluated using the corneal ulcer dataset from SUSTech-SYSU. All models were trained using a standardized preprocessing and training pipeline that incorporated robust data augmentation techniques, normalization procedures and advanced transfer learning strategies to enhance model generalization and performance across diverse ulcer presentations. The ResNet-18 model fine-tuned with a custom sigmoid output layer achieved the highest classification accuracy of $94 \%$, outperforming Deep Keratitis $(92 \%)$ and MobileNetV2 $(89.5 \%)$. Experimental results show that ResNet-18 achieves the best possible balance between computational efficiency and accuracy which support for real-time clinical applications. The proposed system shows promise for deployment in tele-ophthalmology and resource-limited settings, with future work focused on ulcer severity grading, explainability and multi-class classification.

title: Demonstration of a Wideband Mode Filtering Converter Based on the Four-Ridge Circular Coupling-Cavity Structure
authors: Zheng Wen, You Diao, Jun Zhang, Tao Xun, Junpu Ling, Dian Zhang, Difu Shi, Cheng-Wei Yuan
abstract: A mode converter (MC) is often used to convert a specific mode into the desired mode, which has been applied to various electromagnetic systems, while the conventional MC design mainly focuses on conversion efficiency, operating bandwidth, and size but often ignores the sideband performance. As a result, the unwanted modes and frequencies near the sideband may sneak into the system and lead to instability. Here, based on the four-ridge circular coupling-cavity structure (FCCS), we propose a wideband mode filtering converter (MFC) that can be regarded as an integration of an MC, a frequency filter, and a mode filter due to the high mode purity in the passband and out-of-band rejection characteristics, as well as the mode filtering performance. Furthermore, an X-band wideband TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sub> to TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub> MFC was fabricated and tested. The experimental results are in good agreement with the simulation results and also indicate that MFCs possess both the out-of-band rejection and mode filtering characteristics.

title: A Scoping Review of Multidisciplinary and Interdisciplinary Engineering in Higher Education: Unanswered Questions and Future Directions
authors: Zane Reynolds, Shawn Jordan
abstract: This Full Paper Research Study presents a comprehensive scoping review of multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and integrated engineering education in higher education settings. While a growing body of research highlights the benefits of these approaches, there remain critical gaps in understanding their long-term effectiveness, implementation challenges, and alignment with industry needs. Engineering education has increasingly integrated cross-disciplinary learning models to prepare students for the complexities of modern engineering problems. However, questions persist regarding the sustainability of these programs, their measurable impact on career readiness, and how effectively they align with workforce demands. This paper conducts a scoping review of literature from leading databases such as IEEE Xplore, ScienceDirect, ResearchGate and ERIC, applying thematic analysis to identify common trends, unresolved issues, and opportunities for future research. Findings suggest that while these programs enhance student engagement, teamwork, and problem-solving skills, there is limited evidence of long-term career benefits and consistent industry alignment. Additionally, faculty preparedness, institutional support, and curriculum scalability are identified as key barriers to successful program implementation. This review highlights the need for structured assessment frameworks, enhanced industry partnerships, and long-term career impact studies to optimize the effectiveness and scalability of these educational models.

title: WIP: Scaling Principles of Programming
authors: Ryan Meuth, Medha Dalal, Peter Van Leusen
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative practice paper details a scalable “mega-course” model for first-year programming instruction where students of any modality (online, on-campus, or outreach) share not only the same learning outcomes, but nearly the same course experience. As enrollments in CS programs increase, at some universities the number of teaching faculty per unit has not kept pace with this growth. How can the CS teaching model adapt to introduce programming to as many students as possible with lower staffing requirements, while also maintaining learning objective achievement, improving retention rates, and providing adequate student support? We describe the design intentions, development, and implementation details of the course content, as well as the scalable support structures that enable the course population to grow to over 3000 students per semester. We also share how we approach issues of academic integrity, curriculum integration, data-driven content revision, and our staffing model. Evaluations demonstrate high student learning outcomes, improved retention, and consistent achievement in follow-up courses. Looking towards the future, we discuss areas of improvement for the model and how this might be adapted at other institutions.

title: Pre-Conference Workshop: Innovative K-12 Educator Sessions: Partnerships Between TryEngineering & Universities
authors: Stamatis Dragoumanos, Debra Gulick, Dawna Schultz
abstract: IEEE TryEngineering is a program within IEEE Educational Activities that coordinates resources and programs for adults who work with school-aged children. The mission of IEEE TryEngineering is to ensure that all school-aged children see themselves as changemakers who can improve the world through engineering and technology. In 2024 and 2025, TryEngineering provided professional development activities in partnership with U.S. universities through the TryEngineering Educator Sessions which included hands-on activities, videos, tours and expert speakers who worked with educators of K-12 students (children ages 8-17). The workshop will include a discussion of the TryEngineering Educator Sessions held in 2024 and in 2025, and engage the participants in the Making of a Microchip lesson. Participants will learn about the Engineering Design Process and other TryEngineering resources that can be used in the classroom.

title: WIP: Study of the Impact of Pre-Requisite Courses on Student Learning in Linear Systems
authors: Eesha Atif, Laura Bottomley
abstract: This work-in-progress study investigates how prerequisite courses affect student learning outcomes in ECE 301-Linear Systems, focusing on understanding students' perceived effectiveness of prerequisite content from ECE 220-Analytical Foundations of ECE and ECE 211-Electric Circuits. The course, ECE 200-Introduction to Signals, Circuits and Systems, is also of interest, since it is a prerequisite for both ECE 220 and ECE 211, and the concepts are directly linked with topics taught in ECE 301. The paper uses triangulation based on grade distribution data, student surveys, and faculty interviews to draw conclusions about the impact of each of the prerequisite courses. The survey was implemented in a class of ECE 301, toward the end of the semester. Students were asked if specific topics were necessary preparation or unnecessary repetition for ECE 301, specific to their section and offering of enrolled prerequisite classes. Interesting trends led to follow-up interviews with faculty, to ascertain their views on curriculum continuity and instructional strategies. Preliminary findings suggest certain repeated topics were more helpful than others, while certain topics taught in ECE 200 need not be repeated in ECE 220 in the students' perspective. For example, Periodic Signals in the Frequency domain was reported to be helpful for ECE 301 when taught in ECE 200, but students felt it did not need to be repeated in ECE 220. Faculty interviews also provided information on effective strategies that students found helpful. The overall aim of this work is to benefit students and faculty by proposing ideas for enhanced student learning.

title: WIP: Advancing Transdisciplinary Graduate Training at the Intersection of AI and Arid Land Agriculture
authors: Adán M. Delval, Enrico Pontelli, Ruth Torres Castillo, Wendy Chi
abstract: This WIP Research-to-practice study examines the ongoing initiative of the AIALA program which introduces graduate students to the topics of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Arid Land Agriculture (ALA). The main objective of this work is to inform research to practice, with the purpose of contributing to innovative practices in computing education in the future. The program aims to equip fellows with skills needed to implement and develop new AI-driven technologies that address challenges in arid land agriculture. Since the program launched in Spring 2023, AIALA has recruited five fellows. The coursework includes topics in machine learning, ALA, ethics, and proposal development. These topics are complemented by faculty mentorship, research experiences, and professional development workshops. Three research questions guide the AIALA project: (1) To what extent do scholars gain competencies in AI and ALA? (2) How successful is the program in the recruitment and retention of scholars from diverse academic backgrounds, while fostering inclusivity in interdisciplinary research? (3) To what extent does the program prepare scholars with essential professional and soft skills such as teamwork, interdisciplinary communication, and ethics? We present preliminary findings from an evaluation of the AIALA program, focusing on student experiences and learning outcomes. Interviews and surveys were conducted with student participants to assess key programmatic aspects, including learning opportunities, financial benefits, networking, clear expectations, and overall support guidance. Findings indicate that while students value the opportunity to gain content knowledge, hands-on experience, and interdisciplinary perspectives, challenges exist in leveling the knowledge field across different disciplines. Participants noted increased confidence in discussing topics outside their primary field but highlighted the need for structured learning pathways, particularly for those with limited prior research experience. Program strengths include faculty support and networking opportunities, while suggested improvements emphasize practical skill development and adapting research training to the academic backgrounds of participants. A key challenge has been recruiting domestic doctoral students, leading to the inclusion of master's students, which introduced differences in research relevance and quality; addressing this will improve program accessibility while maintaining research standards. In conclusion, AIALA represents a potential training hub focused on the convergence of research themes in AI and ALA, fostering innovative and ethical solutions. Future efforts will incorporate more hands-on learning and refine strategies to bridge theory with real-world applications. This paper not only documents the preliminary findings but also underscores the transformative potential of collaborative, interdisciplinary approaches to education.

title: Using Prompt Engineering to Enhance a Project-Based Learning Course on Project Management
authors: Paula Mendonça, José Reginaldo Hughes Carvalho, Ana Carolina Oran
abstract: This Innovative Practice Paper presents a methodology that integrates prompt engineering of Large Language Models (LLMs) into the teaching of software project management in undergraduate education. Addressing the challenges of conveying complex and evolving project management practices, the approach combines the Project Management Institute (PMI) framework with Scrum and project-based learning (PBL), creating an adaptive learning environment supported by LLM-driven mentorship. During a 12 -week period, the student project team (squads) managed their own software projects, developing documentation aligned with the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) performance domains. LLMs acted as virtual specialists, providing real-time guidance and filling expertise gaps typically addressed by domain specialists. Students engaged in six practical activities that culminated in a cross-validation task comparing results generated by different LLMs. The evaluation focused on the completeness and PMBOK compliance of the produced documentation, with LLM assessments moderated by the instructors. In addition, students applied prompt engineering strategies in a final exam to iteratively refine LLM responses to PMIstyle certification questions. The results align with recent research, emphasizing the role of prompt engineering in educational contexts, and illustrate how LLMs can foster responsive, industry-relevant learning environments. This methodology enhances decision-making skills, promotes hands-on experience with PMI and Scrum, and introduces students to emerging Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies. It also demonstrates scalability and potential for democratizing high-quality mentorship in resourceconstrained educational settings. The paper discusses the implementation, results, and limitations, offering insights for adapting the approach to other software engineering courses.

title: WIP: Networking and Engagement of High School Students for Engineering Technology and Data Operation Careers
authors: Benjamin E. Chaback, Amy Richardson, Michelle Klopfer, Christopher D. Russell, David Knight
abstract: This work in progress innovative practice paper aims to describe multiple support programs developed at Northern Virginia Community College (NOVA) to raise awareness of regional emerging technologies and prepare students for careers in Engineering Technology (ET) and Data Center Operations (DCO). In response to the growing demand for skilled professionals and training in these fields, NOVA launched a suite of initiatives including the ET & DCO summer bridge program, ET Ready summer bridge program, Educator Externship, and the ET Career Scholars program. These programs at NOVA utilize hands-on activities and training, industry tours, campus visits, and targeted support to engage diverse stakeholders such as high school students, high school educators, NOVA administrators, and industry partners. Preliminary evaluation data reveal significant growth in the students' understanding of ET and DCO careers, with many participants enrolling in related ET and DCO programs at NOVA. High school educators also reported increased awareness of ET and DCO career pathways and committed to sharing this knowledge with students and the students' parents. The programs' shared structure minimizes planning efforts while enabling lessons learned to be applied across initiatives. This approach provides a replicable model for other institutions seeking to build awareness of emerging technologies and expand workforce pipelines for students. In addition to high school students and educators, we recommend engaging high school students' families-an essential stakeholder group not always included as partners-in outreach efforts to further support students' educational and career decisions. By fostering partnerships and addressing barriers to training and awareness, NOVA demonstrates how community colleges can play a pivotal role in preparing the next generation of professionals for the rapidly evolving ET and DCO industries.

title: Enhanced PID Tuning Using Hybrid Particle Swarm Optimization for DC Motor Control
authors: Muhamad Aiman Mohd Zaman, Muhammad Zaiyad Muda
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This research focuses on enhancing PID controller tuning through a hybrid Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) approach. Traditional PID tuning methods often lack adaptability and efficiency, especially under dynamic conditions. To overcome these limitations, a hybrid PSO algorithm combining Chaotic PSO, Orthogonal Learning PSO, Adaptive Inertia Weight, and Velocity Clamping, is proposed to improve the optimization process. Implemented on a DC motor position control system using Arduino and an encoder, the method effectively identified optimal PID parameters with K<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>=1.04, K<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf>=37.16, and K<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf>=0.001. The results show significant improvements, including a settling time of 0.441 s , a maximum overshoot of 0.8%, zero steady-state error, and a rise time of 0.189 s . This highlights the hybrid PSO algorithm's potential for delivering efficient, accurate, and robust PID tuning across varying systems dynamics.

title: A Review of Machine Learning Methods Applied to Gas Solubility Prediction
authors: Fahd Saeed Alakbari, Iffah Athirah Binti Kithar, Syed Mohammad Mahmood, Haylay Tsegab Gebretsadik, Mysara Eissa Mohyaldin, Mahmoud M. Abdelnaby
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Gas solubility prediction is foremost in the petroleum industry, affecting reservoir management, production optimization, and safety considerations. This study presents a comprehensive review of machine learning methods used in gas solubility prediction. These methods are Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS), Functional Network (FN), and Support Vector Machine (SVM). The study explores machine learning methods, highlights their capability to predict gas solubility, and discussed some case studies to illustrate their accuracy in gas solubility prediction. The ANNs exhibit adaptability in handling clustered data. However, they are constrained by dependencies on hidden layer configurations. This study also delves into ANFIS, a hybrid model combining ANN learning capacities with fuzzy logic, showcasing its robust predictions for gas solubility. Studies underscore ANFIS's accuracy, especially in uncertain and complex systems, and its ability to overcome fitting challenges. ANFIS models have an Average Absolute Percentage Error (AAPRE) of (4.631-4.719) % for gas solubility prediction. FN emerges as an alternative to ANNs, leveraging domain knowledge alongside data for enhanced insights. The studies indicate FN's satisfactory performance in gas solubility prediction, particularly in estimating gas solubility (Rs) with acceptable error rates. FN models have an AAPRE of 10.2012% for gas solubility prediction. This review also discusses SVM, a supervised learning model effective in regression analysis for gas solubility prediction. The SVM has a lower over-fitting risk and convergence with global optima, especially in the modified versions such as LSSVM for large-scale problems. The SVM models have an AAPRE of 9.0757-15.94 % for gas solubility prediction. This review on the machine learning models in gas solubility prediction underscores their importance in optimizing oil production, enhancing safety measures, and ensuring compliance with environmental regulations in the oil and gas industry.

title: Enhancing Tourist Experience Through Machine Learning Based Destination Prediction
authors: Pankaj Kumar Tyagi, Priyanka Tyagi, Praveen Kumar, S. Jegadeesan, Balakrishnan Ravishankar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The conceived Context-Aware Multi-Modal Traveler Preference Network (CMTN) is an intelligent system of improving the personal travel suggestions with the blending of multiple data types and context variables. Conventional destination recommendation systems have been known to be based on the use of fixed user profiles and historical information and thus cannot respond to the dynamic changing needs of the traveler and changes in the situation. The CMTN method will overcome this shortcoming by using behavioral, semantic, and environmental data in a single model of prediction. It is based on a two-channel architecture in which textual data, including reviews and social media, are fed through a semantic encoder based on transformers, whereas geospatial and temporal also have temporal convolutional networks. Such features representations are combined via cross-attention mechanism which gives less emphasis on irrelevant factors. Moreover, a reinforcement learning layer corrects predictions based on the feedback of the iterative nature to provide adaptability and continuous enhancements in the suggested accuracy. Besides suggesting the appropriate destinations, the proposed system is also able to match destinations with the changing interests and real-life situations that travelers have e.g., weather, events, and time limitations. It is anticipated that through experimental validation, CMTN will surpass the traditional machine learning models mainly due to its overwhelming precision, relevance and flexibility, thus providing a comprehensive and capable solution to the intelligent travel experience personalization.

title: Research on Key Technologies of Autonomous Operation and Optimal Control of Rural Independent Micro-Energy Grid
authors: Yongxiang Cai, Song Zhang, Ke Fan, Mingjun He, Xinyu You
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the rural energy revolution and the advancement of the "Dual Carbon" goals, as the core carrier for rural distributed energy consumption and the guarantee of energy supply quality, the autonomous operation stability, smoothness of mode switching, and scheduling optimization of independent micro-energy grids under different conditions are directly related to the reliability of rural energy supply. This paper conducts research on key technologies targeting two core issues of rural independent micro-energy grids: transient impact after power grid faults and fluctuating islanding-grid connection switching. First, it analyzes the influencing mechanism of voltage-frequency transient response after microenergy grid faults. Second, it designs a smooth islanding-grid connection switching strategy based on droop control; through preset transition control and adaptive parameter adjustment, the voltage fluctuation during mode switching is controlled within ten percent to ensure the stable supply of various energy forms. The results effectively solve the problems of transient stability, mode switching, and scheduling optimization in the autonomous operation of rural independent micro-energy grids, provide technical support for improving the quality of rural energy supply and the local consumption of distributed energy, and contribute to the construction of smart energy systems in beautiful villages.

title: Multimodal Quiz Generation via RAG with LLM-as-Judge Evaluation
authors: Mourya Teja Kunuku, Nasrin Dehbozorgi
abstract: This paper presents a novel multimodal quiz generation framework that integrates audio, visual, and textual data using a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture. The system leverages LLaVA for vision-language understanding and LLaMA 3.1 for text generation to produce contextually relevant and pedagogically meaningful multiple-choice questions (MCQs) from lecture videos. This approach addresses key limitations of traditional text-only quiz generation models by capturing richer, multimodal information. The system was tested on a real-world use case, generating 15 MCQs from the first lecture in an introductory computer science course. To evaluate the effectiveness of the generated quizzes, we designed a two-stage evaluation framework. In the first stage, we assessed retrieval and generation performance using standard metrics such as Hit Rate, Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR), Correctness, Relevance, and Faithfulness. In the second stage, we examined how closely AI evaluations align with human expert judgments. We involved four human raters and three LLM-as-Judge models—Claude 3 Sonnet, GPT-4, and LLaMA 3.1—to evaluate each question. To analyze agreement, we used Percentage Agreement, Cohen's Kappa, Spearman's Rho, and Krippendorff's Alpha, capturing both exact matches and ordinal consistency. Our results show high retrieval accuracy and reasonable alignment between LLM based and human assessments, particularly in factual and procedural questions. However, discrepancies emerged in questions requiring deeper reasoning or visual interpretation, where human raters exhibited stronger consistency. These findings highlight the strengths of LLMs in scalable content generation, while reinforcing the need for human oversight in evaluating complex educational tasks. This work takes a significant step toward more human-aligned and effective AI-driven assessment systems.

title: Deep Learning-Based Tumor Detection in CT and PET Lung Images Using YOLOv7 and YOLOv8
authors: Aliya Thaseen, Durgesh Nandan, Sheshikala Martha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The current paper reports a new deep learning model accurate tumor localization in lung CT and PET-based scans using new YOLOv7 and YOLOv8 models. In contrast to the previous research, the presented method framework will combine individual pre-processing steps and dataset-individual augmentation to maximize tumor position localization in multimodal imaging. The models are also trained and tested on a large dataset that consists of a detailed guaranteed that the models can detect tumors of different size and contrast. Results in experiments show that YOLOv8 has an accuracy higher than 89.3, which is higher than that of YOLOv7 (88.6), at better precision (0.87 vs. 0.85), recall (0.88 vs. 0.86), and shorter inference time (11.8 ms vs. 12.5 ms). The suggested solution saves the fields on the interactivity of GPU memory and the size of models, which enables their implementation into clinical settings. This study confirms that such optimized YOLO models have practical potential of developing tumors at an early phase, fast and precise performance that aims to transform tumor imaging diagnostics in oncological radiology.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Powered Stock Market Forecasting with Metaheuristic Feature Selection Techniques
authors: Ravi Kumar Chandu, Mrinmoy Aich, Laxmi Narayan Pandey, Nidhi Soni, K. Pithambar, Amish Karki
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study introduces an improved AI framework for predicting stock market trends using metaheuristic methods to select meauretics. Since financial time series data is both intricate and complex, the study offered a two-stage hybrid method for choosing important features. At the beginning, the method uses MFFS (Multi-Filter Feature Selection) to put together the rankings of Pearson Correlation Coefficient, ANOVA and Mutual Information to cut out irrelevant indicators. In the second stage, a wrapper-based LFCSO (Levy's Flight Chicken Swarm Optimization) algorithm is used to avoid stuck at local results and rapid convergence and optima the final set of features. Then, the well-defined list of features is given to deep learning models—LSTM, CNN and ConvLSTM—to make accurate predictions about stock prices. Checking on well-known datasets (S&P500, NASDAQ, RUSSELL2000) showed that the results are more accurate than before, as confirmed by the RMSE, MAE and MAPE tests. The introduced hybrid FS model has better accuracy and uses less computing power, compared to well-known optimization methods.

title: Modified Parameter-Scaling Rule of Nonlinear Pulse Propagation in Gas-Filled Capillary Fiber With Waveguide Loss
authors: Donghan Liu, Zhiyuan Huang, Jinyu Pan, Tiandao Chen, Jie Zhang, Wenbin He, Jiapeng Huang, Xin Jiang, Meng Pang, Yuxin Leng, Ruxin Li
abstract: Gas-filled capillary fiber has been widely regarded as an ideal platform for generating high energy, ultrashort laser pulses with broadband wavelength tunability, highly demanded in a few scientific areas. While a variety of soliton dynamics, such as high-order soliton self-compression (HSC), dispersive-wave emission (DWE) and ionization-induced spectral blue-shift (IBS), have been intensively studied in such a capillary fiber system, the parameter-scaling rule of this system is, however, different from that of the hollow-core photonic crystal fiber system, mainly due to the non-ignorable loss of the capillary waveguide. Here, we demonstrate a modified parameter-scaling rule which includes the capillary loss term, being useful to system design and optimization. We illustrate both theoretically and experimentally that this modified scaling rule is valid for all of the HSC, DWE and IBS processes, highlighting the similarities of these nonlinear propagation processes over a large range of capillary sizes. (144 words)

title: Exploring the Impact of the Need for Cognitive Closure on Undergraduate Engineering Students' Cognitive Engagement During Problem Solving
authors: Zain ul Abideen, Sehrish Jabeen, Oenardi Lawanto, Angela Minichiello, Assad Iqbal
abstract: This full paper explores the interaction between varying levels of Need for Cognitive Closure (NFCC) and undergraduate engineering students' cognitive engagement. Engineering students inevitably encounter complex problems. Educational systems aim to equip students with the knowledge, skills, and attitude required to undertake such situations. To address this goal, there is a need to understand the learner's ability and willingness to deal with situations involving complex information. The psychological construct of the NFCC can influence one's cognitive processes associated with problem solving, such as motivation to simplify complex information and avoid ambiguity. High NFCC individuals tend to prefer shallow learning strategies while confronting complex problems, which can hinder deep understanding and engagement. Low NFCC individuals persist through complex tasks and consider alternative solutions that foster engagement and creativity. The relation between the need for closure and engagement during problem-solving needs further exploration in engineering despite the extensive research in psychology. This study investigates the impact of NFCC on cognitive engagement during problem-solving tasks. This mixed-method study will select participants with either high or low NFCC based on a validated need for cognitive closure scale (NFCCS) survey response during the quantitative phase, administered to engineering students. Then, participants were selected purposefully for the problem-solving activity and semistructured interviews in the qualitative phase. Data collection involves audio recordings of participants during problemsolving tasks, which were transcribed and analyzed using thematic coding to identify recurring patterns and themes related to cognitive engagement. This research seeks to provide insights into the cognitive processes that shape problem-solving behaviors, which could inform instructional practices in engineering based on individual differences.

title: Modeling of Dynamic Migration of Z-Curves for GNSS Signals: A Geometric and Numeric Approach
authors: Guoyu Fu, Haidong Wang, Colton Riedel, Jyh-Charn Liu
abstract: A z-curve is the set of points on Earth’s surface that have identical pseudoranges to Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) satellites (A, B). The zero Time Difference of Arrival (TDOA) model eliminates common mode errors in signal transmission and the clock bias of GNSS receivers. Building upon a static model of z-surfaces and z-curves, this paper presents a dynamic model for migration of z-surfaces and z-curves with respect to satellite motions and atmospheric changes. Specifically, we use geometric transformation matrices and numerical solvers to describe the migration of the satellite Terrestrial Service Volume (TSV) model, z-surface, and z-curve. Affine transformations are applied to TSV and z-surface migrations, while for z-curve migration, we adopt a modified Newton’s method and a 4th-order Runge-Kutta method to align z-curve points on ground and within satellite coverage. These migration functions are validated using Global Positioning System (GPS) data.

title: WIP: Centering African American Culture in Engineering Education: Impact of an Africancentered Pedagogy and Curriculum
authors: DeAnna Bailey, Kate Rotindo, Kendal Knox, Charnee Bowens, Krystal Dunn, James Holly
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper describes and presents preliminary results for an approach to inspire African American participation in engineering. This approach utilizes an African-centered pedagogy and curriculum to support and enhance students' interest, knowledge and self-efficacy in engineering. The implementation and efficacy of this approach are currently being studied through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Racial Equity in STEM Education program. This work is guided by following research questions: In what ways does an African-centered pedagogy and curriculum influence the construction of engineering knowledge? and how does an Africancentered pedagogy impact student learning of engineering concepts and engineering identity formation for urban African American learners? The study was deployed through the Conscious Ingenuity program at Montebello Elementary/Middle School in Baltimore City. Participants completed pre- and postprogram surveys. Mid-program interviews with students and parents were conducted which provided additional insights. Data analysis indicated that the African-centered approach to teaching engineering effectively increased participants' interest, confidence, self-efficacy, and knowledge in STEM, particularly engineering. This paper describes African-centered pedagogy and curriculum, discusses the research methods employed to assess their impact, and presents the study's initial quantitative findings.

title: A Study on Mathematical Problem-Solving Skills for Computer Science Undergraduate Students
authors: Thitima Srivatanakul, Virginia L. Thompson, Yonghong L. McDowell, Philip Parzygnat
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper describes a study that investigates the relationship between mathematical skills and programming task performance among undergraduate computer science students. Learning to program involves complex cognitive activities and various skill sets, such as critical thinking, problem-solving, and abstraction. An indicator of student success is often their ability to apply critical thinking, problem-solving, and logical reasoning, skills typically developed through mathematics courses. This study explores the relationship between mathematical problem-solving skills (Calculation, Interpretation, Representation, and Application) and undergraduate computer science students' ability to understand and implement fundamental data structures and algorithms, as well as solve programming problems in their second computer science course. While the current analysis is based on a limited sample, the goal is to establish early insights for a more comprehensive study that will extend to additional courses, sections, and student populations. These initial findings can serve as preliminary data to guide future research and curriculum development. The results indicate that Interpretation and Application skills are positively correlated with higher-level programming tasks, such as analyzing and designing solutions. However, Calculation and Representation skills showed no meaningful correlations with the computer science learning outcomes from this study. The findings of the Problem-Solving Perception Survey reveal that while students are generally confident in problem-solving, they are less confident in applying mathematical skills to programming. The high variability in responses and anxiety with unfamiliar tasks suggest a need for stronger integration of mathematical problem-solving and early support in programming instruction.

title: The Relationship between Tag Values and Redundant Paths in Gamma Networks
authors: Muhammad Zulfin, Maksum Pinem, Raja Harahap, Arman Sani, Rahmad Fauzi, Fahmi Rinaldi, Muhammad Razali
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: This paper discusses the tag values in the Gamma Multistage Interconnection Network (MIN) topology and its relationship with redundant paths. The Gamma network tag value is the difference between the source port number and the destination port number (input-output port number) of the network multiplied by the network size modulo. From the discussion, it is obtained that the number of Gamma network tag values of size N ranges from -(N-1) to (N-1). A Gamma network with a size of 16x16 has a tag value from -15 to 15. The tag value determines the number of redundant paths for each source-destination connection. The number of redundant paths in the Gamma network varies, depending on the tag value ẟ and is calculated using the Fibonacci series. The redundant representation pattern with tag value ẟ can be a routing tag connection (S, D) with a tag value of -(N-ẟ) and vice versa. Specifically, a tag value of zero only produces one redundant path. From the tests carried out using permutations, there is a connection (S, D) that fails when using the first routing tag, but the packet successfully arrives at the destination when using the second routing tag. This shows that redundant paths in the Gamma network can reroute packets through other paths to avoid blocking, thereby improving the network blocking probability.

title: S-LAM3D: Segmentation-Guided Monocular 3D Object Detection via Feature Space Fusion
authors: Diana-Alexandra Sas, Florin Oniga
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Monocular 3D Object Detection represents a challenging Computer Vision task due to the nature of the input used, which is a single 2D image, lacking in any depth cues and placing the depth estimation problem as an ill-posed one. Existing solutions leverage the information extracted from the input by using Convolutional Neural Networks or Transformer architectures as feature extraction backbones, followed by specific detection heads for 3D parameters prediction. In this paper, we introduce a decoupled strategy based on injecting precomputed segmentation information priors and fusing them directly into the feature space for guiding the detection, without expanding the detection model or jointly learning the priors. The focus is on evaluating the impact of additional segmentation information on existing detection pipelines without adding additional prediction branches. The proposed method is evaluated on the KITTI 3D Object Detection Benchmark, outperforming the equivalent architecture that relies only on RGB image features for small objects in the scene: pedestrians and cyclists, and proving that understanding the input data can balance the need for additional sensors or training data.

title: CNN-Based Facial Emotion Recognition for Productivity Analysis in Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)
authors: Adarsh Kushwaha, Kamini Sharma, Amanpreet Kaur, Sonam Bajaj, Rahul Punj
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that is defined by persistent social interaction and communication difficulties, along with limited interests, repetitive activities, and sensory processing differences. ASD individuals tend to have distinct patterns of recognizing, conveying, and reacting to emotions. This paper provides a comparative evaluation of two deep learning methods to facial emotion recognition in autistic children: an adapted DenseNet121 model and a new Hybrid Attention-based Explainable Network (HAXN). Tested on a challenging dataset of 833 facial images for six emotions with extreme class imbalance, our experiments show that although DenseNet121 attains greater overall accuracy (65.33% vs. 61.33%), HAXN exhibits better generalization (72.22% validation accuracy) and offers key model interpretability through built-in attention mechanisms. Both models perform well on the majority joy class (F1 > 0.86) but fail with minority emotions, especially fear (0% F1-score in HAXN). Main conclusions are: (1) traditional CNNs (e.g., DenseNet121) are the current champions on imbalanced emotion classification tasks, over attention-based variants; (2) attention mechanisms allow for clinically actionable model transparency; and (3) extreme class imbalance is still the main bottleneck for autismspecific emotion recognition. This work opens doors to assistive technologies that make trade-offs on accuracy and explainability, and underscores pressing requirements for future minority-class learning work.

title: FuzzyTR Model - Methodological Basis and Use Case in Energy Management
authors: Józef Augustyński, Dariusz Bober, Dariusz Czerwiński, Piotr Kapera, Piotr Miller
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Managing a distributed, multimodal and multicriteria system of interconnected decision-making subsystems requires transparent communication rules. An example of such a system is the modern power grid, where, in addition to classic system power plants, there are many distributed renewable sources, active prosumers, energy storage, electric vehicles, supply virtualization services (virtual power plants, DSR, flexibility service) and forced demand (non-market redistribution of generation constraints) [1]. Currently, power grid management is implemented based on the physical power flow, as well as voltage and frequency control in key system nodes. Exceeding the critical parameters controlled by the security devices results in the immediate shutdown of the affected network node, which in extreme cases can lead to an imbalance between supply and demand, cascading shutdowns of network infrastructure elements, and total blackout. A number of mechanisms are used to balance the network, from planning the operation of controllable power sources, through demand prediction, to DSR and DSM mechanisms. In an era of increasing saturation of the power system with renewable and uncontrollable power sources, these solutions are proving insufficient, as was clearly demonstrated by the blackout in Spain and Portugal, where millions of people were deprived of access to power in practically 3 seconds [2]. Here, the currently applied price mechanism for balancing demand and supply (real-time prices) is too slow to counteract emergency disconnections.The article will present the methodological foundations of the FuzzyTR model and an example of its use in a beverage production company<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>This article is a part of the bigger research project no FENG.01.01-IP.01-A0AH/24-00, being cofounded by the National Centre for Research and Development in Poland. The project title is “Development of an innovative system for managing the energy mix balance in isolated and semi isolated area by using FuzzyTR power mode model”

title: Multi-layer vertex refinement algorithm for online palletization of boxes with varying dimensions
authors: Michał Kaczmarek, Paweł Okuński, Radosław Dębiński, Szymon Kryzel, Tomash Mikulevich, Jan Glinko, Marek S. Tatara, Michał Czubenko
abstract: This paper presents an online palletization algorithm, designed primarily for robotic applications, designed to handle varying-sized boxes in industrial environments. The proposed algorithm leverages the capabilities of articulated robots and 3D camera technology to perform efficient and adaptive palletization. It addresses the significant challenge of accommodating diverse box dimensions through a dynamic, real-time algorithm, that utilizes data from a 3D camera to perceive the size and shape of each incoming box accurately. Subsequently, the robot employs a carefully optimized manipulation strategy to grasp and place boxes on the pallet in an optimal arrangement. The algorithm’s adaptability is emphasized as it continuously refines its palletizing strategy in response to the changing characteristics of incoming boxes. Experimental results emphasize the algorithm’s efficacy, demonstrating an average pallet space utilization between 75.63% and 82.88% for common pallet sizes, with a peak efficiency reaching 92.77%. This research contributes to the evolving field of robotics and automation, offering a versatile solution for palletizing tasks where the box dimensions can vary significantly.

title: Generation of Optimized Digital Surface Model through Deep Learning Technique with High-Resolution UAV Data
authors: Umaid Rafaqat, Muhammad Hamid Ch, Muhammad Hassan Khan, Sami Ullah Khan, Qudsia Gulzar, Urooj Saeed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Understanding the Earth's surface structure is critical for many geospatial processes, yet acquiring proper elevation data remains challenging. Surface elevation estimation from 2D orthomosaic is especially difficult because 2D orthomosaic lacks height information. To deal with this, a Deep learning (DL) based model is developed that predicts Digital Surface Model (DSM) directly from high- resolution orthomosaic. A modified U-Net architecture with residual and dilated convolutional blocks is used to learn the spatial link between visual surface attributes and elevation. The model is trained with drone imagery and corresponding DSM obtained by photogrammetric processing. As the model follows a regression-based approach, a single fixed accuracy value cannot be defined, so when tested on multiple unseen patches, the model achieved an average RMSE of approximately 4–5 meters and an overall accuracy of about 78–80%, demonstrating its reliability and consistency in generating DSM outputs that closely align with ground truth elevation data.

title: Machine Learning-Based Malware Classification in Real-Time IoT Scenarios
authors: Arslan Rafi, Attaullah Buriro, Muhammad Azfar Yaqub, Antonio Liotta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Ensuring the security of future network infrastructures, which include 5G/6G, Internet of Things (IoT) and Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), requires precise identification and detection of malicious/malware families. Although current malware identification methods achieve high accuracy, their validation is largly confined to a narrow range of malware families/samples. Analyses often prioritise families with abundant samples, introducing potential bias and limiting representativeness in classification results. This leads to unreliable detection in real-world heterogeneous network environments. This study addresses the gap by improving malware identification accuracy and robustness through an analysis of dataset size, and class balance, the effect of temporal data augmentation on classifier performance. The study demonstrates that maintaining balanced sample sizes across various malware families significantly improves classifier accuracy by mitigating bias towards majority classes. Our approach leverages state-of-the-art classifiers and two augmentation techniques, Synthetic Data Vault and Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique, to enhance the malware classification, particularly in vulnerable enviornments such as edge networks, ITS and IoT.

title: Behavioral Profiling and AI-Powered Security for IoT Networks in Smart City Environments
authors: Yugandhar Suthari, Karthik Babu Manam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: The accelerated integration of Internet of Things (IoT) devices within smart-city architectures has yielded noticeable gains in operational efficacy and resident well-being. Concomitantly, the same proliferation has rendered attached ecosystems susceptible to increasingly refined cyber attacks. Given the generally open and frequently unregulated characteristics of contemporary IoT networks, surface and attack vectors for malware propagation have widened. In response, this article presents an innovative framework anchored in behavioral analysis and tailors it specifically for the identification of IoT malware within dense metropolitan environments. By assimilating state-of-the-art machine learning methodologies, the framework isolates behavioral anomalies typically consistent with malware interference, thus accommodating the heterogeneous and transitory nature of IoT deployments. Structured around continuous data capture and analytical interrogation, the framework accentuates engineered attributes designed to mirror deviations in operational patterns and in associated network performance variables. Through the supervised application of classification algorithms, the framework achieves pronounced accuracy and operational stability for hostile-traffic scenarios. Conclusive experiments, executed on rigorously standardized datasets, substantiate the framework in discerning legitimate operational baselines from tactical breaches across a spectrum of IoT paradigms. The present inquiry, therefore, not only fortifies the cyber-defensive posture of metropolitan environments but also undergirds a more secure, dependable foundational architecture for communal IoT networks.

title: Bridging Intuition and Intelligence: Managerial Insights on AI-Powered Human Resource Decision-Making in Taiwanese Industries
authors: Idrus Jamalulel, Daniel Hutapea, Melinda, Jovan Hernando, Anfitri Sihombing
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: This study explores the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on human resource (HR) decision-making, specifically focusing on its role in hiring decisions within Taiwanese industries. By conducting a between-subjects experiment with 36 HR professionals, this research compares AI-assisted hiring decisions to traditional, intuition-based methods. Participants were assigned to one of two groups: Group A, which used AI-generated insights to evaluate candidates, and Group B, which relied on resumes and qualitative feedback. The findings reveal that AI-enhanced decision-making significantly improved decision accuracy and efficiency, with Group A achieving higher alignment with expert benchmarks and making faster decisions than Group B. Qualitative interviews highlighted five critical themes: decision quality, fairness, data bias, trust, and cultural consideration. Some are reluctant to fully rely on AI due to its perceived lack of human judgment, which also influences decision-making, suggesting that AI adoption must consider local organizational values. This study contributes to the growing body of literature on AI in HR by emphasizing the importance of human-AI collaboration and providing practical insights into the challenges and opportunities of integrating AI into HR practices.

title: Uplink and Downlink Communications in Segmented Waveguide-Enabled Pinching-Antenna Systems (SWANs)
authors: Chongjun Ouyang, Hao Jiang, Zhaolin Wang, Yuanwei Liu, Zhiguo Ding
abstract: A segmented waveguide-enabled pinching-antenna system (SWAN) is proposed, in which a segmented waveguide composed of multiple short dielectric waveguide segments is employed to radiate or receive signals through the pinching antennas (PAs) deployed on each segment. Based on this architecture, three practical operating protocols are proposed: segment selection (SS), segment aggregation (SA), and segment multiplexing (SM). For uplink SWAN communications, where one PA is activated per segment, the segmented structure eliminates the inter-antenna radiation effect, i.e., signals captured by one PA may re-radiate through other PAs along the same waveguide. This yields a tractable and physically consistent uplink signal model for a multi-PA pinching-antenna system (PASS), which has not been established for conventional PASS using a single long waveguide. Building on this model, PA placement algorithms are proposed to maximize the uplink signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Closed-form expressions for the received SNR under the three protocols are derived, and the corresponding scaling laws with respect to the number of segments are analyzed. It is proven that the segmented architecture reduces both the average PA-to-user distance and the PA-to-feed distance, thereby mitigating both large-scale path loss and in-waveguide propagation loss. These results are extended to downlink SWAN communications, where multiple PAs are activated per segment, and PA placement methods are proposed to maximize the downlink received SNR under the three protocols. Numerical results demonstrate that: i) among the three protocols, SM achieves the best performance, followed by SA and then SS; and ii) for all protocols, the proposed SWAN achieves a higher SNR than conventional PASS with a single long waveguide in both uplink and downlink scenarios.

title: A Robust Deep Learning Approach for State of Charge Estimation: Leveraging LSTM Networks for Real-World Battery Applications
authors: Rezwan Hossain Al Rafi, Zayadul Hasan, Emdadul Haque, Md Abdul Alim Sarker, Sabbir Sarder Munna, Joy Saha, Hasanur Zaman Anonto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: In this paper, we conduct a comprehensive analysis of the state of charge (SOC) assessment, model optimization, and low/medium/high temperature behaviors in a battery modeling and performance evaluation framework. We explore the charge-discharge cycles, voltage ripples, current trends, and temperature behaviors that affect battery efficiencies. The obtained performance of the model is compared with a range between predicted and true value under the circumstances where the temperature is changing. With multiple iterations, RMSE of 0.025 is achieved for the model, again demonstrating better performance than previous models which started to get higher RMSE values. They also tested the performance in extreme temperatures $\left(-10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right.$ and $\left.25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$. The research also proposes a new approach of pruning and projecting that eliminates the combinatorial complexity and keeps the quality of the model. Residuals analysis shows consistent and stable residuals which validate the model and improve their robustness. A confusion matrix analysis in full detail shows the strong holding position of the model on classification with good predictions outside of distribution (OOD) and in-distribution (ID). In conclusion, our work achieves substantial advances in model efficiency, accuracy, and robustness over previous work, enabling nearly real-time use in battery management and energy storage systems.

title: LLM-enhanced Intent-Aware for Proactive Decision Support Services in Industrial Activities_supp1-3650172.pdf
authors: Hongwei Jiang
abstract: The growing complexity of industrial systems demands a transition from passive monitoring to proactive decision support, a shift that hinges on advanced intelligent perception. However, most systems remain confined to brittle, rule-based logic, which operates on fixed symptom-to-action mappings and thus cannot perceive the underlying, context-dependent operational intent. This perceptual gap is particularly detrimental especially in fault diagnosis, where this inability to adapt leads to frequent misdiagnoses and costly downtime. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces the Intent-Aware Enhancement Framework (IAEF)<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>, which replaces static rules by actively creating and reasoning over a dynamic causal model. This is achieved through two core method. The Information Theory-guided Causal Graph Revision (ITCGR) algorithm provides the foundation by constructing a reliable causal model, uniquely leveraging information-theoretic metrics to guide an LLM for verifiable revisions on sparse data. Building on this model, the Multi-scale Adaptive Path Reasoning (MAPR) method then infers the true operational intent, employing a novel adaptive fusion model to robustly navigate complex inference chains. Experimental validation in a real-world case demonstrates the framework’s ability to accurately diagnose fault root causes under varying conditions, a task where traditional systems fail. The proposed approach significantly outperforms baselines, providing a foundational methodology for advancing industrial intelligence.

title: CPFformer: A Hierarchical-Based Graph Modeling Fusion Framework for Making the Emotional Features of Chinese Poetry Pronunciation More Controllable_supp1-3648530.pdf
authors: Qing Wang
abstract: Chinese poetry, a pinnacle of cultural expression, encapsulates human emotions and societal narratives in succinct, evocative language. Its unique blend of linguistic constraints and musicality makes analyzing its pronunciation’s emotional features crucial for enriching children’s linguistic prowess and artistic appreciation. To this end, we propose CPFformer, a novel deep learning framework, merges phonetics, sentiment analysis in order to analyze and predict the emotional feature of Chinese poetry pronunciation effectively. CPFformer, which consists of anomaly detection in spatial network (ADSN), spatial–temporal learning (STL), dimension segmentation and embedding (DSW), extraction of temporal attention (ETA), and encoder-decoder module (EDSM) modules, employs graph structures to capture the global and local consistency of emotional features across spatial and temporal, and a multiscale Mel feature extraction technique ensures comprehensive analysis of speech dynamics, enhancing emotional expression understanding. The mean square error (mse), mean absolute error (MAE), residual standard error (RSE), and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-square (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$R^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of experiments reach 0.3572, 0.2486, 0.2014, and 0.9822, respectively, demonstrating its feasibility and effectiveness, exhibiting its superiority to the state-of-the-art approaches. The creation of a dedicated Chinese poetry pronunciation dataset marks a significant contribution, facilitating further research. The potential of CPFformer in speech technology and education heralds a new era, fostering the integration of traditional culture and artificial intelligence, and promoting the advancement of emotional literacy and smart learning environments. Its interdisciplinary implications promise exciting avenues for research and application.

title: Design and Test of MEMS Setback Arming Device for Fuze
authors: Yu Qin, Yuenan Li, Yuan Liu, Dexin Che, Xiannan Zou, Xiaogang Ma
abstract: To address the structural strength issues in the setback arming devices of existing fuze MEMS, a "hook-shaped" setback arming device was designed. Finite element simulations, simulation tests, and projectile-borne tests were performed on the proposed device. Results demonstrate that this setback arming device improves structural strength and locking reliability. It can withstand a maximum overload of 17000 g during service processing and requires a minimum overload of 1500 g to achieve safety release at the launch stage.

title: Establishment and Uncertainty Analysis of Dynamic Model of Thermocouple Sensor under Laser Pulse Excitation
authors: Yanfeng Li, Jia Li, Zhijie Zhang, Xuejie Wei, Wanjun Li
abstract: Dynamic calibration is essential for reducing measurement errors when using thermocouple sensors for dynamic temperature measurement. This paper proposes and implements a complete analytical framework encompassing time-domain dynamic calibration to frequency-domain uncertainty quantification. A laser-based dynamic calibration system was employed, and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm was used to identify the parameters of the thermocouple dynamic model, with its parameter configuration systematically investigated. A K-type thermocouple was dynamically calibrated to validate the proposed method. The innovation of this framework lies not only in obtaining the optimal dynamic model but, more importantly, in the systematic propagation of the statistical uncertainty of the model coefficients to the sensor’s frequency-domain characteristics, which enables the quantification of confidence intervals for the dynamic response. Furthermore, the impact of frequency-domain uncertainty on time-domain waveform reconstruction fidelity was analyzed, and based on this, the usable dynamic bandwidth of the sensor was defined. This approach provides a comprehensive analysis tool for evaluating the dynamic performance and reliable application of thermocouples.

title: Comparing Feedback Practices in Higher Education: Perspectives from Academics and Students in the UK and Saudi Arabia
authors: Eyman Alyahyan, Mireilla Bikanga Ada, Jake Lever
abstract: This full research paper compares the perspectives of academics and students on feedback practices in computer science higher education across two distinct contexts: the United Kingdom (UK) and Saudi Arabia (KSA). The study examines the frequency of feedback types, delivery preferences, current practices, and student engagement and interest in feedback. A mixed methods approach was used with 340 participants (students: 186 KSA, 67 UK; academics: 72 KSA, 15 UK), using questionnaires available in both English and Arabic. The results indicate that summative feedback is the most common, with a general preference for electronic textual formats. KSA feedback was viewed as more encouraging, while the UK feedback emphasized clarity and alignment with the assessment criteria. However, detailed feedback was often lacking. Mann-Whitney <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$U$</tex> tests revealed significant differences <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(p<0.05)$</tex> in perceived current practices and engagement. KSA instructors rated their practices more positively than the UK instructors and their students. Additionally, students and instructors in both regions differed in how they perceived student engagement with feedback. Qualitative analysis identified four key challenges: feedback quality, communication barriers, fairness concerns, and time constraints. These findings underscore the role of cultural and institutional contexts and point to the need for inclusive and improvement-oriented feedback systems. The study also offers pedagogical insights to support a more effective feedback design in CS education.

title: Improving Student Engagement in Online Courses Through Team-Based Learning
authors: Arko Barman
abstract: In this Research-to-Practice Full Paper, we describe the design and implementation of team-based learning activities in two online courses designed using a flipped classroom setting to improve student engagement. Student engagement, particularly in online courses, is often viewed as a challenge. To address this problem, we introduced two team-based learning assignments - a literature review and a final project - in two online graduate-level master's courses. Both these assignments were designed to enhance agentic, cognitive, behavioral, and emotional engagement in students by addressing the three universal human needs in self-determination theory - autonomy, competence, and relatedness. Further, it was envisaged that these activities would benefit students through collaborative learning, peer learning, and improved emotional and psychological well-being. The design of our team-based learning activities also focused on open inquiry, the highest level of inquiry-based learning. For each of these activities, the student teams proposed their research question, reviewed relevant literature, performed relevant experiments as needed, and prepared a report detailing their findings and comparative evaluations of methods and models. We measured the effect of these activities on student engagement through feedback collected from the students using a student engagement questionnaire adapted for the structure of our online learning courses. Survey results and instructor experiences show a marked improvement in student engagement across all the different aspects of engagement.

title: WIP: Undergraduate Research Platforms for Promoting ECE Career-Connected Learning to High School Juniors and Seniors
authors: Wookwon Lee
abstract: This Innovative Practice WIP paper presents three undergraduate research platforms, i.e., a high-altitude ballooning system, a 1/5th-scale autonomous vehicle, and a heavy-lift drone as the physical platforms to promote career-connected learning at high schools. Intended to promote college education in the fields of electrical and computer engineering, our current effort with a school district is described, providing obstacles and challenges to overcome for a better facilitation of hands-on experiential activities and motivation to pursue post-secondary education in STEM fields.

title: Understanding Evolving Sentiment Dynamics in Indonesian Disaster-Related Tweets using IndoBERT and Temporal Analysis
authors: Nico Valerian Marcello, Frederick Nicholas Su, Henry Lucky, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: Social media platforms generate massive amounts of unstructured data which provide valuable insights into public sentiments in crisis situations. While previous research has demonstrated its value for either sentiment analysis or topic detection, there are still ways to utilize this data by combining these approaches. This study aims to build upon this by integrating aspect-sentiment analysis to capture more detailed and nuanced views often overlooked in disaster contexts. A dataset of 4,506 tweets collected from July 2023 to March 2025 were analyzed with a fine-tuned indobenchmark/indobert-base-p1 model and was able to categorize tweets into different topics and sentiments, uncovering sentiment patterns such as negative sentiments towards response efforts indicating public dissatisfaction or issues with aid. The aspect classifier achieved a weighted F1-score of 0.73, while the sentiment model reached 0.81 F1-score. This comprehensive approach provides deep insights into the public perception of various topics which can enable authorities to better understand public needs and concerns.

title: Advancements And Performance Analysis of Q-Dots Based Quantum Radar Technology for RF Stealth Target Identification
authors: Deepak Vats, Vishal Srivastava, Vasudev Grover
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: This Paper examines novel approach the advancements in Q-dots based quantum radar technology, design considerations for its integration, and quantum radar cross section (QRCS) based on interferometric and quantum electrodynamics. In addition to performing standard target detection and recognition duties, quantum radar systems with quantum measurement assistance may also detect and identify RF stealth platforms and missile systems. In numerous fields of study, the advancement of radar technology is crucial. A quantum radar is a notion that has been developed that uses photon quantum states to gather information about a distant target. A single photon or a small group of photons is directed in the direction of the target. The target absorbs the photons, which are then re-emitted into the receiver. There are two possible approaches to carrying out the measurement procedure. An interferometric analysis can be performed.one can either count the number of photons that return or perform a measurement (or phase measurement) on the photon. Since the latter technique is called Quantum Illumination, the former is called Interferometric Quantum Radar. Entangled states or stationary quantum states of photons can be used for either of those techniques. Entangled states have been demonstrated to offer the best resolution enhancement, reaching the optimum situation. Compared to classical approaches, the advantage of adopting quantum states is that they show more degrees of correlation via which information can be obtained. These additional correlations, sometimes referred to as quantum correlations, increase the radar system's potential resolution and signal/noise ratio (SNR). Relationship research between the two photons is conducted in order to gather data. Coherent state quantum radar relies on coherent state photons and a quantum detection technique to overcome the diffraction limit. The design and operating concepts of quantum applied trends are also reviewed in this work.

title: A Digital Public Health Platform for Combating Isolation and Loneliness
authors: Prasad S, Rehanna Parveen A, Yazhini S, E. P. Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The solution to fight the issue of isolation and loneliness is the Integration platform that acts as an online intervention to combat the social aspect of loneliness and isolation particularly among depressed people. The platform provides customized recommendations in the form of interactive modules which consist of films, music and games based on mood, physical exercises and yoga, food and hygiene recommendations based on photo analysis and chatbots recommendations. It also provides live interactive meetings with psychiatrists and mental health care resource center. The live analysis will offer further customization in the extent of making the site an end to end emotional health and community supporting services.

title: WIP: Assessing the Use of GenAI to Foster Algorithmic Thinking in an Introductory Engineering Course
authors: Juan D. Ortega-Alvarez, Campbell R. Bego, Andres Nieto Leal
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper focuses on algorithmic thinking and GenAI use for programming within a first-year engineering course. In introductory programming courses, students may use GenAI to generate correct solutions without fully engaging in the assignments, thus circumventing the learning process. But students may also engage with GenAI in ways that improve their algorithmic thinking ability. Research is needed to understand whether and how GenAI can be integrated to improve first-year engineering students' programming skills. A necessary first step in this direction is establishing relevant competencies and assessments. In Fall 2024, students in an introductory engineering course at Virginia Tech were permitted to use GenAI within fair use conditions. At the end of the semester, students responded to two instruments: 1) an anonymous survey asking whether and how they used GenAI to submit assignments during the programming unit of the course, and 2) a simplified version of an existing algorithmic thinking instrument. Preliminary findings indicate that around 70% of students reported using GenAI to assist with programming assignments without explicit guidance, though over 80% characterized this use as occasional. More than 75% of students reported using GenAI primarily for syntax assistance. The algorithmic thinking results suggest substantial variability in skill level across students, regardless of their self-reported programming experience. This study suggests that algorithmic thinking, as measured by an abbreviated scale in introductory programming courses, may not correlate with other desirable programming outcomes, like assignment performance, and additional measures may be needed to evaluate the impact of GenAI.
