title: Privacy Preserving of Multi-Party Multiplication Based on Multi-Layer (K, N) Threshold Secret Sharing
authors: Jing Wang, Yuan Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: In cloud analytics applications, $(k, n)$ threshold secret sharing as an important technique in secure multi-party computation, allows a group of participants to compute without revealing their information. While traditional $(k, n)$ threshold secret sharing multiplication sub-protocols are often accompanied by a large number of interactions and communications, which greatly increases their runtime in multiparty secure computation. In this paper, we propose a multi-layer ($k, n$) threshold secret sharing scheme based on access tree structure, which not only realizes the ($k, n$) threshold secret sharing multiplication subprotocol without interaction, but also realizes the multi-layer joint computation of secret values. We clearly evaluate our method in terms of computation, communication, and number of rounds. The results show that our experimental results outperform the existing secret sharing schemes. This is important for operations such as exponential functions that are commonly used in domains including deep learning.

title: Bayesian Network-Based Attention Mechanism for Data Fusion in ADAS Vehicular Scenario
authors: Lakshmaiya N, Seeniappan Kaliappan, M. Muthukannan, T. Roseline Velankanni, Ramya M
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Rising demands in the vehicular technology highly impact the safety measurement and comfort of the driver systems. The Advanced Driver Assistance System is one of the intelligent technologies that considers various sensor information from both internal and external scenarios of the vehicle to make an accurate safety decision. As multiple sensors are involved in ADAS, it is essential to have a unified representation of all the sensed data, prioritising the sensor that provides the highest correlating information for that particular scenario. Based on this objective, this paper proposes a Bayesian network-based attention mechanism for ADAS in the vehicular scenario. The Bayesian network effectively obtains the posterior probability of the feature based on probabilities from the multimodal sensors. Using these probabilities, the attention weights are provided that capture the sensor with highly correlated data. Based on this fusion, the proposed work exhibits an 8% minor deviation due to overestimation when evaluated using the KITTI dataset.

title: Virtual-Force Based Visual Servo for Multiple Peg-in-Hole Assembly With Tightly Coupled Multi-Manipulator_supp1-3653374.mp4
authors: Chengchao Bai
abstract: Multiple Peg-in-Hole (MPiH) assembly is one of the fundamental tasks in robotic assembly. In the MPiH tasks for large-size parts, it is challenging for a single manipulator to simultaneously align multiple distant pegs and holes, necessitating tightly coupled multi-manipulator systems. For such MPiH tasks using tightly coupled multiple manipulators, we propose a collaborative visual servo control framework that uses only the monocular in-hand cameras of each manipulator to reduce positioning errors. Initially, we train a state classification neural network and a positioning neural network. The former divides the states of the peg and hole in the image into three categories: obscured, separated, and overlapped, while the latter determines the position of the peg and hole in the image. Based on these findings, we propose a method to integrate the visual features of multiple manipulators using virtual forces, which can naturally combine with the cooperative controller of the multi-manipulator system. To generalize our approach to holes of different appearances, we varied the appearance of the holes during the dataset generation process. The results confirm that by considering the appearance of the holes, classification accuracy and positioning precision can be improved. Finally, the results show that our method achieves 100% success rate in dual-manipulator dual peg-in-hole tasks with a clearance of 0.2 mm, while robust to camera calibration errors.

title: Adaptive Metamaterial-Based Patch Antenna for Secure and Reliable UAV Communication in Defense and Disaster Response
authors: Sathish Kumar Danasegaran, Pavithra V, Preethi S, Ranjitha T, Raksanasri S, Dhanasekar S
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are relevant in the new surveillance and management disaster interventions conducted within the defense where there are secure and reliable communication channels that are required to improve the real-time functionality of the missions. Microstrip patch antenna based on adaptive, metamaterials are thus developed to improve radiation performance, directivity and electromagnetic stability in an attempt to meet these needs. The suggested antenna is a metamaterial hexagonal patch to provide improved confinement of the field, enhancement of the gain and matching impedance. The antenna has a resonant frequency of 4.5 GHz with a return loss of 4.5 GHz −43.93 dB and VSWR of 1.012. The peak gain of the far-field analysis is 9.52 dB and directivity of 10.1 dBi that are effective and directed radiations with minimum sidelobe interferences. The design has been structured to provide a small yet effective and secure system of communication in the defense and disaster management activities at the UAV.

title: Short-Term Electricity Revenue Prediction Based on Ensemble Learning Models
authors: Shaohong Lin, Yan Weng, Lingyan Xu, Fan Yang, Wei Yan, Wanqi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: As the primary source of revenue for power companies, accurate prediction of electricity charge income is helpful to improve the lean level of capital management of electric power companies. In view of the difficulty in forecasting electricity tariff revenue due to its complex structure and many influencing factors, this paper first screened $\mathbf{1 6}$ potential factors affecting electricity tariff fund inflow from three aspects: temperature, holidays and electricity sales. Subsequently, XGBoost is employed to identify and filter important features, eliminating ineffective and redundant ones to enhance model accuracy. Finally, an ensemble learning strategy combining FCNN, XGBoost, and RF is proposed for electricity revenue prediction. Comparative and ablation experiments were conducted to evaluate the model. The results demonstrate that the proposed ensemble learning model outperforms single models, thereby validating the effectiveness of the FCNN-XGBoost-RF ensemble model.

title: Multi-Objective Collaborative Optimization and Simulation of Intelligent Home Appliance Warehousing Based on Bi-Level Integer Programming
authors: Mengya Zhang, Xueyan Li, Ruiqi Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Currently, purchasing home appliances online has become mainstream. As consumers’ expectations for timely delivery of home appliance products continue to rise, there is an urgent need to enhance the efficiency of logistics warehousing operations and the timeliness of outbound delivery. This study addresses bottleneck issues such as redundant picking paths and equipment collaborative scheduling conflicts in regional distribution centers of the home appliance industry. By integrating theories of intelligent manufacturing and smart logistics, a collaborative optimization framework that combines bi-level integer programming and simulation verification is proposed. Firstly, a bi-level integer programming model that integrates dynamic slot allocation, equipment collaborative scheduling, and path optimization is constructed. Furthermore, combined with discrete event simulation technology, system performance under different order sizes and working conditions is simulated and analyzed. Experimental results show that both on-time delivery rate and order processing efficiency have been improved. This research provides theoretical support and practical solutions for the efficient, low-cost, and robust operation of intelligent warehousing systems.

title: Energy-Efficiency-Aware Fixed-Time Consensus Control for Distributed PMSM Systems
authors: Zeyi Liu, Huaguang Zhang, Jiayue Sun, Zhihong Liang
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative Energy-Efficiency-Aware Fixed-Time (EEAFT) control strategy for distributed permanent-magnet synchronous motor systems. The primary contribution is achieving rapid, precise speed consensus while effectively balancing energy consumption against consensus error, a challenge often overlooked in fixed-time (FxT) control designs. A key novelty lies in the introduction of a real-time reward mechanism, uniquely derived from low-pass filtering both the system's consensus error and the control input signals. This adaptive reward function dynamically adjusts the upper bound on convergence time. When the convergence time becomes excessively stringent, a substantial increase in control effort is required. This can lead to energy spikes and hardware overload. To mitigate these risks, the bound on convergence time is then relaxed. Conversely, when large consensus errors necessitate an accelerated response, the bound on convergence time is tightened to expedite error correction. To enhance robustness against unmodeled friction, winding losses, and external disturbances, a fuzzy logic system is employed to approximate unknown nonlinear dynamics, while a disturbance observer compensates for residual errors. Rigorous theoretical analysis confirms the boundedness of all system signals and guarantees FxT convergence under the proposed EEAFT framework. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the EEAFT-based controller, showcasing high-precision speed synchronization across multiple motors and achieving an improved trade-off between rapid transient response and overall energy efficiency.

title: WIP: Fostering Ethical Judgment in Undergraduate Engineering Students Through Problem-Based Ethics Instruction
authors: Opanuga Toluwalase, Heidi A. Diefes-Dux
abstract: This research WIP paper explores the integration of ethics instruction in an undergraduate engineering course. Engineering students must cultivate ethical responsibility because engineering work affects societies, economies, and technological progress. However, engineering students may have limited opportunity to cultivate ethical responsibility for their future engineering practice because ethics instruction is often not well integrated within the engineering curriculum. Ethics instruction was implemented through problem-based learning (PBL) strategies to foster engineering students' ethical judgement development during complex problem solving. This study took place in a junior-level environmental engineering course at a Midwestern university in the United States. Twenty-one undergraduate students participated in the study. Ethics instruction was delivered in four modules - each entailing lectures, team (in-class) and individual (homework) ethical problem-solving activities. Students submitted work and their responses to a survey on team interaction were collected after each team activity. The students' work was analyzed using deductive content analysis informed by the Systems Thinking Framework. Analysis of the team interaction survey was guided by the Social Constructivism Model of Ethical Decision Making and supplemented with statistical analysis. Anticipated findings will include emergent themes from a holistic analysis of students' work and insights into students' perceptions of team interactions during class activities, both at the team and class levels. These findings may offer engineering instructors research-informed guidance for embedding ethics instruction into engineering courses, with the goal of preparing professionals equipped with sound ethical judgment skills for industry and society.

title: How Risky Is It? A Closer Look at Game Anti-Cheat Software
authors: Amanda Viescinski, Tiago Heinrich, Vinicius Fulber-Garcia, Carlos Maziero
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Anti-cheat software is a system designed to detect cheats (or hacks) in a video game. This paper investigates operations executed by anti-cheat software and their impact on user privacy. We collected data and analyzed three popular anticheat solutions: BattlEye, FACEIT, and Vanguard. Our analysis reveals that these programs interact with system files, memory, and users’ directories. In addition, the privileged access of these anti-cheat solutions to the operating system and the lack of clarity on what data is collected directly affect user privacy. This conduct risks not complying with current regulations.

title: Android-Based Information System for Monitoring Heart Condition
authors: Qanita Khaerunissa, Norma Hermawan, Nada Fitrieyatul Hikmah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Valvular heart disease (VHD) is a type of cardiovascular disease (CVD) that is often asymptomatic in its early stages, resulting in delays in detection and treatment that risk causing serious damage to health. According to data from the WHO in 2019, approximately 17.9 million people died from cardiovascular disease, accounting for 32.9% of total global deaths, and VHD caused 2% of those deaths. The “HeartBeat” application is an Android application designed to support telemonitoring of heart health conditions and display the results of heart valve disease classification. The development is carried out using the Kotlin programming language, with the backend built using Laravel and MySQL as a database. Application testing was carried out with user acceptance testing using the System Usability Scale (SUS) method with 19 subjects, and an SUS score with an average of 87.11 in the excellent category, which indicates a high level of application usability.

title: Prediction in Shopping Apps: A Study on 1D CNN, Random Forest, ANN, and Hybrid Ensemble Performance
authors: Andrew Gregory Winata, Jason, Visella, Nikita Ananda Putri Masaling, Andry Chowanda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: With the dynamic world of e-commerce, accurate price prediction is the key to improved customer satisfaction and improved pricing strategy. Traditional statistical methods are unable to cope with quick changes in markets, demanding flexible, data-driven methods. While some machine learning models like Random Forest, ANN, and 1D CNN have been individually applied to predict prices, there are not many studies comparing their relative performances and the efficacy of applying them in a hybrid ensemble model. This study bridges this gap by comparing and evaluating these three models with a hybrid ensemble method that enhances their performance. Using historical food data from the year 2007 to 2024, all the models were tested and trained in a uniform setting. All the models were exceedingly predictive ($\mathbf{R}^{2} \lt 0.95$), with the Hybrid Ensemble being top in performance ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 9 8 7 6}$), showing its capability to minimize errors and increase robustness.

title: Blockchain and Federated Learning Integration for Secure IoT and Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Deven Chawla, Dipen Chawla, Anurag Shrivastava, Myasar Mundher Adnan, B. Sireesha, Irfan Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) and Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) has ushered in an era of unprecedented data generation and automation. However, this interconnectivity introduces profound security and privacy challenges, particularly concerning the centralized aggregation of sensitive data for machine learning model training. Traditional cloud-centric approaches are vulnerable to single points of failure, data breaches, and privacy infringements. This paper investigates the synergistic integration of two transformative technologies-Blockchain and Federated Learning (FL)-as a robust framework to address these critical shortcomings. Federated Learning enables the collaborative training of machine learning models across distributed devices without centralizing raw data, thereby preserving data locality and privacy. Blockchain technology complements this by providing a decentralized, immutable, and transparent ledger to orchestrate the FL process securely. It facilitates trustworthy model aggregation, verifiable participant contribution, and resilient consensus mechanisms, mitigating risks such as model poisoning and malicious node attacks. The integration establishes a verifiable and auditable trail for all transactions within the FL lifecycle, from participant selection to global model updates. This research delineates the architectural principles of this integration, analyzes its efficacy in enhancing security and privacy for IoT and CPS, and discusses prevailing challenges and future research trajectories aimed at realizing a secure and trustworthy intelligent infrastructure.

title: Semantic Segmentation Using Open3D for LiDAR-Camera Based Scene Understanding
authors: Aarti Vagga, Bharati Dixit
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Semantic segmentation plays a key role for real-time scene understanding in autonomous vehicles or self-driving cars, especially when navigating complex or adverse environments. This paper presents a holistic approach to semantic segmentation of urban driving scenes using camera and LiDAR data, with a focus on sensor fusion and deep learning techniques. The research utilizes the Audi A2D2, Waymo, nuScence, Kitti, Dense, A*3D dataset and Open3D for point cloud visualization and processing. We also present a detailed methodology for data preprocessing, model implementation, visualization, and accuracy evaluation using Jaccard Index, Intersection over Union (IoU) or and Dice Coefficient. Our experiments show that LiDAR and camera data fusion significantly improves segmentation accuracy in diverse driving conditions.

title: Notes on Directional Antenna Alignment Strategies for Neighbor Discovery
authors: Robert E. Hiromoto, Brain Abaah Djitornu
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In this paper we explore probabilistic and deterministic alignment strategies employed by directional antennas in neighbor discovery. Our goal is not to develop optimal discovery time solutions but instead to gain an understanding of scanning strategies that result in misalignments between the transmitter and receiver nodes, resulting in unbounded delays in neighbor discovery time. In one instance, we derive a simple analytical formula for a deterministic, heterogenous antenna scanning strategy whose result are incorrectly reported in the literature. Using this result, a wellknown scanning strategy for neighbor discovery, characterized by its energy conserving property, is extended to encompass a mixture of neighbor nodes with heterogenous numbers of directional antennas.

title: Hybrid Integration of CNN and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks for Multispectral Image Super-Resolution_supp1-3652301.docx
authors: Meihua Bi
abstract: This letter proposes KAN-MSI-SR (KMSR), a novel deep learning framework for multispectral image super-resolution that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs). The model employs a KAN-Block to enhance nonlinear spectral-spatial representation, combined with CNNs for local feature extraction. Supported by channel weighting, residual connections, and global skip links, the approach effectively improves reconstruction accuracy and spectral consistency. Experiments on Sentinel-2 imagery demonstrate that KMSR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both quantitative metrics and visual quality, providing a robust and efficient solution for Multispectral imagery (MSI) super-resolution.

title: Augmented Tank-Based Control Guarantees Passive Individual Interaction Environment for Multi-User Haptic-Enabled Robotic Systems_supp3-3651680.mp4
authors: Mingming Zhang
abstract: Despite extensive investigations into the multi-user haptic-enabled robotic system (M-Hers), achieving scalable control design in the presence of non-passive human operators remains a key challenge. This is primarily due to the increasing complexity of stability conditions and interaction coupling as the number of operators grows. In this study, we address this challenge in two steps. First, we introduce the individual interaction environment (IIE) to isolate the passivity violations, which facilitates the independent control design for each human-robot subsystem, thereby enhancing the scalability with respect to the number of subsystems. Second, within the IIE framework, we identify passivity-violating components caused by partners' active behaviors and propose a novel augmented tank-based controller (ATBC) to guarantee passive IIE while maintaining high rendering accuracy. Specifically, the ATBC employs an energy-related power regulation strategy to enhance interaction safety and a time-varying control gain to mitigate the negative effects of power regulation on rendering fidelity. We validated the proposed method through collaborative haptic tasks on a customized M-Hers composed of three robots in four different scenarios. Comparative studies demonstrate that our approach effectively ensures IIE passivity in the presence of active human behaviors, while ensuring high reproducibility and achieving a favorable balance between passivity and rendering accuracy.

title: Real-Time American Sign Language Recognition Using EfficientNetV2S: A Transfer Learning Approach with Webcam-Based Interface
authors: Andino Fiallos Diego Miguel, Ali Faisal, Talha Ali Khan, Raja Hashim Ali, Shan Faiz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Communication barriers between deaf individuals and non-signers represent a significant accessibility challenge, with over 430 million people worldwide relying on sign language as their primary communication method. Existing automated sign language recognition systems often lack practical real-world deployment capabilities, focusing primarily on controlled dataset performance rather than operational usability in everyday environments. We developed a real-time American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter utilizing EfficientNetV2S with transfer learning for static hand gesture classification. The system processes live webcam input through a Streamlit-based interface featuring dual text feedback for prediction validation. Training employed the ASL Alphabet Dataset containing 28 gesture classes, with standard 80/20 train-validation splitting across 10 epochs. We conducted systematic evaluation across three critical deployment variables: camera orientation angles, background clutter levels, and skin tone variations to assess real-world robustness. The model achieved over 90% accuracy in controlled real-time scenarios with minimal skin tone sensitivity, demonstrating shape-based feature learning rather than color dependency. However, performance degraded significantly with camera side angles (20% accuracy drop) due to gesture distortion, and high background clutter required 6 to 12 prediction attempts versus 1 to 2 attempts in clean environments. The webcam-based interface with transparent prediction feedback demonstrates promising accessibility potential, though deployment requires controlled environments with frontal camera positioning and minimal background interference.

title: PYNQ-Based Testbed for the Evaluation of FPGA-Based Synthetic Instruments
authors: Peter Schulz, W. A. Ahmed Noman, M. Anas Rabbani
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Getting to grips with a ‘real’ measuring device is often intuitive via a user interface. This access is missing with a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA)-based synthetic instrument (SI) which is deeply embedded inside an FPGA chip. While software-implemented synthetic instruments may be easy to embed in a software environment, the test engineer may find it difficult to deal with FPGA tools. This poses a challenge for the integration of an SI as thirdparty Intellectual Property (IP) as well as for one that is under development in-house. Test engineers are often familiar with scripting languages such as Python. A Python environment provides a variety of tools and methods for evaluating measurement data. To bridge the gap between the Python world and FPGA-based SI, we propose a testbed based on a Zynq device from Advanced Micro Devices (AMD). There, the Python environment runs on a processor core and can load SI configurations into the FPGA fabric, execute them there, and subsequently communicate with the instrument. This approach is supported by AMD’s “Python Productivity for Zynq” (PYNQ) environment. The solution described here is related to the publicly funded research program OpenCPTS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>|, which establishes an open-software/open-hardware community for FPGA-based lowcost test systems. The test environment for SIs provides a uniform reference that supports information exchange within the community.

title: iAthena: Research Challenges in the Use of Persuasive Technologies to Monitor People with Depressive Disorder
authors: Fernanda P. Mota, Daniel Capua, Adriana Da S. Pinto, Regina Barwaldt, Adenauer C. Yamin
abstract: This article aims to identify research related to the use of persuasive technologies with the help of the Internet of Things for monitoring people with depression. For that, a general research was carried out, whose processes used for its conception are based on a research methodology known as Systematic Literature Review (SLR). The SLR has a series of steps that help in the literature review of an area of interest; that is, it helps in the identification of articles that contain subjects similar to the research topic.

title: A Trust Assessment Method for Intelligent Connected Vehicles Based on Data Consistency Verification Matched with Adaptive Leader Election in a Zero-Trust Framework
authors: Darong Huang, Liangyu Zhang, Yuhong Na, Fawen Bu, Zhongmei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The use of intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) is an emerging concept in transportation systems, where the platoon leader processes various types of information from followers and roadside units to make accurate decisions. However, in complex network environments, the leader election process can become complicated and inefficient due to potential network attacks and abnormal node behaviours. To address this challenge, this paper presents a leader vehicle election mechanism based on dynamic trust assessment within a zero-trust framework. The proposed mechanism comprises two key components: dynamic trust assessment and adaptive leader election. The dynamic trust assessment method involves a trust evaluation mechanism composed of direct trust assessment and recommendation trust assessment based on the state information of vehicle nodes, where the dynamic trust assessment results are adjusted according to node behaviour information. The leader election mechanism involves periodic elections among the vehicle nodes on the basis of the results of the dynamic trust assessment, in which the vehicle node with the most votes is selected as the leader. Through comparative experiments against a full trust scenario, the proposed method demonstrates superior performance in resisting network attacks and identifying abnormal nodes, thereby significantly improving the safety, stability, and operational efficiency of the vehicle platoon.

title: General-Purpose QC-LDPC Processor for Error-Correction Performance Evaluation
authors: Kangjoon Choi, Jongmin Baek, In-Cheol Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper introduces a general-purpose quasi-cyclic (QC)-low-density parity-check (LDPC) processor (GPLP) developed to evaluate LDPC decoding performance, which is a highly flexible and programmable field programmable gate array (FPGA)-based simulation platform. The GPLP enables to configure LDPC decoding processes, depending on the decoding algorithms and design choices to be simulated and verified. In contrast to traditional FPGA-based approaches, which typically rely on a fixed dataflow, the GPLP offers a reconfigurable, processor-like environment that can be programmed for various design configurations. This paper defines essential atomic operations required for QC-LDPC decoding and proposes the GPLP architecture supporting those operations with vector-based processing. The proposed GPLP significantly enhances simulation speed, providing a performance improvement of 220x to 574x over CPU-based simulations. The platform provides a unique combination of simulation speed, flexibility, and reconfigurability, making it an invaluable tool to rapidly evaluate and optimize LDPC decoding performance.

title: PerSemCom: A Personalized Semantic Communication Framework for Speech Transmission
authors: Kaiwen Tan, Haitao Zhao, Li Zhou, Yichi Zhang, Jun Xiong, Yuyuan Zhang, Haijun Zhang, Jibo Wei
abstract: By focusing on the intrinsic meaning of information, semantic communication (SemCom) marks a fundamental paradigm shift from physical bit transmission to personalized semantic service. Considering the importance of personalized features related to the speaker in speech for source recovery and understanding, we propose a semantic-driven framework for personalized speech transmission, named PerSemCom, which combines speaker acoustic features with semantic information. Specifically, we first introduce an efficient semantic extraction mechanism to achieve the conversion from speech to text transcriptions, and design a semantic corrector coupled with multi-domain knowledge to mitigate the effects of wireless channel distortion. Building upon the reliable transcriptions at receiver, we further establish a speaker embedding vector knowledge base and achieve high-fidelity speech reconstruction through quantitative modeling of speaker-specific acoustic features. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our proposed framework outperforms existing schemes in terms of subjective perception at harsh channel conditions. Complexity analysis and latency measurements also show competitive advantages in computational efficiency and real-time capabilities. Reconstructed personalized speech samples have been publicly available at https://kwtankw.github.io/PerSemCom/.

title: Quasi-Passive Vertical Compensation for Accurate 6-DOF Physical Simulation of Microgravity Collision During Landing on Small Celestial Body
authors: Rui Zhou, Weijie Hou, Lifeng Fu, Hui Chen, Xuedong Chen, Wei Jiang
abstract: Exploring small celestial bodies, such as asteroids, opens new avenues for space exploration, complementing lunar and Martian missions. However, the microgravity environment (∼10−5g) presents significant challenges, particularly for landing. Accurate prelaunch testing of mechanical and control systems is crucial to ensure mission success. Therefore, the ground-based microgravity physical simulation is essential, particularly for accurately replicating its microgravity collision response. However, existing microgravity simulations fail to accurately replicate landing collision response, particularly in the vertical direction. In this article, an air-bearing simulation system with quasi-passive vertical compensation is presented, enabling 6-DOF simulation. The vertical compensation integrates a quasi-zero stiffness unit for passive gravity compensation, complemented by an active following mechanism for extended compensation stroke. The controller is specifically adjusted to generate the vertical virtual mass, ensuring equal added mass in all three directions and eliminating systematic errors. Vertical tests confirm that the system effectively simulates free-floating conditions for the lander simulator up to 1 ton and accurately responds to forces as small as 1 N. The proposed 6-DOF physical simulation system provides a novel technical approach and has been implemented in the ground verification of the Tianwen-2 exploration mission.

title: GraphSTAR: Proximal Operator-Based Graph Neural Network Enhanced by Dynamic Graph Aggregation for Spatial Transcriptomics_supp1-3644379.pdf
authors: Hongmin Cai
abstract: Spatial transcriptomics technologies carry out advanced sequencing analysis of molecular profiles with a spatial context, providing multi-source information essential for elucidating biological regulatory mechanisms. Nonetheless, it poses challenges in the integration of raw spatial coordinates with high-dimensional gene expression profiles in their native feature space. While spatial-aware methods effectively aggregate molecular information from local spatial neighborhoods, they fail to explore the long-range relationships associated with gene expression data. To address this issue, this paper introduces a novel approach termed GraphSTAR that encodes both spatial and gene expression data into undirected graphs, characterizing the local spatial proximity and global transcriptional similarity, respectively. Through a graph aggregation process, GraphSTAR integrates these diverse data sources within a joint graph structure, effectively modeling both local neighborhood relationships and long-range functional associations. Subsequently, a reassembled graph neural network is established by incorporating the graph aggregation into the feed-forward propagation using proximal operators, progressively refining spatial-informed latent representation to decipher spatial expression patterns of genes. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphSTAR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both spatial domain identification and cell-type annotation tasks.

title: The Impact of a GenAI Integration on First-Year Engineering Students' Programming Outcomes
authors: Udit K. Das, Makenzie S. Yates, Kristina A. Bloch, Lilly Hagan, Elisabeth L. Thomas, Gabe Gatos, Alwin K. Rajkumar, Benarji Valavala, Seth Franco, Sudheer K. Divvela, Angela K. Thompson, Campbell R. Bego
abstract: This full-length research study compares first-year engineering student performance on a summative programming assignment before and after integrating Generative AI (GenAI) into the assignment. The code-writing capabilities of GenAI technology can potentially help introductory engineering students with programming. However, the limitations of GenAI, especially its tendency to produce hallucinations, might confuse and/or overwhelm novice programmers. Using a quasi-experimental design, we compared student performance on a final programming project from two consecutive years: one without GenAI support (2022) and one with a guided GenAI integration (2023). The assignment was such that GenAI tools were not likely to complete it correctly solely from the written instructions, and thus students were required to think critically about both programming and GenAI to develop a successful program. Student-submitted programs were evaluated in terms of program accuracy, communication, and functionality using a scoring rubric. It was anticipated that GenAI would improve program functionality, but unknown whether it would have the same positive impact on accuracy and communication based on its limitations. Results revealed a significant overall improvement in programming outcomes from 2022 to 2023, with significantly higher scores for accuracy and communication observed for the with-GenAI group than the without-GenAI group. Functionality scores remained consistently high (at ceiling). These findings suggest that a guided GenAI integration can enhance novice student programming outcomes despite its limitations. GenAI tools are expected to become increasingly valuable for introductory engineering programming instruction and for programming as a field.

title: Robust Watermarking for 3D Mesh Models Based on Geometrically Weighted Aggregation
authors: Fei Peng, Zhanhong Liu, Min Long
abstract: To address the limitations of current 3D mesh watermarking in robustness and imperceptibility, this paper proposes a deep watermarking based on a geometric-weighted aggregation mechanism. The message encoder and decoder networks are first improved to enable the effective embedding of 16-bit binary watermark information. An attack simulation module is then introduced to enhance the decoder's robustness against various distortions. Additionally, an adversarial discriminator is incorporated to guide the encoder in optimizing the embedding strategy, thereby minimizing geometric distortion. Furthermore, a cross-resolution strategy is developed to enable training on low-resolution meshes and perform watermark embedding and extraction on high-resolution meshes. Experimental results demonstrate that it outperforms the existing mainstream approaches in terms of extraction accuracy, geometric fidelity, and imperceptibility.

title: WIP: How Effective are Llm-Implemented Autograders for Programming Assignments Compared to Human Graders?
authors: Kevin Lewis, Hui Chen
abstract: This research-to-practice WIP paper describes the development and evaluation of a generative Large Language Model (gLLM)-based autograder for computer programming assignments. Manual grading is becoming increasingly unsustainable due to growing student enrollment and the demand for timely, high-quality feedback. To address these challenges, this study explores the use of automated grading tools to reduce instructors' workload and improve scalability. The proposed autograder takes a “reverse-engineering” approach, i.e., it converts student code into structured natural language summaries, which are then compared against predefined grading rubrics. An evaluation is performed using an external dataset (the Menagerie dataset), which contains real student submissions graded by four human graders. The objective is to assess the alignment between grades assigned by the autograder and those assigned by human graders. Findings indicate that the autograder closely matches human grading when letter grades are considered, though it performs less accurately with fine-grained numerical scores. While not yet a complete substitute for human assessment, the autograder shows strong potential as a scalable, efficient tool for supporting grading in programming education.

title: Implementing Smart IoT-Based Systems for Real-Time Detection and Management of Natural Gas Leaks in Urban Smart Utility Ecosystems and Management Platforms
authors: Mohanraj Subramanian, Shikhar Verma, S. Gopinath, Madhur Taneja, G. Mathivanan, Swetha K H
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Uncontrolled urban growth and aging utility infrastructure are a looming danger to natural gas leaks, which may cause imperative threats to safety, environment, and economical losses. The study involves a live IoT-enabled tool that can help detect the natural gas leakage in the city smart utility ecosystems/smart city environments in an early stage and in an intelligent way. To be able to identify the leak, the system uses a distributed sensor network combined with edge computing, wireless communication protocols, and AI-based anomaly detection allowing low-latency and high-accuracy detection of leaks. A multi-layered data aggregation model has an ability to ensure a contextual data interpretation and localized response in the way of smart controllers and the city-wide monitoring and predictive maintenance approach at cloud level. The suggested system has fault tolerant nodes clustering, adaptive routing, and secure event-logging on blockchain to ensure resilience, traceability, and trust worthiness. The results on simulations under various urban set ups come out to show enhanced detection accuracy, response rate, energy usage and bandwidth stability over traditional systems. It is easy to scale and modular with opportunities to integrate with the current utility management platforms and regulatory systems. The given work involves a complete and integrated solution based on IoT and AI to support gas safety and sustainability of a smart city using real-time intelligence of its infrastructure. The proposed system surpassed other approaches using a maximum detection accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4. 6 \%}$</tex> and communication success rate of 89.8 %.

title: Towards Automated CVD Diagnosis: Deep Learning-based ECG Feature Extraction*
authors: Youssif Abuzied, Hassan Abd-Eltawab, Abdelrhman Gaber, Tamer ElBatt
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are a major cause of mortality worldwide, requiring early and accurate diagnosis. Electrocardiogram (ECG) signals are essential for detecting CVDs, but manual analysis is time-consuming, error-prone, and often inaccessible in remote areas. This paper presents an open-source deep learning model for extracting interpretable morphological and temporal ECG features with high accuracy to aid physicians in diagnosis. Our approach preprocesses raw ECG signals and uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) for feature extraction. Using the PTB-XL+ dataset, our model shows high correlation with ground truth features, effectively capturing global and leadspecific ECG characteristics. We demonstrate that a single lead (Lead II) performs comparably to all $\mathbf{1 2}$ leads, reducing computational complexity. Additionally, a lower sampling frequency (100 Hz) maintains performance, offering an efficient alternative to 500 Hz. This work provides a practical and interpretable ECG feature extraction tool for regions with limited access to commercial ECG analysis software.

title: Integration of Sensor-Driven IoT Network into Smart Farming Education: Quantitative Evaluation of Student Engagement and Perception
authors: Asmidar Abu Bakar, Azimah Abdul Ghapar, Marina Md Din, Sera Syarmila Sameon, Naziffa Raha Nasir, Rina Anwar
abstract: The deployment of sensor-driven Internet of Things (IoT) architectures within smart farming environments offers a structured pathway for enhancing STEM education through applied, technology-integrated learning. This study details the implementation and educational assessment of an IoT-based smart irrigation prototype deployed in a Malaysian primary school. The system integrates soil moisture sensors, temperature-humidity modules, an Arduino-UNO control unit, and relay-driven irrigation mechanisms to enable autonomous water delivery for a controlled garden plot. A quantitative post-intervention survey involving 20 participants was conducted to measure changes in student awareness, perception, and engagement with IoT concepts. Statistical analysis indicated significant gains in understanding sensor operation, embedded control logic, and environmental monitoring applications. The results demonstrate the viability of sensor-based IoT platforms as dual-purpose tools which are supporting both precision agriculture practices and early-stage STEM pedagogy. The proposed IoT sensor network presents a scalable, low-cost model for integrating IoT-centric learning into national STEM curricula.

title: Recent Developments in Quantum Network Cybersecurity: Exploiting Authentication Protocols to Secure Multi-User Quantum Communication
authors: Abhilash Narayanan, Shiva Shankar Mummidi, Ramanan Sathiaseelan, Paddabbai Chowdari Karanam, Suresh Kottur, IT Arvind Narsing
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: A novel approach to secure data transmission, quantum communication draws on fundamental principles of quantum physics. It ensures that the transmitted information is private and accurate. To provide security, quantum networks implement physical constraints such as the no-cloning rule and quantum entanglement. In contrast, computational complexity is employed by classical networks. However, with the proliferation of multiuser quantum networks, identity verification has become more challenging. People with malicious intentions might easily disrupt services in long-distance quantum networks by impersonating legitimate nodes and sharing entangled resources and quantum channels. This highlights the absolute necessity of secure authentication systems tailored to quantum environments. Enhancements to recent quantum authentication systems have been made utilizing techniques that are resistant to quantum computing. Researchers are looking into quantum digital signatures, entanglement-assisted protocols, and quantum key distribution (QKD) authentication to make multi-party communications more secure. In order to prevent attacks where a user establishes a fraudulent identity or account, these strategies can be applied to quantum networks. This study takes a look at current quantum authentication systems and gives them the once-over, focusing on how well they could handle multiple users. The article delves into the evolution of authentication systems to accommodate the distributed model, where nodes can function as senders, receivers, or relays. We aim to strike a compromise between practicality and security in our lightweight, low-latency protocols. Additionally, the paper discusses quantum-specific issues, such as side-channel attacks and device malfunctions, and how authentication techniques can help prevent them. Finally, this study demonstrates that authentication is the critical component of secure quantum communication for multiple users. The most secure quantum key distribution methods are still vulnerable to attacks from inside or outside the system if proper authentication is not in place.

title: Bi-Level Traffic Steering Decision in High-Mobile and Ultra-Dense Multi-RAT Networks
authors: Mubashir Murshed, Israt Jabin, Afrin Jubaida, H. S. Glaucio Carvalho, Robson E. De Grande
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Technological advancements in cellular networks have enabled to surpass many challenges in telecommunications, but some features remain restricted, such as throughput, packet loss, and latency. User equipment (UE), including mobile, smart devices, vehicles, IoT devices, and smart city infrastructure, requires seamless connectivity to share data and resources effectively. Multiple radio access technology (multi-RAT) scenarios offer a solution to the limitations of individual RATs by combining their strengths. Determining the optimal RAT for traffic steering (TS) in multi-RAT scenarios is challenging due to factors such as high mobility, ultra-dense networks, overall dynamic network conditions, and the unique needs of individual users. In this context, we propose a bi-level approach, called BIL-TS, which includes (i) centrally determining the optimality of RATs and (ii) locally making TS decisions. BIL-TS utilizes the Actor-Critic SARSA Reinforcement Learning (ACS-RL) in level (i) to evaluate the optimality of RATs by considering the entire network, and level (ii) leverages Linear Regression (LR) to make decisions of TS to the optimal RAT based on specific requirements of each UE. Simulation results show that our proposed BILTS approach significantly enhances efficiency in TS, resulting in higher throughput, reduced packet loss, and lower latency.

title: Hyperspectral Image Classification based on Fast Fourier Convolution Mamba Panyu Lu
authors: Panyu Lu, Ziyang Guo, Xiaoya Nan
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Recent advancements in Mamba in long-sequence modeling have achieved significant progress. In order to achieve non-local receptive fields and cross scale fusion in various domains, we propose a novel algorithm which integrates Fast Fourier Convolution (FFC) with Mamba in hyperspectral image classification task. Specifically, we propose three key modules: the Spatial-Frequency Interaction Module, the FFC Module, and the Adaptive Bidirectional Mamba Module. The Spatial-Frequency Interaction Module is adopted for preprocessing and positional attention mechanisms. The FFC Module splits the data into global and local units at a certain ratio. Local output is obtained by summing local and global inputs processed through standard convolutions, while global output is derived by processing global input using Fourier unit and local Fourier unit. These two outputs are then concatenated and fed into the Adaptive Bidirectional Mamba Module, where Mamba is constructed hierarchically. At last, experimental results validates the effectiveness of our proposed method.

title: Enhancing Password Security: Leveraging AI for Typing Pattern Authentication
authors: Mohd Ezanee Rusli, Mohammed Nasr Anes Hasan
abstract: With the increasing need for improved cybersecurity, the limitations of traditional password-based authentication systems have become more evident. This study proposes an AI-enhanced authentication method using keystroke dynamics to reinforce password security. By leveraging machine learning algorithms to analyze users' unique typing patterns, the system offers an added layer of defense against unauthorized access, particularly in mitigating threats such as credential theft, phishing, and brute-force attacks. The research explores various machine learning models, including Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machines (SVM), to determine their effectiveness in classifying genuine users versus impostors. Experimental results show that Random Forest achieved an accuracy of 93.2%, making it the best-performing model in this study. This high accuracy demonstrates the reliability of keystroke dynamics as a method for continuous user authentication. The system’s feasibility is further underscored by its ability to scale easily within existing infrastructures without significant hardware changes. Furthermore, the solution has potential for widespread integration into real-world security systems, providing a robust and non-intrusive method for user verification across various platforms, from personal devices to enterprise-level applications.

title: Using Scrum to Improve Student Teamwork in a Project-Based Hybrid Learning Setting
authors: Essa Imhmed, Edgar Ceh-Varela, Mustafa Elfituri
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper presents a study examining the integration of Agile Scrum methodology and industry practices into a project-based hybrid learning setting to address the challenges of insufficient peer communication and collaboration that hinder team productivity. Our peer evaluation survey data analysis revealed that Scrum effectively improved teamwork performance. On average, up to 91% of teams expressed satisfaction with their teammates' communication, while 89% agreed that their peers contributed significantly to product delivery. Students also show greater understanding and support for teammates who struggled, suggesting that integrating industry case studies and practices into the course curriculum fostered a more supportive team environment. Additionally, team size influenced team performance, with teams of five members reporting higher dissatisfaction with a teammate's contributions than teams of three and four, indicating that smaller teams may be more effective in academic settings.

title: ML-Based Detection of BGP Prefix Hijacking
authors: Daksha Jha, Deepak, Devansh Sharma, Ritu Sachdeva
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: BGP prefix hijacking, when an Autonomous System (AS) wrongly advertises IP routes it is not authorized to announce, remains a serious threat to Internet routing. Cryptographic solutions like RPKI (Route Origin Validation) and BGPsec can stop simple origin hijacks, but their use is still not widespread, leaving many networks at risk. In reality, many Internet Routing Registry (IRR) entries are outdated, which allows attackers to insert fake announcements. In this work, we present a framework that combines sequence-based deep learning and graph-based learning to identify prefix hijacks in real time. We take in live BGP updates from CAIDA's BGPStream and RouteViews/RIS collectors. We extract both temporal features, such as announcement frequency and AS-path changes, and structural features, which include AS-level topology graphs with centrality measures. Our model consists of three branches: a 1D-CNN that processes embedded AS-path sequences, a stacked bidirectional LSTM that handles time-series feature vectors, and a Graph Neural Network (GNN) that analyzes the AS topology. These branches are combined and sent to a classifier that uses binary cross-entropy loss, or an autoencoder to score anomalies. On realistic datasets with known hijack incidents (training on 2019, testing on 2020), our approach achieves very high detection rates, with over 98% accuracy and about 0.98 F1. We compare our method to previous approaches, such as Park et al.'s autoencoder and a recent MAD+ML hybrid, and show better precision and recall. We also address limitations caused by data gaps, like outdated IRR records, and note that BGP monitors can be tampered with by adversaries.

title: Educational Data Analytics: Predictive Insights into Student Dropout and Academic Outcomes Using Machine Learning
authors: Samuel-Soma M. Ajibade, Leomar A. Ypanto, Rex V. Culpable, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, David Olayemi Alebiosu, Almighty Cortezo Tabuena, Bayan Issa, Anthonia Oluwatosin Adediran
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: In this modern era of data-driven society, Social and Web Analytics plays a vital role in understanding student behaviour to improve academic success in higher education institutions. Despite the massive volume of data, many institutions still face difficulties in accurately predicting which students are at a higher risk of dropping out or achieving academic success. The aim of this research work is to develop predictive models using machine learning techniques to forecast students into three categories, "Dropout", "Enrolled", and "Graduate". This research utilizes a real-world dataset of Portuguese higher education students from the UCI Machine Learning Repository. Four machine learning techniques such as Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and XGBoost were implemented and compared based on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score performance metrics. The results indicate that XGBoost achieved the best overall performance, with an accuracy of 76.95% and an F1-score of 76.28%, outperforming the next best model by approximately 1.7%. Future studies could expand this research using multi-institutional datasets and explore techniques to improve interpretability in complex ensemble models.

title: Emotion Classification of EEG Signals Using Parallel Depthwise Separable CNN and RNN
authors: Adila Zahra Sandrina, Esmeralda Contessa Djamal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Emotion classification based on multi-channel electroencephalogram (EEG) signals has been the focus of several previous studies utilizing spatiotemporal analysis. EEG signals from multiple channels can be extracted using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). Depthwise-Cnn significantly reduces the number of parameters and computational complexity by separating spatial and channel-wise feature extraction, making the model more efficient and lightweight. This paper proposed a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates a Parallel Depthwise Separable CNN and a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) for emotion classification. The EEG signal is extracted from different frequency bands, which show strong associations with human emotional states. The EEG signal was extracted into frequency bands using the Wavelet transform. Each band—theta, alpha, beta, and gamma—is modeled by an independent sub-network using a hybrid DSCNN and RNN enhanced by an attention mechanism. Their outputs are fused to leverage complementary information. Experiments on the SEED dataset, involving 15 participants and three emotion categories (positive, neutral, and negative), demonstrate that the framework strikes a good balance between accuracy and computational cost. Comparative analysis indicates that the 2D CNN achieves the highest accuracy (83.28%). At the same time, the 1D DSCNN offers the most efficient design, reducing parameters and inference time without significant loss of accuracy compared to the 1D CNN. These results highlight the promise of lightweight architectures for real-time EEG emotion recognition.

title: Lean from Yesterday to Today: A Comparative Analysis between Traditional and Smart Lean Implementation
authors: Chaymae Marjane, Mohamed Saad Bajjou, Anas Chafi
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Lean Management (LM) as a concept is an approach used to eliminate waste and maximize productivity. Lean Management was developed over time from the Toyota Production System (TPS) to Lean 4.0. This kind of Lean combines IoT, AI, and Big Data, which are used in Industry 4.0. This paper explores a comparative table that integrates the key differences between traditional Lean and modern Lean, facilitating the major purpose of inserting these smart technologies: providing more flexibility to the industry 4.0 while reducing waste and defects in industrial processes without human intervention. Lean is considered a critical strategic approach for introducing IoT and AI into the production process. Although there are limitations in the use of these technologies, they still enable us to digitalize traditional tools such as JIT, Kanban, and Kaizen.

title: Implementation of Text Sentiment Analysis to Digital Psychological Therapy to Classify Patients’ Emotions
authors: Gavriella Tjandra, Sylvana Marine Purnomo, Ivan Sebastian Edbert, Alvina Aulia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: The possibility of unique patients’ demand in digital psychological therapy necessitated the development of solutions to assist therapists. This paper provides a text-based emotion detection to improve and assist digital therapy. This experiment uses an emotion dataset gained from Hugging Face and the Distilled BERT (DistilBERT) model for multi-class detection. The evaluation of the model was conducted using standard metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, $\mathbf{F 1}$-score, and confusion matrix analysis. The model achieved an average accuracy of $92.1 \%$ with six emotion labels (sadness, joy, love, anger, fear, and surprise) and the best classification precision of $98 \%$ for the joy emotion. These results show that the DistilBERT model has the potential to assist real-time digital therapy by providing patients’ emotions based on their text.

title: Evaluating Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) Chunking Strategy for Question Answering in Indonesian Law of The Sea
authors: Iftitahu Ni’Mah, Lyla Ruslana Aini, Radhiyatul Fajri, Siska Pebiana, Nuraisa Novia Hidayati, Rini Wijayanti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: We study the evaluation of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) for question and answering (QA) in legal domain, particularly Law No. 17 of 2008 about maritime law and shipping in Indonesia. First, we create document contexts for RAG pipeline by extracting text from a legal PDF document and segmenting it into text chunks based on three methods: (i) Naive Token-level Chunking; (ii) Hierarchical Sentence-level Chunking; and (iii) Recursive Chunking. Simultaneously, we construct QA pairs from the legal PDF as an evaluation dataset for our RAG pipeline. We further analyze the strengths and limitations of currently available RAG evaluation metrics for investigating three evaluation aspects: Answer Correctness, Answer Groundedness, and Quality of Retrieved Chunks on our constructed QA dataset.

title: Design and Development of an AI-Guided Dual-Axis Actuator for Precision Nozzle Control in Greenhouse Pesticide Spraying Robots
authors: Muhammad Arif Bagus Dewanto, Khairunnissa Zahran Ansyafa, Karlisa Priandana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an AI-guided dual-axis actuator mechanism for precision nozzle control in an automatic pesticide spraying robot for greenhouse applications. The system integrates a stepper motor for horizontal motion and a servo motor for vertical motion, enabling flexible and accurate nozzle positioning. An ESP32 microcontroller coordinates the actuator movements based on input from a Raspberry Pi 5 running a YOLO-trained leaf detection model. The AI model identifies the center positions of plant leaves, allowing for targeted pesticide application. Experimental results show an average positioning deviation of 1.56 cm from the leaf center, yet the spray effectively reached the target. The system achieved an 86% success rate across 50 trials and reduced pesticide usage by 15.5% compared to a conventional spraying system. These findings highlight the potential of combining AI-based vision with dual-axis actuation to enhance the precision and efficiency of pesticide application in controlled agricultural environments.

title: Anti-Jamming based on Beam-Steering Antennas and Intelligent UAV Swarm Behavior
authors: Tiago Silva, António Grilo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: In recent years, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have brought a new true revolution to military tactics. While UAVs already constitute an advantage when operating alone, multi-UAV swarms expand the available possibilities, allowing the UAVs to collaborate and support each other as a team to carry out a given task. This entails the capability to exchange information related with situation awareness and action coordination by means of a suitable wireless communication technology. In such scenario, the adversary is expected to disrupt communications by jamming the communication channel. The latter becomes the Achilles heel of the swarm. While anti-jamming techniques constitute a well covered topic in the literature, the use of intelligent swarm behaviors to leverage those techniques is still an open research issue. This paper explores the use of beam-steering antennas and UAV swarm formation adaptation in order to mitigate the effect of jamming in the main coordination channel, under the assumption that a more robust and low data rate channel is used for formation management signaling. A Genetic Algorithm (GA) approach is used to jointly optimize beam directions, swarm formation and traffic routing. Simulation results show the effectiveness of proposed approach. However, the significant computational cost paves the way for future research.

title: Agile Management of Uncertainties in International Consortium
authors: Galyna Tabunshchyk, Peter Arras, Dirk Van Merode, Carsten Wolff
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Good practices in project management require that a project description contains a risk assessment before it starts. Especially in projects with international partner consortia. However, world turbulences like war, economic crises, and other external factors influence on the project management plan. In this paper, the authors suggest approaches that lead to reach planned outcomes that are resilient to external turbulences.

title: Personalized Marketing at Scale: Leveraging AI for Real-Time Content Recommendation and Optimization
authors: Prithvi Siva Sankar Shunmuga Sundaram
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: We can change and improve AI-based marketing tools. Real-time suggestions based on data help people connect, buy, and stay with a business. The system uses feedback loops and accurate data about people and things to come up with smart, useful marketing ideas. The plan works in three main ways: The first method establishes strong connections and groups users according to their traits. The second method employs attention-based merging, joint filtering, and reinforcement optimization to enhance thoughts. Based on what the user says and what's going on, the third program changes ideas in real time. These pieces allow the system to adapt to user needs. Many studies have proven that the recommended method is more effective than joint filtering, matrix factorization, deep neural networks, and context-aware mixed models. Customer engagement (85.4 %), conversion (17.9 %), suggestion accuracy (94.5%), and response time (1.2 seconds) have changed significantly. Business uses the strategy since it boosts customer term value and marketing ROI. Attention processes, reinforcement learning, and variation regularization help the model balance important, novel, and scalable items. Overall, this research advances next-generation tailored marketing. These technologies will enable flexible, real-time, multi-objective optimization, improving user satisfaction and smart marketing.

title: How are people’s explanations of the behaviour of robots structured? An exploratory study and discussion
authors: Agnese Augello, Maria Rausa, Edoardo Datteri, Nicola Zagni, Antonio Lieto
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: Prior research in human robot interaction (HRI) has largely focused on whether users adopt an intentional stance towards robots. We propose a methodology to investigate people’s explanations of robotic behavior that emphasizes finer-grained distinctions between explanations. The study also explores how users explanations change according to the modelling of a form of social competence in the robot by means of a computational cognitive architecture. Findings offer initial insight into how different explanatory strategies resonate with users.

title: Detecting the Unseen: A Comparative Analysis of Two Deep Learning Architectures for Plankton Species Identification
authors: N Muhammad Irsyaad, H. A. Danang Rimbawa, S.N Ahmad Idlof Dzouqun
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: The present article presents a comparative study of two recent deep learning architectures, YOLOv8n and DETR, for automated image-based recognition and phytoplankton species classification from images of the Makassar River. Plankton are very valuable bioindicators of environmental health but their traditional identification by microscopic examination is time-consuming and error-prone. The present attempt overcomes this limitation using deep learning. The solution was to preprocess and enrich a raw collection of 78 images from the Makassar River to generate a resulting collection of 333 images with 20 proxy species annotation. The models were validated on the major performance criteria: speed of detection, inference time, and performance against small and dense objects. The outcome is an evident trade-off between the models. The DETR model had a higher average accuracy of $\mathbf{8 4. 5 \%}$ against YOLOv8n’s $81.7 \%$, performing superior in the handling of complex morphological details. However, YOLOv8n was significantly faster with an approximate inference rate of 180 ms against 450 ms for DETR. The choice between the two models this hinges on the priorities of the application. DETR is more appropriate for high-accuracy and high-precision applications, while YOLOv8n is optimal in real-time surveillance applications where the most limiting factor is speed. This work contributes to building an improved methodology for scalable technology evolution for aquatic ecosystem monitoring and paves the way for further studies on ensemble or hybrid model architectures.

title: Investigation The Common Components of Augmented Reality in Enhancing Users' Information Literacy Skills in Academic Libraries: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Aisha Mohammed Al-Zaabi, Norizan Mat Diah, Elly Johana Johan, Eimad Eldin Abusham
abstract: The proposed research aims to identify key components of interactive searching using Augmented Reality (AR) that can enhance information literacy skills in academic libraries, considering components augmented into the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT) model. Using Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) as a systematic review as well as meta-analysis method, the most probable components in stimulating user interaction and acceptance of AR technologies were identified by analysing related studies. The findings obtained indicated three high-frequency components that were chosen as a focus of research to determine their significance in enhancing the information literacy abilities of users. The paper will provide valuable insights to help library guardians develop effective courses of action that utilize AR to promote information literacy, in line with contemporary technological advancements in scholarly libraries.

title: Analysis of Vampire Attack Detection in Flying Ad-Hoc Networks
authors: Chhatrapani Gautam, Ankur Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Flying ad hoc network (FANETs) are continues used for critical applications such as disaster response, surveillance and environmental monitoring. However, their nodes are typically battery-powered and have limited energy, making them vulnerable to vampire attacks, where malicious nodes exploit the routing protocol to drain nodes batteries with routing loop or route diversion. To detect and mitigate vampire attacks many research done in wireless sensor network but these solutions do not directly adopted to FANET because of high mobility and frequently topology changes and constraints of wireless aerial links. In this paper, we proposed a heuristic based vampire attack detection to defend FANET. The heuristic identify suspicious routing behavior by monitoring metrics such as path hop-length stretch, loop occurrences and energy consumption per forwarded packet. When a node's routing behavior exceeds threshold heuristics the protocol isolates the suspect nodes by restricting their participation in route formation. Through the network simulation apply varied mobility model of random way point and attack scenarios our heuristic approach increases packet delivery ratio and maintains acceptable latency compared to baseline routing protocols without protection.

title: An Energy Efficient Relay Selection Algorithm for Clustered Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Mohamad El Cheikh, Oluyomi Simpson, Yichuang Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: In this paper we propose an energy-efficient relay selection algorithm for clustered Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). In contrast to conventional multi-hop transmission schemes adopted in clustered WSNs, where only cluster heads (CHs) participate in the transmission, in our method the relay is selected from a set of candidate nodes within the source transmission range, subject to predefined desired transmission power at the source and the relay. The fundamental of this method is to forward the source signal using the node which minimizes the end-to-end total path distance, such that the total energy cost per bit is reduced at the relay and at the source. Thus, the node that satisfies the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) distance-based threshold of both links participates in the transmission. Taking into consideration the circuit energy cost, the modulation strategy and its impact on energy cost are investigated and the optimal choice of the number of bits per symbol is considered to optimize the total energy cost per transmission. The proposed method is shown to be more energy efficient compared to the traditional multi-hop transmission and random relay selection in terms of energy cost for a target bit error rate at the destination. Additionally, the proposed method also outperforms both methods in terms of the network lifetime.

title: Subjective Visual Quality Assessment of Compressed Light Field Images: Learning-based vs. Conventional Methods
authors: Emin Zerman, Soheib Takhtardeshir, Anthony Trioux, Jianlong Qin, Wenjie Wu, Roger Olsson, Mårten Sjöström
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Light fields (LF) technology enables the capture and reproduction of a 3D scene accurately, which enhances visual experience in various applications. The sheer volume of multiplicity of the captured views creates logistical problems in both storage and data transmission, which makes LF compression crucial. Even though many LF compression techniques have been proposed and evaluated in recent years, the leading-edge learning-based approaches have not been subject to the same level of scrutiny. This paper presents a subjective quality assessment study on four different LF compression methods, including two learning-based LF compression methods, which have not been studied before from a subjective quality point of view. For this purpose, subjective opinion scores were collected from viewers in two different universities for a cross-lab study. The results indicate that the learning-based compression methods have different behavior in their rate-distortion curves, and that there is room for improvement for learning-based methods. A qualitative analysis also shows that their artifact structures are different from conventional ones. The results highlight the need for a perceptual objective quality metric that takes different types of artifacts into account. The obtained subjective quality database (MiX-LFQDB) is made public to support further research in this area: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16778670
