title: A Real-World Evaluation of Two Cooperative Intersection Management Approaches
authors: Marvin Klimke, Max Bastian Mertens, Benjamin Völz, Michael Buchholz
abstract: Cooperative maneuver planning promises to significantly improve traffic efficiency at unsignalized intersections by leveraging connected automated vehicles (CAVs). Previous works on this topic have been mostly developed for completely automated traffic in a simple simulated environment. By contrast, our previously introduced planning approaches are specifically designed to handle real-world mixed traffic. The two methods are based on multiscenario prediction and graph-based reinforcement learning, respectively. This is the first study to perform evaluations in a novel mixed-traffic simulation framework as well as real-world drives with prototype CAVs in public traffic. The simulation features the same connected automated driving software stack as deployed on one of the automated vehicles. Our quantitative evaluations show that cooperative maneuver planning achieves a substantial reduction in crossing times and the number of stops. In a realistic environment with few automated vehicles, there are noticeable efficiency gains with only slightly increasing criticality metrics.

title: PosFormer: Generalizable Indoor Positioning via Global–Local Feature Fusion Network
authors: Xing Xiao, Zhiqiang Yao, Xingyu Gao, Menggang Sheng, Deyi Peng, Min Zeng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Ultra-wideband (UWB), a short-pulse radio technology with high time resolution, has shown great potential for high-accuracy indoor positioning. However, UWB-based localization still faces significant challenges in multipath-rich nonline-of-sight (NLOS) environments. Traditional geometry-based positioning methods tend to overestimate distances, while existing deep learning approaches often fail to capture the complex spatial and temporal characteristics of UWB signal propagation, leading to limited positioning accuracy. To address these limitations, we propose a Transformer and convolutional neural network (CNN) dual-fusion network inspired by multipath physical information for indoor positioning, termed PosFormer. The Transformer and CNN modules of PosFormer capture the long-distance dependencies and spatial characteristics of channel impulse responses (CIRs), effectively extracting both global and local multiscale features. In addition, we design a nonadjacent anchor-subsets (NAASs) scheme to enrich the diversity of CIRs and introduce a lightweight transfer learning (TL) framework to improve deployment robustness across environments with limited labeled data. Extensive experiments on public industrial datasets demonstrate that PosFormer achieves a mean absolute error (MAE) of 17.64 cm, significantly outperforming classical models such as CNN, long short-term memory (LSTM), and Transformer. In industrial hall environments with numerous metal obstacles, TL enables the pretrained model to achieve a positioning accuracy of 35.92 cm with only 20% of the fingerprint samples, highlighting its practical value for cross-environment deployment.

title: Study the High Voltage (HV) Distribution on Outdoor Overhead Insulators Under Unusual Contamination Conditions
authors: Salem Mgammal Al-Ameri, Buddhima B. Dona, Waleed M. Hamanah, Ali Ahmed Salem
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Outdoor high-voltage insulators are critical structures in the electrical transmission networks. Their functioning, however, can be degraded depending on the exposure to environmental pollution. This study aims to understand the Voltage distribution on the overhead insulator strings under the influence of different contamination profiles. First, the fundamental background of pin-type glass and porcelain insulators, chosen test parameters at a high voltage level $(132 \mathrm{kV})$, and pointers to allied prior work are determined. The electrical characteristics of glass and porcelain insulator strings were investigated under clean, dusty, and salty conditions. Simulations were done using the Finite Element Method Magnetic (FEMM) software. The results were compared and analysed between both porcelain and glass insulators in order to identify which one of them performs better in each contamination scenario and the voltage distribution along the insulator string. The most critical parameters that were employed to check the performance of insulators included voltage distribution, flux density magnitude, and normal field intensity. The results indicated that the voltage distribution along the glass string insulator performs better compared to porcelain under dust, water, and salt contamination conditions.

title: Slang Context-based Inference Enhancement via Greedy Search-Guided Chain-of-Thought Prompting
authors: Jinghan Cao, Qingyang Ren, Xiangyun Chen, Xinjin Li, Haoxiang Gao, Yu Zhao
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Slang interpretation has been a challenging downstream task for Large Language Models (LLMs) as the expressions are inherently embedded in contextual, cultural, and linguistic frameworks. In the absence of domain-specific training data, it is difficult for LLMs to accurately interpret slang meaning based on lexical information. This paper attempts to investigate the challenges of slang inference using large LLMs and presents a greedy search-guided chain-of-thought framework for slang interpretation. Through our experiments, we conclude that the model size and temperature settings have limited impact on inference accuracy. Transformer-based models with larger active parameters do not generate higher accuracy than smaller models. Based on the results of the above empirical study, we integrate greedy search algorithms with chain-of-thought prompting for small language models to build a framework that improves the accuracy of slang interpretation. The experimental results indicate that our proposed framework demonstrates improved accuracy in slang meaning interpretation. These findings contribute to the understanding of context dependency in language models and provide a practical solution for enhancing slang comprehension through a structured reasoning prompting framework.

title: Cyber-AI-Sentinel: An AI-Powered Intrusion Detection System for Wi-Fi and Cellular Towers
authors: Hamad Labda, Fathelalem A. Hija
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Telecommunication infrastructures such as Wi-Fi networks and cellular base stations are increasingly exposed to sophisticated cyber threats that challenge traditional intrusion detection systems. This paper presents Cyber-AI-Sentinel, a modular and adaptive AI-powered intrusion detection framework designed for real-time protection of heterogeneous wireless environments. The system integrates a Flask-based backend, React operator dashboard, and Docker-containerized services to ensure scalability, orchestration, and visual responsiveness. A hybrid machine-learning engine combining Isolation Forest, Random Forest, XGBoost, and LSTM models detects, classifies, and correlates anomalous network behaviors. A dedicated Threat Analyzer enriches detections by mapping events to MITRE ATT&CK techniques, calculating composite risk scores, and visualizing prioritized alerts for operator response. Supporting components including the ELK Stack, PostgreSQL, and Redis enable centralized logging, caching, and analytics. A real-time monitoring module simulates or ingests live network traffic, providing continuous situational awareness through an interactive dashboard. Deployed in a controlled single-user test environment, Cyber-AI-Sentinel demonstrated high detection accuracy and operational stability. The results highlight its potential as a scalable and intelligent IDS, integrating machine-learning inference with operational visualization to enhance cybersecurity readiness across next-generation telecom infrastructures.

title: Integrating Sustainability Measures in International Non-Governmental Organization Projects
authors: Sharqa Altaf, Rao Aamir Khan, Carsten Wolff, Christoph Albrecht
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This study explores sustainability integration in International Non-Governmental Organizations INGOmanaged projects. Through thematic analysis of the stakeholder interviews, it highlights strategies like capacity building, environmental-economic alignment, and gendersensitive approaches to foster local ownership. Key postproject strategies include public-private partnerships and income generation for financial self-resilience. Challenges like short-term funding, local capacity gaps, and bureaucratic hurdles necessities diversified funding and stronger local collaboration. The findings emphasize adaptive strategies, long-term planning, and partnerships to extend project impact, offering actionable insights for sustainable development Projects.

title: From Powder to Power: Engineering Six-layers High-Performance Ni/YSZ Composites for Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs)
authors: Nor Anisa Arifin, Saidatul Haneen Badruhisham, Saidatul Akmal Biyamin, Anis Muneerah Shaiful Bahari, Nurul Noramelya Zulkefli, Abdullah A. Afifi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs) are high-temperature electrochemical energy conversion devices that operate with fuel flexibility and high efficiency, making them suitable for stationary power generation. In SOFC, Ni/YSZbased cells are the industry benchmark due to their economic value, chemical stability, mechanical durability, and well-established processing compatibility. This study was undertaken to develop high-performance SOFCs by systematically optimising the fabrication parameters of a six-layer planar Ni/YSZ cell architecture and to solve fabrication challenges associated with interlayer material and microstructural mismatches. Multilayer tape casting or co-casting were employed to construct the half-cells, followed by a two-stage co-sintering protocol, targeting mechanical strength establishment and microstructure particle arrangement in the first stage and flattening procedure in the second stage. Material selection and layer composition were optimised to enhance porosity, triple-phase boundary (TPB) density, and interfacial integrity. GDC barrier layers deposition was attempted with tape casting, screen printing and spin-coating with spin coating as the best thin layer deposition technique. Based on the highest performance sample, thin electrolyte and barrier layer thicknesses were achieved; 3.74 and $6.63 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, respectively. Double cathode layer with different thicknesses were attempted with sample with thick cathode current collection layer (CCL) give the highest performance. The optimised in-house fabricated cell achieved an open-circuit voltage of 1.05 V and a peak power density of $0.78 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$ at $800^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, outperforming the commercial reference by $42 \%$. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of fabrication process refinement in improving the electrochemical and structural performance of Ni/YSZ-based SOFCs, while maintaining compatibility with scalable manufacturing practices.

title: Revolutionizing PDF Q&A with Local LLMs and Privacy-Enhanced Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: P Prakash, V Sakthivel, K Rama Abirami, Sumanth Maruthi Kumar Paruchuri, Madhu Sudhana Tallapalli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: With the rising prominence of Large Language Models (LLMs) in natural language processing, our research explores a novel approach to PDF-based question-answering (QA) using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG). Traditional keyword-based QA methods, while effective at basic information retrieval, struggle with contextual understanding and synonym recognition. Subsequently, deep learning models improved these aspects but faced challenges in providing structured answers. The introduction of LLMs addressed many of these limitations; however, they introduced issues like hallucination and high costs for API-based implementations. Our study proposes a cost-effective, privacy-respecting solution that leverages Ollama to run LLMs locally, eliminating the need for cloud-based API calls and mitigating data privacy concerns. Additionally, extensive testing on a structured dataset demonstrates improved accuracy and relevance in answers, making our solution well-suited for secure environments where data sensitivity and cost-efficiency are paramount. This paper contributes a scalable, secure architecture for document-based QA, providing a comprehensive alternative to traditional and cloud-dependent methods.

title: Data-Driven Regression Model for Autonomous IoT Battery State Estimation Considering Environmental Factors
authors: Viktor Zhukovskyy, Nataliia Zhukovska, Oleh Moskal
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Ensuring reliable operation of autonomous Internet of Things (IoT) devices, often powered by batteries recharged via solar panels, is significantly influenced by environmental conditions. This paper addresses the prediction of battery voltage by developing a regression model based on time-of-day and ambient temperature. The study utilized empirical voltage data from a deployed Tank Toad AC-2 water level monitoring device and corresponding historical weather data (temperature and cloud cover) from open-meteo.com for the period September 1, 2024, to February 10, 2025. A stepwise regression methodology, implemented in Mathcad, was employed. Data was initially filtered to isolate nighttime discharge periods following days with low cloud cover, minimizing solar charging effects, with temperature data subsequently binned. The analysis involved fitting power functions to voltage versus time data within temperature bins, followed by second-order polynomial approximation of the power function coefficients against temperature. This yielded an analytical regression model representing the voltage surface. Validation showed good agreement with empirical data, achieving a relative error of 1.37% at a control point. The derived model provides a practical tool for predicting battery state, contributing to improved energy efficiency and operational reliability for autonomous IoT systems.

title: Leveraging Llms for Streamlining and Demystifying the Systematic Literature Review Process
authors: Bo Pei, Xiaojiao Sun
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper describes an LLM-driven interactive platform, AutoLit, for facilitating and interpreting each step in conducting systematic literature reviews. AutoLit is composed of four modules: Research Contextualization Module for generating research background and constructing research questions; Paper Retrieval Module for constructing query strings and retrieving relevant papers; Paper Analysis Module for analyzing the semantic correlations among retrieved papers and research questions; and Paper Coding Module for generating coding schema for systematically addressing the research questions. Compared with the existing literature review tools, AutoLit provides a more user-friendly interface that actively involves human expertise at each stage in the literature review process. It also offers clear visual interpretations of the analytical results, enhancing both the transparency of the decision-making process and the trustworthiness of the platform.

title: Random Forests as a Lightweight Alternative to Deep Neural Networks in Antenna Design
authors: Shehryar Niazi, Muhammad Yousaf, Hamza Imran, Zohaib Ahmad Khan, Hidayat Ullah
abstract: This research work demonstrate the development of a Random Forest (RF) model as an efficient alternative approach to Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) for antenna design and performance estimation. Although DNNs are commonly utilized for characterizing complex electromagnetic features, they usually demand large data-sets and high computing resources. The proposed RF-based approach offers a lightweight, interpretable, and accurate solution for predicting key antenna parameters such as Gain and S₁₁ (return loss) using a set of geometrical design parameters. Based on the patch antennas in 3.25 - 4.25 GHz band on Rogers 5880 substrate, we show how RF is able to achieve the prediction quality comparable to DNN and can be a favorable option for fast convergence and reliable performance in antenna optimization.

title: Adapting Globally Distributed Scrum Team Strategies for University Classrooms
authors: Caleb Ramos, Sarah Reynolds, Lynn Vonderhaar, Alexandra Davidoff, Omar Ochoa, Massood Towhidnejad, James Pembridge
abstract: This full research paper analyzes lessons documented for distributed Scrum practices to improve the teamwork experience during Project-Based Learning (PBL) for engineering education students. While PBL is widely used to teach technical and soft skills in the engineering classroom, there are often struggles in team coordination and collaboration. Scrum, an agile project management framework originally developed for software engineering, has emerged in the literature as an effective framework that can structure and support teamwork environments. This paper specifically looks at Globally Distributed Scrum Teams (GDSTs) to see how challenges related to teamwork and collaboration can be solved when the environment is not conducive to collaboration. Through a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) of 980 sources, 14 peerreviewed studies were identified. These studies detail communication and relationship challenges in GDSTs and outline solutions within adaptations to the Scrum framework. Findings were categorized into communication practices, relationshipbuilding strategies, and adaptations to the Scrum framework. Within these categories, the proposed solutions were mapped to actionable practices that are attainable in the engineering classroom. As a result, this paper offers evidence-based recommendations seeking to improve the experience and effectiveness of teamwork in PBL through Scrum. By translating the best practices found in industry to educational settings, this study supports the development of more impactful learning of both technical and soft skills for engineering students.

title: Zero-Day Botnet Attack Detection in IoV: A Modular Approach Using Isolation Forests and Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Abdelaziz Amara Korba, Nour Elislem Karabadji, Yacine Ghamri-Doudane
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) is transforming transportation by enhancing connectivity and enabling autonomous driving. However, this increased interconnectivity introduces new security vulnerabilities. Bot malware and cyberattacks pose significant risks to Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs), as demonstrated by real-world incidents involving remote vehicle system compromise. To address these challenges, we propose an edge-based Intrusion Detection System (IDS) that monitors network traffic to and from CAVs. Our detection model is based on a meta-ensemble classifier capable of recognizing known (N day) attacks and detecting previously unseen (zero-day) attacks. The approach involves training multiple Isolation Forest (IF) models on Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) servers, with each IF specialized in identifying a specific type of botnet attack. These IFs, either trained locally or shared by other MEC nodes, are then aggregated using a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) based stacking strategy to construct a robust meta-classifier. The proposed IDS has been evaluated on a vehicular botnet dataset, achieving an average detection rate of $92.80 \%$ for N -day attacks and $77.32 \%$ for zero-day attacks. These results highlight the effectiveness of our solution in detecting both known and emerging threats, providing a scalable and adaptive defense mechanism for CAVs within the IoV ecosystem.

title: Clinical Evaluation of Quantum-Enhanced RCC Diagnostics: Expandable Quantum Neural Networks Built on Imaging for Realistic Precision Oncology Usage
authors: Tanneru Venkata Lavanya, Sivaraman. K
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a lethal urological cancer, and high mortality rates associated with the disease are frequently due to late diagnosis and the functional diversity of a tumor. Current diagnostic paradigms, mostly depending on radiological visualization and histopathological evaluation, are plagued with problems in the form of inter-observer variation and lag time in detection, and are also inadequate in recapitulating the heterogeneous nature of the tumor microenvironment. To address these challenges, in this work we propose an intelligent diagnostic framework combining quantumenhanced expandable neural networks (Q-ENNs) and medical imaging for precision oncology. In contrast to traditional DL models, Q-ENNs leverage quantum parallelism and entanglement-induced strategies to traverse high-dimensional imaging spaces by outperforming feature extraction and diagnostic performance. The scalable design can flexibly scale network layers and qubits according to clinical requirements, allowing multi-stage RCC diagnosis. Q-ENNs trained on multimodal imaging data (including CT, MRI, and histopathological slides) outperform state-of-theart convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in the tasks of tumor detection, staging, and subtype classification. In addition, the quantum-assisted optimization approach accelerates the convergence and alleviates local minima, which are not only benefit for better discrimination performance but also robust diagnostic results among different populations of patients. We validate our results by clinical evaluation, where a better trade-off between sensitivity and specificity with higher interpretability are obtained with respect to state-of-the-art through explainable quantum feature mapping, as claimed in precision oncology terms. The system we present is intended to be deployed in a realistic clinical setting, supporting computational performance (scalability), integration in the existing radiology workflow, and generic imaging modalities. By interfacing principles of quantum computing with clinical applications, this study paves the road for the future of oncology diagnostics. These discoveries underpin that quantum-driven diagnostic systems could change the way RCC is assessed, providing for earlier and more reliable detection, help in the personalization of treatment and thus enhance patient outcomes in precision oncology.

title: Cloud-Based Ovulation Detection from Collected Saliva Images using Azure-Powered Machine learning model
authors: Arya U, Venugopal Gopinath
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: In humans, accurate prediction of ovulation day is essential for effective natural family planning, contraception and infertility. For long-term tracking, current methods such as basal body temperature monitoring and urine-based hormone detection can be challenging and expensive. The proposed method illustrates a cloud-integrated ovulation detection technique using microscopic analysis of saliva Ferning. The image acquisition system serves as an IoT device, consists of a Raspberry Pi 4 Model B, Raspberry Pi high quality camera mounted with a 100x microscopic lens and a white diffuser type LED source. For dataset preparation 100 sample images were collected for both ovulation and non-ovulation classes. The captured images are directly transmitted to the Microsoft Azure cloud platform for further processing. In the cloud, the images stored in Azure Blob Storage which triggers an Azure Function to begin the image classification process using Azure Custom Vision. In order to train the classification model, data augmentation was performed for the collected sample images. The results show that, the system ensures effective cloud performance with low latency dropping below 3 ms for image upload. In addition, the classification model attained high accuracy with precision and recall exceeding 98%.For a comparative evaluation with custom vision classifier, a ResNet50V2-based deep learning model trained on augmented dataset achieved 96% classification accuracy, further validating the potential of AI driven ovulation detection. The proposed pipeline offers sustainability in terms of computational efficiency by offloading the image processing tasks to the cloud server and also reduces power consumption on local hardware system. Moreover, this architecture ensures scalability by enabling large scale data storage for a continuous usage. The automated and accessible nature of the proposed method offers significant applicability in digital fertility monitoring.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Imbalanced Bioacoustic Call-Type Classification Using Focal Loss and SMOTE
authors: Ali Raza, Gang Qiao, Lei Li, Mubeen Javed, Muhammad Allah Rakha, Muhammad Bilal, Albert Patrick Sankoh, Shabnam Javed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: This study introduces FOCUS (Focal loss and Oversampling for Classification of Under sampled Sounds), a novel deep learning (DL) framework specifically designed to tackle severe class imbalance in bioacoustics classification. The proposed method combines focal loss, class-balanced weighting, and the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to enhance recognition of rare humpback whale call types. A custom 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) is developed and trained on 8,001 mel-spectral feature samples, with an end-to-end pipeline optimized for imbalanced data scenarios. The model is benchmarked against standard CNN and DNN baselines using stratified train–validation splits and evaluated across multiple metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Experimental results show that FOCUS achieves 96.48% precision and 96.46% F1-score, consistently outperforming traditional approaches. Error analysis further reveals improved sensitivity to minority classes, demonstrating the framework’s potential for enhancing acoustic monitoring and scientific understanding of humpback whale behavior. Overall, FOCUS provides a robust, scalable solution for class-imbalanced bioacoustics classification tasks.

title: Graph Neural Networks for Real-Time Biosignal Analysis in Wearable Healthcare Devices
authors: Anurag Shrivastava, Zaid Alsalami, Rallabandi Venkata Santoshi Saraswati Swetha Nagini, Aman Sharma, Irfan Khan, Manish Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Wearable healthcare devices continuously capture diverse biosignals (ECG, PPG, EEG, EMG, and IMU data) that can enable early detection, continuous monitoring, and personalized intervention. Traditional signal-processing and deep-learning approaches treat biosignals as sequences or images, often neglecting the inherent relational and topological structure among sensors, anatomical sites, and temporal segments. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) provide a principled framework to encode such relational information, fuse multimodal streams, and perform inference with explicit modeling of inter-sensor and inter-feature dependencies. This paper presents a comprehensive treatment of GNN architectures, representation strategies, and optimization techniques tailored for real-time biosignal analysis in wearable systems. We (1) formalize biosignal-to-graph transformations that preserve physiological adjacency and functional coupling, (2) evaluate spatial, temporal, and spatio-temporal GNN variants for latency-constrained tasks (arrhythmia detection, cuffless blood-pressure estimation, EEG-based event detection, and activity recognition), (3) propose lightweight graph convolution and message-passing modules designed for edge inference and energy-efficient deployment, and (4) assess robustness to noise, missing channels, and variable sampling using both open benchmarks and a curated wearable dataset. Results demonstrate that appropriately constructed GNNs improve detection accuracy and calibration while reducing feature-engineering requirements, and that model pruning, quantization, and architecture search enable real-time inference on resource-limited wearable hardware. We conclude with a roadmap addressing clinical validation, privacy-preserving ondevice learning, and standardization of graph construction for reproducible biosignal GNN research.

title: Optimizing Secure Elements Implementation Methods for a seamless Post-Quantum Transition
authors: Eros Camacho-Ruiz, Pablo Navarro-Torrero, Macarena C. Martínez-Rodríguez, Piedad Brox
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The adoption of Post-Quantum Cryptography over the security network layer, such as Transport Layer Security, poses significant challenges, particularly in the context of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, where power and area constraints frequently limit the adoption of hardened security features. In addressing this challenge, hardware-based Secure Elements become a crucial component in facilitating cryptographic operations and storing secret keys within these frameworks. However, the design and validation of such hardware modules require substantial time investment. Consequently, this can result in the allocation of time that could be utilized for the development of other essential components of the Post-Quantum Transition. In this context, the present work proposes a methodology for the integration of Secure Elements on IoT devices, with the objective of reducing the time required for design and validation. To this end, two distinct categories of IoT devices (microcontrollers and embedded processors) have been employed to encompass the broadest possible range of IoT devices. The outcome of this study is the delivery of an open-source cryptographic library that can be deployed in any type of IoT devices. This library facilitates the implementation of Post-Quantum Cryptography in Secure Elements enabling crypto-agility and ensuring a smooth PostQuantum transition for IoT.

title: Deterministic Computing Power Network Routing Algorithm Based on Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
authors: Qi Xu, Yang Yang, Xuesong Qiu, Anni Jiang, Mingyuan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: As edge computing, AI data centers, and supercomputing systems continue to expand, the challenge of deterministic computing power routing has become increasingly prominent. In response, this paper proposes a new hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm that combines node clustering with routing optimization. Our approach employs a hybrid clustering method that integrates Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) and K-Means algorithms to categorize computing nodes into distinct groups based on their operational states and past performance. This framework uses reinforcement learning techniques to optimally match deterministic applications with the relevant node clusters, while modeling the selection of nodes and path planning as a Stackelberg game problem. We solve this game-theoretical problem using a dual-agent reinforcement learning architecture, enhanced by graph neural networks to boost generalization. Additionally, we incorporate a shortest-path-based link attention mechanism to speed up model convergence. Our proposed solution addresses the shortcomings of traditional methods, which often treat node selection and path planning separately. This integrated approach leads to more efficient use of resources and better satisfies deterministic transmission needs.

title: Comparative Analysis of Multimodal RAG Deployment Strategies for Medical Image Understanding: API-Based, Local Fine-Tuning, and Hybrid Approaches
authors: Kai-Chen Yang, Hsueh-Ting Chu
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: The advancement of clinical decision support systems depends on the essential integration of medical images together with their corresponding textual reports. The paradigm of Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation (MRAG) shows promise because it uses external knowledge sources to support Large Language Model (LLM) responses. Recent advances such as MMed-RAG demonstrate up to 43.8% improvement in factual accuracy for medical vision-language tasks. This research investigates three main approaches to implement MRAG for medical image understanding through (1) API-based access to strong general-purpose Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) (e.g., GPT-4V, Gemini), (2) local deployment of Vision Language Models (VLMs) with parameter-efficient fine-tuning (e.g., LoRA, DoRA), and (3) a hybrid method that uses pre-trained embedding models (e.g., CLIP, MedCLIP, BiomedCLIP) for local structured knowledge base retrieval alongside a local VLM for secure context-aware response generation. The evaluation assesses these methods through their documented capabilities and literature-based model efficacy and data privacy aspects for Protected Health Information (PHI) and evaluates their deployment complexity and cost alongside scalability and customizability and latency and transparency and knowledge updatability. Through a conceptual case study and decision framework, we analyze the trade-offs for typical healthcare institutions. The research establishes particular medical use cases which demonstrate the best fit for each approach under strict Institutional Review Board (IRB) regulations and data privacy standards including HIPAA and GDPR. This research establishes a decision framework for healthcare ecosystem MRAG solution selection and implementation to address specific healthcare challenges.

title: DashTalk: An IoT Platform for Data Collection, Visualization, and Advanced Analysis: A Case Study on Outdoor Cycling Activities
authors: Yun-Wei Lin, Chih-Yi Liao
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: The swift progression of Internet of Things (IoT) technology has resulted in the extensive utilization of IoT applications in various fields, such as smart cities, intelligent farming, and connected homes, significantly reshaping contemporary lifestyles and interactions. However, the growing volume of data generated by IoT devices presents challenges in data management and analysis, hindering the realization of their potential value. To address these challenges, this study introduces DashTalk, an integrated data application platform built on the IoTtalk platform, designed to facilitate the real-time display, storage, visualization, and analysis of IoT data. DashTalk offers a variety of visualization tools, such as line charts, histograms, scatter plots, and heatmaps, enabling users to intuitively understand data trends and correlations, thereby enhancing decision-making processes. Additionally, it features advanced analytics capabilities, including data decomposition, outlier detection, and clustering, to uncover hidden insights and provide early warnings of potential issues. The platform's utility is exemplified through the real-world case studies: outdoor cycling activities, showcasing how data visualization and analysis can yield in-depth insights. The findings demonstrate DashTalk's potential to improve productivity and decision-making quality across various sectors requiring real-time data processing, ultimately supporting the continued advancement of IoT technology.

title: SafeBite – A Prototype Design of a User-Centered Mobile App for Food Safety
authors: Kar Yan Fong, Chen Kang Lee, Seow Hoon Saw, Seow Hui Saw
abstract: The lack of food safety awareness in Malaysia increases the risk of food poisoning. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic has led to an increase in food poisoning cases, underscoring the urgency of this study. Successful strategies in the United States (U.S.) and Europe to reduce foodborne illnesses suggest that Malaysia could benefit from a similar approach. Given Malaysians’ high smartphone usage, the primary objective is to design a user-centred mobile app prototype, "SafeBite", that translates complex food safety guidelines into an accessible format, enhancing public understanding and compliance. This study adopts the design thinking methodology, emphasising the creation of an intuitive and informative prototype that bridges academic insights with practical application. A mixed-methods approach was used, including surveys and interviews to gather insights from undergraduate students and cultivators. These findings provide valuable insights for developing user personas, user journey maps, user flows, and system architecture, leading to both low-fidelity and high-fidelity prototypes. Usability testing was conducted using the System Usability Scale (SUS) to evaluate the prototype’s design and functionality. Unlike existing food safety apps, "SafeBite" is tailored to local needs, showing strong potential for relevance and effectiveness based on prototype testing results.

title: Cost-Efficient Deep Learning Model Optimization for Financial Accounting on Cloud Platform
authors: Arjun Chaudhary, Mahatma Reddy Marri, Ashish Kumar, Vivek Banerjee, Harpreet Kaur, Kavita Arora
abstract: Financial accounting information systems (FAIS) play a pivotal role in corporate financial management, yet accurate profit prediction remains a persistent challenge due to the increasing volume, complexity, and dynamic nature of financial data. Recent advancements in deep learning offer new opportunities for financial forecasting, but their deployment is frequently limited by high training costs and resource constraints. To address these limitations, this study proposes a cost-efficient deep learning model optimization framework for profit prediction using FAIS on cloud platform. The proposed methodology integrates an enhanced cubature Kalman optimization (ECKO) algorithm within a cloud infrastructure to enable scalable data storage and efficient resource management, significantly reducing the time and cost associated with large-scale financial analysis. For feature analysis, a transformer model is used to capture complex dependencies and financial patterns. A deep Q-learning model is used for profit prediction, optimizing decision-making within the financial accounting process. The performance of the proposed model is validated using a real-world Kaggle financial accounting dataset. The results demonstrate that the proposed cloud-powered framework achieves superior prediction accuracy while reducing model training costs by 35% compared to conventional deep learning models.

title: Implementation of an Optimized Hybrid Machine Learning–Based IDS for Enhanced Threat Detection in IoT Environments
authors: Ravindra Chopparapu, Sasikanth Yangalasetty, Gaurang Deshpande, Vandana Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The dynamic and heterogeneous nature of IoT environments combined with the blistering development of interconnected devices is then creating an increasing need to employ smart and flexible systems of intrusion detection. In this paper a new Federated Neuro-Symbolic Adaptive Defense Model (FNS-ADM) has been suggested, to support distributed learning, meta-optimization, and symbolic reasoning to increase the threat detection ability and interpretability. The proposed model uses the lightweight neural encoders at the edge to extract the compressed behavioral representations and make localized anomaly detection with the help of few-shot meta-learners. A federated meta-aggregator actively unites model parameters depending on the device reliability and data homogeneity that will allow vigorous global generalization without at the cost of privacy. Anomalies that are detected are now subjected to a symbolic reasoning layer which derives high-level attack semantics and gives human understandable explanations. With the combination of federated meta-learning and neuro-symbolic reasoning, FNS-ADM can be highly adaptable to novel and changing threats being trained and scaled and be transparent. The experimental validation with the help of the benchmark IoT intrusion datasets shows that the suggested framework is superior to the traditional hybrid and centralized recognition systems in terms of detection accuracy, convergence speed, and the ability of connection efficiency. The findings approve that FNS-ADM is a privacy-preserving, explainable paradigm of defense applicable to real-time security surveillance of large-scale heterogeneous networks in IoT security-related matters. The suggested FNS-ADM model attained an overall accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5 \%}$</tex>, exhibiting enhanced detection performance relative to current methodologies.

title: Methods for Estimating Programming Logics Using Machine Learning that Adopts Syntax Trees as Training Data
authors: Mitsuhiro Sato, Ryo Onuma, Sho Onami, Hiroki Nakayama, Hiroaki Kaminaga, Youzou Miyadera, Shoichi Nakamura
abstract: Opportunities for conducting programming education have been increasing, and as such, the demand for its assistance is growing. In order to effectively instruct learners in programming exercises, it is important to grasp the situation of individual learners. However, it is often difficult to do so when a few teachers are responsible for a large number of learners. In addition, the directions taken to construct a program (called programming logics) differ by each learner, even for the same challenge in the programming exercise, which can be particularly difficult for teachers to grasp. While there are many methods for supporting programming exercises, none are able to deal with the diversity of programming logics. Our objective is therefore to develop methods for estimating programming logics from incomplete source codes under being written by individual learners. In this paper, we mainly describe methods for estimating programming logics by means of machine learning that adopts syntax trees as training data. Our experimental findings demonstrate the basic effectiveness of our methods.

title: Radiation Source Localization Algorithm Based on Improved SGBM
authors: Yang Liu, Xuhu Ren, Changda Guo, Chenyang Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: To address the radiation exposure risks associated with traditional manual localization of radioactive sources, this paper proposes an improved SGBM algorithm-based method for radioactive source localization. During the cost computation stage, a mean Census transform is introduced, which uses the average pixel intensity within a window as the reference grayscale value to enhance robustness against noise and illumination variations. In the cost aggregation stage, an adaptive cross-arm window mechanism is adopted to dynamically adjust the aggregation range according to image content, thereby improving matching accuracy in depth-discontinuous regions. Experimental evaluations conducted on source container, source chamber, and buckle within a depth range of 400–600 mm demonstrate that the relative errors range from 0.46% to 1.28%, confirming the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed method for high-precision localization of key radioactive source components.

title: Semantic Feature Learning Using Transformer-Based Deep Neural Networks
authors: Deepak Kumar Gupta, K. Purushotham, Gaurav Dheer, Sruthi P, Vijaya Rama Raju Gottimukkala, Saurabh Kapoor
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The proliferation of smart systems requires superior structures that can derive meaningful representations out of multifaceted and disparate information. Traditional deep learning models lack the ability to handle redundancy, low interpretability, and low efficiency in optimization of multimodal processing. This paper proposes HARMONIC-Net (Hierarchical Attention-Refined Multimodal Optimization Network for Intelligent Classification) as a new architecture that improves the representation of semantics and cross-domain flexibility. The hierarchical attention refinement has been incorporated into the proposed model to sequentially refine the attention to the coarse-fine contextual relationship between capturing and amplifying critical features and suppressing noise respectively. A multimodal embedding fusion technique synchronises many inputs, including textual, visual, and audible data, into a cohesive latent space, using adjustable weighting of modalities to facilitate equal learning. The understanding of consistency is used to supply supplementary structured domain priors, hence enhancing the process of generalisation and semantics consistency. Dynamic gradients control is being applied to stabilise optimum by adapted regulating learning rates in relation to attribute entropy. The design is being integrated into a scalable decoding-encoding system that enhances interpretability and robustness of tasks involving classification. Experimental studies are anticipated to provide superior accuracy, efficient convergence, and enhanced clarity compared to current leading technologies. Overall, HARMONIC-Net signifies a significant advancement toward comprehensible, scalable, and resilient intelligent technologies in application. The proposed strategy achieved an overall accuracy of 94%, significantly exceeding previous techniques.

title: An Efficient Framework for Whole-Slide Cervical Cell Image Classification
authors: Yen-Chun Chen, Lucas Kory Lin, Chih-Hsien Hsia
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: In other words, cervical cancer ranks among the top causes of cancer-related mortality in women. As of now, most studies and diagnosis focus on single-cell image classification, which highly complicates the clinical diagnoses; since they do not align with multi-cell field interpretation scenarios. Providing an essential end-to-end cervical cell classification framework and structure based on Whole Slide Images (WSIs), this paper’s objective is to simulate vivid and concise decision-making used by physicians during future critical diagnostic processes. Our method modifies the CoAtNet diagnosis structure by striking the original Transformer layers, and instead, replacing them with numerous MBConv modules to further enhance the model’s performance and its generalization capability and capacity. Finally, the approach is verified by a widely known and publicly available SIPaKMeD dataset. With a classification accuracy rate of more than 98% from the experiment results, our method also demonstrated high accuracy in precision, recall, and F1-score, depicting a near-perfect, stable, and validated experiment.

title: WIP: Exploratory Analysis of Code Quality Issues in CS1
authors: Isabela Vieira Rodrigues, Igor dos Santos Montagner
abstract: In this Research-to-practice WIP paper we present an analysis of the integration of a code quality tool into a bootcamp-style CS1 course, with a focus on correlating quality issues with a superficial understanding of programming by examining the relationship between code quality issues and limited programming comprehension. Although initially studied in the context of Software Engineering courses, there has also been interest in including code quality in CS1/2 levels. In this paper we examine two main questions: (i) which types of errors do students make when solving CS1 coding questions?, and (ii) is there a correlation between certain types of errors and student performance? We hypothesize that the type and frequency of errors are inversely proportional to students' performance and proportional to assignment complexity. We added a code quality tool to all assignments of an intensive CS1 course and did a retrospective analysis using data from two course offerings in 2024 (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{N}=66$</tex> students, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{N}=851$</tex> code submissions). We analyze 5 high-stakes exams and 5 low-stakes quizzes, computing the frequency and type of the issues flagged. We also correlate each issue type with students' performance. Our analysis shows that most code quality issues identified in student submissions are related to formatting and style, not to code structure. Tasks involving more complex data structures, such as lists and dictionaries, tend to have a higher frequency of code structure-related issues. However, student performance was inversely proportional to issues that were not related to code structure, such as formatting or incorrect use of Python features. Finally, high-performing students still produce code with a significant amount of code quality issues.

title: Next-Gen Power Management for Telecom Towers: Ai-Optimized Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Harjot Singh, Nirmal Punetha
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Telecommunication networks continue to expand into regions where stable electrical infrastructure is limited, forcing operators to rely heavily on diesel-based power systems that impose disproportionate operational and environmental burdens. This study presents a comprehensive, data-centric framework for managing hybrid renewable energy systems (HRES) designed for telecom towers. Central to the framework is a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) forecasting engine that anticipates solar, wind, and load variations to inform real-time power-dispatch decisions. The proposed methodology addresses pervasive challenges such as irregular sensor data, limited historical records, and model-scalability constraints typical in remote telecom environments. It introduces a refined dataengineering pipeline, an adaptive deep-learning architecture, and a multi-criteria optimization layer that jointly minimize diesel utilization while safeguarding reliability. The framework's capabilities are demonstrated through multi-regional case studies and uncertainty-aware simulations. The results reveal meaningful gains in predictive accuracy, economic efficiency, and environmental sustainability, offering a pathway toward resilient and low-carbon telecom infrastructure.

title: Simulation and Hardware in Project-Based Learning for Mobile Robotics and Computer Vision
authors: Victor Hayashi, Murilo Zanini Carvalho, Guilherme Cestari, Lisane Valdo, Rodrigo Nicola, Michele Bazana Souza, Henrique Mohallem Paiva
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper describes explores the role of simulation and hardware-based learning in a Project-Based Learning (PBL) approach for teaching Mobile Robotics and Computer Vision. The research investigates the hypothesis that simulation is more suitable for initial learning, while hardware is essential for consolidating concepts. The study involved 30 second-year Computer Engineering students who developed solutions for an industry-provided real-world problem. Student perceptions were assessed through Likert-scale questionnaires evaluating the effectiveness of tools such as Turtlesim, Webots, Gazebo, TurtleBot, and YOLO. Teachers' insights were compared to student responses, and qualitative data was analyzed using researcher triangulation. Additionally, student performance in simulation and hardware-based activities was quantitatively examined. Findings indicate that students perceived simulation and hardware as equally important for early learning and concept development. However, Mobile Robotics tools were seen as less supportive for experimenting with solutions compared to Computer Vision tools. Most students recognized the complementary nature of both approaches but did not find hardware easier to use than simulation. This study provides insights into optimizing PBL experiences in Mobile Robotics and Computer Vision, emphasizing the strategic integration of simulation and hardware for effective learning.

title: Factors Impacting Faculty Adoption of Project-Based Learning in Computing Education: A Survey
authors: Ahmad D. Suleiman, Yiming Tang, Daqing Hou
abstract: This research full paper investigates the factors influencing computing educators' adoption of project-based learning (PjBL) in software engineering and computing curricula. Recognized as a student-centered pedagogical approach, PjBL has the potential to enhance student motivation, engagement, critical thinking, collaboration, and problem-solving skills. Despite these benefits, faculty adoption remains inconsistent due to challenges such as insufficient institutional support, time constraints, limited training opportunities, designing or sourcing projects, and aligning them with course objectives. This research explores these barriers and investigates the strategies and resources that facilitate a successful adoption. Using a mixed-methods approach, data from 80 computing faculty were collected through an online survey comprising closed-ended questions to quantify barriers, enablers, and resource needs, along with an open-ended question to gather qualitative insights. Quantitative data were analyzed using statistical methods, while qualitative responses underwent thematic analysis. Results reveal that while PjBL is widely valued, its adoption is often selective and impacted by challenges in planning and managing the learning process, designing suitable projects, and a lack of institutional support, such as time, funding, and teaching assistants. Faculty are more likely to adopt or sustain PjBL when they have access to peer collaboration, professional development, and institutional incentives. In addition, sourcing projects from research, industry partnerships, and borrowing from peers emerged as key facilitators for new projects. These findings underscore the need for systemic support structures to empower faculty to experiment with and scale PjBL practices.

title: LLM-Powered Protein Classification: A Deep Learning Framework for Kinases, Phosphatases, and Transmembrane Proteins
authors: Syed Salman Ali Zaidi, Ali Zain Sharif, Muhammad Hassan Shahbaz, Sania Urooj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Accurate functional classification of proteins is essential in biomedicine and therapeutic development. Traditional computational approaches often face challenges in scalability and identifying novel sequences. This study evaluates the performance of several pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs) on two key classification tasks: kinase/phosphatase differentiation and transmembrane protein identification. We fine-tuned and assessed CAFA-5, ChatterjeLab/PepMLM, and ChatterjeLab/MeMDLM using UniProtKB for kinase/phosphatase data and ActTRANS for transmembrane proteins. In contrast to earlier studies such as ActTRANS which focused on binary classification using frozen embeddings and SVMs. The proposed approach employs an end-to-end neural classifier in a broader multi-class setting, demonstrating greater generalizability across protein families. The integration of LLMs with protein sequence analysis offers a scalable and accurate solution that can accelerate drug discovery and optimize therapeutic strategies. CAFA-5 consistently outperformed other models, ranking first in both tasks. It achieved 90% accuracy, 89.74% balanced accuracy, and an Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) of 0.7995 in kinase/phosphatase classification, and 98.9% accuracy with a perfect MCC of 1.0 for transmembrane proteins. While PepMLM also performed well (91.89% accuracy, MCC: 0.84), MeMDLM scored lower (80.53% accuracy, MCC: 0.63). These results highlight the capability of LLMs to detect complex sequence patterns and outperform traditional methods. This work not only advances computational biology but also contributes to precision medicine, particularly in areas like oncology, where understanding kinase-phosphatase dynamics is critical.

title: Optimization of Sigmoid Activation Function on FPGA: An Analysis of Linear Interpolation with Fixed-Point Representations
authors: Prachi Mukherji, Seema Rajput, Vaishnavi Mudaliar
publish: 2025 IEEE Recent Advances in Intelligent Computational Systems (RAICS)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive empirical study of FPGA-based implementations of the sigmoid activation function using lookup-table (LUT) linear interpolation. We evaluate three fixed-point formats (Q4.12, Q5.11, and Q6.10) and introduce a LUT generation technique that employs dense sampling with a step size of 0.125 in high-curvature regions and sparse sampling with a step size of 0.5 in saturation regions. Combined with the symmetry property of the sigmoid, this approach reduces LUT memory by more than half while preserving accuracy. Both the sigmoid function and its derivative are implemented in hardware, supporting efficient neural network training and inference. Synthesized on FPGA, the designs are analyzed in terms of precision and hardware resource utilization. Among these, Q5.11 achieves the lowest error, with a maximum below 6×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−4</sup>, representing an over 93% reduction compared to Q4.12 (maximum error 9.2×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup>) and a approximately 96% reduction compared to Q6.10 (maximum error 1.5×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−2</sup>). This demonstrates that Q5.11 offers the best approximation fidelity, highlighting the trade-off between word length allocation and accuracy. Beyond benchmarking, this work provides a hardwareaware design space exploration of fixed-point formats and LUT strategies, offering practical guidelines for deploying activation functions in resource-constrained neural network accelerators.

title: Robust Least Squares Twin Support Vector Machine With Adaptive Pinball Loss_supp1-3649221.pdf
authors: Hong-Jie Xing
abstract: Compared with the conventional twin support vector machine (TSVM), the least squares TWSVM (LSTSVM) possesses the advantages of faster training speed and better generalization performance. However, the square loss function is used in the optimization problems of LSTSVM, which makes it sensitive to noise contained in training samples and thus suffers from poor generalization ability. In this article, a novel adaptive pinball loss function is proposed, which possesses the merits of both pinball and smooth pinball loss functions. Under a certain condition, the convexity of the adaptive pinball loss function is guaranteed. Furthermore, to improve the anti-noise and generalization abilities of LSTSVM, a robust LSTSVM (RLS-TWSVM) is developed by replacing the square loss function in LSTSVM with the adaptive pinball loss function. The iteratively reweighted least squares (IRLSs) method is adopted to solve the optimization problems of the proposed RLS-TWSVM. The computational complexity and convergence analysis for the training procedure of the RLS-TWSVM are both provided. Moreover, it is proven that the proposed method is insensitive to noise distributed near the classification boundary. It is also shown that the proposed method can simultaneously minimize within-class scatter and misclassification error. In experiments, the proposed method outperforms ten related methods in anti-noise and generalization. Especially, compared with the second-best methods, the proposed method achieves a total average accuracy increase of 3.28% and 1.16% on the original, feature noise-polluted, and label noise-polluted benchmark datasets and MINIST, respectively. The MATLAB codes for the proposed method can be downloaded from <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/hbuxing/APL-RLSTSVM</uri>

title: WIP: Integrating Industry and Research in STEM Transportation Festivals for Middle and High School Audiences
authors: Hope Whiteside, Joni M. Lakin, Bernadette Beavers-Forrest, Kay Love
abstract: This is a WIP, innovative practice paper. Many K-12 students and teachers hold the misconception that engineers work primarily in isolation and on narrow problems involving mathematics and established scientific principles. This perspective overlooks the vast field of engineering research in which large interdisciplinary teams address emergent issues. The present team works in a research institute focused on transportation., including specialization in electric vehicles, battery technology, smart infrastructure, and policy. This paper describes a K-12 outreach event that shows K-12 audiences the many ways engineering research affects their daily lives and safety.

title: Mental Health Needs of International Students: Insights for Digital Solutions
authors: Alex Gurung, Chandra Kala Rai, HousamEldin A. Mohamed, Charlotte Tang
abstract: This research full paper presents findings of an online survey that examined international students' mental health challenges and their coping strategies, as well as their experience with counseling. Guided by Acculturative Stress Theory, international students encounter stress from both extrinsic and intrinsic sources. The extrinsic stressors mostly come from academic pressure, financial concerns, and sociocultural adjustment difficulties, whereas the intrinsic stressors are largely related to post-graduation uncertainty and visa status concerns. Cultural stigma emerged as a significant barrier to seeking professional help, with many students perceiving mental health struggles as a personal weakness. As a result, self-management was common. Students often relied on social support, entertainment, relaxation activities, and campus engagement to manage stress and anxiety. While relatively few had accessed in-person counseling, a substantial majority expressed interest in remote counseling services, citing enhanced privacy, scheduling flexibility, and the elimination of transportation barriers as the advantages. These findings highlight the need for universities to develop culturally sensitive support systems integrating both in-person and remote counseling services. Additionally, increasing awareness of available resources, adjusting financial aid, and structuring programs to support cultural adjustment are crucial for promoting mental well-being and academic success of international students. These insights can guide universities in designing more inclusive mental health support systems.

title: DeepFP: Deep-Unfolded Fractional Programming for MIMO Beamforming
authors: Jianhang Zhu, Tsung-Hui Chang, Liyao Xiang, Kaiming Shen
abstract: This work proposes a mixed learning-based and optimization-based approach to the weighted-sum-rates beamforming problem in a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) wireless network. The conventional methods, i.e., the fractional programming (FP) method and the weighted minimum mean square error (WMMSE) algorithm, can be computationally demanding for two reasons: (i) they require inverting a sequence of matrices whose sizes are proportional to the number of antennas; (ii) they require tuning a set of Lagrange multipliers to account for the power constraints. The recently proposed method called the reduced WMMSE addresses the above two issues for a single cell. In contrast, for the multicell case, another recent method called the FastFP eliminates the large matrix inversion and the Lagrange multipliers by using an improved FP technique, but the update stepsize in the FastFP can be difficult to decide. As such, we propose integrating the deep unfolding network into the FastFP for the stepsize optimization. Numerical experiments show that the proposed method is much more efficient than the learning method based on the WMMSE algorithm.

title: Goal-guided Prompting with Adaptive Modality Selection for Efficient Assembly Activity Anticipation in Egocentric Videos
authors: Tianshan Liu, Bing-Kun Bao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: With the functions of egocentric observation and multimodal perception equipped in augmented reality (AR) devices, the next generation of smart assistants has the potential to reduce human labor and enhance execution efficiency in assembly tasks. Among diverse assembly activity understanding tasks, anticipating the near future activities is crucial yet challenging, which can assist humans or agents to actively plan and engage in interactions with the environment. However, the existing egocentric activity anticipation methods still struggle to achieve a decent trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency, hindering them to be deployed in practical applications. To address this dilemma, in this paper, we propose a goal-guided prompting framework with adaptive modality selection (GP-AMS), for assembly activity anticipation in egocentric videos. For bridging the semantic gap between the historical observations and unobserved future activities, we inject the inferred high-level goal clues into the constructed prompts, which are further utilized to guide a pre-trained vision-language (V-L) model to compensate relevant semantics of unseen future. Moreover, a mask-and-predict strategy is adopted with two imposed constraints, i.e., casual masking and probabilistic token-dropping, to mine the intrinsic associations between the assembly activities within a specific procedure. For maintaining the benefits of exploiting multimodal information while avoiding extensively increasing the computational burdens, an adaptive modality selection strategy is designed to train a policy network, which learns to dynamically decide which modalities should be sampled for processing by the anticipation model on a per observation time-step basis. By allocating major computation to the selected indicative modalities on-the-fly, the efficiency of the overall model can be improved, thus paving the way for feasibility on real-world devices. Extensive experimental results on two public data sets validate that the proposed method yields not only consistent improvements in anticipation accuracy, but also significant savings in computation budgets.

title: High Order Units in Group Rings Given by Finite Field and Cyclic Group
authors: Yevhen Bershchanskyi, Roksolana Oberyshyn, Roman Popovych
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The basis of the vast majority of cryptographic information protection systems are the so called computationally hard problems. One such problem is to find the discrete logarithm in a finite group. The problem consists in obtaining for any two elements of the group such natural number that the first element to the power of this number is equal to the second one. To implement a cryptosystem, one must choose a specific finite group and a high order element in it (so that computing the discrete logarithm is a hard problem). Quantum computers will be able to solve efficiently the discrete logarithm problem in the most common finite groups (the multiplicative group of a prime or an extended finite field, the group of points of an elliptic curve over a finite field). Therefore, as one of the directions, they study groups consisting of units of group rings specified by a certain ring and a group. In this paper, the issue of finding high order units for partial group rings, which are given by any finite field and finite cyclic group, is investigated.

title: SGS-Mamba: Semantic Gap-Sensitive Mamba Network for Medical Small Lesion Segmentation
authors: Xiaoshan Xie, Zhiheng Zhou, Wenlve Zhou, Xu Jing, Ming Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Accurate segmentation of small lesions is critical for the early diagnosis and intervention of severe diseases. U-shaped networks (U-Nets) are widely used models for lesion segmentation, renowned for their strong feature extraction capabilities and encoder–decoder architecture, which incorporates direct skip connection (DSC) to preserve spatial details. However, their decoders often exhibit information-specific biases toward the content provided by DSC due to the semantic gap between the encoder-decoder feature sets, rather than maintaining a strict one-to-one correspondence. This semantic mismatch reduces their effectiveness in segmenting small lesions with weak or indistinct features, thereby failing to meet high-precision clinical requirements. To address this limitation, we propose the Semantic Gap-Sensitive Mamba U-shaped Network (SGS-Mamba), enhancing sensitivity to small lesions across three dimensions: long-range interaction, guided filtering and semantic alignment. Specifically, an adaptive Visual State Space block is designed to focus on small lesions by leveraging long-range contextual modeling. A Self-Guided Filtering Attention (SGFA) at the bottleneck is employed to enhance small lesions through noise suppression and attention focus. The Semantic Gap-sensitive Skip Connection (SGSC), incorporating Cross-Guided Filtering module and Rényi divergence regularization, are designed to bridge the semantic gap through long-range interaction and semantic alignment. Experiments conducted on three small lesion datasets and one multi-label dataset demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, while maintaining competitive computational efficiency. Furthermore, when the SGFA and SGSC modules are integrated as plug-and-play components within other architectures, they consistently yield substantial improvements, underscoring that their benefits generalize effectively across diverse architectures and tasks.

title: iTempDT: AI-Powered Digital Twin for Forecasting Indoor Temperature in Smart Buildings
authors: Md Babul Islam, Antonio Guerrieri, Raffaele Gravina, Luigi Pontieri, Luigi Rizzo, Francesco Scala, Andrea Vinci, Giancarlo Fortino
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Pervasive and Intelligent Computing (PICom)
abstract: This work presents iTempDT, an AI-driven Digital Twin (DT) approach that uses deep learning to forecast indoor temperature based on Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) system operations. Accurate temperature forecasting is essential for smart buildings (SBs), which aim to optimize energy efficiency without compromising occupant comfort. iTempDT addresses this need by providing accurate and timely forecasts that allow intelligent HVAC control and energy-efficient decision-making. At the core of iTempDT is a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) integrated with an attention mechanism to capture temporal dynamics and feature dependencies from multivariate time series data collected from both indoor and outdoor sensors. The model is trained for multi-step indoor temperature forecasting, explicitly conditioned on the recent HVAC status (ON/OFF), allowing for real-time predictions as well as scenario-based simulations. Also, an interactive dashboard enables real-time visualization and virtual control of HVAC settings. To promote sustainable and energy-conscious AI practices, iTempDT integrates a Green AI approach by applying post-training quantization. This reduces the model size and speeds up inference, making it suitable for deployment on low-power edge devices. The DT prototype was developed at the ICAR-CNR IoT Lab in Rende, Italy. iTempDT shows strong performance across key metrics (MAE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and RPD). Finally, the proposed approach is compared with other state-of-the-art models.

title: High-Altitude Balloon (HAB) based Validation of CubeSat Communication Links for IoT Applications
authors: Katakam Sowmyagiri, Erlapally Sai Prakash Goud, Sunnam Venkata Srikanth
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: In recent years, the Internet of Things (IoT) has become one of the most influential technological paradigms, enabling smart sensing, monitoring, and decision-making across diverse sectors such as agriculture, healthcare, environmental monitoring, industrial automation and many more. However, despite the widespread deployment of IoT networks, a significant challenge persists in extending connectivity to remote and rural regions where conventional network infrastructure like Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and Zigbee are limited by range, power constraints, and lack of coverage in isolated areas. To address this issue, satellite communication offers an effective solution however, its economic constraints and lengthy development timelines limit widespread adoption. In response to these challenges, recent advancements in CubeSats operating in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) have emerged as a promising alternative, where the integration of CubeSat technology with Long Range (LoRa) communication operating in the ISM band can effectively bridge this gap. This paper presents a CubeSat-based communication system that uses LoRa technology to enable long-range, low-power communication between ground-based IoT nodes and LEO satellites. To evaluate the reliability of the proposed communication link, a High-Altitude Balloon (HAB) experiment was conducted to emulate satellite communication conditions. The experimental results demonstrate the viability of this approach, indicating strong potential for future implementation in satellite–IoT integration scenarios.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for Optimizing Pricing Strategies in the Airline Industry
authors: K. Sathiyamurthi, M. Ganesan Alias Kanagaraj, V. Vimalnath, K.K. Karthick, Ramar Veluchamy, N. Udaya Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Dynamic pricing is one of the burning issues in the airline industry because it is challenging to maximize revenues because of the dynamic demand, seasonality, and competitor influence. The article suggests that a machine learning-based mechanism that uses splendid feature engineering, modular modelling, and reinforcement learning in dynamic pricing of tickets can be established. The model created was 96.8 percent accurate on a validation on a history of past bookings, competitor rates and external effects including fuel prices and weather and produced an average 8.7 percent increase in income as compared to traditional methods. The SHAP analysis showed that the most significant features are booking lead time, competitor fare difference, and seasonal demand. The quality of the provided system in comparison with accuracy and time of inference is substantiated by comparison with the previous literature. According to the findings, the interpretable and real-time machine learning option combination can contribute greatly to the progress in terms of profitability and transparency of the airline pricing policy.

title: Models of Availability Assessing UAV-based Systems for Monitoring Dangerous Space Considering Human Machine Interface with Embedded AR
authors: Yevhenii Kanarskyi, Vyacheslav Kharchenko, Ihor Kliushnikov, Oleksandr Orehov, Yuriy Ponochovnyy, Anastasiia Stadnyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Modern systems for forest fire monitoring, humanitarian demining, critical infrastructure control, and other dangerous or potentially dangerous spaces require the use of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). To improve their effectiveness, these systems also require the integration of artificial intelligence (AI), cloud technologies, digital twins, and other advanced tools. One such technology is augmented reality (AR), which, when applied in humanmachine interaction (HMI) tools, has the potential to enhance the user experience of UAV operators and significantly reduce the number of errors made during task execution. The objectives of this study are to: (a) develop a simplified architecture of a dangerous spaces monitoring system focused on the interaction between the operator and the UAV; (b) develop a prototype of a HMI using AR technology for UAV operators; (c) develop Markov models that both exclude and include the possibility of operator error during UAV control, for subsequent comparison and assessment of their impact on the system. The main contribution is the AR-based HMI prototype for UAV control as part of a hazardous area monitoring system and results of simulation of suggested Markov models considering UAV operator reaction time and risk of errors.
