title: ExpAbsTanH: A Novel Activation Function for Image and Video-Based Human Activity Recognition
authors: Zeynep Vildan Isik, Tayyip Ozcan
abstract: Activation functions are fundamental components of deep neural networks, providing the nonlinear transformations that enable complex representation learning and strongly influence model performance in deep learning–based artificial intelligence systems. However, despite their proven importance, commonly used activation functions often suffer from critical limitations such as vanishing or exploding gradients, non-differentiability at zero, and instability during training. These limitations become particularly relevant in image classification and Human Activity Recognition (HAR) tasks, where complex spatial or spatiotemporal dependencies, along with noisy data, can adversely affect training stability. To address these limitations, we propose a novel activation function, ExpAbsTanH, which integrates self-gating with exponential control and smooth nonlinearity. To assess its theoretical robustness and stability, initial experiments were conducted on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, demonstrating that ExpAbsTanH consistently delivers strong classification performance across diverse deep learning architectures. ExpAbsTanH was found to outperform ReLU and Swish in most cases, achieving performance comparable to that of Mish. When integrated into ResNet-200, ExpAbsTanH achieved a Top-1 accuracy of 90.08% on CIFAR-10, highlighting its stability and effectiveness in deep convolutional networks. Beyond static images, the robustness of ExpAbsTanH for HAR was evaluated on the UCF-50 and UCF-101 datasets. For temporally complex tasks, a hybrid model combining ResNet-50 with a single-layer Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network and an attention module was employed. On UCF-50, the ExpAbsTanH-based model consistently outperformed the ReLU-based model, achieving Top-1 and Top-5 accuracies of 95.69% and 98.74%, respectively. To further assess its generalization capability, experiments conducted on randomly selected subsets of the UCF-101 dataset demonstrated the highest Top-1 and Top-5 accuracies of 99.47% and 99.79%, respectively. Under noisy conditions, the ExpAbsTanH-based model achieved a Top-1 accuracy of 95.51% on the UCF-50 dataset, consistently surpassing the ReLU-based model. On the UCF-101 dataset, this integration maintained a Top-1 accuracy of 98.63%, demonstrating its robustness against input distortions. Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) analysis further revealed that ExpAbsTanH focused on semantically meaningful and spatially coherent features, whereas ReLU occasionally emphasized irrelevant regions. ExpAbsTanH has become a robust and effective alternative activation function, improving the reliability of real-world deep learning systems by delivering high performance across image and video recognition tasks.

title: Fine-Grained Hashing for High Spatial Resolution Optical-SAR Remote Sensing Image Retrieval
authors: Gu Lingyun, Fang Qingyun, Fang Yuxin, Yang Shaohua, Li Wenping, Xi Xiaofei, Dong Ge
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Optical (OPT) and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) cross-modal remote sensing image retrieval is a key technique for all-weather Earth observation. The enhancement of SAR image resolution has driven the development from conventional scene-level retrieval to object-level retrieval. Inter-class similarity, intra-class variability, and cross-modal discrepancies are general challenges in cross-modal image retrieval. Although existing methods have attempted to address them at the scene level, these challenges persist in object-level tasks due to inherent limitations of the methods, such as detail loss caused by global pooling and insufficient local discrimination. To address this gap, a novel FGHN is proposed to enhance the retrieval accuracy. First, a focus-aware residual network is designed to highlight discriminative local features, facilitating the extraction of semantic details. Second, an intra-class feature aggregation loss is introduced to improve intra-class compactness, reinforcing the consistency of fine-grained representations. Finally, a distance enhanced weighting strategy is incorporated into the hash learning loss to promote similarity among hash codes of the same class. To support fine-grained OPT-SAR retrieval, we construct a High-Resolution OPT-SAR dataset, termed HROS. It is worth noting that the SAR images in HROS were collected by our team. Extensive experiments are conducted to evaluate both FGHN and HROS. The experimental results demonstrate that HROS exhibits high resolution, strong robustness, and superior differentiation, establishing it as a promising benchmark for OPT-SAR retrieval. FGHN achieves state-of-the-art performance on HROS, obtaining 89.80% mAP and 93.95% P@10 for OPT image retrieval with SAR queries at 32 bits hash code. Its strong generalization capability is further validated on the public CBRSIR VS dataset. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of the three innovative modules. Moreover, FGHN proves potential for large-scale remote sensing image retrieval applications.

title: WIP: Defining Collaborative Educational Standards for AI Hardware
authors: Ben A. Tanay, Kerrie A. Douglas, Peter Bermel, Maria Oliveri
abstract: This WIP innovative practice presents an initial list of education standards related to artificial intelligence (AI) hardware that are most relevant for US-based employers (e.g., Department of Defense, Defense Industrial Base, and Commerce) in the semiconductor sectors. It also provides a modular and reusable data collection framework that allows for replication in similarly emerging technical areas. The need for such a list and framework stems from the lack of formally defined educational standards for AI hardware. In the United States, the CHIPS and Science Act continues to fund ongoing efforts to bolster the next-generation engineering workforce with programs that aim to bridge the gap between education in academia and technical work in industry. Our framework is explicitly collaborative in that it facilitates interaction between subject matter experts in academia and industry. Its iterative nature provides consistent opportunities for continuous refinement. Educational standards most prevalent to AI hardware are primarily concentrated around five areas: 1) fundamental of AI hardware, 2) performance and power considerations, 3) industry applications and use cases, 4) hardware-software co-design, and 5) troubleshooting and debugging. Immediately, in providing this list of educational standards, engineering programs and instructors can more effectively evaluate the extent to which their courses currently cover the requirements and where they may need to create additional curricula. In providing this framework for generating educational standards, researchers are provided a flexible protocol to generate similar results - both for AI hardware and other contexts where widely agreed-upon educational standards are not yet standardized.

title: Enhancing Large Language Models for Automated Homework Assessment in Undergraduate Circuit Analysis
authors: Liangliang Chen, Huiru Xie, Zhihao Qin, Yiming Guo, Jacqueline Rohde, Ying Zhang
abstract: This research full paper presents an enhancement pipeline for large language models (LLMs) in assessing homework for an undergraduate circuit analysis course, aiming to improve LLMs' capacity to provide personalized support to electrical engineering students. Existing evaluations have demonstrated that GPT-4o possesses promising capabilities in assessing student homework in this domain. Building on these findings, we enhance GPT-4o's performance through multi-step prompting, contextual data augmentation, and the incorporation of targeted hints. These strategies effectively address common errors observed in GPT-4o's responses when using simple prompts, leading to a substantial improvement in assessment accuracy. Specifically, the correct response rate for GPT-4o increases from 74.71% to 97.70% after applying the enhanced prompting and augmented data on entry-level circuit analysis topics. This work lays a foundation for the effective integration of LLMs into circuit analysis instruction and, more broadly, into engineering education.

title: WIP: Investigating the Effect of Gendered Seating Proximity on Classroom Success for Female Engineering Students
authors: Cassandra Savukinas, Kayla D. Taylor, Ashley Lear
abstract: This research WIP paper examines the impact of gendered seating proximity on academic success for female engineering students. The rate of female students earning engineering degrees has steadily increased over the past few decades but has not yet reached the same level as male students. Understanding the factors that contribute to increased retention and success for female engineering students is crucial to help bridge this gap and improve representation for women in STEM. In undergraduate engineering classrooms, it is common to find female students sitting near each other, rather than evenly distributed, in male-dominated classrooms. Preliminary results indicate that sitting near other female-presenting students significantly increases the perceived performance, comfort, and participation for undergraduate female engineering students. This suggests that female engineering students benefit from sitting near other women, both in terms of classroom experience and academic achievement.

title: WIP: A Pedagogy Study on Human Computer Interaction as a Necessary Foundation for Mobile Application Development
authors: Hongbo Zhou, Michelle Zhu, Liaquat Hossain
abstract: This research WIP paper examines the impact of prior Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) knowledge on student performance in mobile application development courses through a controlled experimental design. Two student groups, one with HCI exposure and one without, were assessed within identical learning environments. Results from both quantitative and qualitative analyses indicate that prior HCI knowledge significantly enhances design thinking, interface clarity, navigation logic, cognitive efficiency, and user-centered development. These effects were consistent across undergraduate and graduate levels. The findings highlight HCI's role in cultivating critical skills for mobile app development and support its structured inclusion in computing curricula. This study offers practical implications for educators and contributes to ongoing efforts to enhance computer science education.

title: A Performance Based Analysis of Terrestrial Networks and Satellite Based Internet in Zimbabwe
authors: Tadzemba Kristian Takudzwa, Clopas Kwenda, Munyaradzi Maravanyika, Mike Kale
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This study shows that internet connectivity in Zimbabwe is strongly shaped by a persistent urban-rural divide, with significant gaps in availability, performance, and affordability between terrestrial and satellite technologies. Fibre networks continue to offer the highest performance in terms of speed and latency, making them ideal for urban environments where infrastructure investment is viable. LTE remains a critical component of national connectivity, balancing cost and coverage but suffering from congestion and quality fluctuations in rural areas. Satellite-based systems, while associated with higher initial deployment costs, provide consistent performance and the potential to extend connectivity to underserved and remote regions where terrestrial infrastructure is not economically feasible. Overall, the results underscore the need for a hybrid connectivity approach that combines terrestrial and satellite technologies, supported by targeted policies and investment strategies, to effectively address Zimbabwe's digital divide. Future work should focus on optimizing cost models, improving technology integration, and exploring innovative policy frameworks to ensure that universal, reliable, and affordable internet access becomes a reality across all regions of the country.

title: An Intelligent Data Extraction Framework for Efficient Model Retraining Under Distribution Shift
authors: Hoo Meng Wong, Ling Ling Chan, Siti Farah Norbaini Binti Mohamad, Sundresan Perumal
abstract: Maintaining the performance of machine learning (ML) models amid evolving data distributions presents a considerable challenge in real-world applications. This paper introduces a framework that integrates model monitoring, intelligent data extraction, and efficient retraining strategies to address distribution shifts proactively. Continuous monitoring facilitates early detection of data drift and enables selective extraction of the most informative data for retraining, thereby reducing computational and storage requirements. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach maintains high predictive accuracy while significantly decreasing both the volume of retraining data and the latency relative to conventional retraining methods.

title: GHAttack: Generative Adversarial Attacks on Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks
authors: Shaoxin Li, Xiaofeng Liao, Huanzhang Zhu, Junqing Le, Lingyang Chu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Heterogeneous graph neural networks (HGNNs) have witnessed remarkable progress and widespread applications in recent years. Meanwhile, there is growing attention regarding their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. Existing attack methods for HGNNs generate perturbations to slightly modify the structure of a heterogeneous graph, thereby degrading the predictive performance of HGNNs on target nodes. However, to craft such a perturbation, these methods require solving a complicated optimization problem, which makes them computationally inefficient for launching attacks during the inference phase. In this work, we, therefore, introduce generative heterogeneous attack (GHAttack), a novel generative attack method for efficient and effective adversarial attacks on HGNNs. Specifically, GHAttack aims to train a perturbation generator, which produces a perturbation for each target node via a simple forward pass, while allowing the perturbation to modify edges on the heterogeneous relations of the graph to obtain high attack effectiveness. To achieve this, we design a novel model architecture for the generator, consisting of an HGNN backbone and a relation-aware output layer. We formulate the training of the generator as an optimization problem and efficiently solve it by addressing a series of technical challenges. Extensive experiments on ten representative HGNNs and six datasets verify the high efficiency and excellent effectiveness of GHAttack.

title: Building a Positive Perception of Biology in Undergraduate Engineering Students
authors: Prashanth Suresh Kumar, Harshpreet Kaur, Ishrat Ayesha Bombaywala, Manaasve Vij, Arya C Vachhani, Brainerd Prince
abstract: Engineering students in India often hold negative perceptions of biology, especially those who did not study the subject in grades 11 and 12. Yet, biology is increasingly essential for addressing complex engineering challenges. In this study, we implemented an integrated, experiential teaching approach combining hands-on demonstrations, non-graded interactive assessments, and project-based learning through structured research writing module. The aim was to improve student engagement and reshape perceptions of biology through active learning. Shifts in student attitudes were tracked using surveys administered at the beginning and end of the course, based on a 5-point Likert scale. Initially, 75% of students viewed biology as overly reliant on memorization; by the end, this figure had dropped to 15%. Likewise, the proportion of students who believed biology could be approached logically and systematically—like mathematics or physics—increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 \%}$</tex>. Despite these improvements in content perception, students' interest in pursuing biology-related majors or careers remained low. In fact, students appeared to shift from a favourable to a more cautious stance regarding biology as a career path. This shift could indicate that the increased clarity about the nature of biology through the course helped students make more informed decisions aligned with their existing interests in engineering. Overall, the findings suggest that this innovative research-based teaching approach can meaningfully improve how engineering students perceive biology.

title: Power Consumption of LED-Based LiFi Transmitters
authors: Xiaochen Liu, Thiago E. B. Cunha, Diego Vargas Romero, Jean-Paul M. G. Linnartz
abstract: Communication via light, particularly light fidelity (LiFi), offers secure wireless connectivity that is free from radio frequency (RF) interference and enables dense spectrum reuse. This paper advances the modeling of the power consumption involved when using light-emitting diodes (LEDs) as emitters. Many earlier publications assume that the electrical power con sumption of a LiFi emitter is proportional to the variance of the input signal, thus to the average of the square of the signal. This widely adopted model has proven to be problematic for several reasons. It implies a potential violation of the law of conservation of energy (LoCoE), overlooks the Shockley diode equation, and disregards the fundamental energy required to generate photons. Therefore, it often leads to inappropriate optimization designs as it assumes that electrical power consumption scales with signal variance. LiFi requires more accurate models to estimate its power consumption than those typically used in the literature. This work introduces a more realistic model. The electrical power consumed by an LED is, in reasonable approximation, proportional to the first moment of the non-negative signal or to the root-mean-square (RMS) standard deviation of the modulation signal. Our results align with the LoCoE, wall-plug efficiency, and the Shockley diode equation. These emphasize that photon generation depends on a relatively constant voltage rather than a voltage that scales linearly with the photon f lux. According to Planck's function, this voltage is linked to a wavelength-dependent constant. We explored counterintuitive consequences of this perspective in detail. Importantly, we show that when power for photon creation is modeled more accurately and applied to an intensity-modulated optical link, the optimal design strategies differ substantially from those derived from RF systems.

title: Sliding Mode Controller Design for Blue Hydrogen-Fired Gas Turbine using Hybrid Approach
authors: Tai Qing Huai, Tamiru Alemu Lemma, Mohd Faizal Bin Mohamed
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid control strategy for isochronous speed regulation of blue hydrogen-fired gas turbines. Hydrogen combustion introduces strong nonlinearities that degrade the performance of conventional PID controllers. A validated Rolls-Royce RB211-61 model was used in MATLAB Simulink to design and evaluate three controllers: Gain-Scheduled PID (GS-PID), Gain-Scheduled Sliding Mode Control (GS-SMC) and Sliding Mode Control with Deep Learning (DL-SMC). Simulation results show that GS-SMC achieved most robust performance, reducing overshoot to 2.43% and steady-state errors to 1.29%, compared with 8.28% and 11.98% with GS-PID. Although DL-SMC provided limited improvements due to the low prediction accuracy (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> < 0.32), it demonstrated the feasibility of intelligent gain adaptation. Overall GS-SMC provided the best trade-off between robustness, adaptability, and implementation simplicity.

title: Analyzing Factors on Customer Perception and Purchase Decisions for Sales of Electric Vehicles Cars in India using ML
authors: Dimple Chawla, Harshit Sachdeva, Alisha Arora
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This research paper involves the use of AI, ML, and Power BI for identifying important market dynamics, consumer preferences, and new trends in electric vehicle sales in India. This paper applies machine learning techniques, namely decision trees, random forests, logistic regression, and support vector machines, to perform predictive modeling and classification on the dataset. The research is based on a realworld dataset comprising buyer's name, age, gender, car, model, price range, battery range in kilometers, discharge notification in percentage, USP, and customer feedback. These models help in highlighting the trend in purchases and pinpoint those elements influencing EV sales. Price and battery range were the most influencing factors in purchase decisions, while gender and age group showed the most active consumer groups. USP and feedback analysis shows product appeal. Power BI dashboards were developed to visualize top selling EV models, common price points, battery performance, also shows how discharge notification percentages influence user's purchasing decisions. The integration of AI/ML with Power BI enables in-depth data analysis, effective market analysis, and sales forecasting, allowing manufacturers and marketers to make informed decisions. Overall, this research contributes to the understanding of EV sales patterns in India and supports growth of electric mobility industry.

title: Respiration Monitoring Through Depth Camera in Moving Scenarios
authors: Antonio Nocera, Linda Senigagliesi, Michela Raimondi, Michele Carloni, Christian Chiappa, Matteo Stronati, Ennio Gambi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Motion-robust, continuous, and contactless respiration monitoring has the potential to enhance clinical assessments by enabling more frequent inclusion of respiratory rate in cardiopulmonary risk evaluation. Depth sensing can be used to extract the torso surface area trend over time, which is the result of the breathing process. Movement artifacts still represent a major problem. In this paper, four subjects are asked to walk and breathe freely in a volume measurement. A commercial wearable chest strap is employed as a ground truth. Each subject pose is tracked by deep learning. Four regions of interest are evaluated for respiratory extraction: the entire torso, chest, abdomen, and chest centroid. To compensate for the effect of motion, the nose, the middle of the shoulder, and the abdomen are considered as possible movement reference points and subtracted from the signal extracted from the previously mentioned region of interest. The best results given by the chest area correspond to a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.958 bpm, a standard deviation (STD) of 2.132 bpm, and a Root Mean Square Value (RMSE) of 2.338 bpm.

title: Enhanced Autism Prediction using Hybrid Machine Learning Model
authors: Bhavya A, Kamakshi Srivastava, Jayapandian N
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a condition where individuals face challenges in neurological development and have verbal, non-verbal, learning and behavioral disorders. Even though this condition is identifiable in the first few years in the children's life, many remain undiagnosed until later. This leads to long term developmental issues and delayed interventions. This is what makes the early detection critical for improving development in children. Despite that, traditional diagnosis approaches like behavioral checklists and pre structured interviews rely on the clinician's expertise and are time consuming and have a risk of inconsistency. This study entails and addresses the above problem by proposing a machine learning based multi model to automate early detection in toddlers aged 12 to 36 months. In the initial stage, the traditional classification algorithms like Logistic Regression, SVM are evaluated with high accuracy, F1 score. Then, hybrid models are developed by combining Gradient Boosting as the anchor model with other high performing algorithms, to overcome the limitation of single classification models. These hybrid models help to overcome the limitations of the individual classifiers. Finally, the best-performing hybrid model is enhanced further by Hyperparameter tuning, Feature selection and Cross validation. The outcome of this research will be a hybrid model, combining machine learning algorithms with the best scores, ensuring high accuracy and low false positives. This aims to help in the detection of ASD in early stages in toddlers.

title: Privacy-Preserving Architecture for Cloud Computing Using Machine Learning
authors: Anjali Yadav, Prachi Patel
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: With the fast-paced development of cloud computing, there has been an increasing need of secure and efficient mechanisms for storing and processing sensitive data. Classic data-encryption methods, while offering relatively strong data protection, hinder the performance of computationally intensive advanced analytics and machine learning (ML) on encrypted data. This study advocates a privacy-preserving architecture that trades off between data security, computational performance, and ML compatibility in the cloud. The methodology involves splitting a document into chunks, creating message digests, and encrypting each chunk with Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC). Replication by creating many encrypted copies is then implemented and stored on distributed servers for fault tolerance and lower access latency. The architecture is divided into three core modules: Client End, Master Server/Distributed Server, and Replication. As experimental results from Java technologies and MySQL show, encryption time increases with file size; however, chunking time remains fairly constant. Being replicated slightly raises the upload time but drastically reduces the download time, thus ensuring data reliability. Further, the design facilitates data protection laws like GDPR and HIPAA via strong access control systems. The architecture proposes further privacy and integrity enhancements with efficient ML processes such as homomorphic encryption, federated learning, and differential privacy. In general, this study provides strong evidence that chunk-level encryption, authentication, and replication based on ECC offer a scalable, secure, and efficient solution to the storage and processing of data in clouds with only minimal performance penalties. This makes it an operational framework for secured ML and cloud service models.

title: Towards a Real-Time American Sign Language Typing Interface Using Static and Dynamic Hand Gestures
authors: Letian Zhou, Guojie Li, Hongyu Yang, Fan Zhang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: This paper presents a vision-based sign language recognition system designed to support real-time communication between deaf-mute individuals and digital interfaces or robotic agents. The system focuses on three primary modules: static and dynamic single-hand gesture recognition, dual-hand static gesture recognition, and an interactive user interface. Static gestures, covering 24 ASL alphabet letters (excluding $\mathbf{J}$ and $\mathbf{Z}$) and two functional commands (YES and NO), are classified using a fine-tuned VGG16 convolutional neural network, which achieved a validation accuracy of 92.17%. For dynamic gestures, specifically J and Z, a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model processes landmark trajectories extracted via MediaPipe, achieving a validation accuracy of 91.67%. The dual-hand recognition component, trained separately using the same CNN architecture, accurately detects more complex gestures such as the word “book.” All models are integrated into a multithreaded Python-based user interface that supports live video input, on-screen gesture tracking, dynamic gesture triggering, and buffered text output. Testing results show high classification accuracy across all gesture categories, with real-time performance and consistent recognition even under variable lighting and hand positions. Overall, the system demonstrates a scalable and accessible approach to gesture-based interaction, providing foundational work for future integration with robotic systems or service-oriented applications for deaf and mute users.

title: Integrating Errorless and Scaffolding Learning Theories in a Generative Artificial Intelligence Supported Virtual Learning Environment: Demonstration and Validation
authors: Masood M Khan, Ryan Liebregts, Chris Ford
abstract: This research-to-practice full paper aims to validate the hypothesis that the errorless and scaffolded pedagogies integrated to GAI and embedded in a Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) would produce a more effective learning outcome than the either one in isolation. As best evidence grounded studies on whether Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) supported learning is effective, ineffective, or alike the traditional learning are not available in the Teaching and Learning (T&L) literature, errorless and scaffolding learning methodologies were systematically integrated with GAI in a VLE for testing the hypothesis. Realizing that learning complex methods and concepts, embedded in STEM subjects can be challenging for high school students, domain of this work was introduction of geometry and trigonometry. The presented work demonstrates how to exploit the Large Language Models (LLMs) for implementing errorless and scaffolding learning methodologies in a GAI-supported T&L application. As such, this paper addresses the current gap in development and practical application of AI-driven VLEs' and educational tools. The interactive VLE was further augmented by the state-of-theart, multimedia cues. For validating the overall system, student post-learning feedback was sought. The system was also assessed and validated using the T&L Impact Assessment Tool (TALIAT), achieving a score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$88 / 160$</tex>. This work demonstrates development of a hybrid static-dynamic architecture and using a dynamic content generation schema with transparent decision-making processes. Furthermore, this work defines a reproducible framework for integrating the latest AI technologies with proven pedagogical strategies, offering valuable insights for future AI-driven developments in educational domains.

title: Cultivating Character and Ethics via a Custom-Built AI-Chatbot in an Electric Circuits Activity
authors: Hussein Abdeltawab, Kyle Luthy
abstract: This innovative practice full paper introduces a novel classroom activity that embeds character education into an electrical engineering assignment using a custom-built AI chatbot, which simulates an electrical contractor. The purpose of this paper is two-fold: (1) to show the custom development of an AI-Chatbot for learning applications while focusing on character development, (2) to evaluate the adoption of an AI chatbot to serve as a surrogate for a real-world professional interaction in both a technical and social context. The custombuilt chatbot was integrated into a role-playing scenario where students take on the role of consulting engineers tasked with reviewing the contractor's project for compliance. The project involves verifying the visual notification devices (strobes) of a fire alarm system. Appliance settings, allocations, and specifications must comply with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) code. Code violations were intentionally added on-site for the students to identify. Students were prompted to confront the chatbot regarding these violations, which is programmed to avoid extra costs and deny responsibility. The chatbot leveraged realistic interactions to challenge students in identifying and addressing ethical dilemmas. Insights into student learning gains and character development are gathered through a survey and evaluations of student work. Further, this scenario conflicts between safety compliance and project constraints, including schedules and budgets. Through post-activity surveys, we found that students reported significantly strengthened commitments to safety, greater confidence in speaking up, and a deeper understanding of ethical responsibilities. The results suggest that AI-driven role-play can effectively cultivate integrity and other character virtues alongside technical competencies.

title: Machine Learning based Breast Cancer Prognosis Analysis on Multi-Source Big Data
authors: Hejia Qiu, Ying Weng
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide with a high recurrence rate. The prognosis estimation of breast cancer remains a challenge, which is only investigated by a few works. In our study, we apply various machine learning methods on multi-source breast cancer big data for feature analysis and prognosis evaluation. Based on our experimental results, we conclude that the implementation of machine learning algorithms helps to extract prognostic information, while strategic feature engineering and multi-source data fusion demonstrate significant potential to enhance prognosis prediction performance and clinical decision-making processes.

title: Edge-assisted Key Provisioning in Industrial IoT Systems with Mobile Nodes
authors: Marco Pettorali, Francesca Righetti, Marco Tiloca, Carlo Vallati, Giuseppe Anastasi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: In Industrial IoT (IIoT) environments and especially for applications relying on Mobile Nodes (MNs), ensuring communication security is a critical requirement, in order to prevent attacks that aim to obtain sensitive data or compromise MNs. In this paper, we focus on the security of IIoT systems based on the 6TiSCH architecture defined by the IETF, in the presence of node mobility. We propose a method for provisioning key material to MNs, enabling the enforcement of a trade-off between security and overhead. Specifically, we consider three security settings, characterized by different security levels and communication/storage overhead. For each setting, we evaluate the impact on performance through simulation. Finally, we provide a set of guidelines to help network operators in the selection of the setting to use.

title: Prediction of MMP-9 Inhibitors as Anticancer Therapeutics by Using 1D-CNN Optimized by Monarch Butterfly Algorithm
authors: Shabrina Salsabila, Isman Kurniawan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: The development of therapeutic drugs targeting MMP-9 inhibitors has shown potential in anticancer treatment. Matrix Metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) inhibitors are biomolecules that offer potential as novel anticancer therapies. The conventional development of therapeutic drugs for cancer faces significant challenges due to the high average cost, and an alternative solution is the use of Machine Learning. This study proposes a deep learning approach using a one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) optimized with the Monarch Butterfly Optimization (MBO) algorithm to predict the activity of MMP-9 inhibitor compounds. The dataset consisted of 1,123 samples classified based on pIC50 values. Three baseline 1D-CNN architectures were evaluated and subsequently optimized through MBO with varying population sizes. The results demonstrate that deeper CNN architectures improve classification performance, while MBO significantly enhances convergence and accuracy. Among the optimization schemes, the third scheme, using a population size of 25, achieved the highest test accuracy of 0.7747 and F1-score of 0.7744, indicating superior generalization. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining 1D-CNN and MBO for efficient and accurate anticancer compound prediction.

title: Real-Time Collaborative Music Creation on the Web: exploiting Web Audio Modules for Interactive Performance and Composition
authors: Michel Buffa, Tom Burns
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Advances in web technologies have opened the way to real-time collaborative music applications, enabling musicians to co-create and perform music from anywhere in the world. This paper focuses on the use of Web Audio Modules, an audio plugin standard for the web (WAMs, aka “VSTs for the Web”) in such applications, with a particular emphasis on sequencer.party, a web-based platform for collaborative music creation. We explore how WAMs can form the basis for modular, real-time music composition and performance, enabling users to manipulate audio, MIDI and generative processes in a collaborative way. The presented platform integrates real-time collaborative music installation creation, state synchronization using conflict-free replicated data types (CRDT) and a flexible, track-oriented workflow for live music performance. Through this case study we demonstrate how WAM-based tools can support both educational and performative contexts, offering a new approach to collaborative digital music creation that bridges the gap between traditional environments and web accessibility.

title: Learning Dynamic Fault Trees from Data for Interpretable Failure Prediction
authors: Rudolf Hoffmann, Christoph Reich
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) is a standard method in reliability engineering to model causes of system failures. While Static Fault Trees (SFTs) capture logical dependencies, they cannot represent time-dependent or sequential failure behavior. Dynamic Fault Trees (DFTs) overcome this limitation but are still constructed manually using expert knowledge, limiting their use in data-driven applications. This paper presents a method for automatically learning DFTs from temporal event data. We extend the LIFT algorithm with support for dynamic gates (PAND, SEQ) and use the PAMH test to evaluate statistical associations between event combinations and their parent, while a Chi-square test distinguishes between SEQ and PAND gates based on the frequency of order violations. The result is an interpretable model that captures both structural and temporal failure logic. We evaluate the method on synthetic datasets generated from a manually constructed DFT designed by a domain expert, with varying levels of noise and event frequencies. The learned DFTs show high predictive and structural accuracy under ideal conditions and remain robust under noise with appropriate parameter tuning. This demonstrates the potential of the approach for interpretable failure prediction in intelligent manufacturing systems.

title: An Extended Fuzzy Decision Model for Predicting Academic Success in Informatics Engineering Candidates
authors: Ditdit Nugeraha Utama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Especially in Indonesia, universities are required to guarantee that prospective students accepted into the university will graduate on time. This means that prospective students accepted into a university must be guaranteed to be able to follow lectures well and graduate. Of course, more effort is needed to achieve this, beyond simply accepting students and completing them. This study is a follow-up study in order to build a fuzzy logic-based decision model to predict the academic success of student candidates, specifically in the Informatics Engineering department. The decision model combines five main parameters—math scores, computer based writing test (CBWT) scores, programming skills, motivation, and discipline—while synthetic data is generated using Monte Carlo simulations to represent candidate characteristics. The main method used in building the model is fuzzy logic. This study will explain the design of the model in more detail. By using an object-oriented approach (with three types of tools: object, activity, and usecase diagrams), the decision model can be clearly explained, so that readers can see the details of the decision model. The decision model itself is developed using the Python language. Simulation results show the predicted average score of 72.93 with a deviation of 8.32. This model can ultimately be used as an alternative model for assessing prospective students recruited by universities, particularly in the Informatics Engineering department.

title: Optimisation of Electromagnetic Interference Sensor Fusion Based on a Multimodal Framework
authors: Binbin Qi, Hongshun Xu, Zhanrong Wang, Jiaqi Peng, Yongliang Mao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: Addressing the issue of fusion failure in industrial safety monitoring systems under high-voltage electromagnetic interference (EMI) environments due to multi-source noise, this study investigates an optimised self-healing fusion method for multimodal sensors. This research constructs a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-driven dynamic weight adjustment framework, employing the Proximal Policy Optimisation (PPO) algorithm to dynamically adjust sensor fusion weights based on real-time perceived EMI intensity. A multi-objective reward function incorporating signal fidelity, system latency, and energy consumption is designed to synergistically optimise the fusion strategy. Simulation results demonstrate that under dynamic electromagnetic interference ranging from 20 to 200 V/m, the system maintains an accuracy rate exceeding 98.47%. Its Composite Performance Index (CPI) score reaches 95.22, representing a significant improvement over Transformer and Kalman filter models. The approach exhibits distinct advantages in disturbance resistance and stability, offering a novel technical pathway for intelligent monitoring in complex industrial environments.

title: WIP: Enhancing Student Engagement and Learning Activity Relevance Through Cross-Course Student Collaboration
authors: Stefan Kleinke, Jillian Schiano
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative-practice paper describes the ongoing effort to enhance student engagement and real-world relevance of course learning activities through the incorporation of scenario-based projects that afford students the opportunity to collaborate across different courses within the same or related STEM degree programs in an asynchronous, fully remote online-learning setting. By allowing a select number of students from different courses within the uncrewed and autonomous systems field to work collaboratively on comprehensive scenario-based projects in fulfillment of their course learning requirements, students get the opportunity to investigate problems from multiple angles, thereby increasing the relevance of learning activities to the students as well as enhancing the applicability of the project work to the real world. Furthermore, in alignment with and application of adult and constructivist learning theories, by repeatedly engaging with and revisiting relevant industry- and peer-generated problems in multiple courses throughout their degree program, students may gain a deeper understanding of interrelated issues and better comprehend the applicability of their generated solutions. Therefore, they get more invested in their projects and the associated learning processes. Thus, in short, the approaches presented in this paper may help to overcome the fire-and-forget mentality often associated with student assignments, especially in a fully online learning environment. Following a handful of past pilot projects that are also discussed in the paper, the presented work in progress is based on the ongoing development, implementation, and testing of a newly created remote sensing and data analysis course, with a focus on describing the learning activity design and logistic requirements for the course rollout that enable the beforementioned collaboration with students in other existing courses on a comprehensive real-world-application project. Preliminary lessons learned and requirements for scalability and transferability are discussed, and the intended research methodology for the work in progress is presented. A vision to expand opportunities for students to collaborate and build on each other's work across multiple courses is also introduced. The ongoing work discussed in this paper represents a further step in enhancing the online learning environment with meaningful activity design and may inspire readers to adopt similar innovative approaches in their own course developments and facilitations.

title: Design and Implementation of GeoMIMO: a Geoinformatic Data Platform for Multi Inputs and Multi Outputs
authors: Ahmad Sutanto, Andre Sihombing, Andri F. Rozie, Andria Arisal, Andy Indradjad, Dede D. Domiri, Emiyati, Esa Prakasa, Hastuadi Harsa, M. Rokhis Khomarudin, Muh. Hafizh Izzaturrahim, Muhammad Hanif Muslim, Nurmajid Setyasaputra, Rifki Sadikin, Rubini Jusuf, Silvan A. B. S. Permana, Sjaeful Afandi, Zaenal Akbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: The growing volume and diversity of geospatial data used in disaster response, environmental monitoring, and land management necessitates robust, integrated platforms for scalable processing and dissemination. In Indonesia, a substantial amount of satellite and remote sensing data remains underutilized due to fragmented storage, limited cataloging, and lack of processing infrastructure. To address this, we introduce GeoMIMO (Geoinformatics Multi Input Multi Output), a modular, open-source platform that leverages High-Performance Computing (HPC) to automate workflows from ingestion to analysis-ready data (ARD) and dissemination. GeoMIMO integrates open standards including SpatioTemporal Asset Catalog (STAC), Open Data Cube (ODC), and GeoNode, and supports multiple input sources (Sentinel-1/2, Landsat, field data) and output formats (GeoTIFF, Shapefile, CSV, APIs). Stakeholder needs were gathered through a national survey and directly shaped the platform’s architecture and features. A prototype deployed on BRIN’s Mahameru HPC validates core functionality, including plugin-based ingestion, ARD generation, and interactive dashboards. Early feedback confirms strong alignment with stakeholder requirements. Future work includes pipeline optimization, broader tool integration (e.g., QGIS, GEE), and preparing for national-scale deployment.

title: Reviewing of Online Grocery Shopping in Review Sentiment Classification on the Sayurbox App on the Play Store using Naive Bayes Algorithm
authors: A. Muhammad Ilham Majduddin, M. Ovha Mustofha Khotib Sudewo, Mulyani Karmagatri
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Shopping for everyday goods online, especially through the Sayurbox app, has changed due to Indonesia's e-commerce industry's explosive rise. The purpose of this study is to use the Naïve Bayes method to analyze the sentiment of Sayurbox app users on the Google Play Store, in order to evaluate the effectiveness of sentiment classification and provide insights into customer satisfaction and perceptions of the services offered. Review data was collected from the Play Store between July 2017 and March 2025, then went through preprocessing stages such as data cleaning, tokenization, stopword removal, and TF-IDF vectorization before being classified using Naïve Bayes. The findings demonstrated that the Naïve Bayes model has a 71.74% accuracy rate in sentiment classification, where 82.4% of reviews were positive and 17.6% were negative. Word Cloud visualization identified keywords such as “fresh,” “quality,” and “fast” as key indicators of satisfaction, while “price” was the main concern in negative reviews. These findings highlight the importance of maintaining product quality, delivery speed, and competitive pricing strategies to increase customer satisfaction and loyalty. These findings provide important insights for brands in improving customer satisfaction and customer experience through sentiment analysis.

title: Developing Multi-Layered Authorization and Authentication Mechanisms to Safeguard Medical Data and Devices Within IoT-Powered Smart Healthcare Ecosystems
authors: Pravin A, Geetha CJ, Pradeepp Shinde, Wamika Goyal, S. Pragadeswaran, Wamika Goyal
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The arrival of Internet of Things (IoT) in healthcare has led to the creation of smart connected medical systems. Nevertheless, this shift to digital transformations also leaves critical weaknesses when it comes to the security of sensitive medical information and other devices. This study proposes a multi-layered robust authorization and authentication system that is precisely developed to fit in IoT-driven smart health care architectures. The system incorporates the principles of the blockchain access validation, biometric-enhanced identity identification, dynamic role-based access control (RBAC), and zero-trust architecture to protect data confidentiality and device integrity. The provided model uses a low weight encryption layer that fits the constrained IoT medical devices strategically to be secured and low latency. The adaptive layer of intelligence is the context-aware access policies as well as anomaly detection mechanisms, which dynamically blocks events of unauthorized or suspected access. Moreover, the system incorporates federated authentication so that decentralized access to various institutions is managed without affecting the privacy of the data. The simulations on a real-time healthcare IoT network have a high resistance to impersonation, data leakage, and unauthorized access. The proposed model has shown dramatic improvement over the traditional single-layer access control systems on detection accuracy, access latency, and success rate of authentication. The architecture has a powerful basis using which next-generation smart healthcare can be developed in hospitals and clinics and even in remote patient monitoring systems found to be scalable and secured. The proposed system surpassed others as the best with the highest accuracy of 96.1% in authentication.

title: Deep Learning-Based Quality Control for Surface Defect Detection in Particle Board Using CNN and ResNet50 Toward Zero Defect Manufacturing
authors: Yustina S Tjahjaningsih, Moses L. Singgih, Putu Dana Karningsih, Chastine Fatichah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: Quality inspection is essential in quality control for particle board manufacturing and plays a key role in achieving Zero Defect Manufacturing (ZDM). Manual inspection, however, is limited by variability and low reliability. This study applies deep learning as an intelligent tool to enhance inspection accuracy. Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and ResNet50 architectures were implemented for surface defect detection across six classes, crack, dust spot, oil stain, thin spot, unsanded board, and good quality with 1,800 images collected and preprocessed using augmentation. The ResNet50 model achieved 91.67% accuracy, outperforming the baseline CNN. Precision, recall, and F1-scores exceeded 0.85 across most classes, while the confusion matrix showed only minor misclassifications between good and visually similar defects. Confidence scores above 0.90 confirmed model reliability. These findings demonstrate that deep learning can strengthen quality inspection, reduce human error, and accelerate decision-making. The proposed approach aligns with AI-driven quality control and contributes to the realization of ZDM in wood-based manufacturing.

title: Mitigating Local Language Loss through Dictionary-Based Translator Design Using Corpus Approach
authors: Inggrid Elisabeth Pardede, Teddy Mantoro, Media Anugerah Ayu, Rahmadya Trias Handayanto
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: Many regional languages in Indonesia are at risk of extinction due to limited digital resources. Most research in machine translation focuses on major languages, leaving regional low-resource languages underrepresented. This study proposes a conceptual design of a translator that integrates dictionary-based and corpus-based approaches. Using a descriptive-qualitative method through literature review, it analyzes prior works on bilingual dictionaries, corpora, and hybrid translation systems. The proposed design consists of three components: a bilingual dictionary to provide word equivalents, a corpus to capture contextual meaning, and data augmentation techniques such as paraphrasing and back-translation to expand limited datasets. The expected result is a translation model that achieves better performance than using only dictionary or corpus approaches. Dictionary-based methods handle basic vocabulary but often lose contextual meaning, while corpus-based methods help interpret idioms, cultural nuances, and polysemy. Evaluation metrics such as BLEU, METEOR, and TER will measure translation quality. This research contributes a framework for developing effective translation systems for regional languages with limited data and aims to implement it as a user-friendly, web-based application accessible to the public.

title: Forecasting Livestock Production Using Time Series
authors: Mazurenko Mykyta, Boiarynova Kateryna, Fartushnyi Ivan, Kravchenko Maryna, Kulyk Anatolii, Lutsyshyna Zhanna
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Building time series from historical data is a key challenge in agricultural sector management, given the vital role of process analysis and forecasting for ensuring food security at the state, regional, and enterprise levels. Using forecasts, enterprises can tailor their production processes to fulfill demand and ensure products reach consumers on schedule. The purpose of this study is to forecast the dynamics of the pig population for 24 months. Three methods were used for this type of analysis, involving autoregression and a probabilistic time series approach. The dataset provides monthly figures on the pig population, encompassing mean, variability (standard deviation), range (min and max), and distribution characteristics (skewness and kurtosis). The dynamics of changes in the pig population in the period from 2008 to 2024 are illustrated. Forecasted values are compared with the actual values, which is illustrated in the graphs. Estimates of RMSE, MAE, MAPE, and MASE are given for forecast periods of $\mathbf{2 4}$ months. By comparing these estimates for different models, the best model for forecasting the pig population was determined. This study enables farms and industry enterprises to estimate the potential volume of products that can be harvested or obtained in the future. It supports informed management decisions such as planning resource needs, improving efficiency, increasing profitability, reducing costs, and adapting to market changes.

title: Load Balanced Congestion Aware Routing Algorithm for Wireless Network-on-Chip
authors: Mohd Shahrizal Rusli, Fasiku Ireti Ayodeji, Muhammad Nadzir Marsono, Jeevan Sirkunan, Mohammed Sultan Mohammed, Ab Al-Hadi Ab Rahman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: As core counts in System-on-Chip (SoC) architectures continue to rise, Network-on-Chip (NoC) faces growing challenges in maintaining low-latency, energy-efficient communication. Wireless Network-on-Chip (WiNoC) has emerged as a promising solution by integrating wireless links with traditional wired mesh networks, enabling single-hop long-range communication. However, with limited wireless bandwidth and nonuniform traffic patterns, WiNoC systems are prone to wireless congestion and inefficient resource utilization. This paper proposes a Load Balanced Congestion Aware Routing Algorithm for WiNoC (LCRAW) that addresses these issues by dynamically balancing traffic between the wired and wireless layers of the hybrid WiNoC architecture. The algorithm dynamically distributes packets between lower-wired paths and upper-layer wireless paths. The wired mesh network is partitioned into small subnets, and source-to-destination distance guides optimal path selection. By monitoring network load conditions, LCRAW adaptively reduces congestion risk in both layers and improves overall throughput. Simulation results using synthetic traffic patterns on the Noxim cycle-accurate simulator show that LCRAW, compared to XY and Latency-Tolerant Congestion-Aware (LTCA) routing, improves throughput by up to 14% and 9%, reduces latency by 19% and 12%, and decreases energy consumption by 13% and 10%, respectively. The proposed technique improves overall system performance and ensures maximum utilization of wireless resources in WiNoC architectures.

title: Using Computer Vision and AI for Monitoring Student Attention in Classrooms
authors: Yousef J. Alawneh, Rana Hamed Al-khateeb, lama Adel Fawzi Salah, Doaa Khazen, Falsten N. Salman, Snehal Hole
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This concept uses a high-tech, two-way AI system to constantly monitor student engagement. Looking at eyes, facial expressions, and body posture using deep learning and computer vision may determine whether someone is awake. The system analyzes data, attributes, and visual and behavioral inputs to identify mental and physical issues. Temporal smoothness and repeated attentional processes may indicate a student's attention shift. Thus, you can always monitor each child. When measuring attention using many methods, you can distinguish between true attention and merely gazing at something. It performed well in the test with 96.27% accuracy, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 5 2 \%}$</tex> precision, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 1 0 \%}$</tex> memory, and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 8 1 \%}$</tex> F1-score. The 18.3-millisecond design performs well in dark and bright courses. With this strategy, instructors may offer immediate feedback. Attention tests are more accurate and understandable when done in this manner. If they can hold students' attention, they may modify their teaching. The study demonstrates smart feedback and numerous observing strategies for AI in classroom analytics. New schools may adjust using data, and students can study in real and virtual courses.

title: Deployable Face Mask Detection for Security and Health Applications Using YOLOv8
authors: Nikita Tukaram Kolle, Ali Raza, Anushka Ramesh Khairnar, Muhammad Maaz Hamid, Raja Hashim Ali, Adnan Shah
abstract: Face mask compliance remains critical for public health and security in crowded environments, even beyond the COVID-19 pandemic. Traditional mask detection systems typically perform binary classification, identifying only "with mask" or "without mask", and fail to detect improperly worn masks, which pose significant health risks. This study presents a deep learning-based framework using YOLOv8 for multi-class face mask detection, distinguishing between properly worn masks, improperly worn masks, and no masks. A publicly available dataset containing 3,000 images evenly distributed across the three classes was preprocessed and augmented with rotation, blur, and occlusion to improve robustness. The YOLOv8 classification model was trained for 20 epochs and evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and confusion matrix analysis. Experimental results demonstrated a top-1 validation accuracy of 99.5% and per-class F1-scores exceeding 98%, confirming reliable classification across all mask categories. Inference speed tests highlight YOLOv8’s suitability for real-time deployment, including on resource-constrained edge devices such as CCTV systems and embedded modules. These findings demonstrate that YOLOv8 can serve as a scalable and practical solution for automated mask compliance monitoring, enhancing safety in public spaces such as airports, schools, and healthcare facilities.

title: Non-Invasive Asthma Detection with FMCW Radar: An Imbalanced Learning Approach
authors: Kokoy Siti Komariah, Ariana Tulus Purnomo, Ding-Bing Lin, Dian Nurdiana, Bong-Kee Sin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: Asthma patients are prone to sudden respiratory failure, thus requiring a non-invasive and continuous monitoring method. This study investigates the use of Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) radar to detect asthma by recording chest displacement signals without physical contact. The extracted respiratory features, including statistical descriptors and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), are analyzed using a machine learning classifier. To address class imbalance in the dataset, imbalanced learning strategies such as Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) and Adaptive Synthetic Sampling (ADASYN) are applied. Among the tested models, the LightGBM-ADASYN combination achieved the best performance with an F1 score of 92.95% on the training data and 92.94% on the testing data. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating FMCW radar with imbalanced learning approaches for the early detection of asthma, enabling timely intervention and improving patient safety.

title: Cross-Modality Bias Auditing and Fairness Evaluation in Generalist Clinical AI Models
authors: Christopher G. Harris
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: We introduce a cross-modality fairness audit for generalist clinical AI systems that integrate structured and unstructured EHR data. The framework combines SHAP, LIME, and counterfactual simulation to expose modality-specific bias and evaluate mitigation strategies. Experiments using MIMIC-IV show that a multimodal transformer achieves AUC 0.88 and F1 0.81, while fairness interventions (adversarial debiasing and subgroup reweighting) reduce Demographic Parity Difference (DPD) from 0.13 to 0.04 and Equalized Odds Difference (EOD) from 0.18 to 0.06 with minimal performance loss. We contribute color, single-column TikZ figures that make the audit interpretable for clinical collaborators, and we discuss deployment implications.

title: An Anatomy-Aware Shared Control Approach for Assisted Teleoperation of Lung Ultrasound Examinations_supp1-3653292.mp4
authors: Davide Nardi
abstract: Although fully autonomous systems still face challenges due to patients' anatomical variability, teleoperated systems appear to be more practical in current healthcare settings. This paper presents an anatomy-aware control framework for teleoperated lung ultrasound. Leveraging biomechanically accurate 3D modelling, the system applies virtual constraints on the ultrasound probe pose and provides real-time visual feedback to assist in precise probe placement tasks. A twofold evaluation, one with 5 naïve operators on a single volunteer and the second with a single experienced operator on 6 volunteers, compared our method with a standard teleoperation baseline. The results of the first one characterised the accuracy of the anatomical model and the improved perceived performance by the naïve operators, while the second one focused on the efficiency of the system in improving probe placement and reducing procedure time compared to traditional teleoperation. The results demonstrate that the proposed framework enhances the physician's capabilities in executing remote lung ultrasound, reducing more than 20% of execution time on 4-point acquisitions, towards faster, more objective and repeatable exams.

title: Rotatable Antenna-Enabled Spectrum Sharing in Cognitive Radio Systems
authors: Yanhua Tan, Beixiong Zheng, Yi Fang, Derrick Wing Kwan Ng, Jie Xu, Rui Zhang
abstract: Rotatable antenna (RA) technology has recently drawn significant attention in wireless systems owing to its unique ability to exploit additional spatial degrees-of-freedom (DoFs) by dynamically adjusting the three-dimensional (3D) boresight direction of each antenna. In this letter, we propose a new RA-assisted cognitive radio (CR) system designed to achieve efficient spectrum sharing while mitigating interference between primary and secondary communication links. Specifically, we formulate an optimization problem for the joint design of the transmit beamforming and the boresight directions of RAs at the secondary transmitter (ST), aimed at maximizing the received signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) at the secondary receiver (SR), while satisfying both interference constraint at the primary receiver (PR) and the maximum transmit power constraint at the ST. Although the formulated problem is challenging to solve due to its non-convexity and coupled variables, we develop an efficient algorithm by leveraging alternating optimization (AO) and successive convex approximation (SCA) techniques to acquire high-quality solutions. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed RA-assisted system substantially outperforms conventional benchmark schemes in spectrum-sharing CR systems, validating RA’s capability to simultaneously enhance the communication quality at the SR and mitigate interference at the PR.

title: Adapting to AI: Innovative Approaches for Homework in Computer Science Education
authors: James Anderson, Schinnel Small
abstract: This innovative practice WIP paper describes the challenges caused by use of AI tools in the classroom. Since the introduction of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools (e.g., ChatGPT, Stable Diffusion, Meta Llama 3, Mistral AI, GPT-4o, etc.) [1] into academia, many students have openly embraced these tools to help them progress in their courses. This has prompted concerns from faculty regarding the maintenance of academic integrity. Despite these concerns, new AI tools continue to be developed, and students are rapidly outpacing faculty in their adoption and use of these tools [2]. This trend suggests that AI is not a passing phenomenon, particularly in educational settings. To understand how students can use AI tools to complete assignments, instructors must recognize how these tools can be misused. Computer Science instructors need to understand how assignments can be presented to AI tools and the types of responses these tools generate. This paper examines the ways students can use AI tools to produce responses that could be submitted as class assignments and compares these results to solutions generated by human authors or instructors. Additionally, the paper recommends strategies for creating assignments that are more likely to be solved by students than by AI tools. Using this knowledge, instructors can be more confident that assigned work will be completed by their students.

title: A Novel Asymmetric V-Type Variable Flux Memory Machine with Hybrid-Layer Permanent Magnets
authors: Qiang Wei, Z. Q. Zhu, Henghui Li, Seyedmilad Kazemisangdehi, Jianghua Feng, Shuying Guo, Yifeng Li, Shouzhi Feng
abstract: In this paper, a novel asymmetric V-type variable flux memory (VFM) machine featuring a hybrid-layer permanent magnet (PM) structure is proposed. This design incorporates two PM arrangements within each pole: one part employs a single-layer variable PM (VPM), while the other part features a dual-layer PM arrangement consisting of a constant PM (CPM) and a VPM. The proposed machine, along with two existing machine topologies: a symmetrical single-layer VFM machine and an asymmetric single-layer VFM machine, is optimized using finite element method with the same stator, rotor diameter, and total PM usage. The electromagnetic performance of the optimized designs for all three machines is investigated and compared. It shows that the asymmetric design can mitigate the intrapolar cross-coupling effect between the CPMs and VPMs found in the symmetrical VFM machine, thereby delivering higher torque output. Furthermore, compared to the asymmetric single-layer VFM machine, the proposed machine can achieve wider flux regulation range and improved overall efficiency due to the series-parallel magnetic circuit enabled by the hybrid-layer structure. Finally, a prototype of the proposed machine is fabricated and tested for validation.

title: Investigation of Electromagnetic Vibration of Low-Cost Single-Phase Permanent Magnet Reluctance Motors
authors: Yingsa Li, Daohan Wang, Yubo Yang, Zeting Yu, Rui Li, Duanfei Shi, Rongxiao Yan, Xinchen Tu, Yonghua Huang, Xiuhe Wang
abstract: Single-phase permanent magnet reluctance motors (PMRMs) have attracted much attention because they combine the advantages of the low cost and simple structure of reluctance motor (RM) with high power density characteristics of permanent magnet (PM) motors. However, the unique topology makes them vulnerable to significant vibrations and noises in actual operation, limiting the potential of PMRM in a wider range of application scenarios. This article first investigates the electromagnetic vibration characteristics of single-phase PMRM. A general analytical model of radial force considering the stator and rotor slots is established to reveal the general principle of radial force frequency distribution of single-phase PMRM. Finite element analysis (FEA) models of different rotor structures are established to verify the theoretical derivation. The results show that the harmonic amplitude of the radial force is closely related to the odd-even nature of the time-frequency orders. Finally, a prototype was fabricated and experimentally tested for vibration and acoustic noise at different speeds under no-load and load conditions. The segmented rotor structure demonstrates its potential in suppressing low-frequency vibrations.

title: Bridging Theory and Practice: Transforming STEM Keynote Presentations Through Experiential and Musical Engagement
authors: Hortense Gerardo, Victor Hugo Minces
abstract: This work-in-progress paper examines the educational impact of a keynote presentation delivered by Dr. Victor Hugo Minces at the California Association of Science Educators (CASE) Conference and explores its implications for engineering education. While experiential and hands-on learning are well-established as effective pedagogical strategies in STEM, such practices are seldom modeled in professional development events like keynotes, which typically favor lecture-based formats. In front of an audience of 500 educators, Dr. Minces transformed a conventional keynote into an interactive and immersive experience by guiding participants through collaborative soundmaking activities using everyday objects. Rooted in the Listening to Waves program-which introduces children to STEM concepts through music-the presentation integrated principles of sound, vibration, signal processing, and computer science. Participants experienced these STEM ideas through playful, embodied engagement, illustrating how artistic and multisensory approaches can make complex content more accessible and memorable. Post-session survey data was collected to assess participant engagement and perceptions of the session's educational value. Quantitative results indicated high intellectual engagement, while qualitative feedback emphasized the session's interactivity, relevance, and enjoyment. This study contributes to the growing body of literature on multimodal learning, embodied cognition, and active STEM pedagogy. Preliminary findings suggest that such experiential approaches can be successfully scaled to large-group settings, with potential applications in both <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{K}-12$</tex> and higher education. Future work will explore the longitudinal impact of music-based experiential learning strategies within engineering curricula.

title: Spatial Attention-Guided Prompt Learning for Anomaly Segementation in Medical Images
authors: Haeyun Lee, Kyungsu Lee, Jae Youn Hwang
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Medicine, Health and Care (AIxMHC)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of anomalies in medical images is critical for early diagnosis and effective treatment planning. Although recent vision-language frameworks such as MediCLIP have shown promise in few-shot settings, they often suffer from limited domain specificity and reduced localization accuracy when applied to heterogeneous medical data. In this work, we propose a fully supervised anomaly segmentation framework that integrates learnable text prompts with a novel Organic Spatial Attention Adapter. Unlike the baseline adapter in MediCLIP, our design employs an Inter-Layer Gated Fusion mechanism to adaptively integrate semantic features from different transformer depths, combined with a lightweight spatial attention module to enhance the localization of fine-grained abnormalities. The adapter also includes a target channel projection for downstream compatibility and residual normalization to ensure stable training. Leveraging curated prompt sets of normal and abnormal anatomical concepts, the model aligns multimodal embeddings for robust anomaly detection. Experiments on the BMAD benchmark—covering BraTS2021, BTCV+LiTs, and RESC datasets—demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in both image-level AUROC (I-AUROC) and pixel-level AUROC (P-AUROC), with notable improvements in pixel-level localization accuracy. These results validate the effectiveness of our architecture in enhancing domain adaptation and anomaly segmentation across diverse medical imaging modalities.
