title: WIP: A Reference Implementation for Course Catalogues in the Erasmus Higher Education Context
authors: Manuel Caeiro-Rodríguez, Fernando A. Mikic-Fonte, Martín Llamas-Nistal, Martín Liz-Domínguez, Adrián Lugilde-López
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative practice paper describes a reference implementation for a CC in the Erasmus+ context. This involves a comprehensive data model, beyond the one described in the “ECTS Users' Guide 2015” specification to include some key entities of interest for mobility students: Organizational Units, Campuses, Alliances, and Academic Terms. It also identifies the need to support key vocabularies and taxonomies, such as the ISCED-F and vocabularies available at curriculum transfer specifications such as ELM. The solution also involves the integration with other systems that manage course catalogue information using existing standards, such as OOAPI and ACAPI. All these elements are intended to offer a more comprehensive set of information to support students in making informed decisions about their study mobility and to streamline the associated processes.

title: Defense of the Clones: Securing Web Applications with Automatic Honeypot Generation and Deployment
authors: Billy Tsouvalas, Nick Nikiforakis
publish: 2025 APWG Symposium on Electronic Crime Research (eCrime)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce Parallax, an automatic, application-agnostic, and resource-efficient web application honeypot generation and deployment framework. Parallax can generate honeypot clones of any live LAMP stack, without interfering with the availability of the web application, and deploys the clones alongside the original web application. In the Parallax-based network deployment, all attackers are seamlessly and covertly redirected to the honeypot clone, while benign visitors may continue their interaction with the original web application, same as before. Alongside Parallax, we introduce three independent sensitive data detection schemes, which we employ to isolate and replace the sensitive data of the original web application on the honeypot clone. As we allow attackers full interaction with all parts of the honeypot clone, we replace the sensitive data on the honeypot with realistic, context-aware, synthetic data using an LLM to ensure that none of the sensitive data of the original web application are compromised by attackers. To evaluate Parallax, we deploy it in the wild for five open-source web applications, and we examine the honeypot generation and deployment performance, as well as the interaction of attackers with the honeypot clones. Lastly, to evaluate the deceptive capability of the synthetically generated data, we conduct a large-scale user study and evaluate how well humans are able to differentiate between real and synthetic sensitive data.

title: Embedded CNN-Based AI System for Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring and Prediction in Smart Cities
authors: Sonal John, Tanmay Kasbe
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Air quality monitoring has turned out to be one of the most vital aspects of the urban sustainability and public health in smart cities. The present investigation puts forward an Embedded Convolutional Neural infrastructure (CNN)-Based AI System for the real-time detection and forecasting of an air quality level that is envisioned to work efficiently on the edge devices that are resource-constrained. The system uses embedded AI architecture to process environmental sensor data locally, thus making it possible to quickly and in an energyefficient manner evaluate air quality without the use of the cloud. The heart of the system is a compact and lean CNN model trained on a variety of air quality datasets collected from a number of different sources and capable of identifying the complex patterns and spatial interdependencies among the polluting elements such as PM2.5, PM10, CO, NO2, and O3. Data preprocessing of input quality is done through a noise reduction and normalization techniques, while the feature extraction that is carried out within the CNN enhances the prediction accuracy. The embedded platform further includes a real-time inference engine to constantly give the air quality monitor levels and trends. The proposed system outlines a number of significant parts including: (i) a compact CNN model restructured for edge computing; (ii) pollution level predictions with high accuracy in the real-time period; and (iii) an energysaving embedded deployment allowing continuous environmental surveillance in the city.

title: SV-NPR: an Open-Set RF Fingerprint Identification Framework Based on Siamese Network
authors: Yutong Li, Yanli Liu, Junbo Su, Xinyu Yang, Xiaoqiang Di, Pei Xiao, Hui Qi
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Radio Frequency Fingerprinting (RFF) exploits the unique characteristics of device hardware and has become a key technology in IoT device authentication and network security. Identification of unknown devices is a key challenge for radio frequency fingerprinting (RFF) in open-set scenarios, the similarity of device hardware characteristics further exacerbates the difficulty of the task. This paper proposes an open-set RFF recognition framework called SV-NPR (Siamese VGG16 with Negative Prototype Rejection). The framework combines the advantages of the VGG16 network in local feature extraction with the contrastive learning mechanism of the siamese network, and can efficiently capture the distribution of local detail features in RF signals. In addition, the introduction of a dynamic rejection mechanism based on negative prototypes improves the robustness and generalization ability of the model for unknown categories. Experimental results show that SV-NPR significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art on the Oracle dataset and exhibits leading recognition capabilities in open-set scenarios.

title: Detecting Human vs AI-Generated Text in Urdu: A Comparative Study of Deep Learning and Transformer Models
authors: Shamyla Firdoos, Muhammad Sheraz Ul Hassan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: The emergence of large language models (LLMs) including GPT-4 has blurred the line between human and machine-generated writing, raising concerns about incorrect information, academic integrity, and content authenticity. This challenge is specifically crucial for Urdu, a low-resource language with limited datasets and NLP tools. To deal with this gap, we employed the Urdu Human and AI text (UHAT) dataset and performed a comparative study of deep learning and transformer-based models for binary classification. Conventional sequence models, such as RNN, LSTM, and GRU with Word2Vec and FastText embeddings, had been benchmarked in opposition to pretrained transformers including BERT, mBERT, UrduBERT, and DistilBERT etc. Experimental outcomes show that transformer models significantly outperform recurrent architectures. Among them, multilingual BERT (mBERT) achieved the best performance with 91.67% accuracy and F1-score, surpassing UrduBERT and previous benchmarks like XLM-RoBERTa on the HLU corpus. These findings set up strong baseline results for Urdu AI-text detection and underscore the potential of multilingual transformers in low-resource settings.

title: OSDMA: Orthogonal Signal Division Multiple Access for Downlink Multiuser Underwater Acoustic Networks
authors: Zhuoran Qi, Zhile Li, Dario Pompili
abstract: The extreme and uncertain underwater environment presents significant challenges in achieving reliable acoustic communications, mainly due to limited bandwidth and time variability. To address these challenges, this work proposes a novel multiple-access technique for downlink multiuser networks, called Orthogonal Signal Division Multiple Access (OSDMA), which enables simultaneous transmission of different data streams from a single transmitter to the corresponding receivers/users by modulating the streams with an orthogonal Inverse Discrete Fourier Transform (IDFT) matrix. In a low-noise environment, each receiver/user can accurately estimate the channel and demodulate the data. Emulations and simulations are conducted based on at-sea channel measurements. The results show that OSDMA offers greater robustness against underwater time-varying channels than Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) and Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA).

title: Multidirectional Strain-Insensitive Stretchable Temperature Sensor for Active Thermal Protection Flexible Skin_supp1-3650255.docx
authors: Xiaozhou Lu
abstract: Flexible skins with active thermal protection systems have attracted considerable attention owing to their role as essential enabling technologies for morphing high-speed vehicles. Temperature sensors integrated into flexible skin can help regulate and optimize coolant consumption. However, it is often difficult to obtain strain-insensitive temperature measurements under multidirectional deformations of flexible skin. Therefore, this study investigates a novel multidirectional strain-insensitive stretchable temperature sensor (STS) based on a hexagram structure. A sensor prototype was fabricated with a measurement range of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$200~^{\circ }$ </tex-math></inline-formula>C and a temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR) of 0.30%/°C. Furthermore, it achieved hysteresis and repeatability errors of 0.83% and 1.79%, respectively. The proposed sensor exhibited a resistance variation of less than 1% under a multidirectional uniaxial tensile strain of 0%–80%, indicating its effective strain decoupling capability. Finally, real-time surface temperature distribution detection was successfully achieved under a heat flux of 202 kW/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> by integrating the sensor array on an active thermal protection flexible skin, demonstrating the potential application of morphing high-speed vehicles.

title: WIP: Review and Analysis of Mixed Methods Approaches in Engineering Education Research
authors: Praveen Meduri, Chillara Venkata Varun, Mary McCarthy Hintz, Lisa Romero, De-Laine M Cyrenne
abstract: This work-in-progress research study reviews the application of mixed-methods research (MMR) in engineering education. MMR integrates quantitative and qualitative approaches across different stages of research design, offering the potential for theory building and a holistic understanding of complex behavioral phenomena. However, the field of engineering education has not fully leveraged the advantages of MMR. This paper reviews ten engineering education studies that employed MMR designs, identifying common challenges and highlighting exemplar cases. It advocates for greater methodological rigor in conceptualizing, conducting, and reporting MMR in engineering education research. Our review revealed limited data integration, vague rationales and inconsistent methodological rigor, indicating the need for standardized frameworks and clear reporting to strengthen MMR quality and impact. Future work involves a systematic literature review, using the PRISMA framework, to further advance best practices in MMR for engineering education.

title: Empowering Pre-College Learners with GDPR Awareness: A Novel Experimental Study
authors: Ankur Chattopadhyay, Alexandra Lisa, Binh Nguyen
abstract: This full paper in the innovative practice category presents a novel experimental study on introducing the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) as a data privacy and security to pre-college learners using an experiential learning approach, that includes hands-on case studies and engaging activities. While browsing online, today's pre-college youth encounter data privacy related consent queries on a regular basis through explicit opt-in and opt-out procedures, which fall under the GDPR jurisdiction. These young online users, who regularly consume web contents, including social media, need to deal with data privacy related disclaimers plus clauses, as posted by technology service providers, who are required to do so to align with the GDPR requirements. With the emergence of GDPR as a major international data privacy law regulating user data, there is a need for these young, naive minds to develop basic awareness of GDPR in order to avoid getting exposed. Existing literature shows that there have been very limited studies on introducing GDPR at the preuniversity level, and this work is intended to address this research gap. This paper describes our nifty introductory GDPR lesson plan, and discusses how we have successfully offered this lesson plan over the last few years for cybersecurity education and outreach primarily at the high school level to develop GDPR awareness and understanding in pre-university students. Over the last few years, we have surveyed several high school community members, consisting of both students and teachers, who have taken part in our GDPR lesson offering, as part of our cybersecurity training camps and outreach workshop sessions. These participants have benefited from our GDPR activities, which include real-life scenario-based case studies, a GDPR enforcement tracker exercise, and a GDPR compliance based game, in terms of learning, and developing concepts, awareness plus interest in data privacy and data security topics. This paper shares and analyzes the preliminary data collected from all these survey responses to evaluate the prospects of our unique GDPR lesson plan as a potential educational and outreach tool for successfully engaging pre-college learners, for teaching data privacy plus data security notions, and for creating awareness plus interest in cybersecurity. To our knowledge, this experimental study using an introductory GDPR lesson plan, as presented in this paper, is a first of its kind research instance involving pre-university students at high school level.

title: Privacy-Protected Hand Pose Reconstruction and Air Writing via Rolling Spheres
authors: Xiao Zhang, Deniz Acikbas, Soham Naik, Griffin Klevering, Juexing Wang, Zaynab Mourtada, Li Xiao, Tianxing Li
abstract: Smart homes, medical devices, and education systems, among other emerging cyber-physical systems, hold immense promise for sensing-based user interfaces, especially for using fingers and hand gestures as system input. However, vision approaches compatible with time-consuming image processing adopt low 60 Hz location sampling rate (frame rate) for real-time hand gesture recognition. Furthermore, they are not suitable for low-light environment and long detection range. In this paper, we propose RoFin, which first exploits 6 temporal-spatial 2D rolling fingertips for real-time 3D reconstructing of 20-joint hand pose. RoFin designs active optical labeling for finger identification and enhances inside-frame 3D location tracking via high rolling shutter rate (5-8  kHz). These features enable great potentials for enhanced multi-user HCI, virtual writing for Parkinson suffers, etc. We implement RoFin prototypes with wearable gloves attached with low-power single-colored LED nodes and commercial cameras. The experiment results show that (1) In flexible sensing distances up to 2.5 m, RoFin achieves an average labeling parsing accuracy of 85%, (2) In comparison to vision-based techniques, RoFin improves the tracking grain with 4× more sampled points each frame, (3) RoFin reconstructs a hand pose in real time with 16 mm mean deviation error compared with Leap Motion under flexible distance, and (4) we further investigated real-world applications of RoFin, such as air writing with smoothed trajectories and mobile-based letter/number recognition in our developed Xamera app.

title: Successful Teaching Strategies in Virtual World Education for Engineering and Computing
authors: Arghavan Nova Ebrahimi, Mary Lou Maher, Harini Ramaprasad
abstract: This research paper examines successful teaching strategies developed by educators in desktop virtual worlds (DVWs). These environments provide unique affordances for creating immersive learning experiences that exceed the capabilities of other online learning platforms. They are particularly valuable for engineering and computing education, where abstract concepts often present significant learning challenges. Given this potential for technical education, this study investigates two key questions: how experienced educators structure learning activities in DVWs and what teaching strategies best leverage the unique affordances of DVWs for learning. To answer these questions, we conducted in-depth semi-structured interviews with 14 educators from the Virtual World Education Consortium with extensive teaching experience in DVWs. Data were analyzed through thematic analysis focusing on identifying teaching strategies and implementation approaches that could be adapted for computing and engineering educational contexts. Our analysis identified ten successful teaching strategies across three categories: Experiential Learning Strategies (including scenario-based learning and scale manipulation); Active Learning & Constructivist Strategies (such as spatial co-presence learning and structured exploration); and Social Learning & Community Strategies (featuring character-mediated instruction and multiuniversity collaborations). These strategies leverage unique capabilities of DVWs to implement approaches that would be difficult or impossible in physical or other online environments. The findings provide practical guidance for educators without prior DVW experience and those seeking to implement DVW teaching in computing and engineering disciplines. The identified strategies demonstrate how virtual environments can enhance conceptual understanding of complex technical subjects, create authentic problem-solving contexts, and facilitate engagement through diverse activities, enhancing student learning experiences.

title: A Compact Dual-CP Planar Monopulse Array With High Efficiency and Enhanced Sidelobe Suppression_supp1-3651532.pdf
authors: Zhiya Zhang
abstract: A compact planar circularly polarized (CP) monopulse array antenna at the S-band based on an air-filled substrate integrated coaxial line (AF-SICL) feeding structure to suppress sidelobes in both sum and difference beam is proposed in this article. The AF-SICL and the stacked patch are tightly integrated to achieve subarray sequential rotation structure with unequally spaced elements, combined with an unequal amplitude feed network with a large power division ratio contributing to reducing transmission loss and achieving a compact structure. The AF-SICL comparator network can achieve stable amplitude and phase correspondence for dual-CP antenna array. Moreover, a physical prototype of an 8×8 monopulse array antenna has been designed and fabricated. The measured results indicate that the sum and difference ports of the antenna array achieve excellent impedance bandwidth within the 8.7% (2.2-2.4 GHz), axial ratio lower than 0.3 dB, a peak gain of 23.45 dBi and the peak total efficiency is 70.2%. The symmetrical radiation pattern with a null depth less than -32.2 dB and the sidelobe levels of the sum and difference beams are suppresd to -16.2 dB and -16.1 dB respectively. The proposed monopulse array antenna holds great potential for high-precision, long-range target localization and tracking.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Route Prediction and Reliable Data Service in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MLRP)
authors: Neeti Shukla, Kamlesh Chandravanshi, Deepak Singh Tomar, Shubhra Mukherjee Mathur, Navin Garg, Lalendra Kumar Khanday
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The main thing that makes data transmission function in a dynamic network is dependable routing. Strong algorithms that can handle changes in network conditions are needed to make sure that data packets are sent quickly. This flexibility not only improves performance but also lowers the chance of losing data while it is being sent. Routing protocols use diverse methods, but without them, data can't be sent from one place to another. Multipath routing introduces the notion of load balancing; nevertheless, it fails to effectively disperse the load across the network, resulting in packet loss that impacts the essential communication resource, energy. This study suggests a routing protocol based on machine learning (MLRP) to manage strong flooding and make routing in MANET better. The reason we are motivated is that most multipath routing protocols are simply dependent on one thing, like the quickest path with a balanced load or energy conservation. The suggested plan looks at energy efficiency, the shortest way, and load balancing to make multipath routing protocols work better. In MLRP, you need to think about both the ML rules for moving data and how to keep congestion down by using several paths in MANET. The resource-like bandwidth influence tells us what is going on with the floods. Flooding data packets slows down performance, but the suggested MLRP controls it well, which cuts down on data loss and overhead. We look at how well flooding, FLBB, and the projected MLRP work. The suggested plan is working well and keeping traffic from being too heavy. The performance reveals that PDR and throughput have improved by at least 6%, which means that there is reduced overhead latency and dropping in the network.

title: WIP: How Compassionate STEM Education is Defined: A Review of Literature on the Role of Compassion in STEM Education
authors: Theo Lazzari, Qin Zhu
abstract: In STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics) education, there has been a burgeoning interest in the significance of care and compassion in shaping aspiring professionals. Prevalent approaches to compassion-oriented STEM education frequently emphasize imparting practical techniques (such as listening skills) or theories (like the human capabilities approach) related to engineering design and decision-making in individual courses. While these approaches offer valuable insights and contributions, they also encounter certain challenges and opportunities for further improvement. This work-in-progress paper aims to review existing literature on the role of compassion in STEM education, guided by the following questions: (1) How do scholars and educators in STEM education justify the need and value of compassion in the field? (2) How do they conceptualize compassion in relation to similar concepts such as empathy? (3) What approaches and strategies have they used to cultivate compassion in STEM education? The findings from this review provide valuable insights for a larger project focused on creating institutional impact by developing communities of practice for STEM faculty committed to fostering compassionate learning environments in their classrooms.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Large Language Models for Test-Skeleton Generation
authors: Subhang Boorlagadda, Nitya Naga Sai Atluri, Muhammet Mustafa Ölmez, Edward F. Gehringer
abstract: This paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate the generation of test skeletonsstructural templates that outline unit test coverage without implementing full test logic. Test skeletons are especially important in test-driven development (TDD), where they provide an early framework for systematic verification. Traditionally authored manually, their creation can be timeconsuming and error-prone, particularly in educational or large-scale development settings. We evaluate four LLMs-GPT-4, DeepSeek-Chat, Llama4-Maverick, and Gemma2-9Bon their ability to generate RSpec skeletons for a real-world Ruby class developed in a university software engineering course. Each model's output is assessed using static analysis and a blind expert review to measure structural correctness, clarity, maintainability, and conformance to testing best practices. The study reveals key differences in how models interpret code structure and testing conventions, offering insights into the practical challenges of using LLMs for automated test scaffolding. Our results show that DeepSeek generated the most maintainable and well-structured skeletons, while GPT-4 produced more complete but conventionally inconsistent output. The study reveals prompt design and contextual input as key quality factors.

title: Cross-Scene Hyperspectral Image Classification via Bidirectional Mamba and Domain Mixing Network
authors: Junzhe Dang, Chengwang Guo, Mengmeng Zhang, Yuxiang Zhang, Wen Jia, Wei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: To overcome the challenges posed by domain shift in hyperspectral image (HSI) classification, methods based on domain adaptation (DA) have been widely used. Currently, most HSI DA methods focus on designing complex strategies to align the distributions of the source domain (SD) and the target domain (TD) in the feature space after feature extraction, yielding promising results. However, when there exists a large domain shift between SD and TD, it becomes challenging to map them into the same feature space. In this article, we propose the bidirectional mamba and domain mixing network (BMDMnet). Since pure CNN architectures are constrained in local feature extraction, while transformer-based models improve global feature capturing capability at the cost of high computational complexity, we propose the bidirectional mamba module (BMM) as an efficient solution for capturing long-range dependencies. In addition, a self-distillation strategy is employed during training. By utilizing a more stable teacher model, reliable predictions can be obtained in the TD. Subsequently, a domain mixing supervised learning (DMSL) module is designed, which creates a mixed domain by selecting low-entropy sample-pseudo-label pairs from the TD and randomly combining them with sample-label pairs from the SD. DMSL aims to introduce mixed domain to mitigate the inter-domain gap in the data space, thereby enabling the model to learn TD representations more effectively. Experiments demonstrate that BMDMnet outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms across three cross-scene datasets.

title: WIP: System Concept Compilation: A Generative AI Approach to Systems Modeling and Simulation
authors: Jon Wade, Richard Gessner
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper describes the design, deployment, and evaluation of a systems engineering modeling and simulation course that leverages generative artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud-based tools to focus on problem formulation and foundational principles. The approach significantly elevates the scope of the course by radically reducing the need for detailed supporting instruction on tools, languages, and syntax. A class of professional students with little or no programming or modeling experience was enabled to utilize modeling and simulation to address a real-world systems engineering challenge. Results indicate that student performance far exceeded what was achievable in the past using standard engineering approaches, with dramatically increased willingness and capability to apply modeling and simulation in professional practice. The success of this approach and lessons learned will inform the redesign of other courses in the systems engineering master's program, with potential implications for engineering education more broadly.

title: Eavesdropping Attack of Two Eavesdroppers on the Ping-Pong Protocol with GHZ triplets
authors: Serhii Havel, Yevhen Vasiliu, Nikolaos Bardis, Sergii Staikutsa
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This work presents an analysis of a sequential passive eavesdropping attack by two eavesdroppers on the ping-pong protocol employing three-qubit Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ) entangled states. An analytical expression is derived for the probability of attack detection by legitimate users. It is shown that increasing the number of eavesdroppers in the quantum channel leads to a higher probability of attack detection. Expressions are also obtained for the maximum amount of information that two eavesdroppers can gain during their sequential passive attack. The analysis demonstrates that the ping-pong protocol with GHZ triplets is no more vulnerable to passive eavesdropping by two adversaries than it is to an attack by a single one. The results can be generalized to ping-pong protocols based on n-qubit GHZ states for arbitrary values of $\boldsymbol{n}$.

title: Have your DAI in Court. The Role of Suggestive Algorithms in Judicial Decision-Making
authors: Paolo Comoglio

title: Work-in-Progress: College-Industry Partnership for Professional Development Through Online Education: Two Case Studies
authors: Reza Rahdar, Yuetong Lin, Jorge Ortega, William Muldoon
abstract: In this work-in-progress paper, we present two college-industry collaboration projects centered on professional development for enhancing workforce skills in engineering and. The first project involved designing a course that integrates both introductory and advanced systems engineering concepts. The second project focused on establishing a university-corporation partnership to develop a professional certification program aimed at strengthening workforce capabilities within a major aviation company. Both initiatives presented distinct challenges related to timelines, stakeholder expectations, and deliverables, making them valuable case studies from a systems engineering perspective. We describe our approach to these projects and share key lessons learned in advancing workforce development through academic-industry collaboration.

title: Ownership-Aware Decentralized Trust Management for Scalable IoT-Enabled Delivery Systems
authors: Salisu Ibrahim, El Ioini Nabil, Iman Yi Liao
abstract: We present a blockchain-based trust management framework tailored for IoT-enabled delivery systems, with an emphasis on ownership-aware accountability. Instead of binding trust to individual trucks, our model anchors it to the registered service provider, allowing scalable identity abstraction and seamless trip reassignment. Each delivery is authenticated using a per-trip ephemeral secret derived via Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange (DHKE), ensuring secure and isolated authentication. Trust scores are computed using a balanced combination of checkpoint-derived metrics and customer ratings, stored immutably on Ethereum smart contracts. Simulation results across 300+ delivery trips demonstrated that the framework supports transparent, scalable, and fault-resilient trust evaluation, with stable gas costs and responsive score updates under varying operational conditions. The system provides a practical foundation for decentralized reputation management in high-integrity logistics environments.

title: WIP: Coding Neurodivergent - a Systematic Literature Review
authors: Veronica Bramlett, Davis Flanders, Anna Manley
abstract: This work-in-process innovative practice paper on nontraditional students provides a look at neurodivergent individuals learning coding, specifically Python, and the struggles and benefits that come from the way their brains are wired. There have been multiple studies done on what programming language is best to start with, and many have selected Python as their selection as a programming language for beginners. One area that has not been widely studied is the learning of Python, or coding in general, by neurodivergent populations. This includes the benefits a neurodivergent learner may glean from learning Python as well as the challenges they may encounter - anything which makes their experience different from that of a neurotypical Python beginner. Resources were pulled together on neurodivergence, focusing on attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), Python as a beginner language, and how it may uniquely benefit or challenge those who are ADHD, autistic, or both. For this literature review, outcomes for which data was sought included cognitive challenges neurodivergent individuals may face, ways in which the neurodivergent brain may be wellsuited to learn Python, and ways in which neurodivergent populations may benefit from learning Python. Python's unique attributes, including its simplicity, readability, and structured environment, make it an effective tool for neurodivergent learners. Future research should aim to expand the body of knowledge by conducting empirical studies that directly investigate the experiences of neurodivergent learners.

title: Exploring Institutional Ethnography in Engineering Education: Methods, Practice, & Possibilities
authors: Victoria Bill, Emily Dringenberg
abstract: This full-length research paper will review the use of institutional ethnography (IE) in engineering education research (EER). IE is an approach and sociology developed by Dorothy Smith from feminist standpoint theories to uncover ruling relations - the hidden norms, policies, structures, and rules that govern socially regulated institutions. Previous studies using IE in EER have mainly focused on graduate students and faculty and have shown how ruling relations in engineering reproduce a gendered and racialized experience. While this paper will not describe an empirical study, it provides a contribution to the research community by synthesizing how this methodology has been used, discussing challenges and opportunities, and outlining the authors' plans to leverage IE in the engineering contexts of co-curricular programs and faculty well-being.

title: WIP: Automated Extraction of Domain-Specific Concept Maps Using a RAG-LLM Ensemble Framework
authors: Zane Hutchens, Qiong Cheng
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper explores the development of an explainable, AI-driven ensemble framework for automatically generating subject-specific concept hierarchies from eTextbooks. Concept graphs play a central role in modern intelligent tutoring systems (ITSs), as they organize domain knowledge and support the tracking of student progress while enabling personalized and adaptive learning pathways or recommendations. Recent studies have explored the use of large language models (LLMs) to extract concept maps, but the generalized nature of LLM training introduces challenges such as hallucinations, mathematical errors, and biases, leading to uncertainty in their outputs. To address these limitations, this study integrates retrieval-augmented generati6ton (RAG)-based techniques with LLMs including Gemini-1.5-flash and Gemma-3. We integrated these models with classical machine learning methods and evaluated our RAG-LLM framework using referencefree verification through multiple benchmarking methods, ensuring reliability and reducing uncertainty in the generated concept graphs. We have been employing CS2-DS as an example to investigate the efficacy of the RAG-based AI-driven ensemble approach. Our preliminary findings indicate good evaluation scores on the following test cases: relevance of answers, context faithfulness, context precision, and context recall. Further systematic investigation will focus on refining and evaluating the use of the framework and comparing different models and fine-tuning techniques.

title: Special Session: Scalable K-8 Math Support for Equitable Engineering Success
authors: Mohamed Y. Selim, Renee Gibert, Namrata Vaswani
abstract: Early mathematics proficiency is a pivotal determinant of long-term success in engineering and computing disciplines, yet disparities in math education persist, particularly for underrepresented populations. This special session addresses the urgent need to close these achievement gaps by implementing structured K-8 math intervention programs that are grounded in evidence-based strategies. This session explores how adaptive technologies, structured tutoring, and community partnerships can collectively close math achievement gaps and foster equity in STEM. The session draws on successful initiatives such as the CyMath program at Iowa State University and the Algebra by 7th Grade program at Purdue University, showcasing scalable models that leverage university-led mentoring programs to provide consistent academic support. Attendees will engage with strategies for implementing sustainable interventions, fostering inclusive learning environments, and utilizing data-driven approaches to monitor progress and outcomes. By cultivating a network of educators, researchers, and practitioners, the session seeks to extend the impact of K-8 math interventions as a critical pathway to STEM success and broadened participation in engineering disciplines.

title: WIP: Negative and Positive Behaviors Exhibited by Students in the Context of Engineering Project Team
authors: Fazel Ranjbar, Junqiu Wang, Samieh Askarian Khanamani, Jutshi Agarwal, P.K. Imbrie
abstract: This work-in-progress study explores the positive, negative, and neutral behaviors exhibited by first-year engineering students working on technical team projects at a large public university. Using open-ended peer evaluations, the research identifies common teamwork behaviors and interprets them through both inductive thematic analysis and a deductive comparison to a four-factor model of team effectiveness: interdependency, potency, trust, and goal setting. A total of 3,874 positive and 1,934 negative comments were analyzed from 1,032 students across 397 teams. Positive behaviors included a strong work ethic, reliable attendance, communication, creativity, leadership, and supportiveness. Negative behaviors focused on poor communication, low contribution, unreliability, controlling attitudes, procrastination, and skill gaps. Many comments displayed mixed values, containing both praise and critique, revealing the complexity of peer perceptions and real-world teamwork dynamics. These findings not only align with established theoretical frameworks but also provide a foundation for identifying dysfunctional teams early and supporting team development. By systematically categorizing student observations, this study contributes to a deeper understanding of how engineering students evaluate peers and how their perceptions reflect broader teamwork constructs.

title: Adoption, Usage, and Perceptions of LLM-Generated Feedback in Computer Science Education: A Cross-Cultural Study of Students and Academics
authors: Eyman Alyahyan, Mireilla Bikanga Ada, Jake Lever
abstract: This full paper explores the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) for generating assessment feedback in Computer Science (CS) education, comparing adoption patterns and perceptions of students and academics in the UK and Saudi Arabia (KSA). The study investigates (1) differences in LLM use and adoption between students and academics in both countries, and (2) participants' perceptions of LLMgenerated feedback, focusing on benefits, challenges, and areas for improvement. A mixed-methods approach was employed, involving 251 participants. The collected data were analyzed through descriptive statistics and thematic analysis. Findings indicate that students in KSA demonstrate higher usage rates of LLMs, with ChatGPT identified as the most frequently used tool. Although KSA academics show limited use of LLMs, UK academics did not use them for feedback generation. Thematic analysis revealed three key themes: (a) “It saves effort”, (b) “It is not as smart and genuine as a human”, and (c) “Making it more like humans and less like a machine”. The findings emphasize the need for institutional policies to guide the responsible integration of LLM-generated feedback, ensuring alignment with teaching goals and improving feedback quality.

title: WIP: Applying Self-Regulated Learning Principles in an Undergraduate Computer Science Seminar
authors: Sophie Engle, Kelsey Urgo, Alark Joshi
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper describes a new computer science (CS) course that provides undergraduates an opportunity to grow their metacognitive and CS skills through self-regulated learning and specifications grading principles. It is motivated by the students' need to stay relevant post-graduation in the rapidly evolving field of CS. However, a traditional CS curriculum provides few formal opportunities for students to navigate their own learning processes. By the end of this course, students will have acquired new CS skills and be better prepared for lifelong CS learning as active, reflective, self-guided learners.

title: WIP: Understanding Student Motivations in Innovation Ecosystems
authors: Abdullah Konak, Sadan Kulturel-Konak
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper focuses on experiential learning experiences such as innovation competitions and programs (ICPs), which foster the KEEN 3Cs-creativity, connections, and creating value. The study asks: (1) What are the primary motivations for students to participate in ICPs? and (2) What factors positively affect student engagement in ICPs? Understanding these motivations is crucial for enhancing program design, increasing participation, promoting inclusivity, and allocating resources efficiently. Thirty-six students from three Northeastern U.S. universities were interviewed via Zoom. Interview prompts were validated by students for impartiality, and transcripts were analyzed inductively by three independent coders. Results show that students join ICPs to gain technical skills, advance career goals, network with peers and faculty, apply classroom knowledge, strengthen resumes, make an impact, and secure funding. Overall, social and utility values of ICPs predominate. The findings suggest that ICPs should deliberately create professional networking opportunities and provide targeted training, workshops, and mentoring to support the development of technical and professional skills. Although ICPs constitute valuable experiential learning experiences that engage students in innovation ecosystems, many students remain unaware of these opportunities.

title: Comparative Analysis of Naïve Bayes Algorithms for Lecturer Performance Classification
authors: Ahmadiar Ahmadiar, Nissa Hasna Nabila, Ramzi Adriman, Agussabti Agussabti, Nasaruddin Nasaruddin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence's Future Implementations (ICAIFI)
abstract: To support the implementation of the Tri Dharma of Higher Education, lecturers are required to fulfill four key performance indicators: teaching, research, community service, and supporting activities, each contributing to the fulfillment of semester credit units (SCU). The quality of a lecturer's performance is reflected through a structured evaluation process. However, this process still faces significant challenges due to the limited accessibility of lecturer performance data, making it difficult to accurately evaluate the quality of the lecturer workload (LW). To address this issue, a classification system using a machine learning approach is proposed to provide transparent and reliable information. This paper compares the performance of four variants of the Naïve Bayes algorithm: GaussianNB, MultinomialNB, BernoulliNB, and ComplementNB. The goal is to classify LW status into three categories: Meets Requirements, Partially Meets Requirements, and Does Not Meet Requirements. Based on the results of the Confusion Matrix analysis, BernoulliNB achieved the highest accuracy at 83%, followed by GaussianNB (77%), ComplementNB (57%), and MultinomialNB (53%). Overall, BernoulliNB demonstrated the best performance for LW classification based on SCU indicators. These findings can establish a foundation for developing an automated evaluation system that utilizes machine learning, supporting an objective and efficient assessment of lecturer performance.

title: The Role of Green Value Chain in Light of Circular Economy for Sustainable Cost Management
authors: Karar Abdulelah Azeez, Muhammad Fawzi Mustafa Al-Azami
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The primary objective of the study is to ascertain the potential integration of green value-chain methodologies and circular economy (CE) principles to mitigate the environmental impact of cost management. We use a design-oriented approach, case studies from diverse disciplines, and a comprehensive analysis of the literature to develop a framework that works. This theory suggests that money is involved in eco-designing products, digital traceability, and reverse logistics. The principle underlying this framework is “design-oriented methodology.” Organizations may become more eco-efficient by using less energy and materials if they make adjustments to their value chain that are in accordance with CE. They could also be able to improve their finance-related KPIs by making sure that their efforts are the proper magnitude. This will shorten the time it takes to pay back the loan and give you a favorable net present value. Closed-loop and refurbishment operations can help reduce waste. The results suggest that these companies can make these changes. The management framework divides the supply chain into five parts: supply-side, production, distribution, consumption, and disposal. During certain periods, you might be able to receive prizes.

title: Analysis of Harmonic Distortion Effects on Grid-Tie Inverter Operation in a Photovoltaic System
authors: Atikah Sari, Syafruddin Hasan, Erwin Sutanto, Pradini Puspitaningayu, Muhammad Aziz, Fahmi Fahmi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: This study presents the design and harmonic analysis of a single-phase inverter using Sinusoidal Pulse Width Modulation (SPWM) to convert DC voltage from a photovoltaic (PV) source into an AC output. A Boost Converter is used to raise the input voltage to 197 V DC, followed by a full-bridge SPWM inverter to generate an alternating voltage waveform. However, the inverter output inherently contains harmonic distortions due to high-frequency switching. To address this issue, an LC filter is introduced at the inverter output to suppress harmonic components and improve the waveform quality. The system is modeled and simulated in Software. Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) analysis is employed to evaluate harmonic content and Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) before and after the filter. Simulation results show that the fundamental frequency at 50 Hz is dominant, and the use of the LC filter effectively reduces the amplitude of higher-order harmonics while enhancing the sinusoidal shape of the voltage output. The filtered output achieves a significantly lower THD, indicating improved power quality suitable for residential or grid-connected applications.

title: Artificial Intelligence Framework for Legislative Candidate Recruitment and DPR Performance Evaluation in Indonesia
authors: Rezzy Eko Caraka, Dodik Pranata Wijaya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer, Control, Informatics and its Applications (IC3INA)
abstract: The accelerated emergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) presents novel prospects to enhance democratic procedures and elevate the quality of legislative governance. This study presents a comprehensive framework that utilizes AI to improve the recruiting process for members of the Indonesian House of Representatives (DPR) and to assess their performance through objective, data-driven metrics. The framework amalgamates many data sources, such as attendance records, legislative initiatives, voting behavior, and public mood, facilitating a comprehensive evaluation of legislative performance. Machine learning models are engineered to recognize patterns of accountability, discover anomalies, and assess the congruence of candidates' histories with the commissions they aspire to join. The proposed technique enhances transparency, meritocracy, and evidence-based decision-making in candidate selection and incumbent appraisal. The research underscores the capacity of AI to enhance institutional trust, mitigate inefficiencies, and foster a more responsive and professional legislative in Indonesia.

title: AFM-Transformer: Adaptive CNN-Transformer for Hyperspectral Remote Sensing Image Classification
authors: Weiyi Li, Ghulam Farooque, Muhammad Majid Hussain, Fazeel Abid, Luo Yunqing, Waqar Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) classification plays a pivotal role in remote sensing applications. Yet, it remains a very difficult task because of the high spectral dimensionality, spatial variability, and scarcity of labeled data. To address these challenges, recent studies have explored architectures that combine convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for capturing local spatial features with Transformers for modeling long-range spectral dependencies. However, existing approaches often suffer from suboptimal feature fusion strategies that inadequately integrate the complementary information from both branches. In this study, we propose AFM-Transformer, a novel spectral-spatial dual-branch framework enhanced by an adaptive fusion module (AFM). The AFM is a lightweight, attention-based gating mechanism that dynamically learns to assign sample-specific importance to features extracted by the CNN and Transformer branches. This enables adaptive and context-aware fusion of spatial and spectral representations, enhancing the model’s discriminative capability. We validate the effectiveness of the proposed AFM-Transformer through comprehensive experiments on three benchmark hyper-spectral datasets. Our model consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy.

title: Concept of a Digital Battery Laboratory for Academic Training of Future Battery Experts
authors: Heiko Fechtner, Alexander Popp, Utz Spaeth, Benedikt Schmuelling
abstract: This research work in progress paper describes a novel concept of a digital battery laboratory for academic education of future battery experts that will be integrated into a blended learning concept and can be used e.g., on mobile devices (such as smartphones) and personal computers. The need for battery experts will continue to grow in the coming years, partly due to the increasing number of electric vehicles and stationary storage systems. Thus, academic teaching in the area of battery technologies is essential to prepare students to handle future challenges in both the energy and mobility sectors. The presented concept offers a promising methodology for equipping students with the skills required to work in the battery industry. In particular, the virtual battery laboratory is significantly less expensive to implement than constructing a physical laboratory. Consequently, this advantage can facilitate the dissemination of the concept presented to a wider audience (e.g., other universities). Furthermore, the concept can also be helpful for other disciplines (e.g., mechanical or safety engineering) that address battery technologies either in their curricula or in future professional practice. Therefore, evaluating the transferability of the concept is also covered in this paper.

title: Design and Development of an AI-Enabled Space Crew Health Monitoring System
authors: Annapurna P Patil, Dhushyanth C, Anirudh S, Chinmai S D, Amar K P
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The development of an AI-powered health monitoring and prediction platform is presented, addressing the unique physiological and logistical challenges associated with space missions. Acknowledging the limitations of conventional medical systems in remote and resource-constrained environments, the proposed system autonomously tracks, analyzes, and forecasts the health status of space crew members through machine learning models trained on synthetic datasets. The web-based architecture comprises two primary components: an onboard interface that enables crew members to input health-related data and access AI-generated insights, and a remote access portal that allows Earth-based medical personnel to monitor the same data, assess AI-driven recommendations, and provide clinical guidance or intervention as required. By integrating real-time artificial intelligence analysis with expert validation from terrestrial healthcare professionals, the platform offers a robust and reliable solution for health management in space. This hybrid framework enhances safety, responsiveness, and decision-making, demonstrating the effective synergy between autonomous systems and human oversight in mission-critical applications. Although primarily designed for aerospace use, the system also establishes a foundational model for remote healthcare delivery on Earth, highlighting the transformative potential of intelligent systems in managing health in complex and inaccessible environments.

title: Robust Real-Time Multistatic Sonar Tracking with Missed Detections and Measurement Bias Using Gaussian Long Short-Term Memory Networks
authors: Thomas Alexander Beck, Martina Brötje
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: We analyze the use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and Gaussian LSTM networks (G-LSTMs) for object localization and tracking based on bistatic sonar measurements in scenarios involving moving receivers, missing detections, and potentially biased Gaussian measurements. We formally derive the Cramér-Rao Lower Bound (CRLB) for the situation including incorporating past information for noisy nonlinear models. Performance is analyzed on decaying coordinated turn tracks and found to be close to the CRLB and the performance of the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), despite having no explicit prior knowledge of the movement or measurement models. The Gaussian and non-Gaussian LSTMs exhibit robustness against missing detections and measurement bias and are able to quantify such biases (if present). This Gaussian architecture shows promise, as performance is slightly worse with their nonGaussian counterparts but offers a covariance estimate and only exhibits a slight underconfidence in predictions. The Gaussian neural networks considered here show the ability to capture environmental uncertainty as given by the dynamic probability of detection. Inference times are small enough to allow for real-time tracking.

title: Reinforcement Learning Based Whittle Index Policy for Scheduling Wireless Sensors
authors: Sokipriala Jonah, Seong Ki Yoo, Saurav Sthapit
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Wireless Sensor nodes used in remote monitoring applications typically transmit data in a timely manner, often optimising for the Age of Information (AoI). However, this approach focuses solely on keeping updates at the sink fresh without considering the actual value of each update. This method is inefficient for sensor networks, which have limited resources. Transmitting data indiscriminately without evaluating its significance not only increases energy consumption but also raises storage requirements. To address this challenge, we propose a reinforcement learning-based scheduling strategy that prioritises sensor transmissions based on the Age of Incorrect Information (AoII) using an edge mining technique. This ensures that the most valuable updates are received while reducing energy consumption. We frame the scheduling problem as a Restless Multi-Armed Bandit (RMAB) and introduce a Whittle Index-based Q-learning (WIQL) policy to dynamically select the most informative sensors. Additionally, we employ an edge mining technique, where raw sensor data is processed locally before transmission, enhancing state estimation at the sink. Experimental results demonstrate that WIQL achieves near-optimal performance while significantly reducing the number of transmitted packets by up to $70 \%$. This reinforcement learning-based approach provides a scalable and adaptive solution for efficient data scheduling in resource-constrained WSNs.

title: Development of a Virtual Laboratory for Simulating Real Experiences: The Case of a Hybrid Drone in Complex Urban Environments
authors: Elio Matteo Curcio, Giuseppe Gencarelli, Stefano Rodinò, Francesco Lago, Francesco Felicetti, Giuseppe Carbone, Francesco Lamonaca
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern urban environments needs innovative solutions for experimentation and education in STEM fields. This paper presents the development of a virtual laboratory based on the concept of a digital twin, focusing on the simulation of a hybrid drone capable of both flying and ground movements, operating in complex urban contexts. The benefits of using digital twins for practical training and research are discussed, as well as the challenges faced in modeling realistic urban environments.

title: AI for Advancement: Predictive Donor Analytics and Fundraising Intelligence at Scale
authors: Shivam Ashokbhai Lalakiya
publish: 2025 IEEE 11th International Conference on Computing, Engineering and Design (ICCED)
abstract: In recent years, artificial intelligence (AI) has improved significantly and revolutionised a number of industries, including nonprofits. Data mining, machine learning, and statistics are all utilized in predictive analytics to find trends and generate systems that can be used to predict future occurrences. AI can assist you in forecasting which donors are most likely to contribute and how much they will contribute by evaluating data. When it comes to donor cultivation and stewardship, this can be immensely beneficial. To ensure a clear grasp of the models’ decision-making processes, we defined model performance indicators using LOOCV and then used SHAP analysis to comprehend feature contributions. In order to convert unstructured donor data into useful inputs for predictive modelling, feature engineering is essential. Measures such as accuracy, precision, recall, and AUC-ROC were used to evaluate the model’s efficiency.

title: Formal Verification of an Authentication Protocol for Internet of Medical Things Using CryptoVerif
authors: Togu Novriansyah Turnip, Birger Andersen, Cesar Vargas-Rosales
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Secure communication and authentication in the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) are critical for patient safety and healthcare data protection, yet existing protocols face significant vulnerabilities that remain undetected by conventional verification approaches. This paper presents the computational security verification of an IoMT authentication protocol incorporating NTRU lattice-based post-quantum cryptography using CryptoVerif, a formal verification tool that provides concrete probability bounds under standard cryptographic assumptions. Through systematic analysis of a multi-entity healthcare protocol, this study identifies two critical security flaws overlooked by previous symbolic verification methods: device registration authentication failure enabling man-in-the-middle device substitution attacks, and forward secrecy violation through static key encryption that exposes historical medical data upon key compromise. To address these vulnerabilities, we provide an enhanced protocol incorporating Strong Unforgeability under Chosen Message Attacks (SUF-CMA) MAC-based device authentication that cryptographically binds device identity to patient identity, and HMAC-based key derivation function (HKDF)-derived ephemeral session keys that achieve forward secrecy through fresh key derivation for each communication session. Our CryptoVerif implementation successfully proves nine security properties including mutual authentication, data confidentiality, device binding, and forward secrecy, with aggregate security bound for 128-bit quantum-resistant security. Unlike symbolic verification tools that assume perfect cryptography, our computational analysis provides concrete security guarantees essential for safety-critical healthcare systems.

title: Enhancing Dielectric Performance of Acrylate-Based Elastomers via Incorporation of Polar Cyano Groups_supp1-3650476.docx
authors: Ying Li
abstract: Dielectric elastomers (DEs) are a class of flexible intelligent materials capable of significant deformation under external electric field stimulation. However, conventional DEs typically exhibit low dielectric constants, necessitating the application of excessively high electric field strengths (>100 kV/mm) to achieve substantial actuation. In this work, we design a series of poly(butyl acrylate-co-acrylonitrile) (PBA-AN) copolymers by introducing polar cyano groups (-CN) from acrylonitrile (AN, key polar monomer) into a butyl acrylate (BA)-based matrix, and systematically optimize the molar ratio of BA to AN. The optimal copolymer composition (PBA<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">70</sub>-AN<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">30</sub>, 70 mol% BA and 30 mol% AN) endows the DE with a balanced combination of high dielectric performance and superior actuation characteristics: a high dielectric constant of 10.89 at 1 kHz, a low dielectric loss tangent of 0.0197, and a reduced Young's modulus of approximately 0.106 MPa. At a low electric field strength of 30 kV/mm, these DEs achieve an area strain of 20%, a 4.4-fold enhancement compared to the commercial material VHB4910 that only delivers an area strain of 4.5% under identical conditions. This study presents a novel approach to the fabrication of high-performance acrylate-based DEs.

title: Explicit Residual-Based Scalable Image Coding for Humans and Machines
authors: Yui Tatsumi, Ziyue Zeng, Hiroshi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Multimedia Signal Processing (MMSP)
abstract: Scalable image compression is a technique that progressively reconstructs multiple versions of an image for different requirements. In recent years, images have increasingly been consumed not only by humans but also by image recognition models. This shift has drawn growing attention to scalable image compression methods that serve both machine and human vision (ICMH). Many existing models employ neural network-based codecs, known as learned image compression, and have made significant strides in this field by carefully designing the loss functions. In some cases, however, models are overly reliant on their learning capacity, and their architectural design is not sufficiently considered. In this paper, we enhance the coding efficiency and interpretability of ICMH framework by integrating an explicit residual compression mechanism, which is commonly employed in resolution scalable coding methods such as JPEG2000. Specifically, we propose two complementary methods: Feature Residual-based Scalable Coding (FR-ICMH) and Pixel Residual-based Scalable Coding (PR-ICMH). These proposed methods are applicable to various machine vision tasks. Moreover, they provide flexibility to choose between encoder complexity and compression performance, making it adaptable to diverse application requirements. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed methods, with PR-ICMH achieving up to 29.57% BD-rate savings over the previous work.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Artificial Intelligence Models: Threat Analysis and Protection Methods
authors: Serhii Bondarovets, Tetiana Okhrimenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Adversarial attacks involve deliberately manipulating inputs to artificial intelligence (AI) systems in order to cause incorrect model outputs. These adversarial examples are typically inputs with small, often imperceptible perturbations that lead the model to misclassify with high confidence. Unlike malware or SQL injection which target software vulnerabilities, adversarial attacks target the data fed into AI models, essentially presenting optical illusions to the algorithm. If left unmitigated, these attacks undermine user trust and can incur severe operational, financial, and privacy damages. In fact, adversarial attacks are now recognized as a primary AI security concern alongside data poisoning and model theft. This review maps the current landscape of adversarial threats against modern AI models and compares prevailing defense paradigms, distilling their empirical robustness, resource overhead and deployment readiness across vision, language and multimodal systems.

title: A Metamaterial-Enabled Reconfigurable Conformal Array with Integrated Nano-Magnetic Particles for THz Wireless Systems
authors: Fatima Abdul Rasheed, Aymen Javed, Muhammad Ayaz, Wajid Mehmood, Areesha Humayun
abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable wedge-shaped patch antenna array designed for the terahertz (THz) frequency band (100– 120 GHz), integrating Nano-magnetic particles and metamaterials to address challenges in conventional mmWave antenna designs. The proposed 1×4 wedged-shaped array achieves dual functionality: dynamic frequency reconfigurability and reduced mutual coupling between elements. Reconfigurability is enabled by nano-magnetic particles embedded within a dedicated lower substrate layer, which can be activated using a tiny external magnet—eliminating the need for complex biasing circuitry found in diode-based systems. Two particle configurations are explored—vertical and horizontal—with the horizontal configuration demonstrating superior frequency tuning capability across the THz band. To mitigate mutual coupling exacerbated by the presence of multiple tuning particles, specially engineered metamaterial structures are incorporated. These metamaterials effectively suppress inter-element coupling, ensuring stable performance at high frequencies. The proposed design is validated through equivalent circuit analysis using Keysight Advanced Design System (ADS), while full-wave simulations (for bending angles 30° and 45°) are performed using CST Microwave Studio confirm enhanced gain, wider bandwidth, and improved isolation between array elements. The compact, reconfigurable design demonstrates excellent potential for next-generation high-frequency wireless communication systems, including integrated circuits and IoT platforms. The combination of nano-magnetic reconfigurability and metamaterial decoupling establishes a novel framework for flexible and efficient THz antenna array solutions.

title: Post-Intrusion Behavior Profiling for Host Intrusion Detection in the SoNiC Network OS"
authors: Dobush Andriy, Havano Bohdan
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The advancement of artificial intelligence in cybersecurity has significantly improved the capability of intrusion detection systems (IDS). Host Intrusion Detection Systems (HIDS) are particularly valuable for identifying unauthorized activities on networked hosts. In this context, developing an AI-driven decision-making model requires high-quality datasets that accurately represent both normal and malicious post-intrusion behaviors. This article focuses on the methodology for collecting and unifying datasets that will be used to train an AI model designed to detect host intrusions in a specific environment: the open-source network operating system SoNiC (Software for Open Networking in the Cloud). SoNiC as a Linux-based open-source NOS, is widely adopted in modern networking infrastructures due to its modular architecture and extensibility. Its unique architecture allows for precise logging and monitoring of system activities, which is crucial for intrusion detection research. To build an effective AI model, it is necessary to collect data reflecting typical post-intrusion behaviors within the SoNiC environment. This includes the simulation of attack scenarios, collection of relevant system call data, and aggregation of logs and system events that signify security threats.

title: Fiscal Efficiency of the Simplified Taxation System in Ukraine: An Information and Analytical Approach
authors: Volodymyr Valihura, Anna Ivanova, Viktoriia Sidliar, Tetiana Valihura
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: The fiscal efficiency of Ukraine’s simplified taxation system (STS) has been researched in the context of increasing uncertainty and the need for economic resilience. Conceptual foundations for the functioning of the STS have been outlined, with emphasis on its role in supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The study has substantiated the need to balance fiscal interests with entrepreneurial incentives by determining the optimal level of tax burden. A regression model has been developed and tested to assess the relationship between tax burden, shadow economy level, and fiscal efficiency. The impact of tax administration reform within the framework of the National Revenue Strategy until 2030 has been analyzed. It has been demonstrated that digital transformation significantly contributes to improving fiscal outcomes by reducing administrative costs and enhancing tax compliance. Based on the results, practical recommendations have been proposed to increase the fiscal efficiency of the STS without undermining the competitiveness of the SME sector.

title: Optimised Indexing Architecture for Efficient Hybrid Storage of Visual Big Data
authors: Roman Romanchuk, Tereshchenko Glib, Iryna Kyrychenko, Kirill Smelyakov, Nataliia Sharonova, Victoria Vysotska, Oksana Oryshchyn
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: In the era of big data, the need for scalable and efficient storage of image data has become critical across domains such as healthcare, geospatial analysis, and industrial monitoring. This paper presents a hybrid image storage model that combines relational, document-oriented, and object-based storage layers through an optimised multilevel indexing approach. A formal conceptual framework is developed to describe the indexing mechanisms, and a theoretical analysis of their computational complexity is provided. Practical validation using large real-world datasets demonstrates notable improvements - the average query time was reduced by more than seventy percent, indexing overhead decreased by nearly sixty-eight percent, and storage utilisation improved by approximately twenty-five percent. Comparative evaluation against traditional storage systems highlights the proposed hybrid model’s superior scalability, adaptability, and performance. The proposed solution establishes a robust foundation for the development of distributed visual data management systems optimised for big data environments.
