title: Tool Condition Monitoring from Workpiece Surface Using an Eddy Current Probe_supp1-3649733.pdf
authors: Kalle Kinnunen
abstract: Eddy current probes are common in various applications, such as nondestructive testing, displacement measurement, and condition monitoring. However, they have not been extensively applied to machining tool condition monitoring. The present study addresses this gap. This study investigates tool condition monitoring method using an eddy current probe. Eddy current probe is used to scan face milled surfaces and the tool condition is inferred from the probe response. 2 probes with different shapes were used, a round-shaped coil and a racetrack-shaped coil. The probes are used to scan surfaces milled using face milling inserts with different wear states. The insert wear is determined from the eddy current probe responses that were processed by filtering and Discrete Fourier Transform. Peak height of the resulting frequency spectra was used to determine the tool condition. The results indicate that the method is suitable for tool condition monitoring. In general, the response peak height increased as the inserts were more worn. The results also show that eddy current probe shape has significant influence to the wear measurement. The racetrack coil was significantly more sensitive for wear measurement compared to the round coil. Future studies could investigate the use of different coil configurations, such as reflection probes or probe arrays.

title: Self-Nomination: Deep Learning for Decentralized CSI Feedback Reduction in MU-MIMO Systems
authors: Juseong Park, Foad Sohrabi, Jinfeng Du, Jeffrey G. Andrews
abstract: This paper introduces a novel deep learning-based user-side feedback reduction framework, termed self-nomination. The goal of self-nomination is to reduce the number of users (UEs) feeding back channel state information (CSI) to the base station (BS), by letting each UE decide whether to feed back based on its estimated likelihood of being scheduled and its potential contribution to precoding in a multiuser MIMO (MU-MIMO) downlink. Unlike SNR- or SINR-based thresholding methods, the proposed approach uses rich spatial channel statistics and learns nontrivial correlation effects that affect eventual MU-MIMO scheduling decisions. To train the self-nomination network under an average feedback constraint, we propose two different strategies: one based on direct optimization with gradient approximations, and another using policy gradient-based optimization with a stochastic Bernoulli policy to handle non-differentiable scheduling. The framework also supports proportional-fair scheduling by incorporating dynamic user weights. Numerical results confirm that the proposed self-nomination method significantly reduces CSI feedback overhead. Compared to baseline feedback methods, self-nomination can reduce feedback by as much as 65%, saving not only bandwidth but also allowing many UEs to avoid feedback altogether (and thus, potentially enter a sleep mode). Self-nomination achieves this significant savings with negligible reduction in sum-rate or fairness.

title: EdgeCNN-TrafficNet v2: Clip-Wise Spatio - Temporal Fusion and On-Device Adaptation for Energy-Efficient Real-Time Traffic Congestion Detection
authors: Ashik Shah Jahangeer, P Shanmugavadivu
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Our solution introduces a lightweight, edgeoptimized CNN with clip-wise, robust, and energy-aware capabilities for deployment on resource-constrained devices. We propose (i) a spatio-temporal fusion head that collates evidence over short clips (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8-12$</tex> frames) to stabilize predictions in night/rain/jitter conditions, improving temporal consistency by 17.3% while maintaining accuracy at 92.1%, (ii) a test-time adaptation (TTA-Lite) routine that updates normalization statistics on-device to avoid drift introduced by the camera/site without retraining on the cloud (recovering 6.8% performance from crosssite), and (iii) auto-compression pipeline (structured pruning + INT8 quantization-aware training with distillation) using compressed, and lower energy consumption by 34 to 39% while maintaining accuracy at 25.8 FPS. A dataset of 48,000 clips from 8 urban intersections with site-held-out splits has been chosen due to its large-scale analysis performance on multi-site CCTV. Performance metrics including accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(92.1 \pm 1.2 \%)$</tex>, precision <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(91.6 \pm 1.3 \%)$</tex>, recall <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(90.8 \pm 1.4 \%)$</tex>, F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(91.2 \pm 1.3 \%)$</tex>, MCC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.862 \pm 0.021)$</tex>, Cohen's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\kappa(0.853 \pm 0.024)$</tex>, AUC-ROC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.958 \pm 0.012)$</tex>, specificity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(92.7 \pm 1.1 \%)$</tex>, FPS (25.8 I/O-inclusive), latency (p50: 39 ms, p95: 54ms), RAM (192MB), power <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3.3 \pm 0.2 \mathrm{W})$</tex>, energy/frame <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(128 \pm 12 \text{mJ})$</tex>, thermal throttling events (2 over 2-hour test). By implementing performance-based solutions, the proposed one has shown itself to possess robustness to unfavourable environmental conditions and provide between 34 and 39% energy savings on Jetson Nano with performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 24$</tex> FPS and explainable performance with the assistance of Grad CAM.

title: DT-Based Cloud Gaming in Softwarized Networks to Enable Players in Developing Countries
authors: Andrea Caruso, Públio Elon Correa Da Silva, Christian Grasso, Giovanni Schembra
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Cloud gaming is a rapidly growing domain that requires low-latency and high-responsiveness architectures to deliver an engaging user experience. This paper presents an innovative Digital Twin (DT)-based framework designed to mitigate the effects of variable network conditions on video streaming and input responsiveness. The proposed architecture integrates Console and User Equipment DTs, which synchronize video streams and user inputs using lightweight RTSP and MQTTbased communication, ensuring real-time interaction even in challenging network scenarios. To validate the framework, we developed a custom cloud gaming application simulating a shark-and-fish pursuit game. This use case allows for precise evaluation of system performance under varying latency and delay conditions. Experimental results demonstrate the architecture’s ability to maintain game responsiveness, revealing critical delay thresholds and highlighting the impact of delay variability on user performance. These findings illustrate the potential of DTbased architectures to enhance the robustness and fairness of cloud gaming systems.

title: WIP Academia to Industry: Mapping Skills and Careers for Engineering Education Doctorates
authors: Lilianny Virguez, Debarati Basu, Sreyoshi Bhaduri
abstract: This research WIP paper investigates the alignment between skills developed in engineering education doctoral pro-grams and those sought in industry. As engineering education evolves as a research-based discipline, its Ph.D. graduates in-creasingly pursue diverse careers beyond academia. However, the alignment between doctoral-level competencies and globally in -demand workforce skills remains poorly understood. This study presents a qualitative mapping of core Ph.D. competencies to the World Economic Forum's (WEF) 26 “Top Skills for 2025,” aiming to identify strong alignments and gaps. The research questions guiding this study are: 1)What competencies are emphasized in leading U.S. engi-neering education doctoral programs? 2)To what extent do these competencies align with the globally in-demand skills identified by the World Economic Forum? Using reflective dialogue and consensus-building, the research team identified seven core competencies in engineering education Ph.D. programs: educational research, curriculum design, assess-ment, communication, project leadership, equity and inclusion, and professional development. These were mapped to the WEF skills using a three-point relevance scale. The resulting matrix and heatmap reveal strong alignment in areas like analyti-cal thinking, problem-solving, and active learning. However, notable gaps exist in technical and digital areas, including AI literacy, programming, and technology use. These findings suggest opportunities for programs to better integrate digital fluency and interdisciplinary leadership. This work contributes to discussions on doctoral career readiness by offering a framework to connect academic competencies with workforce demands, supporting more inclusive and adaptable engineering education Ph.D. pathways.

title: WIP: Professional Identity and Design Engagement: A Study of Practicing Engineers' Identity in Industry Settings
authors: Stephanie Adams, Shane Brown, James Huff, Elliott Clement
abstract: This WIP research category paper explores the relationship between working engineers' identity and their engagement in engineering design activities within workplace settings. Specifically, we examine how professional identity influences practicing civil engineers' engagement in design activities in workplace settings. Using an early stage grounded theory approach, we conducted and analyzed semi-structured interviews with three practicing civil engineers. Interview transcripts were analyzed individually through initial coding and content analysis to identify themes regarding the relationship between professional identity and design engagement. While our analysis is ongoing, we illustrate three cases to demonstrate the powerful relationships between identity and design engagement in the workplace. Preliminary analysis suggest that engineers' engagement in design activities is closely tied to their professional identity development. Similar to patterns in academic settings, these engineers showed engagement behaviors reflecting their engineering identity. However, professional contexts add complexity to how identity shapes design practice. This analysis provides insights for improving undergraduate education by better aligning educational experiences with workplace practices.

title: Structural Design and Optimization of a Tool Transfer Device for Overhead Transmission Lines
authors: Long Li, Pengfei Ren, Qiyu Zheng, Tao Song, Xin Jin, Xuguang Li, Zhao Wang, Yuxuan Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of the power grid scale and the increasing complexity of transmission lines, the demand for tool transfer devices for overhead transmission lines for maintenance and repair is growing. Traditional tool transfer methods have problems such as low efficiency and poor safety, making it difficult to meet the needs of modern power grid maintenance. This paper proposes an overhead transmission line tool transfer device based on a flexible rope-wheel lifting mechanism. Through mechanical performance analysis and structural optimization, efficient and safe transfer of tools is achieved. This device has the advantages of long transmission distance, compact spatial structure, and strong load - bearing capacity, providing a new solution for the maintenance and repair of overhead transmission lines.

title: MiniUn: a Machine Unlearning Method to Minimize Dependency on Original Training Data
authors: Soyoung Youn, Chulyun Kim
abstract: The exponential growth in data volume has driven significant advances in machine learning, but the inclusion of private or unauthorized data in training dataset has led to a surge in deletion requests and privacy disputes. While retraining models without the contested data offers a fundamental solution, it incurs prohibitive computational costs. This challenge has given rise to machine unlearning, a process that selectively removes knowledge of specified data from a trained model. However, most unlearning methods require access to the complete original training dataset and often suffer from degraded generalization performance after unlearning. This limitation makes them impractical in scenarios where the full training dataset is no longer accessible. To address these challenges, we propose a novel unlearning technique for image classification and generation tasks that maintains effectiveness even with a small part of the original dataset. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our method, supporting the right to be forgotten.

title: Audio-Based Rainfall Classification Using Spectrograms and YOLOv8n on Embedded Systems
authors: Roberta Avanzato, Ludovica Beritelli, Kevin Munda, Francesco Beritelli
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: Hydrogeological risks such as floods and landslides increasingly threaten critical infrastructure, emphasizing the need for continuous and reliable rainfall monitoring. Traditional sensing approaches often face limitations in spatial resolution, latency, and installation cost. This paper presents an audio-based rainfall classification system using spectrogram analysis combined with a lightweight YOLOv8n neural network, optimized for embedded deployment. A custom acquisition kit was developed to capture multimodal environmental data, although this study focuses exclusively on the audio channel. Audio signals sampled at $\mathbf{8 ~ k H z}$ were segmented, labeled into six rainfall classes through an automated and manually verified procedure, and converted into spectrograms. Training was performed on a dedicated dataset collected over two rainy days. Experimental results demonstrate a weighted accuracy of $86.99 \%$ and a weighted $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of $86.89 \%$ on unseen data, confirming the potential of acoustic sensing for rainfall classification. Future extensions will integrate multimodal data fusion to enhance robustness in noisy environments and further improve system performance.

title: WIP: Research Skills Development Among Minority Engineering Students Through a Research Mentored Program
authors: Hilda Cecilia Contreras Aguirre, Stephanie Zackery, Luis Rodolfo Garcia Carrillo
abstract: This work in progress research-to-practice paper addresses undergraduate research experiences (URE) among engineering students who participated in the Research-Oriented Learning Experiences (ROLE) program at a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) in the Southwest United States. Like other UREs, participating in the ROLE program was a great opportunity to explore extracurricular activities that can eventually transform student learning experiences and persistence in college. This mixed-methods study explored the learning outcomes of minority undergraduate engineering students after their one-year participation in the ROLE program. The Goal Congruity theory framed the study and informed the importance of students' learning and identity development. Through pre- and post-experience surveys, students assessed their understanding of social and professional skills, research in engineering understanding, and general research abilities. In addition, individual interviews were conducted to explore the reinforcement, development, and changes in student identity. Preliminary results indicated an improvement in students' understanding of engineering and research skills. Students also highlighted aspects such as the programs' interdisciplinarity and research presentations as key to developing their professional identity. To better support minority engineering students' college pathways, the adoption of effective UREs could effectively leverage students' learning and experiences contributing to their persistence in engineering.

title: Agile Mobile Application Development: A Multidisciplinary Approach with CBL, Scrum and Lean Startup
authors: Afonso Sales, Nicolas Nascimento, Rafael Chanin, Aline de Campos
abstract: This Research-to-Practice full paper explores how integrating Challenge-Based Learning (CBL), Scrum, and Lean Startup methodologies into the teaching of mobile application development can simulate authentic work environments and better prepare students for industry challenges. The proposed approach aims to bridge the gap between university-level theoretical knowledge and the practical demands of technology companies by fostering a dynamic and multidisciplinary educational setting. By engaging students in real-world challenges through CBL, facilitating agile project management with Scrum, and enabling rapid hypothesis validation and time optimization via Lean Startup's use of Minimum Viable Products (MVPs), the methodology offers a comprehensive learning experience. Our results indicate significant improvements in student engagement and the quality of mobile applications developed. Additionally, several startups have been founded as a direct result of the integrated approach.

title: Competencies to Educate the Whole Engineer: Building a Modern Engineering Curriculum at Wake Forest Engineering
authors: Olga Pierrakos
abstract: This innovative practice full paper describes a strategic approach to integrating “whole engineer” competencies across the Wake Forest Engineering curriculum. Engineering education reform has been called for in numerous national reports from organizations including the National Academy of Engineering, ASEE, industry, and various professional societies. These reports envision a modern engineer with expanded competencies beyond only technical expertise. Wake Forest Engineering was established with a mission to “Educate the Whole Engineer,” integrating many diverse competencies (e.g. character development, leadership, entrepreneurial mindset, and social consciousness) into a rigorous technical curriculum. This paper presents our strategic approach to curriculum development, demonstrating how we aligned expanded competencies with ABET Student Outcomes 1-7 while embedding professional formation and character formation throughout the engineering experience. From the lens of program leadership, we showcase strategies and specific competency mappings across the core curriculum and describe pedagogical approaches that cultivate technical expertise alongside virtues like integrity, compassion, humility, and leadership. This transformation journey was guided by Kotter's Change Model. This intentional approach to educating the “Whole Engineer” has yielded significant results: high job placement for graduates, strong enrollment and retention of students, ABET accreditation, high program rankings in US News Report, unprecedented student diversity (42 % women, 25% racial and ethnic diversity), recognition for curricular innovation, and evidence of cultivating character. Key success factors included experiential learning integration, diverse stakeholder involvement, strategic internal and external partnerships, team teaching, collaborative sharing of instructional materials, and comprehensive competency mapping throughout the curriculum. While it is important to show measurable assessment results of the learning, this paper focuses on the identification and implementation of the Whole Engineer competencies and not about assessment of these competencies which is a future paper.

title: Enhancing Student Engagement Through Example-Based Short Videos
authors: Suman Saha, Mahfuza Farooque
abstract: In large-scale computing courses, students often struggle to stay engaged with lengthy lecture recordings, especially when learning complex and abstract concepts. Despite the wide availability of recorded class sessions and asynchronous materials, recent studies suggest that learners frequently disengage from videos exceeding 30 minutes. This paper investigates using short, example-based videos-each under five minutes-as a practical alternative to traditional long-format lecture recordings. Grounded in cognitive learning theory and prior work on microlearning, we designed short videos centered on concrete programming examples to target specific subtopics. These videos were introduced in Spring 2025 in a course with 330 students, following a baseline semester in Fall 2024 with 382 students, where only traditional lectures were used. To implement this approach in practice, we embedded the short videos into the course LMS and aligned them with weekly topics and assessments. Analysis of survey results, attendance records, LMS usage, and direct comparisons of long vs. short video engagement revealed several positive outcomes: higher average view counts, increased playback per student, and stronger student preference for short videos in time-limited situations. Students also reported that the example-driven format helped with exam preparation and retention. These findings suggest that brief, focused videos can be an effective research-to-practice intervention for increasing engagement and supporting learning in large computing courses.

title: WIP: Enhancing Grading Efficiency in Engineering Education Through Automation on a Flipped Classroom
authors: Edwin Marte Zorrilla, Kimberly Stubbs, John Mendoza-Garcia, Reymi Then
abstract: This Work-in-Progress paper and Innovative Practice presents a practical method for efficient grading in engineering education by integrating MATLAB Grader with a custom Python script. The approach addresses challenges in flipped classrooms where timely, accurate assessments are critical. Because MATLAB Grader's integration with LMS platforms like Canvas is limited, the authors developed a Python tool to automate grade extraction, format data for institutional rosters, and facilitate uploads to Canvas, reducing instructor workload and improving grading accuracy. Early feedback indicates increased student satisfaction from immediate feedback and reduced grading time for instructors. This practice highlights how educators can leverage automation to enhance learning, with future work to improve usability and LMS integration.

title: DMRS-Based Uplink Channel Estimation for MU-MIMO Systems with Location-Specific SCSI Acquisition
authors: Jiawei Zhuang, Hongwei Hou, Minjie Tang, Wenjin Wang, Shi Jin, Vincent K. N. Lau
abstract: With the growing number of users in multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) systems, demodulation reference signals (DMRS) are efficiently multiplexed in the code domain via orthogonal cover codes (OCC) to ensure orthogonality and minimize pilot interference. In this paper, we investigate uplink DMRS-based channel estimation for MU-MIMO systems with Type II OCC pattern standardized in third generation partnership project (3GPP) Release 18, leveraging location-specific statistical channel state information (SCSI) to enhance performance. Specifically, we propose a SCSI-assisted Bayesian channel estimator (SA-BCE) based on the minimum mean square error criterion to suppress the pilot interference and noise, albeit at the cost of cubic computational complexity due to matrix inversions. To reduce this complexity while maintaining performance, we extend the scheme to a windowed version (SA-WBCE), which incorporates antenna-frequency domain windowing and beam-delay domain processing to exploit asymptotic sparsity and mitigate energy leakage in practical systems. To avoid the frequent real-time SCSI acquisition, we construct a grid-based location-specific SCSI database based on the principle of spatial consistency, and subsequently leverage the uplink received signals within each grid to extract the SCSI. Facilitated by the multilinear structure of wireless channels, we formulate the SCSI acquisition problem within each grid as a tensor decomposition problem, where the factor matrices are parameterized by the multi-path powers, delays, and angles. The computational complexity of SCSI acquisition can be significantly reduced by exploiting the Vandermonde structure of the factor matrices. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed location-specific SCSI database construction method achieves high accuracy, while the SA-BCE and SA-WBCE significantly outperform state-of-the-art benchmarks in MU-MIMO systems.

title: Neural Network Empowered Equalization for SOA Nonlinear Distortions in Coherent Optical Systems
authors: Hamza Imtiaz, Arman Safarnejadian, Leslie A. Rusch, Ming Zeng
abstract: Semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs) are promising solutions for small-form-factor optical signal amplification, but their nonlinear gain dynamics and pattern-dependent effects can significantly degrade transmission performance. While digital back-propagation (DBP) techniques have been used to mitigate SOA nonlinearities in coherent systems, they require accurate SOA parameters, which are often difficult to measure. In this work, we examine a SOA booster configuration with a neural network (NN) equalizer that is not based on a physical model and thus does not require knowledge of device parameters. The NN compensates collectively contributions from all sources of nonlinearity, e.g., nonlinear phase noise (NLPN) and chirp. We examine the trade-offs the NN equalization allows between gain, nonlinearity, and launch power by sweeping the SOA injection current and input power. The NN equalization achieves Q-factor improvements of up to 4 dB over linear equalization for 16-quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) signals at both 30 Gbaud and 60 Gbaud. We demonstrate its effectiveness in compensating SOA distortions over 60 km and 100 km fiber transmission links. The NN equalizer also shows strong robustness to varying training scenarios and signal conditions, and to higher-order modulation formats such as 64-QAM. Performance- complexity analysis of the NN equalizer shows several trade-offs.

title: Special-purpose computer for holography HORN-X enhanced with separable convolution architecture_supp1-3653207.mp4
authors: Tomoyoshi Shimobaba
abstract: Holographic displays employ computer-generated holograms (CGHs) and spatial light modulators to reproduce three-dimensional moving images. They are expected to serve as next-generation cross-reality (XR) or extended reality (XR) technologies. However, the generation of CGHs involves extremely high computational complexity. We have developed a series of special-purpose computers for holography, referred to as HORN (HOlographic ReconstructioN). In this paper, we present the tenth-generation system, HORN-X, which incorporates separable convolution–an algorithm that reduces the computational complexity of CGH generation. Experimental results demonstrate that HORN-X achieves computation speeds up to 65 times faster than a conventional CPU.

title: AtomThink: Multimodal Slow Thinking With Atomic Step Reasoning
authors: Kun Xiang, Zhili Liu, Terry Jingchen Zhang, Yinya Huang, Yunshuang Nie, Kaixin Cai, Yiyang Yin, Runhui Huang, Hanhui Li, Yihan Zeng, Yu-Jie Yuan, Jianhua Han, Lanqing Hong, Hang Xu, Xiaodan Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: In this paper, we address the challenging task of multimodal reasoning by incorporating the notion of “slow thinking” into multimodal large language models (MLLMs). Our core idea is that models can learn to adaptively use different levels of reasoning to tackle questions of varying complexity. We propose a novel paradigm of Self-structured Chain of Thought (SCoT), which consists of minimal semantic atomic steps. Unlike existing methods that rely on structured templates or free-form paradigms, our method not only generates flexible CoT structures for various complex tasks but also mitigates the phenomenon of overthinking for easier tasks. To introduce structured reasoning into visual cognition, we design a novel AtomThink framework with four key modules: (i) a data engine to generate high-quality multimodal reasoning paths; (ii) a supervised fine-tuning (SFT) process with serialized inference data; (iii) a policy-guided multi-turn inference method; and (iv) an atomic capability metric to evaluate the single-step utilization rate. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed AtomThink significantly improves the performance of baseline MLLMs, achieving more than 10% average accuracy gains on MathVista and MathVerse. Compared to state-of-the-art structured CoT approaches, our method not only achieves higher accuracy but also improves data utilization by 5 × and boosts inference efficiency by 85.3%. Our code is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Kun-Xiang/AtomThink</uri>.

title: Joint Deep Learning for Simultaneous Clutter Removal and Buried Object Detection in GPR
authors: Yavuz Emre Kayacan, Isin Erer, Selcuk Paker
abstract: Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) data presents a challenging problem for detecting subsurface targets due to surface reflections and the complex clutter caused by heterogeneous soil structures. While traditional methods treat clutter removal and target detection as separate processes, this study presents an integrated deep learning approach that simultaneously optimizes both tasks. In the first phase of the study, the first proposed model, Dec-YOLO (Model I), demonstrated that “joint training” of clutter removal networks (UNet, CR-Net, DC-ViT) from the literature with a detection network improves detection performance compared to sequential methods. Building on this finding, the second phase proposes the original RAFDeC-YOLO (Model II) architecture. This architecture features a specialized denoising block (decoder) that branches off from the standard YOLOv12 backbone. The fundamental innovation of this branch is that it feeds back the cleaned and enriched feature maps it produces back to the relevant neck layers of the YOLO architecture via the proposed Residual Adapter Fusion mechanism. This strategic feature transfer maximizes discriminative power, particularly in challenging scenarios such as weak dielectric targets and asphalt-covered surfaces, by enabling the detection network to access both noisy raw data and cleaned spatial details. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving over 25.8% higher localization accuracy on hybrid datasets and an 87.5% improvement in challenging real-world scenarios, while reducing computational complexity by approximately 43% for efficient deployment.

title: Enhanced and Precise Estimation of Dielectric Loss in Damped AC Voltage Tests
authors: Peerawut Yutthagowith, Punyavee Chaisiri, Busyapol Paophan, Yoshihiro Baba
abstract: This paper presents an extended approach based on a recently developed method, designed to enhance the accuracy of dielectric loss factor (loss tangent) estimation in damped alternating current voltage (DACV) tests. The estimation process leverages a precise equivalent circuit of the DACV testing system, along with an accurately determined attenuation factor and angular frequency of the measured test voltage, to improve the reliability of loss tangent calculations. The extended approach introduces a new expression for loss tangent, derived from peak-to-peak testing voltages, and incorporates a moving average filter to mitigate the effects of DC offset, amplitude and time quantization errors, and noise. A comparative analysis of simulation and experimental results demonstrates that the conventional method lacks precision in estimating the loss tangent, especially when measuring values as low as 0.1%—a typical range for both new and aged underground power cables. However, the proposed extended method provides reliable loss tangent estimation within this range, ensuring acceptable accuracy and improved measurement consistency.

title: DualBERT: Fusing Symbolic and Temporal Dynamics for High-Precision Log Anomaly Detection
authors: Ahmed Alzamil, Ramzi Guesmi, Amer AlGhadhban, Tawfik Guesmi, Abdennaceur Kachouri
abstract: Anomaly detection in system logs has attracted considerable interest with the development of deep learning and big data. Many methods and approaches have achieved good results in log anomaly detection, but exploiting the rich dependencies hidden in log data remains an extremely challenging task. Recently, Transformer-based models, such as LogBERT, represent a strong and promising foundation thanks to their ability to capture rich contextual information within log sequences. The limitation of these models is that they mainly treat logs as a sequence of discrete tokens, neglecting the crucial and continuous information embedded in the temporal and numerical dynamics between events. This limitation can lead to a high false positive rate, thus reducing the practical utility of the model. In this work, we propose DualBERT, a hybrid framework designed to address this gap. Our approach leverages a dual-model architecture: 1) a primary Transformer (LogBERT) to analyze the log’s symbolic key sequence; 2) a parallel and specialized parameter model represented by an LSTM-based regressor that analyzes inter-event features such as temporal deltas and cyclic patterns. The anomaly scores of both models are then fused using an XGBoost classifier to produce a final robust decision. We conduct a rigorous and fully supervised evaluation on the HDFS benchmark dataset. Our results demonstrate that DualBERT achieves an F1 score of 98.75%, significantly surpassing the satisfactorily evaluated LogBERT benchmark (98.29%). This improvement is mainly due to a substantial increase in accuracy (from 96.64% to 97.70%) and a 43% reduction in the false positive rate. Our results confirm that merging symbolic sequence analysis with dedicated inter-event dynamic modeling is an effective strategy to create a more reliable and practical system for real-world logarithmic anomaly detection.

title: Exploring Disciplinary Identities and Computational Thinking Through Bugs, Repairs, and Resistance
authors: Alicia C. Lane, Efrat Ayalon, Gabriella Anton, Noel Enyedy
abstract: This research category full paper explores how to strengthen expansive approaches toward justice-centered computer science education (CSEd). The study examines how incorporating “bugs” and allowing for student resistance in an unplugged computational thinking (CT) activity can reveal important insights about learners' CT skills and perceptions in real time. The findings suggest that prioritizing opportunities for social and embodied learning, resisting the dominant focus on coding and programming, and expanding research methodologies to include multi-modal analysis can provide a more holistic understanding of students' CT and disciplinary identities. This approach contrasts with dominant CSEd research that is often in isolation from students' lived experiences. Implications include the need to consider teacher moves when designing research studies and the importance of examining the complexity of teaching and learning computational thinking with justice-oriented practices.

title: Hierarchical BERT for Emotion Detection and Engagement Anomaly Analysis in Online Learning Forums
authors: Laila A. Abd-Ellatif, Al-Ayham M. Shamaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) create rich discussion forum data that can be used to provide valuable insights into the affective and behavioral status of learners. Although previous studies have focused on either sentiment or engagement separately, few have combined these two dimensions into a single analytical framework. This paper presents a hierarchical BERT-based model for detecting emotions in MOOC forums, pretrained on GoEmotions and adapted to the Stanford MOOCPosts dataset. The approach classifies sentiment polarity and then performs fine-grained multi-label emotion detection, augmented with contextual embeddings capturing thread structure, temporal dynamics, and user identity. Results demonstrate that transfer learning improves emotion classification performance over baselines, particularly for low-frequency emotions such as confusion and curiosity (Macro-F1 =0.72 vs. 0.52 for logistic regression). Correlation analysis reveals that positive and epistemic emotions (such as curiosity, gratitude, and joy) are strongly associated with deeper thread engagement. In contrast, negative emotions (including frustration and confusion) are associated with lower response rates and participation. Finally, an anomaly detection module combining affective and engagement signals achieves high precision (0.81 at Medium sensitivity) while reducing instructor workload by 73%. Together, these findings highlight the potential of emotion-aware engagement analytics to support scalable, real-time interventions in MOOCs.

title: A Hybrid GraphSAGE Architecture for Floor Plan Recognition in Real-World Networks
authors: Krishna Durbha, Veena S Badiger, Dhananjay kumar Yadav, S. Ramya, Siddharth Sriram, Sridevi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: To overcome this problem of floor plan recognition, a new hybrid architecture Centrality-Based GraphSAGE (CB-SAGE) is presented which models the problem as a graph classification problem. The actual building architectures are translated into a graph structure with each room/compartment becoming a node and the interconnectivity among rooms becoming the graph edges. However, the regular GraphSAGE methods mostly depend on the local neighbourhood sampling and aggregation, risking to neglect more structural properties. CB-SAGE improve upon this by embedding centrality-based measures like clustering coefficient or betweenness centrality directly into the feature matrix of nodes during training. Such metrics provide the graph embeddings with topological context that allows the model to learn more discriminative and informative pattern. Due to that, the model can capture more unique spatial plans and categorizing sophisticated types of floor plans. Evaluation on real-world datasets indicate that CB-SAGE considerably gains the standard models in regard to accuracy and generalization capacity. The approach is of practical value to the fields of architectural analysis, robotics navigation, and the design of smart buildings, where the effective and meaningful graph-based spatial environment representation is important. CB-SAGE unites the benefits of local aggregation with the global structural information, thus providing a potent new paradigm of graph based spatial learning. The proposed system had improved results over alternative approaches and recorded high Macro-F1 score of 77.5 % and purity of 75.4 % on the House-GAN floor plan dataset. It was always outperforming GCN, GAT, and GraphSAGE.

title: Distance to Feasibility: Performance Assessment of Baseline Metaheuristics on University Course Timetabling with Student Sectioning
authors: Sina Abdipoor, Mingxuan Li, Say Leng Goh, Razali Yaakob, Luo Hao, Salwani Abdullah
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: The University Course Timetabling with Student Sectioning Problem, as the subject of the most recent international timetabling competition on educational timetabling, remains a novel challenge. Many successful metaheuristics on previous benchmarks are yet to be tested on this problem. Due to its significantly higher complexity compared to conventional university course timetabling, achieving feasibility is extremely difficult, with current state-of-the-art matheuristic approaches from the literature requiring more than 10 days to achieve feasibility on certain instances. The official validator’s cost metric only evaluates valid solutions and thus provides insufficient guidance for search methods towards feasibility. To address this, we propose a Distance to Feasibility metric as a guiding strategy for metaheuristics and analyze its effectiveness through an empirical study. We apply baseline metaheuristics to the 30 problem instances of the International Timetabling Competition 2019 dataset and assess their performance. Hill Climbing outperforms Random Search by achieving feasible solutions, while RS fails to reach feasibility. Our experimental results demonstrate that the proposed metric effectively guides the search toward feasibility. Furthermore, we show that exploitative metaheuristics are superior in reducing the distance to feasibility, at the higher risk of being trapped in local optima compared to more exploratory methods. Overall, the proposed metric is of significant importance for finding feasible solutions to complex university course timetabling problems.

title: Identification of the Critical Knowledge Areas for Advancing Human-Wearable Robots Interactions: A Delphi Study
authors: Joshua Nsiah Addo Ofori, Mariam Tomori, Omobolanle Ogunseiju, Chuma Nnaji
abstract: This research-to-practice full research paper provides an expert overview of the knowledge areas for advancing human-wearable robot interactions in the construction industry. Wearable robots, such as exoskeletons, are emerging devices for reducing musculoskeletal disorders in the construction industry because of their ability to improve reduce muscle fatigue and strain. The promises of wearable robots, as well as the demands and need for improved health and safety in the construction industry, have prompted construction companies to begin investing in the use of wearable robots. This has necessitated the development of a future workforce equipped with the necessary knowledge to advance human-wearable robot interactions in the construction industry. However, a comprehensive review of existing studies on wearable robots reveals that scholars have primarily focused on assessing their effectiveness and usability. This research aims to identify the knowledge areas critical for advancing human-wearable robot interactions using Delphi study technique. Out of the 25 knowledge areas retrieved from the literature, 10 were agreed upon, with an additional 9 knowledge domains being suggested by the experts. The critical knowledge areas are centered around human factors and ergonomics, safety, technical and social matters. This study sets the pace for advancing human-wearable robot interactions in the construction industry by understanding academic perceptions on the knowledge areas required for advancing wearable robot implementation in the construction industry. Practically, construction engineering and management institutions and professional bodies in the construction industry can utilize these findings to develop tailored curricula for advancing wearable robots in the industry.

title: Enhancing Ultraviolet Responsivity of GaN p-i-n Photodetectors Through Full Depletion Thin-Layer Doping-Induced Carrier Transport Modulation
authors: Shishun Yang, Yaxuan Liu, Huiyi Zhang, Hanlin Li, Jun Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: High-performance GaN-based ultraviolet (UV) photodetectors (PDs) are essential for applications in harsh-environment sensing, space-based UV monitoring, and high-speed optical communications. However, conventional GaN-based p-i-n homojunction UV photodetectors face limitations in responsivity due to significant UV absorption in the p-GaN layer. To address this issue, we propose a novel full depletion (FD) thin-layer structure incorporating a strategically placed 1-nm n-type interlayer at the p–i interface with optimized doping to enhance carrier separation and collection. Results reveal a 27.3% increase in peak responsivity, reaching 0.163 A/W at 360 nm, compared to 0.128 A/W in conventional devices. In addition, the new-structured photodetector exhibits a specific detectivity (D*) of 2.88×1013 Jones, and a low response time of approximately 37 ns. The results of experiments and simulations are highly consistent, verifying the accuracy of the proposed model. Notably, the proposed design maintains excellent electrical performance, with dark current levels comparable to those of traditional architectures, thereby ensuring device stability. The FD-thin doped layer strategy offers a straightforward yet effective route to significantly improve the responsivity of GaN-based UV photodetectors without introducing fabrication complexity or the need for heterojunction integration. This architecture presents a promising pathway toward high-efficiency UV photodetection systems for next-generation applications.

title: WIP: Decoding Cybersecurity: An Ethnographic Case Study of Cybersecurity Awareness Education
authors: Amber C. Williamson, Andrew O. Hall
abstract: This work-in-progress research paper describes a case study of a cybersecurity pathways curriculum for minority students in secondary education. Differences between cybersecurity education, career and technical education, and vocational training can be confusing for students, parents, and administrators. Opportunities for entry-level cybersecurity positions often require experience, education, and certification. The misconceptions about the necessity of obtaining a degree, certifications, and experiences to find employment, as well as the lack of qualified cybersecurity instructors and community role models, pose challenges for cybersecurity education. Minority students continue to face obstacles in pursuing careers in cybersecurity, and we examine the complexities of this educational challenge. This ethnographic case study explores the cybersecurity pathway curriculum in secondary education. We survey students in GenCyber summer camps, students in dual enrollment summer programs, and high school cybersecurity and computer science classes to learn the perceptions of high school students towards cybersecurity education. We also survey the faculty of these programs, as well as faculty from HBCUs that house cybersecurity programs, to explore the concerns of cybersecurity faculty.

title: Listening to Emotions: Inferring User Mood Through Music Consumption Patterns
authors: Roberto Cavicchioli, Marco Furini
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Music serves as a powerful medium for emotional expression, influencing and reflecting an individual’s mood. This study proposes a non-intrusive method to infer a user’s emotional state based solely on their music listening history. Unlike existing approaches that rely on biometric data or textual sentiment analysis, this method ensures privacy while leveraging analytical features of songs, such as tempo, valence, and energy, to classify emotions. The proposed framework maps songs into an emotional space and tracks long-term mood trends by clustering user listening patterns. The experimental phase involved 30 volunteers whose listening histories were analyzed to reconstruct emotional profiles. The results indicate that our proposal might be used to identify stable moods, seasonal trends, and fluctuations. These insights have broad applications, from improving music recommendation systems to informing mental health interventions and improving user experiences in adaptive environments. In summary, this study highlights music as a valuable tool for emotion recognition, paving the way for innovative, privacypreserving applications in personalized digital services.

title: Pixel-Based Glacial Change Monitoring Across Hindu Kush, Karakoram, & Himalayan Ranges
authors: Muhammad Sameer Amjad, Muhammad Jamshaid Ghaffar, Usama Athar, Muhammad Moazam Fraz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Glaciers in the high-mountain regions of the Hindu Kush, Karakoram, and Himalayas are critical for sustaining downstream water resources, yet their short-term and localized responses to climate variability remain unclear. To address this gap, we present a machine learning–based framework for high-resolution glacier monitoring using Sentinel-2 imagery from 2016 to 2024. The proposed approach establishes a complete end-to-end pipeline for glacier change analysis, including satellite image preprocessing, supervised SVM-based tri-class classification (snow, partial snow/ice, and no snow), pixel-level change detection, and temporal trend analysis. The tri-class model achieves an overall accuracy of 83%, capturing detailed variations in glacier surface conditions that conventional binary models often overlook. The results indicate a weakening of the Karakoram Anomaly after 2019, with glaciers displaying divergent behaviors and a general trend toward retreat, particularly at lower elevations. While effective, the approach is limited by cloud-prone Sentinel-2 observations, manual and NDSI-based training data, and reduced accuracy in transitional zones such as firn or debris-covered ice. Overall, this framework advances long-term glacier monitoring by improving spatial and temporal resolution, supports water resource management, and provides a foundation for assessing Glacial Lake Outburst Flood risks under changing climatic conditions.

title: PAUnet: Pyramidal Attention based Efficient Unet for RGB Skin Dermatoscopic Image Enhancement
authors: Javaria Tahir, Tahir Mustafa Madni, Uzair Iqbal Janjua
publish: 2025 International Conference on Frontiers of Information Technology (FIT)
abstract: Medical images are prone to noise and artifacts, which affect their diagnostic performance. Frequency-dependent noise can cause unclear images and complicate disease detection, leading to misdiagnosis. Denoising is a crucial step in preprocessing to improve image clarity and visibility, especially for automated diagnostic processes. The primary focus of this paper is to improve the visual quality of denoised images by preserving fine details and structural similarity (edges), maintaining sharpness, and simultaneously removing blurriness. For this purpose, this study proposed a novel Pyramidal Attention-based Efficient UNet (PAUnet) for RGB skin dermatoscopic image enhancement. The technique uses an efficient UNet as a backbone, incorporating residual blocks to prevent vanishing gradients, and utilizing channel attention in skip connections to enhance feature interdependencies by reducing noise while preserving fine details. Atrous spatial pyramidal pooling (ASPP) in the bottleneck to enhance the capacity of multi-scale feature extractions to speed up the calculations and merge low-level features across multiple resolutions to improve the preservation of structural similarity and edges collectively. This study used a publicly available dataset, i.e., RGB skin dermatoscopic images HAM10000, for extensive experimentation that validates the effectiveness of the proposed PAUnet by improving the values of 0.8601% dB SSIM and 33.4315% dB PSNR, respectively, compared to state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Smart Surveillance for Blinds: A YOLOv5-Based Assistive Vision System
authors: Muhammad Awais, Muhammad Anees, Yasir Mehmood, Aamir Shahzad
abstract: People with visual impairments reduce an individual’s ability to navigate their surroundings safely to keep them-selves from hazards. Recent researchers have made advancements in computer vision and deep learning which can help them in routes life. The proposed work presents a smartphone-based Smart Surveillance System for the Visually Impaired (SSFB) application for blind users which improves nearby environmental alertness through real-time object detection and with voice feedback. The SSFB uses the YOLOv5 object detection model, which trained on a custom dataset with four target labels: stairs, doors, electrical switches, and roads. LabelImg software was used to label the data custom datasets and trained the model in Python via transfer learning techniques to improve accuracy and improve performance for mobile applications. The SSFP application integrates with Python and JavaScript API for text-to-voice conversion to give a voice signal to users in real-time obstacle detection. Obtained results display that the SSFB attains accurate object detection and fast audio feedback, making it an effective, low-cost, and practical solution to support safe and independent navigation for visually impaired individuals.

title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Detection in Women Using Biomarkers for AI-Based Wearable Biosensor System
authors: Deepa Narayanasamy, Arun Kumar Selvam, G. Jeyaram, Balamurugan Balusamy, Devi Thiyagarajan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: PCOS is polycystic ovarian syndrome which is a medical condition related to women's health where their endocrine system gets weakened. Current systems with various screening methods for patients affected from PCOS suffer from various obstacles like early identification of symptoms in addition to the process of biological indicator tracking. Advanced technologies are available in the healthcare domain thereby enabling patients to have personalized choice of treatment from doctors. Still, the usage of wearable gadgets for treatment of PCOS is not prevalent. Biomarkers such as glucose fluctuations in addition to changes in human hormones need to be monitored as wearables lack such capability. Conventional methods used for PCOS diagnosis suffer from several pitfalls. Handheld devices with biosensors incorporated help in filling this research gap that is being identified. Artificial intelligence based devices are integrated with handheld devices in addition to sensor methodologies for tracking PCOS biomarkers. The proposed techniques work on the basis of the above. Saliva analysis is done by these gadgets for identification of hormonal abnormalities by usage of silicon luminescence. The data that is acquired is being processed initially in approaches that are based on YOLO. In the presence of anomalies, an alarm is being dispatched. Ava wristband is employed for PCOS indicator tracking to which AI techniques are combined in addition to biosensor devices that are compatible with the mobile. Variations in the hormones are monitored by the system with advanced nanotechnology along with photonic sensing. Identification of anomalies besides involvement of users along with treatments done to patients in preferred time makes YOLOv8 suitable for implementation. The results obtained show that the system performs well with additional amounts of data and provides better treatment. The suggested strategy outperformed current techniques in testing, achieving a 92% success rate, and 94% specificity, respectively, in identifying anomalies linked to PCOS. The technique offers dependable screening by using aptamer-derived and antibody-associated biorecognition mechanisms to focus on biomarkers, including follicle-stimulating hormone, FSH, and the hormone luteinizing. In the final analysis, this AI-powered wearable provides constant, current data for preemptive management of PCOS and early identification, increasing the effectiveness and accessibility of tailored therapy, 89% sensitivity.

title: Precision Crop Care: Leaf Infection Analytics and Fertilizer Advice
authors: P. Deepika, Jai Jaganath Babu Jayachandran, K. Rajkumar, Swapna Mandu, D. Sravanthi, Ala Tanvi Reddy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Agriculture underpins national development, yet crop yield is frequently threatened by leaf-borne diseases that are difficult to diagnose quickly and consistently by naked-eye inspection. Manual assessment is labor-intensive, subjective, and dependent on scarce expert knowledge. To address these challenges, we propose PDDC-Net, a deep learning framework for Plant leaf Disease Detection and Classification that couples image preprocessing with a residual network-based convolutional neural network (ResNet-CNN). Preprocessing performs denoising, illumination/color normalization, and size standardization to mitigate acquisition variability. The ResNet backbone extracts discriminative texture- and vein-pattern features, while the classification head assigns the most probable disease class. On top of recognition, PDDC-Net integrates a lightweight decision module that maps each detected disease to agronomic guidance—suggesting appropriate remedial actions (e.g., fertilizer amendments and, when relevant, pesticide recommendations) aligned with best-practice guidelines. Experiments on a curated multi-crop image set demonstrate that PDDC-Net achieves high accuracy for both detection and classification and remains robust under changing lighting, background clutter, and moderate leaf occlusion. The results indicate that PDDC-Net can serve as a practical component of precision-agriculture workflows, enabling rapid field-level diagnosis and actionable treatment suggestions to help stabilize yield and reduce input waste.

title: Adaptive Human Activity Recognition with Deep Q-Networks: A Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Abdelouahab Maza, Lyazid Sabri, Nadia Agti
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: A key component of pervasive computing, Human Activity Recognition (HAR) allows smart settings to comprehend, support, and predict human requirements. Despite their excellent recognition accuracy, traditional deep learning techniques frequently use static, completely labeled datasets and are not flexible enough for dynamic real-world situations. Instead of using passive supervision, this study suggests a unique reinforcement learning-based architecture for HAR that enables an agent to learn activity classification through interactive feedback. Our methodology, which makes use of the WISDM dataset, formulates HAR as a sequential decision-making problem in which a Deep QNetwork (DQN) agent observes temporal sensor information and repeatedly refines its predictions in response to environmental rewards. This paradigm change gives HAR systems the flexibility and self-improvement they need to function in dynamic environments and with little prior knowledge. A potential step toward autonomous and self-tuning activity detection systems is indicated by experimental results showing that our RL agent not only learns efficient activity representations but also generalizes well to unknown data.

title: Joint Communication and Sensing in Metaverse over UAVs: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Sabina Jangirova, Latif U. Khan, Branislava Jankovic, Waseem Ullah, Mohsen Guizani
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The development of wireless systems based on metaverse to effectively enable novel applications (e.g., surveillance and remote healthcare) gained significant interest from the research community. A metaverse combines many technologies with a virtual representation of the real world system for enabling applications. Although a metaverse enables many applications, there are challenges associated with its deployment. Therefore, in this paper, we consider sensing in metaverse-empowered unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks. A massive number of sensors are considered to effectively sense the physical world states and share them with the metaverse. A problem is formulated to minimize the cost of sensing in terms of energy and latency. Our problem is based on optimizing the resource allocation and association for sensing units. We present a solution based on double deep Q-network (DDQN) for joint association and resource allocation in sensing for metaverse over UAVs network because the defined problem is non-convex and combinatorial. In the end, we validate our idea with comprehensive simulation results.

title: Big Data-Driven Analytics and Ensemble Machine Learning for Behavior Prediction and Service Quality Enhancement
authors: Lew Sook Ling, Claireta Tang Weiling, Lai Zhi Ming
abstract: This study looks at how big data analytics and machine learning (ML) can improve the tourism sector. It focuses on understanding tourist behavior and enhancing service quality. Traditional methods often lack access to rich information. This research shows how data techniques can help fill those gaps. It reviews both the strengths and weaknesses of using big data. It also addresses ethical and privacy concerns in handling tourist data. The main objectives are to: (1) analyze tourist behavior using big data tools, (2) examine how big data drives innovation in tourism, and (3) explore ethical and privacy issues related to data use. This study uses stacking ensemble learning method to improve prediction accuracy. This study also tests Random Forest (RF) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for a dataset of hotel satisfaction scores in Europe. Furthermore, this study compares stacking with traditional models. With the findings from this study, trends in tourist preferences and satisfaction are revealed for improving services, experiences and innovation.

title: Code Insight: Evaluating an Active Learning Framework for Novice Programmers to Promote the Development of Code Review Skills
authors: Keerti Banweer, Deborah Trytten
abstract: The full research paper describes an active learning based in-class intervention to encourage the development of code review and debugging skills in students from the CS program. The rapid proliferation of AI-based applications has heightened the importance of code review and debugging skills among software developers. Organizations leverage code review processes not only to ensure software quality and accuracy but also to facilitate knowledge transfer, promote productive collaboration, maintain consistency, and share ideas. However, incorporating code review practices into classroom settings presents challenges due to the associated heavy workload, often resulting in low student motivation and participation. To address these issues, we propose an in-class active learning framework, Code Insight, which integrates seamlessly into class lectures without adding extra workload for students or additional grading for instructors. Recognizing that beginner programmers have limited knowledge and experience with programming concepts, the goal of this study is to provide strategic guidance to help students effectively and systematically review, analyze, and evaluate existing code written by others, thereby gaining a deeper understanding of the code. In our study, students participated in the Code Insight activity during class, using a classroom response system to report the correctness of provided code through multiple-choice questions. The impact of Code Insight on learning is evaluated by collecting student feedback at the end of the semester. Our findings indicate that the Code Insight activity presents a sufficient challenge for students, thereby improving their learning experience and highlighting the necessity of integrating more extensive code review practices in entry-level programming courses. Students expressed a preference for these activities over traditional lectures, noting that they helped them debug their programs by identifying and fixing errors, and they feel confident in writing a program and addressing any issues through complex debugging tasks. The proposed intervention provides a platform for students to discuss misconceptions, visualize multiple problem-solving approaches, and thoroughly understand existing code.

title: WIP: Minority Mentors' Learning and Awareness: Role Models for Undergraduate Engineering Students in a Research Program
authors: Hilda Cecilia Contreras Aguirre, Stephanie Zackery, Luis Rodolfo Garcia Carrillo
abstract: This work-in-progress research-to-practice paper focuses on understanding mentors' learning and skill development following their participation in the Research-Oriented Learning Experiences (ROLE) program, a program focused on engineering research at a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) in the Southwest United States. Through a qualitative approach, six mentors were interviewed using a semi-structured protocol that documented their learning process and progress in mentoring undergraduate engineering students. The research questions explored mentors' self-efficacy and confidence, as well as their professional development after their participation in the ROLE program. The growth mindset framework emphasizes the importance of flexibility and change to grow and learn through effort, strategies, and the support of others. Preliminary findings revealed that mentors developed self-efficacy in their research skills and fostered students' confidence in research activities. Overall, mentors recognized the importance of leadership, teamwork, and communication skills as critical elements of college, graduate school, and the workplace.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Task Scheduling Algorithms in Mobile Edge Computing with Performance Improvements
authors: Mohan Sankaran, Juhi Jain, Poonam Khatarkar, G. Durga, Arvind Pujari, P. Deepthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) strengthens computational efficiency through the deployment of cloud services near end-users which shortens processing time and optimizes resource management. The scheduling process of tasks determines how MEC environments achieve their optimal performance levels. This research examines three MEC task scheduling approaches which include Adaptive Task Scheduling Algorithm (ATSA), Smart Execution Scheduling Algorithm (SESA), and Multi-Task Scheduling Algorithm (MTSA). The Workflow Simulator performs algorithm evaluation by measuring three factors including task execution time and completion time as well as throughput performance. Task execution efficiency together with resource utilization and total task throughput stand higher with MTSA than with ATSA and SESA. The ATSA scheduling approach focuses on performing tasks with lower priority yet it executes them quickly yet SESA delivers swift execution and achieves higher throughput rates. The parallel approach used by MTSA creates the most efficient system by minimizing delays of tasks and distributing resources properly. The study presents an approach for helping users choose suitable scheduling algorithms that align with their operational needs. The research shows that efficient scheduling of tasks in MEC systems provides improved performance together with better reliability. Various scheduling techniques demonstrate their effectiveness by managing different MEC workloads which results in better computational efficiency for these systems. The proposed MTSA approach has an overall accuracy of 97%, exceeding that of the SESA and ATSA methods.

title: Application of Double-End Impedance-Based Fault Location for Overhead Two-Terminal Transmission Lines in NGCP Using Data Captured by Network Disturbance and Monitoring Equipment
authors: Richard B. Rivera, Gorgonio C. Vallestero, John Christian Y. Nicdao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: Fault location is vital information for the speedy restoration of faulted overhead transmission lines. Transmission line crew in National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP) rely on the line protections’ internal fault locators. Most, if not all, of the line protections installed in NGCP use single-end impedance-based algorithms, which are susceptible to various sources of error, including fault resistance, soil resistivity, and mutual coupling effects from adjacent lines. On the other hand, double-end impedance-based methods are largely immune to these limitations. Since all the grid transmission lines in NGCP are installed with Network Disturbance and Monitoring Equipment (NDME), this study proposes using a double-end impedance-based technique that utilizes the fault recordings captured by the NDMEs. Fault data can be retrieved from the NDMEs through a central computer connected to a dedicated communication network. The double-end approach has been demonstrated to be both reliable and precise in determining fault locations for a range of scenarios. It performs well for typical fault types such as low-resistance line-to-ground, line-to-line, double line-to-ground, and three-phase faults as well as for less typical cases, including highly resistive ground faults.

title: WIP: Teaching Engineers to Draw People: Enhancing User-Centered Thinking and Self-Efficacy
authors: Shiho Nakamura, Mohen Li, Sarai Colorado-Landero, Denis Dorozhkin, Julie Linsey
abstract: Prior work indicates that simply instructing participants to include figures in their concept generation sketches increases user-centered considerations and prompts greater attention to the diverse needs of different potential customers, leading to more effective products. Unfortunately, the one drawback was that fewer concepts were generated. Therefore, this study aims to investigate the impact of learning different quick and easy human figure sketching styles (stick, jointed, box) on student design outcomes, engineering design self-efficacy, and belonging in engineering. An initial quasi-experimental, between-subject classroom study was conducted with undergraduate engineers, where participants took a pre- and post-survey, then underwent a 30-minute sketching instruction and 30-minute concept generation session. The results show that students in the stick and box figure groups tend towards generating a greater number of design concepts compared to the control group, and the jointed figure group generated about the same number of concepts as the control. Findings from the pre-post design self-efficacy survey found nearly statistically significant increases for Identifying Customer Needs for all figure conditions, but not the control. All figure conditions also have a statistically significant increase for Conduct System Level Design. There were no significant differences for sense of belonging. Future work will analyze the consideration of diverse customer needs and will further investigate the impacts of human figure sketching with a larger sample size and the sketching instruction integrated into multiple assignments. This work aims to contribute to understanding effective instructional strategies and improving engineers' visual communication skills.

title: Pre-Conference Workshop: Write and Evaluate Like a Pro for FIE-Excelling as an Author and Reviewer in Engineering Education Research
authors: Noemi V. Mendoza Diaz, Deborah A. Trytten, Rachel Louis Kajfez, So Yoon Yoon, Saira Anwar
abstract: The field of engineering education has evolved into a recognized discipline, yet many engineering faculty and graduate students lack formal training in educational research methodologies. This gap contributes to variability in the quality of research presented at major conferences, including Frontiers in Education (FIE). To address this, past FIE conference chairs and leaders in the field have designed a recurring 180-minute workshop focused on improving the quality of paper submissions and peer reviews. The workshop introduces participants to a structured framework for research design methods, spanning qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods. Through active learning, hands-on analysis of past conference papers, and small-group methodological exploration, attendees will develop plans for conducting and evaluating high-quality research. Emphasis is placed on research rigor, trustworthiness, and alignment with top-tier journals such as the Journal of Engineering Education and IEEE Transactions on Education. Open to all FIE participants, this workshop provides essential tools for building methodological competence, fostering inclusivity, and preparing the current and next generation of engineering education scholars.
