title: An Improved 3D Gaussian Splatting Method for Smoke Reconstruction
authors: Zhou Zhou, Xiaobo Lu
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: Frequent forest fires pose a severe threat to ecological security, while 3D reconstruction technology demonstrates significant potential in assisting fire field monitoring and prevention. Current mainstream methods exhibit notable limitations: Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF)-based implicit modeling achieves high precision but suffers from prolonged training duration and impractical real-time rendering. Explicit 3D Gaussian Splatting (3D-GS) methods maintain real-time advantages yet face challenges in data storage redundancy and inadequate dynamic modeling capabilities, particularly in handling non-rigid deformations, repetitive textures, and complex illumination variations characteristic of flame and smoke. This study achieves a balance between precision and efficiency through multi-level collaborative optimization. The proposed framework automatically optimizes spatial distribution based on scene characteristics to reduce storage consumption while preserving detail integrity. A frequencyaware constraint module is introduced to suppress reconstruction artifacts via multi-scale covariance matrix optimization. Furthermore, a hybrid image enhancement strategy effectively improves feature discernibility in low-quality fire imagery. Experimental results demonstrate that our method enhances reconstruction quality for dynamic fire scenarios while maintaining real-time performance, providing a practical technical solution for emergency fire response.

title: Combatting Quantitative Erasure of LGBTQIA+ Students Through an Investigation of Their Engineering Identity and Sense of Belonging
authors: Ash Quadd, Justin Major, Allison Godwin
abstract: This research paper focuses on LGBTQIA+ (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer/Questioning, Intersex, Asexual, and additional groups) students' sense of belonging and engineering identity. Belonging refers to one's sense of fit in various settings, such as engineering. In contrast, engineering identity refers to one's belief that they are the “kind of person” who can do engineering and engineering tasks. Both constructs are interrelated, central predictors of student success in engineering. As engineering programs strive to become more inclusive and welcoming to all students, research regarding marginalized students, such as those from the LGBTQIA+ community, and their connections to their engineering programs and identity has grown. However, research on the LGBTQIA+ community remains nascent, especially quantitative work. In part, challenges to this work stem from small sample sizes, which make it difficult to obtain statistical power, necessitating unique approaches to conducting such research. This study focuses on the LGBTQIA+ population, pooling data from several separate studies that included the same engineering identity and sense of belonging items. In doing so, we generate a large sample size to conduct a thorough quantitative analysis of the LGBTQIA+ population. Of the total 6,265 responses we received, 442, or 7 %, of the participants identified as LGBTQIA+. We used structural equation modeling to test direct, indirect, and latent relationships amongst engineering identity and belonging variables. We then compared LGBTQIA+ and non-LGBTQIA+ groups, as well as specific subgroups. We found that participants who identified as bisexual reported a small negative effect on their engineering identity. However, bisexual, asexual, and the larger population of Queer participants all had a lower sense of belonging compared to their peers. Notably, during the analysis, we identified several instances where LGBTQIA+ students were excluded from quantitative research. An overreliance on the text option to identify them, frequently combining LGBTQIA+ groups for analysis, and not having inclusive demographic options were points of erasure noted. Recommendations for remediation of these issues are provided to expand research.

title: Explaining Undergraduate Student Adoption of Integrated Development Environments
authors: Lakshita Malhotra, Jennifer Parham-Mocello
abstract: This full research paper builds upon the crucial role Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) play in facilitating efficient coding practices for programmers. IDEs support programming in various languages and offer distinct features tailored to different user skill levels. For beginners, choosing a suitable IDE that they can easily get accustomed to is crucial for fostering a positive programming language learning experience in early software development courses, which we believe can impact students' decision to further pursue a computational career. In this paper, we study how first-year undergraduate engineering students feel about the IDE they used in their first programming course at the university learning and working on different programming languages. The students are from various engineering majors with different demographics and experiences with programming and IDEs. We use the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT) model to understand how different first-year undergraduate engineering majors with minimal or no prior coding experience find the experience of working with various IDEs. The study focuses on the IDEs used in a first-year programming course for engineering students. We collected and analyzed post-survey responses from 613 consenting students using an extended UTAUT framework that included constructs such as Self-Efficacy and Availability of Resources. We applied Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to evaluate the relationships between key factors that influenced students' acceptance and perception of IDEs. A multi-group SEM analysis was also performed to compare these perceptions across the different IDE groups. By ensuring that factors such as complexity of the IDE, its usability, and the support align with learner needs and backgrounds, the findings of this study offer practical insights for educators to choose the correct IDEs that cater to student backgrounds and technical readiness.

title: Navigating Digital Frontiers: A Comprehensive Analysis of Mobile Device Integration in Engineering Instruction in Bangladesh Using Mobile Learning Readiness Survey
authors: Ninsiima Hafusa, Md. Shahadat Hossain Khan, Mahbub Hasan
abstract: This research WIP paper identified two research questions: How do faculty members perceive the benefits of using mobile devices as learning tools in engineering education? What are the faculty members' perceptions of the prospects of using mobile devices as learning tools in engineering education? Due to covid-19 pandemic, the use of mobile devices such as smartphones, tablets, and notebooks in engineering education in Bangladesh has increased significantly. Will the faculty members sustain the use of mobile devices in the face-to-face teaching and learning contexts in engineering education at post-COVID? Alternatively, will they abandon the mobile devices like before the pandemic and adopt the traditional education tools in the face-to-face teaching practice? The concern elevated how mobile devices could be used in engineering education to promote authentic learning. The Mobile Learning Readiness Survey instrument was adopted as a data collection tool having emphasized four factors: benefits, future possibilities, preferences and external influence. An online questionnaire was sent to the faculty members via email and thereafter, 184 respondents filled the online survey. Data was analyzed quantitatively using descriptive statistics of mean and standard deviation, and so forth. The study found that using mobile devices will improve twenty-first-century teaching and learning skills that will bring new education opportunities. Therefore, using these devices as learning tools in engineering education would be of great benefit. The outcome of this research will impact teaching and learning practices and improve the policy of using mobile devices in engineering education in Bangladesh and other similar contexts.

title: WIP: Data-Driven Adaptive Curriculum-Personalizing Academic Pathways for Enhanced Engineering Student Success
authors: David Mike-Ewewie, Panhapiseth Lim, Alejandro Sotelo, Priyanka Kumar
abstract: This work-in-progress innovative practice paper explores a key reason why many engineering students drop out: rigid university course plans. A single failed class can derail a student for an entire year, a system especially tough for learners who struggle with long-term planning. To address this, we introduce a framework that acts as a personal academic guide. This guide faces a classic learning challenge: It must determine the best course for each student's unique situation (their “context”) by constantly and intelligently balancing what has worked for similar students in the past with trying new options to see if they might work even better. This formal learning problem is known as a contextual multi-armed bandit. Our framework applies this approach to power an adaptive course recommendation system to create a flexible roadmap for each student that adheres to ABET accreditation standards. We tested our bandit framework in an offline simulation on the Open University Learning Analytics (OULAD) dataset, a public record of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 2, 5 9 3}$</tex> students. To solve the balancing challenge, we used a statistical approach that intelligently weighs recommending proven, successful courses (exploitation) against suggesting new, uncertain ones to discover their potential (exploration); a method known as Thompson Sampling. This strategy reduced suboptimal course recommendations by 66% compared to a standard popularity-based method. The system also maintained algorithmic fairness across gender groups and demonstrated it'a potential for real-world scalability. This work demonstrates the practical application of reinforcement learning for a more supportive and successful educational experience.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Infrastructure for Smart and Sustainable Cities
authors: Deven Chawla, Dipen Chawla, Anurag Shrivastava, Myasar Mundher Adnan, B. Sireesha, Irfan Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The rapid and relentless pace of global urbanization presents formidable challenges to municipal infrastructures, demanding a paradigm shift from reactive governance to proactive, data-driven management. Traditional urban systems, often operating in silos, are increasingly inadequate for addressing the complex, interconnected demands of sustainability, resilience, and quality of life. This paper posits that an AI-Driven Predictive Infrastructure constitutes the foundational pillar for the actualization of truly smart and sustainable cities. By integrating cyber-physical systems, Internet of Things (IoT) sensor networks, and heterogeneous urban data streams, this infrastructure leverages advanced machine learning and deep learning models to transition urban management from a static to a dynamic, anticipatory state. We examine the core architectural components of such an infrastructure, including its data acquisition, communication, computational analytics, and decision-support layers. The paper further elucidates the transformative applications of predictive AI across critical domains such as energy optimization, intelligent transportation systems, waste management, and water distribution, demonstrating its capacity to enhance operational efficiency, reduce environmental footprints, and improve civic engagement. Finally, we address significant implementation challenges, including data privacy, algorithmic bias, and cybersecurity, while proposing a forward-looking research agenda to guide the development of equitable, robust, and selfhealing urban ecosystems.

title: Machine Learning for Predictive Customer Retention in Competitive Markets
authors: Prithvi Siva Sankar Shunmuga Sundaram
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This research provides a full method for predicting client retention in a competitive market. Preparing data, updating the model, and generating ensemble forecasts provide crucial information. Early probe preparation and feature engineering are extensive. The procedure includes normalization, missing value estimations, one-hot categorical variable encoding, PCA, and LDA dimension reduction. Synthetic oversampling eliminates class distinctions and improves company service for repeat consumers. A clean, balanced, and feature-optimized prediction modeling dataset is segregated, evened out, and blended after cleaning. Iterative gradient descent, mini-batch optimization, regularization, momentum, and learning rate modifications may reduce overfitting and improve model training. Softmax functions determine event probabilities, while accuracy, cross-entropy loss, F1-score, and confusion matrices evaluate models. Combining many submodels leads to superior outcomes through ensemble learning. Gradient-based fine-tuning enhances the accuracy of weighted predictions. Based on value, this technique rates a customer's likelihood of staying with a firm. This lets you plan and target client retention activities. It outperforms other machine learning models in basic and complicated tasks. AUC, F1 scores, accuracy, precision, and memory matter most. G-mean, log loss, sensitivity, balancing accuracy, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient are advanced measurements. The findings demonstrate that the technique can identify complex consumer behavior and provide data-driven insights. Such analysis keeps organizations competitive in shifting marketplaces and promotes consumer trust.

title: Split Learning Privacy Protection Method Based on Differential Computing
authors: Xiaofeng Lu, Yinghui Li, Pietro Lio
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Split learning is a new distributed deep learning method, which facilitates resource-constrained clients to complete training of neural network models. In the model privacy security of split learning, many scholars have proposed many research schemes, but there may be many or direct or indirect privacy problems in the training process, any of which may cause serious privacy disclosure. This paper mainly considers two easily exposed data in the training process of split learning, namely the output data of the cut layer and the label of the data. In these two parts of the data, different algorithms of differential privacy are used to avoid the direct exposure of the data and protect the model privacy.

title: Decoupled Quadratic Filter for Extended Object Tracking using Multiplicative Noise
authors: Simon Steuernagel, Marcus Baum
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Extended object tracking refers to the estimation of not only the kinematics but also the shape of an object, often modeled by an ellipse. In literature, a closed-form Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for jointly estimating both the orientation and axis-lengths in addition to the kinematics has been proposed. In this work, we observe that it can be favorable to decouple the estimation problem into the kinematics, orientation, and axis lengths, carrying out an interleaved update of the three. By this means, fewer approximations are needed for the derivation, leading to vastly improved filtering. The resulting method can be computed in closed-form, and experiments show significantly improved tracking accuracy compared to the original EKF-based approach, as well as other state-of-the-art trackers.

title: Cell-Free Diffusion Uplink with Fronthaul Noise Adapting Arbitrary Fronthaul Structure
authors: Ziyao Hong, Junli Xue, Xinjiang Xia, Shu Xu, Ting Li, Chunguo Li, Dongming Wang, Xiaohu You
abstract: Cell-free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) represents the pinnacle of distributed antenna systems, offering superior service to all users. However, the distributed nature of access points leads to fragmented information processing, limiting performance in practical deployments. Additionally, existing studies often overlook the impact of limited fronthaul capacity, which introduces noise and degrades the reliability of shared information. In this work, we implement a practical CF-mMIMO prototype under fifth generation new radio standards and propose a diffusion-based uplink scheme that outperforms conventional distributed cell-free systems without cooperation. Our approach adapts to arbitrary fronthaul topologies by leveraging the law of large numbers. We further analyze the linear effects of fronthaul noise and the correlation of uploaded data, demonstrating that the diffusion uplink excels in Rician fading environments while maintaining robust performance in Rayleigh fading. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to employ a diffusion model for mitigating fronthaul non-idealities, enabling distributed cooperative uplink in a real-world CF-mMIMO system.

title: Real-Time Hybrid Stock Prediction and Automated Portfolio Management Using Ensemble ML & Free APIs
authors: Yashmeet Kaur, Sagar Kamboj, Soham Srivastava, Chetan Trivedi, Gagandeep Kaur, Rohit Chawdhari, Yogiraj Anil Bhale
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: We develop and evaluate a real-time, low-cost framework for short-horizon equity prediction and automated portfolio management that relies exclusively on free or freemium market-data APIs and openly available datasets. The modeling core is a hybrid ensemble that combines gradient-boosted trees (LightGBM/XGBoost), a compact feed-forward network, and a lightweight sequence module (Transformer/LSTM), stacked via time-aware out-of-fold meta-learning. The data layer integrates end-of-day and intraday price feeds with fundamentals and optional news-sentiment features, using public APIs for live updates and Kaggle datasets for historical backfills. A cost-aware optimizer translates model scores into investable weights by jointly controlling risk (via Ledoit-Wolf shrinkage covariance, sector and name caps), turnover (L1 penalty and minimum holding periods), and target volatility. We conduct walk-forward, purged/embargoed validation on a liquid U.S. equity universe (multi-year horizon) and report predictive metrics (ROC/AUC, accuracy, RMSE/MAPE), portfolio outcomes (returns, Sharpe, drawdown), and operational characteristics (latency, rate-limit resilience). Results show that stacked ensembles are more robust than single models across regimes and that explicit turnover control preserves net performance under realistic frictions. The work contributes a practical blueprint-covering data engineering, validation hygiene, and optimization-that students and small teams can reproduce with transparent tooling and public data.

title: Lost in Translation: Analyzing Non-English Cybercrime Forums
authors: Mariella Mischinger, Jack Hughes, Fedor Vitiugin, Sergio Pastrana, Alice Hutchings, Guillermo Suarez-Tangil
publish: 2025 APWG Symposium on Electronic Crime Research (eCrime)
abstract: Cybercrime analysis and Cyber Threat Intelligence are crucial for understanding and defending against cyber threats, with online underground communities serving as a key source of information. Classification tasks are popular but demand significant manual effort and language-specific expertise. Prior work focuses on English-language forums, as non-English languages require fluent domain experts. We evaluate machine translation tools for suitability in preserving contextual information in posts and find GPT-4 is most reliable. We leverage existing underground forum post classification pipelines to compare their performance on translated text and original language text. We find classification performed on translated underground forum data is as effective as on original language text, enabling researchers to reuse existing pipelines. Finally, we investigate a fully machine-generated few-shot and zero-shot classification to reduce reliance on manual labeling, followed by a two-step machine-based classification, combining machine-generated labels with the existing classification pipeline. We find machine-based labeling causes errors to propagate downstream. For tasks requiring high-quality label creation, human expertise remains essential. Finally, we provide a qualitative evaluation of disagreements in annotator labels of the original language and the translations, as well as disagreements between annotators and machine labeling.

title: Pair-Bid Auction Model for Optimized Network Slicing in 5G RAN
authors: Mengyao Li, Sebastian Troia, Yingqian Zhang, Guido Maier
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Network slicing is a key 5G technology that enables multiple virtual networks to share physical infrastructure, optimizing flexibility and resource allocation. This involves Mobile Network Operators (MNO), Mobile Virtual Network Operators (MVNOs), and end users, where MNO leases network slices to MVNOs, and then provides customized services. This work considers end-to-end network slicing with a focus on fair sharing and financial-related power efficiency, modeled as a twolevel hierarchical combinatorial auction. At the upper level, an MNO auctions slices to competing MVNOs, while at the lower level, MVNOs allocate resources to end users through their own auctions. Dynamic user requests add complexity to the process. Our model optimizes resource allocation and revenue generation using a pair-bid mechanism and Vickrey-Clarke- Groves (VCG) pricing. The pair-bid approach enhances competition and efficiency, while VCG ensures truthful bidding based on marginal system impact. Simulations validate the model’s effectiveness in resource distribution and financial performance, showing a $\mathbf{1 2. 5} \boldsymbol{\%}$ revenue improvement over the baseline.

title: Evaluating Angle of Arrival and Distance with Ultra WideBand Technology for Indoor Localization
authors: Fabio Mavilia, Francesco Furfari, Paolo Barsocchi, Michele Girolami
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Several radio-frequency technologies have been investigated to develop accurate indoor localization systems, each offering distinct techniques for estimating a target’s position in indoor environments. Among them, the Ultra-WideBand (UWB) technology is a promising approach because it can estimate the distance and angle between a tag and an anchor. In this work, we evaluate the performance of a commercial UWB kit with a systematic data collection campaign. We gather data in a realistic setting, comparing estimated and actual Angles of Arrival (AoA) and distances. Results highlight that, while the system performs reliably in most scenarios, a few instances reveal noticeable deviations from the Ground Truth (GT) data.

title: Exploring Traces from Algorithm Simulation: Students' Conceptions of Dijkstra's Algorithm
authors: Artturi Tilanterä, Ari Korhonen, Otto Seppälä, Teemu Taivainen, Inka Croell
abstract: This full research paper explores undergraduate students' misconceptions of Dijkstra's algorithm quantitatively. Graph algorithm misconceptions have been studied to a modest extent, but they support effective instruction. A visual algorithm simulation (VAS) exercise requires a student to trace the algorithm by modifying a data structure visualization. We investigated effective ways to mine new algorithm misconceptions from VAS exercise data. In addition, we searched for previously unknown misconceptions of Dijkstra's algorithm. Students simulated Dijkstra's algorithm with a VAS exercise by adding edges of a given graph to a spanning tree. The simulations produced execution patterns which were mapped into a canonical form. We constructed another graph representing exercise states in all simulations. Using an interactive visualization of the state graph, we built hypotheses for misconceptions. The hypotheses were modeled as algorithms whose execution patterns were matched against students' simulations to find frequency of the hypothetical misconceptions. Pattern matching indicated that certain simulations resembled depth-first search, breadth-first search, and Prim's algorithm. Other simulations had evidence that students had understood the purpose of Dijkstra's algorithm, but arrived to the correct solution with ad hoc heuristics. The findings demonstrate how a VAS exercise was designed to reveal students' difficulties with graph algorithms. The methodology supports recognizing common misconceptions and therefore giving automated, formative feedback. The misconceptions itself are applicable to any exercise on elementary graph algorithms. Interactive visualization of an exercise state graph demonstrates the use of a new data-driven method for eliciting misconceptions.

title: WIP: Parents Study: A Different Approach to Racial Equity in STEM
authors: E. Shirl Donaldson, Jennifer Lacosse, Thiago Ferreira
abstract: This research WIP paper introduces a study that explores an innovative approach to addressing racial equity in STEM education by focusing on the role of parents in shaping students' experiences and outcomes. Despite the growing body of research on racial disparities within STEM fields, little attention has been given to the influence of parental involvement on students' educational trajectories in STEM. This paper, falling under the “Diversity and Broadening Participation” track, examines how parents' engagement can support racial equity efforts in STEM pathways. The purpose of this study is to explore how parents' perspectives, resources, and involvement can influence racial equity in STEM education. Research questions include: How do parents of underrepresented racial groups perceive their role in supporting their children's STEM education? What are the challenges and opportunities associated with parent engagement in fostering racial equity in STEM fields? How can institutions and educators better support parents in this process? How do parents help prepare their children for careers in STEM fields. We planned a series of three related studies. All of the studies have not been completed, but the initial data is interesting and worthy of exploration.

title: Lightweight LLM for Accurate & Accessible Automated Course Support in Student Forums
authors: Jason L Weber, Ulises Maldonado, Alessio Diaz Cama, Justin Tian Jin Chen, Agustín Herlindo Angulo, Barbara Martinez Neda, Jennifer Wong-Ma, Sergio Gago-Masague
abstract: This research category full paper presents a lightweight, deployable Large Language Model (LLM) pipeline to automatically answer student forum questions about course logistics. By leveraging Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) over course documents like the syllabus and calendar, our Llama 3.1-based model offers an accurate, low-cost alternative to commercial tools. In addition, many countries have strict student-privacy laws, making online third-party solutions difficult or impossible to gain approval for. Unlike large proprietary models, our pipeline runs on consumer hardware and avoids expensive API costs. We evaluated 159 authentic student forum questions across eleven Computer Science (CS) courses, showing that the model accurately answered 74% of logistical queries. Performance improved significantly when filtered by retrieval confidence scores above 0.5, allowing staff to easily identify questions needing review. To contextualize its effectiveness, we compared our pipeline to several state-of-the-art commercial models. While commercial tools slightly outperformed in raw accuracy, our model provided comparable results at a fraction of the computational and financial cost. This tradeoff makes our approach particularly well-suited for educational institutions seeking low-cost, scalable solutions compliant with student-privacy laws such as FERPA. Our findings support the use of lightweight LLMs for automating routine academic support, offering a viable and accessible path forward for institutions with limited infrastructure or privacy restrictions.

title: An NFT-Based Solution to Enhance Trust in Decentralized Marketplaces
authors: Luca Serena, Stefano Ferretti, Moreno Marzolla, Gabriele D’Angelo
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: The rise of blockchain has expanded the possibilities for asset representation, particularly through Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs), which enable unique connections between digital and physical assets. Despite their potential, existing NFT systems face challenges such as high transaction costs and uncertainties related to the management and transfer of associated physical assets. This paper introduces a decentralized marketplace architecture designed to address these challenges, by making use of blockchain-based smart contracts, decentralized storage solutions, and trustless validation mechanisms. The proposed system separates ownership from possession, ensuring secure and transparent asset transfers. The architecture was then tested in a blockchain-based environment, demonstrating its economic viability. This work paves the way for decentralized asset management across various domains, such as rental services and remote logistics. By addressing existing challenges, the proposed architecture provides a usable and cost-effective solution that links digital and physical asset ecosystems while preserving the fundamental principles of blockchain technology.

title: Scalable Deterministic Task Offloading and Resource Allocation in the IoT-Edge-Cloud Continuum
authors: Keyvan Aghababaiyan, Baldomero Coll-Perales, Javier Gozalvez
publish: 2025 IEEE Symposium on Computers and Communications (ISCC)
abstract: Future 6 G networks are envisioned as a “network of networks” (NoN) ecosystem, integrating communication and computing resources across multiple domains. At the deep edge, IoT and end-user devices will form subnetworks for local communication and distributed task processing. These subnetworks will seamlessly integrate into the NoN ecosystem, creating an IoT-edge-cloud continuum. The unified resources across this continuum facilitate dynamic and scalable task offloading, unlocking new possibilities to support emerging services, including critical vertical services with stringent reliability and deterministic service level requirements. In this context, this paper demonstrates that a deterministic approach to task offloading and resource (communication and computing) allocation in the IoT-edge-cloud continuum not only ensures deterministic service levels but also enhances scalability compared to existing task offloading and resource allocation methods. By flexibly managing task completion deadlines while maintaining deterministic (i.e. bounded latency) service levels, deterministic policies achieve a more balanced workload and resource distribution across the continuum, ultimately improving scalability.

title: Locally Adapted Reference Frame Fields using Moving Least Squares_supp1-3634845.pdf
authors: Julio Rey Ramirez
abstract: The detection and analysis of features in fluid flow are important tasks in fluid mechanics and flow visualization. One recent class of methods to approach this problem is to first compute objective optimal reference frames, relative to which the input vector field becomes as steady as possible. However, existing methods either optimize locally over a fixed neighborhood, which might not match the extent of interesting features well, or perform global optimization, which is costly. We propose a novel objective method for the computation of optimal reference frames that automatically adapts to the flow field locally, without having to choose neighborhoods a priori. We enable adaptivity by formulating this problem as a moving least squares approximation, through which we determine a continuous field of reference frames. To incorporate fluid features into the computation of the reference frame field, we introduce the use of a scalar guidance field into the moving least squares approximation. The guidance field determines a curved manifold on which a regularly sampled input vector field becomes a set of irregularly spaced samples, which then forms the input to the moving least squares approximation. Although the guidance field can be any scalar field, by using a field that corresponds to flow features the resulting reference frame field will adapt accordingly. We show that using an FTLE field as the guidance field results in a reference frame field that adapts better to local features in the flow than prior work. However, our moving least squares framework is formulated in a very general way, and therefore other types of guidance fields could be used in the future to adapt to local fluid features.

title: Identifying User Bias as Hidden State in A/B Testing with Hidden Markov Model Approach
authors: Andreana Hartadi Suliman, Fitra Arifiansyah
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Advanced Informatics: Concept, Theory and Application (ICAICTA)
abstract: A/B testing is a software development testing method comparing two software interface designs to determine which one is more effective. A/B testing commonly uses click rate as a metric, but this metric can be affected by user bias, yielding inaccurate results. The Hidden Markov Model (HMM) can used to detect hidden state that affect A/B testing results, which is the bias itself. Through this research, we aim to provide a new solution to overcome user bias in A/B testing by changing the display frequency of each design variation using HMM, which may modify the display frequency of the design unequally and to minimize user bias. The implementation results showed that HMM successfully detected user bias and improved the validity of A/B testing results, an opened up further research opportunities on the application of HMM in software testing optimization.

title: Distributed Stochastic Optimal Dispatching Strategy for the Energy Storage-integrated Soft Open Points in Distribution Networks
authors: Changhee Han, Sungyoon Song
abstract: In this study, we propose a distributed energy management strategy for multi-terminal energy storage integrated soft open points (ES-SOPs) to enable the flexible and coordinated operation of interconnected distribution networks (DNs) with high renewable penetration. We designed a bi-level distributed optimization framework to decompose the overall coordination problem into local DN operations and global ES-SOP management. The operational cost of each DN is minimized under relaxed reliability constraints using a distributionally robust chance-constrained (DRCC) formulation. The coordination layer minimizes the converter and battery losses and ensures a power balance between the battery and soft open points (SOPs). The DRCC approach addresses the PV and load forecast uncertainties without assuming specific distributions. The optimization problem is implemented using an analytical target cascading approach that ensures scalable convergence and preserves the DN independence. We conducted case studies to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in balancing the operational cost of the DNs and power grid reliability by varying the key parameters in the DRCC framework (i.e., ambiguity set radius and risk parameters).

title: Interactive Virtual Try-On Kiosk: Gesture and Voice Controlled Fashion Recommendation System
authors: Arta Kusuma Hernanda, Muhammad Fathi Farhat, Jeremy Johnson, Diah Puspito Wulandari, Eko Mulyanto Yuniarno, Supeno Mardi Susiki Nugroho
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: The fashion retail industry faces challenges in providing contactless, personalized shopping experiences following COVID-19. Traditional virtual try-on systems rely on touch-based interfaces that raise hygiene concerns and limit accessibility. This paper presents an Interactive Virtual Try-On Kiosk integrating gesture-based control using MediaPipe hand tracking with voiceactivated fashion recommendations powered by IndoBERT. Our system enables users to virtually try on clothing through intuitive hand gestures while receiving personalized recommendations via Indonesian voice commands. The gesture recognition achieves 99.67% accuracy at 2-meter distance, while the IndoBERTbased system demonstrates 98.24% accuracy in fashion intent classification. The speech-to-text functionality achieves 82.61% success rate with 24.94% Word Error Rate and 2.36-second processing time. This touch-free interaction creates a hygienic, accessible shopping experience addressing contemporary retail challenges.

title: Code Comprehension for Novice Students: Teaching, Assessment, Tools, and Challenges
authors: Valéria Cavalcanti, Wilkerson L. Andrade
abstract: This Research Full Paper presents a systematic literature review on code compression for novice students. Code comprehension is a fundamental research field in software development, especially in the current context where Large Language Models (LLMs) are transforming programming practices by automatically generating code. This work addresses four central questions: (1) What are the most effective strategies for teaching code comprehension? (2) What methods are used to assess this skill? (3) What tools support this process? (4) What challenges do students face? The methodology integrates an AI-powered tool to analyze more than 18,000 articles, resulting in a selection of 47 relevant studies. The reviewed studies highlight the importance of adopting teaching strategies that help students build solid mental models before they begin writing code. Tools that incorporate such instructional strategies are essential to personalize learning and overcome the challenges faced by novice programmers. Evaluation methods are also evolving, moving beyond traditional assessments to include interactive and formative approaches. This review synthesizes the current state of research and offers recommendations for educators, researchers, and developers of educational tools aimed at fostering code comprehension skills.

title: WIP: Engineering Doctoral Students' Perceptions of Transformative Experiences in Developing Non-Technical Competencies for Faculty Careers
authors: Ibukunoluwa E Salami, Logan A. Perry
abstract: This WIP research paper describes an ongoing qualitative phenomenological study that explores how doctoral education influences the development of non-technical competencies among early-career engineering faculty. Engineering faculty are expected not only to impart technical knowledge but also to mentor students, lead research projects, secure funding, and contribute to academic service and departmental governance all of which demand a diverse set of non-technical skills. While doctoral programs typically emphasize technical training, the development of competencies such as communication, leadership, collaboration, and teamwork is often underprioritized. Yet, these skills are essential for faculty to navigate their multifaceted roles and to foster similar competencies in their students. Prior research underscores the importance of these non-technical skills, but gaps remain in understanding how doctoral education supports their development. This study investigates the lived experiences of early-career engineering faculty to uncover how their graduate education contributed to their personal and professional transformations and shaped their preparedness for academic responsibilities. Preliminary findings offer insights into how graduate programs can more intentionally cultivate the non-technical competencies required for academic success and, ultimately, for advancing engineering education.

title: Chain-of-Thought Prompting for Simulating Scam Interactions with Multi-Role Agents in Digital Literacy Education
authors: Amalia Amalia, Maya Silvi Lydia, Romi Fadillah Rahmat, Mohammad Fadly Syah Putra, Pauzi Ibrahim Nainggolan, Dani Gunawan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electrical, Telecommunication and Computer Engineering (ELTICOM)
abstract: Online scams are increasingly targeting Indonesian users, yet public education on scam detection remains limited in both accessibility and effectiveness. This study presents a multi-role, dialogue-based simulation system designed to enhance digital scam awareness through interactive learning in the Indonesian language (Bahasa Indonesia). Leveraging Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting with Large Language Models (LLMs), the system simulates scam messages, interprets user responses, and provides tailored feedback. The Scammer role, powered by zero-shot CoT, generated contextually realistic messages across four common types of fraud. Human evaluators rated the outputs highly for realism (avg. 4.2/5) and persuasiveness (4.0/5). The Evaluator role achieved an average accuracy of 84.5% in classifying user behavior (vigilant, unsure, deceived), with peak performance in fake prize scenarios (88%). The Educator role delivered rule-based feedback rated 4.5 for clarity, 4.4 for relevance, and 4.6 for educational value. This work demonstrates a scalable, adaptive, and linguistically inclusive approach to digital literacy. By simulating realistic scam interactions and incorporating pedagogical feedback, the system provides an effective anti-scam training tool for low-resource language users, promoting safe and responsible use of LLMs in public education.

title: Enhancing Residential Energy Efficiency through an Integrated Lighting Control System
authors: Vitaliy Bozhovskiy, Ivan Rudavskyi, Halyna Klym
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Intelligent Data Acquisition and Advanced Computing Systems: Technology and Applications (IDAACS)
abstract: This paper presents the development and performance evaluation of an intelligent lighting control system that is based on the Arduino Uno platform. The system automates the process of turning on and off lighting in rooms using motion and light sensors. The aim is to reduce energy costs by minimizing unnecessary lighting when people are not present. Experimental studies have shown that implementing an intelligent lighting control system can significantly reduce energy consumption compared to traditional methods. The analysis of electricity consumption measurements demonstrates potential for savings, especially in commercial and residential buildings where lighting is often left on unnecessarily. This paper emphasizes the importance of intelligent lighting control systems in reducing energy costs and promoting sustainable development.

title: Next-Generation Solar Grid Integration: MMC Topologies Coupled with MPPT Control
authors: Bappaditta Saha Chowdhury, Md Sharif Robbani, Md Jahangir Alam, Md Mobarok Hosen Omi, Tanay Banik, Joy Saha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Green Energy, Computing and Sustainable Technology (GECOST)
abstract: The global shift towards renewable energy sources is imperative to meet increasing energy demands while mitigating environmental impacts. Solar power, as a pivotal renewable resource, requires effective integration techniques to maximize utility and grid compatibility. This study investigates the integration of a 400 kW solar power generation system with the utility grid using a Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) and Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT). Using the Perturb and Observe method, the MPPT effectively harnesses optimal power from photovoltaic (PV) arrays, ensuring efficient energy conversion. The MMC, composed of multiple submodules, generates a multilevel AC output with minimal harmonic distortion, achieving a Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) of less than $5 \%$. The boost converter successfully steps up the PV array voltage to 2000 V, and the output voltage stabilizes within 0.8 seconds. The MMC ensures high-quality power delivery, and the system produces a consistent three-phase output with minimal distortion, improving overall power quality and grid stability. This scalable and reliable approach enhances the performance of solar power systems connected to the grid, maintaining stability even under fluctuating environmental conditions.

title: Revolutionizing the Future of Connectivity: Neutral Host Multi-Operator on Wi-Fi 6 Indoor
authors: Jhon Roy Nasky Simanjuntak, Dadang Gunawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Communication, Networks and Satellite (COMNETSAT)
abstract: The exponential growth of data traffic in indoor environments demands wireless connectivity solutions that are not only high-performing but also efficient in terms of cost and resource utilization. Conventional network models with duplicated infrastructure among telecommunication operators face significant challenges related to scalability, high capital expenditure (CAPEX), and operational expenditure (OPEX). This study proposes a comprehensive framework for implementing a multi-operator Neutral Host (NH) model based on Wi-Fi 6 (IEEE 802.11ax) technology. The framework is designed to provide a multi-dimensional analysis across three key pillars: policy and regulation, technical performance, and economic efficiency. Through a systematic literature review, it has been identified that sharing active and passive infrastructure has the potential to reduce CAPEX by up to 60% and significantly lower OPEX. Wi-Fi 6, with its superior features such as Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA), Target Wake Time (TWT), and Basic Service Set (BSS) Coloring, provides an ideal technical foundation to support multi-tenant environments with guaranteed spectrum efficiency and Quality of Service (QoS). This paper proposes a structured conceptual framework that integrates regulatory, technical, and economic perspectives, serving as a strategic reference for regulators, operators, and property owners in advancing sustainable and future-ready indoor connectivity, with the clear expectation of fostering greater efficiency in both cost structures and resource utilization.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Smart Contracts for Transparency in Insurance Claim Settlements
authors: M. Ganesan Alias Kanagaraj, K. Sathiyamurthi, K.K. Karthick, V. Vimalnath, N. Udaya Prakash, Ramar Veluchamy
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The complexities and inefficiencies that are ever increasing in the payment of insurance claims usually lead to delays, frauds, and disputes, and thus shows the need to allow more transparency and trust to the process. The paper presents a new blockchain-based smart contract platform that automates and simplifies insurance claim settlements through the combination of non-mutable distributed ledger technology and self-executable digital contracts. The presented approach will guarantee transparency since all events associated with claims will be recorded in the blockchain, thereby serving auditable and tamper-proof information which can be accessed by all stakeholders. Smart contracts are coded to ensure that claim conditions are met, triggered automated compensation on meeting policy criteria and the removal of human interaction in the process of decision making, so fraudulent practices and operational expenses are reduced to a minimum. Moreover, this strategy builds customer trust by providing real-time information and decentralized management. The efficiency of the system is measured in terms of transaction speed, cost effectiveness and reduction of fraud and this proves to be much better than the traditional conventional models that are centralized. In this study, the author has identified the revolutionary nature of blockchain to bring change in the insurance industry, a situation where claims can be settled through secure, transparent, and efficient methods.

title: Memory Forensics Using the Volatility Framework: A Structured Approach for Detecting Fileless Malware
authors: Daxa Vekariya, Mukesh Patidar, Manan Amin, Rupesh Shukla, Dhruvi Kikani, Manali Patel, Chandrika Padhiyar
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: The increase in cyberattacks, particularly fileless and memory-resident malware, has highlighted the weaknesses of traditional disk forensics. Since volatile memory (RAM) contains live evidence, such as processes, injected code, registry artifacts, and network connections, memory forensics has become an essential part of modern-day digital forensics. This paper provides a detailed examination of Memory Forensics using the Volatility Framework, an open-source tool and a general-purpose set of tools for RAM analysis on Windows, Linux, and macOS operating systems. Our work is focused on developing a formal approach to the recovery, analysis, and interpretation of memory dumps to detect hidden modules, reveal suspicious network behavior, and determine persistence mechanisms within Windows registry hives. Used tools and technologies Volatility Framework, DumpIt, and WinPMEM for memory analysis and acquisition, and hashing algorithms for evidence integrity. According to the implications, volatility plays a critical role in improving malware detection and incident response by detecting ephemeral artifacts that are impossible to obtain using traditional techniques.

title: Energy-Aware Federated Learning for Traffic Management Tuned by Hybrid Grey Wolf –Firefly Optimizer
authors: Saroja Kumar Rout, V. Muni Sekhar, Kottu Santosh Kumar, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, Samuel-Soma M. Ajibade, Hui Na Chua
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th Conference on Systems, Process &amp; Control (ICSPC)
abstract: Rapid urbanization and the rise of vehicles have caused major problems such as congestion, air pollution, and high energy consumption. In order to build sustainable Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), traffic management has become extremely important. Due to the large amount of data transmitted to central servers, traditional centralized systems suffer from communication delays, data privacy risks, and high energy consumption. In order to address these issues, this paper introduces a framework for Energy-Aware Federated Learning (EAFL). Edge devices work together to train multiple models without sending raw data anywhere. This keeps the data private and keeps the traffic on the network low. EAFL relies on the Hybrid Grey Wolf Optimizer - Firefly Algorithm. The method blends the wide search of the Grey Wolf Optimizer with the fine search of the Firefly Algorithm - the training step becomes faster plus more precise. The algorithm tunes the model parameters - every device spends less time and less power on the task. Simulations show that the HGWO-FA version of EAFL outperforms standard federated learning but also any single alternative approach. It cuts model loss, power draw and delay, which raises prediction accuracy. The framework offers a practical as well as low-impact way to predict and manage traffic in real time inside a smart city.

title: OTA Advertising Strategies Optimization Using Auto-Regressive Model and Decision Trees
authors: Ting Wang, Yanbing Zhao, Wenjia Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (BDAI)
abstract: This paper presents a novel analytical approach for optimizing Online Travel Agency (OTA) advertising strategies by analyzing real-world advertising data on Android channel from Platform T, an OTA platform from China. The study integrates AutoRegressive (AR) modeling and Decision Tree analysis to enhance OTA platforms’ advertising strategy. The AR model identifies the anticipated business peak periods for Android channel, guiding strategic timing for advertising. Meanwhile, Decision Tree model pinpoints key drivers of AD effectiveness. Together, the two methods enable precise resource allocation and timely adjustments, maximizing the overall advertising performance. The empirical implementation of these new strategies over a one-month period demonstrates a significant ROI increase of 5.970% and notable CPA reduction in Android channel when compared to the data from the previous year. This research contributes a data-driven methodology enabling OTAs to enhance advertising efficiency through analytically informed resource allocation and strategic adjustments.

title: Power-over-fiber and distributed acoustic sensing hybridization in single fiber channel
authors: Jing Zhang, Yao Chen, Tianye Huang, Kaifu Chen, Hanlin Guo, Yongkang Huang, Lu Guo, Liangming Xiong, Perry Ping Shum
abstract: The efficient and independent operation of power-over-fiber (PoF) and distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) has been demonstrated using standard single-mode fiber (SSMF). An optical power transmission efficiency (OPTE) of 6.67% and a transmission loss of ~1 dB/km were achieved over an 11.8 km fiber link, supporting both power delivery and distributed optical fiber sensing (DOFS). To minimize cross-talk, the system separates the power and sensing channels by an 88 THz bandwidth. In the experiment, the power and sensing light wavelengths are 1064 nm (continuous) and 1550 nm (pulsed), respectively. As the transmitted optical power increased from 0 W to 2.13 W, the DAS system successfully localized vibration sources with a resolution of 6.29 m and reconstructed phase information, confirming its ability to operate under high optical power. The reported scheme verifies the possibility of constructing the sensing-energy hybrid network based on a conventional optical fiber with the advantages of flexible layout and compatibility.

title: UltraMamba: Mamba-based Multimodal Ultrasound Image Adaptive Fusion for Breast Lesion Segmentation
authors: Jiahui Huang, Jiaxin Huang, Mingdu Zhang, Qiong Wang, Xiao-Qing Pei, Ying Hu, Hao Chen, Yan Pang
abstract: Multimodal ultrasound imaging, combining B-mode ultrasound, shear wave velocity, and shear wave time, is crucial for diagnosing and treating breast lesions, providing insights into lesion characteristics and tissue properties. However, challenges arise from intermodal feature misalignment and attention shifts due to varied capture methods and an overemphasis on vibrant color data. To tackle these issues, we introduce two innovations: a novel segmentation framework and a comprehensive dataset. The UltraMamba framework utilizes bidirectional alignment between modalities and enhances region-specific information to improve breast lesion segmentation accuracy. Key components include the Cross-Modal Knowledge Interaction module for robust information exchange and the Region-Aware Feature Excitation module to focus on relevant features. We also present the BreLS dataset, the first two-dimensional multimodal ultrasound breast lesion dataset, with paired images from 506 cases, serving as a valuable resource for analysis. UltraMamba shows strong performance on the BreLS dataset, achieving a Dice Similarity Coefficient of 72.16% and an HD95 of 42.02 mm, reflecting improvements of 2.59% in DSC and a 6.78 mm reduction in HD95 compared to the second-best framework, MMCA-NET. These results highlight UltraMamba’s potential to enhance segmentation accuracy in clinical settings, facilitating precise treatment planning and, ultimately, leading to improved outcomes. Code: https://github.com/deepang-ai/UltraMamba.

title: Next Gen Text Mining in English Literature: A Machine Learning Approach for Narrative and Stylistic Analysis
authors: Jiby Jose E, Priyanka Biswas
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: This paper presents a research work that is novel in nature, based on a new machine learning framework that focuses on a computational analysis in the field of English literature. This research uniquely aims at focusing on an intersection based on stylistic patterns and narrative structures. The newly proposed model is termed the “Next Gen Text Mining Framework”, which leverages transformer-based models (such as GPT, BERT), along with sentiment trajectory-based modeling, network analysis, and clustering algorithms for extracting stylistic features and latent semantics from the text on a large scale. A meticulously used re-processing type pipelining framework modifies and prepares the data for the model ingestion. The multi-modal approach used in this framework enables the experimental analysis of different models across various diverse corpora in the literature that demonstrate stability, superior accuracy, and robustness when compared to the traditional models, in tasks like the authorship attribution, sentimental trajectory mapping, and the theme-based classification. The proposed framework bridges the gap between distant and close reading practices, enhancing the pedagogically based engagements and translating the computational insights into interpretative forms for research and teaching. This research highlights a scalable and replicable framework model that is a transformative tool when a large-scale inquiry in literature is considered and sets a foundation towards multi-modal, future, cross-lingual, and multidisciplinary-based applications.

title: YOLO-Based Pest Detection in Caisim Mustard Plants with Optuna Hyperparameter Optimization
authors: Arna Fariza, Yuliana Setiowati, Tri Hadiah Muliawati, Setiawardhana, Muhammad Farhan Mustafa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computer Engineering, Network and Intelligent Multimedia (CENIM)
abstract: Early detection of pest infestations plays a critical role in improving crop health management and reducing yield losses, particularly in leafy vegetables such as Caisim mustard greens. This study proposes an automated pest damage detection system leveraging the YOLOv8 object detection model, optimized through the Optuna framework for hyperparameter tuning. A custom dataset comprising 215 annotated images, sourced from field collection and public repositories, was used to train and validate the model. Data preprocessing and augmentation techniques, including image rotation, flipping, noise addition, and color adjustments, were applied to enhance model robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8 achieves high detection accuracy in identifying damage caused by caterpillars and grasshoppers, with strong generalization to unseen samples. To facilitate practical adoption, the optimized model was deployed in a mobile application, providing real-time pest detection and supporting field-based decision-making. This research highlights the potential of integrating deep learning with mobile technology to advance precision agriculture and deliver accessible pest monitoring solutions.

title: On Time Intervals and Assignments in Multi-target Tracking Evaluation
authors: Petr Lukeš, James Wright
publish: 2025 IEEE Sensor Data Fusion: Trends, Solutions, Applications (SDF)
abstract: Track evaluation in sensor data fusion typically relies on assignment-based ground truth association to compute metrics. Although widely adopted, this approach overlooks temporal continuity and can produce misleading performance assessments. This paper highlights the differences and presents a systematic comparison of assignment-based and time-based association in metric computation, with a focus on the target completeness metric, and offers guidance for researchers and practitioners to achieve more reproducible and comparable results. An evaluation is also formed from the perspective of different output frequency of the trackers and its impact on the final metric score. The results show that inconsistencies created using the assignment-based approach can easily reach beyond 20 %. Explanation of when this could happen, how to decide if it happens in a given situation, and the strategy of how to fix this, is provided.

title: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Pneumonia Diagnosis Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Manish Kumar, Manjula Shanbhog, Bosco Paul Alapatt, Kamal Upreti, Ramesh Chandra Poonia
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: Pneumonia is an infection that results in inflammation of the lungs and, if not identified in time, can be life-threatening. The most frequent method of diagnosing pneumonia is chest X-rays; the pictures are scrutinized closely. Pneumonia is still a global health burden. The accurate and timely diagnosis is difficult, especially in low-resource settings. X-rays have served as a primary key for the identification of pneumonia for many years. However, with the recent advancement in artificial intelligence technologies, especially deep learning and machine learning, there's now a potential to automatically detect and classify pneumonia using chest x-ray images. This review examines the research from 2019 to 2024 to understand the current trends and future direction in various deep learning and machine learning models. These encompass the convolutional neural networks, transfer learning methods, combined network designs, explainable AI models, and the use of radiomics with conventional machine learning techniques. However, the three significant challenges remain differences in the data, an imbalance between the classes, and a limited ability to apply these methods in real clinical settings. Based on the review, this paper suggests more future research on machine learning techniques for detecting pneumonia. In this work, a new system is also introduced to improve both case identification and the clinical diagnosis process. The proposed model was evaluated using the Key Parameter Indicator (KPI) as a feature and was compared with an earlier model. Finally, recommendations are provided for future research on trustworthiness, clinical usefulness, and multi-modal AI systems.

title: Blockchain-Driven Supply Chain Automation for Real-Time Traceability
authors: Sanatya Singh, Somnath Banerjee, Mallesh Deshapaga
publish: 2025 IEEE 5th International Conference on ICT in Business Industry &amp; Government (ICTBIG)
abstract: In this paper, a framework of Blockchain-powered Supply Chain Automation is proposed and enacted which would offer real-time traceability, transparency, and security of distributed trade networks. The suggested system implements Hyperledger Fabric with a data acquisition layer of IoT to get valid products information in every node of the transaction. The smart contracting approach can have this framework automate Facebook processes of validation, authorization and data logging without an overall system that will enable the determination of records without tampering. A consensus-based validation protocol contributes to consistency besides minimizing the latency of the transactions. Moreover, anomaly detection by machine learning is added to complete predictive bottlenecks analysis and authorization of fraud. The simulated logistics data performance analysis reveals that it has enhanced the traceability efficiency by 24.6 %, data tampering risks by 31.8 % and verification time by 18.4 % relative to the supply chain systems using the traditional ERP. The findings confirm the appropriateness of the system to enable end-to-end visibility and operational resilience, which makes blockchain technology a game changer to next generation autonomous supply chain ecosystems.

title: Research on line topology model based on graph convolutional neural network
authors: Jiahong Xu, Jiheng Song, Yilun Li, Yi Xin, Zhenxuan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electrical, Control and Artificial Intelligence (ICOECAI)
abstract: With the accelerated advancement of smart grid construction, the power system's requirements for the accuracy and real-time performance of line topology have become increasingly stringent. Traditional topology modeling methods rely on manual rules and static parameters, making it difficult to adapt to the dynamic changes of complex power grids and the efficient processing of massive data. This paper proposes a line topology model based on graph convolutional neural networks, which automatically extracts the spatial features and connection relationships of grid topology through deep learning, and constructs dynamic graph structures by combining node attributes and edge weights. The research focuses on designing multi-layer graph convolution operators to capture local and global topological features, while introducing an attention mechanism to optimize the efficiency of information transfer between nodes. Experiments demonstrate that the model significantly outperforms traditional methods in terms of topology recognition accuracy and anti-interference capability, while also exhibiting excellent generalization and scalability. The research results provide reliable theoretical support for real-time monitoring and fault diagnosis in smart grids, while also opening up new technical pathways for complex network topology modeling.
